Fat White Family sound just like they look—diseased
column3: drug addled
column4: utterly corrupt. The fact that they live above a London pub that stages exhibitions of rectal hand insertions
column5: all while serving Sunday lunch to families
column6: is an almost too-perfect addendum to their bio. Champagne Holocaust is the band’s debut album
column7: a no-budget affair originally released on Bandcamp and now getting a belated North American release after gaining a swell of attention in the UK. The nucleus of the six-piece band is two Northern Irish brothers
column8: Lias and Nathan Saoudi
column9: plus guitarist Saul Adamczewski
column10: formerly of failed indie-punk outfit the Metros. If the album sounds like it cost about 10 of their English pence to record
column11: then it probably did—but that’s all part of Fat White Family’s squalid charm
column12: where rampant idiocy
column13: intelligence
column14: and deranged humor combine.

column1: A cursory look at this band’s early press leaves little doubt that they know how to play the game
column2: with one attention-seeking spectacle after another giving them all the scrutiny they need. Bodily fluids gush forth from the stage when they play
column3: their manager is a tweed-clad fellow named Robert Rubbish
column4: and they even gained note for a mundane stunt to mark the death of Margaret Thatcher. It speaks volumes for how exhausted the corpse of rock & roll is that such antics can still prick the attention
column5: but at least Fat White Family appear to be as genuinely unhealthy and depraved as their records and shows suggest. They’re even topical
column6: with one of their best songs
column7: “Cream of the Young”
column8: taking an unflinching approach to pedophilia
column9: just as their country is sinking in a mire of celebrity related scandal relating to the topic.

column1: It’s unlikely that Champagne Holocaust will be the album Fat White Family is best remembered for—this is the shambolic beginnings of something
column2: full of directions tried and discarded and barely fleshed out. Lias owes a huge debt to Ben Wallers of Country Teasers for both lyrical inspiration and execution
column3: plus a dose of Mark E. Smith and
column4: perhaps more surprisingly
column5: a soupçon of blue-eyed funk and the wistful psychedelic folk of Shimmy Disc outfit Bongwater. It’s distinctly backward-looking in outlook and sound
column6: but that scarcely matters when the force of Lias’ songwriting obliterates the indie template they often take as their starting point. “Who Shot Lee Oswald?” amusingly imagines a series of culprits for the title’s crime
column7: including Andy Warhol and the Velvet Underground
column8: and gloriously devolves into sonic and lyrical chaos that’s just on the right side of stupidity. “Was it a secret government within the American government?” Lias asks at one point.

column1: The place Fat White Family are coming from is just as confusing as the stylistic turns this record takes. They’re part drug addled lunatics hell-bent on blocking out the world
column2: part angry Situationist operatives looking to kick up a shitstorm of trouble as the world disintegrates around them. If contemporaries such as Sleaford Mods also find humor and anger in the wider state of things
column3: Fat White Family are just as likely to turn everything inward and examine their own failings. “If my mind was clean I’d be fine
column4: ” is a key lyric on the raggedy “Borderline”
column5: but instead
column6: we get a distinctly unclean vision of life
column7: with Lias at his best when depicting sordid sexual encounters. Most of those gain a grubby strength from the minutiae he picks up on—the “five sweaty fingers on my dashboard” in his paean to car fellatio
column8: “Is It Raining In Your Mouth?”
column9: being his greatest chant-along moment to date.

column1: In some ways it’s fitting that Champagne Holocaust can’t hold together as a coherent piece
column2: especially when the primary working mode of this band takes disarray as an important requisite to function. The back half is especially weak
column3: leaning into cheery
column4: jangly guitars that don’t have a natural place (“Bomb Disneyland”) and redundant Syd-era Pink Floyd pastiche (“Garden of the Numb”). This version of the record wisely adds one of their strongest moments
column5: “Touch the Leather”
column6: as a final rallying call
column7: with Lias again immersed in a pit of sexual degradation that appears to be the best reflection of his naturally soiled state of being. The video for the song—Lias
column8: missing teeth
column9: his face wrinkled beyond his years
column10: mouthing words in slow motion while his brother moons the camera—illustrates the mix of low-level living and base humor this band has sunk into. It’s not pleasant
column11: maybe not even relatable for many
column12:
but it works simply because it’s so vivid in its depiction of a life permanently on the cusp of falling apart.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20757/homepage_large.74498a4d.jpg|Tashi Dorji|32354.0|Tashi Dorji|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hermit Hut']|2014-08-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:20.834433|"

One fascinating paradox about art is that limits can prove freeing. Narrow your parameters and you might find solutions you wouldn’t have if your choices were infinite. It’s why entire movements have been based on self-imposed restrictions: take the Oulipo group
column2: whose Georges Perec wrote an entire novel without the letter e
column3: or Dogme95
column4: in which directors such as Lars Von Trier and Harmony Korine adhered to rules about hand-held cameras and on-set sound.

column1: It might seem odd to compare those contrivances to the simple act of making solo instrumental guitar music. After all
column2: the form is not exactly unusual
column3: having been around longer than jazz ensembles or rock bands. Still
column4: to play guitar alone is to submit to restrictions—not only in the finite number of sounds you can make
column5: but in what little innovation is still available. So much has been done and so many legends loom large—especially
column6: for anyone picking strings now
column7: the two-headed monster of John Fahey and Derek Bailey—that playing something new seems nearly impossible.

column1: I’m not sure Tashi Dorji has made anything completely new yet
column2: but the range of creative solutions he’s found while trying to avoid the well-worn paths of instrumental guitar music is thrilling. Raised in Bhutan and based in Asheville
column3: N.C. since 2000
column4: Dorji has made a handful of diverse releases in the past decade
column5: mostly on cassette. He and Six Organs of Admittance’s Ben Chasny chose tracks from those (and some unreleased tapes) for his first
column6: self-titled LP. There are only six pieces here
column7: but each feels like its own planet. They occupy the same sonic universe but are different enough to suggest Dorji has traversed light years between each.

column1: Dorji covers a lot of ground inside each piece. Often he’ll counter a dizzying cluster of high-speed plucks with subdued phrases and full stops
column2: in the process echoing blues
column3: classical
column4: new age
column5: and idiom-less free improv. As a result
column6: “Improvisation II” feels like a baroque exercise and a spaced-out head rush
column7: while “Still III” is both meditative and hyperactively impulsive. Dorji seems to cram everything he can think of into closer “Sunder”
column8: whose ringing cycles have a hypnotic persistence
column9: like an image you can’t get out of your head no matter how long you close your eyes.

column1: It might sound like Dorji’s playing is so all over the place that it’s jarring—and it can be—but that’s also what makes it unified
column2: because everything on Tashi Dorji sounds like the tugging and jostling of a single brain. Each piece is a reactive internal monologue wherein previous pushes echo in later pulls. Follow all the darting notes and you can practically see Dorji’s neurons firing at each other
column3: every one a point or counterpoint in an ongoing argument he’s having with himself.

column1: Of course
column2: not everyone likes to watch a fight
column3: and Dorji’s string-wrangling will likely appeal most to those already inclined to wordless note-battles. From a distance
column4: it might even look like his style is not that much of deviation from the patterns honed by the many storied players who preceded him. But sometimes when you zoom in close enough
column5: you can find infinity inside the infinitesimal
column6:
and Dorji has managed to turn what could have merely been small variations into some pretty grand spaces.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20796/homepage_large.05b27725.jpg|Foundations of Burden|30107.0|Pallbearer|['Metal']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2014-08-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:21.646516|"

When underground metal bands appeal to non-metal listeners
column2: it's often because they've found a way to tweak
column3: expand
column4: or do away with genre conventions. Outside of iconic heavy classic rock or shiny mainstream metal
column5: this doesn't mean the music is easier to listen to as a result—there's the collaborative art-drone of Sunn O)))
column6: as unlikely a crossover band as any
column7: and Deafheaven's blend of shoegaze guitar textures and screamo/black metal vocals. It's rare that a contemporary group remains entirely in the metal world and still manages to find an audience outside of it
column8: but the vintage-doom players in Pallbearer have done just that. Their ascension started with their debut
column9: 2012's excellent Sorrow and Extinction
column10: and with the release of their brilliant second album
column11: Foundations of Burden
column12: it's easy to imagine them gaining even more popularity.

column1: When the Arkansas quartet put out Sorrow
column2: they had already built excitement in the metal underground based on a three-song 2010 demo; but for most people
column3: the five-song
column4: 49-minute LP—with its gorgeous guitar tones and sky-soaring vocals—was their first taste of the group. Pallbearer ended Sorrow's thank you list with ""and
column5: of course Black Sabbath
column6: which made perfect sense because they appeal to that diverse cross section of people who also thank Black Sabbath for their own personal reasons.

column1: Two years later
column2: they've returned with a collection that feels even more connected to the pure
column3: unadulterated aspects of doom
column4: and Pallbearer have transcended the need to thank anyone but themselves. The group were given a bigger budget from their label Profound Lore to record Foundations
column5: and they did so with Billy Anderson
column6: who also sat behind the controls for the classic Sleep oeuvre and has recorded seminal works for High on Fire
column7: Melvins
column8: Jawbreaker
column9: and others (including Red House Painters
column10: who's early material had a sense of space that makes sense in this realm).

column1: In an interview I did with Pallbearer co-founder/co-lyricist/bassist Joseph D. Rowland
column2: he said Anderson told them he's never recorded a band that used so many guitar tracks—an element of Pallbearer's sound that explains the massiveness of Foundations
column3: as well as how they saw  Sorrow's successes as an opportunity to deepen and strengthen their craft. This is an ambitious record that doesn't feel at all over-worked or stale
column4: and while Sorrow and Extinction holds up beautifully two years later
column5: Foundations is the stronger collection to the point that Sorrow almost comes across as demos for this new material.

column1: Though Pallbearer arrived fully formed
column2: vocalist/guitarist Brett Campbell's stirring voice was a little pitchy live
column3: suggesting that he was sometimes straining beyond his abilities. When I reviewed Sorrow
column4: I said that ""Campbell has been described as a young Ozzy Osbourne
column5: and that influence is certainly there
column6: but imagine if a young Ozzy had the ability to transform into Geddy Lee."" His singing on Foundations has more ease
column7: soul
column8: and grit
column9: and he sounds steadier
column10: smoother
column11: and more assured. It helps
column12: too
column13: that bassist Rowland and guitarist Devin Holt offer their own vocals on three tracks
column14: adding details
column15: depth
column16: and complexity to the melodies. When they join Campbell
column17: you get the sense of a madrigal
column18: with overlapping harmonies that will give you goosebumps. You get a taste of it right out of the gate on the 10-minute opener
column19: ""Worlds Apart""
column20: a song that features cascading three-part vocals powering upward between layered guitars that crunch at the same time as they soothe. On ""The Ghost I Used to Be""
column21: Rowland's screamed vocals mix with Campbell's more honeyed voice
column22: creating a raw
column23: almost punk dynamic for Pallbearer that didn't exist previously.

column1: There's dense
column2: regal play all over Foundations: guitars collide
column3: a Rhodes adds subtle details in the distance. There are new textures
column4: bigger tempo shifts
column5: and dynamic turns. It's a great headphone record
column6: but you'll want to be listening to these songs in a larger room where you can move around and make contact. Where Sorrow often felt like a great solitary album—especially in its focus on death and mortality—Foundations is clearly built for larger communal spaces
column7: as even the quiet moments are massive. Pallbearer are patient
column8: and the textures they build feel painterly (kudos to Anderson
column9: many times over). There are moments where things drop out
column10: like on ""Watcher in the Dark""
column11: where you get some low-level fuzz accompanied by Mark Lierly's nimble drumming (he's a more agile
column12: technical player than original drummer Chuck Schaaf). When the rest of the instruments return at full volume
column13: it's physically impossible not to want to move. In the same song
column14: there's a limber guitar solo over gentle piano parts; elsewhere
column15: synthesizers hum
column16: bells chime
column17: the band showcases a newfound swagger to go with the psychedelia and '70s prog.

column1: The music's catchy
column2: too
column3: and full of hooks. Pallbearer are proud fans of rock groups like Boston and Rainbow
column4: and these songs
column5: while long
column6: go down easy. As Rowland told me
column7: ""[Our songs] are all almost exactly three times the length of a standard pop song
column8: almost to the second
column9: so I decided that that's our version of writing pop songs."" With the twinkling three-minute ""Ashes""
column10: you actually get to hear them doing doom-as-dusky ambient pop.

column1: Rowland has talked about how Sorrow was focused on a loved one's death
column2: and that the subject matter of Foundations is more varied; even so
column3: these songs deal in ashes
column4: formless voids
column5: feasting on blood
column6: time crushing things
column7: and in general
column8: loss. Still
column9: it's never a bummer. In ""Worlds Apart""
column10: Campbell sings ""Where lays our heart of hearts defined/ My darkness and your light
column11: still yet remain entwined."" This mixture of light and dark seems to be the crux of Pallbearer
column12: a group who make sadness seem uplifting
column13: darkness seem bright
column14: and songs about mortality seem life-giving. The final words of the album are: ""We're always shifting/ And always becoming."" The sentiment comes during the stampeding moments of the heady
column15: muscular ""Vanished""
column16: and that endless becoming is fitting on both an emotional and conceptual level. Foundations finds a band firing on all cylinders
column17: and surpassing what seemed like a watermark for the genre. As obsessed as Pallbearer is with endings
column18:
the music here is timeless.

"|19570.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19570-pallbearer-foundations-of-burden/|8.6|Brandon Stosuy

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20837/homepage_large.ff5f4aa8.jpg|In The Wild|28128.0|FaltyDL|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2014-08-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:22.424839|"

I once played FaltyDL's ""Metacognist"" three times in a row in a Berlin nightclub. Not because people kept shouting for rewinds
column2: but I had the opening slot and wanted to begin my set with the song
column3: which seemed like it would be perfect for creating a sense of atmosphere
column4: given its dusky
column5: slow-burning qualities. I had forgotten
column6: however
column7: that it takes time for the few people who actually arrive by midnight to get through coat check
column8: make their way up the stairs
column9: and so on
column10: so I just kept on playing it until the first clubbers finally walked in the room
column11: feeling satisfied that my careful attention to scene-setting hadn't gone to waste.

column1: I mention this anecdote only because In the Wild
column2: Drew Lustman's fourth LP under the alias
column3: follows a surprisingly similar principle. Breaking all the established rules of album pacing
column4: it moves in fits and starts
column5: a tangled succession of intros
column6: interludes
column7: and outros
column8: with the occasional song thrown into the mix. It's perpetually on the edge of getting started—except when it isn't
column9: and then it's winding down just halfway through. Five of its 17 tracks are less than two minutes long
column10: and even some of its longer cuts feel like extended interludes.

column1: ""Aquí
column2: Port Lligat"" opens the album with 93 seconds of gorgeous
column3: halting ambience that glows like the dawn and rolls like the tide—a fitting tribute to the coastal Catalan village it's named for. ""New Haven"" is immediately off and running
column4: careening along at 150 beats per minute as the detuned notes of a prepared piano scatter like pebbles; in the background
column5: there's a doo-wop group warming up on a treadmill
column6: huffing and out of breath. But the 30 seconds of beatless harmonium wheeze that follows
column7: ""Uptight""
column8: pulls the rug out
column9: and the next track
column10: ""Do Me""
column11: restores the music's pulse without necessarily suggesting much in the way of forward motion. ""Do me
column12: do me
column13: do me
column14: do me
column15: do me
column16: huh
column17: intones a digitally processed voice
column18: incessantly
column19: over chugging breakbeats
column20: glistening keys
column21: and wisps of delay. As many times as I listen to it
column22: I can't quite figure out where it's trying to go or what it's trying to do
column23: although that's hardly a complaint; druggy and fumbling
column24: it offers a more accurate representation of post-club eros than any attempt at overt sexiness.

column1: The rest of the album proceeds in similarly scattered fashion. After ""Greater Antilles Pt. 1""—a minute of shuffling rumble followed by 30 seconds of fading drones—""Nine"" pits pitched-down strings against flickering bells and a woman's voice whispering something like ""Listen""; it comes off like a Oneohtrix Point Never record that's greased up in some kind of unidentifiable gunk
column2: and although it's one of the album's longer songs
column3: it still feels like a sketch. The same could be said of ""In the Shit""
column4: which moves from cosmic arpeggios into 150-BPM breakbeats and weird
column5: dissonant synthesizers that sound lifted from 1960s IRCAM tapes; the beat fades out before the song hits the halfway mark
column6: leaving a long denouement of mirage-like shimmer.

column1: There are few obvious singles
column2: although that's not to say there's not plenty here that adventurous DJs might put to good use. ""Frontin'"" sounds like DJ Rashad recording for Hamburg's Smallville label
column3: drizzling looped vocals (""We on some bullshit"") and pastoral piano over chopped-up congas; it moves like a plastic bag in an updraft. ""Dos Gardenias"" is another house-tempo bump-and-grinder
column4: even if it begins with strummed acoustic guitars that might be outtakes from Swans' The Burning World. And just before the album ends
column5: ""Danger"" plunges into the 2-steppy breakbeats of FaltyDL's early years with great gusto; a club DJ could easily spin it alongside Disclosure (and make Disclosure look meek and wan in comparison).

column1: Some listeners will undoubtedly find In the Wild's diffuse qualities frustrating—particularly after last year's Hardcourage proved Lustman's abilities to target sleek
column2: emotive music directly towards the center of the dance floor. Hardcourage was his most streamlined
column3: professional-sounding work to date
column4: right down to the Ed Macfarlane guest vocal; it brimmed with potential hits. It would be all too easy to imagine him basically remaking that album
column5: but In the Wild isn't trying to be that kind of record
column6: and it benefits from its eccentricities. The sounds themselves—sumptuously tarnished samples and breakbeats worn smooth as river rocks—are their own reward
column7: even when they don't do what you expect them to.

column1: If Lustman were following the smart money
column2: he'd craft an album full of songs that could double as festival-roster calling cards
column3: but instead he's thrown caution to the wind and come up with something much more interesting. Who knows
column4: maybe his next album will be wall-to-wall bangers
column5: and that might even be a welcome thing. But there's a pleasure in the odd
column6: quiet
column7: open spaces that In the Wild suggests
column8: in which pivoting gobos draw lonely beams across open floor
column9: and dry ice wafts uninterrupted by moving bodies. Zones without people
column10: main rooms without dancers—the album feels like an answer to the old adage about a tree falling in a forest unattended
column11: and as such
column12:
In the Wild is brimming with imaginative potential.

"|19611.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19611-falty-dl-in-the-wild/|7.0|Philip Sherburne

Childhood recall approximately two dozen different British bands during their debut LP Lacuna
column2: which is key to their appeal. If you’re an American who consumed rock music via mainstream channels during the 1990s
column3: there were certain UK acts you’d find in the back pages of a mainstream mag’s review section
column4: late at night on MTV
column5: or wedged into alt-rock playlists; they may have been on major labels and were not the least bit compelling or innovative
column6: but they sure seemed foreign and exotic. Such specific revivalism can seem refreshing considering the relative lack of competition in this field
column7: but there’s an unintentional truth in advertising with this London quartet's debut: put together
column8: “Childhood Lacuna” loosely translates to “a nostalgic void.”

column1: Though very much indebted to their national iterations of jangly
column2: light heavyweight indie
column3: Childhood show enough range to make it clear they formed in college during the 2010s. “Blue Velvet” suggests they’ve unconsciously internalized deep cuts from Wavves’ King of the Beach; before the tidal rise of the chorus
column4: its similarity to “Baby Say Goodbye” is so extreme and specific that it almost has to be unintentional. “As I Am” traces the stately guitar infrastructure of Real Estate while adding a bit more curve and verve (as well as Curve and the Verve in their earlier
column5: lighter shoegaze iterations). Throw in a song called “Chiliad”
column6: and they’ve put together one hell of a turn-of-the-decade time capsule.

column1: But given the proper template
column2: Childhood know how to put a song together—most often comprised of a soft-focus verse that sharpens right in time for the chorus
column3: with the notable exception of “Right Beneath Me”
column4: wherein Childhood melt right along with Ben Romans-Hopcraft’s falsetto
column5: instigating a chocolate fountain of viscous sweetness. Such moments are abetted by the production of Dan Carey
column6: known for the sync-friendly sheen he recently gave to Hot Chip
column7: Bat For Lashes and Chairlift. Childhood are stylish
column8: but they’re not fashionistas—this is a cushy and comforting recording
column9: more akin to a worn sweater than a crisp
column10: club-ready button-down. That element has a certain charm
column11: though Childhood could stand for something more form-fitting
column12: as the second half of Lacuna retreats into a mid-fi
column13: reverbed shimmer and fade.

column1: Granted
column2: Childhood are more tuneful than the scores of other bands doing something similar. But their myriad reference points has the effect of making you think about the few bands they don’t emulate—Oasis
column3: Urban Hymns-era Verve
column4: Blur
column5: the Stone Roses
column6: and the bands that appealed to millions due to the belief in their own greatness or songs that truly wanted to be adored. Sure
column7: such goals are anathema for true indie types
column8: and the first line on Lacuna is a sheepish
column9: “We said way too much”
column10: so fittingly
column11: they don't say much else at all for the duration of Lacuna. When the chorus of ""As I Am"" boasts
column12: “So tell me what you wanna do/ And take me as I am
column13: ” Childhood sound defensive rather than bold
column14: as they're too low-key to be issuing ultimatums.

column1: It’s coincidental that the timing of Childhood and Richard Linklater’s Boyhood should overlap somewhat—they both deal with similar themes in their dialogue
column2: including miscommunication between the sexes
column3: the bittersweetness of youth and home
column4: watching television. Likewise
column5: the ambition is in the comprehensiveness
column6: as there isn’t a whole lot of major action while it’s happening. But with Boyhood
column7: you grow invested in the characters as they evolve over 12 years; you can enjoy the flow of Lacuna just as much
column8: but in the 11 songs here
column9:
you just wish there was some character to begin with.

"|19584.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19584-childhood-lacuna/|6.1|Ian Cohen

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20926/homepage_large.4519b1c7.jpg|Imagine Yourself in a Free and Natural World|32430.0|B L A C K I E|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-08-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:23.858454|"

One of last year’s most overlooked albums
column2: Fuck The False
column3: came from Houston’s folk-hero noise rapper (and sometimes-credited predecessor to Death Grips’ style)
column4: B L A C K I E. The self-produced
column5: mostly industrial record not only saw him wailing motivational sermons to himself and listeners
column6: it also highlighted what had been a recurrent source of adulation for Kanye West’s Yeezus—that is
column7: exploratory rap production driven home by an exceptional level of vocal conviction. But while West's experimentation was met with surprise
column8: B L A C K I E has been making such range in soundscapes a calling card for his entire career; his 2012-released standout GEN wielded similar subject matter
column9: but over mostly acoustic production assisted by keys
column10: horns
column11: and guitar riffs.

column1: When I interviewed B L A C K I E last year
column2: he told me that he’d recorded Fuck The False in one take
column3: fueled by Red Bull and whiskey
column4: and that his new project would be mostly jazz-based. The premise was a head-scratcher
column5: but B L A C K I E’s career has consistently rested on the outskirts of rap. On his latest album
column6: <i>Imagine Your Self in a Free and Natural World
column7: he’s barely clinging onto the genre.

column1: With two of the album’s three tracks eclipsing the sixteen-minute mark
column2: B L A C K I E’s penchant for storytelling and intense imagery are at center stage. “Wings Blocking Out the Sun” and “Forest of Ex-Lovers” materialize piece-by-piece with scene-building electric bass riffs that abruptly crash into B L A C K I E’s commanding vocals. The latter begins with eerie screeches
column3: placing him in a state of vulnerability where he faces his fears head-on and talks emptily to shadows. In the former
column4: a vulture rises up and “Turns itself into a fist” in what feels like a post-apocalyptic dystopia.

column1: B L A C K I E’s layering of saxophone over bass in Imagine Your Self in a Free and Natural World adds to the uncanny atmosphere. The album’s instrumentation positions it more as an avant-garde
column2: free-jazz effort in the line of Herbie Hancock and Sun Ra than the punk-rap that's come to be expected of B L A C K I E. Still
column3: reference points be damned
column4: the album doesn’t quite sound like anything else. On “Cry
column5: Pig!”
column6: the climb in B L A C K I E’s emotion conveys an effective message of frustration

column1: On Imagine Your Self in a Free and Natural World

column2: someone else would have. Never mind that

column5: saccharine-sweet new album could be seen as an antidote to the aggressive
column6: toxically masculine culture that’s pervaded mainstream American dance culture over the last few years—a culture whose fuck-it sense of hedonism has recently resulted in fatal consequences
column7: even as its corporate benefactors continue to cynically bleed its participants dry. Much more than a corrective gesture

column9: part twinkling bedroom-beatmaker fare

Like Flying Lotus and his Brainfeeder imprint or Oneohtrix Point Never with Software
column3: Actress' Werkdiscs label owes much of its aesthetic to its owner's permeating influence. Plenty of producers try to imitate the desaturated avant-techno of Hazyville or Splazsh's dadaist dancefloor
column4: but you can hear Actress in Werkdiscs mostly because the essence of Darren Cunningham's sound is pure lightning in a bottle—it's a creative path designed to take you to the places he uncovers. One kindred spirit to land on Werkdiscs is Moiré
column5: an essentially anonymous Londoner.

column1: The actual similarities Moiré shares with Actress are surface level
column2: though. When the producer debuted in early 2013 with his Never Sleep EP
column3: autonomic
column4: skeletal tracks like ""Lose It"" used the same gassy basslines and mindless propulsion of Splazsh's ""Lost""; by the time Moiré's Rolx EP arrived three months later
column5: he'd already began to inch towards a more discernible identity. And those changes—no matter how rudimentary or superficial—have served him well. Because once you strip away his tunes' decaying proto-futurisms
column6: the mechanics underneath reveal a producer working to restore function to Actress' decidedly dysfunctional strain of club music.

column1: Shelter
column2: Moiré's first full-length
column3: arrives 18 months into his career
column4: and it couldn't be more timely. The record's eight productions are lean and effective in ways that most music currently inhabiting this scene can't or won't aspire to. Where Brooklyn's White Material Records pushes dirty hardware house and Jimmy Edgar's Ultramajic label treats Detroit techno like a sex toy
column5: Shelter boils its run-in-the-red low end and hissing hi-hats until you can see yourself in their vacuum-sealed sheen. Chunky tech-house cuts like ""Dali House"" sound cold and antiseptic
column6: but there's a slyly lascivious nature to the way Moiré buffs over his quicksilver synths with a gummy bassline. Bones' vocal turn—a deep
column7: drawling tone not unlike of-the-moment house producer Galcher Lustwerk—only adds to the music's dark sexuality
column8: sounding like unrequited come ons reflected off sheet metal. Shelter's penultimate tune
column9: ""Rings (feat. Charlie Tappin)""
column10: treads similar territory
column11: though its clinical milieu is more content to sit back and entice you with throbbing energy and ghostly wiles.

column1: The remaining instrumental productions go further towards establishing Moiré's own place in the techno landscape. These tracks oscillate between affecting the styles of Ostgut Ton-with-charisma (""Attitude"" and ""No Gravity"") and Omar-S-imitating-M.C. Escher (""Infinity Shadow"" and ""Stars"")
column2: and always with a generously rigid UK ethos. At nearly eight and a half minutes
column3: ""Elite / Hands On"" uses its ample space to blend Shelter's predominate mentalities
column4: collaging workmanlike grooves and heady ornamental indulgence with an impromptu precision. The resulting song isn't the brightest moment of the tracklist
column5: though it manages to show how Moiré can simultaneously and confidently operate on a few different wavelengths.

column1: Dialing down his avant tendencies has given Moiré a fresh perspective and helped tame his music
column2: for better or worse. There are few Hazyville remnants other than slightly askew four-on-the-floors and the odd trampled vocal clip. As such
column3: Shelter suffers at times from a subconscious dedication to balance and restraint—it's ""No Gravity""'s unwieldy sub frequencies and the cacophonous stomp of ""Stars"" that disseminate the producer's personality
column4:
not the rote arpeggiations that color ""Mr. Figure"" with listless monochrome. But these few missteps don't tarnish Shelter's stainless-steel exterior.

Dan Boeckner is over a decade into his career
column2: and he’s spent most of it playing in bands whose appeal was at least partially based on their interpersonal dynamics. He was the lapsed paladin writing woolly Bruce Springsteen homages along mana-crazed warlock Spencer Krug in Wolf Parade
column3: a band whose contributions to the halcyon days of '00s indie rock are now rather underrated; his work in Handsome Furs with ex-wife Alexei Perry hung on the implied sexual tension between his chugging riffs and her icy
column4: frenzied synth lines; and as the co-leader of Divine Fits
column5: he pitted his raw
column6: heart-on-sleeve growl against Britt Daniel’s cooler
column7: detached yelp
column8: and ended up stealing the album’s best moments. Given that rich collaborative history
column9: Boeckner’s first EP with his new band
column10: Operators
column11: makes for a slightly disconcerting listen: for the first time in a long time
column12: he’s alone at the front
column13: a lead voice who’s spent his career defining himself against the voices of others. Based on the short and tidy EP1
column14: Boeckner isn’t going to dramatically change the formula that’s won him fans and critical acclaim now that he’s the only one steering the ship. Its five songs are an extension of the gruff
column15: melody-driven rock he’s been making for a decade
column16: granted an electronic bent and license to hit the dancefloor.

column1: Operators’ sound is clearly derived from a long-running line of smart
column2: populist bands that blurred the boundaries between electronic and rock music: New Order’s mechanical precision and sturdy rhythms
column3: Depeche Mode’s ambitious
column4: dramatic stadium goth
column5: and the ragged
column6: crate-digging electro of the DFA label’s early period. These influences have always been present in Boeckner’s music—Handsome Furs was synth-pop
column7: just set in an alternate timeline where the Soviet Union became the dominant world power
column8: and Wolf Parade deployed vintage synths with wild-eyed glee—but they’ve never been as explicitly rendered as they are on EP1. The EP’s sprawling penultimate track
column9: “Ancient”
column10: is a good example: Boeckner is backed up by synths that misfire and slowly rise before cresting and plummeting—it’s a drop
column11: real and earned—into a filthy
column12: swaggering little groove. It’s a show of good faith on Boeckner’s part: it’s one thing to pay lip service to the idea of bridging contemporary rock and dance music
column13: and quite another to actually get people moving. He seems honestly invested in the concept. There’s a welcome physicality to the music
column14: too
column15: helped along by the reliable contributions of Divine Fits drummer Sam Brown and keyboardist Devojka. These songs gobble up space and hit hard.

column1: The qualities that help EP1 hang alongside Boeckner's other
column2: more prominent work are its unabashed sincerity and total investment in the idea of relevant
column3: visceral rock music. Perhaps the EP's heart-on-sleeve pursuit of greatness isn't a huge surprise
column4: given the band's creative core—we're talking about a guy whose finest moments are ripping
column5: raw songs called ""This Heart's on Fire"" and ""My Love Is Real""—but either way
column6: it's endearing. Rather than feeling born out of boredom or trend chasing
column7: EP1 radiates a reverence for its major influences
column8: and a real excitement in its brightest
column9: loudest moments. When the lurching
column10: buzzing ""Book of Love"" splits open with a minute left and births a gorgeous
column11: spiraling keyboard melody
column12: you can almost see the band grinning and launching into their parts with renewed vigor; the same feeling is generated when lead single ""True"" first falls into its lockstep groove
column13: or when the band kicks out the jams on the aforementioned ""Ancient"". Their joy is infectious
column14: and it helps paper over some of the EP's cheesier moments. The repeated question ""Who put the ancient code in your bones?"" on ""Ancient"" might be the goofiest lyrical query this side of ""Are we human or are we dancer
column15:
but it's easier to forgive when it's delivered with energy and enthusiasm. That's what makes this first effort from Operators a worthwhile exercise: it's a chance to hear a veteran like Boeckner taking mild risks and having fun.

To be a student of pop music history is to grapple with the story of Lou Reed’s 1975 double album Metal Machine Music. No record by a major artist on a major label is so puzzling and so contradictory—it’s simultaneously dismissed out of hand and written off as a joke and cited as both important and hugely influential. Where you fall on that spectrum has a lot to do with how receptive you are to the idea of noise music in general. While there was music before MMM that was just as harsh and intense (parts of John Cage’s “Cartridge Music” come to mind)
column2: Reed’s album was the first to re-imagine noise for the post-acid-rock era.

column1: Pure noise had previously been a classical phenomena
column2: the logical endpoint of the dissonance introduced early in the century by modern composers like Schoenberg and Webern (and in fact Reed had originally hoped MMM would come out on a classical label) combined with the tinkering of musique concrète. In the late 1960s
column3: the idea that extreme distortion
column4: static
column5: and feedback could be a part of popular song changed the way people understood noise
column6: turned it from exclusively the realm of “art music” into something that could be appreciated more viscerally—a pop intensifier.

column1: So the context of Metal Machine Music is what made it so revolutionary (or repulsive): listeners found it in the racks next to the rock’n’roll records
column2: a 2xLP “electronic instrumental composition” by the guy who the year before had charted with a funky number called “Sally Can’t Dance”. The idea that MMM was a joke or a contract-breaker has been convincingly discredited in the last couple of decades; it seems clear that
column3: whatever Reed’s state of mind in the mid–1970s (and there’s a great deal of evidence that heavy drugs were doing strange things to it)
column4: he created the record and put it out there because he thought it sounded neat. “I honestly thought ‘Boy
column5: people who like guitar feedback are gonna go crazy for this.’ Count me among them. If you like loud guitars
column6: here we are
column7: ” he told Pitchfork in an interview in 2007.

column1: I’m not a connoisseur of noise but I’ve heard my share
column2: and Reed’s original Metal Machine Music strikes me as one of the more unique albums the genre has produced. You hear it and know what it is immediately. It’s heavy in the midrange and high frequencies
column3: so it can be overpowering at even modest volume
column4: but there is a tremendous amount of textural detail the more closely you listen. Even though it was apparently created with what seem now to be simple tools (guitars
column5: a few pedals
column6: amps) there always seems to be so much going on
column7: and most of all the whole thing is constantly changing
column8: a vibrating sculpture that looks different every time you see it.

column1: A little over a decade ago
column2: the experimental music ensemble Zeitkratzer began performing a live arrangement of Metal Machine Music. It was the sort of thing that sounded ridiculous: how could you possibly notate this stuff? Composer Ulrich Krieger
column3: working with Zeitkratzer accordion player Luca Venitucci and with Reed’s blessing
column4: found a way. The key to the live MMM project is that the scored version pays particular attention to what’s changing in the music
column5: where our ears initially lock in to what stays the same. Metal Machine Music throbs
column6: with feedback in constant modulation
column7: and that’s part of what makes it sound so alive. Zeitkratzer evoke that quality by having rapidly sawing violins mimmic the squall of the feedback
column8: and with those central oscillations established
column9: the other instruments interject with their drones and squawks and cries and blasts. They performed the composition live with Reed in 2000s
column10: with the orchestrations augmented by his electric guitar
column11: and recordings from those shows were released on CD and DVD in 2007. This new version of the recording is made from more recent Zeitkratzer shows
column12: all acoustic and without Reed
column13: and it’s the first orchestrated version to incorporate the original album’s four 16-minute pieces in full.

column1: The first thing I can say is that Zeitkratzer’s arrangement enriches my appreciation of Metal Machine Music as a whole. The spirit of the music
column2: as well as its general sense of shape structure
column3: is rendered so well it gives you a deeper understanding of what the layers of sound in the original are doing
column4: and how the interplay between the competing bits of noise adds up to something that exceeds the sum of its parts. There’s no question that hearing the music rendered on acoustic instruments (clarinet
column5: trumpet
column6: trombone
column7: piano
column8: bowed guitar
column9: percussion
column10: violin
column11: violincello
column12: doublebass) changes its essential character
column13: and makes it seem more controlled and less dangerous. But the fact that it’s less of a pulse-quickener is offset by the sheer beauty of the sound
column14: and sometimes that sound moves to surprising places. The held trombone drones
column15: for example
column16: lend the music a feeling of symphonic grandeur
column17: and there’s a sense that the piece is in a constant state of collapsing and re-assembling itself.

column1: Metal Machine Music in any form isn’t about dynamic range; the music never really gets noticeably quieter or louder; it changes
column2: yes
column3: but only within strict parameters. As such
column4: it’s not “emotional” music in the way I usually think of the term. There is very little in the way of contrast and
column5: since individual emotions acquire meaning by how they differ from other emotions
column6: it’s never about evoking easily named states as “sad” or “frightened” or “angry.” That’s partly why Metal Machine Music works as a mediation piece
column7: a wavelength of energy that some want to be carried along on and others want to avoid at all costs. Zeitkratzer’s version taps even more deeply into that meditative energy and provides another intriguing chapter in a story that
column8: it’s clear now
column9:
will have no end.

Charlie Ahearn had a dilemma. When the director first started working out the details for his pioneering hip-hop docudrama Wild Style
column2: one of the most crucial pieces needed some negotiation: what to do for the beats. The wide-open frontier of emerging hip-hop style meant trends could grab hold fast and then become outmoded just as quickly; a popular break making the rounds during early shooting—say
column3: Taana Gardner's “Heartbeat”—could be played out from overexposure by the time post-production rolled around. And even turning to the disco
column4: funk
column5: and classic rock staples that still proved deathless through the late 1980s heyday of sampling would've left the production vulnerable to the costs and whims of music licensing and copyright ownership. Ahearn needed a Plan B
column6: and it was this: get together a band and record an entirely new set of instrumentals. Critically
column7: the music would have to be distinctly in keeping with the eclectic source material of early '80s hip-hop breaks without actually falling into soundalike pastiche.

column1: Because music history sneaks up on you sideways
column2: Ahearn's top consultant in soundtrack-related manners was Fab 5 Freddy
column3: who happened to have some left-field collaborators at hand. Before Debbie Harry canonized him by name in “Rapture”
column4: Freddy rubbed elbows with Blondie guitarist Chris Stein as a cameraman and developing
column5: future-VJ on-air personality on Glenn O'Brien's Warhol-sensibility New York cable access show TV Party. Stein's role in the TV Party house band put him in close quarters with drummer Lenny Ferrari
column6: who had to circumvent the TV studio's no-drums policy by banging out beats on an issue of The New Yorker. Throw in a mysterious Brooklyn disco-vet session bassist named David Harpur (or Harper—accounts differ)
column7: and you've got the band that Freddy recruited to lay down the instrumentals for what would become cinema's first hip-hop soundtrack—and
column8: as of 1983
column9: one of the last prominent examples of studio-band hip-hop before 808s and
column10: eventually
column11: samplers took precedence.

column1: There have been countless bootlegs
column2: reconstructions
column3: and facsimiles of the Wild Style instrumentals over the years
column4: but this special collection—remastered and overseen by hip-hop and house DJ/re-edit maestro Kenny “Dope” Gonzalez—is as definitive as it gets
column5: albeit while still being mildly revisionist. For one thing
column6: it's the first collection to re-imagine the original Wild Style breakbeats as song-length instrumentals
column7: something the original 100-pressing DJ-only 12-inches never were. Thanks to Kenny Dope's supervision
column8: cuts that were originally a minute and change are stretched further into the three-minute mark
column9: with intros seamlessly looped and breaks nimbly extended into more substantial stand-alone works. There's another catch: as of this writing
column10: the only pressing of this collection is as a combination art book/7” box set. That's fine for at-home listening and perusing
column11: but Serato jockeys and Technics traditionalists alike are out of luck; the all-45s format ironically makes the prospect of actually cutting and mixing them less a Grandmaster Flash true-school tribute than a kind of outlandish impracticality that DJ Shadow and Cut Chemist turned into unprecedented stuntwork.

column1: If you're tempted to hold off on pulling the whole deal apart
column2: you can flip through some sturdy packaging (a book and a 45 folder all in the same heavy binding)
column3: read some informative liner notes on the whole making-of process
column4: and get a good look at photos of the original master tape case. (Until practicality demanded otherwise
column5: every track was titled “Funky Break #[1 through 13]”.) It's not just pointless collector-dork debris by any stretch—it's easy to leaf through it and get lost in the atmosphere of the time
column6: the same intersection of hip Uptown and hardcore South Bronx dramatized in the film itself
column7: and get a very real sense of how seat-of-the-pants crazy the creation of this music was. It's hard to pick out which revelation gives the music on this collection more weight: the fact that such taut funk was individually recorded one instrument at a time by each musician
column8: none of whom actually played together during the sessions and some of whom recorded in entirely different studios; that Freddy got Grand Wizard Theodore to make Ferrari a tape of popular breakbeats for inspiration
column9: none of which any of the parties can remember in retrospect; or that the entire expenditure was a ridiculously thrifty $1
column10: 000 for three days of work.

column1: The tracks themselves still resonate
column2: of course
column3: so quintessentially tied into the roots of hip-hop that they're literally impossible to deny
column4: at least from a more contemporary perspective. (Not for nothing does a skulking
column5: slowed-down sample of “Subway Beat” take center stage in Illmatic's scene-setting opener “The Genesis”.) Freddy's masterminding of the original project resulted in an unlikely but resonant collection of future classics
column6: laced with his own wigged-out chaos—the overlaid effects-record sirens
column7: machine guns
column8: old-timey radio announcers
column9: and ad-libs are his doing. And Ferrari's unshakably expert drumming and Chris Stein's weirdo-dub Roland guitar synthesizer effects gave centerpieces like the spaced-out “Cuckoo Clocking” and the glowering “Gangbusters” an off-kilter personality that was hard to mistake for anything else.

column1: The catch was that some of these beats were a bit too off-kilter: when the original 100 copies containing the minute-and-change instrumentals were handed out
column2: DJs like Flash
column3: Grandmixer DXT
column4: and Grand Wizard Theodore gravitated towards roughly half of the total tracks on offer
column5: with the relatively straightforward
column6: rubber-bass funk stylings of “Down By Law” proving an almost monopolized consensus choice because it skewed the closest to the traditional breaks they'd already familiarized themselves with. Some cuts
column7: like the serrated
column8: bottom-heavy Warriors funk of “Subway Beat” became acquired-taste staples—“kind of dry
column9: ” in Theodore's words—though the film's success in hip-hop circles sped up other instrumentals' adoption in the crates of the select few DJs who possessed them.

column1: Others were put by the wayside
column2: much to Ahearn's disappointment
column3: ostensibly for being a bit too weird. Some of that disappointment is justified—in the liner notes
column4: Ahearn likens one of the unused instrumentals to Watch the Throne highlight “No Church in the Wild”
column5: and a listen to the simmering John Carpenter-does-Afrobeat “Jungle Beat” bears out that comparison. Wringing a few rare surprises and a few more new interpretations out of an essential classic is worth the boutique treatment
column6: and this box gives yet another level to what was originally perceived as low-budget
column7: Plan B kind of music. Thanks to the liner notes' context
column8: Kenny Dope's immaculate edits
column9: and the way history played out
column10:
the Wild Style instrumentals sure don't sound like a hastily assembled oddball stopgap now.

column3: a persona that has

Lyrically

as some argue) of someone like Ty Dolla $ign with a more benign disposition.

column2: Coliseum still makes a compelling case. Out of print since 2006

It’s likely to go down as the only reissue in history produced by a member of Sebadoh (Jason Loewenstein) and remixed by a member of Toxic Holocaust (Joel Grind)—a fact that’s indicative of Patterson’s wide-ranging sensibility. Not that Coliseum is what you’d call eclectic: Like chunks of charred flesh
column4: “Detached” and “Burn Out Bright” come with a stench of agony and angst that splits the admittedly slim difference between the vintage D.C. hardcore of Swiz and the apocalyptic d-beat of Discharge. But the album isn’t just straight homage to ’80s punk; on “Hostage of Privilege”
column5: the bruised
column6: lunging blues of classic Motörhead is shoehorned in—“Fast” Eddie-esque solo and all—and on “Give Up and Drive
column7: ” there’s a dissonant
column8: Jawbox-like interplay between Patterson and second guitarist Tony Ash. But it all congeals into a howling
column9: harrowing whole.

column1: Patterson’s lyrics dwell on politics and pain
column2: hardcore’s standby settings
column3: so it’s all in the delivery—and his voice is an air-raid siren pitch-shifted down to the frequency of an earthmover. That tone is used for surprisingly fun effect on one of the Coliseum reissue’s bonus tracks
column4: a previously unreleased cover of Ramones’ “Judy Is a Punk”. Instead of singing it straight
column5: Patterson trawls his own intestinal tract in search of the perfect
column6: sustained grunt. It makes for one of the best Ramones covers in ages
column7: although Patterson doesn’t nail the chemistry quite as well on Coliseum’s cover of Fear’s “I Don’t Care About You”
column8: the other cover that appears among the bonus tracks. Originally part of the band’s 2004 split 7” with fellow Louisville band Lords
column9: it’s a rock-solid rendition
column10: but it doesn’t do much besides fulfilling the needs of completism.

column1: The remainder of Coliseum’s half of the split single with Lords is more essential— in particular
column2: the song “No Salvation”. Three years later
column3: Patterson would use that title for Coliseum’s sophomore album; here
column4: it’s the reissue's fiercest track
column5: a harbinger of the needling mixture of anxiety and aggression to come. Demo versions of four Coliseum songs are also included
column6: but they serve to show just how quickly the group came together between 2003 and 2004. There’s a knuckle-gnawing desperation to these tinnier iterations that Patterson only intensified by the time they entered the garage with Loewenstein
column7: itching to lay down a statement.

column1: Multiplatinum punks were all the rage in 2004
column2: but that year also saw milestone releases from a profusion of post-hardcore groups
column3: These Arms Are Snakes
column4: The Blood Brothers
column5: and Breather Resist among them. (In fact
column6: Patterson’s younger brother
column7: Evan Patterson
column8: played in Breather Resist—and now Young Widows
column9: with whom Coliseum issued a split in 2006.) Coliseum represented the extreme wing of that wave of groups; they hardwired brains and intricacy into a thunderous undercarriage of sludge and crust
column10: and in doing so wound up creating a more timeless debut than most of their contemporaries.

column1: Patterson is the only remaining original member of Coliseum
column2: and the band has broadened its horizons even further since 2004; his old Louisville comrade
column3: Will Oldham
column4: even pops up as a guest on their 2010 album House With a Curse. A decade is a long time to be puking blood and pissing battery acid
column5: and Coliseum’s ability to tweak the attack over the years has kept their music vital. But Coliseum’s strength—then and now—lies in its lockjaw tenacity
column6:
its willingness to buck every expectation while boiling hardcore down to the thickness of tar. Not to mention a deep belief in punk’s prerogative to scrap the bullshit and start over.

If the purpose of the ubiquitous instrumental album introduction is to set the mood for the material that follows
column3: then “Intrusion"" is a score of functional genius. But the opening to Nachtmystium's latest record
column4: The World We Left Behind
column5: doesn’t establish a tone that’s particularly infernal
column6: anxious
column7: depraved
column8: or depressive—qualities to be expected from what might be the final record from these black metal modifiers. Instead
column9: the spiraling
column10: simple riff and plodding rhythm section betray a presiding laziness
column11: a lack of effort and imagination that feel altogether alien for the long-intriguing Chicago band. Even when the drums finally shift into a gallop and Nachtmystium trigger a quick
column12: classic thrash finale
column13: the fatigue is palpable
column14: as though the band is staring expectantly at a countdown wall clock
column15: ticking patiently toward the end.

column1: That air of obligation presides during The World We Left Behind
column2: a nine-track slog that follows an intense period of personal and professional turmoil for founder Blake Judd. Nachtmystium has always dealt with one form of ignominy or another
column3: from associations with racist factions of the metal underground to a perpetual motion machine of ever-changing membership. Judd’s consistently used Nachtmystium’s music as an act of bloodletting
column4: then
column5: a chance to let his problems with addiction and despair drip into public awareness.

column1: But since the release of 2012’s Silencing Machine
column2: he’s ripped off fans and distributors for merchandise he never delivered. In October
column3: he was arrested for theft and given a bail of $25
column4: 000. A month later and out of jail
column5: Judd issued a statement to thank fans for their support
column6: to say he was retreating for a bit and to release “Voyager
column7: ” the first cut from a forthcoming Nachtmystium album that “has everything to do with the demons I’ve been battling leading up to this very dark period of my life.” If the circumstances around its release weren’t so dim
column8: the song might have been taken as a joke. Above an undifferentiated mess of cheap riffs and unsophisticated drum rolls
column9: Judd screamed from his diary like a pimply teen: “Striving along
column10: year after year/ This is my calling
column11: I have no fear.” When Century Media announced that the album from which it was taken would be Nachtmystium’s finale
column12: which Judd recently recanted
column13: the decision seemed to make sense. “Voyager” proclaimed that Nachtmystium had little to offer aside from the transmission of Judd’s whimpering ego
column14: anyway. End it already.

column1: During the last half of the last decade
column2: Nachtmystium made music that suggested black metal in America might not always hang out in its dark
column3: cloistered corners or its critically sanctioned circles. From 2006’s Instinct: Decay to the two-album Black Meddle set that followed
column4: Nachtmystium resurfaced popular canvases
column5: like the thrum of New Order or the sprawl of Pink Floyd
column6: with serrated screams and quick-picked guitars. You could almost imagine it on the radio. Silencing Machine
column7: released in 2012
column8: pulled back on the pop drive and the psychedelic breadth
column9: retrenching the aggression of the band’s earlier material while not giving up altogether on the recent exploration
column10: either.

column1: Anything on The World We Left Behind that feels vaguely experimental
column2: however
column3: is almost altogether inchoate. The best moments here are the most focused and formed. The first four minutes of “Into the Endless Abyss” offer some of the most direct and compelling black metal of Judd’s career. A cavalcade of drums powers a magisterial wash of guitars
column4: moving in waves beneath Judd’s end-times desperation. Its power recalls the charge of Instinct: Decay and Silencing Machine
column5: its romance the allure of Addicts: Black Meddle Pt. II. And though the title track lingers too long in both the prelude and the postlude
column6: the middle traces a wonderful arc of momentum
column7: pushing ahead through a succession of increasingly grand moments. The chorus is simple
column8: undistracted and effective
column9: Judd fashioning despair into a hook that catches on the first pass. It’s the epitome of Nachtmystium’s magnetism.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: though
column3: efficiency seems like an anathema for Judd
column4: whose lassitude shows here not only in a dearth of imagination but also through a general lack of editing. Without necessity and with the warning only of a quick guitar-pick slide and a grunt
column5: the great “Into the Endless Abyss” shifts into a truly abysmal second half of four-on-the-floor dance metal. Above laughable video-game synthesizers and a beat that could last for days until someone took notice
column6: Judd yells about descending “into this mortal hell.” You kind of wish he’d stop talking about it and get going already—at least that would have saved him from the song’s second half.

column1: Likewise
column2: “In the Absence of Existence” is a seven-minute
column3: string-padded rock waltz with no more payoff than an attenuated chorus of self-pitying juvenilia. “Hidden away
column4: alone I pray/ For a quick death every day/Never a moment to get away
column5: ” Judd croaks. During some of the song’s instrumental breaks (and there are plenty)
column6: you can hear the utter lack of inspirations and ideas. A sidewinding guitar hangs mostly still
column7: waiting for something else to do. A synthesizer swells
column8: searching for a role bigger than that of ancillary noisemaker. Instead
column9: the song just marches from one final refrain into a distended dénouement
column10: doubling down on the time it’s wasted by repurposing the same filler solo it’s already used. Closer “Epitaph for a Dying Star” delivers Judd’s approximation of vogue shoegaze-and-black-metal chimeras
column11: assisted by a gospel singer’s ululations and padded production. It lasts for nearly eight unchanging minutes that you’ll never get back.

column1: Indeed
column2: all of the problems on The World We Left Behind—the absence of transition and sequence
column3: the lack of focus and coherence
column4: the presence of awful lyrics and middling riffs—all seem to be symptoms of its creator’s vainglory. Judd gives priority to his time and problems even though he has little compelling to say about them and even less to give to the supporters for whom he is “deeply grateful.” Judd has the audacity to overindulge on the unimaginative and peddle its whimpering results as some grand closing statement—at least for a time
column5:
at least until it is convenient to take it all back.

It seems like it's hard to go a day in 2014 without running into a new purveyor of alt-pop and her new hyperkinetic vision of an alternate-universe top 40 chart. For such a crowded and seemingly welcoming genre

column1: Later

King Louie's Tony is a force of nature and one of the strongest projects of his career. This is no small feat in a 13-tape discography stretching back eight years (2007's Boss Shit
column2: recorded when he was just a teenager

column6: then away from

column1: Thematically and conceptually
column2: this isn't new terrain for street rap. What is novel is the sound Louie's cultivated throughout
column3: which is darker
column4: more coherent
column5: more purposeful than before. Tony crackles with an empowering
column6: unpredictable energy
column7: his performance concomitant with the tape's horror film canvas. The beats are gritty and seething

column6: his words batter the listener with percussive start-stop flows that build into repeating patterns (""Talking broke is foreign

column8: tryna shoot a porn""). But nuance and emotion are in his writing
column9: not his delivery. His rap style remains one of detached cool

column1: Tony itself
column2: however

It must have seemed like quite a boon to guitarist Phil Carney when Mark Kozelek
column2: his leader in Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon
column3: started contributing vocals to Carney’s own Desertshore project. From a listener’s perspective
column4: however

column9: his name was on the marquee. Understandably

column6: the no-nonsense rhythm section goading the hoarse screams of Kjellman like a pack of dogs in pursuit. A minute in

column8: the guitars peel away
column9: splitting from the pummel into a race through prismatic twists and turns. It’s a psychedelic smear shot through the base of a 100-second tantrum. But “Martyren” inverts that approach
column10: with twin guitars spiraling over a mid-tempo rhythm section. The bright leads and gleeful solos suggest the inevitable arrival of some vaunted hero. The instrumental indulgence may seem like a preamble
column11: but it lasts for four minutes
column12: longer than most songs in Martyrdöd’s catalogue. Kjellman finally enters as the band picks up and latches down the tempo; he screams a few lines
column13: lets the final word decay in exhaustion
column14: and steps aside for one more resplendent solo. It’s a melodramatic guitar fantasy with a bit of hardcore slipped neatly in toward the end
column15: an exclamation mark that comes before the end of a declarative sentence.

column1: The unfurling triumph of “Martyren” is an exception for Martyrdöd
column2: a group more prone to use crust punk as the core and not the accouterment. Still
column3: it epitomizes the quartet’s quest to do more than turn up the amps
column4: turn on the distortion and bluster through functional forebear mimesis. “Synd” claws through a doom introduction to land squarely in a marching punk marathon
column5: but even at the song’s most ferocious clip
column6: Kjellman and lead guitarist Redig push the limits of what can fit into the space. While one guitar barrels through the riff
column7: the other pirouettes into loops of misdirection; at one point
column8: Kjellman tracks a high-flying solo with his lead
column9: his vocal flexibility showing just how carefully Martyrdöd manages the writing and rendering of these songs.

column1: Even the most straightforward numbers here go at least one step beyond D-beat primacy. “Victoria”
column2: for instance
column3: adds a pop rapport by hanging bright guitars over a belligerent beat
column4: like Torche snapping out of the sludge. And though the drums never pull up during “Varningens klockor
column5: ” the guitars lace around it
column6: softening the blow with a tone so crisp it seems to jangle. Moments of Elddop hint at the Allman Brothers Band
column7: AC/DC
column8: and Nirvana. Martyrdöd
column9: then
column10: have accepted the spirit and sound of their lineage only on the condition that they’re not limited by it.

column1: What’s most remarkable about Elddop isn’t the extent of the ground it covers
column2: or the amount of memorable choruses and riffs it loads into the trek. Instead
column3: these hyperactive songs never feel enervating or overworked. There are enough changes within these 15 tracks to elicit seasickness
column4: from the stop-and-storm hyperactivity of “Mer skada än nytta” to the flips between chest-pounding hardcore and deep-brooding doom during “Tentakler.” In some sense
column5: every Martyrdöd album has felt that way
column6: but this is the first to pull the reins just enough for the material to be more inquisitive and involving than merely jumpy. What’s more
column7: all of that intricacy never stands in the way of Martyrdöd’s sheer enthusiasm
column8: the quality that makes Elddop so very bracing and breathless. These 15 tracks hit hard
column9: early
column10: and often
column11: but Martyrdöd have become experts at finesse
column12:
too. They’re able to buttress the blows with elements that seem unexpected even when they repeat. Call it crust-plus.

Television Man is a tough
column2: grimy album made by three young men who sound like they could use more ""outside time"" in their lives. Its province is the damp basement
column3: the dirty aquarium
column4: dreamy half-places of strange light and no easy egress. No surprise that Naomi Punk are from the Pacific Northwest
column5: a region legendarily devoid of sun but graced with persistent
column6: almost prehistoric lushness—somewhere that feels both forbidding and overgrown at the same time.

column1: This is a band with a narrow idea of what it wants to do and a firm confidence in doing it. Most of Television's songs—and most the songs on 2012's The Feeling
column2: for that matter—are slow and grunge-like
column3: anchored by vaguely radioactive-sounding guitars and vocals mumbled to the point of unintelligibility. They are heavy and romantic but sour end-to-end
column4: the ballads of a teenage swamp thing preening in the dark.

column1: They're also unexpectedly pretty
column2: filled with twists of melody and structure far more sophisticated than they need to be to fly in the realms of punk and underground rock. Even on my fourth and fifth listen
column3: I couldn't see all the way to the end of ""Television Man"" or ""Linoleum Tryst #19""
column4: which have the psychedelic quality of a yawn that peels open to yet some improbably bigger yawn
column5: stretching for a resolution always just out of reach.

column1: In that respect
column2: one obvious touchstone is Nirvana
column3: who among other feats wrote noisy
column4: guitar-based rock songs around chord changes so beautiful and labyrinthine that on first listen they somehow seem wrong. (If you haven't listened to ""Lithium"" in the past year
column5: treat yourself.) At root
column6: this is basic but deceptively simple stuff about the way two chords can sit next to each other like two familiar flavors paired in some revelatory way. The wit is not in the ingredients
column7: per se
column8: but in the contrast between them.

column1: My introduction to Naomi Punk was through Parquet Courts' 2013 mixtape
column2: which has continued to serve as a reliable map of underground bands marrying the simplicity and aggression of punk with the opacity of ""art
column3: by which I generally mean ""things that aren't obvious."" Television isn't an album I listen to all the time—I value a positive outlook on life—but when I do listen to it
column4: I savor it by the minute. Its style is limited
column5: but the band manages to spread out within it
column6: discovering their own idiosyncratic little vocabulary without ever exhausting it. And at bottom
column7: that's what I find so attractive about the album: Despite its dimness and introversion
column8:
it always suggests a horizon.

These days
column2: the Rosebuds sound like a band out of time. They made their debut in 2003
column3: long before their (former) label Merge Records began celebrating anniversaries and even longer before North Carolina was lousy with amazing bands rethinking local and regional musical traditions. During their first decade
column4: they seemed more like one of those boy-girl indie-pop bands
column5: like Mates of State or Georgie James
column6: who were more upbeat than catchy. The Rosebuds were founded on the romantic relationship between Ivan Howard and Kelly Crisp
column7: who formed the group when they started dating
column8: married at the height of their success
column9: and kept it going even when they divorced. 2011’s Loud Planes Fly Low was a breakup album as reassertion of creative partnership
column10: although their official-ish follow-up to that album was a full-length cover of Sade’s Love Deluxe that barely featured Crisp at all.

column1: Since then
column2: Crisp enrolled at Columbia and moved to New York
column3: while Howard stayed in North Carolina and released a solo-ish single featuring the Spacebomb Studio band (better known as Matthew E. White’s collective/back-up orchestra). Recently
column4: the duo reconvened at Justin Vernon’s April Base Studio in Eau Claire
column5: Wisconsin
column6: to record tracks for their sixth (or seventh
column7: depending on how you count) studio album
column8: Sand + Silence. Even if this isn’t their first album together as exes
column9: it still sounds like they’re figuring out what the band is now and how it operates.

column1: And it sounds pretty much like a Howard solo project
column2: with Crisp hanging back. She adds some piano to a few tracks
column3: some backing vocals
column4: and “handclaps”
column5: but the give and take between them
column6: the sense of friction that bolstered Make Out and Birds Make Good Neighbors
column7: is largely absent on Sand + Silence. Howard indulges genre exercises throughout the album
column8: and his mastery of rock history is impressive
column9: at least for a few songs. Openers and album highlights “In My Teeth” and “Sand + Silence” hinge on intricate earworm choruses and some intriguing rhythmic underpinnings
column10: convincingly updating the ‘70s singer-songwriter mood to the 2010s. It’s part Kenny Loggins
column11: part Steely Dan.

column1: If those don’t seem like the usual touchstones
column2: that may be the point. Much like their superfan/benefactor Vernon
column3: whose Bonnie Raitt and Bruce Hornsby big-ups churned up some hubbub a few years ago
column4: the Rosebuds seem intent on mining historical territory that is largely untouched by most of todays’ indie musicians. Perhaps it’s generational—two veterans drawing inspiration from the music of their own youth—but whatever their motivation
column5: it works well enough and points to a new and arguably more ambitious chapter in the Rosebuds’ career.

column1: But Sand + Silence is built on a sandy
column2: not solid foundation. As the album progresses
column3: the Rosebuds try out all sorts of new ideas but lose all sense of momentum and
column4: ironically
column5: adventure. “Mine Mine Mine” sounds like George Harrison by way of the Love Language
column6: with a chorus that grows more grating with each repetition. “Looking For” is sickly-sweet doo-wop that mistakes cutesy for twee
column7: and “Esse Quam Videri” is clumsy prog-based pop that uses the North Carolina state motto as its title (translated from Latin
column8: the phrase means
column9: “To be
column10: rather than to seem (to be)”). It’s not that these experiments don’t quite work or even that they don’t really cohere into much of a statement. The main problem is that the music is so self-conscious
column11: as most of these songs sound like a band still trying to feel its way forward. The quest is noble and even necessary; the results
column12:
much less so.

The Chicago rock band Twin Peaks spend half their time as a chugging power chord factory and half as a winsome power-pop band. Their first album
column2: Sunken
column3: which ran a compact twenty minutes and was as refreshing and ephemeral as a popped Schlitz can
column4: contained hints of both. Their second
column5: Wild Onion
column6: is more than twice the length
column7: in which they seem to be offering two distinct versions of themselves: in one
column8: they're good-times party rockers
column9: and in the other they're heartbroken sweethearts. You could cull down Wild Onion to make one nine-song version of either album
column10: and one would be just okay and one would be really good.

column1: The really good one would be the quieter one
column2: probably: Twin Peaks are better melancholy than they are raucous. The mid-tempo rocker ""Making Breakfast"" has a riff and a wryly rueful air that recalls Tom Petty. ""Mirror of Time"" is a loopy and sweet psychedelic pop song
column3: with a twinkling and watery mix of guitars and a melody like a pinwheel; ""Telephone"" is uptempo but light-footed and soft.

column1: The melodies for their slower and more winsome songs hit harder and soar higher than the power chord explosions
column2: which can feel a little stale
column3: like maybe someone forgot about that Schlitz can. ""Flavor"" sounds suspiciously like Weezer's ""Dope Nose"" by way of ""Rock And Roll All Nite."" Their best songwriting flashes the joyful interplay of the guitars—Twin Peaks are the kind of guitar rock band who write riffs and solos you can hum—so the straight power chord stompers cut off their brio
column4: a little bit.

column1: There is one song they write on each record that feels like a next step: on Sunken
column2: it was the chiming ""Irene""
column3: and here it's the cool breeze of ""Ordinary People""
column4: which channels the Kinks and Os Mutantes. It is a new mode for Twin Peaks; neither heartbroken nor fist-pumping
column5: it's musing
column6: distant
column7: and a little dazed
column8: like a good Clientele song. Also
column9: like a good Clientele song
column10: it makes you think of rain
column11: whether it's mentioned in the lyrics or not. It is a bemused-thirtysomething song
column12: written by some kids who have barely rounded 20
column13:
and it's a fresh testament to their talent.
