0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20782/homepage_large.0ac2cb98.jpg|Gist Is|32361.0|Adult Jazz|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Spare Thought']|2014-08-06 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:38.450154|"

In the early-to-mid 2000s
column2: unconventional
column3: long-form song structures became something of a trend in North American indie rock
column4: which created resonances with the flashy
column5: epic-poetic progressive rock of the 1970s. The music of Leeds-based quartet Adult Jazz recalls this (now somewhat unfashionable) approach; their debut album
column6: Gist Is
column7: is full of formally convoluted songs which seldom run shy of five minutes
column8: and feature plenty of brisk
column9: ponderous guitar figures and difficult-to-parse drumbeats. However
column10: the album’s complexity is the brushwork rather than the subject described; a gentle flow of melismatic
column11: often beautiful melody takes center stage and provides the band's compositions with a necessary unifying element.

column1: It’s often easy to discern Adult Jazz's base of contemporary influences. Opener ""Hum""
column2: with its blue-eyed soul aspirations and vocal processing
column3: recalls Bon Iver's most recent album
column4: while the histrionic vocalizations on more angular and dissonant tracks (""Donne Tongue""
column5: ""Be A Girl"") invites comparisons to like-minded British iconoclasts Wild Beasts. However
column6: the band eventually refract and re-contextualize even their most familiar-sounding gestures
column7: leaving room to showcase plenty of their own signature tics. Lead singer Harry Burgess usually doubles or extends his meandering
column8: plainchant-like vocal melodies on guitar rather than providing them with chordal support (on ""Am Gone
column9: the technique closely resembles the signature scat-alongs of adult-contemporary jazz favorite George Benson). Meanwhile
column10: the sporadic
column11: acerbic percussion remains affectively detached from the slickness of the rest of the ensemble
column12: and compellingly dense.

column1: There are also jarring interjections from sampled
column2: electro-or-acoustic reeds
column3: horns
column4: strings
column5: harp and vocals—their processed quality sometimes evokes the pitch-shifted trumpet work of Eno/David Sylvian collaborator and avant-New Ager Jon Hassell. However
column6: these gestures provide mere coloration; the base arrangement is always skeletal. Frequently
column7: there are passages of just two or three instruments playing at once
column8: and the full force of the entire ensemble is used sparingly. This allows Adult Jazz to maintain powerfully restrained dynamics when desired
column9: as on the muted “Pigeon Skulls
column10: ” which mixes deft
column11: Richard Thompson-esque acoustic guitar picking with disconnected wisps of vocal melody.

column1: For the most part
column2: Adult Jazz avoid the typical gambits of the post-Funeral Indie Rock Song; songs end abruptly
column3: like their allotted time is up
column4: without heavy-handed catharsis or blaring
column5: tacked-on codas. The one exception to this is ten-minute album centerpiece “Spook”
column6: which closes with an extended section attempting unsuccessfully to deliver some tom-heavy
column7: Peter Gabriel-esque gravitas. The song’s three or four movements mix somewhat pat chord structures with nondescript vocal licks
column8: and ultimately the track comes across like a jambalaya of undeveloped sketches—juxtaposed without meaningful connective tissue.

column1: Another element of Gist Is that may be initially difficult to stomach is its lyrics
column2: which read something like a collection of Gertrude Stein poems (“Bold claim to taste a feel in felt/ To ham it up
column3: the heart’s a sore/ For babies sake and nothing more”). Sentences sometimes go unfinished
column4: devolving into nonsense and half-words. However
column5: the gibberish often proves to be just as expressive as the cogent language: colorful
column6: motormouth ululations represent Burgess’ addressee “going on and on” in “Am Gone
column7: ” and the vocal tracks on “Idiot Mantra” are cleverly scrambled
column8: reversed
column9: or crudely cut off mid-phrase to evoke its eponymous sound. One of Burgess’ discernible themes is the fundamental difficulty and ineffectuality of communication (“It’s all in aphorisms/ I was just believing myself slowly/ And the feeling changed”)
column10: so when the band engages in this type of onomatopoeia and word painting
column11: it seems appropriate and makes for some of the album’s most memorable moments.

column1: Ultimately
column2: the primary appeal of Adult Jazz’s music is in its unique and playful syntax
column3: which is neither indulgently collage-like or remotely predictable. Their sound is not revolutionary
column4: but nonetheless wholly distinctive—and nowadays
column5: this seems a hard bargain for any rock band to strike. Gist Is is full of clever turns of musical and lyrical phrase which will dispel possible accusations of self-indulgence and pretension
column6: and somehow
column7: within just a few listens
column8: it becomes easy to enjoy this unusually paced album of so few easy hooks
column9:
and so many seemingly insignificant words.

Extreme metal works well within the EP format. After all
column2: some of the best releases in heavy metal history have barely scraped the half hour mark (lest we forget
column3: Slayer’s immortal Reign in Blood screamed by in a scant 29 minutes) but sometimes a 7” just isn’t enough to satiate a listener’s thirst for the raw stuff. When musicians strive to create the most abrasive
column4: alienating sounds possible
column5: shorter formats just make sense. The ornery subsect of black/death metal can be especially taxing on even the most diehard eardrums
column6: which is why releases that clock in on the shorter side inevitably rise to dominance. It’s one of the oldest tenets in show business: leave ‘em wanting more.

column1: Louisiana newcomers Abysmal Lord definitely follow the “less is more” doctrine
column2: and perhaps surprisingly
column3: their latest release shows that they take a few other cues from Slayer
column4: too. Storms of Unholy Black Mass is a five-song hellride that just exceeds twenty-six minutes in length and takes heavy cues from war metal godfathers Blasphemy and Impurity while channeling the newer
column5: more cerebral school of occult death metal. The former’s sunglasses-at-night aesthetic is in full force
column6: which is just as well; it gets sunny down in New Orleans
column7: and most of the band originally hails from Alabama
column8: having cut their teeth in the similarly chaotic Grave Ritual. The EP marks their debut following a 2013 rehearsal demo; the lion’s share of Storms of Unholy Black Mass is culled from that demo
column9: but while that statement may lead one to expect an uptick in complexity or recording quality from the embryonic versions
column10: rest assured that the earlier versions’ primal abrasiveness has been retained.

column1: Abysmal Lord is not the kind of band that would benefit from a more polished approach. Rather
column2: their confrontational style depends on the muddy
column3: lightless effect created by the a stripped-down production job and untold layers of distortion and reverb to achieve its vision.  “Terrorist Dawn (Introwehrmacht)” starts off so quietly that one’s instinct is to crank the speakers up
column4: but try to resist the temptation: twenty seconds in
column5: the volume leaps up into an absolute roar
column6: establishing a violent precedent for what’s to come. The aptly titled “Gnashing of Teeth” is a savage affair
column7: as vocalist M.C. garrots his vocal chords into deep inhuman growls and douses the whole pulpy mess in Ross Bay reverb while bashing away at his guitar
column8: backed by understated drums and a throbbing bassline that simmers just below the surface.

column1: The riffs often veer towards workmanlike and wouldn’t leave much to write home about if M.C. didn’t spend time coaxing wild
column2: howling leads from his fretboard like a young and hungry Kerry King. The doomy “Angels of Persecution” dials the tempo back and bogs it down in a thick river of sludge
column3: made all the more foul by those deranged vocals and the fluttering background blasts. Its seven-minute stretch offers a welcome respite from the non-stop onslaught the rest of the album launches
column4: and even gets into an unexpected bout of black metal replete with sharp tremolo. “Storms View” is a weaponized
column5: Slayerized
column6: and pressurized black/death burst with a satisfyingly groovy second half
column7: and the fast and thrashy death metal ripper “Revelation” ties it all together with a near-homage to early Morbid Angel
column8: ghouls and all.

column1: The album whips by in a blinding flash
column2: and despite how well that brevity works in its favor
column3: Abysmal Lord could’ve stood to tack on another song or two
column4: especially if it had given them more room to explore those doomier inclinations. Luckily
column5:
there's more than enough time to flip the record over again before their full-length drops.

"|19588.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19588-abysmal-lord-storms-of-unholy-black-mass/|6.0|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20808/homepage_large.2d53d0e6.jpg|Time Is Over One Day Old|5531.0|Bear in Heaven|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2014-08-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:39.789164|"

Bear in Heaven are a difficult band to describe
column2: which actually made them easy to categorize at one point. When Animal Collective was indie rock’s undisputed
column3: reigning MVP in 2009
column4: a record like Beast Rest Forth Mouth could elevate a promising prospect to All-Star status: there was a demand for bands that were percussive and electronic with some basis in rock-band composition
column5: bearing boyish vocals that were still handsome and masculine. The Brooklyn-via-Atlanta trio
column6: like most in their position
column7: got more urbane and technophilic on their follow-up <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16440-bear-in-heaven-i-love-you-its-cool/""><i>I Love You
column8: It’s Cool
column9: a solid record but also a holding pattern that established staying power at the sake of artistic momentum. Animal Collective's 2012 album Centipede Hz clearly signaled the end of an indie rock era
column10: so Bear in Heaven have more incentive and maybe even a necessity to define themselves on their own terms. And in a way
column11: Time Is Over One Day Old does that—if you've kept up with them to this point
column12: you know it’s Bear in Heaven that you're listening to—but while they remain difficult to describe
column13: in this context
column14: it’s for less flattering reasons. In 2014
column15: it's hard to say what makes Bear in Heaven stand out.

column1: As it turns out
column2: that still makes Time Is Over One Day Old easy to categorize—as with Yeasayer and Hooray For Earth’s most recent releases
column3: it’s a notable example of a band ostensibly trying to figure out where they fit in as festival-going indie fans have simultaneously embraced more esoteric material alongside the most overt pop and R&B. So Time Is Over One Day Old comes across as being not quite centrist enough to qualify as pop
column4: but nowhere near experimental enough to appeal to the fringe. In the current state
column5: Bear in Heaven’s left-of-center translates to “middle of the road.”

column1: Of all the things Time Is Over One Day Old strips away from Bear in Heaven
column2: foremost is the upward propulsion. The tone of the band's rhythm section is strapping and muscular
column3: yet most of these songs begin by finding a cruising speed and end with Bear in Heaven having maintained a straight line throughout. Upon arriving at their choruses
column4: “Time Between” and “Memory Heart” are given the chance to take the same thrilling leap as “Lovesick Teenagers” and “Ultimate Satisfaction”
column5: but they politely demur and step back. “If I Were to Lie” and “Demons” bear interesting texture and try to work up same perpetual motion as “The Reflection of You”
column6: but they end up simply running in place.

column1: Even in their earliest days
column2: Bear in Heaven were more economical and precise than their peers
column3: so it’s not surprising that their leanest album yet reveals what often amounts to a prim and trim krautrock band. Jon Philpot’s diction is clean and legible
column4: his melodies are clearly enunciated
column5: and opener “Autumn” sounds like a distant
column6: colorless cousin of Caribou’s The Milk of Human Kindness. When Bear in Heaven steer off-track
column7: the results are intriguing but unrealized: “Time Between” attaches itself to an alt-hip-hop beat distractingly similar to Lenny Kravitz’s “Fly Away”
column8: and halfway through “They Dream”
column9: Bear in Heaven veer off into a beatless coda that stops Time completely. When “Way Off” and “Dissolve the Walls” make similar moves toward the record’s closure
column10: Bear in Heaven sound like they're running on fumes.

column1: Still
column2: Time Is Over One Day Old knows how to fill a room. It’s tasteful
column3: electronic indie as ambient music
column4: and when you lean into it
column5: it rarely pushes back. The evenness of Philpott’s delivery ensures that lines such as “You told me lies and I believed you”
column6: “Suicide or stay alive...you decide to stay alive hopeless as a virgin”
column7: and “Holy cluster fuck
column8: you love a lot” all register at the same level of impact. Meanwhile
column9: the uncanny
column10: luminous production of “The Sun and the Moon and the Stars” puts it at odds with Philpot muttering with stony casualness
column11: “the sun and the moon and the stars are hanging out with me.” On Time Is Over One Day Old
column12:
any emotional extreme or attempted musical shift just ends up sounding like stasis.

"|19582.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19582-bear-in-heaven-time-is-over-one-day-old/|5.9|Ian Cohen

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20859/homepage_large.c266747c.jpg|Frozen Letter|28414.0|Spider Bags|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2014-08-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:40.944449|"

Life is tiring
column2: and Spider Bags have always provided a party for the increasingly fatigued. Frontman Dan McGee’s words have had a whiskey-slouch to them ever since the band's 2007 debut
column3: A Celebration of Hunger. It could spring from his North Carolina clime
column4: but there’s a Southern gothic bent to Spider Bags that separates them from a lot of American garage fare. McGee gives a leery eye to all there is to love; he whips dry vitriol and broken-hearted balladry into roadhouse punk songs that sound like they’re barely hanging together. This is part of the fun of listening to any Spider Bags song
column5: as they cause you to ask to yourself
column6: “Might this whole thing crumble into a pile of dirt and rust?”

column1: Over the years
column2: things congealed more and more
column3: which culminated in their most cohesive work to date
column4: the 2012 album Shake My Head. That album was crammed with life
column5: skipping around from shit-kicker fuzz to psych freak guitar solos while keeping the twangy energy up the whole way through. It follows that Frozen Letter is a bit of a comedown
column6: drunk on its own sound; McGee
column7: aged and with two kids under his roof
column8: sounds utterly windburned by life. It’s their first record for Merge

column1: The band split Frozen Letter into two divergent sections
column2: as the first four tracks kick-up all this dirt only to have it idly settle as the album winds on. It has the shape and feel of a sturdy ‘70s classic rock record

column4: the vocals
column5: and the lyrics are flayed and bony

column7: which works both for and against the band.  Frozen Letter is at its best when McGee plays sweet and direct as on “Back With You Again In The World”

column11: his words tumble out with ease

column1: The record is filled with little moments that pop—the guitars that scream at the end of “We Got Problems” and their cover of Texas rocker/drifter John Wesley Coleman’s “Summer of ’79” are two big highlights—but in between are long

column3: but on Frozen Letter it sometimes sounds like they're surrendering to them instead. The album title itself comes from ""Coffin Car”
column4: where McGee imagines a frozen letter jutting out of the ground
column5: then strolls about for five minutes detailing oblique visions of grey horses
column6: curtained rooms
column7: and shiny smokestacks. This
column8: like much of the record
column9: doesn’t build a song so much as it does a series of Rorschach splotches. Everything finally comes together at the end with a big glam blowout
column10: as McGee screams

column1: As the record closes with the too-fried psych “Eyes Of Death”
column2: it's clear that Frozen Letter exudes ambition without having accomplished much. Spider Bags all but perfected lolling alt-country on Goodbye Cruel World

column5: raw feel doesn’t sync up with its songwriting. There's a limp
column6: mostly-constructed skeleton of a great rock record here

as there's empathy to be found in hearing Spider Bags tirelessly trying to put these songs back together.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20741/homepage_large.37b8d42b.jpg|The Number Ones|32349.0|The #1s|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deranged'

'Static Shock']|2014-08-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:41.570343|"

There’s a pub in Dublin called the Thomas House
column3: west enough of the trendy Temple Bar district to keep away the tourists. It’s a punk pub
column4: and on any given night
column5: you’re as likely to see a wizened Oi! band like Angelic Upstarts as you are to see a gaunt
column6: bald man with an acoustic guitar strumming a harrowing cover of Townes Van Zandt’s “Lungs”. They serve food
column7: as long as you consider a packet of Tayto crisps to be dinner. In the men’s room
column8: the walls are thickly plastered—not with gig flyers or snot
column9: but with a yellowing pantheon of superheroes cut out of old Jack Kirby comics.

column1: It’s the kind of place you could easily imagine The #1s playing in
column2: and sure enough
column3: they sometimes do. The power-pop foursome have been kicking around the Dublin scene for a couple of years now
column4: although members of the band also play in various other groups like Cheap Freaks
column5: the Pacifics
column6: and Cian Nugent & the Cosmos. But The #1s’ self-titled debut album marks the point where this scene may start to get noticed a bit more: it's more ambitious and unabashedly brilliant than four modest walls can contain.

column1: “Heartsmash” is the album’s lead single
column2: and it couldn’t have been better plucked from the pack. A stuttering drum beat similar to the Strokes’ “Hard to Explain” launches it off
column3: but from there the song takes a gleeful belly-flop backward into the classic power-pop era of the late 1970s. The #1s hail from the Republic of Ireland
column4: but they not-so-secretly owe a big debt to Northern Ireland’s bouncy punk scene from 35 years ago—in particular
column5: the groups Rudi
column6: Protex
column7: and naturally the Undertones. Instead of leaning on the default setting of The Undertones’ “Teenage Kicks” phase
column8: though
column9: “Heartsmash” is more in tune with that band's 1980 effort Hypnotised: still bratty
column10: but less frantic
column11: and with a self-awareness that revels in its own lovesick ache. Guitarist Seán Goucher sings in a sugary
column12: swooning yelp
column13: then he screams like his leg got caught in a trap. Tenderness and desperation collide and combine
column14: thrillingly.

column1: The #1s' songs are simple on the surface
column2: but a sophisticated sense of craft lurks beneath the popped pimples and crumpled beer cans. On “Sharon Shouldn’t”—one of four album tracks that appeared in less evolved forms on prior cassette and 7” releases—singer/guitarist Eddie Kenrick takes the lead
column3: his voice more clear and keening than Goucher’s heart-in-throat croon. Melodies drift fluidly through rapid-pulse riffs. Minor chords whizz by
column4: microbursts of melancholy that add dimension but never threaten to drag
column5: and that goes double for “Boy” and its back-to-back sequel
column6: “Girl”. The first is a fizzy
column7: tinny tribute to garage-pop rawness buoyed by Nugent’s bubbly bass runs; the second is a ballad awash in wobbly romanticism and a piercing sense of helpless chivalry.

column1: The dynamic is giddy
column2: and it evokes something even more gut-punching
column3: as this is music for the mood swings that come with the onset of chronic love. The hooks sink deep
column4: and they cling with all their might. It’s a continuum that stretches from Buzzcocks to the Exploding Hearts
column5: on to more recent proponents such as Something Fierce and Gentleman Jesse. The #1s are the greenest of the lot
column6: but they’ve been around the power-pop block long enough to know the best spots to stop in for a good pint and a good cry.

column1: Power-pop comes and goes in a cycle that’s about as long as a doe-eyed freshman’s transformation into an oh-so-weary senior. At heart
column2: though
column3: the genre’s best bands bottle the most ephemeral substance imaginable—youth—and pickle it to perfection. They make lust
column4: discovery
column5: and impulsive desire resonate not just with young people
column6: but with anyone who’s ever considered themselves in any way young. Power-pop quite often seems sickly saccharine; don’t trust it if it doesn’t. But great power-pop is sweet and sour at the same time
column7: an alchemy of new hormones and old souls. The #1s know this in their bones
column8:
and their album is a master class in that eternal truth. It zings and zooms with all the pop-art spunk of a pub wall papered in cut-up comic books: faded and tattered but still fantastically bright.

Indie-pop artist Hideki Kaji has been one of the most consistent forces in Japanese music over the last two decades. The Tokyo singer-songwriter’s latest album
column2: Ice Cream Man
column3: is his 15th original full-length
column4: and it marks no major sonic changes from what preceded it. It’s an up-tempo album taking cues from the Cardigans
column5: Aztec Camera
column6: and countless other European pop acts
column7: filled with lyrical references to the English Premier League and various EU nations. Kaji long ago carved out his ideal sound
column8: and Ice Cream Man serves as more of a good gateway into his body of work more than anything else.

column1: Such a gateway is necessary
column2: though
column3: because Kaji has always been slept on outside of his home country. In the Western world
column4: he’s either best known for the song “Tokyo to London” which found him dueting with Saint Etienne’s Sarah Cracknell—or for becoming a “news of the weird” item in 2009 after being mugged in Sweden while dressed as a pineapple for a video shoot. In Japan
column5: however
column6: he played a large role in the 1990s Shibuya-kei movement
column7: a genre-and-decades-blending scene that saw the likes of Pizzicato Five and Cornelius (who released much of Kaji’s music via his Trattoria imprint) bum-rush domestic charts and build cult followings outside of the scene.

column1: Shibuya-kei is now mostly a memory
column2: Cornelius has recently been soundtracking anime
column3: and Cibo Matto chase nostalgia-fueled attention—yet Kaji persists in keeping the indie-pop-derived sound alive
column4: along with its globe-trotting aesthetic. He’s always been fascinated by Europe and its culture—his nickname is “Mr. Sweden
column5: ” still trumpeted in press materials despite him being beat up there—and some of Ice Cream Man’s most rollicking moments come when he’s indulging in it. “Happy Manchester” shuffles forwards on guitar and piano
column6: giving Kaji plenty of space to sing about the titular city in a surreal way
column7: wherein assorted legends from the Manchester United soccer team roam the streets (“Over there!/ Giggs and Scholes drink ginger ale”). “Brand New Boots and Panties” references Ian Dury in the title
column8: but nabs lines from London club Chelsea’s “Blue Is The Colour” anthem.

column1: Ice Cream Man is at its best when it embraces its role as a summer-focused album
column2: as Kaji delivers skippy indie-pop songs centered on sweet choruses. “Jam & Butter Song” and “Summer Camp” are driving numbers that find Kaji and his backing band play at a fast clip
column3: which allows them to quickly arrive at the easy-breezy hooks. Opener “Tropical Girl” sweetens this formula up by adding horn blurts and bongos
column4: making for the album's most season-appropriate cut; the title track tries out ‘50s-inspired bubblegum pop
column5: and its unflinching commitment to the concept pays off in a silly-yet-memorable way.

column1: Ice Cream Man sputters when Kaji slows down
column2: which he does a bit too often. The skip of “Life Goes On” and “Rainy City” are almost salvaged by trumpet flourishes and jazzy organ
column3: respectively
column4: but they both still come off as sleepy compared to the rest of the album. The meditative acoustic strum of “Pool Side Calling”
column5: especially
column6: is less a breather from the uptempo songs that surround it and more of a total brakes-screeching ballad. Every album Kaji has released in the past decade
column7: though
column8: has possessed these types of moments. The bulk of his post-‘90s output has resembled a more polished version of what he did during the boom days of Shibuya-kei
column9: and Ice Cream Man is
column10: at its best
column11:
another worthy record in his long-running career.

"|19661.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19661-hideki-kaji-ice-cream-man/|6.5|Patrick St. Michel

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20809/homepage_large.ccab3c19.jpg|Claw|32373.0|DAMA/LIBRA|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Northern Spy']|2014-08-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:42.964579|"

DAMA/LIBRA is a new project from Joel RL Phelps—best known as the former singer/guitarist for Silkworm and current leader of the Downer Trio—and G. Stuart Dahlquist of Asva
column2: formerly of Sunn O)))
column3: Goatsnake
column4: and Burning Witch. Fans looking for a Phelps and/or Dahlquist solo project
column5: in which one musician’s artistic vision and strengths are jettisoned to elevate the other’s
column6: will be disappointed. But open-minded fans and patient
column7: uninitiated listeners will be rewarded
column8:
as DAMA/LIBRA is a partnership that’s artfully smudged with the fingerprints of both of its participants.

DAMA/LIBRA’s experimental meditations are heavy
column9: though not in the typical sense. Dahlquist is known mostly for doom metal
column10: and DAMA/LIBRA's sound certainly doesn't traffic in that genre—but connecting the dots between his former bands and DAMA/LIBRA isn’t too much of a stretch. Dahlquist is using different tools here
column11: particularly organ
column12: chimes
column13: bells
column14: and lots of open space; distorted guitar shows up only briefly on “The Chant” and again in a vampy outro for “Only Medicine”. Claw’s low rumbles and drones are doom-y in their own way and best heard loudly. It’s bizarre
column15:
enthralling and unlike anything I’ve heard in a while—like two guys playing a less world-y version of Dead Can Dance in an empty church.

Closing track “Thine” is the piece that first brought Dahlquist and Phelps together; it initially existed as an instrumental collaboration between Asva and French artist Philippe Petit. After hearing the track
column16: Phelps reached out to Dahlquist and asked if he could add some vocals
column17: which he did
column18: dividing the song into three stanzas: “Stolen
column19: sleeping
column20: broken
column21: thine
column22: ” “Stolen
column29: rise.” Dahlquist said the final result of “Thine” nearly brought he and his wife to tears
column30: and the piece's redemptive progression is certainly noticeable. Phelps has often become synonymous with hopeful catharsis
column32: the 2013 release from Joel RL Phelps & the Downer Trio
column33: or on his contributions to Songs: Molina
column34: a benefit compilation “for Jason Molina’s survivors.” His songs are soaked in almost-KOs and their resuscitative aftermaths.

column1: Without Phelps
column2: much of Claw would sound like hymns for the doomed
column3: and that wouldn’t be all bad. Some tracks play to those strengths (“Destroy”
column4: the lyric-less
column5: thunder-clapping “Death Rattle”). But Phelps is taking these hymns for the doomed and turning them into survival canticles for the day after doomsday
column6:
when the dust has settled and you realize that maybe it wasn’t doomsday after all.

It doesn’t take much digging into the personal lives of Phelps and Dahlquist to make some educated guesses about Claw’s inspirations
column7: even though the lyrics are vague enough that they could point to many things. Given Phelps’ openness about his struggles with alcohol addiction
column8: it’s probably not a stretch to apply much of Claw’s hopefulness to his sobriety. Plus
column9: Dahlquist and Phelps have known each other for 25 years
column10: along the way sharing tragedies like the death of Dahlquist’s brother Michael
column11: the Silkworm drummer who was the victim of a woman’s failed vehicular suicide attempt in 2005. Those are some long
column12: deeply intertwined roots
column13:
which undoubtedly helped bridge the distance gap as the two emailed files back and forth between British Columbia and Seattle while putting the record together.

The downside to Phelps’ cathartic tendencies and off-kilter vocal style is that he sometimes misses his mark. In a more traditional rock group like the Downer Trio
column14: the notes he doesn’t quite hit become part of a larger package; with DAMA/LIBRA
column15: the straining and reaching beyond his register work on songs like “Boy
column16: Dock”—the prettiest
column17: most hymn-like on Claw—and “Been to the Water
column18: ” probably the only song you’ll find yourself humming later. But on “Only Medicine” Phelps’ reedy sliding and stretching can be grating
column19: and when he beckons the guitars with a yell of “Welcome to the niiiight
column20: ” it feels like a failed attempt at sounding metal. Still
column21: none of those moments ruin any song entirely
column22:
nor this adventurous record as a whole. A few sour notes is a fair tradeoff for a sound this fresh.

All these soulsuckers
column2: they're among us. They're stealing our privacy
column3: our convictions
column4: the very essence of our being
column5: and leaving behind little more than a ""for sale"" sign and some vague
column6: constant hollowness. In music
column7: a dwindling whirlpool of funds only spurs on these parasites as they scavenge for scraps of humanity wherever ears can hear. Their thirst is real. And artists—those blasphemous and holy conduits for truth
column8: liberty
column9: and whatever else is missing from our lives—can't help but succumb. To last more than 20 years in rock'n'roll without sacrificing a lethal amount of one's soul requires a certain vigilance; to navigate around the pitfalls of both punk and ambition without tripping-up on either can seem just as hard as making a great album. But Spoon
column10: one of the most stand-up bands of their generation
column11: have figured all of this out. On their eighth album
column12: they laugh in the face of leeches
column13: defy gravity
column14: suspend time. ""All they want's my soul
column15: yes
column16: yes
column17: I know!"" hollers Britt Daniel
column18: stretching every crevice of his 43-year-old throat. His message is clear: They can't have it.

column1: Spoon's soul is theirs alone. It's not James Brown's soul
column2: and though Daniel was raised Christian in conservative small-town Texas
column3: it's not God's soul
column4: either. It's not exactly classic rock
column5: not quite post-punk. It's not the soul of indie idealists blindly conflating modesty and virtue. Instead
column6: this band is about capturing the unknown—those ""finer feelings
column7: as Daniel once put it—and simply letting it float. Many of their songs are meticulously crafted
column8: but they also breathe and break with crackling spontaneity. Theirs is an in-between soul happily seeking limbo as its own destination. It's manly in an old-fashioned way
column9: but still scuffed-up and vulnerable. It's allergic to empty sentiment. It's smart but not eggheaded
column10: tough but not dumb. It's Costello
column11: Lennon
column12: Can
column13: and the Cure. It's all-knowing and hopelessly fallible
column14: mysterious with a purpose. It's going to be crushed by life and love
column15: and it's going to endure.

column1: They Want My Soul is the quintet's most booming LP
column2: eons ahead of their Pixies-worshipping beginnings and a far cry from the relatively small-scale charm of their early-2000s touchstones Girls Can Tell and Kill the Moonlight
column3: as well as their self-consciously lo-fi 2010 record
column4: Transference. The album sounds like a proper follow-up to Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga
column5: the clear-eyed 2007 LP where everything clicked into place and a restless band finally hammered themselves into stone. Some of the new record's sonic forthrightness comes courtesy of two indie-hit-making producers new to Spoon's world: über-pro Joe Chiccarelli
column6: who's worked with everyone from Frank Zappa to the Shins to Jazon Mraz over the last 35 years
column7: and psychedelic guru Dave Fridmann
column8: who's helped turn unapologetic weirdos Flaming Lips and MGMT into festival headliners. Spoon
column9: who also co-produced every song on the album
column10: lie somewhere between those two poles—pop and outré—and the triangulations happening throughout They Want My Soul flow out unencumbered. These songs rip and burst and go.

column1: As guitar rock continues its slow and inevitable transition into a bygone art
column2: They Want My Soul pulls at familiar threads
column3: fraying things to make them seem now
column4: if not new. There's an inherent nostalgia in the kind of alchemy Spoon are mixing up here
column5: and the band is wise enough not to shy away from it. But instead of glowing in the light of good times past
column6: They Want My Soul is constantly negotiating with the memories that make up our minds
column7: trying to decide if they're traps or blessings. ""Do You"" plays it both ways
column8: starting off with Daniel wistfully reminiscing about vomiting on a curb—""I was half out of a bag
column9: he grins—before zooming out with a succinct world-weariness that comes from chronicling humanity's small giveaways for more than two decades: ""You tiptoe for ages
column10: but lose yourself/ Flippin' back pages
column11: unbuckling belts."" Daniel has talked about how he was a ""mean and ornery"" teenage outcast
column12: and much of his subsequent years have been spent wearing-down that sharpness with empathy while trying to retain bits of its hard-nosed rigor. On the barrelling ""Rainy Taxi""
column13: he has trouble living in the greys
column14: describing an all-or-nothing romance he can't help but fall for. ""When you stand beside me I feel something stronger than I ever could
column15: he says with hope
column16: before the ultimatum: ""But if you leave you better run away for good."" A happy ending is a boring ending.

column1: And who wants an ending anyway? ""Inside Out"" finds submissive contentment amidst a drift that hints at eternity. ""There's intense gravity in you
column2: Daniel lilts
column3: ""I'm just your satellite."" And then the track willingly enters that ether as koi-pond synths twinkle in the distance
column4: its tranquility tempered by the fact that Spoon have never made a song quite this pretty before. So have Spoon gone soft? Have they been watered-down by commercially-minded collaborators? Have they crushed the DIY dream by leaving indie utopia label Merge? They Want My Soul makes such questions sound about as petty and irrelevant as the thousands of bands that have come and gone (or come
column5: gone
column6:
and reunited) since Daniel and drummer Jim Eno started Spoon in the months just before Kurt Cobain's death. They didn't burn out. They're not fading away.

David Kilgour’s decades-long body of work
column2: both solo and with his vastly influential New Zealand indie-pop band the Clean
column3: has been remarkably consistent and reliable. That’s a horrible thing to say about an artist
column4: even when meant with the best intentions
column5: yet there it is: you can pick up any of Kilgour’s releases over the years and be assured
column6: within a small margin of variance
column7: that the music on said release will be jangly
column8: charming
column9: unassuming hummable
column10: and non-cloyingly cozy. His latest
column11: lovely solo album
column12: End Times Undone
column13: is no different. But in this case—as with all his more recent albums—consistency and reliability do not necessarily mean stagnancy and complacency.

column1: For one thing
column2: End Times Done isn’t all jangle. Bucking the reductive Dunedin Sound stereotype
column3: but not too radically
column4: the album bobs on a sea of distorted swirl and psychedelic drift. “Like Rain” has all the languorous aggression and romanticized gloom of early Jesus and Mary Chain—including a couple licks of vocal melody that seem like nods to “Just Like Honey”—only rendered in a bursts of stained-glass-filtered sunlight. In the most panoramic way possible
column5: “Crow” evokes vintage Neil Young & Crazy Horse
column6: a veritable horse’s skeleton of a song
column7: all sun-bleached bones and sandblasted
column8: single-note leads. That motif of dreamy Americana resurfaces in “Comin’ On”
column9: an exploration of the admittedly narrow overlap between Loaded-era Velvet Underground and R.E.M.’s formative twang.

column1: Kilgour is a cultural institution in his native New Zealand
column2: but his vista has always been much broader. In that sense
column3: he’s a kindred spirit to fellow NZ-born songwriter Dean Wareham—and whether it’s synchronicity or something more premeditated
column4: there’s something Galaxie 500-like to “Dropper”. Kilgour’s keening voice slices through a druggy fog
column5: and his monstrously blown-out guitar solo winds its way through the song like a disembodied earthquake. That dynamic drops with a sharp intake of breath on “I Don’t Want to Live Alone”: “She’s got trees in her head/ Dancing trees in her head”
column6: sings Kilgour over a playfully shambolic keyboard vamp. Limber and loose
column7: it’s the album’s best ventilated moment—and when the song ultimately disintegrates
column8: it’s like a child who finds himself abruptly bored with his toy.

column1: Kilgour’s history as a songwriter is considerable
column2: but he never seems obsessed with it. End Times Undone is a record that
column3: like his best work
column4: exists in the interminable
column5: indefinable now—a rapturous purgatory of memory
column6: images
column7: and slippery wisps of emotion. It’s as anti-ego as music gets
column8: and that’s always been one of the most beautiful things about Kilgour’s songs
column9: a virtue that makes his steady consistency less of a hindrance and more of an aesthetic quirk. His ability to barely change is one of the most intriguing things about him—and that’s never been more evident than in End Times Done’s high point
column10: “Some Things You Don’t Get Back”. Foregoing jangle in favor of slashing strum
column11: the song comes on pensive but never goes over the melancholic cliff. In some ways
column12: it feels like a celebration. Some things you don’t get back because you shouldn’t get them back. That’s a good thing. In much the same way
column13: End Times Undone neither elbows past nor dwells too much on Kilgour’s considerable legacy. It’s a frozen moment in a continuum
column14:
and it shines with suitable magic.

column3: thin-sounding synths over reverberating disco guitars
column4: guiding it all with his breathy
column5: nasal whine. Every dazzling melody is sandwiched together

column12: but Fan Fiction's core conceit lies in asking you whether they're mutually exclusive after all.

column1: O'Connor frequently nods backwards in time
column2: but he's also part of a contemporary moment in Australian music. Fellow Chapter acts like polymath Darren Sylvester and leather-daddies Standish/Carlyon
column3: as well as recent Remote Control signees Client Liaison
column4: are all gauzy embodiments of arch seduction
column5: turbo-capitalist production
column6: and indulgence. In the New Australian New Wave
column7: corporate culture is mined for aesthetic value
column8: yuppies are the new hipsters
column9: and nihilism has been usurped by the possibility offered by wealth.

column1: But O'Connor's power moves are just the shadow cast by his burning submissiveness. It's clear that the relationships he details are built on addiction instead of trust
column2: so Fan Fiction portrays O'Connor as helplessly willing
column3: a wretch begging for punishment if it means at least one night with someone. ""Please"" finds him begging a woman to take the frustration of her failed relationship out on him
column4: while ""Another Time"" is verb-heavy and overwrought
column5: reading like erotic fiction. ""My Greatest Hit"" uses the triple-entendre of junkie dialect
column6: music industry jargon
column7: and PUA grossness to go full-on stalker
column8: while ""Into My Hands"" praises O'Connor's target of obsession as the final miracle. On album closer ""Centre of the Room""
column9: O'Connor swirls sex and death into destiny and gulps it down—a mortal resignation which
column10: given the album's sequencing
column11: seems all too appropriate.

column1: On Fan Fiction
column2: O'Connor is drowning in his nymphomania
column3: and the only time he kicks against the tide and shows a little agency is on ""Giving It Away""
column4: in which he casts off the trappings of a previous relationship. The notion that personal heartbreak is more epic and unknowable than any heartbreak that came before it is a common delusion
column5: but that just reinforces O'Connor's cretinism. The woman in ""Her Name On Every Tongue"" enraptures every boy she meets
column6: hiding anxiety behind charisma; on ""Please""
column7: a female target has been ruined by 12 years of ""the same clumsy fuck.""

column1: O'Connor also describes her having sex with said clumsy fuck as ""playing dead""
column2: which could just as well describe all the characters on Fan Fiction. Although there are hints of personality traits that occasionally shine through
column3: the characters detailed throughout largely seem like they've been robbed of their own lives
column4: prisms through which O'Connor can examine those hidden impulses. And so O'Connor makes himself into the villain
column5: or at least the antagonist
column6: of his own work
column7:
and Fan Fiction never suggests that any of this is admirable or contemptible—it just is.

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magnetic South']|2014-08-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:45.657340|"

Apache Dropout are drenched in retro signifiers. They took their name from a song by 1970s Brit group the Edgar Broughton Band and covered 1910 Fruitgum Company
column3: their album art resembles classic poster styles
column4: and their music bleeds history with its fuzzy garage riffs
column5: cardboard-box beats
column6: crackly movie-dialogue samples
column7: and the Roky Erickson-worthy yelps of rubber-voiced singer Sonny Blood. It’s almost too perfect that the Indiana trio called their last album Bubblegum Graveyard and adorned it with a Tales From the Crypt-style zombie cartoon–their music often sounds like '60s DIY pop rising from its own ashes.

column1: Yet unlike a lot of retro-styled groups
column2: there’s not much nostalgia going in Apache Dropout’s music. Their simple tunes and the earnest way they bash them out suggest they see the past not as an escape
column3: but a source of fuel. They tap into the gut-level immediacy of garage rock in order to make their music sound present. In this way
column4: they share a sensibility with the many retro-tinted groups Ian Svenonius has fronted
column5: but without his sly commentary. Where Make-Up or Chain and the Gang are often winking
column6: Apache Dropout stare straight ahead.

column1: Immediacy is the most distinguishing characteristic of their third album
column2: Heavy Window. Their 2011 self-titled debut was a bit more primitive
column3: and Bubblegum Graveyard perhaps had sharper songs—but Apache Dropout has never sounded as fiery as they do in these 11 tracks spread across a hectic 34 minutes. They open with Blood's trademark screech
column4: and from then on rarely stop to breathe
column5: chugging and churning through every three-chord cycle and one-two stomp like they have a curfew. The speed varies
column6: but the urgency is constant
column7: and the sound is more combustible now too: Blood’s sandpaper guitar and Anu Nath's fur-lined bass rub together like kindling
column8: shooting off sparks at every turn.

column1: That combination lights up so often that it threatens to immolate the album; “Tired Old Story” actually descends into pure fuzz
column2: burying drums and vocals beneath a wall of flame. But Apache Dropout follow that with their snappiest tune
column3: “Crystal Ball”
column4: feeding off of Lord Frye’s two-slap drumming and a flourish of acoustic strums. Finding those kind of momentum shifts inside such a well-defined sound makes Heavy Window more than a one-shot energizer. Garage rock records often lose their juice after repeat plays like
column5: well
column6: overchewed bubblegum. But Apache Dropout know how to find new paths even while sprinting. You won’t hear anything besides garage here
column7: but inside those confines you’ll hear a lot.

column1: Still
column2: nothing Apache Dropout does is likely to convert the garage-averse. But the funny thing is
column3: when Heavy Window’s playing
column4: I’m not thinking this is great garage rock–I’m just thinking it’s great music
column5: and that jibes with Apache Dropout’s smart take on the past. They use it for what they need rather than getting lost in it for its own sake
column6: making music that points to itself more than its influences. Some retro-sounding records are good examples of a time or a sound
column7:
but Heavy Window is a lot more direct than that.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20853/homepage_large.71de283e.jpg|Music From The Mountain Provinces|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2014-08-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:47.330426|"

The backstory to Music from the Mountain Provinces positions it as a set of field recordings
column2: all captured on tape during life-risking ventures into the Philippines during the late 1980s. David Blair Stiffler
column3: a veteran documenter of uncommon sounds for the Folkways label
column4: took a small crew into remote mountain regions of the country on three separate occasions spanning 1986-88
column5: ultimately getting kidnapped at gunpoint and held for 18 days on their final journey. Incredibly
column6: as documented in the liner notes on this release
column7: Stiffler simply carried on recording while in captivity
column8: although many of those works were confiscated by the rebel faction who abducted them. Despite such bravery
column9: these recordings have never surfaced before
column10: with the passing of Folkways head Moses Asch preventing their release at the time
column11: and the reliable Numero Group now picking up the pieces many decades later.

column1: Like the best recordings of their type
column2: Stiffler’s work here gives a strong sense of place. The natural world around the musicians is as important an ingredient as the instruments and vocals of the musicians he encountered. His use of space is important
column3: too. On one track
column4: simply titled “Man Whistling”
column5: the recording takes in every breath of its player
column6: making it feel like you're about three feet away while it was being played. Elsewhere
column7: acres of room expand outward—on “Lullaby” the instrumentation is so distant it sounds like it’s a different song
column8: being played somewhere else
column9: in another time entirely. Sometimes chatter drifts in and out of the mix
column10: or leaves crunch underfoot. It’s an interesting juxtaposition to the playing
column11: which is often taut and disciplined. The ensemble of gong players that opens up the album makes it arresting right from the beginning
column12: with tension and pace gathering quickly then loosening at the close.

column1: While working through Mountain Provinces it helps to have Stiffler’s liner notes to hand
column2: to provide a sense of journey as he ghosts through various regions on his journey. He points out the political turmoil in the Philippines in 1986
column3: discusses how these cultures struggled to maintain their identity at the time
column4: and sets the scene by describing it as a mix of “spectacular landscapes and a cultural heritage of blood feuds and head hunting.” There are distinct phases to the record
column5: with the July 1988 trip
column6: for example
column7: focussing on throat singers and other vocalists in a region around where Apocalypse Now was filmed. It’s appropriate they landed in a location once deemed filmic
column8: as the problems around Mountain Provinces give it the air of something like Werner Herzog’s Fitzcarraldo
column9: which focuses on the struggle to pull a huge ship over a Peruvian mountain. Stiffler’s battle was more internalized but no less difficult
column10: as he exited the region with recordings lost
column11: his life just about intact
column12: and with no end product to show until now.

column1: Moods shift dramatically across the pieces Stiffler and his team managed to capture
column2: from the light and airy trio of “Bamboo Zither” songs to the positively doomy “Group Singing with Gongs”. On the latter there’s an air of creeping tension
column3: a feeling perhaps easy to ascribe from an outsider's perspective when bearing in mind the political strife in the region at the time
column4: but certainly hard not to notice as a cacophony of discordant gongs builds over its ragged course. Most striking is one of the few recordings to remain from Stiffler’s bout of captivity
column5: which features a woman singing a lullaby to her baby. There’s tenderness and fear in her voice
column6: especially when it descends into bouts of un-language
column7: where the woman simply hums the melody of the song and her inflections beautifully rise and fall.

column1: Although Stiffler’s liner notes to this compilation are reasonably comprehensive
column2: still some holes remain in the stories surrounding these songs. Mostly
column3: we don’t get to find out how long they have been around
column4: or how off-the-cuff the performances are. Some are undoubtedly songs passed down through generations
column5: but whether they pick up different shades and colors as the times change remains a mystery. One such track
column6: named “Rice Winnowing Song”
column7: bears a dream-like quality
column8: rendered by the layering of the women’s voices throughout. On “Rice Winnowing Song” it’s easy to drift off and forget the world
column9: just as it’s easy to imagine the world impinging rather more heavily on material that becomes torn around the edges. The broad range of feelings captured is what gives Music from the Mountain Provinces its strength—this is a vivid snapshot of a particular place and time
column10:
with all its divergent moods bursting into life again after being lost for so long.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20925/homepage_large.a939d035.jpg|Romantic Times|32304.0|Lewis|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-08-01 00:00:00|1985|2016-06-11 16:34:47.892242|"

It sounds too good to be true. Just two months after Light in the Attic released L’Amour
column2: the amazing lost debut by an artist known as Lewis
column3: vinyl hunter-gatherers in Canada found what appeared to be an even more lost second album. A story that once seemed so abruptly truncated now appears to have at least one more chapter. Lewis—or Randall A. Wulff
column4: or whatever his name actually was—simply disappeared after recording L’Amour in Los Angeles
column5: presumably driving his pearly white Mercedes convertible off into the sunset. But now we know that he kept making music and recorded at least one more album
column6: this one called Romantic Times.

column1: When online forums began bustling with rumors of the discovery (in a collector’s vast archive of forgotten LPs) and when a sealed copy showed up on eBay (ultimately going for upwards of $1
column3: it looked like Romantic Times might even be a hoax—some internet troll playing gotcha with vinyl fetishists. Not that it would be especially hard to parody the recent obsession with Lewis. On the surface the story seems to reinforce every negative stereotype of rock nerds: that they (let’s drop the pretense and just say “we”) are obsessives with little access to direct sunlight
column4: who appreciate music more for its obscurity than for any integral quality it might possess. Such accusations might stick if L’Amour weren’t so good
column5: so fascinating
column6: so damned compelling on every level. It’s a puzzle to be solved
column7: a story with no final chapter. Even more intriguing than Lewis’ identity and his fate
column8: however
column9: is the music itself. If he projected early 1980s alpha-male swagger—the perfect hair
column10: the deep cleft chin
column11: the bedroom eyes
column12: the ostentatious ride—why did he create music that was so aggressively introverted
column13: so hushed and precarious?

column2: however
column3: it’s not difficult to imagine L’Amour finding a mainstream audience
column4: although it may be somewhat fanciful. Now that Romantic Times is getting an official release (pre-orders for the August CD release and November vinyl release include an immediate download) and we’re finally hearing this 30-year-old album
column5: here's the questions that come to mind: What if Lewis did find an audience in his time? What if
column6: instead of fading even deeper into obscurity
column7: he had somehow built up some kind of following? What if he was able to record a follow-up with a bigger budget
column8: some grasp of what distinguishes him as an artist
column9: and even a hazy idea that there were expectations he needed to live up to?

column1: That’s a lot of hypotheticals
column2: but the answer may
column3: in fact
column4: be Romantic Times. It’s certainly more self-conscious than Lewis’ debut
column5: not to mention more assertive. It’s loopier
column6: kitschier
column7: and certainly less personal
column8: although it might be more fun. First of all
column9: there’s that voice
column10: which graduates from the seductive mumble of L’Amour to a more enunciated moan. On “Bringing You a Rose” it’s more sexual than sensual
column11: as though he’s turned the studio into a boudoir. Elsewhere
column12: you can actually understand the words he’s singing
column13: which certainly dispels much of the intrigue that clung to his debut. His transformation into a ghostly crooner pushes his songwriting to the forefront and proves a clever
column14: albeit single-minded
column15: lyricist. Opening with a shameless moan
column16: “Don’t Stop It Now” sounds initially like he’s repeating a few short lines into a long song
column17: but with each repetition he alters the refrain slightly—not just the words but which syllables he accentuates
column18: which ones he draws out languidly.

column1: And then there’s the music. Synths and guitar still provide the foundations for these songs
column2: but Lewis has accessorized. Just a few measures into opener “We Danced All Night”
column3: a saxophone wanders onto the stage
column4: played by who the hell even knows. The instrument will show up a few more times on Romantic Times
column5: less musical texture than a luxury item. And Lewis seems to have bought a drum machine of some sort
column6: which pulses gently throughout these songs. “Be in Love with Me” sounds like Giorgio Moroder if Giorgio Moroder only used factory presets. The music on L’Amour was so delicate that any hint of percussion might have fatally weighed it down
column7: but the beats here are so peculiarly buoyant that they actually hold these songs aloft. “It’s a New Day” and “Where Did My Love Go Away” sound about as weightless as a bubble bath.

column1: If Romantic Times is less special for sounding familiar
column2: that may have more to do with listeners in the 2010s than with Lewis in the 1980s. There’s no way we could ever hear this album with fresh ears
column3: away from the mysteries surrounding its creator. Nevertheless
column4: there is still so much to enjoy here
column5: so many unexpected musical flourishes and lush textures
column6: so many elegant melodies and odd arrangements. From its amazing album cover to the single-mindedness of its subject matter
column7: there is something incredibly endearing about the sheer ridiculousness of Romantic Times and its innate understanding of music as a luxury item
column8:
as prized as a white Mercedes or a private jet.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20863/homepage_large.9119b276.jpg|Rückverzauberung 9 / Musik Für Kulturinstitutionen|5821.0|Wolfgang Voigt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profan']|2014-08-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:48.494701|"

Wolfgang Voigt is far from a household name
column2: but he nonetheless proved one of the most influential artists of the last decade. The Cologne producer and Kompakt co-founder has put out a mountain of material under a variety of aliases over the last 20-plus years
column3: but it’s his work as Gas at the turn of the century that’s proved most lasting in a way that transcends techno nerdery. Inspired by Voigt’s experiences taking acid in Köln’s Königsforst forest when he was younger
column4: his four albums as Gas—most notably
column5: the 2000 masterstroke Pop—are pinnacles of ambient music
column6: applying a 4/4 sensibility to dense
column7: pretty thickets of drone. The project was direct inspiration for Axel Willner’s classic 2007 debut as the Field
column8: From Here We Go Sublime
column9: a titanic crossover record for techno that
column10: in turn
column11: lent inspiration to scores of bedroom producers to this very day. (Even Voigt himself has indirectly addressed this legacy
column12: briefly resurrecting the dormant Gas project last year to remix the title track to Willner’s latest album as the Field
column13: Cupid’s Head.)

column1: Gas is an incomplete representation of Voigt's work
column2: and that goes for anything else from his catalog
column3: too. His sonic shifts from one release to the next that have proven as quixotic as they have pleasurably surprising. The last five years
column4: especially
column5: have been creatively fertile for Voigt
column6: and a small sampling of his catalog from that time period suggests an artist that
column7: even as he grows older
column8: remains restless: last year
column9: he resurrected his Mike Ink alias to put out three engaging 12” of 303-abusing techno
column10: while 2010’s Freiland Klaviermusik was almost infuriatingly unique
column11: an anti-musical combination of piano loops and dry synthesized bass that ultimately grated on the ears. Last year’s Zukunft Ohne Menschen was a sometimes-beautiful collection of arpeggiated tonal work; earlier this year
column12: he released a pair of singles dubbed Polkatrax
column13: which—you guessed it—took polka’s flatulent accordion sound and twisted it to fit a traditional techno structure.

column1: Despite the lamb-and-tuna fish-like combination of that description
column2: the Polkatrax singles were among of the more listenable and straightforward of Voigt’s recent releases
column3: which highlights why
column4: despite his difficult reputation
column5: Voigt’s latest work is always worth seeking out. You never know what you’re going to get from him next
column6: . Rückverzauberung 9/Musik Für Kulturinstutionen continues the trend. The five-part suite was crafted for an exhibition in Berlin’s Haus Der Kulturen (featured
column7: luminously and beautifully
column8: on this release’s cover art) called Doofe Musik
column9: Lieder zum Träumen
column10: Betäuben Und Vergessen
column11: which translates to “dumb music
column12: songs for dreaming
column13: numbing and forgetting”. So without hearing a note of this work
column14: there’s an academic
column15: distanced element to this release that might scare away casual passersby. But Rückverzauberung 9 tuns out to be his strongest release of this decade thus far.

column1: ”Rückverzauberung” roughly translates to English as “reverse enchantment
column2: ” and Voigt has used the word over the last few years to tag a series of releases that fit the bill. In terms of Voigt’s 2010s catalog
column3: Rückverzauberung 9 bears strongest resemblance to 2011’s Rückverzauberung 4
column4: a release that alternated between harmonious noise and discordant
column5: colliding soundscapes that sounded like a few disparate instruments playing simultaneously and out of melodic step with one another. That certainly sounds complicated
column6: and makes Rückverzauberung 9’s comparative appeal easy to understand: its composition is almost brutally simplistic
column7: with slow loops of brass and accordion that double over themselves
column8: become untangled
column9: and messily rejoin over 52 contemplative
column10: blissful minutes. The textured
column11: nearly studious approach to repetition is unmistakably Voigt; even in a genre where it's considered a kind of monastic virtue
column12: few artists have done as much with the concept as he has
column13: and this is the latest example of his finding quiet nirvana in the realm of the infinite.

column1: The temptation to compare Rückverzauberung 9 to Voigt’s work as Gas is understandable; this is
column2: after all
column3: the closest he’s come to replicating his work in the field of ambient techno in quite some time. There’s no pounding 4/4 beat lying underneath these tracks
column4: but the way the brass loops hypnotically undulate as the music plays does provide a specific pulse. As the proclamatory fanfare of Rückverzauberung 9’s opening minutes turns slightly menacing
column5: hitting an exquisite stretch of gloom near its midsection
column6: I’m reminded of Voigt’s work with Jörg Burger as Burger/Ink on the pair’s classic full-length from 1998
column7: the deep techno opus Las Vegas—specifically
column8: the dark magic of “Flesh & Bleed”—not so much in terms of genre constraints as in its ability to conjure a downcast mood that
column9: even as it sounds forbidding
column10: invites you to get lost in its elliptical glory.

column1: As Rückverzauberung 9 crests
column2: falls
column3: and crests again before embracing a slow fade in its closing moments
column4: Voigt’s golden-sounding fog most smacks of a release that isn’t his own—specifically
column5: Icelandic composer Jóhann Jóhannsson’s 2004 composition Virðulegu forsetar
column6: which similarly stretched a single cluster of brass-based melody over the course of an hour
column7: to dazzlingly hypnotic effect. Virðulegu forsetar’s 2003 live premiere was in a large cathedral in Reykjavik
column8: accompanied by under-inflated helium balloons that slowly fell into the crowd over the course of the performance’s runtime
column9: and while taking in the gorgeous sighs of Rückverzauberung 9
column10:
it’s hard not to close one’s eyes and imagine something similarly serene.

Dikembe Mutombo was the most intimidating shot-blocker of his time
column2: and yet
column3: his signature response to being challenged in the paint was a ridiculous
column4: WWE heel-style finger-wag: the perfect encapsulation of his ability to simultaneously convey comedy and gravity. The former is likely what inspired a Florida punk band of wisecracking NBA fans to use him as a namesake—the incomprehensible voice
column5: ""Dikembe Mutombo's 4 1/2 Weeks to Save the World""

column7: and of course
column8: the “who wants to sex Dikembe?” urban legend. But there’s also Dikembe Mutombo
column9: Georgetown grad
column10: builder of hospitals
column11: Congolese humanitarian
column12: head of the Dikembe Mutombo Foundation. This is the direction in which Mediumship takes Dikembe. A year removed from an EP that used the 1994 Bulls roster for a bunch of weed jokes (Chicago Bowls)
column13: Dikembe is in a position to be taken seriously and is making much more serious music.

column1: Just about every one of Dikembe’s peers has experienced the same trajectory—as with You Blew It!
column2: Modern Baseball
column3: Into It. Over It.
column4: Dads
column5: the Hotelier
column6: and countless others

column8: they’ve taken their exposure as a challenge and inspiration and have gotten better in the process
column9: clarifying their vision and growing more ambitious; they want to sound professional. However
column10: the difference here is that Dikembe is just about the only one who hasn’t gone in a more accessible direction—Mediumship is actually the most risky of the new breed because it could possibly alienate old fans for reasons that go beyond punk ethics.

column1: On Mediumship
column2: Dikembe are unquestionably committed
column3: but less enthusiastic. Spiky energy and jangled nerves have been swapped for slow-burn guitar patterns played clean
column4: yet the minor keys and ringing overtones ensure that whatever linked Dikembe to the “twinkle daddy” prank genre has been clouded by overcast
column5: turbid atmosphere. Often anchored by portentous drums and downcast lyrics
column6: just about everything here would be the slowest
column7: sparest song on Broad Shoulders.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Dikembe honor their roots by avoiding the most played-out signifiers of “serious” indie rock discovery. There’s no Smiths
column3: no Joy Division
column4: no Slint
column5: but there is a hell of a lot of an increasingly prominent influence in “thinking man’s punk”—post-Deja Entendu Brand New
column6: particularly the quiet things that no one ever gives that band enough credit for. Steven Gray’s vocals are a dead ringer for those of Jesse Lacey's during the verses of any given Brand New song
column7: as Gray never reaches for the piercing pop hooks. His lines are short and delivered with furrowed brows
column8: squints
column9: the telltale physical signs of small emotional implosions; opener “Even Bother” betrays the commitment in Dikembe’s complete sonic overhaul when Gray moans
column10: “It’s been a long time coming/ I spent a long time rotting.” Then
column11: a prickly palm-muted verse blasts into a full-on distorted blowout.

column1: Granted
column2: such things are typically a demonstration of musical virility. But when Dikembe do the same on the following “Hood Rat Messiah”
column3: the contrast between Gray’s deflated tone reveals this move as defense mechanism
column4: one last wounded swipe before tapping out. Though they don’t bear the same unbridled energy as in the past
column5: Dikembe are still a little too agitated to make “pretty” music. They can make ""mood music""
column6: though
column7: and the pervasive uneasiness of Mediumship lingers more than the songs.

column1: Gray’s lyrics exist somewhere between poetry and straight talk
column2: just insular enough to be frustrating—when he sings “Safe to say mistakes were made/ Now all my lungs are heart-shaped/ But I can’t find a better way to be
column3: ” it's typical of a legible feeling verbally twisted to the point where it’s meaningful to Gray on a personal level. But you just wish Gray could come out and say it
column4: whatever “it” is. Meanwhile
column5: as the record progresses
column6: the quiet-loud dynamics start to become predictable
column7: and the most interesting songs are a result of avoiding easy crescendo; “Mad Frustrated” is a silvery
column8: post-rock mini-epic that descends into an engrossing drum solo
column9: while “Donuts in a Six Speed” abruptly shifts gears into a startling
column10: math-y breakdown.

column1: Dikembe is a band that clearly has a personality; the truly affecting video that accompanied their cover of Mariah Carey’s “All I Want For Christmas Is You” is proof enough and in the tradition of their most well-known song (“Keys to the Jeep”)
column2: they continue to be the one punk band whose hip-hop references come exclusively from female rappers—this time out
column3: it’s Lauryn Hill (“Mad Frustrated”)
column4: Rah Digga (“Hood Rat Messiah”) and Nicki Minaj (“Donuts in a Six Speed”). It’s a sign of the scene’s health that a record as strong as Mediumshipcan feel like a missed opportunity;
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> they’re a band in transition rather than one that fully realized their potential at the height of their visibility. Then again
column6: Mediumship strongly suggests that they could get there once the gawkers have moved on; if you were willing to identify as emo in 2010
column7: you’ll do so when the trendpieces stop
column8:
too.
