column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20897/homepage_large.14bea114.jpg|Wastoid|27923.0|Stardeath and White Dwarfs|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Federal Prism']|2014-08-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:49.480344|"

There's an interview where Dennis Coyne
column2: nephew of Wayne
column3: recounts a ""pivotal"" moment in his life: being in the front row for a hometown Flaming Lips show when they were touring behind The Soft Bulletin. ""I was like
column4: 'Damn
column5: that is really cool
column6: more people need to do that.'"" Since then
column7: Dennis' band Stardeath and White Dwarfs have become some of the Lips' go-to fwends
column8: having joined Uncle Wayne and co. for full album covers of Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon and King Crimson's In the Court of the Crimson King
column9: plus a smattering of other recorded and live endeavors.

column1: Even when the Lips aren't around
column2: you can hear the undeniable influence of their records and live show on Stardeath and White Dwarfs' albums—in the unmistakably Coynian vocals of ""Keep Score"" from their 2009 LP The Birth
column3: or in the minimal-then-blaring opener ""The Chrome Children"" (which could feasibly be mistaken for an Embryonic or The Terror outtake)
column4: from their latest album
column5: Wastoid. But their proximity to the Lips is both a boon and a hang-up. While their profile has grown due to their Lips affiliations
column6: that comes with a price: it's difficult to approach this LP without thinking of their more famous counterparts. At worst
column7: this album frames Stardeath and White Dwarfs as an off-brand Lips offshoot—the Scrappy-Doo or Care Bear Cousins to the Flaming Lips' unmistakable protagonist. SWD and the Flaming Lips are undoubtedly similar
column8: but Wastoid just isn't very consistent.

column1: The strongest and most grabbing elements on the album—the occasionally Fuzz-like percussion
column2: the beautiful acoustic bridge at the heart of ""Frequency""—are undercut by cheeseball lyrics. They often look to establish a sensual connection through coolly delivered phrases like
column3: ""I'm the fire in your eyes"" or ""I'm the hot upon your skin"". On ""Birds of War""
column4: they sing ""Take my mind away
column5: Mary Mary Jane"". But the narrative on ""All Your Friends"" is perhaps the most difficult to digest. The narrator sings to the person he loves
column6: who doesn't care for life on the road
column7: but he knows that the person who's leaving him will eventually realize that ""Each town is all the same""—and the narrator will be waiting and eager to take that person back just as soon as they concede that he was right all along.

column1: Dennis also shares his uncle's penchant for collaborating
column2: as some of Wastoid's best tracks feature guests. New Fumes show up for ""Hate Me Tomorrow""
column3: adding urgency to an acoustic churn with a looming
column4: buzzing low-end and scratching sonics. The album's title track
column5: which features Chrome Pony
column6: is a prog-pop tune with tambourines and a call-and-response chorus. But the album's undeniable high point is ""The Screaming""
column7: which features the Flaming Lips themselves. It's a six-minute sprawl that most closely resembles something from The Terror
column8: and while several tracks on the album aim for this same vibe
column9: nothing feels quite this effortless or satisfying. The lyrics
column10: too
column11: manage to connect in their simplicity: ""I heard her answer me
column12: I saw her smile/ I turned around and see 10
column13: 000 miles."" ""The Screaming"" makes subtle shifts to keep things captivating
column14: starting out bleak and eventually finding bliss.

column1: The Birth was the work of a band with very good hooks peppered with proggy inclinations; by contrast
column2: Wastoid only offers a few momentary bursts of life
column3: like the squelchy synths that break up the monotony of ""Sleeping Pills and Ginger Ale""
column4: or the funky rhythm section that marks ""Guess I'll Be Okay"". At the best
column5: Stardeath and White Dwarfs suggest the potential to branch out and find their own lane; unfortunately
column6: more often they repeat an idea for too long
column7:
and predictability sets in.

"|19671.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19671-stardeath-and-the-white-dwarfs-wastoid/|5.7|Evan Minsker

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20868/homepage_large.ac4070c3.jpg|Late Night Tales Presents After Dark: Nightshift|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Late Night Tales']|2014-08-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:50.024601|"

The novelty of the Late Night Tales series of compilations stems in part from hearing what bands themselves like to hear. To date
column2: the music contained in each edition is as eclectic as the bands chosen to curate the series: Four Tet
column3: MGMT
column4: Röyksopp
column5: Lindstrøm. Hearing these bands as selectors has a certain charm
column6: be it Belle and Sebastian’s affection for post-punk and the Lovin’ Spoonful or Trentemøller’s alignment with the Black Angels and the Shangri-Las. But in tapping Bill Brewster for a second compilation in as many years
column7: Late Night Tales’ newest iteration of the series has a proper selector at the helm.

column1: For those not familiar with Brewster
column2: he runs the DJ History site and label
column3: publishing dance music tomes such as the massively influential Last Night a DJ Saved My Life
column4: a compendium of the Boy’s Own acid house ‘zine and first disco scribe Vince Aletti's weekly columns from the late 1970s. Brewster’s knowledge of dance music both old and au currant feels fathoms-deep and broad. It makes perfect sense that the week Brewster’s new set sees release
column5: you could also find him on BBC4 discussing Northern soul.

column1: Last year’s Brewster mix was a heady mix of old and new
column2: unearthing unreleased remixes and also heady tracks from the turn of the new century
column3: moving from sleaze to cop show themes
column4: French hip-hop to dubby house. Nightshift continues in a similar vein but sounds even more streamlined. Outside of two late '70s cuts
column5: Nightshift sounds all of a piece
column6: pulling from the same late-‘00s era of nu-disco. It opens with DJ Nature’s strings-and hand drum-heavy remix of Typesun’s “Last Home” and then into a similarly string-filled track from the Blaxploited Orchestra.

column1: The eighteen tracks that comprise Nightshift offer the slightest variations of a restricted sonic palette: disco’s boisterous basslines
column2: hand percussion that echoes from deepest space
column3: clean upstrokes of guitar
column4: crisp hi-hats
column5: swinging horns
column6: swelling organs and electronic washes that arise and recede
column7: any of the above elements prone to being dubbed out in the mix. And with no beat nudging past midtempo
column8: it makes for smooth sailing
column9: but as background music it tends to blend together in a way that is tough to differentiate.

column1: But it speaks to Brewster’s expertise that he can fold in outliers like Salsoul Invention’s mid-70s disco stomp “Soul Machine”
column2: or a deep cut from Kirk Degiorgio’s As One alias circa 2001
column3: or an album track from Justus Köhncke
column4: and make them all sound as if they could have been pressed to vinyl in an edition of 150 hand-stamped copies last year and available for a minute at Phonica Records. There’s even an appearance from Robert Fripp
column5: working in conjunction with Dave Ball and Richard Norris of the Grid. Particular highlights include the deliriously infectious “Mopedbart"" from Hubbabubbaklubb
column6: the catchiest song about a moped in recent memory. Had Brewster included the digital-only instrumental version of the Neurotic Drum Band’s 2009’s “Neurotic Erotic Adventure”
column7: it might have provided an early peak in the mix; as it stands
column8: the track–which otherwise smears acid
column9: house and cosmic disco across a sensuous seven minutes—is derailed by its insipid humor
column10: still making me grit my teeth five years later whenever the robot voices enter.

column1: In mining such a small sliver of a sub-genre as late-'00s nu-disco
column2: it seems that Brewster has his work cut out for him
column3: but his ear is such that he can find small gems almost anywhere on any remix or rare B-side. There may not be towering heights here
column4: but at almost any given moment in the mix
column5: there’s a thrilling swirl of filtered strings
column6: a nimble interlocking of hi-hat and kick
column7: sweet outerspace synth blasts
column8: or a catchy bassline that ushers you through to the next track. If I can’t differentiate between the likes of Paqua
column9: Mugwump
column10: or the Emperor Machine
column11: others might be hard-pressed to; but on shuffle
column12: the sameness of the tracks give Nightshift a curious trait in that almost any track can segue into the randomly generated next
column13:
making for a new mix each time.

"|19642.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19642-various-artists-late-night-tales-presents-after-dark-nightshift/|7.4|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20912/homepage_large.e97e412e.jpg|The Voyager|6113.0|Jenny Lewis|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-07-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:50.596970|"

In the 1930s the writer Gertrude Stein traveled to the Bay Area
column2: where she visited her hometown of Oakland. When she arrived
column3: she discovered that her childhood home had been razed and in its place erected new
column4: anonymous buildings. It was a different and less inviting place
column5: one that did not match up to her memory. In her journals
column6: which were published as Everybody’s Autobiography in 1937
column7: she wrote about the experience and concluded about Oakland
column8: “there is no there there.” Jenny Lewis examines a similarly thwarted nostalgia on her third solo album
column9: The Voyager
column10: and on the opening track “Head Underwater”
column11: she sings
column12: “I never thought I would ever be here/ Looking out on my life as if there was no there there.” It’s a pretty devastating admission of disconnection with oneself
column13: as though the Jenny Lewis of today had no means of identifying with any of the Jenny Lewises of the past.

column1: Not that you would immediately sense such alienation in “Head Underwater”. The beats thump with a laidback bustle
column2: the synths shimmer as if submerged in a pool
column3: the Watson Twins harmonize perfectly in the background
column4: and Lewis’ vocals swoop sharply and assertively
column5: with a slight ascending vocal arc that conveys optimism rather than its opposite. After the first verse
column6: however
column7: a dark
column8: post-punk guitar theme emerges
column9: more East than West Coast
column10: casting a darker spell. The song strikes a particularly Californian balance of sun and sadness
column11: and this glossy rumination is Lewis’ true milieu: If her trio of solo albums all sound different
column12: they emanate from the same perspective. It’s been four  years since she released that Jenny and Johnny album and six since she released her last solo album; even though the new album falters a bit
column13: it’s nice to see the world from that point of view again.

column1: The Voyager is defined and motivated by a sense of personal nostalgia
column2: as these songs sift through Lewis’ past to find some key to her present. There are passing references to the L.A. Riots and 9/11
column3: which act as clearly identifiable landmarks in in her (and many people's) life. There are musings on her past selves
column4: such as the “furious and restless” teenager in “Late Bloomer” or the woman chasing an ex on “She’s Not Me”. If this is Lewis’ most adult album—which is arguable
column5: as the self-possession she conveys plays as a kind of maturity—then it’s primarily because she’s more adult now
column6: with more experiences and more past selves. These songs wonder not only about how she got where she is
column7: but also where that is exactly. She still sings about cheating on her boyfriend on “Slippery Slopes”
column8: but justifies the discretion by claiming it makes her feel closer to him while she’s on tour: “If for just one second it helps us to remember that we like each other the most.”

column1: The album title and its NASA allusion may refer to the rocket-fueled momentum with which “every boy and girl” flies through life
column2: as Lewis muses on the title track. But the word also applies to her approach to making music. Especially as a solo artist apart from Rilo Kiley
column3: she has moved from one style to the next
column4: trying on genres and traditions like an actress visiting the wardrobe department. It was rhinestones and Nudie suits for her debut
column5: Rabbit Fur Coat
column6: which plumbed the Golden State’s country and country-rock history. She explored psych-pop on her 2008 follow-up Acid Tongue.

column1: By contrast
column2: The Voyager is not quite so easily summed up. It’s not anchored in one particular scene
column3: but plays as broadly California
column4: with sly nods to the Byrds in the guitars
column5: the Go-Go’s in the vocals
column6: and Randy Newman in the wry humor. On the other hand
column7: the album is produced to sound produced—that is
column8: to remind you that it is the product of a studio
column9: and in particular
column10: the studios of Beck and Ryan Adams. Such an approach lapses occasionally into tedious self-referentiality and even more tedious self-regard
column11: especially on “Aloha & the Three Johns”
column12: about rock stars on vacation. The song plays like an episode of some low-rent game show where the contestants can’t even appreciate the luxury of their surroundings. Of course
column13: the characters aren’t meant to be sympathetic
column14: but they’re not especially relatable either.

column1: Most of the time
column2: however
column3: Lewis is her usual smart
column4: funny self—a singer whose default setting is wry skepticism and a songwriter with a gift for the telling detail and the blunt confession. On the Beck-produced single “Just One of the Guys”
column5: she all but stops the song to underscore a moment of dire self-assessment. As the tempo slow and the instruments all fall away
column6: shit gets real: “There’s only one difference between you and me/ When I look at myself
column7: all I can see/ I’m just another lady without a baby.” Those lines nod to the expectations women of a certain age face not only from others but from themselves
column8: yet Lewis manages to personalize it. Her delivery adds another layer of self-awareness and perhaps something darker
column9: like resignation or regret. It’s a complicated sentiment nestled into a breezy pop tune
column10:
which is Lewis’ specialty. That precarious balance means there’s more than enough there there.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20773/homepage_large.c2802abe.jpg|Seven Years Week|32356.0|Hanssen|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hush Hush']|2014-07-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:51.206027|"

Bob Hansen
column2: the Seattle-based producer who sometimes records as Hanssen
column3: spent the first decade of his career making dancefloor-oriented music that occupied a wide spectrum of playfulness. When working as part of the duo Jacob London
column4: a collaboration with friend Dave Pezzner
column5: Hansen focused on a goofy
column6: skittering brand of house
column7: stuffing EPs like Casual Bingo and Brown Alert with songs that sounded like Luomo after a classic funk YouTube binge. His first few EPs as Hanssen
column8: released around the turn of the decade
column9: remained within the realm of beat-driven electronic music
column10: but with a much greater seriousness; glitch and gimmickry were largely replaced with an elemental bent
column11: by songs that either sprouted sturdy rhythmic roots or fizzled into the sky. His debut full-length Seven Years Week marks another step away from zany
column12: cluttered body music
column13: but retains some of the imagination and quirk that made that work special.

column1: The best contemporary analogue for the sounds Hansen is exploring on Seven Years Week is probably the work of groups like Emeralds—and the solo work of that band’s members
column2: Mark McGuire and Steve Hauschildt—who make melodic
column3: surprisingly dense ambient music. The genre’s lineage stretches back to German pioneers like Popol Vuh and Tangerine Dream
column4: groups that stretched the new technology behind synthesizers to its breaking point as the ‘60s morphed into the ‘70s
column5: and that heritage is certainly identifiable in Hansen’s work. He spends much of Seven Years Week looking into the stars
column6: whether through the cascading
column7: echoing synth lines of “Solar America” or the more explicit titular homage of chugging closer “Lunar Sleep”. With that said
column8: you get the sense that Hansen isn’t content just evoking the names of kosmische luminaries and calling it a day: he conducts a few experiments with texture and rhythm throughout the album
column9: and the results are tracks that tend to linger once they’re finished. “Cholesterol” is a good example
column10: built around a skittering
column11: surprisingly nimble beat and a vocal sample that’s been sucked through an astral vacuum
column12: and while Hansen eventually steers the song into more typical electronic terrain
column13: it feels like it could’ve taken many different forms: downcast electro-pop
column14: fodder for avant-garde rappers
column15: a stretchy synth odyssey. He’s very good at inviting the listener to consider the wide range of possibilities that stem from a single beat or synth line
column16: as if concepts are spilling out of his hyperactive brain and trickling down past the borders of his compositions.

column1: Another one of Seven Years Week’s strengths is its brevity. Ambient and drone music sometimes can’t help but invite sprawl
column2: with its slow-motion unfurling and occasional lack of focus
column3: and there’s often a great deal of pleasure to be found in losing oneself to the slow
column4: warm drift of a lone synth
column5: floating through infinite space like the Voyager twins. Hansen refuses to give in to this impulse
column6: and it shows in the album’s length: Seven Years Week only breaks the half-hour mark by a few minutes
column7: and none of its eight tracks come close to cracking the six-minute mark. It occasionally works against him—there are a few tracks
column8: like “Solar America” and “Everyday with Rachael”
column9: that could easily double in length without arousing a complaint—but overall
column10: it keeps the album clean and refreshing rather than messy and exhausting
column11:
a veteran move from a producer who’s continued to mature without becoming stiff or sedate.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20832/homepage_large.87d1a060.jpg|Persona|32374.0|Puce Mary|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Posh Isolation']|2014-07-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:51.863008|"

Take a brief listen to any of the dusky tunes that Frederikke Hoffmeier has released as Puce Mary
column2: and a startlingly bleak picture begins to form. Grating percussive scraping and nail-on-chalkboard vocalizations dominate her creeping compositions
column3: even as her instrumental work runs the gamut from deafening drones to clattering industrial drum beats. It's a bitter and icy collection of short form pieces and collaborations when taken as a single entity
column4: but her first LP Success didn't provide a compelling full-length exploration of that tenebrosity. With Persona
column5: her new record for Posh Isolation
column6: she's finally figured out how to present her strain of nauseating noise as a totemic
column7: engaging whole.

column1: Just as friends and fellow members of Copenhagen's underground music scene like Lust for Youth
column2: Lower
column3: and Iceage continue to flirt with slicker production and pop structures on recent releases
column4: Hoffmeier too has abandoned the universally bummed out aesthetic that's marked all of her efforts so far.  But rather than abandon the project's characteristic abstraction and abrasiveness
column5: Hoffmeier uses Persona to diversify the moods that Puce Mary covers
column6: offering disaffection
column7: sexuality
column8: and outright ferocity in addition to the desolation she's offered to date.

column1: ""Courses"" relies on a blown out kick drum and the shrill trill of Hoffmeier's distorted vocals to offer a ferocious red herring to kick off the record. The outright terror and lurching subversions of industrial genre tropes rank it among the best in the mode that she's worked in most frequently. But where other noise records would offer little variations on that track's unhinged theme
column2: Hoffmeier chooses to stagger in completely different directions for the rest of the record's six tracks
column3: offering stark ambient pieces (""The Viewer"")
column4: squalling
column5: sprawling noise jams (""Persona"")
column6: and the slow drone of the codeine-slurred ""Gesture"".

column1: It's a daring move to expand the project's thematic focus so drastically
column2: and though it sticks the landing on the tracks that retain ties to the all-encompassing darkness Hoffmeier knows so well
column3: Persona offers a handful of missteps too. Two of the album's longer pieces
column4: ""The Viewer"" and ""Impure Fantasy""
column5: rely a bit too heavily on vocal melodrama to underscore their sweeping instrumentals. In the former
column6: Hoffmeier unleashes a string of phlegm-y coughs to punctuate a gradual synthesizer swell; the latter features distant sounds of spitting and rattling chains underpinning what would otherwise be a compelling spoken-word exploration of empowered sexuality. In each of these cases
column7: a flair for theatricality undercuts tracks that were already unsettling enough on their own. But in taking the risks that spawned those blunders
column8:
Hoffmeier has managed to create a varied and rewarding record that's uniform in its gloominess.

"|19606.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19606-puce-mary-persona/|6.7|Colin Joyce

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20786/homepage_large.5381d924.jpg|Wilderness of Mirrors|10567.0|Lawrence English|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Room40']|2014-07-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:52.556242|"

Australian sound artist Lawrence English is responsible for the existence of a daunting number of recordings. As the founder of the Room40 label
column2: he curates contemporary ambient and experimental music by the likes of Mike Cooper
column3: Ben Frost
column4: Grouper
column5: Tim Hecker
column6: Greg Davis
column7: Oren Ambarchi
column8: and David Toop
column9: and English makes the same kind of music he releases—in abundance. The selected discography on his website runs to more than 30 items. Diving in at random
column10: you could luck into the glittering electro-acoustic miniatures of A Path Less Travelled
column11: his collaboration with Japanese group Minamo
column12: or the brightly mottled drone of A Colour for Autumn
column13: one of English's most fully realized works by the traditional album standards of variety and cohesion.

column1: But you could just as easily land in more of a niche taste
column2: such as the fine but ascetic For/Not for John Cage or the crumbling edifice of organ chords on Lonely Women's Club. Save yourself some floundering
column3: then
column4: by starting with English's newest album
column5: Wilderness of Mirrors. His first proper solo album since 2011's chorally inclined The Peregrine
column6: it gins up infernos of harmonic distortion not unlike the heavier sides of Hecker and Frost. With a couple of minimalist exceptions—<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column7: serif;"">the
column8: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">winding gusts of ""Guillotines and Kingmakers"" hearken back to Cage
column9: while low frequencies roil between ghost harmonies on ""Wrapped in Skin""—this is a maximalist effort
column10: smear-painted on an abyssal dynamic range in scintillating masses of slow-moving tone.

column1: English has said that the album is named after a line from T.S. Eliot's poem ""Gerontion"" and is conceptually based on Cold War misinformation campaigns—which
column2: sure
column3: why not? If abstract music has to be about something
column4: that'll do. More meaningfully
column5: English saw killer shows by Swans
column6: Earth
column7: and My Bloody Valentine while recording the album and was inspired to pump up the volume and density of his music
column8: which is felt right away on ""The Liquid Casket""
column9: a giant exhalation of thickly flexing drones that soon ignites in a radioactive mushroom cloud. English is an experienced technician
column10: and his saturation of stereo space and tonality never grows murky—the songs make distinct impressions
column11: from the backwards suck of the title track
column12: like a foghorn tolling over heavy traffic
column13: to the slowly subsiding muffled concussions of ""Another Body"" and the ritualistic cadence of ""Hapless Gatherer"".

column1: Consistently
column2: English cannily weighs out sticky
column3: swarming passages against smooth pearlescent lengths
column4: often drawing one out of the other with magisterial patience. The compositions range from delicate to mighty
column5: and always activate invigorating corporeal effects. Wilderness of Mirrors isn't groundbreaking in general
column6: but it is new territory for the often-cerebral English
column7: and he puts an engaging
column8:
commanding stamp on this style of ambient overdrive hymn.

"|19559.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19559-lawrence-english-wilderness-of-mirrors/|7.5|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20812/homepage_large.20a0b418.jpg|Bled White|32375.0|Novembers Doom|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['The End']|2014-07-31 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:53.090311|"

There are really only two ways to go if you’ve decided to ply your trade in death/doom: either ape Autopsy or Skepticism and get as ugly as possible
column2: or revel in the stately melodicism of My Dying Bride and mid-period Katatonia. Chicago veterans Novembers Doom have always aligned themselves firmly with the latter camp
column3: and have been steadily releasing heavily emotional melodic doom since 1995. Sole remaining original member and driving force Paul Kuhr started the band in Chicago back in 1989
column4: so at this point Novembers Doom are showing their age—but they are doing so as gracefully as one might expect from a band who have dedicated their career to the beauty of melancholia.

column1: Novembers Doom have always existed as a Midwestern Agalloch of sorts (or perhaps a Yankee Woods of Ypres). Several members have even collaborated with Agalloch bassist Jason Walton on past Subterranean Masquerade recordings
column2: and there are stark parallels to be drawn between the bands
column3: in aesthetic if not entirely in sound. Novembers Doom have always worn their hearts on their black sleeves and remained partial to the kind of nature-driven imagery that Agalloch loved so much
column4: but beyond that
column5: both bands’ approach to doomy
column6: intense
column7: yet still very melodic and earthy dark metal has remained mostly unchanged throughout the decades.

column1: While still a certifiably underground entity
column2: their name may sound very familiar to millenial metalheads who first stumbled across them during the band’s mid-'00s heyday. Their earlier recordings were less polished by default
column3: but as studio budgets and the members’ own confidence in their abilities grew
column4: so did the bombastic nature of the music itself. Bled White marks the band’s ninth studio album and fifth for The End
column5: and this time they’ve pulled out all the stops: the inimitable Dan Swanö’s perfectly polished mix gives the album a big
column6: commercial feel
column7: not too far removed from his work on Bloodbath’s flawless Nightmares Made Flesh. Kuhr’s full-throated roars even echo Peter Tägtgren’s delivery at their deepest
column8: adding a welcome edge and highlighting the proggy undertones on much of the album.

column1: Heavy moments abound
column2: but the band's focus lies on the gentler
column3: more complex melodic doom harmonies rather than the pummeling moments of death/doom. The sheer quiet prettiness of acoustic interlude “Scorpius” leading into the full-throttle aggression of “Unrest” sums up the album neatly
column4: as Novembers Doom do their best to summon their own interpretation of darkness and light
column5: quiet and thunder
column6: and make sense of the spaces in between.

column1: There’s a strong gothic feel to all of Novembers Doom’s material and their deeply personal
column2: occasionally histrionic lyrics makes for an affecting listen. Bled White would be an excellent album to give to your younger cousin before bequeathing them your Candlemass and Paradise Lost records; it’s gateway doom
column3: and there is something to be said for that. There's nothing wrong with accessibility
column4: even when discussing metal’s more ostensibly extreme offshoots. Novembers Doom peddle sorrow rather than savagery
column5: and this time around
column6:
they’ve done an admirable job of making that sale stick.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20893/homepage_large.19e430ad.jpg|Beck Song Reader|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2014-07-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:53.619763|"

At every stage
column2: Beck's music has reflected Los Angeles: The hodgepodge jigsaw of Odelay and Mellow Gold; the temperate melancholy of Sea Change and Morning Phase; the posthuman decadence of Midnite Vultures; and the all-purpose sunshine of The Information and Modern Guilt
column3: which convey joy in the muted way only Southern California can. He is ratty palm trees and rolling hills; he is five-dollar coffee and hand-stitched fedoras; he is a Burbank strip mall jammed with sundry and outdated business catering to everyone and no one at the same time.

column1: Warby Parker Presents Beck Song Reader is part of his showbiz phase; a laid-back benefit album that if nothing else reminds you that Beck may have started as an outsider but has long since become part of the establishment. Executive produced by Wes Anderson music supervisor Randall Poster
column2: it features 20 interpretations of songs written for his Song Reader project
column3: which was originally released as a book of sheet music by the indie publishing cottage McSweeney's. Contributors include alt-Grammy types like Jack White and Norah Jones; budding national treasures like Jeff Tweedy and Jarvis Cocker; and curiosities like Swamp Dogg and Sparks
column4: who skirted the mainstream but never quite assimilated to it.

column1: Then there's Warby Parker
column2: as in Warby Parker Presents Beck Song Reader
column3: a sunglasses company whose <a href=""http://l.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/nMplo2LpYdEPG6FMhvPGjg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3M7cT04NTt3PTYzMA--/http://l.yimg.com/os/publish-images/finance/2013-03-27/7f5536db-d0d3-485f-b222-9d97448ed6bd_1-warby.jpg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">chunky
column4: bohemian frames look like the kind of things an Upper West Side intellectual might have worn during the 1960s or '70s. Proceeds from the album go to 826 National
column5: a nationwide nonprofit committed to helping school-aged kids with creative and expository writing
column6: co-founded by Dave Eggers
column7: who
column8: is also the founder of McSweeney's. At some point describing the project becomes a Russian nesting doll of branding and attribution
column9: brought to you by someone in conjunction with someone else for the benefit of yet someone else. Between Parker
column10: McSweeney's
column11: and the album's lineup itself
column12: Song Reader crystallizes the maturation of the white indie set to the new ruling class—an arc traced by Beck's own career. This is a world of people who are mellow
column13: organized
column14: emotive within reason
column15: a little retro and graced with just a zest of modernity.

column1: Of course
column2: there's no point in giving numerical grades to charities or sociological phenomena. Though the cause behind Song Reader is vital
column3: the album is mealy
column4: governed by some strange centripetal force that manages to pull a group of otherwise interesting artists toward a mean of midtempo Americana and light roots music. If you'd never realized how much fun. could sound like Jeff Tweedy or Norah Jones like Laura Marling
column5: you soon will. Instead of highlighting the differences between its contributors
column6: Song Reader makes them all feel roughly the same.

column1: Speaking of fun.
column2: they emerge sounding inspired
column3: shedding the Kevlar of their White Triumph routine for something more vulnerable. Same goes for Bob Forrest
column4: who manages to capture the rooty
column5: mahogany implications of the music better than just about anyone here. Most striking is Swamp Dogg's ""America
column6: Here's My Boy""
column7: in part because it's hard to imagine it being written by Beck. A gutted
column8: funereal ballad built on piano and voice
column9: it plays like a black hole in a wide swatch of beige—the kind of transformation of source material to final product that makes a prospect like Song Reader exciting in the first place. It reminded me of the first time I heard Johnny Cash sing ""Rowboat""
column10: a modest country song from 1994's Stereopathetic Soulmanure. Not only did it suit Cash's talents
column11: but also it revealed in Beck a capacity for music people hadn't yet expected from him. Both came out looking good.

column1: Beck's last five or six years have been rife with experiment. Most of these experiments don't lie in the music
column2: but how it's made. His Record Club projects gathered loose groups of interesting people to cover entire albums in single days; his dedication to the maverick composer Harry Partch was written in Partch's own 43-tone scale; and his contribution to the Philip Glass remix album ended up being a sprawling
column3: 20-minute dream consisting of passages of Glass' music with Beck drifting in and out over top.

column1: And
column2: of course
column3: there's Song Reader
column4: a project that pushes against the instantaneity of how we consume art in the digital world. On the one hand
column5: nothing is as old-fashioned
column6: or in particular a songbook
column7: which speaks to ideals of music as something generated between live human beings around parlors and campfires. On the other
column8: no digital stream could ever be as ephemeral as something that was never recorded in the first place. The idea is clever
column9: and very Beck: a mix of the modern and the antiquated so fluid that you start to see how they're not that different to begin with. The execution feels out of his hands
column10: and really
column11:
out of everyone's—just another project whose purpose seems lost in the labyrinth of production. 

"|19667.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19667-beck-song-reader/|4.5|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20916/homepage_large.e9f43a1f.jpg|Pe'ahi|3531.0|The Raveonettes|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Beat Dies']|2014-07-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:55.121065|"

A decade on
column2: it’s safe to conclude that the quality of the Raveonettes’ albums depends on a unifying concept. The pair of records that kicked off their career
column3: the Whip It On! EP and Chain Gang of Love
column4: were lurid
column5: cinematic
column6: and written entirely in single keys; career highlight Lust Lust Lust was a raw
column7: roaring response to the band’s play for wider recognition
column8: a failed gambit built around their second album Pretty in Black. These albums weren’t major stylistic departures or markedly more ambitious than the rest of their work
column9: but they succeeded because they pitted the Raveonettes’ basic proposition—simple pop songs and sweet melodies
column10: coated in layers of malicious fuzz and laden with comically dark lyrics—against clearly defined rules and boundaries. Conditioned with even the most trite gimmick
column11: Sune Rose Wagner’s compositions have a better chance of acquiring staying power; left to stand on their own
column12: they mostly achieve a pleasure that’s pleasant but fleeting. With their seventh full-length
column13: Pe’ahi
column14: the band attempts to steer clear of the latter problem by shifting their sound markedly.

column1: Pe’ahi doesn’t sound much like any of the Raveonettes’ other records
column2: and that’s largely because they've added greatly to the instrumentation and effects. Where once Wagner and partner Sharin Foo were content to let their vocals and simple guitar chord patterns bear their songs’ melodic weight
column3: they now employ harps
column4: choirs
column5: xylophones
column6: and electronics; basic drum machine pulses are eschewed in favor of more complex
column7: swinging breakbeats. These songs are different on a structural level
column8: too
column9: as Wagner leaves traditional verse-chorus-verse behind several times throughout the album
column10: opting instead for multi-part mini-suites. They’re dense enough to honor the album’s namesake
column11: a legendary Maui surf break
column12: but still navigable; Justin Meldal-Johnsen
column13: the veteran producer and multi-instrumentalist who mans the album’s boards
column14: helps keep Pe’ahi clean despite all the layering and misshapen sound. Making sure to use every tool in their box
column15: the band plays with dynamics to amplify choruses and hooks
column16: a choice that yields the album’s finest moments; when “Sisters” explodes from a pristine harp pattern into a noisy wall of wild-eyed riffage
column17: it provides a visceral thrill that lasts
column18: even with repeated listening.

column1: The greater range of tones and textures is coupled with lyrical material that skews uncomfortably personal. Pe’ahi was written and recorded in the wake of Wagner’s father’s unexpected death last Christmas Eve
column2: and he spends much of the album grappling with the complicated realities of that paternal relationship. “Kill!” is the most obvious example—there’s really no denying the significance of a line like “One time I saw my dad fuck a redhead whore/ I never ever thought I would”—but even when Wagner isn’t explicitly discussing his father’s indiscretions
column3: he’s thinking about the impact that behavior might’ve had on his own patterns of infidelity. The few tracks on the album that deviate from this theme aren’t beacons of light and joy
column4: either; opener “Endless Sleeper”
column5: studded with guttural yelps and propelled by a shifting breakbeat
column6: recounts a near-death experience Wagner had while surfing in Hawaii half a decade ago. The Raveonettes are no stranger to bleak
column7: almost decadent darkness—they’ve always used sex
column8: drugs
column9: and violence as propulsive devices
column10: and one of their greatest songs is a jangling
column11: ascending ditty called “Boys Who Rape (Should All Be Destroyed)”—but the level of detail and consistency of Pe’ahi’s assault renders the album oppressive.

column1: The large evolutionary leap the Raveonettes have made on Pe’ahi raises an important question: does stepping away from sonic simplicity compromise the core of the band’s appeal? Though the band’s work has scattered along a narrow spectrum in the decade since they began their career
column2: that kind of reliability holds value for both longtime listeners and casual fans. They’ve also come to serve as an effective “gateway band” for younger listeners who haven’t yet encountered the band’s considerable influences
column3: funneling those nascent music fans towards the Jesus and Mary Chain and the meticulous
column4: distinctive  pop craftsmanship of Phil Spector. The diversity of sound the band rolls out on Pe’ahi is certainly refreshing
column5:
but it takes a chunk out of the foundation of their career. 

"|19689.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19689-the-raveonettes-peahi/|6.3|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20902/homepage_large.dc176cf1.jpg|Magical Pessimism 2014|31594.0|Default Genders|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-07-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:55.823914|"

Magical Pessimism 2014 lives on the internet. For one thing
column2: you cannot own a physical copy of James Brooks’ first full-length as Default Genders. More importantly
column3: Brooks takes a principled
column4: proactive stand against patriarchy
column5: rape culture
column6: rockism
column7: and punk fascism in a way that should be familiar to anyone who discusses pop culture on Twitter or Tumblr. You almost feel obligated to say Default Genders is well-intentioned; being mindful of privilege is surely a good thing
column8: no? But like much of the discourse confined to the internet
column9: Magical Pessimism often substitutes accusation for empathy
column10: conviction for coherence
column11: and straw men for actual people to the point where you wonder whether Brooks’ intentions are to draw attention to the problem or just his own moral superiority.

column1: This is an admittedly unusual way to begin a discussion about a pop record; Magical Pessimism isn’t a pamphlet. And though Brooks would likely claim Default Genders as a multimedia project
column2: before the association with Grimes and before giving himself a feminist rebrand twice
column3: he was gaining attention with Ruin
column4: the intriguing collection he made as half of Elite Gymnastics. As with his politics
column5: Brooks’ musical ambitions are bold and don’t hold up to a lot of scrutiny. He expressed a desire to invert the canon so it debunks Radiohead and deifies the Romeo + Juliet soundtrack—which conveniently ignores the 11th track on that CD. Moreover
column6: Brooks’ statement was an attempt to distance himself from the supposedly “nerd-male” influences (New Order
column7: Joy Division) he felt marred Ruin
column8: a record that sounds a hell of a lot like Magical Pessimism.

column1: That’s a good thing
column2: since Ruin was onto something
column3: combining harsh drum'n'bass beats
column4: blown-out ambience
column5: and shards of noise
column6: yet still found ways to fit Brooks’ predilections for classical composition and non-Western pop into the crowded mix. It rarely gels here
column7: but you hear why artists have taken a shine to Default Genders; Brooks is an ""ideas guy"" and the application of lo-fi and punk aesthetics to non-guitar music tends to be exciting on general principle.

column1: But Magical Pessimism still abides by typical “rock” signifiers to provide its most satisfying moments: basic A-B song structure
column2: choruses that surge on distortion (“The Trees in the Driveway”)
column3: and beats that more often recall Moby’s midtempo big-beat crossovers or even the blazingly hetero KROQ-core of the 1975 (“Stop Pretending”). Brooks is at his best making anthems
column4: while his deconstructionist tendencies are easy to confuse with carelessness—on the high-NRG tracks
column5: the EQing is boxy and the mixing is inconsistent
column6: at times burying Brooks’ voice
column7: something that barely works as texture. Tracks cut out and begin erratically
column8: sacrificing any semblance of cohesion or flow. Only an extremely generous interpretation would be to assume these are part of Brooks’ greater aim to demystify or at least denigrate The Album
column9: that totem of rockism.

column1: Then you have Brooks’ vocals
column2: a tuneless
column3: meek mutter used for chest-poking confrontation
column4: divisive by design. At times
column5: they lend an ear-turning effect to otherwise basic melodies and a conceptual force that has endeared him to a young
column6: plugged-in niche audience. Not only does Brooks' approach tell the listener
column7: “anyone can do this
column8: even <i>you
column9: ” but he shares a teen’s tendency towards thinking in absolutes about their own perceived persecution and the failings of others. And besides
column10: his conversational cadence is the only delivery in which his most angsty lyrics (“Fine
column11: cool whatever
column12: thanks for clearing that up”
column13: “Fuck that
column14: fuck them
column15: fuck you
column16: ugh...fuck my life”) can sound less awkward than they read.

column1: The problem is that Brooks applies the same black and white thinking to some of the most mature and complex topics which prove to be way out of his depth. He’s a thoughtful
column2: sincere person and that comes through in his interviews or an unadorned observation about a stock
column3: upwardly mobile type from “The Trees in the Driveway”—“You have to take out your piercings before you get to work/ But otherwise they’re pretty cool about the way that you dress.” When he tries to convey unearned gravitas
column4: it just results in leaden metaphor that hits with a dull thud—“The trees in the driveway start to shed all their leaves/ Some people would it’s cause they’re dying/ But to you it just seems like they’re focused on the important things.”

column1: Worse is that he shows little interest in actually getting to know the enemy—“punk” and “the suburbs” and “pain” are shoebox dioramas in which the characters serve as action figures
column2: free of agency and simply arranged by Brooks to demonstrate his place on higher moral ground. If you have any kind of lingering guilt about your own privilege
column3: a line like
column4: “Tell me again how heavy the crown is/ About the weight of the burden of being white and male” should decimate you. But in the context of Magical Pessimism’s pervasive self-congratulation
column5: the takeaway is that Brooks would obviously never do such a thing.

column1: This becomes almost impossible to bear during “On Fraternity”
column2: originally recorded under Brooks' Dead Girlfriends moniker and raising the question of whether there’s a wrong way to do the right thing. It’s been understandably viewed as a companion piece to Grimes’ “Oblivion”
column3: a brilliantly conceived pop song you can hear at malls
column4: gyms and on the street—the same places where one could be subject to the harassment Claire Boucher speaks upon. “On Fraternity” is in a different
column5: more checkered tradition of men writing songs about misogyny
column6: which can go extremely wrong
column7: but the risk can occasionally be justified by the reward. Fugazi’s “Suggestion” was both a bold strike against their peers and sensitive towards it subject
column8: while on Pissed Jeans’ ""Male Gaze""
column9: an average schlub showed that admitting his faults and changing his behavior can be a powerful display of allegiance.

column1: “On Fraternity” got people talking about these things
column2: and shouldn’t that be enough? Its Xiu Xiu-esque scree provides Magical Pessimism’s most arresting musical moment
column3: but lyrically
column4: it’s got the resonance of a #yesallmen hashtag. On its own accord
column5: “The way they act like even bringing it up/ Means you’re the one with the problem” could be a powerful
column6: concise acknowledgment of the presumptions of guilt and ""blame the victim"" investigative process that often prevents sexual assault claims from being reported in the first place. Instead
column7: you’re seemingly meant to marvel at Brooks’ bravery here.

column1: That’s how “On Fraternity” and much of Magical Pessimism comes across
column2: and yet I don’t truly believe Brooks thinks that way—even he’s called the song a ""total failure."" I wouldn’t be surprised if Brooks comes up with a long Tumblr post about all the ways this record has been misconstrued and he could be right about all of it. After all
column3: you live on the internet for long enough and you realize how often good intentions can be completely negated by ineffective communication; that in real life situations
column4: you might be friends with the guy you’ve been beefing with for months
column5: and a two-minute conversation can defuse a grudge that resulted in reams of Twitter dialogue and reblogs. Magical Pessimism is hardly a total failure
column6: and like many talking points that live on the internet
column7:
it can cause a discomfort that feels productive. But it’s ultimately up to the speaker to make the best use of his limited communication tools and Default Genders reminds you why so many people are relieved that Twitter finally has a “mute” function. 

"|19676.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19676-default-genders-magical-pessimism-2014/|5.6|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20858/homepage_large.738e295e.jpg|Call 4 Fun|32398.0|Actual Water|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bad Actors']|2014-07-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:56.511827|"

Call 4 Fun is that CD you fish for while out driving in the summer
column2: buried underneath a dirty work shirt and some old burger wrappers. It’s less than half an hour of garage power-pop that takes itself about as seriously as its finger-tapping guitar solos and songs about kids eating McDonald’s at 3:00 a.m. Actual Water are underachievers who worship simplicity. They make music from the same cro-magnon tools that built rock’n’roll
column3: but the Toronto band do it with a wry smile
column4: playing dumb while being in on the joke.

column1: In 2012
column2: Actual Water said they wanted to be <a href=""http://www.chartattack.com/news/2012/01/24/get-to-know-actual-water/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""><span class=""s2"">“ABBA with denim jackets on
column3: ” an elevator pitch that ably describes where the band landed with Call 4 Fun. But their history of experimentation and relatively stingy album output give these songs some actual dimension. The winding trip went from blown-out
column4: jazzy krautrock on their 2008 LP Double Negative to the more AM-radio 1960s psych of 2011’s The Paisley Orchard. Through the years
column5: band mainstays Gary Pooni and Anthony Nemet have been slowly clipping off the noise and polishing their sound until their love for Neu! and Swell Maps gave way to their love for Sloan and Led Zeppelin.

column1: Pitchfork writer Stuart Berman once called band's journey like ""The Beatles evolution in reverse
column2: an arc that continues here with “Latoya""
column3: whose polite three-part harmonies and gee-golly lyrics sound ripped right off a broadcast of The Ed Sullivan Show. “Latoya” is a fine emblem of how frictionless they sound now. It's one of those shiny pop products that couldn't just come spilling haphazardly out of a basement jam session. It's not necessary to have the context of their early albums to hear the craft that went into this
column4: but it's a large part of what makes Call 4 Fun have a bit more longevity than your average garage record.

column1: The band's pedigree matters far less than the album's hooks. There’s a bit of slurring
column2: New York post-punk on the closer “Gorgeous George”
column3: and a bit of Jerry Lee Lewis piano dancing on “Take The Stairs”
column4: but those just add color to the style they've found. It helps that they don’t aimlessly tour around rock history so much as cull from the best parts of it—or the parts that sound the good after eight cans of Old Style. The guitars sound like they only have one or two pedals hooked up to them. The drums have a boomy Keith Moon feel
column5: and their vocals find a nasally medium between snotty punk and Elvis Costello. Something like “Power Pop Radio” functions like an instruction manual for the album: “Get drunk with your friends so we know we’re not alone
column6: ” they sing on the chorus. The song
column7: naturally
column8: is a prototype power pop jam
column9: which continues the long tradition of writing songs about a genre
column10: in the style of that genre.

column1: In just 23 minutes
column2: Actual Water create the feel of a summer full of love and delinquincy. It’s about what could happen if you dialed that phone number in the bathroom stall
column3: the one that says “Call 4 Fun” underneath it. The days could lead to sitting around talking shit about a blowhard named “Waldo Jackson”
column4: or coming home late at night and housing fast food in front of a computer. And while most of these songs are suited for doing donuts in the high school parking lot
column5: there's a funny
column6: kind of poignant moment in ""The Wait"". It's simply about a ride to somewhere
column7: interminibly delayed: ""January through November/ We've been waiting for you."" That univsersal feeling of waiting for that guy to come pick you up to take you to that party that's going to rule? Actual Water are definitely that guy
column8: and here they are
column9:
so hop in.

"|19632.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19632-actual-water-call-4-fun/|7.4|Jeremy D. Larson

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20852/homepage_large.a882383f.jpg|Money Green Viper|32393.0|Zackey Force Funk|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hit + Run']|2014-07-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:57.120569|"

Tucson-raised singer/producer Zackey Force Funk walks the line between straight-faced sincerity and pranksterish weirdness
column2: and he's found some cohorts in other fields to help him negotiate that paradox. The most notable of these is Tobacco
column3: who pulled him in to work out some synthesized body-horror psych boogie as Demon Queen. But music under Zackey's own name is still relatively overlooked
column4: with earlier releases like 2011's glitchy
column5: hit-and-run Criminal Wave EP and the abstract sludge rap of Blood Brother
column6: his 2010 teaming with brother Nathan No Face
column7: proving ambitiously eclectic enough to make categorization elusive.

column1: Considering his professed debt to '80s-baby fixtures like Prince and Egyptian Lover—understandably earned
column2: since the now-40 ZFF was an impressionable grade-schooler back then—it wouldn't be out of the question to call Money Green Viper the best intro to his catalog. Even if it's not necessarily his best or his most startling
column3: it's probably the most fun entry point to people looking to figure out his whole deal. And the easy route is to draw parallels to Dâm-Funk with a sliver of Chromeo in his veins—the joy of electro-boogie cut through with a nod of sly loverman irreverence.

column1: But deeper examinations reveal a couple of complications. First off
column2: most of the dominant electro-boogie vibe comes from other producers
column3: with Inkswel's slightly-warped but immediately catchy ""Glass Tear Groove"" and Tom Noble's Parade-vibe ""Cocaine Lady"" making for early highlights. Meanwhile Zackey's own time behind the boards produces beats that
column4: while immersive
column5: also feel like outliers: wavy 808 pastel-beach slow jams (""Montego Bay"")
column6: choppy weed-cough lounge-Stevie (""Zackey Can't Rap""; ""Fuck Your Fire"")
column7: and a head-swimming electric piano instrumental (""Suicide"") that plays like a Lonnie Liston Smith interlude. And secondly
column8: Zackey's presence as a singer is a tricky thing to get used to
column9: as his falsetto creaks and mutters as much as it glides. It takes some patience to get past that—as well as the fact that some of the stuff he's singing
column10: like the first-draft come-ons of ""Yo Bael"" (""Wanna get close to you
column11: what you say/ Oh girl
column12: let's take this party to my room
column13: babe"") or the pitched-up entry-level pimp talk of ""A$$$low
column14: scans a little off either ironically or sincerely.

column1: Problems like that mostly stick out as a brief mid-album speed bump to be endured
column2: however
column3: with the back-loaded latter half of Money Green Viper revealing a few deep-cut surprises. There's the aforementioned ""Zackey Can't Rap"" (a legit funny bit of shit-talk directed to Zackey's mic skills that's either channeling some unnamed hater or ZFF's own self-effacement) and the soothing
column4: floaty ""Suicide"". But there's also the Quik-in-space bounce of the Max Kane-produced ""Out My Mind"" and a run of songs—""Gunny Peace
column5: ""Roch
column6: and ""Write Her Name""—that reveal a genuine eccentricity that's neither an affectation or an obstacle to get his stay-posi side across. It's not the easiest music to love sometimes
column7: but with all the oddball goodwill at work
column8:
it's even harder music to hate.

"|19626.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19626-zackey-force-funk-money-green-viper/|6.6|Nate Patrin

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20911/homepage_large.abcc1043.jpg|Who Will Cut Our Hair When We're Gone?|4436.0|The Unicorns|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Caterpillar']|2014-07-29 00:00:00|2003|2016-06-11 16:34:57.726712|"

It’s a bit misleading to say the Unicorns have reunited after a 10-year absence
column3: because they always seemed like they were barely holding it together in the first place. It wasn’t just that the band was built precariously upon the complementary-but-combative songwriting partnership between Nick “Diamonds” Thorburn and Alden “Ginger” Penner
column4: or that their infamous live shows were liable to degenerate into a chaotic clusterfuck of broken gear and profanity-laden tantrums. For the Unicorns
column5: this instability was embedded into their music’s root DNA; they took the term “pop music” at face-value and left us with a gooey
column6: messy
column7: combustible splatter. But with 2003’s Who Will Cut Our Hair When We’re Gone—their first and
column8: to date
column9: final widely released recording—Thorburn and Penner effectively got their shit together just long enough to herald their band’s demise.

column1: In an early-2000s Montreal music community renowned for heart-on-sleeve
column2: shoot-for-the-moon rockestras (see: the Dears
column3: Stars
column4: and
column5: of course
column6: scene lynchpins Godspeed You! Black Emperor)
column7: the Unicorns were the odd band out. From the color-coordinated white-on-pink stage attire to their bottomless well of theme songs for imaginary cartoon characters (“Jellybones”
column8: “Sea Ghost”) to the vintage synthesizers set on “fart
column9: ” the Unicorns seemed to be the antithesis of their more openly impassioned
column10: stern-faced peers. And the one emergent local band with whom they initially shared a predilection for gimmicky onstage attire
column11: vocal hysterics
column12: and volatile performances—the Arcade Fire—would soon solidify into a model of poise and professionalism
column13: something the Unicorns could never hope to become. Sadly
column14: they didn’t survive long enough to divest their almost-anthem “Let’s Get Known” of its aspirational irony: After touring themselves into the ground over the course of 2004
column15: the Unicorns would unceremoniously disband just as south-of-the-border publications like the New York Times and Spin were flying reporters up to Montreal to soak up the city’s je ne sais quoi.

column1: Eleven years may strike some as a premature anniversary for a reissue
column2: but the Unicorns’ moment feels so much deeper in the past when you consider how slick and streamlined popular indie-rock has since become
column3: and how few records have matched the scatterbrained unpredictability
column4: frayed-nerve unease
column5: and tooth-rotting tunefulness of Who Will Cut Our Hair. Throughout its 13 tracks (many of which are re-recordings of songs from two limited-run self-released discs)
column6: the Unicorns gleefully defy easy categorization as if they were a group of sneaky seventh-graders playing dodgeball: Too complex to be classified as garage-rock
column7: too unsettled to be psychedelic
column8: too hooky to be described as art-damaged
column9: and too fiercely funky to lapse into twee solipsism. (The latter quality came courtesy of secret-weapon drummer Jamie Thompson
column10: who only appears on a handful of tracks here
column11: but who became a full-fledged member after the album’s release.) Each song seems to undergo a diagnostics check—squelching synth test patterns
column12: random rimshots
column13: documentary snippets about Satanism—before it’s set loose
column14: eventually traversing enough twists and turns to rival the Who’s epic “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eIpsDTSmRyM"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">A Quick One
column15: While He’s Away” in half the time. And even after living with this album for over a decade
column16: you’re still never quite sure where it’s going to take you.

column1: Unlike many songwriting foils
column2: Thorburn and Penner have similarly peculiar voices
column3: giving their melodic interplay a finish-each-other’s-sentences sense of intuition while lending their moments of playful in-song sparring a discomfiting tension. When the two start trading “No you’re not”/ “Yes I am” schoolyard-grade taunts on “Child Star”
column4: it’s not unlike watching Siamese twins head-butting one another. But if that song—reportedly inspired by an unpleasant encounter with a past-his-prime Corey Haim—sees the two engaged in obvious role-play
column5: other tracks blur the line between pretend-jousting and actual acrimony.

column1: True to their capricious nature
column2: the band’s would-be theme-song celebration
column3: “I Was Born (A Unicorn)”
column4: devolves into a custody battle between Thorburn and Penner for control of the band: “I write the songs” / “I write the songs!”/ “You say I’m doing it wrong”/ “You are doing it wrong!” But while the Unicorns may act childish
column5: their sense of nostalgia flies in the face of today’s Instagram-filtered
column6: #tbt sentimentalism; instead
column7: Who Will Cut Our Hair transports you back to that pivotal moment in childhood when you first realize the meaning of death
column8: and one’s sense of naïveté and frivolity give way to confusion and terror. For all their surface silliness—this is a band whose idea of sensitivity is serenading lines like “Somewhere in the asshole of my eye/ There’s a muscle which relaxes when you cry”—the Unicorns were motivated by a genuine desire to comfort
column9: using fantastical images of ghosts and haunted houses to temper real-life fears and anxieties. After all
column10: an album that begins with the flustered “I Don’t Wanna Die” ends with the peaceful “Ready to Die”
column11: suggesting that acceptance of death is the first step to truly living.

column1: That certainly seems to be the case for Thorburn
column2: whose ambitions have since shifted into overdrive
column3: with forays into hip-hop (Th’ Corn Gangg)
column4: Everly Brothers-style harmony-folk (Human Highway)
column5: 1950s doo-wop (Mister Heavenly)
column6: and cinemascopic art-rock (Islands). Penner
column7: by contrast
column8: has resurfaced only sporadically
column9: taking a rough-hewn
column10: deconstructionist tack with his short-lived band Clues and his recently released solo album. But the duo’s divergent post-Unicorns trajectories ultimately reemphasize the perfect
column11: delicate balance the duo achieved together.

column1: While it remains to be seen if their recent reconciliation will yield any new material
column2: for now
column3: the four rarities included on this reissue function as fresh flowers at an old gravesite
column4: offering affectionate reminders of a legacy cut short prematurely. These include two intricate-yet-immediate songs (“Evacuate the Vacuous” and “Let Me Sleep”) that fit snugly within Who Will Cut Our Hair’s prog-pop parameters
column5: and a live recording of the never-released “Haunted House” that provides a glimpse of the Unicorns’ notoriously off-the-cuff performances and Thorburn’s cheeky banter.

column1: But perhaps the best exemplar of The Unicorns ethos can be heard in their excellent cover of “Rocket Ship” by Daniel Johnston
column2: the Texan pop savant who first formulated the uncanny mix of innocence and horror that informs every song in the Unicorn canon. That Johnston nod further positions the Unicorns’ modest modus operandi in stark contrast to that of their world-beating Montreal-scene mates. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">The reformed Unicorns will be opening some amphitheater dates for their old pals the Arcade Fire next month
column3: but this reissue serves as a warm reminder that
column4: once upon a time
column5:
the idea of the opposite scenario happening in 2014 wouldn’t have seemed so ridiculous.

"|19685.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19685-the-unicorns-who-will-cut-our-hair-when-were-gone/|8.9|Stuart Berman

column2: when he spoke to a reporter from DJ Mag
column3: the Israeli producer Guy Gerber was still allowing for the possibility that 11:11
column4: his long-awaited collaboration with Diddy
column5: might not come out by its projected mid-August release date — or
column6: indeed
column7: at all. ""I would say middle of August
column8: he told DJ Mag. ""And if it doesn't come out then
column9: OK
column10: maybe we should never release it.""

column1: But what's another week or two (or fifty-two
column2: for that matter) in the case of an album that was supposed to come out nearly three years ago? In pop music
column3: any three-year delay is kind of a big deal—just ask Axl Rose—but that's especially true when your record has a numerologically significant title with a hard expiration date: November 11
column5: to be precise. Nevertheless
column6: some 42 months after Gerber told Pulse Radio that he was ""just adding finishing touches"" to the album
column7: it's finally here
column8: and it's a head-scratcher.

column1: That's not necessarily for the reasons you might expect
column2: beginning with the fact that Gerber and Diddy make for an exceptionally odd couple. After all
column3: despite the narrowing distance between hip-hop and dance music over the past couple of years
column4: the two musicians occupy vastly different spheres. Gerber
column5: a 12-year veteran of the European tech-house scene
column6: is known for moody
column7: instrumental cuts designed to worm their way into fried synapses at stupid o'clock in the morning; they're spaced out but subtle
column8: hovering hypnotically on the cusp between melody and monotone. (They're also frequently kind of boring
column9: but hey
column10: ketamine is a hell of a drug.) Diddy
column11: on the other hand
column12: is one of the rap game's greatest hustlers
column13: a master of the obvious who wouldn't know subtlety if it knocked the umbrella out of his manservant's hand.

column1: The two musicians hooked up when Diddy used one of Gerber's tracks for 2010's Last Train to Paris
column2: a club-influenced album released under his Diddy-Dirty Money moniker; Diddy subsequently flew Gerber to New York and set him to work making beats
column3: giving him one of Gerber's own tracks as a guide. Fittingly
column4: 11:11 sounds very much like a Guy Gerber record. Most of its 11 tracks cruise along at a mid-tempo
column5: four-to-the-floor chug; they're full of sensual suggestion and druggy melancholy
column6: with purring vocals pitched low and drum machines dissolving into spirals of analog delay. Massive Attack and Mathew Jonson are the main outside influences
column7: the former for their smeary dub effects
column8: and the latter for his Middle Eastern-tinged scales and gently filliping glissandi.

column1: But
column2: like Gerber's Fabric mix of all-original material
column3: it's too often meandering
column4: unfocused and undifferentiated
column5: the mixdown muddy and gelatinous. Setting aside the aimless opener
column6: ""Never Walk Alone""
column7: a four-minute instrumental that sounds like they tried to make something modeled after the Cure's Disintegration but accidentally leaned on half the mixer's track-mute buttons
column8: the album actually gets off to a strong start with ""Broken Windows"". Over a dry
column9: loping drum beat
column10: a wistful little synth melody sashays back and forth
column11: backed by faint chimes and fluttering keyboards
column12: and a queasily processed voice sings of distance and unrequited love. It's the one truly original moment on the album
column13: the one greater-than-the-sum-of-its-parts fusion of their respective talents for atmosphere and pop songcraft.

column1: But from there
column2: the album tends to hopscotch from holding pattern to holding pattern. ""Floating Messiah"" drizzles melting horns over an ostinato bass line as Gerber fiddles with FX and Diddy mutters about divine love and the love of the divine (""You gotta believe in something
column3: I believe in her… Y'all think I'm talkin' about women? I'm talkin' about God
column4: or a higher being
column5: whatever you believe in""). ""Lifted"" trots out a snapping
column6: Cobblestone Jazzy synth-and-drum-machine jam while Diddy reels off vocoded nonsequiturs. It doesn't feel as fresh as ""Broken Windows
column7: but it's probably the album's standout club jam
column8: setting aside ""Tourist Trap""
column9: a minimal-house anthem that samples Diddy-Dirty Money's ""Hello Good Morning"" and was a big deal in clubs way back in 2011.

column1: ""Angels
column2: with its watery wibbles
column3: psychedelic guitar and loping disco beat
column4: sounds like a confused fusion between Cocteau Twins
column5: Pink Floyd
column6: and Soul Clap; ""I Hear Her Calling Me"" is similarly bathetic and even more unfocused
column7: with piano noodling tangled up with dub delay
column8: trap hi-hats
column9: and about 17 layers of background vocoder. And so it goes
column10: all the way through to the closing ""Terminal K""
column11: an altered-states ode that sounds like Ricardo Villalobos clumsily remixing Dead Can Dance. (No prizes for guessing what that letter stands for
column12: given that back in March
column13: Diddy confessed to listening-party attendees that they considered calling the album Ketamine.)

column1: Diddy's interest in dance music actually goes back more than a decade. Way back in 2004
column2: he enlisted Stuart Price
column3: Nellee Hooper
column4: and Erick Morillo
column5: among others
column6: to make a project called Divided Soul
column7: an Ibiza-inspired record that got derailed when Ibiza proved a little too inspiring. (""We rented a house [in Ibiza]
column8: and we started
column9: Diddy told Pete Tong at the IMS Engage conference in April. ""We were supposed to record for seven days
column10: but once I went out to the clubs I didn't return back to the house for seven days."") A few years later he discovered DC-10's Circoloco parties
column11: where he brandished a miniature vuvuzela and mingled with the sweaty
column12: sunglasses-wearing masses to the strains of DJs like Perlon's Zip.

column1: So it's not that surprising that Diddy would gravitate towards the deeper
column2: more ruminative strains of European tech-house
column3: rather than the flash-bang varieties of EDM that have captured the imagination of hip-hop artists from Araabmuzik to Lil Jon. What's surprising is how little of Diddy there seems to be in the record at all. Despite the album's lengthy gestation period
column4: 11:11 doesn't feel like some epochal meeting of the minds; it feels like a Guy Gerber album where Diddy occasionally turns up to mutter free-associative fragments or sing a few lines through a vocoder.

column1: Given that both artists often come across like Spinal Tap characters come to life
column2: their collaboration should have been
column3: by all rights
column4: some kind of gonzo
column5: pinch-yourself-to-make-sure-it's-real
column6: over-the-top fusion of American entrepreneurship and Ibiza spectacle
column7: of urban smarts and Balearic cool. Instead
column8: for all its self-indulgent qualities
column9: it's merely tasteful and weirdly tentative. And there's little inkling as to the significance of the title 11:11
column10: which Gerber once said was meant to indicate ""a date when a mystical gate is open and two worlds collide."" Perhaps when the gate slammed shut on that November 12
column11: three years ago
column12:
they should have realized it was time to go back to the drawing board.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20754/homepage_large.76e2d073.jpg|Cold World|32353.0|Naomi Shelton & The Gospel Queens|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Daptone']|2014-07-29 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:34:58.720618|"

Naomi Shelton has been singing the Lord’s praises longer than most of us have been alive. Born in the early 1940s
column2: she began performing with her sisters at their small church in Midway
column3: Alabama. After graduating high school and discovering soul music
column4: she moved first to Florida and then to New York City
column5: where she continued singing in church but also held court in Brooklyn nightclubs under the name Naomi Davis. Like many African American singers at the time
column6: her repertoire balanced the secular and the spiritual
column7: the worldly and the heavenly. Even though her singing career spans half a century
column8: her recording career has been much shorter. In 1999
column9: she and an old friend/collaborator named Cliff Driver formed a gospel group that attracted the ear of Gabriel Roth. At the time he was running a label called Desco
column10: for which Shelton recorded two sides; when it folded
column11: she signed with his new venture
column12: Daptone Records.

column1: She’s been a major presence on that label’s roster
column2: touring the world with the Daptone Super-Soul Revue and singing with the Sugarman 3. Never quite as popular or as prolific as Sharon Jones (who is Daptone’s flagship act)
column3: Shelton has proved a powerful vocalist and performer even into her 70s. In 2009
column4: she finally released her debut full-length for the label
column5: <i><a href=""https://daptonerecords.com/shop/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=82"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">What Have You Done
column6: My Brother?
column7: which closed with a soul-stirring cover of Sam Cooke’s “A Change Is Gonna Come”. Five years later
column8: she’s finally following it up with Cold World. As the title suggests
column9: Shelton is concerned not just with the individual sinner but with the sad state of the world. Faith is never a private matter; because it informs how we treat ourselves and others
column10: it is a social concern.

column1: Consequently
column2: Shelton is drawn to songs that address social issues and paint the world bleakly. “It’s a Cold
column3: Cold World” describes the back-stabbings and betrayals among humans (“They’ll step on you every every day!”) and points to a certain carpenter as the truest friend possible. With Shelton and the Gospel Queens (Bobbie Jean Gant and Edna Johnson
column4: plus newcomer Angel McKenzie) delivering a lively call and response
column5: the song itself sounds steeped in ‘70s R&B
column6: as though making a conscious nod to the heyday of the Staple Singers. Yet
column7: the conviction in their voices rescues the song from any sense of nostalgia
column8: lending it some persuasive topicality beyond its musical reference points.

column1: Roth
column2: producing under his alias Bosco Mann
column3: has put together a band of R&B veterans to back Shelton and the Gospel Queens on Cold World. If they weren’t such fine players
column4: sensitive to the cadence of Shelton’s vocals and the sentiments of these songs
column5: you might think they were hired for their historical connections to artists who likewise blended the secular and the spiritual. Driver himself has played with Sam Cooke and Solomon Burke; bass player Fred Thomas was a JB in the 1970s. Somehow
column6: the music occasionally sounds too Daptone
column7: as though these backing tracks could have been created for Jones or anyone else on the roster. That shouldn’t reflect on Shelton
column8: but should suggest either the label’s somewhat limited sound or Roth’s too-familiar production style.

column1: But the band cover a lot of ground on Cold World
column2: toggling between the reggae-tinged rhythms of “Sinner” and the breezy groove of “Everybody Knows (River Song)”
column3: a cover of the 1965 O.V. Wright tune. Still
column4: it’s Shelton who confidently ties everything together and insinuates a larger story arc in the sequencing: a journey that begins in doubt (“Sinner”) and ends with salvation and gratitude (“Thank You Lord”). If her label defines itself by the past tense
column5: Shelton understands that gospel is rooted in the present (the tribulations we face today) and the future (the promise of eternity in heaven). It may seem like a minor distinction
column6: but on <i>Cold World
column7:
it’s the difference between revival and revivalist.
