Brooklyn-based Jim-E Stack grew up in a pre-gentrified San Francisco
column2: surrounded by a variety of different cultures and sounds; after an early stint as a drummer
column3: he started making beats in high school
column4: and though he was turned on to house music in his late teens
column5: you can still hear echoes of all the styles he’s loved on his debut full length
column6: Tell Me I Belong.

column1: Much of Stack’s reputation comes from his live sets
column2: and his feel for mood and transitions on the first half of the album justifies his reputation as a club DJ. Tell Me I Belong has a narrative ambition not often present on electronic LPs
column3: and Stack takes plenty of time patiently building energy for the album’s early climax
column4: “Reassuring”. Leading up to that track
column5: the listener is taken on a slow climb through the mid-tempo Baltimore club-influenced “Run” and “Below”'s saccharine electro. “Reassuring” is the reward at the top of the mountain
column6: a deep house jam with a screwed-up vocal sample
column7: plaintive R&B keys
column8: and a dancehall shuffle. The track that follows
column9: “Everything to Say”
column10: is the perfect denouement
column11: and if Tell Me I Belong were an EP consisting of these five tracks
column12: it would be hard to find anything wrong with it.

column1: But the second half of the album is a lesser echo of the first
column2: up to and including its vocal-looping climax
column3: “Without”
column4: which
column5: at best
column6: stands as a mere duplicate of “Reassuring”'s charms. Other counterpoints are similarly weak: the blocky stabs at house and B-more club on “Out of Mind” feel random when compared to the precision of “Run”
column7: and the working man's samples-n-synths package on the one-minute
column8: “Ease Up”
column9: while an amusing diversion
column10: could use a little extra weight.

column1: When the second half of Tell Me I Belong finally deviates from the established blueprint
column2: Stack comes through with “Wake”. It’s a full-fledged
column3: album-ending anthem that manages to combine the emotional heights of “Reassuring” and “Without” with the sure-handed patience that marks the album’s superb sequencing. Skip to any two random points within the track
column4: and there’s a chance that they’ll make absolutely no sense in relation to one another. But in real time
column5: these disparate moments are smoothed out by Stack’s ability to shift gears with the speed and serenity of a Formula One driver. ""Wake"" is a reminder of Stack's talent as a storyteller; shame
column6: then
column7:
that the narrative of Tell Me I Belong doubles back on itself  halfway through the tale.

When it comes to heavy music
column2: niche politics exercise a disproportionately powerful role in shaping a band’s musical identity. There's an obsession with compartmentalizing every last guitar lick or drum beat and planning the listening experience accordingly
column3: almost as if by algorithm. This approach offers an easy way to establish distinctions between artists
column4: but it comes at the expense of a reduced appreciation of metal's liminal spaces and atypical arrangements. Case in point: Brooklyn's visionaries of filth Mutilation Rites. However strong the Darkthrone worship may have shone through on Empyrean
column5: the band's excellent 2012 debut
column6: their blackened riffs were ultimately overshadowed by their rabid
column7: punkish attitude
column8: unpredictable percussion
column9: and cross-pollinating song-craft.

column1: Two years later
column2: Mutilation Rites return with Harbinger
column3: their second album. Like its predecessor
column4: the new record splits its time between lengthy
column5: metamorphosing epics and thunderous rabble-rousers
column6: with nary a synth or sample in sight. This time around
column7: however
column8: improved sonics and sharpened songwriting streamline the band's venture into the void
column9: recalling a garagey Gorgoroth at some points and a filthier Converge at others. Frequently
column10: their smoke-enshrouded roar resonates with a sneaky immediacy reminiscent of early Mastodon; with its unstoppable guitar hook and seething
column11: grunge-y coda
column12: “Contaminate” is easily Mutilation Rites' “Blood and Thunder”
column13: while closing dirge “Tactical Means of Ouroboros” would have felt right at home on Remission. Like the Atlanta legends
column14: the quartet exercise mind and muscle equally
column15: striking a difficult balance between galloping polyrhythms and beefy guitars on opener “Black Pyramid”. At the same time
column16: they don't stick around to stargaze for too long; where there's a mournful melodic seep (as on “Exhaling and Breathing In”)
column17: a shuddering screech from vocalist George Paul never trails far behind.

column1: Harbringer’s gut-lurching thrills rely heavily on drummer Justin Ennis
column2: formerly of fellow Brooklynites Tombs. Guided by some arcane intuition
column3: he carves out the violent spaces where the band wreaks havoc and detonates them as he sees fit. On “Suffer the Children”
column4: his kit ricochets between black
column5: death
column6: d-beat
column7: doom
column8: and grindcore temples
column9: repeatedly threatening the track's inevitable collapse across six pulverizing minutes. As the blast-beats bear down on the second half
column10: the song’s kinetic force strengthens in a caustic crescendo that defies logic
column11: endowing the din with unexpected depth. It's a bit of percussive wizardry on the part of engineer Kevin Bernsten
column12: best known for his work with speed demons like Magrudergrind. Snare
column13: cymbal
column14: and bass each carry twice as much weight in his mix
column15: making Ennis’ fills—rather than the riffs of Paul and Michael Dimmitt—the focal points of songs like ""Contaminate” and “Gravitational Collapse”.

column1: In spite of their motions towards transcendence
column2: Mutilation Rites’ complex racket is never accompanied by an elitist aftertaste. Considering their associations with the notoriously overachieving Brooklyn metal scene
column3: that’s both a relief and a blessing—freedom to enjoy the adrenaline rush of Harbinger without getting bogged down by form or philosophy
column4:
the sound of four guys paying tribute to chaos the best way they know how. 

"|19509.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19509-mutilation-rites-harbinger/|7.5|Zoe Camp

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20857/homepage_large.cc761557.jpg|Lese Majesty|28847.0|Shabazz Palaces|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-07-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:00.668106|"

Shabazz Palaces’ Sub Pop debut Black Up breathed indelible soul into the Seattle duo’s formidable style
column2: an assemblage of chaotic grooves that spun out
column3: pivoted on a crafty turn
column4: and hightailed it home along the back roads. The 2011 album cut former Digable Planets member Ishmael Butler’s opaque mysticism loose on a palette of intricate
column5: dreamy soundscapes provided by resident producer Tendai Maraire
column6:
sacrificing traditional songwriting conventions like verses and choruses to sojourn to rap’s frayed edges. Ish’s musings on love resonated in their leveraging of heady imagery with wizened world-weariness; his songs triumphed in their arrangement of familiar ideas into peculiar shapes.

Rather than mining Black Up’s fertile retrofuturist boom-bap further
column7: the group have since decamped to parts unknown. The duo’s latest album Lese Majesty boasts 18 songs grouped into seven suites
column8: with a subtle science fiction theme. If that sounds a bit Close to the Edge
column9: get used to it. Lese Majesty aims to free the group’s songwriting apparatus from its trademark purposefulness
column10: to chart a course that zags where earlier work zoomed. While the opening suite “The Phasing Shift” leads with three straight cuts in the spirit and form of Black Up
column11: the record doesn't stay in one place for long. From the moment “They Come in Gold” fades into the undulating drone of “Solemn Swears”
column12: it's clear that
column13: for the duo
column14:
space is the place.

The “Touch & Agree” suite is a good primer for what to expect from Lese Majesty. “Solemn Swears” builds on a bed of synth pulses and a playful riff from Ish before collapsing into “Harem Aria”
column15: a disorienting romp whose upbeat never hits where it’s supposed to. “Harem” becomes “Noetic Noiromantics”
column16: which peels a few layers back to tease a hook out of the maelstrom only to dissipate as quickly as it congealed. Lese’s individual tracks aren’t so much songs as ramshackle ideas subject to crumble or explode into something unfamiliar at a moment’s notice. The passage through these movements feels like an itinerant drift
column17: a conscious rejection of the methodical drive of its predecessor.

column1: Lese’s moves aren’t always subtle
column2: though; the album gets shiftier as it progresses
column3: dispensing with the comfort of thematic unity. The run from “#CAKE” to “Mind Glitch Keytar Theme” flies through tribal drum vamps
column4: Miami bass
column5: horror soundtrack synths
column6: and a frayed 190 BPM house workout in just a few minutes
column7: ramping up the intensity before easing off it with the album closing chillout suite “Murkings on the Oxblood Starway”. This is a producer’s album
column8:
constructed to showcase a versatile sound architecture the same way Black Up highlighted Ish’s way with words.

Sometimes that means Ish's vocals are a tool in the production arsenal
column9: distorted and distended rhythmic elements instead of guiding points. In Lese’s more erratic passages
column10: Ish is content to toy around with an intriguing turn of phrase instead of unfurling the impressionistic poetry that electrified Black Up
column11:
but that doesn’t mean this is just an assortment of chants and sketches; Ishmael’s showcases are a grounding force for a body of songs fixated on the cosmos.

“Lèse-majesté” is a capital crime in stricter monarchic societies that loosely translates to ""the offending of royalty."" It's an appropriate title for the network of verses Ishmael presents here
column12: which glibly taunt the kings of the modern rap mainstream for slacking on the job. Questioned about Shabazz Palaces' overarching purpose in a recent NPR interview
column13: Ish retorted
column14: ""Make no mistake
column15: this is an attack
column16:
and cuts like ""Suspicion of a Shape"" (""All you guys are quantized"") and “...down 155th in the MCM Snorkel"" (“The type of MC you’d be back then is ‘sucka’”) are rife with bile for feted lesser talents.

Similar to recent albums by the Roots and Common
column17: Lese Majesty is an Armageddon-esque suicide mission to crash into rap's consciousness in hopes of tipping it away from a dangerous path. While its peers have set about their objectives this year with a staunch
column18: unblinking seriousness of purpose
column19: Ish is more forgiving. The Rucker reminiscence ""...down 155th in the MCM Snorkel"" recalls the days of doorknocker earrings
column20: Dapper Dan suits
column21: and fair ones without pining for a time machine or hawking staid old school invective. These aren’t condescending “Real Hip-Hop” platitudes: this is a call to arms for hip-hop’s creative fringe to snatch the reins from a power structure more interested in self-preservation than the advancement of the culture. The soul of Shabazz Palaces is pairing next-gen sounds with classic brass-tacks show-and-prove emceeing
column22:
and Lese Majesty tugs those extremes as far as they've ever been pulled; that it never shows signs of wear speaks to the strength of the bond.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20735/homepage_large.ae2d3f8f.jpg|Racy|29244.0|Hooray For Earth|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dovecote']|2014-07-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:01.334421|"
column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">A band doesn’t have to be legendary
column3: or even great
column4: to be definitive. Case in point: Hooray For Earth. If you consider “alt synth-rock” to be a thing—and you should—any given release from the Brooklyn band could be considered state of the art. In the three-year stretch between their first EP and 2011’s True Loves
column5: their aesthetic evolved from a less polychromatic rendering of MGMT’s Mario Paint symphonies to a parallel of the percussive
column6: vaguely mystic electro-pop streamlining of Animal Collective and Yeasayer. Three years later
column7: Racyreflects where we’re currently at; this type of band no longer has any pretense of being “indie rock” in anything but a nominal sense. Racy is big
column8: it’s bold
column9: and positions its creators closer to ""pop""
column10: only to reveal them as a pop band by context rather than nature.

column1: And they were in a much more flattering context three years ago. True Loves was stacked with relatively bold
column2: overt singles and equally stacked with the requisite
column3: billowy deep cuts like “Black Trees”
column4: so defined by atmosphere and drums that a doom metal cover by the Atlas Moth maintained its original character. Racy unifies those disparate aims of Hooray For Earth and the result is an album where everything could be the single—which ultimately has the reverse effect
column5: as little stands out amidst its consistent
column6: ingratiating quite-goodness. They’ve once again enlisted producer Chris Coady
column7: who’s worked on records for Cold Cave
column8: Future Islands
column9: and Beach House—the guy knows how to make alt synth-rock loud and direct.  Any semblance of roundabout drum circle percussion gets pointed endlessly forward and upward; guitars are no longer choppy
column10: the synthesizers are in bolder neons and fluorescents.

column1: As a result
column2: Racy is just what it promises: sleek
column3: aerodynamic
column4: and defined by its vertical momentum. The entire album is comprised of songs taking flight in some way—while “Keys” zooms skyward like a 747
column5: the title track slowly elevates like a hot air balloon. It can occasionally be thrilling
column6: as with any occasion where the human will for technological advance conquers natural limitations.  And though this is 2014
column7: most bands of Hooray For Earth’s ilk are reminiscent of a time when Big Music was an actual term; when U2 and Echo and the Bunnymen and Big Country inverted post-punk’s negation to create a new
column8: more fantastic
column9: and spiritual state of existence. The songs on Racy follow suit and have a synaesthetic effect; they’re widescreen
column10: panoramic
column11: HD—and I can’t remember for the life of me what actually fills out these expanses.

column1: Noel Heroux is a strong vocalist
column2: maintaining his composure when most in this genre are sucking helium. His tousled tone has more in common with a garage rocker and no matter how demure he sounds on any given verse
column3: he hits his choruses with gusto. But he’s not really an expressive vocalist
column4: and all of his words slide right off Racy’s glassy surface
column5: such as when he sings
column6: “As soon as I said it/ Immediately regret it”
column7: without any sense of what he said
column8: why he said it
column9: and why it’s regrettable. “Last
column10: First” channels Joe Jackson’s “Steppin’ Out” in both the concept and the bouncy synth chords
column11: evoking a night on the town as a kind of spiritual purification (“Socialite
column12: for tonight/ You take me out”).  It just turns out to be another muddled rumination on a relationship in flux —“I was acting over the line/ Saying you were mine.” Is it a breakup song? An argument? A tortured confession about unrequited love? Credit can be due for keeping it open-ended
column13: but like so many other moments on Racy
column14:
it feels direct and intentional without revealing the intentions themselves.

Kim Shattuck takes a quick breath at the beginning of the Muffs' first new album in 10 years
column3: then picks up exactly where she and the band left off--snarling
column4: very tunefully
column5: about a boy
column6: verse-chorus-verse
column7: ooh-ooh-ooh
column8: WAAAAUUUGH. That's also exactly where the Muffs began. There is scarcely a more consistent band in all of American pop-punk; singer-guitarist Shattuck and bassist Ronnie Barnett have been Muffs since 1991
column9: and drummer Roy McDonald is the new kid
column10: having joined in 1994. Nothing on Whoop Dee Doo would have been out of place on any of their five earlier records.

column1: And that's saying a lot
column2: actually: they haven't slowed down or softened their attack
column3: or lost their way with tune-construction. Even Shattuck's voice remains barely touched by time. The scratchy sleepless-night tone she used to reserve for her bloodthirsty end-of-verse howls has crept into most of the rest of her singing
column4: although it's not unwelcome. (As for her habit of inserting little glottal stops into syllables that go on for more than one note—""yoo
column5: oo
column6: ou""—that's more of an acquired taste.)

column1: The Muffs apparently never really broke up
column2: although they spent a while out of the public eye; their biggest recent exposure came when Shattuck was Kim Deal's stand-in for the Pixies for six months last year. That role didn't last
column3: but it was an inspired choice on the Pixies' part: the Muffs' instrumental sound had
column4: and still has
column5: more in common with the Pixies than with most of their grunge-era contemporaries. Their songwriting
column6: on the other hand
column7: is very different (they're writing much better songs than the Pixies are these days
column8: too)
column9: and it's very heavily inspired by '60s rock 'n' roll. Specifically
column10: mid-'60s British rock'n'roll. More specifically
column11: the Beatles' Rubber Soul.

column1: Shattuck doesn't often telegraph the resemblance
column2: and the band's growl-and-bash obscures it
column3: but if you're listening for Beatles-of-'65 nods
column4: they're all over Whoop Dee Doo. ""Like You Don't See Me"" might as well be an answer song to ""You Won't See Me""
column5: ""Where Did I Go Wrong"" recasts the unpredictable phrasing and two-step beat of ""I've Just Seen a Face"" as hardcore
column6: and the first song they released from the new record
column7: ""Up and Down Around""
column8: has a vague resemblance to ""Girl"" underscored by deadpan ""dit-dit-dit-dit"" backing vocals. ""Cheezy"" reaches back a little further—it's ""I Should Have Known Better"" (the opening harmonica solo is the tipoff) by way of Nirvana's ""Sappy
column9: and it's got a stinging hook: ""And I really liked you/Till I got to know you.""

column1: That's another big part of the Muffs' charm: Shattuck's perpetual balancing act between romantic vulnerability and indignant fury. ""Take a Take a Me"" sounds like a love song with a beat for frugging
column2: but closer inspection reveals it to be a threat directed toward a rival (""she could never never never take a take a me—WHAAAAAAA!"") The album's catchiest bridge begins ""And I would like to strangle you or punch you in the face"". She reserves her most venomous slapdowns for variations on the ""freaky little adolescent"" she describes in ""Because You're Sad""
column3:
but there's a lot to admire about a 51-year-old rocker's enduring command of her own adolescent freakiness.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20793/homepage_large.07436fe4.jpg|UltraMantis Black|32367.0|UltraMantis Black|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Relapse']|2014-07-28 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:03.318135|"

Violence has been a part of hardcore for as long as hardcore has been around—it’s implicit in the name and the execution. But there’s always been a certain amount of ritual and theater to the violence of hardcore
column2: which is not lost on UltraMantis Black. And how could it be
column3: when the hardcore band’s eponymous frontman is a professional wrestler?

column1: As one of the founding fighters of the independent
column2: Philadelphia-based Chikara wrestling federation
column3: UltraMantis Black—his real name is not public knowledge—has spent the past decade refining his masked identity: an insect-like amalgam of the Japanese superheroes Kamen Rider and
column4: more blatantly
column5: Ultraman. But an ear for music lurks behind that mask. His entrance themes over the years have consisted of Cradle of Filth
column6: Man or Astro-man?
column7: and Japanese proto-metal masters Flower Travellin’ Band. So UltraMantis Black has decent taste—which is also evident in his recruitment of Matt Korvette and Brad Fry of Sub Pop noiseniks Pissed Jeans to record UltraMantis Black
column8: his eight-song hardcore debut.

column1: It’s a violent record. The entire thing weighs in at under 14 minutes
column2: a salvo of short
column3: sharp shocks to the nerve clusters. “Biomonster DNA” writhes like a worm on a hook
column4: as the band jabs blastbeats into muscular breakdowns with indiscriminate bloodlust. Yet it’s also focused
column5: potent
column6: and controlled
column7: the force of a wholesale beating condensed to the flick of a finger. The same goes for “Oil and Gas”
column8: a whiplash windup of tension with no hope of release
column9: and “Stockpiling Graves”
column10: a minefield of disorienting screams and dissonant riffs. UltraMantis Black’s precedents are clear—Agoraphobic Nosebleed’s progressive grind; Das Oath’s screamo antics; the formative metalcore of pre-Jane Doe Converge—but they’re synthesized instinctively and savagely.

column1: The band’s dominant lineage
column2: though
column3: is powerviolence: particularly the mutated strain engineered by the Locust
column4: only minus the sci-fi keyboards and Dadaist song titles. With his bug-eyed mask and wiseass mystique
column5: UltraMantis Black even looks like he could be a long-lost member of that band—and make no mistake
column6: UltraMantis Black has a wiseass streak a mile wide
column7: at least during his day job as a wrestler. His ringside persona is one of an utter asshole: speaking in rarified tones
column8: like a cross between some stereotypical English dandy and Ed Grimley
column9: he plays up his self-styled role as a cult leader and quasi-mythical being. It’s part of his perverse charm
column10: but there’s one thing he’s never less than serious about: veganism. He sips soy chai during interviews and advocates oatmeal and fresh fruit for breakfast
column11: sounding more like a reader of Michael Pollan and Mother Jones than a villainous overlord set on world domination.

column1: When it comes to being the lead singer of UltraMantis Black
column2: he’s similarly serious
column3: and his poker-faced
column4: militant outrage is one of the record's most startling aspects. “Experiment with the delicate nature of nature/ Faulty technology
column5: widespread crop failure
column6: ” he screeches on “Biomonster DNA”
column7: railing against GMOs. Big Pharma gets the boot on “Prescription Culture”: “A prescription for any and all pain/ Best treatment for a billion-dollar cure.” “Oil and Gas” tackles fracking with an almost poignant appeal for preservationism
column8: while “Deepest Ecology” is like being throat-punched with a copy of Silent Spring. It’s classic hardcore righteousness without an ounce of irony
column9: but as with the best politicized hardcore and grind
column10: Ultramantis’ technical
column11: lecture-ready lyrics approach a kind of apocalyptic poetry: “Ecologically regressed to a minimalist existence/ One-sided endosymbiosis
column12: fatal collapse.""

column1: UltraMantis Black may not be a joke
column2: but is he a novelty? He’s backed by two members of Pissed Jeans
column3: after all
column4: an outfit not exactly known for its heartfelt sincerity. Korvette and Fry
column5: to their credit
column6: take a back seat to their leader; while Fry’s haywire guitar in Pissed Jeans sounds almost like its mocking itself
column7: here it’s pounded down into a disciplined
column8: utilitarian barrage. This is not simply sped-up Pissed Jeans with a dude in a mask yelling over the top of it
column9: and the closest UltraMantis Black comes to Pissed Jeans’ grungy nihilism is on the record’s longest track
column10: the three-minute “Gloom of Prosperity”
column11: which alternately plods and thrashes as the singer recites a megaphone-like rant. As gleefully bipolar as it is
column12: there’s no humor in it
column13: gallows or otherwise: “We are told
column14: however
column15: that we have choices/ That we can dream
column16: that we can mold our own future
column17: ” UltraMantis howls into the void of encroaching Armageddon. At heart
column18: though
column19: he seems to be clutching at some twisted
column20: bittersweet hope. This is not the same UltraMantis Black
column21: supercilious and snide
column22: who struts around the lucha libre ring with delusions of cartoon godhood. If ever his fans have been given a peek at the man behind the mask

column1: Oddly enough
column2: UltraMantis sounds at least as seasoned as anyone else in his group. His phrasing is fractured here
column3: blurry there—as much of an exercise in choreographed chaos as any of his signature finishing moves between the turnbuckles. There are hundreds of bands making music like UltraMantis Black
column4: old and new
column5: in existence right now. What sets UltraMantis apart is his embrace of pageantry
column6:
his open admission that catharsis and social consciousness can be stylized as well as served raw. As for the violence: Its just another way to connect.

"|19567.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19567-ultramantis-black-ultramantis-black/|7.4|Jason Heller

East coast rap and Southern rap are often discussed as existing in opposition to each other
column2: but the production on Gene the Southern Child's new album Southern Meridian shows how the two sounds can achieve a ready synthesis. Parallel Thought
column3: a team that includes members from both New Jersey and Alabama
column4: handle the production; Gene
column5: too
column6: is from Alabama
column7: and his rapping on the album is deeply Southern
column8: both in its slow-flow storytelling and the slow revelation of its singularity.

column1: Upon a first listen
column2: Parallel Thought's contributions dominate. Their production incorporates all sorts of beat variations
column3: samples
column4: and rapid-fire scratching while still maintaining a pocket of negative space for Gene to fill. Their thorough
column5: deliberate approach is reminiscent of the production adorning tracks from Southerners like Big K.R.I.T. and G-Side
column6: but the concepts undergirding the samples and scratching and the busyness of the beats here are unmistakably East Coast-derived.

column1: At first
column2: it feels like Southern Meridian succeeds primarily because of the beats. When analyzed on a line-by-line basis
column3: Gene's lyrics aren’t particularly compelling; “Flo-Town”
column4: for example
column5: includes such clichéd statements as “Haters die slow
column6: fuck 5-0"". But the rapper’s uncanny focus and subtle charm is slowly revealed throughout the album. Lyrically
column7: Gene has very little interest in pogoing from topic to topic as so many of his contemporaries do. He's meticulous in his description of scenes and scenarios
column8: and his best songs unfold like Technicolor panoramas. “Ride With the Southern Child” could easily come off as a cursory love song
column9: but even as he rattles off boilerplate club pick-up lines
column10: Gene manages to seem charismatic
column11: and absorbing. “Split Personality” has a lot in common conceptually with Dr. Dre and Eminem’s “Guilty Conscience”
column12: but Gene goes for pathos over comedy and makes the conceit work on his own terms.

column1: Gene also reveals a surprisingly dynamic mix of flows
column2: especially on the bonus track “Sucka Deal”
column3: where he accelerates through his bars and actually manages to make a song about the music industry compelling. (Caness
column4: the Alabaman member of Parallel Thought
column5: is featured rapping on the track
column6: and his verse is a reminder of how boring songs about the business usuually are.)

column1: Both Gene and Caness are from Muscle Shoals
column2: an area of Alabama that has produced an impressively dynamic music scene—artists like G-Side
column3: Block Beattaz and Bentley all hail from the area
column4: which is also home to the rich history of recording studios like FAME and Muscle Shoals Sound. Rap artists from Muscle Shoals have cultivated a deep
column5: easily identifiable sound
column6: but Parallel Thought’s work on Southern Meridian doesn’t quite fit neatly in with the pack. No wonder then
column7: that it's found a home on Adult Swim’s Williams Street Records
column8: which has released music by unlikely partnerships like Danger Mouse and MF Doom and El-P and Killer Mike. Southern Meridian feels like it has more in line with those projects than with much of the Muscle Shoals canon
column9: profiting from a diverse
column10:
accepting collaboration between artists who feed off of each other’s differences.

Few releases have so effectively shrugged at the supposed dichotomy of “alternative” and “traditional” R&B over the past few years than Late Nights with Jeremih
column3: the free mixtape from Jeremih that quietly grew to be a cult favorite after dropping from left field in 2012. And anyway
column4: that binary—which took real shape around 2011
column5: thanks in large part to the clamor around the Weeknd’s landmark debut
column6: House of Balloons—has always been more about the audience than about the artist. There are vague aesthetic similarities among R&B artists pegged as “alternative” (or otherwise)—a focus on vibe over narrative
column7: a tendency to distort vocals to the point of disembodiment—but what it more often designates is a certain seal of approval
column8: a go-ahead for guilt-free consumption by whatever your term of choice may be for those who’ve warmed to R&B in the 2010s but approach the bulk of the genre under the protective cloak of irony.

column1: Late Nights
column2: at once radio-driven and experimental
column3: shared some of those aesthetics but managed to duck that conversation so thoroughly that it made you question if the conversation was worth having to begin with. Its oddness was approachable from all angles
column4: as Jeremih and a league of ambitious producers (Mike WiLL Made It in his absolute prime
column5: pop soothsayer Tricky Stewart
column6: occasionally Jeremih himself) took cues from the sounds of the underground but never quite presented them as “cool.” All this was especially surprising coming from the guy best known for “Birthday Sex”
column7: a doofy novelty hit that’s endured solely because people continue to  have birthdays. But even then
column8: there were glimmers of promise: in a 2009 acoustic performance of the same song
column9: he transformed it into something intimate and feather-light
column10: accompanying himself on piano.

column1: When Jeremih initially linked last year with moody L.A. producer Shlohmo for Yours Truly and Adidas Originals’ Songs From Scratch series
column2: it wasn’t such an improbable pairing: here was a singer willing to go all in with producers’ stranger impulses working with a beatmaker that possesses omnivorous tendencies
column3: whose gooey sad-boy soundscapes draw from ghostly R&B balladry
column4: abstracted hip-hop percussion
column5: and hissy ambience alike. (The first half of last year’s Laid Out EP could
column6: with very slight stretches of the imagination
column7: be considered some warped form of R&B itself.) That collaboration
column8: “Bo Peep (Do U Right)""
column9: was proof enough: gorgeously smoggy
column10: humid
column11: and sort of tragic despite the surface romance
column12: with Jeremih’s weightless falsetto piercing through the groaning bassline
column13: “Wish somebody would’ve seen us
column14: baby.” It was heavier than Jeremih’s usual stuff
column15: but it worked
column16: at least as a one-off. A year later
column17: the duo aim to replicate its magic on No More
column18: their six-track collaboration; but where Jeremih floated on “Bo Peep
column19: ” the majority of the EP falls flat.

column1: Shlohmo’s productions are typically dense and blurry
column2: his bittersweet melodies rendered in smudgy sepia tones and built from intricately arranged layers of what sound like organized anxieties. When there are vocals
column3: they’re often samples; even when they’re not
column4: as with “Don’t Say No”
column5: his lovely 2013 collaboration with How to Dress Well
column6: vocals tend to serve as yet another instrument in the mix
column7: rather than the focal point. Though “Bo Peep” proved an exception
column8: Jeremih’s voice isn’t intended for this sort of environment; there’s a translucency to his falsetto that radiates when given the proper space
column9: but gets bogged down by too much outside noise.

column1: Late Night’s best moments— “773 Love
column2: ” “Fuck U All The Time
column3: ” “Go To The Mo”—shared a certain sense of delicacy
column4: their productions defined primarily by negative space. No More could benefit from some of this airiness; instead
column5: it often feels stifling
column6: Jeremih’s voice mired in the layers of hi-hat twitches and bass grumblings. Title track “No More” burbles and quivers yet doesn’t quite move in any particular direction. “Let It Go” is pretty—it’s certainly the best new song on the project—but ultimately reads as a slightly subpar cousin to “Bo Peep”. And when the duo aim for sparseness
column7: on skeletal closing track “The End
column8: ” they’re left with a handful of parts and not much whole; Jeremih’s a touch off-key and slightly out of time
column9: and a tacked-on appearance from Chance the Rapper is a bizarre choice for a finale
column10: entirely at odds with the warm
column11: woozy sensuality of the preceding tracks.

column1: Most questionable here is the inclusion of Shlohmo’s “Fuck U All the Time” remix
column2: the original version of which he released well before the two ever crossed paths. It’s essentially just an extended version of the original
column3: which boasts an additional Jeremih verse packed with mildly cute
column4: mostly embarrassing lines like
column5: “Don’t let the time ticky-icky-icky while I’m snapping off your bra/ And biting on your Vickies.” Moments like that are forgivable
column6: if a bit dorky (and it’s far from the first remix of the song crammed with superfluous verses)
column7: but it’s harder to understand the impulse to improve upon a song that draws seductiveness from subtlety by piling more stuff on top—that familiar moaning bassline
column8: those little beeps and clatters. It’s that same impulse that characterizes much of the past few years of so-called alt-R&B: pile on the effects
column9: pitch down the voice
column10:
and let 'er rip. That impulse holds No More back from approaching the transcendence of Jeremih and Shlohmo’s first collaboration (or most of Late Nights): too much of the EP feels like a drawn-out remix of a song that didn’t really need it in the first place.

Common exists in sainted territory in hip-hop: the rare rapper who's appeared on ""Oprah""
column4: he's earned a default level of respect and can reliably release major label albums every few years
column5: no matter what the industry climate. For many
column6: Common's latest album
column7: Nobody's Smiling
column8: will hold a polarized position in the midst of Chicago's senseless violence
column9: a symbol of all that is right in a genre too often derided for moral depravity and/or artistic bankruptcy. Others will cynically dismiss this latest effort
column10: as Common hasn't lived in Chicago in years but is releasing a record capitalizing on the city's newly gritty national reputation. But Common's not interested in moralizing
column11: nor trendchasing. Although he writes a familiar snapshot of Chicago
column12: its troubles seem a catalyst for his own creativity. The album's most convincing when tackling the push-and-pull conflict between the individual and his hometown
column13: as Common's good intentions are buoyed by memory
column14: generosity
column15: and attentiveness to his craft.

column1: Looming over the album is the specter of Chicago's gun violence and the music which first brought it to our attention; Common's 2011 album The Dreamer/The Believer was released just weeks before Chief Keef hit the national radar. So Nobody's Smiling displays some idealism-drain
column2: its black and white cover art reflecting a stripped down sound. Common and longtime producer No I.D. aren't interested in competing with the street sounds emanating from his hometown. Instead
column3: they go for a complementary feel
column4: with old head-friendly percussive loops and blaxploitation rhythms (""Blak Majik
column5: ""Speak My Piece
column6: ""Hustle Harder""). Common's delivery has a loose
column7: nimble quality throughout
column8: his words tumbling out with practiced ease. His lyrics are writerly
column9: internal rhymes focused on a history he can recall but which seems distant now: ""Have you ever heard of Black Stone around Black Stones?/ And Four CHs
column10: Vice Lords
column11: Stony Island on Aces/ The concrete matrix
column12: street organizations
column13: they gave violations
column14: hood public relations.""

column1: Common's approach here is to intertwine his own story with his memories of Chicago in order to forge a connection to the next generation. The use of a Biggie sample on ""Speak My Piece"" is emblematic; when Common was an emerging artist
column2: the young Christopher Wallace spoke powerfully to the same state of mind Chicago's street rappers wrestle with today. ""7 Deadly Sins""
column3: a bonus track on Nobody's Smiling
column4: sounds like another way to integrate a mid-'90s street feel
column5: complete with a ""Ten Crack Commandments""-esque concept and Wu-Tang-recalling beat. Throughout
column6: Common attempts to speak to everyone
column7: offering bits of wisdom for a new generation while contextualizing for an older
column8: outside audience.

column1: This attempt at generational continuity also explains why Common grants a platform for a phalanx of strong guest stars to shine. Opener ""The Neighborhood"" features Lil Herb
column2: a young street rapper whose memories of his era are more freshly etched in each bar: ""Used to post up on that strip
column3: I look like a street sign/ I been out there three days and I got shot at three times."" Meanwhile
column4: West Side rapper Dreezy's verse on ""Hustle Harder"" argues convincingly that she might be the best bar-for-bar rapper in Chicago right now: ""I could be a lady in the streets
column5: but in the booth I pull triggers/ Shots fired
column6: I go harder than a nigga.""

column1: Other guest artists
column2: like Def Jam signees Vince Staples and Big Sean
column3: acquit themselves well
column4: providing different points of view on the record's central conflict. Big Sean tones down the usual hamminess
column5: perhaps due to the severity of the subject matter
column6: and catches a slick behind-the-beat flow. But Staples stands out particularly: ""Lean and took a puff and then she gave it to my father/ Used to take the bullets out so I could play with the revolver/ Satan serenading ever since I was a toddler."" But it's poet Malik Yusef who nearly steals the show
column7: appearing at the end of the album's title track and spitting an evocative piece that captures the album's real central paradoxes: ""Now I see how my daddy felt the dark day he discovered that black power didn't keep the lights on."" ""They drilling on my land but ain't no oil to be found / I might be part of the problem."" He hits especially hard while engaging with wordplay in the differences between ""shy"" and ""Chi"": ""Are these celebrities way too shy to be loyal to the town?""

column1: The album's closer
column2: ""Rewind That""
column3: is one of Common's most personal records in quite some time
column4: reflecting on the ups and downs of his relationship with No I.D. and meditating on the loss of J Dilla. He  addresses his own conflicted decision to leave the city and people that so greatly shaped some of his best music. Truth is complex
column5: and the popular manichean tensions don't map out so predictably atop ""conscious"" and ""gangster"". That's true for street rappers themselves
column6: who have to navigate an ever-increasing divide between their lives and those of the communities who propelled them to fame. And it's true for Common
column7: too
column8: who had to leave his home to continue his career
column9:
and for whom—nearly two decades later—finds that the decision still weighs upon him. Nobody's Smiling is driven by the search for this common denominator.

In Ambrose Bierce’s 1890 short story “An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge”
column3: a would-be Civil War saboteur named Peyton Farquhar is caught and sentenced to hang. During his execution
column4: his perception of time
column5: memory
column6: and physical reality begins to warp. He vividly hallucinates
column7: and ultimately he dies
column8: but not before experiencing one last bittersweet spasm of happiness and hope. On The Black Angels’ latest EP
column9: Clear Lake Forest
column10: there’s a song called “An Occurrence at 4507 South Third Street”—and the resemblance to the Bierce story can’t be an accident. It drifts in a kind of murky
column11: death-steeped dreaminess
column12: and then there’s the sick gallows joke at the heart of the song’s chorus: “You keep me hanging on.”

column1: The Black Angels’ fourth and most recent full-length
column2: 2013’s Indigo Meadow
column3: suffered from a lack of that murky
column4: dreamy atmosphere. It was so hi-fi that it hurt
column5: with no room left for the listener to meet the material halfway—which is part of the function and the fascination of psychedelic music. Psychedelia can be vivid
column6: but it shouldn’t be HD
column7: and the Austin band has corrected that mistake on Clear Lake Forest. Like “Owl Creek Bridge”
column8: there’s ambiguity and space for interpretation
column9: both sonically and lyrically. “An Occurrence at 4507 South Third Street” jerks and pounds on a sinister organ riff
column10: churning up the rotted flotsam of the '60s that Boomers seem happy to forget. “Tired Eyes” and “Sunday Evening” are two of the flat-out catchiest
column11: most dynamic songs the group has ever recorded
column12: with frontman Alex Maas’ trippy croon finding new ways to thread their way through some truly inspired pastiches of Summer-of-Love jangle and echo.

column1: That inspiration hasn’t felt so strong since The Black Angels’ 2006 debut
column2: Passover. But that was eight years ago
column3: when they were more locked into a holding pattern of overdriven drones. There’s far more range here
column4: but Clear Lake Forest’s influences tend to feel more like Easter eggs than stepping stones. “Sunday Evening” is a blob of psyche-pop bubblegum that’s as sweet as (but also more sour than) the Lemon Pipers; “Diamond Eyes” summons Tommy James-level tremolo and reverb
column5: even as it lets the oscillations fall in and out of synch with the beat in a bleary smear of rhythmic phasing. As psychedelic influences go
column6: these are not deep
column7: and so “An Occurrence at 4507 South Third Street” invokes the smoky menace of Brecht/Weill’s “Alabama Song” through the middleman of The Doors’ cover
column8: which is almost shamefully mimicked.

column1: The mishandling of influences has long been a problem of the Black Angels
column2: although it’s also been part of the thrill of seeing them evolve. At the least
column3: they’ve always been open about paying homage to their heroes
column4: right down to the group’s Velvet Underground-referencing name. But on one of Clear Lake Forest’s worst tracks
column5: “Linda’s Gone”
column6: that worship once again crosses over into near parody; the song’s taut
column7: stuttering lead guitar is a far too on-the-nose reference to VU’s “Run Run Run”
column8: it manages to sound reverent and cavalier at the same time
column9: and not in a good way.

column1: The EP’s other low point
column2: “The Executioner”
column3: is a soggy wad of weak blotter acid that serves only one real purpose: It links to the lyrics of “An Occurrence at 4507 South Third Street”
column4: right down to the line “A rope for your sins”
column5: reinforcing the loose concept winding through the record. The Black Angels deserve credit for attempting what is
column6: in essence
column7: a mini-concept album rendered in subtle
column8: muted shades. It’s a lot to tackle in seven songs
column9: but there’s a depth and richness in both texture and songwriting that show glimpses of a new direction
column10:
one that might free them from their own drone-rock noose.

column3: DJs have approached crossing over into the rock world like a military operation
column4: loading up on firepower—i.e.
column5: <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bunkka"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">random
column6: WTF celebrity guests—for maximal in-the-red impact. It’s a strategy with which Adam Freeland is well familiar. While the veteran British beatmaker’s fondness for boisterous breaks always aligned him spiritually with arena-rattling rock—as manifest in his white-label remixes of the White Stripes’ “Seven Nation Army” and Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit”—over the past decade
column7: that influence has become evermore explicit. After kicking off his 2005 Back to Mine comp with a Trail of Dead track
column8: Freeland went all-out for his 2009 artist album
column9: Cope
column10: enlisting a veritable VH1 special of notorious noisemakers
column11: including Tommy Lee
column12: Marilyn Manson’s Twiggy Ramirez
column13: Brody Dalle
column14: the Pixies’ Joey Santiago
column15: and Devo’s Jerry Casale. However
column16: rather than join the likes of LCD Soundsystem and Justice in the indie-disco champagne room
column17: Cope became something of an instant anachronism

column1: Perhaps the cool reception to Cope has inspired Freeland to plot his current crossover move from an entirely different direction
column2: concealing his identity within a collaborative project and deploying a sound that doesn’t so much thunderously rain down from above as seep up from the sewers. The Acid is a three-way union between Freeland
column3: L.A. producer (and certified Ableton Live instructor) Steve Nalepa
column4: and Ry Cuming
column5: a.k.a. RY X
column6: an Australian singer/songwriter (and one-time Sara Bareilles collaborator) in the moodily romantic Jeff Buckley/young Thom Yorke mold who scored a minor chart hit last year in Europe with the haunting ballad “Berlin.” (The D’Angelo-esque NSFW video probably helped.) As legend has it
column7: the trio met a house party in Los Angeles last year
column8: but the music they create together is better suited to the completely opposite scenario: insomnia-riddled nights spent tossing and turning in a windowless flat
column9: with nothing to amuse yourself with but your most depraved fantasies and deepest regrets.

column1: If Freeland’s Cope synthesized and streamlined the various strains of mid-2000s dancefloor-directed indie
column2: The Acid’s debut full-length
column3: Liminal
column4: does the same for post-dubstep British rock: Portishead’s Third
column5: the xx
column6: The King of Limbs
column7: James Blake. This Acid bears no hallucinogenic qualities
column8: but rather slow-burn
column9: corroding effects: songs that begin with a drip—snare-rim taps
column10: synthetic handclaps
column11: bass frequencies that throb like a merciless migraine—and eventually leave burn marks. But where the Acid’s immediate antecedents were attempting to push their songwriting to minimalist
column12: brutalist extremes
column13: Liminal is something of a recoil move back toward the realm of pop accessibility
column14: an effort to extract warm blood from cold concrete and offset the bleak with some sleek. (Or
column15: put another way
column16: it’s a savvy reconstruction of sullen source material into potential sync-license gold.)

column1: Liminal may be unforgivingly austere in presentation
column2: but it’s not without a desire to uplift—while Cuming doesn’t so much sing these 11 tracks as tremble through them
column3: his bruised croon and spectral harmonies at least serve as flashlight-sized beacons to guide you through the album’s shadowy
column4: greyscale terrain. The first words we hear him sing on Liminal are “I need your love”
column5: and the songs that follow catalogue his various ploys to get it
column6: from restraining-order-worthy lechery (the “Machine Gun”-loaded “Creeper”) to egomaniacal posturing (“Fame”—not a Bowie cover
column7: but a similarly sardonic comment on starfuckery) to gentle reconciliation (the acoustic reprieve “Ra”). His is a deft highwire dance between serving as album’s emotional center and dissolving into a textural detail; by the end of the penultimate “Clean”
column8: Cuming’s titular incantation has become the song’s click track.

column1: But while Liminal is a testament to the Acid’s breadth of vision and production prowess—seamlessly incorporating everything from subterranean techno and avant-R&B to proggy sci-fi soundscapes and sad-bastard bedroom folk—its uniformly predictable pacing
column2: with every song painstakingly built up from a pause to a pulse
column3: grows wearing over a 51-minute stretch. Curiously
column4: Liminal’s release was previewed by its most atypically lucid
column5: palpably angst-ridden track
column6: “Basic Instinct”
column7: whose raw
column8: distorted-guitar-driven climax is seemingly at odds with the meticulous mise-en-scenery in effect everywhere else on this record. But its late appearance here proves strategic: when
column9: on the chorus
column10: Cuming declares he’s “coming up for air
column11:
” it’s a welcome relief for our lungs as much as his.

When Dylan Carlson’s electric guitar swells from silence to an acute roar at the start of “Gold XIII”
column2: from his third full-length in three years under the solo guise of Drcarlsonalbion
column3: the sound induces a sudden shiver
column4: as though a closed window has been unintentionally sprung during the middle of a fierce winter gale. It’s a harrowing tone
column5: a somehow glowing rush of cold that Carlson lets linger. He eventually flicks a few isolated notes over the lonesome drone
column6: letting them fade into the backdrop like ghosts vanishing against the night. When the 30-second instrumental goes almost quiet
column7: Carlson strums a few quick
column8: bright chords
column9: like he’s willed the sun to rise again. It’s a moment of hope that borders on optimistic
column10: but it barely lasts 10 seconds before Carlson shifts to the snarling
column11: aching blues figure of “Gold XIV”.

column1: That’s the general temperament of Gold
column2: which comprises 24 instrumental vignettes that originally served as the score for a 2013 film that chronicled the ruinous journey of seven German immigrants into the northwest during the Klondike Gold Rush at the tail of the 19th century. It’s often been suggested that Carlson’s despondent instrumentals with Earth—both the monolithic early iteration that established drone metal as a genre and the latter-day take known for its blues-crawl refinement—would serve as suitable soundtracks for film renditions of Cormac McCarthy’s books. The westward Klondike trek killed thousands
column3: subjecting the naïve to the abject nature of untamed wilderness and lawless humanity
column4: so Gold is a litany of awful events
column5: where hardscrabble characters endure painful deaths and existential crises
column6: abject loneliness and corrupted dreams. It is
column7: at least
column8: in the McCarthy milieu
column9: finally offering an appropriate cinematic environment for the slow sweep of Carlson’s guitar.

column1: In the movie itself
column2: Carlson’s miniature instrumentals serve mostly as frames
column3: musical borders that guide transitions between scenes and help reinforce moods. But you can trace the same worry
column4: regret
column5: uncertainty and foolhardy aspiration that define the movie through the pieces
column6: too. Together
column7: “Gold III” and “Gold IV” form a brief miasma of self-defeat
column8: each note that Carlson elicits suddenly swallowed by the noisy roar of his amplifier; every picked string is the start of a trip that stands no chance of success.

column1: “Gold XIX
column2: ” one of the longer numbers here
column3: staggers along the edge of a slow
column4: angled melody
column5: a precipice rising above a dangerous descent. By track’s end
column6: though
column7: Carlson can barely move through the riff
column8: his motion beset by whorls of noise and the rising wash of Davies’ cymbals. It’s the sound of trouble morphing into terror. The sparkling
column9: if sullen
column10: theme of “Gold XXIII” renders halcyon moments of deliverance. Whether through the release of death or the relief of a stream and clean water
column11: the at-risk adventurers seem to find some relief
column12: maybe even a mirage of it. Carlson lets the end of each phrase float skyward
column13: ascending toward anything else
column14: anywhere but here.

column1: The music on Gold isn’t difficult. The riffs are simple patterns that most anyone with a guitar and a sense of scales could soon pick out. They’re largely unadorned
column2: too
column3: accompanied only by splashes of cymbals and
column4: once
column5: a bass drum from Earth drummer and Carlson savior Adrienne Davies. That might make Gold a hard sell for many. Both the rhythmic grace of recent Earth and the overwhelming volume of early Earth—the band’s central assets for many—are all but absent. But the twist
column6: and the real feat of Gold
column7: comes instead in the guitarist’s simultaneous control and exploration. These are mostly solitary conversations between Carlson
column8: his instrument
column9: his amplifier
column10: and a few effects pedals. Sometimes
column11: it seems
column12: he’s playing pieces of riffs only to hear what they sound like when they decay; at other times
column13: he repeats fragments of melodies in a process of accretion
column14: their repetition building until he can coax feedback from a gently picked purr.

column1: To that end
column2: Gold suggests a crossroads of the dual versions of Earth
column3: where the deliberate melancholy of the latter fuels the amplifier worship of the former
column4: albeit in a much more restrained and reserved space. In their own modest way
column5: these 24 pieces suggest systems music
column6: where the configuration of the guitarist in a room with his guitar and its accessories is more important than the input of what he actually plays. It’s a system with a predisposition for the forlorn
column7:
a ghost in the machine that allows these snippets to work onscreen and off.

The term “country” was first applied to music in the 1940s as a substitute for the pejorative label “hillbilly
column2: ” and it has since been used to describe everything from the Carter Family’s mountain hymnal to Florida Georgia Line’s hip-hop-inflected radio hits. “Funk” has a similarly long history in pop music—a piece of Jazz Age slang that would eventually describe Parliament/Funkadelic’s mothership jams
column3: Death Grips’ industrial beats
column4: and nearly everything in between. Even among broad genre tags
column5: both “country” and “funk” are incredibly elastic terms. Put them together and somehow they stretch even further. Never a set scene and not quite a movement
column6: country funk was just something in the air during the late '60s and early '70s
column7: when the give and take between what is generally considered “white” music and what is generally deemed “black” music was at its most open and open-minded.

column1: That unlikely marriage inspired Light in the Attic’s first Country Funk collection in 2012
column2: which sounded revelatory because it reveled in the slippery quality of its own premise. In 16 songs
column3: the comp showed how artists from different locations
column4: backgrounds
column5: and genres combined these two seemingly disparate traditions in new and often surprising ways
column6: as though there were infinite variations of country funk. So it’s startling—and even a bit dismaying—that the label’s second volume stretches those two terms until they almost snap. Most everything on Country Funk Vol. 2 is self-evidently funky
column7: although a few songs sound more like country tunes with a prominent drum track. When it’s Jackie DeShannon butchering “The Weight”
column8: it’s a problem. But when Dillard & Clark covers the Beatles’ “Don’t Let Me Down” or JJ Cale waxes romantic about the “Cajun Moon”
column9: who’s complaining about semantics?

column1: If Vol. 1 was about mapping the country funk trend via trucker GPS to show how widespread these sounds were
column2: Vol. 2 is more about showing just how high up the ladder these ideas went. The new tracklist is peppered with familiar names
column3: like Townes Van Zandt and Kenny Rogers. Dolly Parton’s “Getting Happy” boasts a ridiculously effervescent chorus and a runaway snare drum that flirts with country disco
column4: and she sells the tune by virtue of her light vocal touch. When she recorded it in 1974
column5: Parton had recently ended her long partnership with Porter Wagoner and had barely established herself as a solo artist. Released the same year as “Jolene” and “I Will Always Love You”
column6: “Getting Happy” reveals just how musically omnivorous Parton was at this point in her career.

column1: At times Vol. 2 is driven as much by its performers’ personalities as by the songs’ syncopated backbeats. Just a few years before Red-Headed Stranger and Wanted! The Outlaws made him the most popular man in country music
column2: Willie Nelson was still tinkering with his redneck-hippie sound on “Shotgun Willie”
column3: the title track to his 1973 album. It’s a trip hearing Nelson in this setting: As the rhythm section struts and the Memphis Horns punctuate the groove
column4: his nylon-string guitar zigs and zags effortlessly around the beat
column5: as though taunting his band. In his signature stoned cadence
column6: Nelson sings about the misperceptions of country life
column7: and you can hear both the mischievous humor and cold derision in his voice when he gets to the verse about the KKK wizard selling sheets on the family plan.

column1: Funk
column2: it turns out
column3: was a way to loosen country up a bit
column4: to move it away from its stodgy conservatism. “Shotgun Willie” is only one of several songs on Vol. 2 that confronts and sometimes satirizes the cultural divide between the establishment and the counterculture. Bob Darin’s “Me and Mr. Hohner” describes a hippie’s run-in with cops in South Philly
column5: and the relentless harmonica stomps evokes the danger of the situation. (He’s the unlikely hero of both volumes
column6: and hopefully it’s only a matter of time before Light in the Attic reissues his 1969 album Commitment.)

column1: Kenny Rogers’ encounter with the law is much less fraught on the First Edition’s “Tulsa Turnaround”
column2: which may be the highlight of Vol. 2. Opening with the narrator on the run after getting the mayor’s daughter stoned
column3: the song was widely covered in the early '70s
column4: with recordings by Three Dog Night
column5: Goose Creek Symphony
column6: and weirdly enough Helen “I Am Woman Hear Me Roar” Reddy. But this may be the ultimate version of the song
column7: thanks to the rhythm section’s narcotized groove and the gritty chagrin in Rogers’ voice as he dispenses outlaw wisdom: “If a man’s gonna eat fried chicken
column8: he’s gotta get greasy.”

column1: Vol. 2 may lack the sense of purpose and discovery that defined Vol. 1
column2: which remains one of the best reissue comps of the 2010s. But credit Light in the Attic for digging deep
column3: for avoiding the obvious
column4: and for rescuing obscurities like Jim Ford’s bizarre b-side “Rising Sign” and Willis Alan Ramsey’s “Northeast Texas Women”
column5: a wry dose of back-porch funk that closes the album. Similar series
column6: including Country Got Soul and Dirty Laundry: The Soul of Black Country
column7: stopped after just two volumes
column8:
but the label’s adventurous approach may give Country Funk a much longer life. Vol. 2 proves there’s more than enough country funk out there to fill a good Vol. 3.

Ed Russell's singles as Tessela have been described variously as jungle
column2: hardcore
column3: drum & bass
column4: rave
column5: and just about every other style of English dance music developed around the time Russell was born. Last year's crown jewel was something called ""Hackney Parrot""
column6: which pushed the unstable syncopations of breakbeat to such cartoonish extremes that the track seemed to barely touch the ground

column1: Regardless of how you classify it
column2: his music is hard and appears to be getting harder. Rough 2
column3: his third single for Belgium's R&S label in the past year
column4: is a smartly titled piece of work
column5: suggesting not only a texture but a state of indeterminate completion
column6: differentiated only by a number. Most of the sounds on it seem borderline-broken
column7: either from bad maintenance or general overuse. But if the palette is industrial
column8: the decay is reassuringly human. By the end of Rough's three tracks—which arc from funky and coherent to forbiddingly abstract—I feel the same mild
column9: anthropomorphizing pity I feel for a boombox running low on batteries. It's machine music
column10: minus the implied invincibility.

column1: Nothing here is as immediate or durable as ""Hackney Parrot"" but nothing is as conservative either. If Russell doesn't seem as fully formed as period-piece masters like Special Request (who remixed ""Hackney"" last year) it's because his music isn't as narrowly defined. Consistency comes at sake of experiment
column2: brand identity at the sake of progress
column3: et cetera. What Rough does demonstrate is range and willingness to take chances. Like Blawan

column5: Russell is working in multiple directions
column6: a polyglot and a dabbler
column7:
more interesting when taken as a whole than piece by piece.  I'll be curious to hear Rough 3.

For The Recently Found Innocent is the fifth album by White Fence
column2: the stage name of Los Angeles-based psych-rocker Tim Presley. Presley is a highly prolific songwriter who compulsively writes and records skewed tunes to a four-track tape recorder in his bedroom. This budget conscious home studio setup has given his music—most of which has been released via the labels Woodsist and Castle Face—a distinctly wobbly and elastic sound. Midway through
column3: a song might slip suddenly into an entirely different set of chord changes
column4: as if Presley had simply stopped and pressed record again on another idea. Sometimes a track will lurch forward or backward in tempo as a result of a bump or tweak to the recorder’s pitch knob; the drums are usually little more than single-bar breaks snipped out of other rock songs and haphazardly strung together into off-kilter loops.

column1: But by the time of 2013’s Cyclops Reap
column2: Presley had gotten handy with that tape machine
column3: and the strange transitions and shaky rhythm tracks started to seem like a natural and indispensable part of White Fence’s headspace. For The Recently Found Innocent
column4: Presley’s debut for Drag City
column5: is the first White Fence LP to be recorded outside the confines of his home—but it’s not as if he’s moved into Muscle Shoals. The recording quality a modest step up at best
column6: with Presley swapping out four-tracks for eight and his bedroom for Ty Segall’s garage. It’s a change in pace
column7: but not necessarily a nudge out of White Fence’s comfort zone. Segall and Presley collaborated together on 2012’s excellent split LP
column8: Hair
column9: and they have similar sensibilities when it comes to guitar solo
column10: fuzz pedals
column11: and out-there production tricks.

column1: As a result
column2: some of the wonky studio artifacts from Presley’s bedroom days have mostly been preserved
column3: which is a good thing. Though Presley’s music takes melodic inspiration from ’60s psychedelic pop—both British weirdos like Syd Barrett
column4: and West Coast folk-rockers like Buffalo Springfield—it’s rare that his songs cop their druggy feel from fuzz pedals or delays. Instead
column5: weird tape tricks and glitches do the work by skewing the listener’s perception of time.

column1: Presley is also a better lyricist than your average Nuggets devotée. He has a talent for making surreal psychobabble sound musical
column2: and for implying a sense of narrative in verses that aren’t immediately understandable. But there's often a clear intent in the songs that's enhanced by the gonzo wordplay. On “Like That""
column3: Presley half-jokingly pines for lifestyle upgrades that prove to be out of reach on an underground rock salary—silver gates
column4: disposable income
column5: less attention from police. ""Clean and sharp and always laughing/... Police see us but don't see us
column6: ” he sings. “I want to live like that.”

column1: Last year
column2: Castle Face released a live White Fence record that was recorded with a full backing band
column3: a tight and energetic reading of songs from Presley’s back catalog that stretched all the way back to his self-titled debut. For the first time
column4: you could hear White Fence outside the context of Presley’s four-track
column5: and it sounded pretty huge; even his grimiest tracks came alive in a way that the tapes didn't always suggest. It wasn’t unreasonable to hope for something along those lines from Presley’s first non-bedroom LP
column6: but in comparison
column7: To The Recently Found Innocent is fairly subdued. It's a record shot through with feelings of anxiety and anger seemingly related to money
column8: art
column9: and other artists. Presley's finally made a step into the outside world
column10:
but it hasn't made him particularly comfortable.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20820/homepage_large.2e5da275.jpg|Melted Toys|32381.0|Melted Toys|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Underwater Peoples']|2014-07-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:09.737579|"

San Francisco quartet Melted Toys make dream-pop for the waking life. Drawing upon 1980s jangle-drone touchstones from Flying Nun to 4AD (and contemporary variations thereof)
column2: their songs are made of radiant colours
column3: clean contours
column4: and propulsive rhythms—but behind the immaculate exterior lies an unshakeable mental fogginess. The band’s self-titled full-length debut feels not unlike embarking on a morning rush-hour commute on just three hours sleep—a sense of feeling simultaneously present and absent. However
column5: in this case
column6: there’s no readily available grande Americano to shake you out of your somnambulant state.

column1: It’s somewhat ironic that Melted Toys have found their most visible champion in fellow San Franciscan Christopher Owens
column2: who invited the group to open dates on his Lysandre tour last year. Where Owens has established himself as the most guileless songwriter in America
column3: Melted Toys mouthpiece Steven Harkins seems almost aggressively vague—and it’s not like the band's sound is so dense as to overpower him. While dream-pop is traditionally reliant on texture and haze
column4: Harkins isn’t getting drowned out by noise; it's more like his mic has been dipped in a vat of Vaseline.<span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> In lieu of decipherable lyrics
column5: he’s content to let the mere tone of his voice and the band’s expressive
column6: often gorgeous guitar interplay do most of the communicating for him. (Or
column7: failing that
column8: they’ll just give the songs titles like “Bummed Out.”)

column1: It wasn’t always this way: Melted Toys’ seven-song 2011 EP
column2: Washed & Dried
column3: may have possessed a primitive
column4: demo-like quality and murkier post-punk aesthetic
column5: but Harkins' words were
column6: for the most part
column7: easy enough to parse
column8: and even introduced an element of playfulness to a normally dour subgenre. And yet the album’s most fully realized track
column9: the Chills-esque “Come On”
column10: was also its most emotionally ambiguous
column11: with Harkins introducing the distant but affective vocal style that’s been promoted to the defining feature of the band’s debut. “Come On” has been re-recorded here
column12: yet we’re no closer to unlocking the song’s secrets; it remains a silhouette
column13: albeit rendered by a brighter
column14: more powerful backlight. In contrast to Washed & Dried
column15: this self-titled release (written following a sojourn to Japan and Taiwan) is more a case of Dried & Washed—Harkins is colouring between more clearly defined lines
column16: but still using blobs and smears.

column1: As per the standard set by “Come On
column2: ” it’s an approach that works best when the band tap into their latent sense of urgency (like on the early-R.E.M. drive of “Horizons
column3: ” or the “Ping Pong”-ed pop of “Always”)
column4: with the blurred vocals effectively serving as the vapor-trail exhaust to the band’s accelerated motion. But it can prove frustrating when the band slow down and stretch out: “A Postcard” boasts the album’s most beguiling groove
column5: setting a shuffling funk to dew-soaked fretboard fills straight out of Mac DeMarco’s tiki-lounge beer cooler
column6: but even in these more comfortably intimate surroundings
column7: Harkins remains evasive. And when the emotional temperature turns more temperate (as it does on the album’s second half)
column8: the songs are simply left to coast on pretty guitar lines
column9: shimmering synths
column10: and breezy backbeats
column11: perilously toeing the line between bliss and blasé. Like their namesake
column12:
Melted Toys’ willfully warped nature can get in the way of their utility.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20831/homepage_large.f1965946.jpg|Orange Co. Serenade|30783.0|Daniel Bachman|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bathetic']|2014-07-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:10.316598|"

Over the last four years
column2: Virginian guitarist Daniel Bachman has lazily meandered through the outer realms of American music. Cribbing the best bits from a long line of outré acoustic guitarists
column3: Bachman's taken an academic approach to the wide-ranging styles once herded under the umbrella of ""American Primitivism
column4: and on his newest LP
column5: Orange Co. Serenade
column6: he sculpts his work into a comprehensive thesis.

column1: Where Bachman once made stylistic leaps in between songs
column2: he now ambles effortlessly. Opener ""Blue Mass"" leans on a lurching drone to underpin its melodic play
column3: which couldn't be farther from the nimble-fingered twang of ""Pig Iron"" that shows up just two tracks later. Bachman has gotten better at using these interstitial moments to stitch together his disparate interests.

column1: Despite the fact that the seams show less frequently
column2: Bachman nonetheless retains his adventurous approach to the acoustic guitar. Whether relying on subtle slide flourishes
column3: as on ""Little Lady Blues""
column4: or on the slippery
column5: barely-there melodic leads that mark ""Up and Down the C & O""
column6: he uses the familiar language of American folk music to conjure a quietude that's unique to his particular brand of guitar work. Even the tracks with more locomotive fingerpicking
column7: like ""Pig Iron"" or the dreary ""And Now I Am Born to Die""
column8: use minimal melodic movement as a way of eliciting stillness from that apparent motion.

column1: Though the record is largely uniform in its instrumentation
column2: Bachman still leaves plenty of room to ramble. Unlike William Tyler or Steve Gunn's interpolations of pop structures into instrumental guitar music
column3: Bachman largely leaves his melodic lines open ended. Even the title track
column4: the only track on the record that comes close to possessing a proper refrain
column5: swells to the fullest expanses of its three-and-a-half minute runtime while exploring variations on its loping theme
column6: until Bachman wipes it away with smears of slide work.

column1: On Orange Co. Serenade
column2: Bachman delves into the joyous (""Little Lady Blues"") and the desolate (""We Would Be Building"") with the same amount of gleeful fascination. The album underscores all the little emotional breakthroughs that Bachman has made over his career thus far
column3:
but it also serves as a reminder that he's more interested in the act of discovering rather than the discoveries themselves.

"|19605.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19605-daniel-bachman-orange-co-serenade/|6.8|Colin Joyce

Part of retro culture's weird sorcery is that most of it doesn’t even recapture an old moment
column3: but constructs a new one that summarizes how we imagine the old one went. Take La Roux
column4: a Grammy-winning synth-pop project whose music scans as ""'80s"" despite having no perfect corollary in the 1980s. It is crisp and modern
column5: but cheerful
column6: too
column7: like a Patrick Nagel in Hockney color
column8: or the diminuitive little ""i"" in Apple products—the machine that wants you to take it home and make it your pal. Someone could use it to sell things
column9: and they have.

column1: Their first album
column2: La Roux
column3: was an instant success
column4: debuting at No. 2 in their native England
column5: inspiring remixes by Skrillex and guest spots by Kanye West
column6: and opening the door for an inevitable marathon of TV and festival appearances. They were a duo then
column7: singer/songwriter Elly Jackson and producer Ben Langmaid; she a walking magazine cover with hair like an ice-cream cone and he an older guy so disinterested in keeping public face that he let Jackson tour alone. After four years of rumors and false starts
column8: Jackson announced that Langmaid had left.

column1: Langmaid or not
column2: La Roux still sound like La Roux: slick
column3: bright
column4: and instantly familiar. The music on Trouble in Paradise breathes more than it did on their debut
column5: with slower tempos and less of an emphasis on the vacuum-sealed sound of electronics—a reminder that funk was made by people before they had the machines to make it for them. Jackson has loosened up a little too. No longer the irritable pixie routine of ""Bulletproof""
column6: her delivery has become both sultry and anxious
column7: stiffening up in the middle of lines about sexual curiosity before shivering away into vibrato. That modernist tower of hair has turned into a suggestive swoop.

column1: Sex
column2: generally
column3: becomes a stand-in for everything that gives Jackson the willies
column4: whether excitement or insecurity or some intoxicating mix of the two. ""Oh you make me happy in my everyday life/ Why must you keep me in your prison at night?"" she sings on ""Cruel Sexuality""
column5: a suggestion of the gap between companionate love and something a little less sanitary. On the other hand
column6: I don't know what to make of ""He never answers the phone/ Oh I'll bet money money money/ I'll bet/ He's at the sexotheque
column7: other than to say that ""sexotheque"" sounds like a word made up by someone who has heard of sex but doesn't yet know how it works.

column1: The familiarity of Jackson's sound is a virtue and a liability. Listening to Paradise for the first time
column2: I kept feeling like I'd already heard it
column3: only to realize I was mistaking each song for the one before it. Other times I stopped halfway through because I wanted something the music couldn't give me: surprise. Then again
column4: the music probably isn't built for surprise. For all Jackson's personal struggle and exploration
column5: Paradise feels like a safe record
column6: calibrated for the comfort of an imagined audience
column7:
working at its best when it becomes almost invisible—the accessory to the experience and not the experience itself. 

"|19665.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19665-la-roux-trouble-in-paradise/|6.5|Mike Powell
