Short bursts of anger snap into place in the dimly lit songs of the Amazing Snakeheads
column2: a Glasgow band enamored with the well-worn fusion of punk and classic rock'n'roll. If punk represented a new year zero for rock to some
column3: for others it carried all the hallmarks of a past worth digging up and fusing with its abrasive form. This is the punk that takes Jerry Lee Lewis as its starting point instead of
column4: say
column5: the Stooges or Suicide. It’s unashamedly backwards-looking
column6: caught somewhere between the precipice gazing of Nick Cave in his Birthday Party days and the plastic Elvis front Jon Spencer took in the Blues Explosion. It wouldn’t work without the robust commitment of singer Dale Barclay
column7: who’s spitting and cursing one minute (“I’m a Vampire”) then lost at the end of his tether over a woman the next (“Heading for Heartbreak”). The whiff of pomade may be palpable
column8: but so is the air of commitment.

column1: There are two distinct parts to Amphetamine Ballads
column2: the four-piece band’s debut album for indie behemoths Domino. The first half is full of Barclay falling to the floor
column3: lying prostrate
column4: kicking against everything around him. By the album’s close
column5: with an actual ballad titled “Tiger By the Tail”
column6: there’s tasteful Spanish guitar and a deep air of surrender. Watching Barclay get there is this album’s greatest asset
column7: setting an overall narrative to a series of songs that would otherwise be struggling for air amid the morass of greasy material by countless other bands in this vein. “Nighttime” is typical of the band’s vigor
column8: with vicious slide guitar riffs overlapping pounding drums and the odd lyrical clunker (“I’m a soul sucker
column9: I’m here to suck your soul”). Barclay’s not the strongest writer
column10: but he overcomes it by throwing everything of himself into the music—on “Swamp Song” he dispenses with words altogether and simply screams
column11: David Yow-style.

column1: Cave’s Birthday Party era is going to be a constant comparison point for the Amazing Snakeheads
column2: but most of the time they appear to be working through various descendents of Cave’s style. “Heading for Heartbreak” works along the same lines as Gallon Drunk’s distinctly North London take on Cave’s blues
column3: recalling their standout track “You Should Be Ashamed”. Elsewhere
column4: the band works in a bubblegum edge on “Here It Comes Again”
column5: mirroring the pop-garage approach of the earliest White Stripes material
column6: while “Flatlining” hurtles toward the MC5 with Barclay at his authoritarian best as he rips shreds out of his vocal cords. The join between the different sides of the band isn't easily glued together—when they stretch out into the seven-minute “Every Guy Wants to Be Her Baby” it feels like momentum gained has suddenly been lost
column7: especially as nothing strong enough happens to sustain its runtime.

column1: If the Amazing Snakeheads sound like a drunk stumbling around looking for the next bar at the close of this album
column2: it’s at least an appropriate way for them to operate. This is music cast in the after hours world inhabited by the characters of Tom DiCillo’s Johnny Suede or Jim Jarmusch’s group of Memphis drunks from Mystery Train
column3: if not quite (yet) breathing the same air of total fatalism as Nicholas Ray’s They Live By Night. Amphetamine Ballads doesn’t come bearing a fully formed vision of a band
column4: carving out insight with switchblades right from the start. At its worst
column5: you can at least hear where Barclay is yearning to get to—that transient place where acrimony collides into reflection then rebounds back again. There are a handful of moments here when he turns himself inside-out over the course of a song
column6:
bringing him into the orbit of those artists he so obviously idolizes. Now he just needs to figure out how to emulate his starting position.

For teenaged lo-fi diddler Aaron Freeman
column2: the rarefied state of “brown” was the ultimate achievement. Starting with 1986’s home-recorded The Crucial Squeegie Lip
column3: Freeman and his best friend Mickey Melchiondo
column4: recording as Gene and Dean Ween
column5: aimed to create a sound (and life) experience that was extremely “fucked-up
column6: in a good way
column7: ” as Melchiondo describes it. What #based is for Lil B—a good-natured raison d’etre doubling as a foggy aesthetic manifesto and rallying cry for fans—“brown” was for Ween. Early on in the duo’s fledgling career
column8: brown meant making themselves happy
column9: often at the expense of their audiences. During an opening slot for Fugazi in the late 1980s
column10: ex-Ween tourmate Matt Sweeney remembered in a recent book
column11: “they were pelted with change by newly bald straight-edge kids as Aaron sang the same Cat Stevens song over and over.""

column1: Flash-forward 30 years from the DIY spirit of Ween’s early recordings and performances
column2: past the decade-plus when they packed amphitheaters
column3: played late-night TV
column4: got Elvis’ old backing group to perform on an album with a song called “Piss Up a Rope”
column5: and released a double-disc live album on Elektra called Paintin’ the Town Brown. Now
column6: there’s FREEMAN: on Aaron Freeman's self-titled solo album
column7: the 44-year old singer finds himself on the other side of recovery
column8: atoning for a life lived brown. “Covert Discretion” opens the album with a crushing level of vulnerability: “Another gig now
column9: got an aching head
column10: and I’m back on display
column11: ” he murmurs in a soft
column12: folky voice that hasn’t deepened much since he was a teenager. “I’m your best friend
column13: I’m your superstar/ Yeah
column14: I’m down with the brown.” Despite it all
column15: Ween could be a very reflective band
column16: but “Discretion” is the first song sung by Aaron Freeman about the cost of living as Gene Ween.

column1: “Discretion” is also the first public step of a drying-out process triggered by a sad January 2011 Ween show in Vancouver that would lead to the band’s dissolution the following year. In front of 3
column2: 000 fans who paid $50 per ticket
column3: Freeman laid down on the stage during songs and slurred his lyrics when he could remember them. The same behaviors that a 20-something Freeman would use to antagonize audiences
column4: and with which he accumulated a fanbase of countless suburban stoners
column5: had become blatant symptoms of a serious problem—what made Ween also killed it. As is his wont
column6: however
column7: there’s no easy emotional true north on FREEMAN. After gently pirouetting on a “Dust in the Wind”-style guitar figure for a few minutes
column8: “Discretion” suddenly shifts gears into a slick hesher anthem. “Fuck you all
column9: I got a reason to live/ And I’m never gonna die
column10: ” he asserts
column11: as the image of a New Age recovery facility gives way to a vision of a packed arena. Such balance of abject pathos and profane teenage-boy hardheadedness is a Ween trademark
column12: which Freeman mastered on 1994’s “Baby Bitch
column13: ” a heartrending breakup song that had “Bitch” in the title and the line “Fuck you
column14: you stinkin’-ass ho” gently inserted into the verse.

column1: Indeed
column2: part of what made Ween so great was Freeman and Melichiondo’s refusal to distinguish between sincerity and silliness
column3: a mainstay of the druggy teenage boyhood that neither ever left. On “(For a While) I Couldn’t Play My Guitar Like a Man”
column4: Freeman toys around with a bluesy lament
column5: but it’s impossible to tell if he’s aiming toward a Crossroads-style soul-selling or a 12-step-style soul search (or if
column6: after Clapton
column7: there is even a difference). Though “Black Bush” was inspired by the bucolic surround of the upstate New York region where the album was recorded
column8: Freeman takes the opportunity to sing about the “crab man” and “woody-pecker” in his most cartoonishly mannered guru voice
column9: even lapsing into Hindi on the chorus. FREEMAN is a thoroughly mellow—one might say anesthetized—recording
column10: but throughout
column11: Freeman’s gentle absurdity combines with the crack studio musicianship (Megafaun’s Brad Cook and the Foreign Exchange’s Chris Boerner contribute) to make an eerily soothing form of psychedelia bent on exploring the other side of getting fucked up.

column1: Aaron Freeman’s search for brown has long faded
column2: and what powers FREEMAN is his unique gift—audible since Ween sequenced the heartbreaking “Birthday Boy” two tracks after “Papa Zit” on 1990’s God Ween Satan—in his inability to compartmentalize his emotions in his creative work. For three decades
column3: he sacrificed his sobriety and nearly his life so that people like me could soundtrack stupors and sentimental moments in equal measure. As a teenager
column4: I watched my skater friends huff Redi-Whip in an attempt to really understand “Big Jilm” (perhaps the band’s brownest song)
column5: and 12 years later
column6: I watched two of my best friends dance to “Stay Forever” at their wedding reception. For Ween newcomers
column7: FREEMAN is bound to sound odd
column8:
even off-putting. I get it. But this is the promise and labor of appreciating a lifelong cult artist like Freeman: taking the time to engage him on his own terms.

Adam Schatz
column2: the leading force behind Landlady
column3: is short
column4: spasmodic
column5: and intense. Onstage
column6: his whole body often balls up like a fist
column7: and his eyes bug open like someone receiving shock therapy. His voice occupies some middle distance between a young Randy Newman and an older Morrissey
column8: yowling up into fluttery melismas and then settling into a barrel-chested belt. He's emotionally generous and theatrical
column9: his musical ambitions too on the-sleeve to fit comfortably in the circumspect land of indie rock. Landlady move through their second record Upright Behavior like the USS Sincerity
column10: offering to share with you in your biggest fears: death
column11: loneliness
column12:
lack of purpose.

Musically
column13: they occupy a big middle space always in need of willing entrants: brainy
column14: melodic pop-rock. Their arrangements
column15: full of hard lefts and detours
column16: pack paragraphs full of ideas into five minutes. Landlady songs are eventful
column17: with chorales and middle eights opening up like big yellow umbrellas. On the fidgety
column18: starched-collar ""Dying Day""
column19: the hard downbeat repeatedly evaporates into a flutter of cartoon bluebirds. On ""Under the Yard""
column20: the band stops playing so the members can sing a chorale based around the phrase ""Next to the tomato seeds is where I count my sheep
column21: like an eccentric vocal warm-up exercise.

column1: The band is an impressive battalion
column2: and they move from mallet percussion to violin to keyboards with the nimbleness of a traveling theater troupe. The songs jump-cut from moment to moment
column3: often landing in a different key or time signature out of the clear blue. The transitions sound clearly influenced by Smile
column4: and sometimes
column5: Upright Behavior feels like Schatz's attempt to make three Smiles at once. There are moments
column6: here and there
column7: where beleaguered listeners might wish for a few more full stops
column8:
fewer semicolons and embedded parentheticals.

What saves Landlady's music from being swallowed by stagecraft is Schatz. He writes big hooks that hover like big neon signs over his bustling songs
column9: and each one frames a glowing homily: ""We just want someone to turn on"" (from ""Girl"") or ""Where do I go when the blood won't go far enough to reach my heart?"" (""Under the Yard""). ""You and me
column10: in the flood/ We survive
column11: he sings
column12: in a triumphantly up-swelling melody on ""Upright Behavior""
column13: taking the phrase through it's melodic paces until he has plumbed every possible meaning out of them—wonder
column14: disbelief
column15: regret
column16: defiance
column17: gratitude. ""Please
column18: allow me to believe in something bigger than my appetite
column19: he pleads on ""Fine"". He comes across like Kevin Barnes
column20: if Barnes were less arch and more concerned with cheering up your depressed great-aunt than with subversion. Upright Behavior is Schatz's attempt go pack as much of this essence into one space as possible
column21:
and it comes on like a combination Chinese finger trap and bear hug.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20730/homepage_large.976c5042.jpg|Passerby|32346.0|Luluc|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-07-23 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:14.373096|"

On the title track to Luluc’s second album—and their Sub Pop debut—Zoë Randell laments what she calls “the passerby life.” The song recounts several friends who have come and gone
column2: some human and some not: a bearded guy named Mike Brown
column3: an old man she knew as Mr. Finnegan
column4: “a young dying baby lamb” that she fed by hand
column5: “a tiny Christmas Island bird” with a broken wing. They’re lovely images and poignant remembrances
column6: especially sung in Randell’s robustly ruminative voice and set to Steve Hassett’s gentle acoustic strums. As befits a duo that moved around the world to soft-start their career
column7: the song dispels any romanticized notions of connection and memory: Everyone is a passerby in your life
column8: and you’re merely a passerby in theirs.

column1: And then Luluc ruin it. Randell ends the song with a blah couplet—“And as you go
column2: know I love you so”—that brings the song to a rousing conclusion
column3: completely undercutting the tough-minded verses. What begins as a world-wear reverie finishes as a Nicholas Sparks epilogue
column4: as Luluc choose to state the obvious in the most obvious way possible. It’s not that those lines are wholly unnecessary
column5: but that they carelessly cordon off the song’s emotions to deliver pat catharsis. Similarly
column6: Passerby toggles awkwardly between the evocatively melancholy and the chintzily sentimental
column7: rendering the carefully composed and performed music as little more than pretty.

column1: This stumble will be all the more disappointing for anyone who heard the Brooklyn-via-Australia duo play on last year’s Way to Blue: the Songs of Nick Drake. It was an ill-conceived public tribute to a deeply private artist
column2: yet Luluc’s versions of “Things Behind the Sun” and “Fly” were highlights that showcased both the dignified yearning of Drake’s lyrics and the easy chemistry between Randell and Hassett. They were something of an anomaly for those live performances
column3: as at the time they had only one album
column4: self-released back in 2008
column5: to their name. On the strength of that tiny catalog and Randell’s big voice
column6: Luluc signed to Sub Pop
column7: where they join the Head & the Heart and Mirel Wagner on the folksier side of the roster.

column1: Perhaps more crucially
column2: Luluc gained the ear of the National’s Aaron Dessner
column3: who agreed to produce Passerby at his studio in Brooklyn's Ditmas Park area. His contributions are low-key and mostly unobtrusive. To reinforce the theme of departure and travel
column4: he emphasizes the spry rhythmic guitar strums on opener “Small Window” and peppers “Early Night” with low-key industrial noise. Only “Tangled Heart” builds to anything that might be considered a big moment
column5: with its texturing of horns greeting the Randell’s romantic regrets. Still
column6: even Dessner can’t nudge Luluc out of their comfort zone: Every song trudges by at the same midtempo
column7: conjuring the same atmosphere of glum reminiscence with no relief or variation.

column1: As rich as Randell’s voice may be
column2: this collection portrays her as a sharply limited artist
column3: with only one mode and a few interpretive tricks up her sleeve. Occasionally she goes purposefully flat like Nico
column4: other times she rounds her vowels luxuriantly
column5: but there’s no tension
column6: no conflict
column7:
no story to connect those moments into something larger. The result is a strictly passerby album: one that is heard and then quickly forgotten. 

"|19505.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19505-luluc-passerby/|4.9|Stephen Deusner

Forget the forced quirkiness

column6: and its weaknesses—obvious visual framing
column7: a reliance on juvenalia for comedic effect
column8: a bizarre focus on discouraging the use of antidepressants for the mentally ill—are present and plentiful. But Garden State’s appeal was and still is inherent to anyone who’s experienced or been able to recognize the emotional selfishness that comes with feeling adrift in your mid-to-late twenties. Even if the film failed to truly change viewers’ lives
column9: at the least it convinced them of the power of large-sized headphones.

column1: Indeed
column2: Garden State’s legacy in the decade since it hit theatres isn't really about the film; it's become a pop culture totem
column3: especially its Grammy-winning
column4: platinum-selling soundtrack. Braff described it at the time as “a mix CD with all of the music that I felt was scoring my life” while he worked on the film's screenplay
column5: but few mix CDs have such an impact on the zeitgeist. It's often and incorrectly cited as the first time the Shins were exposed to mainstream culture—you have a different
column6: more insidious corporate entity to thank for that eventuality—but the Garden State soundtrack's tasteful folk-pop
column7: unassuming electronica
column8: and occasional old classic or two marks the point in the last decade when the term “indie” became more associated with how music sounds than the ethos behind how music’s made. Whether or not you’ve followed Imogen Heap’s solo career since
column9: its existence is partially owed to Garden State; the set is responsible for much of the music you hear in Starbucks
column10: as well as much of the music you can purchase at Starbucks.

column1: A cultural event that arguably sowed the seeds for the musical conservatism infecting present-day mainstream rock
column2: Garden State is mentioned with ire as much as it is with nostalgic fondness; in other words
column3: it provokes strong feelings. So it’s understandable that
column4: 10 years later and without much else since to lean on in terms of artistic credibility
column5: Braff’s returned to the shallow well with Wish I Was Here
column6: his second directorial effort. Frequently billed as Garden State’s “spiritual sequel” and sharing little with its predecessor beyond a strongly unlikable protagonist and the ever-present spectre of death
column7: Wish I Was Here is a sometimes-bland
column8: sometimes-intolerable mix of tired platitudes
column9: overbearing religious themes
column10: casual racism
column11: and sappy sentimentality that
column12: quality-wise
column13: makes Garden State look like The Graduate by comparison.

column1: Which is fine. Braff’s most vaunted position in pop culture circa 2014 isn’t as the actor who played the annoying guy on the TV show your college roommates watched all the time
column2: or as a fervent Redditor who once assisted in helping someone propose to their girlfriend online
column3: or as a distant blood relative to Mitt Romney. Arguably
column4: he’s not even most known as the guy who directed Garden State—he’s the guy who put together the Garden State soundtrack
column5: and so the question surrounding Wish I Was Here is a strange one that most films aren’t subject to: What does it sound like? Braff himself is undoubtedly aware of this expectation
column6: going as far as to promise an early stream of the soundtrack to those who backed the film’s funding on Kickstarter.

column1: Such an incentive would have been unimaginably useless in Garden State’s case
column2: as the film’s soundtrack was largely compiled of tunes that existed before its release; that’s not the case for Wish I Was Here
column3: which features new songs written specifically for the film from the Shins
column4: Bon Iver
column5: and most curiously
column6: a collaboration between Cat Power and Coldplay. With the exception of Bon Iver (whose “Holocene” is also featured here
column7: almost to the point of self-parody)
column8: these acts were active concerns circa Garden State—for Coldplay and the Shins
column9: it’s their second trip soundtracking Braff’s explicitly caucasian middle-class take on generational malaise—and their presence alone was practically preordained. The music on the Garden State soundtrack still sounds unmistakably like 2004
column10: and Wish I Was Here follows suit; if we’re being charitable
column11: the dated musical timeline it establishes plays like an alternate-universe pop cultural atmosphere that ground to a halt shortly after the release of Bon Iver’s 2009 EP Blood Bank—a scenario where Coldplay never went EDM
column12: Cat Power never worked with a French house duo
column13: Justin Vernon never collaborated with Kanye West
column14: and (one can dream) Broken Bells never happened.

column1: Banjos
column2: acoustic guitars
column3: and unbearable expressions of earnestness abound; Paul Simon’s “The Obvious Child” is included
column4: because of course it is. Gary Jules
column5: an also-ran singer/songwriter whose maudlin cover of Tears for Fears’ “Mad World” went viral after being featured in the closing moments of the 2001 sci-fi-cum-coming of age film Donnie Darko and more or less hasn’t been heard from since
column6: shows up with the muddy
column7: unlistenable “Broke Window”
column8: taken from that year’s Trading Snakeoil for Wolftickets; elsewhere
column9: alt-rock casualties Jump Little Children
column10: who broke up nearly a decade ago
column11: are featured with the impossibly plastic-sounding “Mexico”
column12: a California-namechecking song that elevates Phantom Planet to Randy Newman status. Perhaps the strongest song featured on the soundtrack is Badly Drawn Boy’s contemplative “The Shining”—taken from an album which first saw release nearly 15 years ago
column13: cementing the soundtrack’s functionality as a nostalgia trip that registers on the level of seeing a Kerry/Edwards bumper sticker on a car windshield.

column1: As for the new stuff: Bon Iver contribute “Heavenly Father”
column2: a watery
column3: over-processed slice of electro-folk that was perfected on the project’s self-titled 2011 LP and comes across as an unwanted leftover from those sessions. The film’s corresponding title track carries writing credits from Coldplay and features Cat Power’s Chan Marshall singing lead
column4: and “Wish I Was Here”’s melodic structure certainly sounds like Coldplay
column5: a subdued
column6: unfussy version of the weirdest mega-band in the world’s skyscraping tendencies. But Marshall’s flat
column7: unaffecting vocal take
column8: along with the dull arrangement
column9: makes for a boring ballad that outpaces anything on Coldplay’s recent misfire Ghost Stories in terms of tedium. In a sense
column10: “Wish I Was Here” a perfect representation of the film and
column11: by extension
column12: Braff’s overall preferred aesthetic—moderately palatable
column13: harmless
column14: uninteresting
column15: and ultimately less forgettable than you’d want it to be.

column1: Fittingly
column2: the sole new contribution that doesn’t scan as a failure comes from the Shins
column3: a project that will probably never be able to escape the spectre of Garden State as long as there’s people out there who will marvel over the dirt in their fries. Shins bandleader James Mercer has
column4: against all odds
column5: spent the last decade quietly establishing himself as one of North America’s finest songwriters
column6: turning out pretty-sounding songs that sound effortless in their simplicity
column7: and “So Now What” is the latest example of him flexing his inimitable talent. It’s not the best Shins song
column8: nor would any fan likely include it in a “Best of” compilation for the band
column9: but it’s a better song than Braff’s film deserves
column10: as Mercer’s voice gorgeously crests on a bed of reverb and synthetic strings.

column1: The Shins’ last album from 2012
column2: Port of Morrow
column3: found Mercer taking the cheesier sounds of rock music’s past and spinning gold out of them; the floaty textures of “So Now What”
column4: on the other hand
column5: sounds undeniably current
column6: standing in opposition to the short-term retro malaise that Wish I Was Here’s soundtrack ultimately and greatly suffers from. Whether or not Braff was intending to capture a cultural moment with Garden State’s soundtrack
column7: that’s exactly what he did; this time around
column8: the moment eludes him
column9: making his previous success as a musical tastemaker seem more than ever like a happy accident. Next time—if
column10: God help us
column11:
Hollywood and the internet band together again and decide to give this guy another chance—he might be better off exploring the infinite abyss for inspiration.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20806/homepage_large.43096097.jpg|For Those Who Stay|28555.0|PS I Love You|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paper Bag']|2014-07-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:15.521950|"

PS I Love You's third album is scrappy and self-deprecating guitar rock that often finds Paul Saulnier freaking out about his inability to handle life’s uncertainties. This is an act which actually requires a great deal of resilience and self-belief; after all
column2: this kind of music doesn’t find itself on the receiving end of a lot of outside validation in 2014. This circularity of struggling for struggle’s sake is even more pronounced in the title of For Those Who Stay; it can be read a show of confidence and gratitude to listeners who’ve stuck with this unfashionable
column3: workmanlike band over the past eight years
column4: as well as an acknowledgment that it’s hard to stick with an unfashionable
column5: workmanlike band for eight years. At least there’s a level of comfort on both sides
column6: though
column7: and For Those Who Stay embodies the minor stakes and moderate goals of both performer and audience—it’s PS I Love You trying to be the biggest band for their little niche.

column1: The title track is over six minutes long and about half of it is earmarked for a funk-grunge jam session; it arrives backed by a washed out remix courtesy of chillwave diehard Teen Daze. “For Those Who Stay” is also the first single
column2: so this is clearly not a band who’s going out of their way to expand their reach. PS I Love You might not have a legitimate crossover
column3: go-for-broke
column4: all-singles album in them
column5: but if they did
column6: it would probably sound like this.

column1: Compared to the murky
column2: macabre Death Dreams
column3: For Those Who Stay practically sparkles
column4: as it was recorded in a “proper” studio and with a lot of what Saulnier calls “fancy gear”. Small indulgences creep in
column5: as there’s often a third guy playing on any given song
column6: contributing ARP string ensemble
column7: piano
column8: field recordings
column9: Hammond B-3
column10: stylophone
column11: and other keyboards they proudly specify in the liner notes. The arrangements are incrementally more complex
column12: though the stylistic range on For Those Who Stay is by far PS I Love You’s most expansive move yet—“In My Mind At Least” sneaks in mid-period Cure jangle before “Advice” lays back in the pocket with bloozy amble. “Bad Brain Day” and “Limestone Radio” show a surprising facility for both unencumbered acoustic balladry and QOTSA-style riffs slapped together with a New Wave chorus.

column1: They all sound like little nudges at PS I Love You’s set boundaries
column2: since the duo are still an indie rock band first and foremost. You know this sound by now: fuzzed-out guitars that simultaneously handle rhythm and lead
column3: steady
column4: unshowy drums
column5: and a general sense of hang-doggedness that could be heard as reflex
column6: a sadness borne of realizing you’re drawn to a style of music that prefers a downer disposition. The first line on For Those Who Stay is
column7: “I’m sorry I forgot about that thing I was supposed to do last week
column8: ” an offhand remark that somehow spells out an album’s entire emotional state of creeping guilt and regret.

column1: Saulnier’s voice somehow makes that line sound like an apology worthy of a cataclysmic
column2: life-altering failure
column3: as his adenoidal squawk (think Dan Bejar or Alec Ounsworth) the one thing that most distinguishes PS I Love You from their fuzz-duo peers. On the other hand
column4: it’s the one thing that could trigger the kind of allergic reaction unattributable to their fuzz-duo peers who lack such idiosyncrasies good or bad.

column1: But this divisiveness has already been established; For Those Who Stay won’t change your opinion either way
column2: and at the most
column3: it might make you feel more strongly about what you already believe. In turn
column4: that seems to calcify opinion into hard truth—that PS I Love You are a band that’s pretty great at being pretty good
column5: while lacking the sort of risk and extroversion that can trigger real passion. The songs are catchy but they don’t quite feel anthemic; they’re loud and distorted
column6: but they probably couldn’t start a mosh pit. Yes
column7: it’s a shame that another Canadian duo that got started around the same time does this kind of thing on a much
column8: much higher level
column9: but you stack a line like “We’re never gonna win/ Keep tryin’ is all you can do” or the shrugged resignment of “Hoarders” and “Friends Forever” against their Vancouver peers’ raw lust for living
column10: and PS I Love You's modest place in the grand scheme of things just feels like an accurate reflection of their ambitions.

column1: And really
column2: the one thing that probably determines your excitement and enjoyment of For Those Who Stay is just how much you’ve invested in PS I Love You being one of your favorite bands. You get the weird sense that For Those Who Stay is at its best when you’re its captive audience and as Saulnier belts out a line like
column3: “How much did it hurt to make it this far?/ I still believe in you all
column4: you can at least root for PS I Love You
column5:
even if you don’t love them.

Strange Weather
column2: an EP featuring five new covers
column3: sounds like an extension of Anna Calvi’s debut single
column4: 2010’s “Jezebel”
column5: which remains arguably her best song and certainly a deft means of introduction to her commanding voice. Originally a hit for Frankie Laine in 1951
column6: it’s been covered often in various languages and genres
column7: although most versions gently reinforce the song’s matter-of-fact pop sexism. Borrowing from Edith Piaf’s cover (“c’était toi!”)
column8: Calvi turns the song into a flamenco rock aria
column9: her voice soaring accusatorily and her guitar providing sinister commentary. With its emotions blown up to operatic scale
column10: “Jezebel” plays less like a woman-baiting lament and more like a powerful fanfare. Calvi may sing in second person
column11: but she embraces the role of Jezebel as one of immense power.

column1: That single introduced Calvi as a song interpreter with unique vocal power and timbre as well as versatile guitar chops
column2: but her first two albums—2011’s Anna Calvi and last year’s weirdly under-the-radar One Breath—settled into a more workaday singer-songwriter mode. For that reason
column3: a covers EP sounds like a natural and promising endeavor
column4: one that lets her concentrate exclusively on crafting nuanced performances. She could easily level a small city with her voice
column5: but instead chooses to emphasize subtlety and incremental shades of mood on these five songs. “Papi Pacify” becomes a slow blues seduction
column6: not too far from FKA twigs’ original in tone and setting
column7: but Calvi draws out the ""ooh""’s leading up to the chorus and settles into the languorous guitar chords afterwards. The song takes on a pattern of tension and release that sounds slyly sexual.

column1: Subtlety and restraint are
column2: refreshingly
column3: crucial to Strange Weather. She dials her vocals back considerably for Keren Ann’s “Strange Weather”
column4: a duet with David Byrne
column5: which sounds like a quiet moment after some great cataclysm. Even the climax of “I’m the Man
column6: That Will Find You” plays things close to the chest
column7: as Calvi relegates the dramatic wailing to the background in order to make her measured lead more prominent. Connan Mockasin’s original still sounds like a put-on—a half-joke built on aspic-wobbly vocals and a winking slink of a groove—yet Calvi takes the lyrics at face value and rescues the song from such fatal irony. Even so
column8: its power lays not so much in her vocals but in her guitar playing
column9: as she draws out that central riff like it’s an old delta blues lick.

column1: None of these covers is quite as transformed as “Jezebel”
column2: so nothing on Strange Weather delivers the same subversive charge. Partly that’s due to her choice in material

column5: more tedious than thrilling. And closer “Lady Grinning Soul” foregoes the cosmic pomp and self-regard of Bowie’s early ‘70s original for an easy elegiac tone that allows Strange Weather to simply dissipate into the ether. Her restraint is commendable
column6:
but on these two songs it curdles into something like hesitation.

column1: During the last five years

column13: uninterrupted audio. Blackshaw’s new music is the sound of someone actively pressing against the boundaries of expectation.

column1: Fantômas: Le Faux Magistrat is Blackshaw’s most audacious attempt yet to shatter that mold. Recorded live in Paris last Halloween
column2: the seamless 74-minute piece stemmed from a commission for a live score for the 1914 silent movie Le Faux Magistrat. The fifth film in a series of classics by Louis Feuillade
column3: Le Faux Magistrat ended a centennial celebration of the director at the prestigious Théâtre de Châtelet. Preceded by the likes of Tim Hecker and Yann Tiersen
column4: Blackshaw was tasked with providing accompaniment to the screening. Rather than write a long and loping guitar piece
column5: though
column6: Blackshaw took it as an invitation to exercise his unrest. He recruited a quartet to work through a set of a dozen interconnected movements
column7: surprisingly filled with dissonant electronics and consonant strings
column8: dynamic percussion and versatile saxophone. Blackshaw leads with piano
column9: nylon-stringed guitar and an electric
column10: but he often yields the foreground to the group
column11: slipping into the mix like a composer watching from the wings as an ensemble goes to work.

column3: electroacoustic luminescence and sweeping post-rock
column4: without pause. Duane Pitre and Charlotte Glasson—American and British experimental multi-instrumentalists

column6: accenting the music’s range. Pitre moves between electric guitar harmonics and subdural drones
column7: while Glasson adds bold saxophone and sweeping strings

column9: almost incidental percussion and thundering drums. Indeed
column10: their most powerful moment as a group comes at one of Blackshaw’s most surprising turns as a composer. While he plays what could pass for a sample of “A Love Supreme” on piano
column11: Scott and Pitre
column12: now on bass and synthesizer
column13: form a punishing
column14: doom-like rhythm section. Glasson laces the load with vibraphone whorls and saxophone sighs. She is the bait
column15: balanced at the lip of the trap.

column1: The condition that gives moments like this their intrigue—that is
column2: Blackshaw is actively working to outstrip his past—is also the source of Fantômas’ overall error. Blackshaw and his band return to a handful of themes and textures
column3: such as the piano ostinato that serves as a bridge between several pieces. But it all seems a touch desultory
column4: too
column5: as though Blackshaw’s suddenly large toolkit tempted him to build too much too soon. Parts evolve with force
column6: not finesse
column7: and many moments seem undeserved and undeveloped
column8: as when electronic washes empty into the mix like a transitional crutch.

column1: In the past
column2: Blackshaw’s music seemed to reveal cathedrals of wonder and mystery
column3: a quality that made it worth revisiting. But much of Fantômas seems plain and pat
column4: the sort of structures one might make while learning the basics of a trade. Many of the piano lines here mirror Blackshaw’s guitar work
column5: but they’re less powerful and wooing in their new
column6: almost hesitant voice. And at worst
column7: the nylon-string bits can feel like outright pap
column8: cheap filler in a broad and ornate scheme. During the piece’s grand moment of high-rising action
column9: for instance
column10: Blackshaw takes what sounds like Europe’s “The Final Countdown” for a lap of soft-rock shuffle. Intentional or not
column11: it’s a hilarious distraction from the music’s pensive mood

column1: Fantômas is certainly a pleasant listen
column2: perhaps a bit jumbled for any immersion but varied and arching enough to soundtrack household chores. Still
column3: its most notable accomplishment is that it should emancipate Blackshaw
column4: once and for all
column5: from his 12-string-guitarist cloister
column6: or from the prevailing if obsolete notion that he does only one thing. Ideas abound during Fantômas

column8:
even if necessitates a rather forgettable present.

column2: the New Orleans sludge scene has been especially active as of late. Previously propelled by the slow chug of their peers

column5: the quartet has been merging black metal
column6: thrash
column7: and the blues into a direct
column8: southern-fried take on the genre. The Louisianans’ structural scope may be limited <span class=""s1"">to brief barn burners
column9: but they have largely managed to avoid stoner metal's ubiquitous bloat

column1: At first

column11: perplexingly

column1: In Goatwhore’s wicked universe
column2: sexuality and the supernatural always go hand-in-hand—an unsurprising paradigm
column3: considering that the quartet hail from one of North America's most haunted cities. The lecherous hydra that graces Constricting Rage’s cover is an emblem for the album’s broader lyrical themes

column5: Satan

One of the most persistent trends to emerge from the dubstep diaspora has been a growing interest with American R&B—specifically
column2: the turn-of-century eccentricities turned in by Timbaland
column3: the Neptunes
column4: and their acolytes. It was always in the style's DNA: dubstep forebears and 2-step monkey-patched glossy house tunes
column5: with the type of ornate syncopations that Timbaland improbably turned into chart-topping pop. Somewhat inevitably
column6: the interest in the productions fostered interest in the vocalists. Zomby's Aaliyah-jacking ""Float""
column7: from 2008
column8: is one of the earlier examples
column9: and Jacques Greene's ""Another Girl"" seemed to put a point on the vogue in early 2011.

column1: Hyperdub
column2: intentionally or not
column3: has served as one incubator of this style in its admirable quest to foster urban club music. Hyperdub 10.2 represents the second of four compilations documenting the label's first decade (but largely displaying its most recent five years). Focusing on the label's self-professed R&B offerings (the first volume having showcased the label's club music)
column4: 10.2 mixes new offerings from Kode9
column5: Cooly G
column6: and Jessy Lanza with older tracks from Burial
column7: DJ Rashad
column8: and Terror Danjah. A mixed bag
column9: stylistically
column10: 10.2's tracks are bound by rustling vocals
column11: lights-low tempos
column12: and sultry arrangements.

column1: Having grown fond of sampling vocals from R&B divas
column2: the UK underground took the next logical step and began singing themselves. Acts like Katy B and AlunaGeorge represent a generation for whom Aaliyah and Amerie typify pop normalcy
column3: a generation who watched the avant-garde crystalize into the mainstream. So there are large swaths of 10.2 that
column4: in 2014 (or
column5: frankly
column7: scan as fairly catholic takes on minimal
column8: electro R&B.

column1: This is where the material falters
column2: at once hewing too closely to R&B's sonic template while pulling its emotional punches. Cooly G's ""Obsessed"" details an infatuation but censors itself: ""Looking at me/ Watching me/ Wanna f--- me"". Jessy Lanza's ""5785021"" turns a phone number into a chorus
column3: tightroping the line between coy and corny. On tracks such as Terror Danjah's ""You Make Me Feel"" and Morgan Zarate's ""Pusher Taker""
column4: the vocal performances struggle to keep pace with the tricky
column5: intriguing productions. Too often
column6: dubby reflections and breathy whispering are substituted for more traditional melisma and inflection; the effect isn't seduction
column7: but apprehension.

column1: 10.2 fares better when it engages R&B on more ephemeral terms. Burial's inky transmissions dissolve the late-night
column2: call-in loneliness of Quiet Storm R&B. The Inga Copeland tracks that bookend the album—first with Dean Blunt and then Kode9—are intoxicating
column3: her flatlining
column4: anti-diva voice bristling against seasick arrangements
column5: the finest marriage of the label's avant-garde instincts with pop forms. DJ Rashad's ""Only One"" skirts the R&B conversation entirely: it's the rare footwork track that trades freneticism for tenderness. DVA's ""Just Vybe"" features Fatima
column6: the best
column7: most idiosyncratic singer on 10.2; she offers up a tart melody that feels like a proper UK take on welterweight R&B. Its charm exposes how labored and earnest much of 10.2 is.

column1: Electronic music's interest in R&B mirrors a more general trend in underground music
column2: one that has recently extended further into the past
column3: touching most recently on Jam & Lewis' glassy funk (Kelela's Cut 4 Me mixtape being the most prominent example). But it's safe to say that
column4: as yet
column5: the songwriting and vocal components of the genre have failed to inspire the same unbridled creativity as the productions. Hyperdub's relationship to the form is less developed and less guided than their stewardship of footwork or UK club music
column6: and it leaves 10.2 in the lurch
column7: lacking clear purpose. At times it feels like dabbling
column8: on the part of both the label and the artists (see Ghostface's bolted-on guest appearance on Morgan Zarate's ""Sticks & Stones""). There's enough flair on 10.2 to justify further exploration
column9:
but it's premature to label this ""future R&B"" when its participants seem so uneasy with the genre's past.

column3: it’s “Alvvays” as in “always
column4: ” not “All-vays”—but that typographic quirk is more than just an opportunistic ploy for this Toronto quintet to enhance its search engine optimization. (If anything
column5: Alvvays’ dual affinities for post-C86 girl-group revisionism and dusty-grooved distortion strongly suggest they’re yearning for a time when seeking out bands involved trans-Atlantic fanzine correspondence and mail-order forms.) Apparently
column6: the curious spelling was implemented to avoid confusion with <a href=""http://www.allmusic.com/album/thames-valley-leather-club-and-other-stories-mw0000104648"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the bygone

column8: Alvvays actually proves to be a perfect visual manifestation of this band’s thematic framework: with nearly every crestfallen song on their debut pitched at the crossroads of commitment and abandonment
column9: nostalgia and uncertainty
column10: the band’s name effectively becomes the textual representation of the broken promises catalogued within.

column1: Such quarterlife-crisis concerns—the bane a generation that
column2: as one song puts it
column3: feels like it’s “too late to go out
column4: too young to stay in”—are natural preoccupations for a band of twentysomethings that is the very product of upheaval and a clean-slate reset. As recently as two years ago
column5: Nova Scotia native Molly Rankin was still trying to establish her identity as a solo artist on the maritime club circuit—a task made all the more formidable by the fact she’s a descendent of Canadian roots-music dynasty the Rankin Family. An EP released under her own name in 2010 suggested she was destined to travel down a similarly bucolic path
column6: casting her cheekily self-deprecating lyrics and siren of a voice in familiarly folksy surroundings. However
column7: her partnership with that record’s guitarist Alec O’Hanley (formerly of Prince Edward Island power-popsters Two Hours Traffic) would eventually turn more ambitious. With Rankin enlisting childhood friend Kerri MacLellan on keyboards and O’Hanley recruiting PEI pals Brian Murphy and Phil MacIssac on bass and drums
column8: the quintet relocated to Toronto last year with their new name
column9: new aesthetic
column10: and
column11: in former brunette Rankin’s case
column12: new hair.

column1: But it's not just the singer’s striking
column2: peroxide-blond locks that make Alvvays stick out from the infinite number of contemporary indie acts forging a similar union between early-’60s AM-radio pop and late-’80s freak-scene discord. On the band’s winsome Chad VanGaalen-produced debut
column3: it’s the disarmingly frank
column4: aching lyricism that ultimately raises them above the cardiganed fray
column5: capturing both the humour and heartache of seeking intimacy in the big city. Amid the buoyant surf-tingled jangle of the opening “Adult Diversion
column6: ” Rankin isn’t just discreetly ogling a fellow commuter from afar; she’s already plotting out their future domestic bliss
column7: asking her oblivious object of desire
column8: “How do I grow old with you even if you don’t notice as I pass by you on the subway?” The rousing
column9: pints-aloft follow-up
column10: “Archie
column11: Marry Me”
column12: serves as a sequel of sorts where Rankin has got the guy
column13: but not the ring—and yet she already sounds less like she’s fighting for the love of her life than checking items off a list (“Honey
column14: take me by the hand
column15: and we can sign some papers/ Forget the invitations
column16: floral arrangements
column17: and breadmakers”)
column18: thereby proving that the only thing more tragic than a break-up song is one about a person desperate to break in.

column1: Rankin possesses the sort of radiant but deceptively deadpan voice that lets her to infuse these lovelorn laments with sly
column2: sometimes sinister wit: when she sings
column3: “I left my love in the river” on the drowned-boyfriend requiem “Next of Kin”
column4: there’s the simmering implication that she could’ve done a little more to save him. (The chorus to the dreamy slow-motorik ballad “Ones Who Love You
column5: ” meanwhile
column6: is home to the most beautifully nonchalant f-bomb.) This sense of irreverence bleeds into the album’s production
column7: whose scabrous guitar lines
column8: synth-blurred vistas
column9: and drum-machine experiments reveal the band are hardly the purists their pedigree might indicate. Presenting a brighter contrast to the claustrophobic insularity heard on VanGaalen's own recordings and in his work with the much-missed Women
column10: Alvvays eagerly scuffs up the band’s gold sounds with dissonant edges—not to deliberately obscure the gleaming melodies or make the band seem tougher than they are
column11: but to enhance the very feeling of raw-nerved unrest seeping through Rankin’s lyric sheet. This is the sound of pristine pop music blasted through cheap
column12: blown-out headphones—and every time it seems like a song is about to decay before your ears
column13:
you sense both the sadness and liberation of knowing that nothing lasts forever.

Pop-punk has certain stylistic rules about song structure and topicality that detractors often refer to as clichés
column2: and it’s much easier to break these rules than to do something notable within them.
column3: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> The latter explains how Joyce Manor have grown to be one of the most popular and interesting bands in their realm:
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">yes
column5: they’re from Torrance
column6: California and write 90-second
column7: hook-filled songs called “Orange Julius” and “Leather Jacket”. They also take prog-like liberties with format and assume their subject matter is as fascinating as science fiction. They take pride in their given aesthetic
column8: and the quartet’s third LP Never Hungover Again is a pop-punk cliché itself: the one where an ascendant
column9: dearly beloved band signs to a big label
column10: hires a hotshot producer and
column11: oh shit
column12: are those keyboards? The successes of Never Hungover Again are numerous
column13: and the foremost is how Joyce Manor's most ambitious and diverse album is just like their other ones—10 songs
column14: 19 minutes
column15: every second as weird as it is instantly enjoyable.

column1: Assuming you’re approaching this record as a self-identifying “indie rock” fan
column2: there isn’t a single “legitimate” precedent that will walk you through this—maybe “west coast Lifetime” comes close
column3: considering Barry Johnson’s perpetual slur
column4: self-deprecation
column5: and goofy earnestness. Joyce Manor are a stylistically comprehensive band and this record is a consolidation of their talents
column6: accomplishing the difficult task of welding the straightforward charms of their increasingly canonical self-titled debut and the ambition of Of All Things I Will Soon Grow Tired
column7: a record praised at the time for its relatively experimental leanings and in retrospect for having the fortune of being produced by “the Sunbather guy” (even though numerous Deafheaven songs are longer than the complete running time of Of All Things).

column1: Of All Things’ “Bride of Usher” was typical of that record’s dilettantism
column2: Joyce Manor playing a Smiths song by cribbing Johnny Marr’s leads and their rhythm section’s bounce; it felt as much of a cover as their actual take on the Buggles. The remarkable “Falling In Love Again” reverses and imagines if the Smiths wrote a Joyce Manor song—Tony Hoffer (Beck
column3: M83
column4: Air) adds a glycerine sheen to the slashing guitar chords and maxes Johnson’s vocals to a state of high school high drama; you can believe the title is being played straight or you can hear lines of Moz-like ambivalence (“Hope you don’t think that I care/ ‘Cause I do I just don’t know if I should feel this bad about you”) as being par for Joyce Manor: falling in love again is just the first step to the preferred resting state of falling out.

column1: This is how Joyce Manor operates: in the past
column2: beach communities
column3: toothaches and model train sets were merely symbols and mirrors for Johnson’s infinite sadness.  So while “End of the Summer”
column4: “Heated Swimming Pool”
column5: and “Heart Tattoo” are indicative of Joyce Manor’s suburban purview and are about the exact things they promise
column6: Johnson’s subtle and powerful insight allows him to expose new angles and multitudes in the mundane. “The Jerk” is
column7: yes
column8: about being a jerk and also watching the titular movie and learning “that stuff don't work."" In both “Christmas Card” and “Heart Tattoo”
column9: love can only be legitimized by pain—“I want it to hurt really bad/ That’s how I’ll know it’s real.” Johnson’s lyrics are conversational
column10: kegside and half-pipe ruminations taking on a heft and layered meaning that likely escapes everyone involved until they’ve had a chance to mull them over alone: “Never really had a drug phase/ So you think you’re fucking miserable now?”
column11: “I always knew you'd join the army
column12: ”  “I wish you would’ve died in high school/ So you could be somebody’s idol.”

column1: But if you want to hear Never Hungover Again as a summer record
column2: Joyce Manor mask their depressive streak with chiming
column3: fake 12-string riffs
column4: midtempo jangle
column5: group harmonies
column6: and basically everything that can be crammed into pop-punk without turning it into plain ol’ “indie rock”. Most bands working on a two-minute time limit tend to strip things down to the most rudimentary aspects and Joyce Manor can do that—the strict tense verse/explosive chorus template of “Victoria” is proof enough
column7: though it’s an outlier that reflects how unconventional the band’s songwriting is throughout. The velocity of Never Hungover Again has an illusory effect where you can hear these songs as having been isolated from lengthier ones— the strange riff that bisects “Schley” sounds like it was excised from a long-winded solo
column8: “Catalina Fight Song” is a 64-second perpetual crescendo that’s missing the expected
column9: vestigial four-minute run-up
column10: and “Falling in Love Again” churns tempestuously through near shoegaze synth ambience without ever hitting a predictable peak.
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Upon first listen
column12: the brevity of Never Hungover Again
column13: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> can sound less effective than
column14: say
column15: trying to hammer to home a chorus for the third time
column16: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">. But once you stop trying to label what should be a hook and focus on what is
column17: the ingenuity of each song’s design and the ear-turning nature of every maneuver speaks to Never Hungover Again's inexhaustible quality
column18: the kind of album you can play three times in a row without any part wearing out its welcome.

column1: Yet
column2: the broad appeal of this record somehow makes it a more precarious sell than something that can be easily pegged; pop-punk literalists may reflexively hear the slick production as a betrayal and compliments such as “smart” or “crafty” as backhanded against its visceral
column3: pleasure-seeking genre
column4: similar to “conscious rap” or “intelligent dance music”. Meanwhile
column5: it may be seen by indie fans as less substantial than Perfect Pussy

column7: White Lung
column8: Cloud Nothings
column9: and <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/31939-the-hotelier"">the Hotelier

column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> Joyce Manor make punk music for the other 99% of waking life when you're not functioning at peak intensity—for getting drunk
column12: being bored
column13: falling in love
column14: feeling like shit
column15: and wondering if your best days are behind you before heading out to a pool party you're pretty stoked about. The optimal balance of maturity and immaturity is right there in the title
column16: so throw on Never Hungover Again when you’re still looking to get into dumb shit
column17:
but you just want to be smarter about it.

Liam Betson jams a lot of words into the first album under his own name and one in particular stands out: ""Depression."" It's a big
column2: sticky noun
column3: clinical
column4: embarrassing to say
column5: let alone sing. But he works it into the penultimate song on The Cover of Hunter
column6: ""Made From Tin""
column7: naming the illness the ""guts and gore"" of an allegorical body that's also tethered by anxiety and whipped by insecurity. The song
column8: one of the record's fastest
column9: fills the space between its shaky guitar strokes with patient breaths of clarinet. At the chorus
column10: Betson borrows the vocal lilt Conor Oberst used on the Bright Eyes deep cut ""Amy in the White Coat"". ""For you
column11: the world is poorly lit
column12: he sings
column13: ""so by nightfall
column14: you're used to it.""

column1: Not every lyricist is agile enough to be this blunt. Furious and mournful in turn
column2: The Cover of Hunter navigates a hot
column3: blurry headspace
column4: the kind of slow-burning panic that corners you into the back of your own skull. Betson barely keeps the quiver in his voice under control as he wrings out his catalog of thick and heady lyrics. A former guitarist for Titus Andronicus (Patrick Stickles guests here on ""X"")
column5: he's inherited that band's feel for dynamics. Songs glide
column6: then crumple. The eight-minute opener ""I Can't Tell If You're Looking At Me"" kicks from a mellow strum into a bout of inflamed rock
column7: all the while standing on just a handful of chords. Betson's careful with the notes he lets into his space. He'd rather see how far a simple progression can stretch than try to expand upon it. He begins Hunter with the same gall it took for Built to Spill to start off You In Reverse with ""Goin' Against Your Mind""
column8: a nine-minute song made of just two chords.

column1: ""Cop Car"" is another sprawler
column2: one with so much space under its roof that it starts to breed its own ecosystem. Betson's unsure voice calculates its internal logic; he watches his feelings shift in color from lavender to blue
column3: watches his love transform from beautiful to pure. I don't know why purity excludes beauty
column4: but in his voice I can feel the tension between the two. I can feel how sad it is that the last hints of red have dripped from him.

column1: At times
column2: Betson's words bunch up on him. On the tight and fiery ""Pocket Knife""
column3: he moves from imagining himself as an idol
column4: a doll
column5: and a decaying concrete slab to just imagining ""what's possible""—then he repeats ""what's possible"" so many times its meaning starts to drain. Later
column6: he saturates ""The Primordial Will"" with the phrase ""sobbing in my bed"" until the words become architectural
column7: a haven
column8: both comforting and claustrophobic. Betson drags the same pleasure out of language that you get from a riff looping around itself.

column1: As rich in words as it is
column2: The Cover of Hunter can grow dense to the point of alienation. Some clusters
column3: like the one at the end of the third person flash fiction ""X""
column4: don't quite make it out of the universe where they're conceived. Two film samples on the opener and closer also crack the album's fever. It doesn't help that the first sample is the same one that How to Dress Well used on Total Loss
column5: a clip from the film Streetwise that forges an unnecessary portal between the two records. But that's a minor distraction. Betson strings his nerves taut here
column6: straining for the better part of an hour not to fray. Words tumble out of him like he's trying to talk away the ennui
column7: trying to get something
column8: anything
column9:
to stick to someone besides himself. The Cover of Hunter keeps busy in order to smother its loneliness. It's the kind of desperation worth reveling in.

Trepaneringsritualen is the solo project of Swedish noise artist Thomas Ekelund
column2: known previously for his work with Dead Letters Spell Out Dead Words
column3: Nullvoid
column4: and Th. Tot. He’s kept awfully busy in the years following the project’s 2008 inception
column5: releasing or appearing on a total of 17 albums
column6: EPs
column7: and compilations (most notably on split releases with Deathstench and Sutekh Hexen). His latest work
column8: Perfection & Permanence
column9: was recently released by UK institution Cold Spring
column10: and marks his most strangely listenable output yet.

column1: Trepaneringsritualen christens itself “Götisk Dödsindustri”
column2: or ""death industrial""
column3: and the project delivers on thats promise by saturating Ekelund’s scrapings with gloomy
column4: gothic atmospheres and a heavy ritual ambient influence. The songs are molded upon burly loops that shudder and sway beneath Ekelund’s perpetually mutating vocals. Laden with distortion and effects
column5: hints of melody pulse ominously beneath the heavy synth lines and bludgeoning rhythmic core. It’s disturbing and appealing in equal measure
column6: and its droning characteristics lend an almost psychedelic quality to some of the longer
column7: more convoluted passages that litter tracks like the murky “Liken Ingen Jord Vill Svälja”.

column1: “Venerated & Despised” opens the album carefully
column2: lulling the listener into a false sense of security before revealing the true horrors it holds. There’s no lack of aggression on tracks like the menacing “Alone/A/Cross/Abyss” or the genuinely frightening “Castrate Christ”
column3: which finds Ekelund’s vocals devolving into a nasty reptilian croak buried under noxious waves of distortion and reverb. Minimalist interlude “39 Lashes” offers a brief respite before the hoarse
column4: repetitive abrasion of “The Seventh Man” kicks in. Even the relatively restrained “A Black Egg” seeks to unnerve with its skittering percussion
column5: hovering
column6: ghostly loops
column7: and Ekelund’s strident spoken meditations on spectres in black and depravity.  The songs are quite short
column8: only surpassing the five minute mark on the ultra-distorted closing hellscape of “He Who Is My Mirror.”

column1: Unlike so many projects that labor beneath the wide banner of power electronics
column2: Trepaneringsritualen overlooks humanity’s sickness and instead concerns itself with matters of magick
column3: religion
column4: and the occult. The ritualistic feel to much of Ekelund’s output is no accident
column5: and Perfection & Permanence delves bone-deep into the dark recesses that fuel his need to create. Bleak
column6: apocalyptic dirges and mechanical menace abound. The most insidious aspect to this album lies within its accessibility and crossover appeal. As much as this project owes to noise and ambient music
column7: there are similarities to the most extreme metal as well
column8: especially in aesthetics and intent.

column1: Trepaneringsritualen often plays gigs in and around its native Sweden with occult-minded black metal bands like One Tail
column2: One Head
column3: and even appeared at this past year’s Inferno Metal Festival in Norway alongside Watain
column4: Blasphemy
column5: and Mgła. He performs covered in animal blood
column6: wild-eyed and violent; his long hair and beard stream with offal
column7: and his brutally confrontational approach leaves audience members reeling. Ekelund’s sworn allegiance to distortion
column8: decaying atmosphere
column9: and all-around depravity mirrors a good deal of what many of black metal’s best new bands are doing. The two genres have long enjoyed a cozy relationship
column10: and while Dominick Fernow’s now-defunct Hospital Productions enclave was perhaps the most obvious manifestation of the ties between raw black metal and harsh noise
column11: bands like Trepaneringsritualen make it crystal clear that its effects were felt far and wide. Perfection & Permanence is not a black metal record
column12: but it’s no coincidence that it has resonated so strongly with those who perform and consume black metal.

column1: Culumatively
column2: the album makes for a perversely satisfying experience. With Perfection & Permanence
column3: Ekelund has created that most chimeric of beasts: an accessible
column4: even what some might say commercial
column5: noise album. The shadowy world of power electronics and by extension death industrial can be tough for a novice to navigate
column6:
but Trepaneringsritualen makes for an excellent starting point.

column7: straight-up instrumentals have their use; a clean 90 seconds of any of these tracks should keep a DJ set near peak highs
column8: and every hip-hop radio station needs bumper music
column9: but don't expect them to jump to the foreground and demand your attention unless you're a mixtape rapper in freestyle-candidacy mode. The form here is more Instrumental University than the first FPUO
column10: with a bit of difference-splitting that still acknowledges the way he's molded trance divas and hoover synths into his own building blocks the way a previous generation's producers upended R&B.

column1: But that's only sort-of-bad news
column2: really
column3: and the moody-EDM vibe that his originals and remixes thrive off is still welcome enough. Tracks like ""Don't Pretend 1.5"" (Super8 & Tab's ""Black Is Back"" sifted through a foggy trap drumroll) and ""Ghost Story"" (a canny midtempo gothification of JES' ""Ghost (Deepsky Club Mix)"") pull some deep comedowns off minor-key melancholy
column4: noir counterpoints (and counterparts) to the more blissed-out purveyors of cloud rap. What's left during the less mind-blowing moments
column5: then
column6: is an opportunity to bask in Araab's craft
column7: pick up on how he still has a way of building and breaking down beats. Even his straight-up loops have a structure that's worth soaking in
column8: where wallpapery bass churn conceals artfully timed snare rolls and skyscraper synths are built on a foundation of piston-punch drums.

column1: Some of this material has already been successfully field-tested. ""Money Talks"" dropped as a Fabolous showcase on last year's Funkmaster Flex release Who You Mad At? Me or Yourself?
column2: and it made for a solid dose of vintage East Coast soul-loop flow accompaniment. ""Keep 100"" came out a couple months back as a Slaughterhouse cut
column3:
where its combination of spacey prog loops and concussion-causing drums made for a powerful shit-talk backdrop. And there are already a host of hopefuls who tackled ""Ghost Story"" and the Halloween car alarm banger ""Black Out"" when they were Soundcloud releases and made their own rap tracks over them. Maybe that's the real benefit of this record: motivating others into new levels of their own professionalism.

Over the last five years
column2: a group of Brooklyn musicians got together and recorded songs from a planned musical about a doomed interracial romance in a Pennsylvania coal mining town
column3: drawing inspiration from an old folk song taught to children in Quaker schools in the 1950s. No
column4: that’s not a summary of a special East Coast episode of “Portlandia”—this actually happened. Break Line the Musical is a song cycle written by Yeasayer vocalist/multi-instrumentalist Anand Wilder and pianist Maxwell Kardon
column5: and work on the project began a decade ago when they were fiddling around with a guitar and a banjo on a front porch in Philadelphia. They spent the next five years sporadically working on the songs and began putting them to tape in 2008; around that time
column6: details of the project emerged
column7: including the potential involvement of a gospel choir and plans to bring the production to the stage. The latter hasn’t happened yet
column8: and if the liner notes for this recording are to be believed
column9: the former never happened at all; regardless
column10: Wilder and Kardon’s sense of ambition is inherent.

column1: Considering Wilder’s main gig
column2: the mere existence of Break Line makes some sense. Yeasayer’s buzz-generating 2007 debut All Hour Cymbals leaned hard on proggy mysticism
column3: while the melted pop structures of Odd Blood from 2010 and Fragrant World from 2012 exuded a try-anything-once sense of adventurousness. While Fragrant World was a dismaying
column4: grayed mix of muddy electronics and moody vocals that smacked of a band getting lost in their own heads
column5: the initially divisive Odd Blood has aged better
column6: its high points an intriguing realization of the psychedelic-pop promise some of their peers once held. Even at their lowest
column7: Yeasayer have never sounded “normal
column8: ” and it’s that relative weirdness that has
column9: for the time being
column10: drawn the curious towards the band and their associated projects.

column1: In a recent interview with The T Magazine
column2: Wilder claims the pair looked to Celine Dion and music from the ‘70s for creative inspiration for this project. But despite those claims and his own pedigree as a moderately odd songwriter
column3: the most surprising thing about Break Line is how ordinary the project sounds. These 11 songs are almost disarmingly straightforward and simplistic
column4: adhering to the platitudes and rigid structures of a high school musical. From the harmonica that kicks off “Coal Into Diamonds”
column5: featuring vocals from Aku Orraca-Tetteh of synth-proggers Dragons of Zynth
column6: it’s apparent that Wilder and Kardon weren’t interested in taking risks. But even after discarding any expectations brought to the table while approaching the project
column7: Break Line is as an exceptionally dull collection of songs
column8: with flickers of hammy theatricality weighed down by leaden arrangements that sound boring even by the standards set by modern self-important faux-indie music.

column1: Heard as an album
column2: the mid-tempo bombast and insufferable balladry of Break Line coalesces into flavorless mush
column3: so maybe it’s better to approach it as a musical with a cohesive narrative. But it's no better on that level. Beyond the details already provided in the lead-up to the album’s release
column4: few lyrics suggest a narrative—Suckers’ Quinn Walker plaintively singing about blowing up coal mines over the folksy shuffle of “They’re Stealing Our Coal”
column5: the ruminations on strikebreaking and lynching uttered by that same band’s Austin Fisher over the colorless plod of “Better to Die”. But even with a lyric sheet on hand
column6: it’s impossible to understand what
column7: exactly
column8: Break Line is about.

column1: Whatever sense of story exists comes from the rotating cast of vocalists: In addition to Walker
column2: Fisher
column3: Kardon
column4: and Wilder
column5: there’s Yeasayer co-lead singer Chris Keating
column6: Vampire Weekend’s Rostam Batmanglij
column7: Dirty Projectors’ Haley Dekle
column8: and Man Man’s Honus Honus
column9: among others. (MGMT's James Richardson and Delicate Steve contribute instrumentally
column10: but you can’t hear either in the music’s beige Americana.) With the exception of Wilder
column11: who is painfully awkward on “Wedding Day”
column12: none of these vocalists embarrass themselves. Honus Honus
column13: in particular
column14: has never sounded more at home than he does barking about “bombs in the mineshaft” over the coffee-shop blues of “It Doesn’t Seem Right”
column15: a pairing so hilariously on-the-nose it scans as unintentional comedy.

column1: The most notable contributors to Break Line are Yeasayer themselves. Three-quarters of the band’s current lineup pitches in
column2: along with former member Jason Trammell. And while it’d be unfair to think of this record as the proper follow-up to Fragrant World
column3: Wilder’s recent claims that the band will be taking a more organic approach to their next album is
column4: in the face of this collection’s plain-faced blahs
column5: disheartening. For now
column6: though
column7: Break Line is a musical without an audience
column8:
and its creators might be better off if it fails to find one.

Honeyblood’s Thrift Shop EP was the stuff of serendipitous discoveries. The EP—basically a cassette single
column2: B-side and all—was recorded in a bathroom and sounds as such
column3: but its lyrics were at turns sharp and swooning
column4: with just enough charm breaking through the lo-fi roar. The band's members
column5: Glaswegians Stina Tweeddale (Boycotts) and Shona McVicar (Partwindpartwolf)
column6: met at a show both acts were playing and bonded over being women in their respective bands—in Tweeddale’s case
column7: the only woman in the band—as well as the music they grew up with. Thrift Shop's crunchy cover of The Innocence Mission’s “The Girl on My Left”—an inspired choice from a 1990s act with a devoted cult fanbase—spoke to both connective threads.

column1: Honeyblood have since signed to Fat Cat and scrubbed out the static with producer Peter Katis (Interpol
column2: the National); inevitably
column3: the duo have picked up a slew of comparisons to acts of the past (the Breeders
column4: Throwing Muses
column5: Hole) that Honeyblood have also mentioned as influences. However
column6: the band has no shortage of current-day peers
column7: from hypermelodic rock acts like Best Coast
column8: countrymates Camera Obscura
column9: Speedy Ortiz
column10: and Courtney Barnett (whom Honeyblood opened for). So it can be hard to hear the duo's self-titled debut on its own terms
column11: but Honeyblood is far from pastiche: they don’t sound that much like their influence
column12: except perhaps in how they arrange their harmonies or in short three-second bursts. The first bars of “Choker”
column13: in particular

column1: One part of ‘90s indie lineage that usually goes unmentioned among the nostalgics is that the era's albums tended to dissolve into filler in the back third
column2: and Honeyblood is no exception. Just looking at the album's tracklist
column3: you can almost pinpoint the spot where they’ll break the monotony with an uptempo cut—in this case
column4: the clipped exasperation and petulant shout-along of “All Dragged Up”—but for the most part
column5: Honeyblood admirably sidesteps the potential pitfalls. Some bands record lo-fi albums as a statement of purpose; others because that’s all they could afford. Honeyblood were previously in the latter position
column6: and as a result their debut doesn’t sound overproduced as much as it does properly heightened
column7: like a well-developed photograph.  The lovelorn “Fall Forever” melts on record like a sugarcube
column8: “No Spare Key” and single “Bud” receive a clean frame around their lyrics
column9: “Killer Bangs” is properly raucous
column10: and the quieter “Super Rat” is gracefully produced
column11: with guitars that initially sound like little pirouettes escalating the song to the level of ripping contempt: “SCUM! BAG! SLEAZE! SLIME! BALL! GREASE!”

column1: As you might imagine from that exultation
column2: Honeyblood is populated by the canonical post-riot-grrrl cast of characters: asshole dudes
column3: and the women exasperated or over them in the most cathartic ways. But though Tweeddale’s still working through growing pains as a lyricist—for every great opening salvo
column4: there’s a throat-clearing hedge—Honeyblood’s got a sense of voice some debut acts would be lucky to possess. “Choker”
column5: in particular
column6: feints past platitudes and scumball-sleaze dude clichés to become something more layered; it was inspired by <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bloody_Chamber"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Angela Carter’s story “The Bloody Chamber
column7: ” about a bride marrying a man implied to be the Marquis de Sade
column8: whose wedding gift is a choker of “flashing crimson jewels round [her] throat
column9: bright as arterial blood”; the song
column10: accordingly
column11: whiplashes from hooky to doomy to unnervingly placid. It’s not exactly a dark song
column12: though
column13: which is key
column14: as the best moments on Honeyblood work in complex emotions.

column1: “Biro” is the most wistful track on the album
column2: a late-summer wash that sounds gorgeous on record. It possesses the record's most lasting hook
column3: as well as its most indelible line: “All the pain you’ve been through will be the making of you.” It works both as something to take to heart and a to-date career statement
column4: as the making of Honeyblood turned out all right
column5:
after all.

Before disbanding earlier this year
column2: the Brooklyn trio Mr. Dream released an album and an EP that advocated enthusiasm over originality. Knowing that vocalist/guitarist Adam Moerder and drummer Nick Sylvester are music critics (both have written for Pitchfork and elsewhere) made that exultation in musical influences even sweeter: these were music geeks
column3: geeking out about the stuff they love
column4: in song form. It wasn’t all as reductive as that
column5: though; there were still touches of sarcasm
column6: cynicism
column7: and slyness found in those two releases
column8: a self-awareness about the open appropriation of musical heroes. But with the group’s posthumous full-length
column9: Ultimate in Luxury
column10: that swirl of perk and punk has turned a little sour.

column1: The loving pastiches of indie-rock past are still there
column2: but Mr. Dream has flipped the calendar forward dramatically. “Making Muscles” slips
column3: shudders
column4: and shivers in a gut-churning approximation of Chavez’s art-drone lope. It’s ’90s alt-rock turned in on itself until it knots up into prog
