column6: despite Moerder’s attempt to stab some of the prickly atmospherics of Public Image Ltd.’s “Theme” into the mix—an element the track doesn’t have room for
column7: let alone need.

column1: Ultimate in Luxury inches backward from there
column2: but only briefly. Bits of Brian Eno and David Bowie emerge
column3: particularly on “Cheap Heat
column4: ” an adrenaline-injected take on the icicle jangle of ""Needle in the Camel’s Eye”—complete with Moerder trying to hit the stars with his high notes—and the cheeky call for “rock ’n’ roll patricide” on “Bloodmobile”
column5: as if driving the nail in Bowie’s “Rock ’n’ Roll Suicide.” It’s clever
column6: and it says nothing. Even worse
column7: it that frame of reference is at odds with the early-00s dance-punk of “Fringy Slider”—which
column8: regardless of the Pavement-esque name
column9: approximates the sashay of early Franz Ferdinand—and “Work Faster”
column10: which boogies as clumsily as a Dismemberment Plan song dressed as a !!! song for Halloween. Bassist Matt Morello unfurls some monstrous
column11: art-funk low-end
column12: but Sylvester’s half-hearted hand with disco rhythms somehow has the power to make a drum kit sound sarcastic.

column1: Sincerity is as much of a false virtue as originality
column2: and Mr. Dream know it
column3: maybe too well. Scattershot instead of eclectic
column4: tentative instead of thoughtful
column5: tracks such as the Girls Against Boys-leaning “Loud Tools” and the jittery “Sad Bastard Unit” can’t seem to decide if they even believe in themselves
column6: let alone what they might be trying to convey. That is
column7: until the album’s final three songs. “Watched It Wrong”
column8: “Just Results”
column9: and “Mouth Off” are catchy
column10: dynamic
column11: and astringent in all the right ways and places. Moerder’s dissonant string-bends
column12: plucked straight out of “Scentless Apprentice”
column13: actually click into place on “Watched It Wrong”
column14: as does his Mark E. Smith snarl-croon on “Mouth Off.” Inspiration and perspiration finally meet
column15: mingle
column16: and melt.

column1: Those three songs would be more suited to the kickoff of their next album than the end of this one; it’s a shame that album won’t come. Sometimes the only thing separating a middling band from a magnificent one isn’t just the ability to write and play strong songs
column2: but to do so consistently and convincingly. If Ultimate in Luxury had been able to fully seize and own that potential
column3:
Mr. Dream might have left a better aftertaste.

For all of its bluster of rebellion and individuality
column2: metal remains a particularly conservative genre. There are entire labels affiliated with the genre that are dedicated to the idea of preserving the old
column3: signing a glut of bands that
column4: at best
column5: unfavorably smack of the innovators they're so slavishly devoted. So California duo Wreck and Reference provide a radical vision of what the metal of the future might look like with their latest album
column6: Want. Their version of metal does not have guitars
column7: bass
column8: leather
column9: devil horns
column10: or any other metal tropes; their arsenal is comprised of  a sampler
column11: drums
column12: voice
column13: and bottomless despair.

column1: Limited instrumentation does not stop Wreck and Reference from bringing in a range of dark sounds
column2: as they have a habit of flipping their own script quickly. This is evident from the smooth transition from the industrial squeals of opener “Corpse Museum” into the piano-driven “Apollo Beneath The Whip”
column3: or the shift from the dimly-lit lurch of “Bankrupt” to their interpretation of doom metal on “A Glass Cage For An Animal”. Want maintains a consistent atmosphere throughout
column4: excelling even as it broadens and warps the definition of metal. Felix Skinner
column5: who handles electronics and some vocals
column6: conjures up the closest thing to big
column7: blocky riffs that an experimental effort like this can offer
column8: feeding them through dehumanized filters.

column1: While Wreck and Reference are redefining metal
column2: “Whip” is their most metal song in a sense
column3: mainly because of its enveloping buildup. As drummer Ignat Frege gets busier
column4: Skinner’s piano sounds more nervous
column5: and his vocals sound grander in their misery
column6: resembling a charismatic preacher that wants to swallow you in the greater void. The songs on Want are too diverse for Wreck and Reference to possess a “signature song
column7: ” but “Whip” deserves to become one of their staples.

column1: For a band driven by electronics
column2: it might seem that using a drum machine would make the most sense
column3: Frege serves as both a compliment and a foil to Skinner
column4: amplifying his movements without going overboard. He also takes a freer approach to drumming on Want
column5: removing blast beats from his repertoire; on “Museum”
column6: he flirts with the technique but ends up holding back just enough to lend a looseness that works with Skinner's electronic freakouts. Frege's cymbal rides on “Bankrupt” are tense
column7: making Skinner’s howls and spare electronic hums loom even more dreadfully. It's often perceived that hitting the snare and double bass hard and fast is a surefire way to sound “heavy”
column8: but Frege challenges that notion by doing more with less. His performance is such a secret weapon that it’s quite missed on “Machine of Confusion”
column9: an ambient break that is the only song not to contain drums.

column1: Amidst the boundless experimentation
column2: there's one flickering light of traditional metal on Want. Closing track “Apologies” features swells that are oddly reminiscent of the opening to ""Cathedral”
column3: Eddie Van Halen’s solo guitar piece on 1982’s Diver Down where he gorgeously replicated a church organ. ""Apologies"" is the closest thing the album comes to providing a comforting presence
column4: in terms of both lushness and familiarity
column5: but it’s still buried beneath the overbearing existentialism that Skinner and Frege traffic in
column6: its beauty interrupted by faint snare rolls and creeping static.

column1: Most metal groups are either blind to the future or are scared shitless by it. Wreck and Reference take on what’s on the horizon
column2: and while most metal groups are content to yell that they don’t give a fuck
column3: Skinner and Frege put it into principle too. Metal claims to be challenging
column4: but on Want
column5: Wreck and Reference go one step further
column6:
challenging the genre's practicioners to pull themselves out of complacency.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20751/homepage_large.29de1326.jpg|Blue Bell Knoll|785.0|Cocteau Twins|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['4AD']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|1988|2016-06-11 16:35:26.480212|"

It’s impossible to make out most of the lyrics on the title track to the Cocteau Twins’ 1990 album
column2: Heaven or Las Vegas. Over Robin Guthrie’s shimmery
column3: shivery guitar strum
column4: singer Elizabeth Fraser bends her notes into mysterious shapes. She coos and squawks
column5: mews and barks
column6: murmurs and wails
column7: as though singing in a new language. One minute she sounds like an opera singer
column8: the next like a mother baby-talking to her new daughter. The effect can be dizzying
column9: and the illegibility of her performance only makes it more
column10: not less
column11: human. Yet
column12: a few words do stand out
column13: primarily that title phrase: “Heaven or Las Vegas.” The Cocteau Twins’ music has always sounded otherworldly
column14: and their many fans would certainly describe it—and rightly so—as heavenly.

column1: But Las Vegas? It stands out as an odd
column2: jarring reference. Their fantastical music would seem to brook nothing quite so earthly
column3: so garish
column4: so thisworldly as Sin City
column5: which hauls unlikely baggage into “Heaven or Las Vegas”: gambling
column6: corruption
column7: tacky tourism
column8: and cheesy crooning. But if we forget everything we know about the city and reduce Las Vegas to its atomic elements—millions upon billions of lights—perhaps we might see heaven in the radiance. This is essentially how the Cocteau Twins’ music works: Fraser’s voice doesn’t behave the way a pop singer’s voice typically behaves
column9: nor does Guthrie’s guitar deliver the usual melody or rhythm. Along with bass player/keyboardist Simon Raymonde
column10: whose contributions shouldn’t be discounted
column11: they found new ways to use old instruments in the 1980s
column12: in the process devising a unique and wholly beguiling sound. If punk had chased beauty instead of glorious ugliness
column13: if goth had emphasized light rather than fetishize darkness
column14: those movements might have sounded like the Cocteau Twins
column15: who had contemporaries but no real peers. Somehow
column16: there is immense aggression and subversion in the sheer loveliness of this music
column17: which makes it more than just art for art’s sake.

column1: Most people in America
column2: however
column3: didn’t know any of this in the 1980s
column4: as the decade was almost over before the band officially released any music in the States. Ever since Guthrie and Fraser had shown up on 4AD Records’ doorstep like orphaned goths in 1982
column5: the Scots quickly developed both a sound and an audience in the UK
column6: culminating in the 1984 album Treasure
column7: which was the first to truly capture the wildness of Fraser’s vocals and Guthrie’s ambitiously skewed arrangements. By the late '80s
column8: they were successful enough to play increasingly cavernous London venues
column9: to build their own 24-track studio
column10: to rent practice space in Pete Townshend’s building. There was also friction between Fraser and Guthrie
column11: who had been a couple throughout the life of the Cocteau Twins. Due to the pressure of the business and especially to Guthrie’s rampant drug abuse
column12: their marriage was fraying. But they still made beautiful music together
column13: and they signed a deal with Capitol Records to distribute their fifth album
column14: 1988’s Blue Bell Knoll
column15: in America.

column1: That album is one of two getting a deluxe vinyl reissue this week via 4AD. It’s certainly a pivotal album in their career
column2: but not necessarily one of their best. Did the Cocteau Twins tame some of their wilder elements for American audiences? Or did the prospect of reaching a whole new continent of ears even enter their minds when they recorded these songs? Blue Bell Knoll sounds minimalist
column3: workmanlike at times
column4: never quite matching the rapturous invention of Treasure. It’s their airiest
column5: cottoniest album
column6: with an enticing use of space on the production but with hooks that sound oddly restrained. As a result
column7: it can sound as monochromatic as its album cover.

column1: On the other hand
column2: its general dismissal by critics and fans as a lesser Cocteau Twins album may have less to do with the album itself and more to do with the fact that it is bookended by better and more ecstatically creative works. There are moments of disarming beauty on Blue Bell Knoll—the melting keyboards on “Cico Buff”
column3: the lush vocal layering of “Athol-Brose”
column4: the shooting-stars opening of “A Kissed Out Red Floatboat”
column5: Raymonde’s syncopated bass trudge of “The Itchy Glowblo Blow”
column6: the whatever that is at the end of “Spooning Good Singing Gum” (I think it might be a herd of lovelorn goats playing saxophones). But the standout is “Carolyn’s Fingers”
column7: which would become the Cocteau Twins’ first American single. The band never utilized its rhythm section to better effect: Against Guthrie’s crisp guitar line
column8: that churning momentum pushes Fraser’s vocals to greater and greater heights
column9: her unexpected swoops and eloquently rolled consonants creating a bewildering indie-pop aria.

column1: Even as the band soared commercially and creatively
column2: personally they suffered. Between the release of Blue Bell Knoll and the recording of Heaven or Las Vegas
column3: Fraser gave birth to the couple’s first child
column4: a daughter
column5: yet Guthrie remained deep in the throes of drug addiction
column6: which made him paranoid and angry. Raymonde mourned the death of his father. Suddenly the stakes for the Cocteau Twins seemed impossibly high. “Fraser named the album Heaven or Las Vegas [as] a suggestion of music versus commerce
column7: or perhaps a gamble
column8: one last throw of the dice
column9: ” Martin Aston writes in Facing the Other Way: The Story of 4AD
column10: implying that the band was close to imploding.

column1: Instead
column2: they turned all that turmoil and uncertainty into the best album of their career. Heaven or Las Vegas explodes in Technicolor from the first melty guitar chords on “Cherry-Coloured Funk”. Every note sounds like a new and richer shade of indigo and scarlet and violet than the previous one
column3: and it doesn’t fade until closer “Frou-Frou Foxes in Midsummer Fires” descends into silence. If Blue Bell Knoll is spare and ambient
column4: Heaven is supersaturated: lush without being vulgar
column5: luxuriant without being indulgent. Tellingly
column6: some lyrics bubble up to the surface
column7: often loaded with personal meaning: “cherry
column8: ” “perfection
column9: ” “burn this madhouse down.” On a song called “Pitch the Baby”
column10: ostensibly written for—or at least sung to—the couple’s infant daughter
column11: Fraser repeats
column12: “I’m so happy to care for you
column13: I only want to love you
column14: ” as a sweet lullaby. We may not always be able to understand her lyrics
column15: but that doesn’t mean they’re not important. In fact
column16: her lyrics would never be more vital or confessional than they are on Heaven or Las Vegas
column17: which lends the music added emotional and conceptual heft.

column1: What’s particularly remarkable about the album is how compact it is: All but two of these 10 tracks clock in around three-and-a-half minutes
column2: and the whole thing is over and done with in a mere 38 minutes. That succinctness may have something to do with Raymonde’s increasing role in the group. His bass playing
column3: especially on “Pitch the Baby” and “Fotzepolitic”
column4: not only adds to the texture and
column5: yes
column6: the groove of the music
column7: but also gingerly anchors these songs: He prevents them from flying off into the ether
column8: but never lets them grow rigid or staid. The result is an album that perfectly balances ambition with accessibility. Together
column9: these two releases—which were their last for 4AD—present the Cocteau Twins as first and foremost a pop band
column10:
and pop rarely sounds as transformative and as transfixing as it does here.

column1:
1|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20752/homepage_large.17479e50.jpg|Heaven or Las Vegas|785.0|Cocteau Twins|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['4AD']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|1990|2016-06-11 16:35:26.480212|"

It’s impossible to make out most of the lyrics on the title track to the Cocteau Twins’ 1990 album
column2: Heaven or Las Vegas. Over Robin Guthrie’s shimmery
column3: shivery guitar strum
column4: singer Elizabeth Fraser bends her notes into mysterious shapes. She coos and squawks
column5: mews and barks
column6: murmurs and wails
column7: as though singing in a new language. One minute she sounds like an opera singer
column8: the next like a mother baby-talking to her new daughter. The effect can be dizzying
column9: and the illegibility of her performance only makes it more
column10: not less
column11: human. Yet
column12: a few words do stand out
column13: primarily that title phrase: “Heaven or Las Vegas.” The Cocteau Twins’ music has always sounded otherworldly
column14: and their many fans would certainly describe it—and rightly so—as heavenly.

column1: But Las Vegas? It stands out as an odd
column2: jarring reference. Their fantastical music would seem to brook nothing quite so earthly
column3: so garish
column4: so thisworldly as Sin City
column5: which hauls unlikely baggage into “Heaven or Las Vegas”: gambling
column6: corruption
column7: tacky tourism
column8: and cheesy crooning. But if we forget everything we know about the city and reduce Las Vegas to its atomic elements—millions upon billions of lights—perhaps we might see heaven in the radiance. This is essentially how the Cocteau Twins’ music works: Fraser’s voice doesn’t behave the way a pop singer’s voice typically behaves
column9: nor does Guthrie’s guitar deliver the usual melody or rhythm. Along with bass player/keyboardist Simon Raymonde
column10: whose contributions shouldn’t be discounted
column11: they found new ways to use old instruments in the 1980s
column12: in the process devising a unique and wholly beguiling sound. If punk had chased beauty instead of glorious ugliness
column13: if goth had emphasized light rather than fetishize darkness
column14: those movements might have sounded like the Cocteau Twins
column15: who had contemporaries but no real peers. Somehow
column16: there is immense aggression and subversion in the sheer loveliness of this music
column17: which makes it more than just art for art’s sake.

column1: Most people in America
column2: however
column3: didn’t know any of this in the 1980s
column4: as the decade was almost over before the band officially released any music in the States. Ever since Guthrie and Fraser had shown up on 4AD Records’ doorstep like orphaned goths in 1982
column5: the Scots quickly developed both a sound and an audience in the UK
column6: culminating in the 1984 album Treasure
column7: which was the first to truly capture the wildness of Fraser’s vocals and Guthrie’s ambitiously skewed arrangements. By the late '80s
column8: they were successful enough to play increasingly cavernous London venues
column9: to build their own 24-track studio
column10: to rent practice space in Pete Townshend’s building. There was also friction between Fraser and Guthrie
column11: who had been a couple throughout the life of the Cocteau Twins. Due to the pressure of the business and especially to Guthrie’s rampant drug abuse
column12: their marriage was fraying. But they still made beautiful music together
column13: and they signed a deal with Capitol Records to distribute their fifth album
column14: 1988’s Blue Bell Knoll
column15: in America.

column1: That album is one of two getting a deluxe vinyl reissue this week via 4AD. It’s certainly a pivotal album in their career
column2: but not necessarily one of their best. Did the Cocteau Twins tame some of their wilder elements for American audiences? Or did the prospect of reaching a whole new continent of ears even enter their minds when they recorded these songs? Blue Bell Knoll sounds minimalist
column3: workmanlike at times
column4: never quite matching the rapturous invention of Treasure. It’s their airiest
column5: cottoniest album
column6: with an enticing use of space on the production but with hooks that sound oddly restrained. As a result
column7: it can sound as monochromatic as its album cover.

column1: On the other hand
column2: its general dismissal by critics and fans as a lesser Cocteau Twins album may have less to do with the album itself and more to do with the fact that it is bookended by better and more ecstatically creative works. There are moments of disarming beauty on Blue Bell Knoll—the melting keyboards on “Cico Buff”
column3: the lush vocal layering of “Athol-Brose”
column4: the shooting-stars opening of “A Kissed Out Red Floatboat”
column5: Raymonde’s syncopated bass trudge of “The Itchy Glowblo Blow”
column6: the whatever that is at the end of “Spooning Good Singing Gum” (I think it might be a herd of lovelorn goats playing saxophones). But the standout is “Carolyn’s Fingers”
column7: which would become the Cocteau Twins’ first American single. The band never utilized its rhythm section to better effect: Against Guthrie’s crisp guitar line
column8: that churning momentum pushes Fraser’s vocals to greater and greater heights
column9: her unexpected swoops and eloquently rolled consonants creating a bewildering indie-pop aria.

column1: Even as the band soared commercially and creatively
column2: personally they suffered. Between the release of Blue Bell Knoll and the recording of Heaven or Las Vegas
column3: Fraser gave birth to the couple’s first child
column4: a daughter
column5: yet Guthrie remained deep in the throes of drug addiction
column6: which made him paranoid and angry. Raymonde mourned the death of his father. Suddenly the stakes for the Cocteau Twins seemed impossibly high. “Fraser named the album Heaven or Las Vegas [as] a suggestion of music versus commerce
column7: or perhaps a gamble
column8: one last throw of the dice
column9: ” Martin Aston writes in Facing the Other Way: The Story of 4AD
column10: implying that the band was close to imploding.

column1: Instead
column2: they turned all that turmoil and uncertainty into the best album of their career. Heaven or Las Vegas explodes in Technicolor from the first melty guitar chords on “Cherry-Coloured Funk”. Every note sounds like a new and richer shade of indigo and scarlet and violet than the previous one
column3: and it doesn’t fade until closer “Frou-Frou Foxes in Midsummer Fires” descends into silence. If Blue Bell Knoll is spare and ambient
column4: Heaven is supersaturated: lush without being vulgar
column5: luxuriant without being indulgent. Tellingly
column6: some lyrics bubble up to the surface
column7: often loaded with personal meaning: “cherry
column8: ” “perfection
column9: ” “burn this madhouse down.” On a song called “Pitch the Baby”
column10: ostensibly written for—or at least sung to—the couple’s infant daughter
column11: Fraser repeats
column12: “I’m so happy to care for you
column13: I only want to love you
column14: ” as a sweet lullaby. We may not always be able to understand her lyrics
column15: but that doesn’t mean they’re not important. In fact
column16: her lyrics would never be more vital or confessional than they are on Heaven or Las Vegas
column17: which lends the music added emotional and conceptual heft.

column1: What’s particularly remarkable about the album is how compact it is: All but two of these 10 tracks clock in around three-and-a-half minutes
column2: and the whole thing is over and done with in a mere 38 minutes. That succinctness may have something to do with Raymonde’s increasing role in the group. His bass playing
column3: especially on “Pitch the Baby” and “Fotzepolitic”
column4: not only adds to the texture and
column5: yes
column6: the groove of the music
column7: but also gingerly anchors these songs: He prevents them from flying off into the ether
column8: but never lets them grow rigid or staid. The result is an album that perfectly balances ambition with accessibility. Together
column9: these two releases—which were their last for 4AD—present the Cocteau Twins as first and foremost a pop band
column10:
and pop rarely sounds as transformative and as transfixing as it does here.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20827/homepage_large.d66334af.jpg|Friends EP|32135.0|Seven Davis Jr.|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Classic']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:27.127431|"

While it might appear that dance music producer Samuel “Seven” Davis Jr. did a mushroom-like trick
column2: appearing overnight with the success of last year’s ecstatic vocal house track “One”
column3: it was actually the end result of an artist grinding in a variety of music genres for well over a decade. The Houston-born
column4: Los Angeles-based Davis Jr. was reared in the gospel world and played piano in blues clubs on the Third Coast
column5: but also spent time in the Bay Area
column6: where he purportedly ghostwrote lyrics for rappers and toured as a member of MC Hammer’s gospel choir.

column1: While the aforementioned gigs on his résumé suggest a knack for working in the background across many disciplines
column2: only in the last few years did his own words and music gain traction. Working with another L.A. producer Kutmah (since deported back to the UK) brought his Dâm-Funk-indebted demos to light as The Lost Tapes Vol. 1. With Friends
column3: his newest two-track single released on Derrick Carter and Luke Solomon’s Classic Records label
column4: Davis Jr. meets and exceeds the often mutually exclusive wallflower demands of pop and house music. As last year’s “One” and the more recent P.A.R.T.Y. EP from earlier this year have proven
column5: Davis Jr. is adept at crafting an infectious pop song and a body-tweaking beat
column6: making them both convene in joyous nexus. He touches upon bedroom funk
column7: old soul
column8: and underground house with equal aplomb. And judging by Life in Deep Space
column9: his e-folio of poems
column10: he’s as taken by cosmic turns of phrase as he is by a tight beat.

column1: Clocking in at 127 BPM
column2: “Friends” is built up from a mouth-hummed bassline that brings to mind Timbaland (and also serves as a rubber band stretching from doo-wop to Kenny Dixon Jr.). “Friends” expresses a sentiment familiar to fans of Michael Jackson’s “Working Day and Night” or even Mac DeMarco
column3: in that Davis Jr. works all week and looks forward to the weekend. There need not be a simpler chorus than: “It feels good to be/ Be with all my friends.” There’s echoing handclaps
column4: a simmering hi-hat
column5: and the gentlest scent of synths
column6: all held together by Davis Jr.’s almost blasé vocal delivery. That he can sound so casual on “Friends” is not a chance result
column7: as Davis is careful in his craftsmanship—how he spaces the track
column8: how his vocal blurs into the beat. One gets the impression that Davis Jr. could putter about his house humming to himself and come up with an enticing track.

column1: “Beautiful” clocks in at the same tempo as “Friends” but feels more hectic
column2: with keys
column3: thumps and vaporized vocals zooming about the field. He extends and teases out the line “Never gonna let ya go” with the kind of finesse that brings to mind the towering thrills of Vocalcity
column4: but Davis Jr.’s mindful to bring the pop payoff much sooner
column5: cooing “You’re so beautiful” in his finest Prince come-on (which makes sense
column6: considering he did a fine rendering of “Controversy” late last year). He utters that line right as spine-tingling synth arises.

column1: On the digital version of Friends
column2: he adds on a live edit of “One”–which is now a pricey single in the online market—which is as joyous a vocal house track as any I’ve heard in the past few years. It’s a love song about a special chemistry
column3: the chorus up-front and earnest: “Wassup with you and me?/ I’m thinking maybe you’re the one.” It’s a house track that doubles as a great pop song
column4:
the kick as giddy as a heart in the first palpitations of love.

"|19601.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19601-seven-davis-jr-friends-ep/|7.9|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20802/homepage_large.6bb67536.jpg|Here Comes Now|32369.0|Rioux|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Connect']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:27.721820|"

The idea of an album that aims to explore the relationship between electronic music and the creation of the universe comes across as heavy-handed
column2: ponderous
column3: and more than a little silly. It’s a relief
column4: then
column5: that Here Comes Now
column6: a collaboration between the Trinidad-born saxophonist and theoretical physicist Stephon Alexander and the Brooklyn electronic musician Erin Rioux
column7: only fulfills that last expectation. It’s light-hearted
column8: fun
column9: and on occasion
column10: very silly.

column1: Much of Here Comes Now takes the form of electro-powered free jazz
column2: and as a whole skips merrily by—a listener could be forgiven for not recognizing the album’s core concept (which is driven home by a track named for Stephen Hawking’s A Brief History of Time) on the first few spins. But Alexander isn’t a dilettante in either of his fields: he received his physics doctorate from Brown University and currently holds an associate professorship at Dartmouth
column3: and he also considers music
column4: particularly improvisational jazz
column5: an important element of his academic pursuits.

column1: Rioux's propulsive
column2: cheery beats give the album its momentum. The music mostly races forward with gently twinkling synths and drums
column3: punctuated by long saxophone solos and short riffs. Perhaps the most involved example of the duo's sound comes on the xylophone-incorporating “I Guess We’re Floating”. It features Arto Lindsay and possesses a great chorus
column4: which takes the shape of an elongated appeal to keeping faith and letting go.

column1: The silliness on Here Comes Now mostly comes from the lyrics
column2: which tend to take the form of mantras:  “I just want to be the person that I am in my mind
column3: ” “The light in you
column4: the darkness in you/ It’s all precious.”  These clichéd sentiments can grate
column5: but they’re also reassuring to hear emanating from someone as smart as Alexander. The album’s other weak spots come when Rioux and Alexander fail to balance each other out.  There may be a grounding scientific concept that helps to justify the existence of slower
column6: sax-heavy tracks like “Running from the Cosmos” and “Ornette’s Vortex”
column7: but their presence hurts the record’s pacing and threaten to relegate it to the realm of background music; Rioux’s influence is less obvious on these tracks
column8: and the music suffers for it.

column1: But even if Here Comes Now doesn’t always hold the listener’s attention
column2: it is extraordinarily pleasant as background music. Alexander investigates big questions for a living and the finesse he shows here
column3: in tandem with Rioux
column4:
allows the duo to ably sidestep expectations and deliver an album that fulfills the promise of its concept.

"|19576.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19576-rioux-stephon-alexander-here-comes-now/|7.2|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20753/homepage_large.d0cc9333.jpg|Sunburner|32352.0|United Waters|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bathetic']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:28.377352|"

The sound of United Waters is rock and roll submerged. The New York trio’s music is H20-logged and woozily off-speed
column2: as if they’ve been playing in the deep end so long their notes and beats have contracted a case of the bends. The resulting effect is simultaneously close and distant. Some individual elements
column3: like the looping guitar riffs and the machinistic drum beats
column4: feel close enough to touch. Yet every inch of Sunburner is muffled and drenched as if it's wearing a sweater in 100-degree weather; at times
column5: it resembles a Joy Division record played under a stack of mattresses.

column1: That sounds like a formula for a downer slog of an album
column2: but sealing United Waters’ songs in a claustrophobic envelope makes them more engaging. The way the wiry guitar lines creep toward the surface
column3: and the way Brian Sullivan’s doubled moans rise from the buried tunes like ghosts
column4: beckons you to dive for more. It’s a feat Sullivan is used to pulling off; his excellent noise-rock duo Mouthus spent most of the 2000s baking together layers of sound that you could spend hours peeling away. They became so skilled at it they could even turn a Fleetwood Mac song into a growling industrial cycle.

column1: Nothing on Sunburner is that abstract
column2: but United Waters isn't that radical a departure for Sullivan. He's long had a warped sense of time and an obsession with density
column3: and those traits persist despite these songs being ostensibly simpler than what Mouthus normally made. He indulges in a love of repeition
column4: riding out hooks and humming melodies until they attain the power of mantras. It’s so easy to be hypnotized by those loops that you might not realize how far the band has traveled until you’re suddenly adrift in one of their foamy crescendos. Their patience in crafting those waves makes the crests feel earned rather than gratuitous.

column1: That dedication also gives Sunburner an uncanny familiarity
column2: as inside all the reflecting echoes lie figures that feel elusively classic. The six-feet-under sonics overlap with the lo-fi rattle of Dirty Beaches
column3: but where Alex Zhang Hungtai’s tunes tend toward garage
column4: Sunburner feels more like smeared pop. The music here is also reminiscent of the point in Sightings’ career when they shed some clamor
column5: and Mark Morgan’s vocals went from desperate yell to eerie moan. But part of the fascination there was hearing the absence of all-out noise; with United Waters
column6: there’s nothing missing. The songs are enjoyable strictly as songs
column7: not so much as contrasts to what could be.

column1: So when the guitars twist into knots on “Turn On Your Century”
column2: or engines rev at the end of the title track
column3: or the rock turns to roll halfway through “Out of Flight”
column4: it’s not just impressive to behold—it’s fun to listen to as well. Granted
column5: that was also true of Mouthus’ best stuff
column6: but with Sunburner
column7:
it's not necessary to burrow into a genre or be attracted to a specific sensibility to get locked into the music. The songs are magnetic enough to do all the pulling for you.

"|19527.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19527-united-waters-sunburner/|7.7|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20849/homepage_large.fa2e7b46.jpg|Gangsta Stripper Music 2|32391.0|BeatKing|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-07-16 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:29.851398|"

Texas rapper BeatKing’s Gangsta Stripper Music 2 is in-your-face
column2: crude
column3: lowbrow rap music. For BeatKing—the self-professed “Club God”—the strip club is not just an inspiration
column4: but his entire milieu
column5: his kingdom. GSM2 is a triple-X-rated rap record
column6: where a song called “Smile” has nothing to do with the face; if you have trouble separating the attitudes professed in music from real life
column7: or are put off by graphic depictions of sex acts from aggressively macho personalities
column8: read no further. But if your main concern is one dimensional subject matter
column9: or the way BeatKing unapologetically re-upholsters current trends (the “We Dem Boyz” “Hol’ up! Hol’ up! Hol’ up!” chant
column10: or multiple uses of the Migos flow)
column11: don’t be dissuaded. These rap cliches are mere tools in the service of much more purposeful ends: personality
column12: wit
column13:
and a novel approach to sound and songwriting.

BeatKing is
column14: in essence
column15: a Houston punchline rapper making crunk records
column16: but he's one of the biggest rappers in Texas right now because the sum is so much more than those parts. For a record that holds onto all the formal elements of a Southern strip club record
column17: identifying the ephemeral gestures that comprise BeatKing’s persona can be a challenge. But from his punchlines to his barked delivery to the raunchy interludes (one skit is excerpted from a radio appearance
column18: in which a fan calls in with an offer for oral sex)
column19:
it’s the elusive spine of personality that makes Gangsta Stripper Music 2 a worthy listen.

At first
column20: BeatKing built his fanbase in the usual way: freestyling with friends
column21: distributing ”Sharpie-marked CDs”
column22: and hustling his wares to regional radio. But in 2011
column23: he hit upon a formula that propelled him to the top of Houston’s competitive rap food chain
column25: reactive rapping commentary on whichever shocking viral video made the rounds on social media that day. <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwtjIQ8z7Dc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“I wait until stupid shit happens
column26: ” he explained in the introduction to his ""Amber Cole Freestyle""
column27: “And then I freestyle about it.” The freestyles were like running Greek chorus commentary
column28: irreverent clowning not unlike the kind you’ll find on Twitter. He turns these records over quickly—he told Complex that it took him an hour to record his “Sharkeisha” freestyle. His rapping often resembles the Dozens
column29: and this think-on-your-feet humor is at the core of his rap style. On Gangsta Stripper Music 2
column30: this style is adapted to a stronger
column31:
more varied sonic canvas—although that improvisational edge is still present in his rapping.

BeatKing is large: everything about his music is constructed to emphasize mass and dimension. His voice—that gruff
column33: and he’s drawn to punchy flows
column34: like those of Migos or Lil Reese. His ‘drop’ is based upon the first two notes of the theme from Jaws. The 808-driven beats he chooses sound enormous and seem designed to imply physical presence; the mixtape’s climactic record “Club Godzilla” is most explicit in its size
column38: and roaring Godzilla effects. And then there’s his lyrics
column39: where mass is always in motion: “Throw that ass back
column40: like a boomerang.” Sound reverberates viscerally: “Four 15s hittin’
column41: I can feel the bass on my balls.” And then there’s a more mythic
column43:
flex forever.”

Although the music is belligerent
column44: his lyrics are playfully irreverent. His punchlines are the album’s Easter eggs
column45: the kind of lewd cracks delivered with a straight face for totally guilty
column47: as on ""Strip Club Trappin'"": “She throwin’ ass on Instagram in the hotel/ When she sucked my dick it made me happy like Pharrell”. (No need to go into how he makes “Babe Ruth” rhyme with “Babe Ruth.”) These punchlines
column49: lose a bit of their luster; the reason they’re so funny in his songs is how little attention he draws to them
column50: like an incidental byproduct of his craft. His bellowing delivery
column52:
don’t crack.

This off-the-cuff balance of bombast and humor proves that each is essential to the process. (On “Been Thru
column53: ” BeatKing goes for straightlaced seriousness—perhaps out of deference to the song’s role as a feature for H-Town legend Lil Keke—but abandons the rapper’s signature charm.) It’s also clear that a lot of forethought went into the record’s presentation. Conceptually
column54: Gangsta Stripper Music 2 flips through a variety of creative ideas without abandoning the overall BeatKing style—everything from the titanic “Clubgodzilla” beat to the way “Smile” repurposes Bell Biv Devoe’s hit “When Will I See You Smile Again?” for a song about a
column56:
different kind of smile.

“Stunt N!gga” swipes its hook from Birdman’s now-classic adlibs on Drake’s “The Language”; that track also displays the breadth of BeatKing’s lyrical talents
column57: with some of his most deft rapping in its second half. There are Memphis tribute records with Gangsta Boo (“Dat Bag”) and Skinny Pimp (“Powder 2014”)
column59: and a monumentally regal closer (“End of the Day”). Much like his lyrically-lyrical Texas counterpart Doughbeezy
column60:
BeatKing has forged a new path for Texas rappers that is at once of history without being hobbled by it.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20864/homepage_large.c0ed7da9.jpg|The Next Four Years|32333.0|United Nations|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Temporary Residence']|2014-07-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:30.505527|"

""Serious Business
column2: the first song on United Nations' The Next Four Years
column3: opens with a bloody Cuisinart blur of power chords and blast-beating drums
column4: vocalist Geoff Rickly letting out throat-flaying screams. It is a blinding place to touch down
column5: like being deposited ass-first and blind-folded onto a five-lane superhighway. United Nations are a complicated semi-lark that Rickly
column6: former lead singer of Thursday
column7: has kept going in some form or another since 2005
column8: and they have always practiced warfare via confusion. Their music is the point where unreadable intentions meet white-hot conviction: you might not know what they mean
column9: exactly
column10: but you understand they mean it with every fiber of their being. ""This is serious business
column11: Rickly shrieks on the song
column12: a line with about seven trap doors around it. Seconds after he utters it
column13: one of them yawns open: What is that familiar melody the chords are tracing? Oh right
column14: that's the central motif of the Phantom of the fucking Opera.

column1: It's a fascinating little quote
column2: intentional or not
column3: and it winks at the central concern of The Next Four Years: punk rock as (possibly exhausted) theater
column4: and how a sagging
column5: ticket-sale-hoovering mainstream behemoth like Phantom might have more in common with hardcore than meets the eye. Speaking with Pitchfork
column6: Rickly was full of sardonic observations about the ways in which punk subcultures are inherently a series of petty squabbles: ""It's maybe 10 different layers of hypocrisy: everything from a Minor Threat T-shirt being $28 at Urban Outfitters
column7: to that being a thing where somebody would set up a whole set of ideals to combat the $28 Minor Threat shirt
column8: to the fact that Minor Threat accidentally started straight-edge in the first place. There's so many layers to what's wrong with that.""

column1: In response
column2: he's built The Next Four Years as an elaborate joke. The album is structured around the fake mythology of a band
column3: beginning with their first cassette detailing their earliest days and progressing through two slightly more melodic and doomier 7""s before landing on what he calls the band's ""pretentious phase of trying to sound like Godspeed! You Black Emperor."" If you purchase the limited-edition box set from Temporary Residence
column4: you can find these thematic distinctions made physical: A black tape
column5: wrapped in the actual cease-and-desist order Rickly's band received from the real UN
column6: two 7""s
column7: and a 10"" inch record. The packaging is covered in fake news stories from 2016-2021; in one
column8: United Nations perform songs from their debut (""now available on vinyl as well as direct mindlink"") in North Korea.

column1: It's a stunning product and a black-belt level conceptual framework. Paging through it all
column2: you can close your eyes and see the message board posts proliferating in its wake. But when you actually listen to the album
column3: all of this subtext flies past you like fine print on the side of a bullet train. It's true that after an initial burst of of furiously scraping songs (""Serious Business
column4: ""Meanwhile On Main Street
column5: ""Revolutions At Varying Speeds"")
column6: the sound opens up slightly
column7: allowing more space in between the hail of kick drums for richer melodies to bloom. And toward the back half
column8: interludes of brooding clean-toned guitars (""F#A#$"") bring the music to a brief resting pulse.

column1: But taken as a whole
column2: The Next Four Years moves like a piece of fine engineering—all curved lines
column3: no wind resistance. ""Revolutions at Varying Speeds"" enters a cycle so brutal in its final seconds that it seems to be reversing on its axis. The same thing happens on ""Between Two Mirrors"" where the drums push the song gently into a wind sprint that gradually and gracefully winds back down
column4: the song resting its hands on its knees and panting. There are little ghosts of melodies lurking here and there
column5: in the interplay between the bass and the minor chords
column6: and occasionally in the vocal lines.

column1: Rickly has expressed concern that listeners will miss ""the jokes"" on The Next Four Years
column2: which mostly take the form of self-inflicted gut blows and eye jabs. When he sings ""Everything That We Touch Is Made for Sale"" on ""Meanwhile On Main Street""
column3: it's difficult to parse if it's a sincere sentiment or Rickly pulling a face at us. This is a band that started out performing in Reagan masks
column4: after all
column5: and good ol' Reagan's face shows up on the box set packaging in a very Dead Kennedys-esque collage. The punchline
column6: in the end
column7: might be that poking punk hypocrisy in the eye feels as familiar and unsurprising as punk itself. Subcultures are necessarily in love with rules—when you strip a subculture down to its skeleton
column8: after all
column9: what remains is a handful of rules—and Rickly ends the album
column10: on ""Music For Changing Parties""
column11: with the following chant: ""Changing parties/ Always the same/ Changing lives/ Always the same/ Changing hearts/ Always the same/ Changing minds/ Always the same.""

column1: All of these Easter eggs help make United Nations an album fun to think about when it's not playing. But parsing The Next Four Years too closely
column2: at least while it's on
column3: flies in the face of the music's reason for being—that is
column4: to blur together moments
column5: to speed up time. Slowing it down would kill it
column6: and the highest compliment I can pay The Next Four Years is that
column7: no matter how often I play it
column8: it's over before I've had time to think. Then
column9: perplexed yet exhilarated
column10:
I play it again.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20789/homepage_large.9e3bfe80.jpg|Friend of Mine|32365.0|DJ Dodger Stadium|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Body High']|2014-07-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:31.326035|"

“Lately I’ve been singing love songs by myself.” Those eight words
column2: an unashamed proclamation of loneliness and heartache
column3: form the mantra around which DJ Dodger Stadium's delirious new album Friend of Mine is built.  The album is the first full-length release from the Los Angeles dance imprint Body High
column4: and DJ Dodger Stadium is the name that founders Jerome LOL and Samo Sound Boy have chosen for themselves as a duo. The moniker is fitting in its audacity and camp
column5: as well as a celebration of Los Angeles as both city and symbol.

column1: Friend of Mine is built on ecstatic forms of house and techno
column2: but its influences go both broader and deeper than simple genre revivalism. At its core
column3: the album draws energy from the intense emotionality trumpeted in the music of artists like Body High associate Shlohmo. Jerome LOL
column4: both with the defunct LOL Boys and in his own solo work
column5: has long shown the ability to mine authentic emotion from what might otherwise seem a particularly cerebral form of dance music. Samo has similarly tempered his technical finesse with wounded samples that elevate his projects beyond your casual beat-happy wonkery. Together
column6: the two wed their technical expertise to produce an album that’s far more trickier to pull off than it sounds: through the majority of the churning
column7: frantic Friend of Mine
column8: they maintain a sense of near-constant climax.

column1: The need to reach that peak and stay there
column2: and the previously mentioned words that form the album’s mantra
column3: originate on the thumping “Love Songs”
column4: which repeats those eight words endlessly without losing momentum. It’s a difficult feat to pull off
column5: and the duo accomplish it by adjusting almost every other element in the song—pulling a gun-patter drumbeat in and out of the mix
column6: shifting the volume and clarity of the sample
column7: and playing with countless other minor beat variations that keep things fresh for the entirety of the track’s running time.

column1: “Love Songs” is the best song on the record and a blueprint for the rest of it
column2: as its perennial high and repetitive vocal loop are echoed on the majority of Friend of Mine’s ten tracks. This maximalism is maintained by clever sequencing; though the repetitive vocal sample on “One Who Lost” could prove numbing in the wake of ""Love Songs""
column3: it’s quick and effective in its delivery. But even the seemingly lighter songs here reach an eventual fever pitch. The album's exception to that rule is the organ-powered “Sit Down Satan”
column4: which reaches for a more explicit type of ecstasy and is perfectly positioned to stoke momentum for the album’s final flourishes.

column1: DJ Dodger Stadium’s sound counters assertions of superficiality in current-day dance music by doubling down on the human element within their music. Some of that humanity is owed to the record’s firm sense of place. Los Angeles is inescapable here: on the carnival sounds and Salvadoran sermon incorporated into “The Dust”
column2: the Hollywood-style intro “The Bottom is As Low as You Can Go”
column3: and in <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qi11LVYL8g4"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the video for “Love Songs
column4: ” which used an aerial drone to capture a one-shot take of the duo’s Westlake neighborhood. With its happy contradictions—theatricality and genuine emotion
column5: self-consciousness and self-awareness—Friend of Mine functions as a symbol of the neurotic
column6: nocturnal Angeleno
column7: happily alone upon the highways or anonymous on the city’s dance floors
column8:
free to lament and to celebrate existence.

"|19562.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19562-dj-dodger-stadium-friend-of-mine/|8.0|Jonah Bromwich

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20771/homepage_large.8959bd18.jpg|Conversations|31690.0|Woman's Hour|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Secretly Canadian']|2014-07-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:32.008830|"

London foursome Woman’s Hour was formed by two siblings and two friends in 2011
column2: but the band didn’t launch in earnest until last year. Cribbing their name from a popular
column3: long-running BBC radio show focused on women’s issues and interests
column4: the band worked intensely with producer Tom Murray on honing their aesthetic—clean lines
column5: no color
column6: arty pretensions—synthesizing much of the last half-decade’s developments in dreamy
column7: simply melodic pop music. Many of the band’s readily identifiable influences are fellow Brits: the grayscale glamour of Bat for Lashes
column8: Jessie Ware’s cool
column9: mannered tone
column10: and the minimal romanticism of the xx all snake their way through Conversations
column11: Woman’s Hour’s debut. The results are erudite
column12: slim dream-pop
column13: made distinct in its best moments by an open-hearted sweetness and innocence.

column1: The purest expression of Woman's Hour sound is Conversations’ title track
column2: a song that revels in bookish charm and a yearning
column3: endearing performance from lead singer Fiona Burgess. Burgess sings about “awkward moments of strange affection
column4: ” exactly the sort of moments this music could ably soundtrack; the subject matter and sound lends itself well to library-set fantasies
column5: with romantic pairs whispering through stacks of books. There’s a tightness to the band’s ensemble that enables the cultivation of a careful
column6: genuine intimacy.

column1: The work of Beach House hangs over much of Conversations
column2: from Burgess’s vocal tone to the clear
column3: luminous sound of the album’s arrangement. The slowly blooming keyboard that cracks open ""Our Love Has No Rhythm"" is instantly reminiscent of songs like ""Gila"" and ""Heart of Chambers"". Beyond issues with overfamiliarity
column4: much of Conversations falls victim to a lack of consistency and individuality. The band has no trouble putting together pleasant melodies
column5: but those melodies more often than not scan as ephemeral.

column1: <div>Woman's Hour's readily identifiable influences also prove a hindrance; for new groups
column2: being tagged as formulaic isn't necessarily a bad thing
column3: but truly great bands transcend that label by carving out a niche for themselves. Woman's Hour's formula helps listeners find their footing
column4: but it also makes it more difficult for the band to establish their own voice. The best songs on Conversations point to a viable middle ground where earnest delicacy and shadowy tones co-exist
column5: but the band has yet to fully explore that realm."|19544.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19544-womans-hour-conversations/|6.3|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20787/homepage_large.362815a2.jpg|Move to Pain|32363.0|Sons of Magdalene|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Audraglint']|2014-07-15 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:32.564556|"

Move to Pain
column2: the debut solo album by Josh Eustis of defunct Chicago laptop duo Telefon Tel Aviv
column3: had a gestation that was long and landmarked by tragedy. Eustis started using the name Sons of Magdalene in 2007 after his father contracted cancer
column4: then recorded some of the record's songs not long before his musical partner Charlie Cooper died suddenly in 2009. Eustis finished the album in 2010 and put it on the shelf until now. Perhaps unfairly
column5: this backstory sets up expectations for a certain kind of record—an emotionally bared and demonstratively tormented one where the artist emerges transfigured by grief.

column1: But while listening to the music featured on Move to Pain without context
column2: you'd never guess at the circumstances surrounding its conception
column3: as it sublimates misfortune into distantly sad wisps of retro electro-pop and church-stern interludes. Created while Eustis was learning to work without his longtime partner
column4: Move to Pain sounds understandably tentative and cautious; taking his former band's sound to unaccustomedly poppy places
column5: it's agreeable but innocuous. Dreamy dance-pop
column6: driving atmospheric ligature
column7: and threads of sinuously clipped IDM
column8: with 808-style claps and blocky arp bass slathered everywhere
column9: are all blended into one simple
column10: unassuming consistency.

column1: Telefon Tel Aviv traded in chill
column2: jazzy electronic music with lots of samples
column3: glitches
column4: clicks
column5: and cuts. At best
column6: they cobbled tough
column7: supple rhythms and fine
column8: gummy tones into shuddering structures that felt bulky but delicately detailed—sonic objects you could feel in your ribcage as well as abstractly admire. At worst
column9: they could be numbingly polite
column10: like something sleek but ignorable you’d half-hear in a coffee shop
column11: and the featured vocals often sounded dreary. Those inconsistencies also hold true for Sons of Magdalene; the best tracks balance the formidable and the fragile
column12: making sub-bass fluctuations and slanted sequences feel blown up under a microscope. ""Crows on the Eaves of My Father's House"" is a particularly compelling look
column13: with gulping vocal cut-ups that recall Andy Stott's ""Numb"". But that close focus slips on the more traditional songs
column14: which range from functional but unimaginative to almost rote.

column1: As a singer
column2: Eustis gets the job done without frills
column3: but he seems hesitant about letting us hear his voice and lyrics. He claims the foreground in opening track ""Hold On Hold Still for a Second""
column4: maneuvering a pretty
column5: watery melody through a rubbery sheath of thrumming arps
column6: drilling claps
column7: and plunging synth toms. He scores his most mobile and charismatic vocal performance on ""A Strange Sound""
column8: a sea breeze of electro-pop (rendered just slightly strange by the skippy pitches in the harmonies) that builds to a rewarding Panda Bear-like conclusion. Less successful is his stab at a louche electro style on the haunted dub of ""The Whip""
column9: which lands somewhere between Matthew Dear and Trans Am. But more often
column10: we can barely hear him
column11: as on his timid dance-diva take on the title track or his shy coloring of the oily bass music braid ""O Death"".

column1: Move to Pain is most noticably held back by its rudimentary tones and structures
column2: which are surprising from someone who's proven capable at cultivating complexity and detail. The songs either crescendo like opening funnels or orbit through sequenced arpeggios
column3: contrasting counterpoint and drifting harmonies with dead-predictable dynamics. In either case
column4: they feel overly straight and preordained
column5: not taking us very far from beginning to end.

column1: The music is simple
column2: but not enough to be sublime; it's active
column3: but not enough to find transcendence. And it doesn't render commonplace technology personal and alive—there's not much here that a savvy amateur couldn't do with GarageBand
column4: a low bar to clear when grid-based composition with soft synths is so accessible. The results that Move to Pain yields are pleasantly neutral
column5:
with nothing going spectacularly right or wrong.

One of my favorite things that I’ve ever seen at a concert happened in 1995
column2: when Peter Murphy was touring behind his fifth solo studio album
column3: Cascade. That wasn’t a particularly good album
column4: and the tour wasn’t particularly impressive either–he’d occasionally leave the stage and return in a new shirt
column5: which struck me as combining the pretension of Ziggy Stardust-esque multiple costume changes with a low-budget shabbiness. But few of the hundreds of devotees who showed up seemed to care. The two most rapt audience members were a pair of highly done-up goth boys who were jammed against the center of the stage. Murphy noticed their laser-like focus on his performance
column6: and part way through his set he took a towel he’d just used to wipe sweat off his head and draped it gently over the face of one of the boys. He spent the rest of the show cradling the towel against his chest
column7: in the embrace of his partner–a goth boy wrapped around a goth boy wrapped around Peter Murphy’s sweaty towel. I’ve rarely seen anyone as totally transported by a concert experience since then.

column1: Those are the kind of fans that have sustained Murphy’s career during the occasional periods where his fairweather fans lose interest. The latest stretch has been taking place since Bauhaus’ unexpectedly triumphant 2005 reunion fell apart two years later. Now would be a good time for those more capricious fans to get back on board
column2: as Murphy's new solo LP
column3: Lion is one of the best he’s ever released.

column1: Aside from the Bauhaus reunion
column2: Murphy’s spent most of the new millennium working in various shades of esoterica; he recorded an album of electronics-enhanced Turkish folk music
column3: a set of classic rock covers
column4: and a couple of efforts that resurrected the more delicate
column5: acoustically-flavored sounds that defined his early solo albums like Deep and Holy Smoke. Lion picks up where Bauhaus’ gleefully abrasive 2008 album Go Away White left off. Working with producer Martin Glover
column6: aka Youth
column7: he’s completed that previous album’s mission to bring industrial-tinged gothic dance-punk into the present.

column1: Lion opens well into the red with “Hang Up”
column2: a super-dense fusion of rolling
column3: slow-motion arena rock drums
column4: swarm-of-bees synthesizers
column5: and Murphy’s unsettlingly intense vocals
column6: which have a frantic energy and the raw timbre of someone who’s been pushing his larynx to extremes for the past few decades. Between Murphy’s ragged howl and Glover’s typically noisy electronic production it sounds something like what Scott Walker might be making now if he’d never abandoned pop structures. The album doesn’t let up from there: “I Am My Own Name” throws sheets of guitar noise over a darkly throbbing dance beat
column7: with Murphy taking the same death-disco diva role he played on classics like “Bela Lugosi’s Dead”. “Low Tar Stars” finds him emulating Bowie for the umpteenth time in his career
column8: only this time it draws from his quasi-industrial
column9: collaborating-with-Trent-Reznor period in the '90s.

column1: Glover’s recent work with Paul McCartney was evidence of the producer's unique ability to locate the pent-up energy lurking inside an artist who’s reached a point in his career where he could comfortably
column2: justifiably
column3: coast
column4: and on Lion he does the same with Murphy
column5: who doesn’t just sound energized
column6: but electrified
column7: too. Peter Murphy’s once again located the razor-thin line between restraint and complete unhingedness that he hasn’t walked since Bauhaus’ first time around
column8:
and following his recent exploits has never felt more rewarding.

""We were paralyzed by the dumbness of the times. So we did our best to change them."" That's Morrissey
column3: on how clueless gatekeepers blocked the Smiths' ""How Soon Is Now?"" from bigger commercial success
column4: in the new book Mad World: An Oral History of New Wave Artists and Songs That Defined the 1980s. His comments here are striking partly for how little has changed—in Morrissey's telling
column5: everyone else was wrong: the other Smiths
column6: who were ""embarrassed"" by the lyrics; producer John Porter
column7: who downplayed them; Rough Trade head Geoff Travis
column8: who relegated the song to a UK B-side; and the American chartkeepers and TV producers
column9: who failed to recognize the track's genius. Morrissey's remarks also stand out
column10: though
column11: for their optimism. All his hope might've been gone
column12: as he sang
column13: but he still left a scrap for the rest of us.

column1: Though World Peace Is None of Your Business
column2: Morrissey's first album in five years
column3: comes in times that are undoubtedly just as dumb in their own way
column4: the Smiths' place within them is secure. Defunct for almost three decades
column5: the band is a perennial subject of Coachella reunion whispers. Morrissey elicits tributes in ""Parks and Recreation"" dialogue and Peanuts-themed Tumblr mashups alike. The gap between albums is his longest since virtually disappearing between 1997's misunderstood Maladjusted and 2004's tommy gun-blazing You Are the Quarry
column6: but nowadays Morrissey is rarely far from the public eye
column7: whether publishing a sometimes-brilliant memoir
column8: canceling tour dates (while blaming the opener)
column9: or getting into it over animal rights with Jimmy Kimmel and Los Angeles' Staples Center. Remember when he appeared to start using Twitter? Then denied using Twitter? Post-financial crisis
column10: he's as ubiquitous as global protest movements.

column1: Tour and Twitter drama aside
column2: the rollout of World Peace has still managed only to raise Morrissey's profile
column3: from the album's priceless album cover and tracklist to unconventional spoken-word videos guest-starring past musical collaborator Nancy Sinatra and fellow PETA activist Pamela Anderson. The full-length itself
column4: though—in a characteristic Morrissey twist—is hardly welcoming to newcomers. It's musically as rich and worldly as Morrissey gets
column5: and the 55-year-old who early last year addressed another round of health concerns by quipping that ""the reports of my death have been greatly understated"" proves he can be as hilarious and multi-dimensional as ever. But it's also a deeply sour record
column6: even for Morrissey. He's always had it both ways
column7: singing his life but with a wink that resists literal interpretations; even so
column8: this album's expressions of wide-ranging contempt are at times unbecomingly convincing.

column1: Ever since You Are the Quarry weathered criticism for Jerry Finn's unsubtle production
column2: Morrissey's albums have flourished sonically
column3: and that growth is its furthest-reaching to date on World Peace. Boz Boorer
column4: on guitar since 1992's Your Arsenal
column5: brings a muscular continuity and sense of comfort—but keyboard/synthesizer newcomer Gustavo Manzur and producer Joe Chiccarelli (the White Stripes
column6: Beck) go beyond the Ennio Morricone orchestral cameo from 2006's Ringleader of the Tormentors and the unpredictable luxuriance of 2009's Years of Refusal. Recorded in France
column7: the album makes the world its business
column8: encompassing meditative drones along with flamenco guitars and mariachi horns. It's as meticulously detailed as it is cosmopolitan
column9: and marks the second straight Morrissey album that rewards listening without paying attention to the lyrics.

column1: Morrissey's golden vibrato also sounds gloriously undamaged by his recent medical woes. As ever
column2: it's most evident in his nonverbal tics—the way he stretches out the word ""ways"" into umpteen syllables on ""Staircase at the University""
column3: an ""Ask""-jaunty number about a student whose academic imperfections lead to suicide
column4: and how he melismatically unfurls ""cries"" on ""The Bullfighter Dies""
column5: another cheerfully morbid song cheering the perfectly Morrissey-esque subject of the title (""because we all want the bull to survive""). ""Neal Cassady Drops Dead"" is as jagged and punchy as its bleakly funny
column6: faux-Beat tirade about ""babies full of rabies/ Rabies full of scabies/ Scarlett has a fever.../ The little fella has got Rubella."" Morrissey still knows how to be cranky with aplomb.

column1: Still
column2: at times the intricate arrangements come across as a means of covering up unmemorable songwriting. The murky midtempo rock of ""Istanbul""
column3: about a father who identifies the body of his dead son
column4: and the ornately textured strummer ""Mountjoy""
column5: which finds grim equality in a notorious Irish prison (""We all lose/ Rich or poor"")
column6: are evidence of how these songs often tend to drag. The worst offender is nearly eight-minute centerpiece ""I'm Not a Man""
column7: which grows from ambient twinkles and show-tunes crooning to gutsy modern-rock pounding and howling as Morrissey reaches new levels of self-righteousness: ""I'd never kill or eat an animal/ And I never would destroy this planet I am on."" All credit to Morrissey for speaking inconvenient truths
column8: but it doesn't take joining the Koch family to possess the ability to walk out of this lecture. Forget ""man""—what about ""charming""?

column1: Along with the occasional trudging bits
column2: Morrissey's smug preachiness is the album's other off-putting point. The title track is ingeniously catchy and deeply sardonic
column3: but dismissing protesters from Ukraine to Bahrain as ""you poor little fool"" and coining the mantra that ""Each time you vote/ You support the process"" isn't a dose of welcome realism; it's cynical and self-absorbed (Americans in Morrissey's lifetime marched and died for voting rights). The glamorous
column4: self-mythologizing romantic melancholy that's Morrissey's stock-in-trade
column5: meanwhile
column6: comes up only rarely
column7: though you can hear its echoes in the joyously ""Besame Mucho""-flipping ""Kiss Me a Lot
column8: and Morrissey's exaltation of ruffians in the vaguely sexualized violence of ""Smiler With Knife"". The album's most miserablist songs
column9: to use the word long applied to Morrissey's music
column10: nevertheless zoom out for a wider view: there's the Spanish-tinged romp ""Earth Is the Loneliest Planet""
column11: where ""You fail as a woman/ And you lose as a man
column12: and the pointedly dirge-like ""Kick the Bride Down the Aisle""
column13: where Morrissey's scorn for institution of matrimony leaves me longing for the Hidden Cameras' more entertaining ""Ban Marriage"".

column1: On finale ""Oboe Concerto""
column2: which idiosyncratically leans on Boorer's sax and clarinet
column3: Morrissey repeats
column4: ""There's a song I can't stand/ And it's stuck in my head."" Beneath electronic blips and burbles
column5: the lurching bass line is reminiscent of the Smiths' 1987 song ""Death of a Disco Dancer"". There
column6: he familiarily sings: ""If you think peace is a common goal/ That goes to show how little you know
column7: adding
column8: ""Love
column9: peace
column10: and harmony / Oh
column11: very nice
column12: very nice
column13: very nice
column14: very nice / But maybe in the next world."" Or
column15: as he intones now
column16: ""Round
column17: round
column18: rhythm of life goes round."" Morrissey
column19: a wag might say
column20:
is none of our business.

In the summer of 2013
column2: an anonymous UK production duo only known by the initials of J and T released a 7"" under the name of Jungle. From this side of the Atlantic
column3: there was a bit of an eye roll: anonymous Brits who are taken with the sound of pirate radio jungle rendered back when they were just weens? But rather than follow in the lineage of the likes of Zomby
column4: Burial
column5: and the like
column6: the video for that first single “Platoon” (featuring Ellen’s favorite B-girl) revealed that Jungle weren’t early '90’s ‘ardcore enthusiasts as much as they were just two blokes into Jamiroquai.

column1: For a recent series of sold-out shows in Europe and New York City
column2: J and T have dilated to a seven-person live band that features some chops and muscle
column3: but at the root of their 12-track self-titled debut for XL
column4: Jungle retains the constricts of the original duo of producers Josh Lloyd-Watson and Tom McFarland. Throughout their first album
column5: they favor the bantamweight soul reminiscent of early '80s British acts like Imagination
column6: Fun Boy Three
column7: I-Level and Fine Young Cannibals
column8: to name but a few. But it’s the group’s sense of simple
column9: dance-focused visuals  that have attained a certain level of buzz. Peel back those effective visuals and their sonic palette is rather confectionary: pliant bass
column10: simple 4/4 beats
column11: spindling guitar. Sometimes the synths that underpin the tracks are frothy
column12: other times airy
column13: in a few instances bubbly
column14: but they are almost impossible to differentiate from track to track. The synthesized horns and eddying synth washes of “Busy Earnin’” are a nice garland for a track that laments the self-centeredness of being “Too busy earning/ Can’t get enough.”

column1: Too often
column2: Jungle’s shimmering surfaces belie the flimsiness of the songs themselves
column3: which buckle under any sort of weight. Take opener “The Heat”
column4: a catchy
column5: light funk number which manages to shoehorn in three separate “heat” references in under 10 seconds: actual temperature
column6: sexual intensity
column7: and the police (via a sample of wailing sirens). It’s the image of the roller-skating b-boys in matching tracksuits in the song's video
column8: and not the song itself
column9: that leaves a lasting impression.

column1: Digested as individual singles rather than as an entire album in one sitting
column2: Jungle fares far better. “Platoon” remains a standout
column3: as does “Time”
column4: though these songs’ distinguishing features blur due to the indistinguishable tracks that border either side of them. The falsetto-castrato harmonies—<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">just beyond the range of Pharrell—that deliver each chorus and hook proves tiring on the ears
column6: too: imagine TV on the Radio’s “I Was a Lover” with Tunde Adebimpe and Kyp Malone forever in the purgatory of that high
column7: grating register
column8: never to descend back into a growl or tenor
column9: much less their regular singing voice. With an expanded band
column10: one hopes that Jungle might broaden their template and branch out into different timbres. As it stands
column11: remaining at that upper register with every word and line
column12: the album’s 39 minutes feel much longer
column13:
leaving one high and dry.

Rebecca Taylor and Charles Watson
column2: the Sheffield duo who record as Slow Club
column3: have a knack for patient
column4: confident evolution. Their debut
column5: 2009's Yeah So
column6: was a collection of peppy
column7: straightforward folk-pop that earned the band comparisons to pairs from the White Stripes to the Fiery Furnaces; by 2011
column8: they had moved on to a richer
column9: more tonally diverse sound
column10: one captured by their strong sophomore effort Paradise. The band's new record
column11: Complete Surrender
column12: continues their developmental trend: Taylor and Watson have taken a large
column13: proud step into the world of soul.

column1: The transformation is comprehensive: arrangements move and swing
column2: newfound emphasis is placed on rhythm
column3: blooming horn sections hold court
column4: and Taylor taps into a reservation of emotion and sheer vocal power that was kept hidden on the band's earlier records. But even as Slow Club moves from sound to sound with each new full-length
column5: the core of their appeal—their unique relationship and vocal interplay—remains uncompromised. Taylor and Watson spend a lot of time singing about love and how it's won and lost
column6: but they shy away from playing a couple or suggesting some unresolved romantic drama. Instead
column7: they usually end up sounding like two old friends who share a powerful
column8: purely platonic love
column9: and have spent years singing together and for each other. That interpretation of their dynamic is complemented by their vocal strategy: they frequently sing in unison
column10: eschewing harmony save for situations where special emphasis is required.

column1: Complete Surrender preserves this core strength and doubles down on a few others
column2: giving Slow Club a solid base from which they play with genre and density. The album was produced by veteran Colin Elliot
column3: who has a good ear for space dynamics whether the arrangements are jam-packed (on rompers like ""Suffering You
column4: Suffering Me"" and ""The Queen's Nose"") or sparse (the stunning piano-led ballad ""Number One""). Elliot understands that Taylor and Watson's voices are the keys to unlocking the band's songs
column5: and he highlights them accordingly
column6: making sure they remain at the forefront no matter how much action is taking place in the background.

column1: <div>Taylor
column2: continuing a pattern of improvement that began with Paradise
column3: is an absolute titan of a lead vocalist. Her voice is big
column4: bright
column5: and open
column6: with a complete lack of pretension. She's an expert at conveying a wide range of emotion
column7: which renders her an instantly familiar presence; when she cuts loose on a dusty
column8: grand ballad like ""The Queen's Nose
column9: it's like having your face unexpectedly melted by a neighbor or co-worker at a local open mic. Given that she spends much of Complete Surrender singing about complex relationships and different strains of heartbreak
column10: it's a valuable quality
column11: as she has no trouble connecting with the listener. Watson is a good singer in his own right
column12: too—he carries the aforementioned ""Number One"" with surprising tenderness—but he's best when serving as Taylor's backup or enthusiastic foil.

column1: An important contributor to Complete Surrender's success is the reverence and respect with which Taylor and Watson approach the material. They're not the first group to evoke the spirit of Northern soul
column2: but they understand that the genre deserves more than a few bleating horns. Their strong sense of identity helps
column3: too: it's clear that the duo have a good handle on their strengths
column4: and even their less successful experiments or compositions can fall back on a base level of chemistry and comfort. Listening to Complete Surrender
column5: you get the sense that Taylor and Watson would be just as happy making music for
column6: and with
column7: each other in their spare time
column8: revelling in their companionship."|19553.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19553-slow-club-complete-surrender/|7.6|Jamieson Cox

Matthew McQueen’s music as Matthewdavid started attracting attention at the top of this decade
column2: and the California-via-Florida-via-Atlanta beatmaker benefited from excellent timing. After a few years of bouncing around Los Angeles’ burgeoning electronic music scene—an exploratory period that included the founding of his initially cassette-focused label Leaving—he caught the discerning ear of Flying Lotus
column3: who signed McQueen to his own Brainfeeder imprint. His proper debut LP
column4: Outmind
column5: was released in 2011
column6: which
column7: depending on how you look at it
column8: was either a very fertile or very tough period for bedroom producers who drew influence from hip-hop. At that time
column9: musicians of questionable talent emerged constantly in this sphere
column10: and many of them directly ripped off FlyLo’s sidechained
column11: fusion-focused sound. McQueen's aesthetic bore a clear debt to his label head
column12: but Outmind stood apart from the pack
column13: a static-riddled document that infused its more straightforward moments with dense thickets of obscured noise.

column1: McQueen’s latest full-length
column2: In My World
column3: could be considered Outmind’s proper follow-up after a few low-profile releases
column4: but the album represents a move away from earlier style. The shift is immediately apparent in the opening title track
column5: which pairs a decaying AM-radio sample with a pulsing rhythmic framework and
column6: most notably
column7: McQueen’s voice. “In my world
column8: it’s paradise for you
column9: ” he sing-raps
column10: before stating plainly
column11: “Outer space is where I want to know you.”

column1: This latest detour could owe something to significant life events—McQueen recently married and had a child—and In My World certainly seems more personal than his previous work. Regardless
column2: his choice to sing
column3: rap
column4: and sing-rap throughout In My World is obviously risky; his vocals tend to distract from what surrounds them
column5: and his skill on the mic is
column6: at best
column7: rudimentary. McQueen’s turn here brings to mind fellow West Coast hip-hop-influenced oddball James Pants
column8: another polyglot artist who had a brief moment of increased visibility earlier this decade; at times
column9: In My World’s fixation on R&B-abused frameworks and dub-influenced sonics comes across as similarly dated.

column1: In My World’s back half briefly ditches McQueen’s voice and is more engaging for it—”West Coast Jungle Juke”
column2: in particular
column3: heads back to Outmind’s foggy swarm before quietly erupting in an ‘ardcore break near its end. And when he takes the mic again on the closing cut “Birds in Flight” it’s his strongest vocal on the album: he simmers and whines over a bed of rainforest sonics and distant flute
column4: a soothing and somewhat affecting creation reminiscent of Animal Collective member Avey Tare’s solo work. Even at its best
column5: though
column6: In My World resembles a less-engaging version of someone else
column7:
the sound of an artist regressing instead of stepping forward into new territory.
