Greg Cartwright’s Reigning Sound came into existence in 2001
column3: just as garage rock was readying an assault on the mainstream that would make Jack White one of the least likely superstars of the nascent 21st century. White
column4: of course
column5: had already been kicking around the garage-rock scene for years— but nowhere near as long as Cartwright
column6: whose résumé stretches back to the ’80s
column7: although he made his first mark with the Memphis band the Compulsive Gamblers in the early ’90s. His subsequent group
column8: Oblivians
column9: became his best known
column10: and for good reason: Like a chunk of bloody meat chucked into a carburetor
column11: Oblivians was a wonderful mess of primitive R&B and punk. But even under all that gunk
column12: one thing was clear: Cartwright was a man who knew how to craft songs and coax melodies. Reigning Sound became the vessel for broadening ability
column13: to the point where their 2009 album
column14: Love and Curses
column15: owed as much to early Elvis Costello as to the Cramps. On Shattered
column16: Reigning Sound’s first album since 2009 and first for Merge
column17: Cartwright has dialed down the fuzz— and cranked up the songcraft— even more.

column1: There aren’t many new elements to Shattered as compared to earlier Reigning Sound releases
column2: but it marks a decided shift in how those elements are employed. Recorded in Daptone’s studio in Brooklyn rather than on Cartwright’s home turf of Memphis
column3: and with a relatively new roster
column4: the album is loose
column5: flowing
column6: and at times downright funky. Ironically
column7: it sounds more like a vintage
column8: Stax-era production than anything Reigning Sound ever did back home. “Baby
column9: It’s Too Late” smothers itself in earthy organ
column10: ventilated by stinging
column11: Steve Cropper-esque licks. “North Cackalacky Girl” is a mod-R&B rave-up with only a tinge of punk ruggedness. For a band that titled its 2004 album Too Much Guitar
column12: there’s a noticeable subjugation of that instrument; Cartwright’s riffs are cleaner
column13: sharper
column14: and more sparingly applied
column15: and they punch harder thanks to that tasteful dynamic.

column1: The fluidity and lyricism in Cartwright’s playing has always been hinted at in Reigning Sound but never fully explored. The same goes for his voice
column2: a husky
column3: charismatic bellow that’s able to dip into a supple
column4: soulful croon. His full range is stretched into thrilling places
column5: though
column6: on Shattered’s handful of roots-rock tracks
column7: some of which solidly straddle the country-soul divide. “Never Coming Home” and “Once More” sport mournful strings
column8: lonely spaces
column9: and the kind of choked-up twang that can overcome even the tritest of lyrics—one of the few major drawbacks of the album. A shining exception is “Falling Rain”
column10: the record’s dizzying apex. Approaching Dylan-and-the-Band chemistry
column11: Cartwright and his current lineup pull together every thread that’s unspooled throughout the album; meanwhile
column12: their leader’s lyrics take homespun
column13: borderline mundane sentiments about the sadness of loss and call forth an inspired
column14: gut-deep pathos that transcends the ostensibly basic blocks it’s built from.

column1: “Starting New” is one of Shattered’s subtlest songs
column2: but also one of its most telling. Introspective and impressionistic
column3: Cartwright rhapsodizes and pitches woo with all the caressed
column4: tender phrasing of “T.B. Sheets”-era Van Morrison. The funk is subliminal; the country comes from nowhere and everywhere. Like an attempt at unified field theory of American music
column5: the song is a leap forward for Reigning Sound
column6: one of many on Shattered. Cartwright’s contemporary
column7: Jack White
column8: may be probing the outer limits of his own domain with his new album Lazaretto. But in a humbler
column9: warmer
column10: more openhearted way
column11:
Reigning Sound have risen above themselves—as well as the garage-rock idiom that spawned them— while spiritually hewing true.

Things were different the last time The-Dream released a project for free. 1977 arrived as R&B’s perennial underdog was knee-deep in the murky low tide of his unfinalized second divorce
column3: and his relationship with Def Jam was visibly unravelling. Above all else
column4: the name: he’d left his “ratchet sex hero” cape in the phone booth this round
column5: temporarily abandoning “The-Dream” moniker for his real name
column6: Terius Nash. It made sense; though he’s spent his solo career forging a path perpendicular to the machinations of popular R&B
column7: Nash has always been strategic
column8: if not cautious
column9: with regard to his audience’s demands
column10: balancing his restless compositional impulses with a mercenary’s knack for instantly catchy melodies. 1977 was a gamble
column11: its rawness a potentially jarring departure from the orgasmic excess of his first three albums that often gestured towards vulnerability but never quite went all in.

column1: There are no such cautionary measures in place for Royalty: The Prequel
column2: the seven-track EP he released for free download
column3: as The-Dream
column4: one day after announcing its existence and a handful of days after his third wedding. In part
column5: it’s because he’s got no one to answer to but himself these days; he left Def Jam in January
column6: and is currently helming Contra Paris
column7: a “designer and culture label” along with longtime partner Tricky Stewart. But though the EP’s a closer descendent of 1977
column8: in form and content
column9: chronologically it follows IV Play
column10: Nash’s fourth and worst-received studio album. IV Play wasn’t a failure
column11: but by Nash’s standards
column12: it was unprecedentedly un-great; its first half in particular felt desperate to prove a point—somewhere in between “I can still hang with the kids” and “the kids aren’t all that great anyway”—that
column13: if not totally inaccurate
column14: wasn’t particularly inviting. But with Royalty
column15: removed from the demands and delays of a major label and rebounding from the harshest criticism of his solo career
column16: Nash finally has nothing to prove
column17: resulting in some of his most honest work yet.

column1: Nash’s lyrics and love life have a history of being inextricably braided together
column2: but—aside from 1977—never more transparently than here. His stubborn belief in the unflinching realism of R&B at its best
column3: combined with a compulsive
column4: truth-serum narcissism (when he’s writing for others
column5: he fully becomes them
column6: but on his own
column7: he’s himself to an arguable fault) has always been the quality that’s made his music so piercingly relatable. There were moments of vulnerability on his first three albums
column8: but they tended to shift focus to derail true self-reflection: Love Hate’s “Nikki” replaced the unsolved tension of then with the instant gratification of now; the two-part title track of Love vs. Money skimmed the surface of his skewed priorities that ended a relationship
column9: then quickly devolved into petty blame games. As Nash has grown more willing to face the potentially gnarly complexities of love and loss head-on
column10: though
column11: a funny thing has happened: the separation between his love life and his career has whittled away
column12: to the point where it’s often hard to tell which he’s actually addressing. It’s a diehard music nerd’s way of navigating life: as he draws parallels between himself and the music he loves
column13: each makes a little more sense.

column1: Royalty blurs these lines more than any of Nash’s earlier projects
column2: tilting potentially straightforward ballads into thinly veiled pop music criticism. (1977’s “Ghetto” set the precedent—“She want that old thing back
column3: that ride it like a pony” doubled as a remembrance of fucks past
column4: and an R&B classicist’s nostalgia for an era where Ginuwine’s no-punches-pulled raunch ruled the charts; IV Play’s “Slow It Down” made the ambiguity between lover and audience more explicit than ever
column5: not to mention complained outright at the current state of radio R&B— “Always with you baby
column6: I’d never sell out/ Them other niggas had to do a dance record or the label wouldn’t put ‘em out.”) Nash makes this duality immediately clear on opening track “Duet”
column7: its punny hook a tongue-wagging sex-as-music metaphor. It’s most poignant on “Lake Michigan”
column8: on which he simultaneously eulogizes the naive intensity of first love
column9: and grasps in vain for a long-gone time when he could create art for its own sake. And on “Cold”
column10: a continuation of the shots fired on 1977’s super-salty “Form Of Flattery
column11: ” a lover listening to his R&B peers in front of him is an unforgivable act of infidelity.

column1: True to form
column2: new songs are in constant conversation with echoes of past work. “Culture”
column3: with its wispy new-money elegance
column4: serves as a sequel of sorts to fan favorite “Fancy”
column5: updated with a brisk reality check. The Fendi shoes and Bentley coupes remain
column6: but it’s complicated—now
column7: Nash blatantly ogles the French restaurant waitresses and gets loaded off Patron while his date sips Riesling. And on standout track “Wedding Bells
column8: ” a deceptively buoyant response to 1977’s “Wedding Crasher”
column9: Nash shifts from inebriated interloper to inebriated groom. In both scenarios
column10: he’s not as happy in the moment as he might have expected
column11: but the spiteful scowl of 1977 and the try-hard smirk of IV Play are replaced by what feels like sincere
column12: if jaded
column13: acceptance
column14: at least for the moment.

column1: There are no features here
column2: no elaborate interludes
column3: and none of the cheeky ayy!s and ella!s that punctuated his previous records. Where Nash plays here is in the intertextuality between his real life and his lyrics
column4: between his new and old works
column5: and between himself and his influences. IV Play’s rap verses felt awkward
column6: shoe-horned in for credibility; on Royalty
column7: he weaves his rap touchstones into his narratives instead. The faded memories of first love are made crisper by remembering the first time hearing Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik on “Outkast”
column8: and a sample of Mobb Deep’s “Shook Ones Pt. 2” drives home the message on “Cold” (if naming seven of his peers outright wasn’t direct enough). If 1977 was Nash’s lesson in vulnerability disguised as a break-up album
column9: and IV Play a semi-rhetorical question about his place in contemporary R&B
column10:
Royalty isn’t so much a tribute to new love but—left to his own devices at last—a complicated love letter to music itself.

Tyler
column2: the Creator and Earl Sweatshirt remain the linchpins of Odd Future’s rapping prowess

column6: shows him to have made major improvements since the last time we heard from him (on the smoked-out MellowHigh). The way he skates over his verses
column7: threatening to spin recklessly out of control while never doing so

column1: Hodgy’s improvement is most obvious on Insa’s more high-energy tracks. The mixtape’s lead single
column2: “Nowadays""
column3: is the best example

column1: Mellowhype live up to their portmanteau on the other half of the record; when the hype dies down

column4: Syd’s calming presence providing a proper foil for an agitated Hodgy.

column1: Though Hodgy has undoubtedly improved

column3: on Mellowhype albums
column4: Left Brain has swooped in to save songs where Hodgy falls flat—his production has always been at least as compelling as Hodgy’s verses and the duo’s best songs
column5: from “La Bonita""
column6: to “SmokeSumKushWitme""
column7: have benefitted from his  enigmatic
column8: energetic beats.  On <i>Insa
column9: for whatever reason
column10: he’s pulled back a bit
column11: flirting with boom-bap and quiet storm samples in contrast to his usual bombast and left field choices
column12: and as a result
column13: there’s nothing to redeem Hodgy when he gets caught in a bad loop. So whether it be on the rote gangsterisms of “Belly’s” second verse or the rote misogyny of the concept song “7” (“got a bitch for every day of the week”)
column14: Left Brain’s beats here are a little too subdued to entirely rescue the worst of the rappity-rap proceedings.

column1: Insa (which stands for “I need some answers”) was released on July 4th as a free mixtape
column2: and as such
column3: it punches well above its weight
column4: a reminder of just how skilled the broader Odd Future collective is. And yet
column5: like the class clowns they were billed as when they introduced themselves to the world
column6: the group’s potential always seems to loom above their output as a ceiling they haven’t yet cracked—file Insa as another release from the collective that’s a shrug-worthy solid rather than the rap-realigning release that was once predicted for the group. Hodgy Beats and Left Brain are capable of being a top-rate rapper and a top-rate producer respectively
column7: and neither is a kid anymore. Isn’t it past time that they came out with something a little more challenging
column8:
or at least more memorable?

Matt Kivel's Double Exposure was a deeply solitary record. The lyrics brimmed with death
column2: stillness
column3: pale horses
column4: and Kivel recorded it largely alone
column5: away from his other projects
column6: Gap Dream and Princeton. It was initially difficult to tell if anyone else even noticed this stark
column7: beautiful little gem--it came out in late 2013
column8: a tough time for indie records
column9: especially ones by new

column11: living with it

column1: Someone else must have been

column3: and his follow-up
column4: Days of Being Wild
column5: arrives less than one year later. Kivel is touring with Steve Gunn and the Clientele now

column5: Crooked Rain song

column3: he whispers fragmented FM rock signifiers—""Black is night/ The highway/ Her nails so red and wild/ Green and slip/ The oceanside""—like Bob Seger via William Carlos Williams. On ""Little Girls
column4: he sings ""Honey I ain't got forever/ You take me now or never/ Just step into the night/ There I'll be gone."" On the title track

column6: of all things. As with everything else
column7: it's handled gently

column10: the imprint they leave in the mind.

column1: Kivel's voice is as much a warm shape and the guitars: As on Double Exposure
column2: he's barely intelligible save for isolated phrases. Pieced together
column3: these little snatches of clear communication convey almost as much
column4: in their evocative settings
column5: as the full lyric sheet does. One of them
column6: from ""Only With the Wine
column7: is ""She fucks with other guys/ But why?""
column8: and another
column9: from ""End of Adventure
column10: is ""Slapped on your ass."" One of the welcome surprises of spending prolonged time with Kivel's music is discovering how quietly libidinous it is. Of course
column11: another clear
column12: ringing lyric piercing the haze is ""I don't wanna die/ But I will."" But compared with Double Exposure's central confession ""I want to kill myself"" (from ""Whip"")
column13: the line feels positively life-affirming. Kivel is still troubled by mortality
column14: but on Days he is pushing away from it
column15:
towards life and contact.

It is a staggering task—one that would take several hours—to listen through the recorded output of Edwin and Andy White. The two brothers
column2: Florida-raised and currently Brooklyn-based
column3: have released an alarmingly unwieldy pile of music over the past few years. Edwin makes records under the name Eola
column4: and his last album Ye features elaborate
column5: dramatic choral arrangements where he's the sole vocalist. Andy's records as Andy Boay are psychedelic and unpredictable—he creates cluttered
column6: maximal song structures that can shift suddenly from ethereal to heavy. Together
column7: they're Tonstartssbandht (pronounced tahn-starts-bandit)
column8: an endlessly touring project that's always been eclectic.

column1: For the majority's of the band's lifespan
column2: the two brothers have lived apart—Andy in Montreal
column3: Ed in New York—so their records came together during brief stints of in-person collaboration and
column4: as Andy said
column5: through ""<span>a ton of emailing
column6: megauploading
column7: and mediafiring songs to each other."" The resulting records aren't easily definable by a long shot. ""Our style of music definitely goes all over
column8: Edwin told Interview

column10: echoing tracks that are more reminiscent of straightforward rock'n'roll—you could spend the better part of a day cataloging this band's many disparate sounds. But regardless of where you hit play on any of their 24 solo and collective Bandcamp albums
column11: you'll find two talented musicians self-recording an enormous pile of ambitious music.

column1: Still
column2: the best way to experience Tonstartssbandht isn't by clicking around their various releases—it's to hear what the two brothers create in a live setting. In addition to being an accomplished vocalist
column3: Edwin is an incredible drummer. Andy creates an enormous
column4: lush sound with his 12-string Danelectro. As a duo

column6: though nothing's bleary or incomprehensible. Everything they perform seems just slightly hazy and out of reach. They're jammy

column10: their voices dart in separate directions
column11: finding harmonies that aren't always intuitive

column1: That's why Overseas is

column4: though it's not done in one live take. Much like how Ed collaged together a series of letters and words to come up with the band's name

column8: Newcastle
column9: and other cities overseas. Clearly
column10: this band thrives in ""collage"" mode

column13: a sparse
column14: echoing interpretation of the Rolling Stones track.

column1: Several times on Overseas

column3: they find the perfect spot for boiled down grooves by Amon Düül II or Pharaoh Overlord. Others more closely resemble verses-and-choruses songs

column6: invoking International Harvester's ""Sov gott Rose-Marie"" with reverence. They interrupt their 2011 track ""Hymn Our Garden"" with a maximum R&B version of Steppenwolf's ""The Pusher"". Andy's proclamation of ""I smoke a lot of grass

column8: howling that phrase and more with the gritty sincerity of his longhair forebears.

column1: With their prolific nature
column2: it would be easy to give Tonstartssbandht bonus points simply because of all the different sounds they can make
column3: but this band and Overseas are special because of how they utilize all the tools at their will. It's a live record

column8:
their proximity matters little.

Steve Gunn hadn’t been born by the time Mike Cooper decided he was done with folk-rock. After becoming one of Britain’s brightest young blues pickers and declining an invitation to join the then-fledgling Rolling Stones in the early 60s
column3: Cooper made a string of singer-songwriter records for the British label Pye. That relationship both climaxed and closed in 1972
column4: with the release of Cooper’s outlandish The Machine Gun Co.—the last in a series of three transgressive folk-rock explorations
column5: where blooming free jazz and spiraling psychedelics disrupted any simple
column6: sing-and-strum notions. Cooper lost his record contract and
column7: during the next four decades
column8: let his musical investigation and imagination run amuck. He still played the blues
column9: yes
column10: but he also mined electroacoustic improvisation and Hawaiian music
column11: operatic composition and Brion Gysin-like cut-ups. Folk-rock? Nope. Cooper bequeathed that mantle long ago
column12: only for it to be taken up in recent years by the young Gunn and scores of his peers. Once again
column13: they’ve worked to expand the sounds that such a drab term might entail
column14: picking up the antagonism that once made Cooper an outcast.

column1: But late last year
column2: despite the four decades and the ocean that separates them
column3: Cooper and Gunn rendezvoused in a Portugal airport
column4: launching 10 days of shows and a retreat in a Lisbon studio. The partnership came as a commission from RVNG Intl.
column5: the New York-based label that has issued a string of similar one-off encounters—<a href=""http://igetrvng.com/shop/frkwys-vol-8-blues-control-laraaji/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Blues Control
column6: meet Laraaji; Emeralds
column7: meet Alan Howarth—as the aptly named FRKWYS series during the last five years. The edict was simple: Make some new music
column8: and attempt to sort it into a record.

column1: The seven-song result
column2: Cantos de Lisboa
column3: might feel at first like a grab bag
column4: as the pair moves freely between a number of styles
column5: techniques
column6: and instruments. They’re both best known for their intimate voices and their intricate picking
column7: but they sing very little here and surround their guitars with a host of distractions. While they begin with twin forlorn guitars on opener “Saudade Do Santos-o-Vehlo”
column8: they shift to scraped gongs and scrambled electronics for “Song for Charlie”
column9: or at least most of it. “Pony Blues” showcases two dexterous players
column10: winding through lithe licks with the agility of the Shetlands of which Cooper sings. The focus of “Saramago”
column11: though
column12: is that of outré players
column13: with scraped strings and manipulated notes
column14: ruptured harmonics and dissonant strums suggesting the acoustic improvisations of Derek Bailey and Eugene Chadbourne.

column1: Restless
column2: career-long collaborators on their own
column3: Gunn and Cooper twirl across the electrostatic cello lines of Helena Espvall during “Pena Panorama”. Gunn sings at the end
column4: offering up a bucolic refrain about perseverance. It’s the closest the album comes to the folk-rock that serves as Cooper and Gunn respective calling card
column5: but that most accessible bit comes bound to four minutes of impish abstraction—fitting symbols for both careers.

column1: Beyond the sonics
column2: though
column3: Cantos de Lisboa isn’t nearly as sporadic or assorted as it might seem. In a brief introductory essay
column4: Cooper notes that he and Gunn attended a concert in a Fado club while in Lisbon. The spirit of that wonderfully sad music pervades and links these numbers. It’s at times obvious; drifting invocation “Saudade Do Santos-o-Vehlo” takes its name from saudade
column5: the emotional essence that bands Fado together. But you can hear that same doubt lingering inside “The Enchanted Moura”
column6: a brief and bristling cut that creeps with uncertainty. Cooper
column7: who lives in Rome
column8: and Gunn
column9: from Philadelphia
column10: seem to offer a multilingual celebration of the blues—not as a musical style
column11: but as a condition bound to the sounds of more than the Mississippi Delta or the Brits who salvaged that music. A feeling holds Cantos de Lisboa together where its music cannot.

column1: Results of forced
column2: paid-for collaborations like those on FRKWYS or the dormant In the Fishtank can be spotty
column3: plagued by outside expectations and prevailing legacy. A curator hears something connecting two artists or ensembles on record
column4: but in person
column5: those aspects don’t sync into serendipity to make new music worth hearing. Within both series
column6: examples of ideas that worked on paper and fizzled in person abound. But Cantos feels more like the start of a spark than a sample of a bankrupt idea. Gunn
column8: is an active collaborator
column9: sure
column10: from supporting songwriter Kurt Vile to exploring arid blues with drummer John Truscinski. He hasn’t had the time or the space to plunder far-flung genres and idioms the same way Cooper has. Here
column11: the elder feels like the guide
column12: leading an able and adaptive acolyte into moments that extend Gunn’s previous grasp. Cantos makes you want to know how far he will eventually go. There’s nothing quite as wild and discursive in Gunn’s catalogue as “Lampedusa 2013”
column13: for instance
column14: an abrasive philippic that might pass for Current 93. It’s one of this set’s most surprising and exciting bits
column15:
a moment that mostly makes you hope there’s more to come.

column3: during the first decade of their existence

column5: the music that Nathan and Aaron Weaver made thrived on inherent unease with expectations. On their earliest releases
column6: they repurposed the furor of black metal

column12: telling interview

column1: That distance
column2: in turn
column3: became one of music’s great recent press hooks: Wolves in the Throne Room lived on a farm
column4: not off the grid but wanting to be while growing a wide variety of vegetables and raising livestock. That tale became part of most every Wolves in the Throne Room story—how the band couldn’t wait to leave the road
column5: to return “to living in a rhythmic sort of rural way.” Otherness was the very core of their creation myth. True to form
column6: though

column9: the band admitted that maybe homesteading wasn’t such an imperative
column10: that Nathan Weaver didn’t even like sunlight very much. Still
column11: following the release of 2011’s Celestial Lineage
column12: their most compellingly restless album to date
column13: they announced with some pomp that they were taking a break—not so much breaking up as “reconnecting to hearth and home.” With Wolves in the Throne Room
column14: most everything has always been an antagonistic

column1: Given that steady tradition of ever-shifting defiance
column2: Wolves in the Throne Room’s first album in three years
column3: Celestite
column4: represents a logical oxbow. The 46-minute record foregoes the band’s former volume and tempo for a liminal mix of synthesizers and beat machines
column5: droning guitars and cascading horns. There are no propulsive blast beats or breathless tremolo guitars

column7: the Weavers used a panoply of modular and analog synthesizers to improvise collage-like instrumentals that pivot between the legacies of a dozen obvious predecessors. Those heroes come scattered between New Age and doom metal
column8: industrial and electronica: Brian Eno
column9: Coil
column10: John Carpenter
column11: Hans-Joachim Roedelius
column12: Wendy Carlos
column13: Mark Isham
column14: Stephen O’Malley and so on. Backed by horns and woodwinds and assisted by producer Randall Dunn

column1: “We didn’t want to have songs in that traditional sense
column2: ” Aaron Weaver recently told the blog Steel for Brains about the material on Celestite. “We wanted to have soundscapes
column3: and we wanted to have washes. We wanted to have planets moving past each other.” But Celestite isn’t quite the about-face it may first seem or that the Weavers might have you to believe. Ambient and exploratory passages have always been an intriguing part of Wolves in the Throne Room’s approach
column4: from the ululating female vocals that served as preludes to the field recordings and granulated sounds that functioned as interludes. In the past
column5: those moments were mere window dressing
column6: accessories that emboldened the power of everything else. Here
column7: though
column8: they become the main event

column10: writ large and with aplomb.

column1: But Celestite falls far short of the canonical references it invokes
column2: offering an attenuated version of the trips that its predecessors once provided. The same dogged mercury that made Wolves in the Throne Room interesting even when frustrating for the last decade turns Celestite into an indecisive mess. The operative pieces of opener “Turning Ever Towards the Sun”
column3: for instance

column5: it swivels between twinkling minimalism and droning languor
column6: full-volume noise and movie-theme melodies
column7: icy drift and humid electronica. During the 11-minute piece’s second half
column8: a phantom beat emerges
column9: throbbing beneath the shifts overhead. The pulse intensifies and quickens
column10: suggesting that all this harried motion might lead to one magnetic moment. But the momentum stalls out
column11: the possibility falling either to the band’s technical failure or philosophical non-commitment. It’s less a singular
column12: captivating journey
column13: a la Cluster or Popol Vuh

column1: “Celestite Mirror
column2: ” the album’s other long haul
column3: suffers the same shuffle mentality. The band moves between colossal organ roar and flute-led New Age vibrations
column4: kill-switching the sounds as though the very concept of transition were poison. The piece ends with the record’s heaviest moment

column1: In the past and at their best
column2: Wolves in the Throne Room have been able to overpower the seams in their composite music
column3: to rely more on the romance of their clamor than their middling skills as composers. They managed to retrofit black metal to post-rock by force

column1: Since word of Wolves in the Throne Room’s shift in sound began to spread earlier this year

column4: limited by definitions of metal or music or meaning at large. But why? Does a band deserve a free pass for making the “bold” decision to alienate its traditional fans

column11:
their next step remains far beyond their grasp.

In Macklemore’s wake

column8: G-Eazy will be the first to do so without relying on a dated notion of hip-hop’s sound. But ultimately These Things Happen’s strongest statement concerns the seismic impact of the artists who influenced its creation.

column10: embarrassing the rapper: “Wait up

Late last year
column2: Grass Widow's Hannah Lew released Worms/Year 5772

column4: on her own label

column1: Lew’s songwriting shifts between separate but related states—life and death
column2: shadow and sun
column3: together and apart

column1: Lew has a remarkable talent for portraying scenes in the starkest terms. “Face of the clock is never kind

column4: ” winding us in its gears. Violent symbols are everywhere. “Give your sharp knife
column5: ” she commands in the rollicking “UV

column7: mirrors

her music. But she’s looking.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20819/homepage_large.346fe00a.jpg|Promise EP|31766.0|Spazzkid|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magical Properties']|2014-07-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:42.608737|"

It takes guts to be as emotionally open as Mark Redito is on the songs he releases under his Spazzkid moniker. The Los-Angeles-via-the-Philippines producer has always let gooey sentiments slide into his work
column2: dating back to his earliest rinky-dink demos under the name Cocolulu made almost a decade ago. That willingness to let his feelings flutter out remains as he’s grown older and refined his style
column3: blossoming on last year’s Desire. That full-length found Redito dipping into new sonic territories
column4: from bouncy electro-pop to hushed numbers built around samples of Canadian duo Memoryhouse that came off like a warped VHS tape. The one consistent element and what really elevated that album
column5: however
column6: was his lyrical honesty—the very first line on Desire was “We’ve only just begun/ but I think you’re the one/ breathing life into me
column7: ” and it only got more intimate from there. The latest offering from Spazzkid
column8: the four-song Promise EP
column9: is a worthy follow-up to the vulnerable-but-dreamy Desire
column10:
as Redito continues exploring the thrills and lows of romance without hesitation.

As charming as Redito’s emotional directness can be
column11: he’s not just an adept diary keeper reciting his words over Garageband loops. His music-making smarts are just as solid
column12: and his catalog has plenty of wordless highlights too
column13: such as Desire’s woozy “Kokeshi Doll” and the J-pop-sampling “Weird Girl"". He’s taken cues from the beat music flowing out of LA over the last ten years and sculpted them into something all his own. Fittingly
column14: one of the city’s electronic-scene mainstays Daddy Kev mastered Promise
column15: giving Redito’s creations extra force compared to the wispier Desire. The EP opens with the instrumental “Lovers""
column16: a number that slinks like a more jelly-limbed Toro Y Moi cut
column17: punctuated by digitally twisted syllables.

column1: “Lovers” also signals the biggest change between this EP and Desire—whereas Spazzkid operated in a more hushed
column2: breath-on-neck mode last year
column3: Promise leans towards ecstatic release. “Truly” recruits Sarah Bonito from poppy London trio Kero Kero Bonito to tag-team with Redito. She speak-sings her segments while switching between English and Japanese rapidly
column4: keeping the song on its toes. The music matches Bonito’s playfulness
column5: as Redito drops in various sampled sounds into the mix
column6: ranging from vocal snippets to the familiar squeak of Jersey Club bed springs. The title track takes this joyful embrace to its limits
column7: Redito’s devotional claims (“I want to be the one for you/ I think I’ll be the one for you/ to hold you and to cherish you”) soundtracked by the EP’s most energetic electronics
column8: accented by his shouts
column9: turning potential greeting-card fodder into a lively sentiment.

column1: Despite the bulk of the EP being upbeat
column2: the highlight of Promise comes when Redito faces the other way. “Goodbye” is built from faux steel drums and squiggly electronics
column3: but coupled with the conflicted words at its center (“I’m leaving you tonight/ I hope someday everything’s gonna be alright”) the overall mood is less late July and more early October
column4: the beaches all closed and good times well gone. Even though it's the droopiest moment here—Redito’s singing is especially meek—“Goodbye” still bursts into a jog in its back half
column5: a twist that keeps the song from turning into too gloomy. Promise is a small introduction to Spazzkid
column6:
but one that highlights the project’s two strongest aspects—Redito’s directness and the lush music that makes him one of the most promising artists out of L.A. at the moment.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20804/homepage_large.883e2f06.jpg|Things Change|32371.0|Late Bloomer|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Self Aware'
column2:
'Tor Johnson']|2014-07-10 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:43.390983|"

You can sense that North Carolina rock trio Late Bloomer hears Dinosaur Jr.
column3: Hüsker Dü
column4: and Nirvana differently than most revivalists
column5: that they’re doing so without any pretense of sounding cool. In fact
column6: Late Bloomer don’t think of their heroes as ""indie rock"" at all
column7: but rather as some of the most popular bands of their time
column8: actual heroes who deserve to be spoken of with grand gestures.

column1: Though Late Bloomer’s forerunners have their moral
column2: ethical and sonic superiority played up in Our Band Could Be Your Life
column3: one thing that gets understated is that those bands were the ones that made it (if not necessarily financially). And so Late Bloomer sees no issue with playing this kind of music as straight-up radio rock. Opener “Use Your Words” buzzes through a descending chord progression we’ve heard countless times as well as a lyrical paradox about the failure of language; there’s the fuzzed-out guitars
column4: the thin leads over chunky
column5: descending chords
column6: the major 7ths offering a ear-turning dissonance. And yet
column7: whereas most bands of this sort allow or prefer their vocals to be buried
column8: Late Bloomer wants to be a pop band rather than a guitar band
column9: maintaining the guileless melodic simplicity of early Cloud Nothings with the brutal pace and intensity of their present work.

column1: While a strong lead single
column2: Things Change quickly diverts from ""Use Your Words"" with a couple of reverberating anthems that go on for five minutes and more
column3: recognizing that Kurt Cobain and J. Mascis likely played in the same venues as U2. “Dr. Abernathy” and “Children” are proto-grunge transferred to an arena
column4: though that doesn’t make them Pearl Jam; you hear a band that’s opening for someone at that level
column5: belting it out even as maybe 1/4th of the attendees slowly file in.

column1: There’s a degree of confidence that’s necessary to make music this familiar sound like it’s destined for something bigger than local acknowledgement; the dealer metaphor of “Dr. Abernathy” goes back damn near a half century to Revolver but Neil Mauney belts it out like he’s the first person to ever cut out the middleman between the effect of the medicine and the guy who prescribes it. On the next track
column2: he yells “I’M NOT WHO I THINK I SEE IN THE MIRROR!” and breaks out into some fancy hammer-on riffs like they’re trying to land a Guitar World transcription in 1995. If you stop for a second
column3: “Mirror” sounds like positive reinforcement and epic negation at the same time
column4: in other words
column5: an alt-rock hit.

column1: These moments tend to happen more often when Mauney is at lead; though bassist Josh Robbins has the more distinct vocal tone
column2: Mauney’s better with the one-liners. Quite literally
column3: as his verses tend to be a single phrase delivered with Bill Callahan’s acerbic
column4: deadpan succinctness—“I heard you like Jimi Hendrix too/ You smoke potpourri and then you go to school”; “I lost all the cassettes you gave to me/ There was good stuff on there."" Conserving energy by not really giving a shit becomes a manifestation of intelligence. And the emotional tenor of the LP is appropriately delivered on the title track:  “Things change/ I won’t change”. Is Mauney proud of being more unyielding than an inanimate object or the metaphysical? Or is this a terribly depressing confession?

column1: There is a stubbornness that causes Things Change to wane in its second half
column2: and that’s Late Bloomer remembering their current situation: they’re a newish indie band in a relatively marooned indie rock locale (Charlotte) with a regrettable name knocking around in small shows. And the ambition occasionally reflects that: “No Mistakes” tastes of Tropical Skittles and the first Surfer Blood album
column3: elsewhere
column4: they’re doing decent variations on Yuck’s better songs. They’re still catchy
column5: though Things Change wouldn’t really merit mention if Late Bloomer did nothing but exceed lowered expectations or just sound like a more polished version of their very undistinguished self-titled debut.

column1: On the whole
column2: Things Change is a nice surprise
column3: an opening act that actually keeps your attention for the half hour they’re allotted
column4: something that’s always a treat regardless of what genre it’s working—you don’t hear “potential” or the next great advance in indie rock. Maybe they’ll be emboldened by attention
column5: maybe they’ll decide to get day jobs
column6:
maybe they’ll continue the exponential improvement.  That’s all up to Late Bloomer and how much they’re willing to change.

"|19578.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19578-late-bloomer-things-change/|7.0|Ian Cohen

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20825/homepage_large.521a6038.jpg|Part 6 EP|29142.0|Herbert|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Accidental']|2014-07-09 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:44.006945|"

Matthew Herbert debuted his first opera earlier this year
column2: which
column3: in typically perverse fashion
column4: encouraged audience members to leave their cell phones on during the performance. It followed a flurry of activity in 2013
column5: including the release of The End of Silence
column6: an album structured around a sample of a plane dropping a bomb on Libya
column7: and a 130-track box set of the house oriented material he’s released as Herbert. Regarding the latter
column8: it felt like a typically obtuse move to take arguably his most accessible work and turn it into a test of stamina. But at this point in his career there are few surprises from Herbert
column9: to say the least. On Part 6
column10: a follow-up to his Part 1-5 series from the mid 90s
column11: he strips out all the conceptual horseplay and follows a relatively smooth path. It’s hard to know whether it’s a confounding turn or a logical one. Somehow
column12: it feels like both those things at the same time.

column1: Nothing is ever played totally straight in Herbert’s world. He steadily works through styles over the four tracks on this EP
column2: looping in strands of downtempo house
column3: soul
column4: funk
column5: and acid house. It’s unabashedly retro in its trimmings
column6: although like most Herbert releases
column7: he always throws in elements that stop his audience from fully getting their bearings. “Grab That Bottle” may initially appear to be a direct march into blocky machine noise
column8: but it evolves into something far more playful and light. In those moments Herbert reaches a point Richard D. James sometimes aims for
column9: somewhere between beauty and humor
column10: like a bird pooping in your eye as you marvel at a spectacular sunset. Herbert’s career is full of such moments
column11: but he’s managed to keep it fresh despite the enormous amount of releases under his belt
column12: largely because of how well he executes the barrage of ideas charging through his mind.

column1: Herbert specializes in tracks that pull you in with surface level fixtures
column2: only to reveal greater depth once you’re two or three plays in. “My DJ” appears to be a light dance groove spun under a pitch-shifted vocal snippet
column3: but dig deeper and there’s a far greater intricacy to it
column4: with its repetitive piston-like rhythms resembling hundreds of tiny pieces of factory equipment all working in tandem. “Manny” works in the same way
column5: only getting prettier and more inviting if you go the long haul with it
column6: as its strings of dovetailing vocal samples open up to reveal a deeper level of complexity. Both tracks form a useful parallel to Herbert’s overall career
column7: where most of his projects come bearing overarching concepts that come off as inspiring or insipid
column8: and generally find a greater weight when you strip away a few layers of theoretical decoration. Those details are important
column9: of course
column10: but often only parts that build toward the greater whole.

column1: Herbert's popularity has likely peaked
column2: but the thought of him rising up as a contemporary Bill Drummond-type figure is certainly an intriguing proposition. The opening “One Two Three” from Part 6 isn’t without its commercial charms
column3: especially in the vocal from Rahel of the London-based Hejira. It’s perfect twilight-hours house
column4: with Herbert mostly quashing the need to meddle and going straight down the line with a set of dimly-lit rhythms. Still
column5: as with most of his material
column6: it’s hard to imagine this getting play almost anywhere outside his cult
column7: perhaps unfairly. On “One Two Three” he’s somewhere close to the song oriented material that lit up his excellent work with Róisín Murphy on Ruby Blue
column8: where he instinctively knew when to pull back from the brink. Here
column9: Herbert’s somewhere between his avant and commercial selves
column10:
allowing two contrasting parts of his brain to feed off one another instead of going into all-out attack mode.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20774/homepage_large.d85ab4ee.jpg|Falling Apart|28626.0|Babe Rainbow|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kinky Beggar']|2014-07-09 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:44.523884|"

On two early EP’s for Warp
column2: Shaved and Endless Path
column3: Cameron Reed of Babe Rainbow was still feeling things out while working in a loosely post-dubstep realm. But even then
column4: you could feel him striving to separate himself from the constraint of genre
column5: and indeed
column6: his best music emerged when he shelved his cursory or redundant beats and explored more ambient
column7: textural terrain. Eventually
column8: he became frustrated and uninspired
column9: and briefly abandoned electronic music; he joined How to Dress Well’s touring band
column10: and started working at the Toronto label Arts & Crafts
column11: looking for something new.

column1: He appears to have found what he was looking for. His new album
column2: <i>Falling Apart
column3: finds him in an exploratory mode
column4: moving away from idiom and crafting a sound anchored by synths
column5: piano keys
column6: and a sense of narrative build. The record begins Eno-ambient and slowly builds into a momentous
column7: sometime triumphant gloom that recalls a range of other electronic experimentalists from Shigeto to Daniel Lopatin. In an interview with Fact Magazine
column8: Reed said that he did not want to be “saddled to a style or a genre
column9: ” and he has made good on that pledge.

column1: The challenge for him
column2: then
column3: is to bring the different sounds and textures that he explores into harmony with each other. On the best tracks here
column4: Reed takes his knowledge of a diverse array of styles and creates music with a sense of story. This holds true on both a track-to-track basis (the build from “Dub Music” to “Twin Peaks” to “Falling Apart” is exquisite)
column5: and within individual tracks. “Swept Stairs” is one of the longest tracks on the album
column6: but it's constantly introducing something new
column7: beginning as a buzzing ominous landscape and then shedding that skin in favor of a joyous
column8: piano-powered anthem. “Things That Were Not” is another highlight
column9: a haunted and unhinged cacophony that Reed manages to tame into a sensible moving machine.

column1: Reed has freed himself to pursue music that isn’t easy to categorize or predict
column2: but his sense of adventure can work against him. Falling Apart is uneven. “The Bells”
column3: for instance
column4: is one of the best tracks here
column5: a propulsive dance-floor track banger. But it operates at about twice the speed as the rest of the album and it seems like an interjection from another record. Then too
column6: there are songs like ""Plucks"" and ""The Walker""
column7: which fail from lack of momentum. They might have made sense if they’d been placed in the first half of the album
column8: when things are still moving at tortoise-pace
column9: but they seem out of place and unnecessary here. Reed has found an admirable sound on Falling Apart
column10:
but his promise not to honor any one style ultimately hurts the album’s cohesion. 

"|19547.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19547-babe-rainbows-falling-apart/|6.5|Jonah Bromwich

Black Anvil may have been forged in the mercurial fires of the New York hardcore scene
column2: but don’t call them punks. When Raeph Glicken
column3: Gary Bennett
column4: and Paul Delaney of esteemed outfit Kill Your Idols branched off to form their blackened band in 2007
column5: they abandoned the rigidity of their former craft almost immediately
column6: focusing instead on long
column7: winding assemblages of weeping guitars
column8: thrashy tempos
column9: and hard rock hooks. For every pound of black and roll gristle the band packed on to their most recent effort
column10: 2010’s Triumverate
column11: there was ample brain power to match—a labyrinthine riff here
column12: a blast-beat there. Black Anvil's impressive balance of progressivism and putridity led to their prompt inclusion in the canon of overachieving area extremists
column13: such as Liturgy or Krallice.

column1: If their new album Hail Death serves as any indication
column2: the New Yorkers have no intention of going back to basics. To buttress their fanged jams and fill in some holes in their current live setup
column3: they’ve added a second guitarist
column4: named Sos
column5: to their ranks
column6: granting a boost to both melodics and critical mass. They’re amping up the concepts as well: Hail Death centers around around the inevitable end
column7: as well as the varying degrees of madness which emerge as its approach hastens. The band treats their theme with wicked reverence
column8: expanding the song lengths to accommodate more swells and swathes of feedback. At the same time
column9: they’re the most batshit band of conductors
column10: ceaslessly toggling between turbo and turbid. There’s “Seven Stars Unseen”
column11: a harrowing ride through the void that straddles the threshold between dirge and d-beat
column12: and opener “Still Reborn”
column13: whose rich Spanish guitar provides a haunting contrast to the electrics that scream in their stead.

column1: Barring the 12-minute “Next Level Black”’
column2: which never seems to muster up enough magnitude
column3: the metamorphic approach bodes well for Black Anvil. This is due largely to their appointment of engineer J. Robbins (Modern Life is War
column4: Government Issue)
column5: whose conservative approach to mixing ensures that Hail Death’s many guitars don’t collapse into one low-res mess. By putting Bennett and Sos further back
column6: he creates a pocket of space for the vocalists’ lilting harmonies to seep in
column7: lending straightforward headbangers like “ Until the End” morbid beauty. Distinguishing between individual riffs proves trickier
column8: as their already-reduced presence is placed constantly under threat by the throttle of the blast-beats. The only fretwork left to gawk at are the solos
column9: which follow in the slithering style of Marduk and
column10: while far from revolutionary
column11: serve an invaluable role in maintaining momentum when things slow to a stoned sprawl.

column1: “To us
column2: it’s the next level
column3: ” Glicken said in a recent Decibel documentary chronicling the making of Hail Death
column4: ""Something to aim for
column5: something to shoot for
column6: something to take me out of this mundane existence.” His vague phrasing begs the question: is Black Anvil’s death drive fueled by their art
column7: or is it the other way around? On Hail Death
column8: the relationship is symbiotic; the album's darkness fuels its shifting sounds
column9: which in turn amplfies the dread. Hopefully
column10: as the outfit continues this march of mayhem
column11: the hellish balance will remain intact
column12:
securing the band’s reputation for mongrel metaphysics.

"|19440.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19440-black-anvil-hail-death/|7.5|Zoe Camp

""I’m not easy to love
column2: but I'm easy to forget
column3: Mart Wilson sings on ""Easy to Forget""
column4: the title track and thesis statement from the London dream-pop trio SIGHS' debut EP. The line is delivered with a shrug and a whisper
column5: the downy electric guitars blotting out Wilson's voice like the cotton balls in a pill bottle. Wilson has perfected the hangdog-loser pose that pairs naturally with dreamy indie-pop
column6: but Easy to Forget is the work of someone talented and confident
column7: and not looking to be forgotten.

column1: SIGHS is a studio project for now
column2: not quite a band
column3: and the six songs on this EP have the feel of a progress report. Wilson writes in scraps and fragments and often records to whatever consumer technology is handy—the voice memo app on his cell phone
column4: for instance. The second half of Easy to Forget consists of his home demos
column5: unvarnished. And these are particularly unvarnished: The rhythm track of ""Sights"" is an actual
column6: dully clacking metronome
column7: with a single keyboard note quivering feebly above it. It's not much to go on
column8: but even here the sturdy bones of Wilson's songwriting are traceable
column9: and it's not a massive leap to imagine the tremendous power-pop song the demo longs to burst into.  ""Sights""
column10: along with ""Lifetime Away"" and ""Waste""
column11: feel like diary exercises in the workbook of an excellent songwriter
column12: but they don't quite work as lo-fi recordings
column13: for reasons that are made abundantly clear in the EP's first half.

column1: The first three songs—""Easy To Forget""
column2: ""Bruise""
column3: and ""Fears""—were recorded with Misha Hering at Holy Mountain Studio
column4: and they gleam like cake toppers. The arrangement to ""Easy to Forget"" bustles with Northern-soul horns
column5: pianos
column6: chimes
column7: synths
column8: and the chorus
column9: warmed with backing vocals (""You know this house
column10: it holds so many memories/ you know this house
column11: it holds so many threats"") opens like a time-lapse video of a flower blooming. The chord progressions on ""Bruise"" feels deftly patterned after the Posies
column12: in their Frosting on the Beater era
column13: and the sound is similar: The distortion thick
column14: the mood downbeat
column15: the songs whipped higher than meringue peaks.

column1: Wilson is sharp with opening couplets
column2: which often sketch vivid scenes in minimal space. ""Bruise""
column3: which is sung to a friend trapped in an abusive relationship
column4: opens with him picking up the phone: ""Wasn't expecting this call
column5: wasn't expecting this news/ In seconds empires fall
column6: in seconds lies become truths."" ""Easy to Forget"" begins with the bemusing couplet ""'L-M-A-K-O-A E-F-X'/ She hammers at the keys
column7: though it didn't make sense."" Wilson has a feel for the gentle
column8: compassionate darkness that often feeds the subtext of the best indie-pop. His voice is human
column9: self-deprecating
column10: and relatable
column11: and when he concludes ""Bruise"" with the simple
column12: disarming promise ""If you talk
column13: I'll listen
column14: he's affecting
column15: too. There are a million just-okay power-pop bands and a scarce handful of great (or potentially great) ones
column16:
and it's heartening to hear a new band with some latent greatness in it.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20685/homepage_large.af3a9b66.jpg|DJ-Kicks|32331.0|Will Saul|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['!K7']|2014-07-09 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:46.921967|"

Will Saul’s been around for more than a decade now
column2: but in recent years the Glastonbury producer/DJ’s profile reached new levels of visibility. He started the Simple imprint in 2003 and three years later launched Aus with help from Cornwall musician Fin Greenall. Both labels continue to release material
column3: but Aus in particular has developed into one of the UK’s most notable house/techno imprints. At its best
column4: Aus has served as a breeding ground for promising talent
column5: and even its lesser releases over the last few years have lent the label a reputation for consistency.

column1: Aus and Simple have released their share of floor-driven bangers but both tip towards subtlety
column2: and that extends to Saul’s own work as a producer and DJ. In the former guise
column3: he’s worked infrequently and under his own name; last year
column4: he released a solo album as Close
column5: Getting Closer
column6: that mixed conventional melodic form with slow-burn pacing while yielding two club jams
column7: “Beam Me Up” and “OSCAR”. The approach extends to his DJ work. Although sections of his 3xCD Balance mix in 2009 showed his skill with uptempo pyrotechnics
column8: elsewhere he’s favored a more patient structure. This was none more apparent than on his contribution to BBC radio’s Essential Mix series last year
column9: which found him leaning on key players from his labels’ rosters to create a mix that relied more on mood than immediacy.

column1: His latest mix
column2: for !K7’s esteemed DJ-Kicks series
column3: continues in that vein
column4: with Saul tapping frequent Aus and Simple contributors for unreleased cuts and showing off some of the label’s more notable recent releases over the course of its 80-minute runtime. His feel for composition hasn't diminished; the mix’s first 12 minutes move by at a slow climb
column5: setting a gradually evolving mood. Things finally pick up during the back half of head-in-the-clouds Berlin techno producer Youandewan’s “Ego”
column6: which develops from a wet pound into a spinning array of soft-focus tones. ""Ego"" has the feel of a track that transforms the mix into something greater
column7: but instead it transitions into Jabru and Joel Culpepper’s ”Church”
column8: a sultry
column9: shuffling vocal tune that sounds nice enough but would’ve fit better alongside Getting Closer’s avant-pop stylings.

column1: Last year
column2: Spanish deep-house producer John Talabot’s own entry in the DJ-Kicks series proved it was possible to create a forceful document that unraveled with a slow
column3: psychedelic feel; so the relative stasis of Saul’s entry is
column4: on one level
column5: a letdown. While its stilted
column6: dreamy sense of pacing is easy enough to get lost in
column7: it’s even easier to tune out entirely. Still
column8: engaging stretches abound: Swedish house producer and co-head of the playful Studio Barnhus imprint Axel Boman impresses with the wobbly
column9: crisp-light “Dubbel (Dub)”
column10: while the mix’s final third locks into a satisfactorily consistent groove cemented by Saul’s ruddy gear workout “Pedal Power” and Dutch weirdo Legowelt’s watery
column11: aptly named “Ethereal Techno Music Will Never Die”.

column1: Of the three roles Saul plays
column2: his talents as curator are most evident
column3: and so the best moments of his DJ-Kicks installment are from artists who’ve made their name
column4: partially or entirely
column5: through releases on his labels. Irish duo Bicep
column6: who have achieved a startling level of consistency over the last few years
column7: return with the skipping
column8: high-octane “Nova”
column9: while George FitzGerald
column10: one of house music’s rising talents
column11: comes through with a big-room sheen and computerized vocals on “Wanting Needing”. Depending on where you looked
column12: FitzGerald’s tunes were all anyone could talk about in 2013; this year
column13: that title belongs to Leon Vynehall
column14: whose Music for the Uninvited showcased an appealing
column15: tasty approach to house. His contribution to Saul’s DJ-Kicks
column16: “Time”
column17: is out of step with his usual jacking fare and all the better for it
column18: a wistful slice of body music that wields subtlety with a steady hand. The lovely
column19: subdued “Time” is a prime example of the type of refined dance music Saul’s expertly curated over the last decade or so; his DJ-Kicks mix could use more moments like it
column20: but the highlights compiled here nonetheless speak to Saul’s excellent taste
column21:
as well as a reminder of why Aus and Simple have been worth following. 

"|19463.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19463-will-saul-dj-kicks/|6.1|Larry Fitzmaurice

column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Topshelf']|2014-07-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:47.630485|"

The first Braid album in 16 years ends with a song called “This Is Not a Revolution” and man...it’s hard to resist tweaking its title to comment on its surrounding circumstances
column3: i.e.
column4: “this is not a revival.” Or
column5: in the case of Braid themselves
column6: “this is not a reunion.” It’s been called one for understandable reasons. So many of their peers have gotten the band back together recently and the excitement of seeing American Football or Mineral for the first time since the late 1990s might lead you to overlook Braid having played Fun Fun Fun Fest in 2012 or a couple of gigs in 2004. Or maybe it’s just that their 2011 EP Closer to Closed is better off being forgotten. It was a Braid release in name alone—one cover and three nondescript
column7: tentative Braid originals made less because they wanted or needed to
column8: but because they could. The one lyric I remember was fitting: “I want a do over.” Consider No Coast a promise kept.

column1: No Coast doesn't pick up where Frame & Canvas left off. It doesn't sound like a band in their mid-20s
column2: though you could hear the antsy
column3: arms-akimbo “Put Some Wings on That Kid” and “Lux” as an effort by Braid to show they’re still capable of playing songs from their under-appreciated second album The Age of Octeen. Rather
column4: this is precisely the kind of album you’d expect out of Braid if they kept going after Frame & Canvas and learned how to adjust with age. Unlike Closer to Closed
column5: No Coast retains an identifiable Braid-ness
column6: the knotty musicianship that subsequent offshoot Hey Mercedes untangled and straightened—the sudden stops and cuts
column7: vocals in friendly competition
column8: an active
column9: inventive rhythm section that never calls attention to its trickery. Singer Bob Nanna was hoping people would consider Braid as a forerunner and a peer of You Blew It! and A Great Big Pile of Leaves
column10: and you can definitely hear where their new label-mates got some of their moves.

column1: But the new guys operate at full speed; Braid don’t have the athleticism or explosiveness of their earlier days
column2: but in a Tim Duncan way
column3: they’re craftier
column4: better about picking their spots. “Bang” and the title track showcase Braid’s rhythmic double clutches
column5: their pivots after sudden silence in more methodical
column6: midtempo ways
column7: patiently working towards conventionally pleasing codas. Other times
column8: Braid just goes straight for the big
column9: alt-rock chorus
column10: as “East End Hollows” and “Damages!” show Chris Broach channeling his agitation into legitimate
column11: singalong (not shout-along) hooks. His vocals have developed a high
column12: Mark Hoppus nasality
column13: which has the occasionally unfortunate effect of stressing some of No Coast’s too-cute lyrical puns. But it plays wells with the more measured and mature Nanna. While they maintain the exuberance of having too much to say at the same time
column14: the two vocalists are less likely to topple over each other; check the one-man give-and-go on “Many Enemies”
column15: or the pick-and-roll performed during the bridge of “East End Hollows”. In fact
column16: on a song-by-song basis
column17: No Coast is actually more consistent than Frame & Canvas
column18: though it wants for something as scene-defining as “The New Nathan Detroits”.

column1: But maybe they’re in a position define an entire new “scene”
column2: or at least a demographic. With the exception of Lifetime’s 2007 self-titled return
column3: I’m not sure if there’s much precedent for artists from this world making such a strong statement in their late-30s as the same band. And so No Coast is an inspired record for a very tangible reason that goes beyond associating with an in-demand producer (Will Yip) and a hip new label: Braid have taken stock of their own lives as unintentional elder statesmen and treat it as worthwhile subject matter.

column1: “Light Crisis” begins with an old recording from Nanna’s grandfather
column2: while “Put Some Wings on That Kid” obliquely references the adoptee’s recent discovery of his birth parents. But such direct
column3: autobiographical details are less frequent that the generational resonance found in the title track’s opening line: “No coast/ Is how I feel the most/ In the middle
column4: a little invisible
column5: the ghost.” The title of No Coast was intended as positive reinforcement for the band
column6: and it’s also indicative of a spiritual displacement
column7: of being overlooked and at the same time
column8: not quite sure if you're confident enough to be looked at. Two of the first three songs contain the line
column9: “This is the life
column10: ” most notably in “No Coast”: “This is the life we chose”. That life being one that hasn’t gotten Nanna or Broach much separation from the scene and people who might refer to Braid as “legendary” or Frame & Canvas as a “classic”; they probably get recognized in bars
column11: have some nice email exchanges and the occasional shout out from an up-and-coming band. But these aren’t the sort of things that would satisfy the nagging parent in “The New Nathan Detroits
column12: ” the one asking them if all of this will ever compare to a house
column13: kids
column14: and everything else that seemed for the taking for a band of Braid’s ilk right before emo's commercial breakthrough.

column1: Nanna spends a lot of time in that ""middle"" he speaks of
column2: not quite domesticated
column3: but not young and untamed either; when he calls himself a ""runaway train"" on ""Bang""
column4: it sounds like an admission of being set in one's ways rather than out of control. No Coast is very
column5: very Chicago in both sound and spirit (specific streets are name-dropped on “Light Crisis”)
column6: though in Nanna and Broach’s lyrics
column7: you’d think it was the world’s biggest college town and any given day can be a class reunion that allows you to feel the same twinge of warm nostalgia and cold reality of time moving forwards. “East End Hollows” initially sounds laudatory
column8: Broach dreaming of “drunk lust and punk love” and reveling in a DIY spirit where “happiness is in the doing
column9: in the making.” The catchiest song on No Coast is the most conflicted as well
column10: as Broach notes the false sense that happiness is also tied up in the gossip of “who knows who and what happened” and bars where diehards balance “Another drink/ Another lifetime of regret.” The chorus “You take these dreams and throw them out the window” can sound like a command rather than a lament
column11: of Broach try to live the ideals of “no coast” surrounded by people who aren’t doing shit besides resting on their laurels.

column1: But there’s no bitterness in No Coast
column2: just perspective and empathy for those who actively seek to follow in their path. Nanna understands the inherent
column3: nostalgic pull of listening to Braid in the first place and his lyrics often follow suit; he’s wishing for his bucket of old tricks in “Damages!” and grapples with young love transitioning into suburban comfort on “Pre-Evergreen"". Meanwhile Broach laments faded friendship on “Many Enemies” and marvels at the blind energy of youth of “Doing Yourself In”. Or at least that’s what I hear; Nanna and Broach are more careful about choosing their words as well and while No Coast is always emotive
column4: it’s open-ended and serves to point out that for many
column5: the “emo” established by Braid and their ilk and sought after by their fans constitutes a set of musical values as defined and worthwhile as “post-punk” or “house”. Nanna expressed that he wanted No Coast to be “exciting and vital for people that aren’t in their late 30s
column6: ” and those who’ll check it out simply because it’s on Topshelf won't be let down. But if you're a Frame & Canvas lifer who's made a home and put the kids in their beds
column7:
No Coast lets you know the great mistakes to make and chances to take are still out there.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20818/homepage_large.424c42fe.jpg|Pika Pika Fantajin|31566.0|Kyary Pamyu Pamyu|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Japan']|2014-07-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:47.764983|"

In April
column2: Avril Lavigne released a video for her song “Hello Kitty” that found the Canadian pop star wandering around downtown Tokyo and eating sushi while shouting out various Japanese phrases. Dozens of websites quickly reacted in horror to the clip
column3: outraged at her robotic
column4: personality-devoid back-up dancers and her “appropriation” of Japanese culture. These criticisms were valid
column5: but few pointed out who Lavigne took the most cues from-Harajuku-raised fashion-blogger-turned-model-turned J-pop-singer Kyary Pamyu Pamyu. Lavigne mimicked the way she often bases her fashion on sweets
column6: and filmed the bulk of “Hello Kitty” in Kyary’s stomping grounds
column7: even dancing in a store whose clothes Kyary modeled early in her career. It was a clear stab at replicating her visual aesthetic
column8: something many Japanese viewers picked up on.

column1: Lavigne didn’t pick a bad artist to imitate
column2: though. Kyary’s imaginative get-ups and surreal videos have turned her into one of Japan’s premier performers and the most globally visible J-pop star today. Outside of her home country she’s still a niche act
column3: but one whose developed a fanbase capable of selling out a three-continent-spanning tour and attracted admirers such as Ryan Hemsworth
column4: Grimes
column5: and Katy Perry. Yet non-Japanese media focuses almost exclusively on her visual side
column6: with many write-ups and reviews focusing on her “quirky
column7: ” “colorful
column8: ” and “bizarre” side. Her music is often an afterthought. Kyary’s songs
column9: however
column10: are far more complex than any of those adjectives imply
column11: and her third full-length
column12: Pika Pika Fantajin
column13: highlights the diversity within her songbook. Despite being her least consistent release to date
column14: it still reveals she’s more than a weird-Japan meme.

column1: It helps that Yasutaka Nakata
column2: one of the most famous Japanese producers of the last decade
column3: writes Kyary’s songs. With his personal project Capsule and the chart-topping trio Perfume
column4: he crafted catchy music bridging the gap between 1990s Shibuya-kei and more modern maximalist electro-pop. Working with Kyary has allowed him to experiment
column5: peaking with Kyary’s 2013 earworm-packed Nanda Collection
column6: which doubled as a thoughtful look at the onset of adulthood. Fantajin isn’t as lyrically deep
column7: but features similarly catchy pop via its singles—“Mottai-Nightland” is a good gateway into her peppier material
column8: the song ringing forward breathlessly towards a playful center. Even better is “Kira Kira Killer
column9: ” the album’s most radio-ready cut. Nakata builds the song from the same bells and digital whistles as “Mottai-Nightland”
column10: but rounds it out with a bouncy chorus wherein every syllable shines and Kyary’s backing swoons make it all the sweeter.

column1: These songs have been ever-present on Japanese TV and radio since their release
column2: but it’s not just because of their catchiness. Many J-pop singles come into existence thanks to advertising campaign tie-ins
column3: companies approaching well-known performers and giving them a vague idea what they want and letting them come up with the rest. The aforementioned Kyary tracks both soundtrack ads for cellphones
column4: while another Fantajin number
column5: “Yumeno Hajima Ring Ring”
column6: serves as a theme for an apartment-finding app. What separates Kyary (and Nakata) from many other J-pop acts is a refusal to be lazy about it
column7: as they try to make these more than disposable jingles. Whereas many other songs aimed at graduating students (possibly in need of housing) are gloopy ballads
column8: the melancholy “Yume” skips ahead
column9: backed by breezy guitar and anxious lyrics more worried about the future than nostalgia. Even “Family Party”
column10: created as the theme song for an animated movie—an assignment Nakata has mailed in before—at least finds Kyary trying out a chirpy chiptune sound that is serviceable for its brief run time.

column1: Fantajin’s most interesting developments come on the album-only cuts. “Serious Hitomi” rolls out the most aggressive guitar playing to appear on a Kyary Pamyu Pamyu song
column2: yet the in-your-face playing backs up a song about being deeply shy
column3: and swivels into one of the best and cuddliest choruses on the album. “Tokyo Highway” teases EDM with its skittering repetition of Kyary’s voice
column4: but Nakata never lets the song drop in on itself
column5: instead settling into a twinkling jog accented by the prettiest keyboard plinks on the album. But Fantajin’s highlight is also its biggest curveball. “Sungoi Aura” plays out like a silly Broadway musical number more than a pop song
column6: but it features Kyary at her most clever
column7: lyrically
column8: and Nakata nailing all the details needed to really sell the theatrical bend of the track (those piano flairs!).

column1: Pushing yourself
column2: however
column3: means falling flat on your face sometimes. “Koi Koi Koi""'s semi-creepy-waltz vibe runs out of steam quickly
column4: while closing track “Explorer” features sparse production that puts the spotlight on Kyary Pamyu Pamyu’s voice
column5: which is not equipped for hitting the high-notes she aims for here. The biggest misfire on Fantajin—and the worst song of her career thus far—is “Ring a Bell
column6: ” her first all-English effort. Its existence is strange enough
column7: given that her growing international fanbase doesn’t seem to care if she can sing a song in English. It sounds like a bad children’s TV show theme that ran out of ideas in 30 seconds pressed on for more than four minutes.

column1: Fantajin stumbles at times and ultimately feels like a transitional album
column2: but its mix of new sonic twists and straight-up pop delicacies make for good listen overall
column3: underscoring the fact that Kyary Pamyu Pamyu is more than a YouTube oddity. And more people are picking up on that: Kyary is currently working with wonky producer Sophie and French pop act Yelle on new music
column4:
an intriguing development in her still-young career.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20777/homepage_large.8ea7d214.jpg|Wooden Head|32358.0|The Proper Ornaments|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland'
column3: Argentinian songwriter Max Claps and James Hoare
column4: of UK indie-poppers Veronica Falls
column5: started a London band named after a song by so-square-they're-psychedelic 1960s baroque-poppers the Free Design. What the Proper Ornaments have in common with ""The Proper Ornaments""
column6: from 1967 opus Kites Are Fun
column7: isn't immediately obvious
column8: but it starts with a penchant for hypnotic harmonies and continues with an insistence on the right decorations. Where those sunshine-y forebears quasi-ironically skewered ""Mad Men""-era superficiality—""brand new car
column9: ""hat and gloves
column10: ""pretty wife who you almost love""—the '10s model proudly accessorizes itself with scruffy neo-psych.

column1: The stylistic touches on Wooden Head—billed as the Proper Ornaments' proper debut LP after last year's promisingly ramshackle Waiting for the Summer
column2: which collected previously released singles and EPs—are extraordinarily ordinary ones for an indie band. Next to those sweet Beach Boys vocal counterpoints sit Byrds-buzzing guitar interplay and some-Velvet Underground-morning detachment. With its rickety eight-track recording
column3: you'd be hard-pressed to guess whether the album was influenced more by the O.G.s or their offshoots: the British C86 scene
column4: California's Paisley Underground movement
column5: New Zealand's Flying Nun label. In woolier moments
column6: throw in the Beta Band. In shoegazier
column7: throw in Ride or even early the Verve. There's a song called ""Stereolab""; it actually sounds a bit like a Stereolab.

column1: As that list of comparisons probably suggests
column2: the Proper Ornaments mix and match these related yet distinct sonic accoutrements well enough that they might one day become a reference point themselves—which you might expect
column3: considering they've shared bills with fellow magpie-connoisseurs such as Crystal Stilts
column4: Woods
column5: and Real Estate. As with those bands' efforts
column6: though
column7: Wooden Head is strongest when it leaves you remembering smart hooks rather than a clever aesthetic. Check out ""Magazine
column8: maybe the breeziest song ever from the point of view of ammunition
column9: or elegiac finale ""You'll See"". Weather
column10: a recurring theme since the previous record
column11: is beside the point on the gentle ""Summer's Gone""
column12: which applies the sepia softness of the Clientele to being ""old enough to lose your own mind.""

column1: For every band like Deerhunter or Los Campesinos!
column2: who turn their indie-inclined record collections into something appealing of their own
column3: music history is littered with others who mine the clerk-approved past without adding much to those halcyon days at all. Claps and Hoare
column4: joined here by bassist Daniel Nellis and drummer Robert Syme
column5: certainly skirt that risk—the guitar chimes on ""What Am I to Do?"" bring to mind ""Dear Prudence"" by the Beatles
column6: whose enshrined-in-marble likeness rarely flatters anybody. But the Proper Ornaments may have been just as shrewd in naming their album as in naming their band: Wooden Head was the title of a 1969 odds and ends compilation by the Turtles
column7: released after the ""Happy Together"" group split. As humble
column8: tastefully appointed psych-pop goes
column9: the Proper Ornaments surely have their hearts—and heads
column10:
wooden or not—in the right place.
