When Donovan Quinn and Glenn Donaldson of the Skygreen Leopards sing about love
column3: you don’t have to fear for your heart. The California psyche-pop duo’s latest album
column4: Family Crimes
column5: has a triptych of love songs that are gentle enough to only scratch the surface of melancholy. “Love Is a Shadow” shuffles through piles of fallen leaves
column6: with Quinn and Donaldson harmonizing like sun and honey. “Is It Love
column7: Love Love” saunters along
column8: a nugget of cosmic country with an aftertaste of Tang instead of blotter acid. And “It’s Not Love”
column9: the darkest of the three
column10: goes so far as to sketch an ever-so-slightly harrowing scenario on a sheet of squeaky-clean folk-pop: “Too much blood on the water/ Nothing left to say/ It’s not love/ It’s just blood.” It’s alright
column11: ma; they may be only bleeding
column12: but they have a box of Band-Aids handy. The Skygreen Leopards once wrote songs with far more twists and turns. In particular
column13: 2006’s Disciples of California embraced ragged edges
column14: off-the-beat wobble
column15: and an almost aggressive lethargy. That slight yet deliberate rawness is all but gone on Family Crimes; in its place is soft-focus haze that barely conceals the group’s penchant for neat-as-a-pin precision.

column1: Mostly
column2: it works: “WWIII Style” is breathless
column3: studio-apartment pop
column4: with the high notes seemingly sung into a sink. “Reno Wedding” rings and twangs with Byrds-like shimmer as Quinn’s and Donaldson’s voices tumble out of them like bashful apologies. There are regrets embedded in “Crying Green & Purple” and “Mascara Priscilla”—they do both allude to tears
column5: after all—but the clouds are thin and wispy
column6: and they’re blown away as quickly as they gather.

column1: Some of the internal references on Family Crimes feel like hyperlinks. “Leave the Family”—a gorgeous splay of Crayola colors and therapeutic jangle—is later reincarnated as “Leave the Family Reprise”
column2: a sloth-paced coda that acts more as a balm than a parting shot. And when the la-la-la-happy “Josephine” segues into “Mascara Priscilla”
column3: it’s as if they’re flip sides of the same conflicted character. “I’m all right with the Christian life
column4: ” goes a line in “Mascara Priscilla”
column5: and the reference to the Byrds’ cover of The Louvin Brothers’ “The Christian Life” feels less like a wink and more like a solemn nod.

column1: Nebulous Christian themes have popped up before in the Skygreen Leopards’ songbook
column2: and Family Crimes is no different. “Suburban Bibles” is so mumbly and bright-eyed
column3: it might as well be a sing-song lullaby for Sunday school naptime. “Selling T-Shirts” even veers into the realm of Jonathan Richman with its chiming strum and the mundane juvenilia of lines like
column4: “Drop me off at the shopping center.” Granted
column5: the phrase “Quaalude rapture” is also bandied about; the pharmaceutical-friendly Skygreen Leopards of old still make their presence known
column6: just more subtly and wryly. Quinn and Donaldson may be getting somewhat longer in the tooth
column7: but they’re sounding younger. And whatever darkness lurks within Family Crimes is swallowed back down with a wise
column8:
dreamy smile.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20718/homepage_large.1b3c1d83.jpg|Calypso: Musical Poetry in the Caribbean 1955-69|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soul Jazz']|2014-07-08 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:49.678674|"

Chances are that if you grew up in North America you probably think of calypso music as conga-line fodder for sunstroked tourists on Club Med cruise ships. In truth
column2: its history and function is more like early hip-hop’s: Party music that doubled as a delivery system for current events
column3: street wisdom
column4: social humor
column5: and reflections on daily life from the vantage point of an imagined Average Joe.

column1: Take some of the songs on Soul Jazz’s new compilation
column2: Calypso: Musical Poetry in the Caribbean
column3: whose subjects include the James Bond movie Goldfinger
column4: the 1969 Moon landing
column5: interracial heart transplants
column6: and how a young man who calls himself Brownie would like to be reincarnated as a bedbug so he can nibble on the asses of any woman he deems chubby enough.

column1: They are sweet songs
column2: told with a big heart and sly sense of humor. Even when political
column3: they are good-natured
column4: almost resigned
column5: more apt to shrug at the chaos of life than imagine they can do anything to control it. Listen to 1980s hardcore and you may come out incensed by evil and greed; listen to calypso and you may come out feeling like your only recourse is to raise an eyebrow and watch the parade go by. Calypso’s ambivalence is especially interesting given that it reached full bloom during the 1940s
column6: when American occupation of Trinidad had led to economic inflation and a spike in prostitution. It could have been protest music but it took the high road and became satire.

column1: As advertised
column2: Musical Poetry spans 1955-1969. In 1948
column3: Calypsonians like Lord Kitchener and Young Tiger had moved to London to get work at clubs. (Where did these people get their names? My only answer implies the existence of divinity.) In 1950
column4: the West Indies cricket team beat England at Lord’s
column5: a symbolic event commemorated in Lord Beginner’s “Victory Test Match”. By 1957
column6: the Guyanese performer Cy Grant was making regular appearances on a BBC news program called Tonight
column7: where he sang short calypsos about daily events
column8: each with the assurance that “We bring you the news that you ought to know/ In Tonight's topical calypso.” What started as regional Trinidadian music had by the mid-1950s become continental pop.

column1: Musical Poetry is charming but lightweight. Several of its tracks are instrumental
column2: which offer glimpses into the genre’s connection with jazz but aren’t sticky or complex enough to come back to. Though I hoped Young Growler would be able to break his prepubescent fascination with the name Pussy Galore while singing about Goldfinger
column3: it was not to be
column4: nor is Azie Lawrence able to offer insight into England’s Carribean Diaspora beyond the notion that they must get pretty cold in the winter. And black people are great athletes and white people can’t dance
column5: et cetera. One of the album’s highlights
column6: “The Bedbug Song”
column7: is a cover of Mighty Spoiler
column8: which is only disappointing because one of the wonderful promises of calypso is that anyone can get up there and offer their weird little opinion
column9: sans poetry or finesse.

column1: My favorite song here might be Lord Cobra’s “Negro Heart”
column2: which reports novel news of the world’s first successful human heart transplant
column3: performed in late 1967 by the South African surgeon Christiaan Barnard. For a calypso
column4: the song is uncharacteristically mournful
column5: processing at a mid tempo in a minor key. “I hope I am not talking to quickly
column6: ” Cobra says. “It’s a negro that did do the trick/ The heart patient was living the longest
column7: a negro heart beating inside his chest.”

column1: Only that wasn’t what actually happened. The donor
column2: Denise Darvall
column3: was a white woman who’d been fatally killed in a car crash the day earlier. Cobra’s news is a fiction. The salience of the metaphor is not lost
column4: especially in the context of music born in the colonies and popularized among the supposed civility of the mainland: Inside a white man beats a black man’s heart. “Bom
column5: bom
column6: bom
column7: ” the backing vocalists chant in rhythm
column8: mimicking the pump.

column1: For interested parties
column2: there are other
column3: better places to start: Mighty Sparrow’s Volume One
column4: Rounder Records’ Calypso Calaloo
column5: the first volume of the perennially lauded series London Is the Place for Me
column6: released by Damon Albarn’s Honest Jon’s label. <i>Calypsos From Trinidad: Politics
column7: Intrigue and Violence in the 1930's is great too
column8: as is 16 Carnival Hits
column9: by Sparrow and Lord Kitchener.

column1: The lessons of the genre—stay grounded
column2: pay attention
column3: nourish your skepticism and don’t forget to laugh—seem bizarrely unheralded. I
column4: for one
column5: tend to side with Viper
column6: a singer who takes news of the Russian space dog Laika as final evidence that he would be better off on all fours
column7: “Eating all good things as I like
column8:
and now and then a cruise in a satellite.”

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20720/homepage_large.bd879680.jpg|"""Cassette"" EP"|32165.0|Viet Cong|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer']|2014-07-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:50.254307|"

The Calgary-based band Women had the enviable ability of being able to shake up a bunch of familiar ingredients and come out the other side sounding like little else. Both their albums
column2: Women and Public Strain
column3: had the air of works made in isolation
column4: with the band members cut adrift from contemporary movements and prevailing stylistic forces. Women ended in acrimony and tragedy
column5: but two of their number
column6: Matt Flegel and Mike Wallace
column7: have picked up the pieces in Viet Cong
column8: where they work alongside Scott Munro (from Women producer Chad VanGaalen's band) and guitarist Daniel Christiansen. ""Cassette"" is their scrappy introduction to the world; it’s the sound of parts congealing but not yet feeding off one another
column9: as you might expect from something originally put out as a tour-only release. Now it's been buffed up and cleaned out
column10: and with Mexican Summer behind it and Women’s reputation on their backs
column11: it’s no longer the low-key intro it may have been conceived as during the band’s formation.

column1: There’s something welcoming and likeable about ""Cassette""
column2: from the awkward lurches in style to the desire to stick something out that’s less than fully formed. Women certainly didn’t operate that way
column3: instead creating a world full of chilly remove. Viet Cong appear to be systematically lessening that bite and opening themselves up to their audience
column4: although traces of their former selves remain. It's a process of steadily rinsing out the old to get to somewhere new. On “Bunker Buster” (not included on this release)
column5: the nascent Viet Cong impaled themselves on jagged guitar lines
column6: lost monotone vocals
column7: and lines where they “slowly fall through the snow.” So far
column8: so familiar
column9: but there have been changes since then
column10: some of which hint at a future for this band that could outstrip anything that came before.

column1: Viet Cong's songs are complex puzzles. It’s like they hear the direction a song is going in and then purposefully take a step in a different direction
column2: and from that place they try to figure out the least obvious way to get back to where they started. The thrill of listening to them is in hearing how they deliberately hurl obstacles in front of themselves while trying to maintain a sense of forward momentum. “Throw It Away”
column3: one of their strongest songs
column4: begins as a ringer for the Damned’s “New Rose” before diverting into knotty math-rock guitar lines and Wendy Carlos-inspired synth drones. On “Throw It Away” and the similarly clattering “Oxygen Feed”
column5: they’re stern
column6: frantic
column7: driven by a need to get right up in people's faces. Women’s music was sometimes so out of reach it felt like an intrusion to be in the same room as them; in contrast
column8: Viet Cong thrive on audience-performer conflict.

column1: The cover of Bauhaus’ “Dark Entries”
column2: which sounds like a live recording
column3: is a peak for the nihilistic streak that cuts deep into this band. It’s their most forthright performance
column4: strung somewhere between garage rock and straight punk but with a weirdo edge simmering over the top
column5: recalling the mixture of studied mannerisms and unhinged damage that Clinic could produce at their peak circa Internal Wrangler. When Viet Cong deviate from the bloody path there are mixed results. In placid mode they get back to Women’s altered-states take on the Beach Boys
column6: which was never that band’s strongest look (“Static Wall”); and the attempt at digging up cold wave synth tones and substituting fury for furrowed brow crooning is best forgotten (“Structureless Design”). It’s in those moments that the original intent behind this EP comes bruising back into view—it’s the sound of a group of people finding their way
column7: testing out ideas
column8: sketching out the little details but not coloring in the bigger picture just yet.

column1: What ""Cassette"" ultimately does is throw down a set of directions Viet Cong could head in and allow us to sit back and wonder which will be the strongest thread. As a glimpse of what a band could be it’s fascinating
column2: especially as the songs leave the impression of a group with strong personalities in the mix
column3: all determined to leave a stamp on the music they make. Flegel and Munro have talked about their day jobs
column4: in flooring and cupcake delivery
column5: respectively. At their best
column6: the band reads as a group of people trying to make beautiful and extraordinary art rise from mundane circumstances. On ""Cassette"" they’re halfway there
column7: feeling out designs
column8: seeing what sticks
column9: nixing what doesn’t. This is a picture of the process of making music
column10:
with all its flaws and triumphs intact. 

"|19495.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19495-viet-cong-cassette-ep/|7.8|Nick Neyland

Of all the bands that have contributed to Crammed Discs’ Congotronics series over the last decade
column2: Kasai Allstars are the one that cast the widest sonic net. It’s built into the band and reflected in their name; they’re allstars because they play in other groups. Five
column3: to be exact
column4: each representing the electric street music of a different ethnicity. They are a cultural melting pot
column5: blending the hovering guitars of Congolese pop music with heavy percussion
column6: electrified likembes (thumb pianos)
column7: a couple of different vocal styles
column8: and a seemingly sharp awareness of the way they’re perceived abroad as much as a story as a band.

column1: Beware the Fetish is their second Western release
column2: produced by Vincent Kenis
column3: and it is a sprawling document
column4: clocking in at an hour and 42 minutes. It is
column5: to state the obvious
column6: not the right entry point into the Congotronics series (the first Konono N°1 album probably deserves that distinction)
column7: but it offers a lot to explore for anyone looking for more of the peculiar buzz and rumble that characterizes the series. While past entries in the series
column8: including this group’s debut
column9: have had the feel of albums or compilations with carefully honed structures
column10: this one is about as immersive an experience as you’d expect something almost two hours long to be. It’s a well-curated field recording
column11: for all intents
column12: capturing the band in action as it explores its own sound.

column1: This leads to some arresting moments. “As They Walked Into the Forest on a Sunday
column2: They Encountered Apes Dressed as Humans” somehow lives up to its title
column3: the likembes
column4: xylophones and hand drums building into a dark and knotty groove. On nearly every track
column5: the elements of the song move around in the mix as though the microphone is exploring the room to get a different angle on the proceedings. Vocals drift to the forefront and then fall back to reveal a cycling guitar figure or a fuzz-toned likembe. It’s an almost diagrammatic approach to sound; different parts of the diagram shed light on different details.

column1: Listeners shouldn’t come looking for alternative takes on funk and rock
column2: or even anything like a punchy song or arrangement. Those things are all expectations we map onto this music
column3: and none of them are anything like the point of this record. This is an album that asks you to sink into its sounds
column4: takes a left every time you expect it to take a right and moves slowly most of the time
column5: letting things happen rather than forcing them. It’s not quite like anything else
column6:
including the other Congotronics releases.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20724/homepage_large.3bb02750.jpg|The Phoenix|32344.0|Fhloston Paradigm|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2014-07-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:51.422643|"

When King Britt's Presents Fhloston Paradigm first appeared on Hyperdub in 2012
column2: it seemed a fairly gritty offering from a producer known mostly for emotive house. But the Philadelphia-born DJ
column3: who got his start touring with Digable Planets
column4: is also something of a shapeshifter: with his “King Britt Presents…” projects
column5: he’s shuffled through a number of styles with seemingly unstoppable energy—he’s mixed classic disco-funk with jazzy chill-out textures under the name Sylk 130; another project consisted entirely of re-mixed vocals from New Orleans gospel singer Sister Gertrude Morgan. One of the threads through this eclectic catalogue is an underlying Afrocentrism; another is Britt’s studied approach to meticulous genre emulation.

column1: His new album
column2: which sees Britt assuming the name Fhloston Paradigm as a full-on alias
column3: revisits and fleshes out the same territory as the EP
column4: which functioned as a kind of alternate soundtrack to Luc Besson’s pop-art sci-fi flick The Fifth Element (the name Fhloston Paradigm itself originated with “Fhloston Paradise
column5: ” the futuristic resort Bruce Willis’ character visits in the film.) It’s a concept that recalls not only the Afrofuturist tendencies of early techno
column6: but the heady positivity of '90s pop culture
column7: when science fiction trafficked more in sensory manipulation than dystopian paranoia. Britt carries it off with a sonic precision that can be dazzling
column8: but at times strays into territory that feels blinkered by nostalgia.

column1: The menacing
column2: back-to-basics EP cut “Chasing Rainbows” reappears
column3: and its slowly downshifting melody remains the most memorable earworm here. The rest of The Phoenix distances itself from the gear-grinding analog techno of the EP
column4: applying that track’s mutant-pop gravitas as a schematic for something more dramatic. The production sounds more expensive
column5: and the arrangements more elaborate
column6: with six of the tracks featuring guest vocalists.

column1: As a producer
column2: Britt is in fine form here
column3: and listening to the album on a good pair of headphones reveals truly beautiful details—the expressive drumming on “Letters of Past”
column4: the subtle
column5: woozy dissonance that emerges from the immersive clouds of album closer “Light on Edge”. Surprisingly
column6: Britt’s melodic sense is easier to appreciate on the fully instrumental tracks—see the icy synth lines on the dizzying “Race to the Moon”
column7: an early highlight. By contrast
column8: the sung melodies sound simplistic
column9: and when there are discernible lyrics
column10: they’re more distracting than atmospheric. It’s hard to hear Natasha Kmeto’s appearance on “Light on Edge” without thinking of Fhloston Paradigm’s fantastic
column11: seductive remix of her track “Deeply”
column12: which saw him embellishing around a straightforward vocal line to hypnotic effect.

column1: The pinnacle of the album comes on the nine-minute title track
column2: its mutating rumble of drums and ominous chords anchoring a teased-out jumble of synth notes that eventually emerges as a bee-sting-precise melody. There’s nothing more absorbing on the album
column3: or sweeter on the ears. It’s a massive-sounding elaboration on burnt-out techno
column4: and inventive enough to explain why a somewhat backward-looking project would find a home on Hyperdub
column5: a label that’s always seeking to push dance music into the future.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the rest of The Phoenix has a tendency towards the anodyne
column3: a flaw that lies more in the languorous composition than the execution. “Tension Remains”
column4: which features operatic vocals from Pia Ercole
column5: sounds like a fairly explicit call-back to Besson’s famous blue-skinned diva
column6: but The Phoenix lacks the narrative quality to make it anything more than an amusing reference. The album is also an hour long—short by film score standards
column7: but for an album with several leisurely ambient stretches
column8: it’s a commitment to sit through. Fhloston Paradigm’s continued association with The Fifth Element makes sense: that film’s vision of the future was more concerned with the surface-level pleasures of gaudy costumes and kinetic choreography than developing a deeper subtext. The Phoenix is a similar beast
column9: simultaneously muscular and fluffy
column10:
a well-polished album that sometimes feels perplexingly one-dimensional.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20805/homepage_large.17f21229.jpg|What Moon Things|32372.0|What Moon Things|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hot Grits']|2014-07-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:52.038739|"

During the queasy
column2: airlocked “The Astronaut”
column3: Jake Harms belts out
column4: “I’m nostalgia” and “I’m alcoholic dreams of being 19
column5: 23.” Both of these lines are indicative of What Moon Things’ preoccupation with both the allure and incapacitation of addiction. Unsurprisingly
column6: the trio’s debut LP is haunted by the most recognizable junkie of folklore
column7: the vampire—just peep the inclusion of both “The Vampire” and “Vampir” on the tracklist and its cover
column8: which would look mighty fine on the front of a high school goth's Trapper Keeper in 1992. And they indeed have a nostalgic
column9: youthful idea of how vampires and indie rock should interact—think “Nosferatu Man” and “Bela Lugosi’s Dead”
column10: and forget Stephenie Meyer ever happened. As such
column11: nothing about What Moon Things is sexy
column12: cute or dashing; instead
column13: these eight anti-romantic horror stories find a band who's fanged
column14: emaciated and out for blood.

column1: What Moon Things developed their doddering
column2: incommunicado sound in New Paltz
column3: New York
column4: a place that's isolated even by the standards of the other isolated Empire State outposts that have made major contributions to indie rock in 2014—it’s about three hours from Perfect Pussy’s homebase of Syracuse
column5: about half that from the SUNY Purchase enclave that has abetted NYC’s minor explosion of folk weirdos. You might think What Moon Things was part of the latter scene
column6: seeing as how Harms’ voice is almost indistinguishable from that of Porches./Frankie Cosmos’ Aaron Maine; his singing is off-key but on-point
column7: a desperate yelp from an unstable man
column8: though the assumed squalor makes you think of a guy trapped in a well rather than a dive bar.

column1: Cooperstown and Queens are about equidistant from New Paltz and if What Moon Things didn't drive upstate to see the Modest Mouse and Brand New co-headlining show that took place earlier this year
column2: I guarantee they'll head to the city for the one in August. And I guarantee they hoped the former played nothing from after 2000 and the latter played nothing prior to 2006. What Moon Things tease out the similarities between those responsible for “Jesus Christ” and “Jesus Christ Was an Only Child”: for one thing
column3: a protagonist who narrates with an uneasy
column4: medicated or even kinda alien worldview. Either way
column5: something’s just off about the guy and he functions more as a slightly removed observer of life than a participant.

column1: The connection is also played out in Harms' guitars; befitting his name
column2: nothing here is strummed or caressed. He fills out the spaces of What Moon Things with palm-muted clean riffs
column3: gnarled note clusters
column4: and pinched harmonics flanged out to be slightly sharp. John Morisi plays with a similarly effective anti-technique; his disregard for actual timekeeping and proclivity to just hit every single piece of his kit as hard as possible would drive a drum teacher insane. Only the quasi-title track keeps the same tempo throughout its entirety and that’s only because it’s a one-minute instrumental. Abetted by the dry
column5: stark production
column6: every drum thwack is the sound of metal hitting bone and flesh
column7: the lack of decay echoing the shock of seeing someone actually get injured. Harms’ vocals and odd melodic sense ensure What Moon Things sticks; Morisi ensures that you hear them differently every time.

column1: Within the context of What Moon Things
column2: the physical musicianship draws out an underlying potential for violence in Harms’ downcast demeanor. He sings of vampires when he’s more of a zombie
column3: a zoned-out
column4: single-minded half-human. “Get you” is notably spelled as “getchoo” in the lyrics sheet and that should give you an indication of where Harms often goes mentally to source the pathetic
column5: needy nature of male heartbreak: “I’m such an adult/ With high school stuck in my head”; “I see your face on every girl”. “Staring at the Radio” is the one time he’s actually able to get out of the house and it’s only to sit in a car
column6: waiting for the battery to die; the title itself twists a common trope to be even more fucking piteous
column7: like he can’t even handle the visual stimuli of television.

column1: What Moon Things describe the totality of this sound as “dreamo”
column2: which I believe was a phrase first coined by non-descript At the Drive-In offshoot Sparta; What Moon Things sound nothing like Sparta and Sparta sounded nothing like particularly atmospheric emo. What they mean to say is that they like both shoegaze and emo
column3: two genres which really don’t intersect as much as one would expect; both are concerned with conveying a feeling
column4: but the former stresses sensual implication
column5: the latter articulation. What Moon Things aren’t very “dreamo” either: their shoegaze isn’t pretty
column6: as the gaseous
column7: suffocating “Doesn’t Make Much Sense” and “Squirrel Girl” finds Harms’ head in an oven rather than the clouds.

column1: While fine pieces of exhaust pipe ambience
column2: those two songs are less intriguing than the striking minimalism of “The Vampire” and “The Astronaut”
column3: proof that What Moon Things benefit from directness and concision. This much is evidenced in What Moon Things potentially qualifying as one of the strongest EPs of the year
column4: but it’s a full-length that may have been forced against its will to get there. The consecutive sequencing of its two most distorted tracks
column5: the instrumental and the near-reprise of “Vampir” verge on introducing redundancy to a very short record. Still
column6: the rousing closer “Son
column7: Where’s the Fire” makes a great case for What Moon Things’ promise rather than their limitations; the group chorus is the only true extroverted
column8: urgent moment
column9: and it gives an compelling voice to a cosmic teenage demand to take the power back: “Sun
column10: where’s the fucking fire?” After all
column11: What Moon Things recognize the world is a vampire
column12:
sent to drain.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20749/homepage_large.e03b0c58.jpg|We Are Only What We Feel|32351.0|NONONO|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2014-07-07 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:52.781865|"

There's nothing wrong with affirmation
column2: but NONONO doesn't sound like a project that knows exactly what it's affirming. A new collaboration between production duo Astma & Rocwell and singer Stina Wäppling
column3: the Swedish trio gestures toward the otherworldly moodiness of more adventurous electronic artists from their corner of the world. The group's debut We Are Only What We Feel is full of the kind of itchy beatwork that populated MØ's No Mythologies to Follow earlier this year
column4: but falls even further from the Scandinavian equilibrium of terror and pleasure best embodied in the Knife's early work.

column1: NONONO hold onto a distinctly West Coast optimism on their first LP
column2: cutting a closer kinship to their future tourmates Foster the People or even the Dandy Warhols than any of the iconic electro-pop artists whose trappings they channel. Slick and shallow
column3: the production on tracks like ""Jungle"" pairs a software-preset's take on ""tribal"" drums with guitar strokes so tight it's impossible to tell if they ever shook out of a real instrument. Advance single ""Pumpin Blood"" moves from a two-note intro borrowed from Snow Patrol into a chorus that wants so badly to be joyful
column4: but leans entirely on the whistlecore that unraveled when Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros' ""Home"" got its two-thousandth play on Clear Channel.

column1: The songs here wear happy on their skin
column2: but start to take on the quality of a smile held too long to be natural. Wäppling sings ""Pumpin Blood"" like it's more of an earworm than it is
column3: enunciating lyrics that don't do much besides reiterate anatomical fact: ""It's your heart/ It's alive/ It's pumping blood."" In a Knife song
column4: the words might come through almost as a threat
column5: rife with irony. Pasted onto this song's bare
column6: obvious melody
column7: they feel forgettably thin.

column1: Though We Are Only What We Feel plods through similar tempos and uniform textures
column2: Wäppling sings with enough character to keep the record from fading into the background. On ""Like The Wind""
column3: she counters clumsy percussion with an unsettling squawk that does more to divide time than the beat. Against a staid piano arpeggio and bizarrely mismatched fuzz bass
column4: her head voice strains with longing through the chorus of ""Echo"". At times
column5: it feels like Wäppling is even fighting against her collaborators; ""Down Under"" punctuates her lines with a cheap sci-fi arpeggio
column6: like Astma & Rocwell wanted to insist upon their presence as real producers of real electronic music.

column1: Maybe there's an idiomatic rift at play here—it could be that Swedish is a language less inundated with poetry about the heart and its zest for life—but it seems more likely than NONONO started to feel comfortable before they felt confident. Very little in the album speaks to risk or discovery. The patches are the same ones that scatter throughout Soundcloud under the hands of kids trying Ableton for the first time
column2: while the lyrics don't strive for much beyond #poetry. More than complacency
column3: I hear a gridlock. Wäppling and her producers seem to be staring at each other from across an unproductive vacancy
column4: not generating new ideas from their discrepancies
column5: but playing in their own worlds
column6:
barely communicating.

"|19524.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19524-nonono-we-are-only-what-we-feel/|5.8|Sasha Geffen

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20766/homepage_large.9e0fc0ea.jpg|High Life|526.0|Brian Eno|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2014-07-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:53.601254|"

In 2010
column2: the announcement that Brian Eno had signed to Warp Records was an event. His decades-long history of groundbreaking electronic music had a lot to do with Warp even existing at all
column3: so the fact he was going to be working with the imprint known for taking the torch in the 1990s and 2000s brought dreams of great things. Lost in the excitement was the memory that Eno had for a number of years been making low-key records that made little impact outside of his cult. Another Day on Earth from 2005
column4: his first song-based solo album in many years
column5: had some <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YxOCdRdYzZw&feature=kp"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">memorable songs
column6: and his 2008 pairing with David Byrne
column7: Everything Happens Today
column8: found an audience. But ’90s and ’00s instrumental releases like Drawn From Life
column9: The Drop
column10: Neroli
column11: and The Shutov Assembly didn’t come close to entering his canon. The Warp signing obscured the fact that Eno always had more than his share of uneven records
column12: in part because he’s never been the sort of artist interested in perfection. So the fact that four of the records and collaborations released on Warp have ranged from a lovely retread of familiar ground (2012’s Lux) to eminently forgettable collaborations (the two records with poet Rick Holland
column13: and the first with Underworld’s Karl Hyde) should surprise nobody.

column1: High Life
column2: though
column3: is a genuine surprise. As the second meeting between Eno and Hyde in the last four months
column4: it would have been reasonable to expect outtakes
column5: another set of OK half-songs to accompany the ones released earlier this year. But High Life—recorded in just five days
column6: with much of it played and processed live—is something else altogether. This is Eno’s best vocal album in 25 years
column7: since his 1990 collaboration with John Cale
column8: Wrong Way Up. It’s interesting to go back that far because High Life has a few things in common with that record
column9: most prominently the elements inspired by pop music from the African continent. Yes
column10: this is a recurring obsession of Eno’s
column11: dating back at least to his first co-billed collaboration with David Byrne
column12: 1981’s My Life in the Bush of Ghosts. But on High Life it’s again made explicit
column13: from the title (Highlife is a broad genre of jazz-inflected West African pop music that emerged late in the last century) on down.

column1: That said
column2: many of the references are less musical and more textural
column3: and guitars are the first thing you notice. The opening “Return” is nine minutes of drone-guitar bliss
column4: as Karl Hyde strums two chords furiously with the sort of pinched
column5: trebly
column6: delay-heavy tone that evokes both West African styles and the Edge circa The Unforgettable Fire. The tension of pivoting between those two chords without resolution is softened by Eno’s voice
column7: which he layers into sturdy central melody softened by billowing harmonies. It’s the kind of blindingly simple thing that nobody does better than Eno
column8: and it points to why this record towers over much of his recent output—it sounds analog
column9: like people in a room playing who could make mistakes. Despite his technological pedigree
column10: Eno has always been most inspired by the place where abstract mathematics meet the messiness of nature. His earlier collaborative efforts on Warp
column11: as well as Small Craft on a Milk Sea
column12: felt like records where meaning was carved from endless possibility; High Life shows how much more he can wring out of just a handful of ideas.

column1: If I’m leaning heavily toward Eno’s contributions here
column2: it’s because so many of his songwriting and production signatures are in the foreground. Hyde is the guitarist throughout the record
column3: but Eno’s fingerprints are all over his approach. “DBF” is a relatively upbeat track with a chicken scratch-funk feel that makes me think of Talking Heads’ “Born Under Punches”
column4: while the slow and dreamy line in “Time to Waste It” brings to mind an ’80s interpretation of King Sunny Ade. But we’re talking about something more than just a collection of global music signifiers here—influences are stripped down
column5: transformed
column6: and often turned into something disorienting and strange through Eno’s processing. “Time to Waste It” has pinched
column7: warped
column8: and ultimately very weird vocals of uncertain origin which seem to be singing lead from different songs with each new line. “Lilac”’s overlapping guitar lines have the frenetic pulse of classical minimalism
column9: with odd bleeps and squawks mixing in with the chords
column10: and they’re contrasted with the richly harmonized vocals
column11: which remind us how in tune he is with the pure joy of singing.

column1: That big-hearted spirit is embedded into the record as a whole. I count one dud among the six tracks
column2: the just-OK “Moulded Life”
column3: which has some nice sounds but feels a bit like processing-for-processing’s-sake. But that is more than redeemed by the elegiac closer “Cells & Bells”
column4: where grinding Fennesz-like electronics are set against a mass of voices singing a dark but faintly hopeful prayer. It’s a moving end to a startling and inspiring record. Eno’s been involved with quite a few of those in the past
column5:
but it’s especially nice to experience a new one that reaches us in the present moment.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20705/homepage_large.697fbdc5.jpg|Decline and Fall EP|32310.0|Godflesh|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Avalanche']|2014-07-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:54.164144|"

If Trent Reznor can win an Oscar for scoring a movie about Facebook and Ministry’s Al Jourgensen can read the five-day Los Angeles forecast for thousands of perplexed viewers in El Paso
column2: there’s no reason to be surprised by the rebirth of Godflesh. When the band broke up in 2002 following the departure of bassist G.C. Green
column3: its death seemed final. Justin Broadrick fell into a depression
column4: canceling their tour and rarely leaving the house
column5: ultimately solidifying the group's passing in a promotional poster for his next project that proclaimed : “Godflesh is dead. Long live Jesu.” But here comes Broadrick more than a dozen years later
column6: wizened by his years spent making post-rock and
column7: with Green back in tow
column8: promising an LP and an EP from Godflesh in 2014. They return with Decline and Fall
column9: a four-track show of force that laughs off any notions that they've fallen off.

column1: Godflesh’s metal machine music resurfaces at a time where satellites and fiber optics networks muffle the once-unchallenged roars of factory machines. The production of Decline and Fall could be heard as band’s protest against the sanitization of these industrial sounds. Godflesh remain fiercely loyal to lo-fi
column2: treating songs like as caustic exercises in overstimulation. “Ringer” stirs up shivers by way of a direct confrontation with mechanical chaos: the drums lock into a dull
column3: arrythmic throb picked up by the grizzled bass
column4: leaving Broadrick to embellish the din with a combination of throaty growls and slightly soured singing. In turn
column5: “Playing With Fire” welds these rotting melodies together into grating harmonies that attract and repel in equal measure.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Godflesh reach for the crunchy industrial rock of their prime: half of the EP remains entrenched in rhythmic
column3: bass-heavy metal that some listeners have preemptively dubbed “Kornflesh.” This pejorative
column4: of course
column5: ignores the appropriation of the band’s hybridized sound by more palatable commercial artists such as Faith No More (whose invitation to join Broadrick turned down)
column6: Fear Factory
column7: and yes
column8: Korn. At the same time
column9: it captures what makes gnarled jams like “Dogbite” so compelling: namely
column10: that Godflesh can return from a 12-year absence—long after the demise of nu-metal
column11: for that matter—having perfected and refined the style of their co-opters. Such a reclamation manifests itself in “Dog Bite” in the form of a thick
column12: sludgy guitar hook that stomps along to form a rowdy groove
column13: an approach they take again on the title track
column14: this time with a greater emphasis on the drum machine for an unexpected hit of hip-hop.

column1: Avant and yet strangely accessible
column2: industrially-minded but all-embracing
column3: Decline and Fall confirms that a decade-plus-long absence has dulled neither Godflesh’s industrial spirit
column4: nor their devotion to experimentation. Will they be able to sustain that line of energy for an entire album? That question must go unanswered until the release of <i>A World Lit Only By Fire
column5:
the band's first full-length since 2001.

When Mister Saturday Night began as a dance party back in January of 2009
column2: it looked nothing like its current incarnation. It took place in Manhattan at an established nightclub with four DJs at the helm. In just under a calendar year
column3: it came under the control of Justin Carter and Eamon Harkin and relocated out to Brooklyn
column4: where for the past five years the party has hewed closer to the DIY spaces like 285 Kent
column5: Market Hotel and Silent Barn than any sleek dance club
column6: moving to barely legal warehouse and loft spaces throughout the borough. The party took in Saturday as well as Sunday and for the first few years of Mister Sunday
column7: it hosted a wide range of DJ guests: Theo Parrish
column8: Michael Mayer
column9: Mr. Scruff
column10: and Optimo
column11: to name but a few headliners.

column1: As the party grew in popularity
column2: though
column3: it no longer needed to rely on international DJ guests
column4: instead emphasizing the wide-ranging sets of local hosts Carter and Harkin. And when the duo started the Mister Saturday Night imprint back in spring of 2012
column5: they emphasized homegrown talent across their first few vinyl-only releases. But as this 2xCD (or 3xLP) label compilation Brothers and Sisters makes evident
column6: Mister Saturday Night is at once local and international
column7: with artists both in their backyard and in countries like Scotland and Japan.

column1: The set opens with “In Brackets” by Dark Sky
column2: a trio of producers who touched on a few genres over releases across a variety of labels before dropping this decidedly house single for MSN. “In Brackets” builds from silky pads and a crisp 120 BPM beat
column3: a shimmering yet wistful melody twining around the track. Another Brooklyn trio
column4: Archie Pelago
column5: follows with “Brown Oxford”
column6: one of four tracks on the set; despite having one of the most cringeworthy names in recent memory
column7: the jazz-steeped
column8: Ableton-dabbling trio stay just this side of mushroom jazz. Their eight-minute compilation closer “Frederyck Swerl” brings to mind of Terry Riley’s looping soprano saxophone pieces
column9: but there's always a moment in their tracks where I wish it was less about chops and trickiness and more about serving the track at hand.

column1: Jazzy flourishes tend to derail some of the music here and the tracks that stand out are those that overlap with fellow Brooklyn imprint
column2: L.I.E.S.
column3: embracing the noisy side of current dance music. Gunnar Haslem’s glowering “Let A Hundred Flowers Bloom” is one obvious example
column4: since he himself is a L.I.E.S. alum
column5: but it also holds true for newcomers like Brooklynite Hank Jackson and Okayama-based producer Keita Sano. Their squalling contributions Jackson's “Cole’s Lullaby” and Sano's “People Are Changing”—taken alongside some L.I.E.S. releases and the abrasive Feral Grind comp from late last year—posit a parallel world where the most influential dance act to hail from the DFA catalog in the past decade was Black Dice
column6: not LCD Soundsystem.

column1: Other tracks do woozy Balearic (Lumigraph’s “Yacht Cruiser”)
column2: distorted tribal weirdness (General Ludd’s “C”)

the comp emulates the party itself: not always cohesive but always inclusive.

Vermont duo the Vacant Lots have been co-signed by Suicide's Alan Vega. Their debut album Departure was mixed by Spacemen 3's Sonic Boom and features guitar work from Galaxie 500's Dean Wareham. They were brought on tour with the Brian Jonestown Massacre. Frontman Jared Artaud just released a poetry book
column2: and if his last name seems familiar

column6: even it's largely been attained through nostalgic associations.

column1: After the promising 2011 single ""Confusion""
column2: the trick for the Vacant Lots is to add authority to their psychedelic street cred with a solid album. Departure

column4: doesn't get there. The album opens with a bleating
column5: attention-grabbing synth hook on ""Mad Mary Jones""
column6: but you won't find many aberrations or change-ups beyond that. Even when percussion and guitar come in to take the song in a new direction
column7: it becomes another unvarying parallel road alongside that initial synth refrain. Most of these songs follow a hook a little too far and
column8: sometimes
column9: like on ""Paint This City""
column10: they slog through slower
column11: still repetitive material. The vocals
column12: often monotonous with several choruses only offering a handful of repeated and deadpanned words
column13: don't help. At times
column14: Artaud recites the lyrics
column15: slow and drab
column16: as poems. They may read well on the page
column17: but as songs

column19: with lines like
column20: ""The void filled by a penetrating eye with an electric pupil.""

column1: Still
column2: this album can't be written off purely as a repetitive mess—this is the sound they were going for
column3: after all
column4: and when they rely less heavily on repetition
column5: drones
column6: and electronics
column7: they find some decent material. Take the tambourine on ""Before the Evening's Thru""
column8: which roots them in an earlier era of psychedelia. It's a small thing
column9: but the percussion pairs well with their persistent electronic warble

column11: which has one of the album's best hooks and
column12: following the verse
column13:
a fantastic shift in texture that brings to mind Michael Rother or Utopia-era Todd Rundgren. But those occasional flare-ups and moments of potential are exceptions on an album that needs anything to happen more frequently.

Despite their name
column2: Serpentine Path have never entailed very much winding

column5: circuitous paths to arrive in the New York all-star quintet
column6: with individual stops in Electric Wizard

column10: Serpentine Path showcased an unwavering focus
column11: marching through eight barbaric bits of doom at very low tempos and with very little distraction. They occasionally decorated songs with spooky samples as preludes and sometimes let guitarist Tim Bagshaw step out of rhythmic lockstep for slow
column12: swollen solos. Mostly
column13: though

column15: with Ryan Lipynsky’s bellicose rasp peeking through the band’s deliberate plod
column16: a dim lantern lighting the way through a darkened forest. In spite of the extensive résumés of those involved

column18: avoiding the most general pitfall of veteran talent aggregates: indecision.

column1: In the last two years
column2: Serpentine Path haven’t veered from that course
column3: but they have added a fifth member and second guitarist
column4: Winter co-founder Stephen Flam. On Emanations
column5: Flam lends finesse to that focus
column6: giving their doom a new depth. Flam refuses to mirror or retrench the burl of Bagshaw’s riffs; instead
column7: they work together to add underlying layers to the brood
column8: with lines of dissonant squeal and sordid distortion peeling off of the group’s headlong direction. The distinction becomes clear only a minute in to Emanations
column9: when a brief break in Lipynsky’s arrogant agitation allows the guitars to split at the seams—one snarling and thin
column10: the other thick and suffocating. For Serpentine Path
column11: Flam introduces a new element of the unknown
column12: and the established group responds in kind for the entire album. They disrupt rhythms where they once would have stayed in time
column13: and they break patterns that
column14: only two years ago
column15: felt settled. If Serpentine Path were a declaration of intent
column16: Emanations is an attempt to steer clear of its rut
column17: to make sure that the supergroup’s core doesn’t become deadweight.

column1: Serpentine Path haven't given up on doom
column2: or even steered from it
column3: really. These seven songs still feel like leaden hammers swung by giants. “Disfigured Colossus” is enormous and odd
column4: grisly guitar tones twisted over an imposing rhythm section. “Torment” is an italicized attack
column5: its mid-tempo lurch aiming ever ahead. Throughout Emanations
column6: though
column7: Serpentine Path find subtle
column8: compelling ways to scatter that power
column9: to accompany their force so it never seems to be the sole purpose. “Treacherous Waters”
column10: for instance
column11: flips between an insistent lumber and double-kick bursts
column12: the switches in tempo reinforcing the dour temperament of Lipynsky’s lyrics. “Drawn into the depths
column13: ” he bellows after one of those changeups
column14: the band surging beneath him. “Vacant incantations.” And “Torment""
column15: that closing fisticuff
column16: zigs and zags
column17: pushing through a bridge bent by a bleary-eyed guitar soliloquy and ending with glorious guitar harmonies. That push and pull between insurgence and excursions is most evident on “Systematic Extinction”
column18: a fetching stoner anthem that moves Serpentine Path the farthest afield from their stylistic center that they’ve ever been. Flam and Bagshaw step out for solos between every verse and chorus

column20: psychedelic pinwheel. With its stack of refrains and bridges

column1: On a song like “Systematic Extinction”

column3: supergroups seem to take the opposite tack
column4: starting from the ideas that made the musicians successful in the past and
column5: with time
column6: possibly finding a distinction all their own. On their debut
column7: Serpentine Path decided how they would sound and what they would ply; on Emanations

column9:
the origin of a path from which they can move off and on at will.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20711/homepage_large.879e6cd0.jpg|Live at Biko|2331.0|Mark Kozelek|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Caldo Verde']|2014-07-01 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:56.592502|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".1u70dqe2fb4.1.6:0.1.0.$19487/=1$19487.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><div><span style=""color: #222222; font-family: Georgia
column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px; background-color: #ffffff;"">Judging by the not-exactly-cryptic title
column3: you’d think Live at Biko
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px; background-color: #ffffff;""> was just another in long line of Mark Kozelek solo concert albums
column5: this one recorded at the titular venue in Milan this past April. But it’s actually the greatest collection of deadpan one-liners this side of Steven Wright’s I Have a Pony. For example: “If you’re a guy and you ask me when’s my record coming out on vinyl
column6: I’ll kick the shit out of you. If you’re a girl
column7: I’ll talk to you for an hour about it.”  Or: “Are you getting tired of these middle-aged ramblings of mine? Because I’m going to do a lot more of them.” And: “When I was young
column8: in my 20s
column9: they’d tell me I looked like Matt Dillon. And then I get into my 30s
column10: and I cut my hair short
column11: they told me I looked like John Malkovich. And now I’m fucking 47
column12: and girls don’t even talk to me anymore. It sucks.” (This is to say nothing of the True Detective season recap Kozelek offers partway through.) But Kozelek saves his biggest howler for the end
column13: when prior to the closing lullaby “Elaine”
column14: he says with a straight face
column15: “this one’s from my record Among the Leaves—old album. Old album.”

column1: For those who haven’t been keeping score
column2: Kozelek has been making records for 22 years now. Among the Leaves—his fifth proper album under the alias Sun Kil Moon—came out a mere 22 months before this Biko performance. But
column3: as the old saying goes
column4: Kozelek’s quip is funny because it’s true. Since Among the Leaves
column5: Kozelek has issued a covers collection (Like Rats)
column6: full-album collaborations with the Album Leaf’s Jimmy LaVelle (Perils From the Sea) and San Fran rockers Desertshore (Mark Kozelek & Desertshore)
column7: a soundtrack to a documentary (On Tour)
column8: not to mention at least five live limited-edition live records. But the distance between Among the Leaves and 2014 feels all the more vast in light of this year’s Benji
column9: a career high watermark that managed to pack a lifetime’s worth of familial grieving
column10: bittersweet nostalgia
column11: celebrity namedrops
column12: and CNN Breaking News headlines into its one-hour running time.

column1: An album that puts the “me” in “meta
column2: ” Benji is so dense with intensely personal history that it practically necessitates drawing up a Kozelek family tree and consulting a map of Ohio to follow along. But for all its inter-song connections
column3: Benji is ultimately an anti-concept album
column4: a song cycle whose connections are less the result of a grand narrative than a comment on the uncontrollably random yet cruelly cyclical nature of life. And
column5: in light of Kozelek’s faded public profile
column6: it proved to be a resounding comeback effort from a guy who seemed so resigned to his fate as the cultiest of cult artists that
column7: just last year
column8: he was compelled to write a song called “Hey You Bastards I’m Still Here”. Granted
column9: that’s a Steve McQueen quote from ""Papillion""—Kozelek’s all-time favorite movie
column10: we learn on Live at Biko—but the sentiment perfectly defines Kozelek’s temperament these days: perennially disillusioned with the mind-numbing
column11: ceiling-gazing drudgery of small-scale touring
column12: but still emboldened by the intimate connection he has with the audience that remains. (As he sums up toward the end of the set: “I want to thank the people from Biko
column13: who’ve been wonderful and cooked me some really great food … thanks to everybody for being so polite
column14: I’m having a good fucking time. Now I’ve got to go to Scandinavia and eat really shitty food.”)

column1: But Live at Biko is more than just another vault-clearing quickie to keep the diehards satiated. Most of Kozelek’s recent live releases have featured grab-bag setlists
column2: complementing his Sun Kil Moon repertoire with samples from his canyon-deep arsenal of covers and even the odd Red House Painters classic. The Live at Biko set
column3: by contrast
column4: focuses squarely on Kozelek’s post-2010 songbook
column5: and thus functions as both a tidy summation of an especially prolific period in his career
column6: as well as a snapshot of how he’s evolved from one of indie-rock’s most enigmatic figures to its greatest oversharer. And with Kozelek adapting his ambient-electronic excursions with LaVelle and electric-guitar jams with Desertshore to the solo-nylon-acoustic mode of the most recent Sun Kil Moon records
column7: we see a clearer path through his winding discography en route to the staggering peaks of Benji.

column1: At the same time
column2: when placed alongside Kozelek’s preceding work
column3: you can hear why Benji has struck a deeper chord with people who've never really engaged with his music before
column4: or hadn't in years. As Live at Biko illustrates
column5: Benji was hardly the first time Kozelek had crafted a tragic character study about a fleeting acquaintance (“Gustavo”)
column6: commented on the thankless plight of the fortysomething working musician (“Sunshine in Chicago”)
column7: eulogized a dead relative (“Ceiling Gazing”)
column8: or relayed a deep-seated memory through pop-cultural color commentary (“Tavoris Cloud”) or a beloved old film (“Hey You Bastards I’m Still Here”). But where those songs feel like wistful internal monologues
column9: the Benji tracks featured here—particularly the bloody-knuckled performances of “Richard Ramirez Died Today of Natural Causes”
column10: “I Watched the Film the Song Remains the Same”
column11: and “Dogs”—are more like exorcisms
column12: as if decades of pent-up anxieties and insecurities were finally being unleashed through a ceaseless stream of words that threaten to overwhelm the songs’ structures. His unflinching candor has been matched with do-or-die ardor.

column1: But where Benji’s lyrics have a rambling
column2: made-up-on-the-spot quality
column3: Live at Biko reinforces just how architecturally intricate they actually are—as emphasized by Kozelek’s remarkable ability to remember entire 70-line songs without flubbing a single word. And Live at Biko is quick to remind us that Benji is as much a comedy as tragedy
column4: at times forcefully so: After the cheeky reference to albino rocker Edgar Winter in “I Love My Dad” fails to elicit the expected chuckle of recognition from his quietly reverential Italian audience
column5: Kozelek opts to just scrap the song altogether midway through. (“It just sucks. Noted: ‘I Love My Dad’ does not work in Italy.”) Because even if the guy can’t watch the film The Song Remains the Same without being haunted by memories of dead classmates and some poor kid he once suckerpunched on the schoolyard
column6:
Kozelek still seeks to answer its eternal question: does anybody remember laughter?

Like the rural
column2: middle-country escapes that it evokes
column3: Luke Abbott's music derives part of its charm from the fact that
column4: as a point of pride

column7: and for Border Community boss James Holden

column10: boutique world of modular synthesizers. The sound they've settled into—more motive than Boards of Canada
column11: softer and more abstract than club music—redefines British pastoral music for the plugged-in and fuzzed-out. The sound came to a head with Holden's 2013 epicThe Inheritors
column12: a bristling display that sounded like someone carved crop circles into UK techno. Abbott's second album
column13: Wysing Forest
column14: parries The Inheritors

column1: Of Border Community's principal players
column2: Abbott has long been the gentlest. His debut album
column3: Holkham Drones

column5: reveal him a descendant of kosmische dreamers like Cluster and Popul Vuh. He drew careful
column6: cross-stitched melodies and purring rhythms from his tools

column1: Abbott loosens the reins on Wysing Forest
column2: conjuring instead a boggy psychedelia thicketed with noise. ""Amphis""

column4: curiously

column7: its carbonation gone flat. ""Amphis"" is raw and jammy without being loose or free

column1: What Wysing Forest truly misses is cohesion. Where The Inheritors carved out an alien mysticism and previous Abbott works revered in domestic warmth
column2: Wysing Forest feels both vague and detached. There is a general lack of structure. ""The Balance of Power"" is a classic slow-builder
column3: but it doesn't gather momentum; it just drifts prettily for four minutes
column4: becomes loud
column5: and then hushes itself. The effect isn't enchantment but indecision
column6: something for which nature
column7: but not synthesizer music
column8: can be forgiven.

column1: Wysing Forest is stuck
column2: then
column3: between Abbott's enviable past work and his indeterminate future. Perhaps the best indictment of Wysing Forest is that it's difficult to discern just what Abbott was aiming for: to make his music more random
column4: less discreet
column5: noisier? Every option feels like a step back for a composer and sound designer of Abbott's talents. And that leaves Wysing Forest
column6:
a record too tart for beauty and too well reared for intractability. Let's chalk it up to a rare moment of disobedience for Abbott's synthesizers.

column3: there wasn’t much evidence to suggest that the band would be any longer lived than the numerous other satellite projects rattling through deep space orbit alongside Japanese noise-rock giants
column4: Boredoms. OOIOO (say it oh-oh-eye-oh-oh) has endured
column5: though
column6: and nearly twenty years and six albums later
column7: the all-female quartet—lead by Flaming Lips LP namesake and Boredoms percussionist Yoshimi—have established their own voice
column8: audience
column9: and influence
column10: long since transcending their origins as ancillary Bore-product. Gamel—which arrived last year in Japan on Boredoms’ own Shock City imprint and which is only now seeing wide release through Thrill Jockey—is OOIOO’s seventh full-length and also the group’s strongest effort in some time. Like the group's best work
column11: it takes a number of heady out-rock ideas and lines them up into a fairly easy to digest mixtape.

column1: Given their shared DNA
column2: Boredoms and OOIOO mirror one another in a number of ways
column3: particularly in their zeal for primitivist rhythms

column5: and trippy fluorescent color schemes. But while the former has gradually evolved into a sort of high concept drum circle—with performances that often involve a seven-necked guitar and dozens of percussionists—the latter has consistently kept things small. For the past decade

column9: Konono No. 1
column10: and the European prog-rock band Gong within the same five minutes.

column1: Still
column2: the best OOIOO records have always benefited from a central theme—be it kraut rock-style repetition (Feather Float) or tribal psychedelia (Armonico Hewa)—to ground the band’s ever-mutating sensibility. This time around

column4: alternate tunings

column1: Prior OOIOO albums were
column2: evidently
column3: recorded by the band and then extensively tweaked and edited by Yoshimi in studio post-production
column4: but Gamel was mostly recorded live. As a result
column5: the music isn’t quite as crowded. Yoshimi has laid off the effects—echo
column6: reverb
column7: and synthesizer glop—and there are fewer hard turns and zig-zags in the compositions. For the first time
column8: OOIOO actually sounds like a real
column9: living breathing band.

column1: One of the best things about OOIOO records is that they provide a way to experience a number of fairly culty musical ideas—prog rock
column2: psychedelic music
column3: and so on—from a point of remove. The band's nonsense chants and jagged melodies provide all of the weirdness without necessarily conjuring the established imagery and associations

column7:
qualities that Gamel definitely possesses.

In the five years since Rachel Evans of Motion Sickness of Time Travel began collecting subdued drone music on Bandcamp
column2: she's managed to put out 50 releases. Though that number is padded by several shorter EPs and a handful of splits
column3: when paired with her output as Quiet Evenings (a duo with her husband Grant Evans)
column4: her rate of production outclasses many of her peers. And this in a field where prolificacy is almost a given. Given her pace of creation
column5: her compositions are almost by definition ephemeral. But occasionally
column6: as on her new cassette release Alpha Piscium

column1: Conceived as a follow-up to her elegiac 2012 self-titled double LP
column2: this new tape carefully pushes Evans' abstract Berlin School inclinations toward something more sculpted and structured. Much of Alpha Piscium finds Evans working in short form; she still relies mostly on an array of synthesizers and her own voice
column3: but here she's bearing down to give tracks like the album's throbbing opener ""The Blossoms"" urgency and forward momentum. More happens in less time. Placid clicks and flickers at beginning of ""Ikebana II"" give way to circling
column4: birdlike synthesizer melodies before falling back apart into its constituent electronic elements
column5: all in the span of four minutes.

column1: Evans has spent the better part of the last year exploring her more intense and tortured side on a series of CD-Rs dedicated to each month's full moon
column2: and those dark and distended releases come to mind here in the gloomy hiss of the album's longest track ""You Don't Know What It's Like"". Her voice
column3: which has been used in the as a means of giving her reverberant hymns a sense of uplift
column4: functions here to issue brief discordant moans
column5: unsettling little vocalizations that echo the dreariness of the 11-minute dirge.

column1: The more significant releases in Evans' catalog function as a sort of summation
column2: compiling all the tricks and techniques she's learned since the last one. Given the number of Motion Sickness of Time Travel releases since her self-titled LP
column3: her sound has acquired a number of new wrinkles. But Alpha Piscium mostly picks up on the general path she's followed of her entire career. She's aiming for a little more momentum and a little more unease
column4: teasing the idea of more straightforward structures. At a fraction of the length of Motion Sickness of Time Travel
column5: Alpha Piscium might be just a hair less ambitious
column6: but it's world of gauzy (and this time around
column7:
unnerving) synthesizer drones still invites exploration.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20800/homepage_large.199f2ca5.jpg|Caustic Window LP|32378.0|Caustic Window|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Rephlex']|2014-06-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:59.234303|"

When Richard D. James released 2001’s Drukqs
column2: the last proper Aphex Twin album
column3: it was considered a massive disappointment. The 2xCD set mixed frenetic drill’n’bass tracks with gorgeous Satie-like miniatures for prepared piano
column4: and the feeling at the time was that he’d been here before and done it all better. After 1999’s “Windowlicker”
column5: a landmark track that was both deeply strange and also somehow a pop hit
column6: there was an unspoken dream that James might just might change popular music completely
column7: remake it in his image. Drukqs didn’t come close to fulfilling that promise
column8: but listening to it 13 years later
column9: perhaps not surprisingly
column10: it sounds more interesting than it did at the time. Could this have something to do with it being the last Aphex Twin album? When we heard it in 2001
column11: we had every reason to think that there might be another around the corner in a year or two.

column1: So Drukqs seemed more like a bump in the road
column2: maybe
column3: than an artist coasting for a minute. It wasn’t the last we heard from James—there were the many Analord releases in 2005
column4: some stray tracks
column5: additional work as the Tuss—but James’ unbelievable 10-year run as a creative force mostly ended just after the turn of the millennium. Since we’re still left wondering if and when he’ll make a full return to the world of recorded music
column6: the huge clutch of music he did release seems more classic with each passing day. He’s become something like electronic music’s post-retirement Miles Davis: from the vantage point of the 1980s and later
column7: say
column8: everything Miles released through his 1975 hiatus sounded amazing. An artist who quits can become so revered
column9: what output there is becomes enveloped in a kind of aura
column10: and you start to hear it differently. Tracks that don’t necessarily connect in a big way on their own become understood as an important part of a bigger picture
column11: and its perceived importance grows exponentially.

column1: I mention all this by way of saying that the “new” album by Richard James
column2: the Caustic Window LP
column3: sounds very good
column4: but there’s so much wrapped up in hearing new/old music from him it can be hard to puzzle out. That this set has such a strange genesis also seems appropriate
column5: given James’ very low public profile and long history of “Is this him or someone else?” releases. Earlier this year
column6: a test pressing of a previously unreleased LP by Caustic Window
column7: one of James’ many pseudonyms
column8: originally intended for release on Rephlex
column9: the label he owns with Grant Wilson-Claridge
column10: appeared for sale on Discogs. Members of the We Are the Music Makers forum
column11: an active message board dedicated to electronic music in general and Aphex Twin in particular
column12: persuaded Rephlex to sanction an unusual idea for distributing the music: they would raise money through Kickstarter and those who contributed would get a high-quality digital copy of the record
column13: recorded from a needle-drop of the test pressing. After the project was funded and the music digitized
column14: the test pressing was auctioned on eBay. Some of the money went to the label
column15: some went to charity. But 4
column16: 000 people got lossless files of the record from donating
column17: and then of course it leaked. It’s a long way for music to travel in 20 years
column18: and it’d be an interesting story based only on the crowd-funding angle
column19: showing the connectedness of fandom in the digital era. But the music has its own rewards.

column1: It helps to understand where James was in 1994. For the previous three years
column2: he’d been issuing a string of 12""s and EPs under various names
column3: most of which were firmly under the umbrella of acid house and techno. You can find these tracks scattered across the Caustic Window set Compilation
column4: the Aphex Twin collection Classics
column5: the Polygon Window album Surfing on Sine Waves
column6: and the Analogue Bubblebath EPs. In addition to functional dance music
column7: James had also put out Selected Ambient Works 85–92 and
column8: around the time this album would have come out
column9: the legendary Selected Ambient Works Vol. II
column10: so we’re talking about some serious output in just a couple of years.

column1: During the early days
column2: James tended to go to extremes. He made dance music that was often harsh and repetitive and then he made ambient music that was stirring in its simple beauty. He was exploring the edges
column3: figuring out where the boundaries were
column4: and in the second half of the 1990s he figured out how to make it all work together. What’s interesting about the Caustic Window LP
column5: especially relative to the abrasive material collected on Compilation
column6: is that it’s generally measured
column7: never too harsh or too fast and also never especially lyrical. It feels like an album
column8: with tracks that were not singles meant to be heard together. James uses this middle ground as a showcase for his unerring feel for structure and his ability to make electronic tracks there were futuristic but also imbued with personality
column9: where you get a sense of the man behind the controls.

column1: So the highlights here
column2: which include the bouncy electro-cruncher “Mumbly” (later a live staple)
column3: the spacious and easily tuneful “Fingertrips”
column4: the salsa-inflected acid house “Squidge in the Fridge”
column5: and the chilled-out and playful neo-trip-hop “Jazzphase”
column6: sound best in the context of the record as a complete listen
column7: with its gradually shifting palette and BPMs. James’ work during this era had a slightly crude
column8: homemade quality that brought it down to earth but also
column9: with its contrasts
column10: served to highlight the overall musicality. If these are not necessarily the prettiest melodies he created
column11: Caustic Window LP is still filled with tunes that work brilliantly as tunes
column12: with memorable chord progressions that move through clearly delineated sections. One of James’ defining qualities is that he’s almost never boring; there’s almost always some element of fascination in his tracks
column13: whether it’s an oddball sample
column14: a weird texture
column15: an impossibly heavy percussion line
column16: or tune that won’t leave your head.

column1: It’s only on the album’s final third that the record takes a sharp turn
column2: as the nice but ultimately too-long mood piece “101 Rainbows (Ambient Mix)” leads into the hyper-distorted “Phlaps” and the blistering acid of “Cunt” and then into a listen-once track of phone pranks. It’s tempting to speculate on how the record would have been received at the time and why it might have been shelved. James was moving fast in those days
column3: so it’s possible that this album felt too much like where he’d been before
column4: especially given the new ground he was breaking with SAW II. By the following year’s I Care Because You Do his sound was again changing rapidly
column5: and the rest of the decade saw him attaining the status of a serious composer. Given all that
column6: Caustic Window LP probably wouldn’t have left a significant mark
column7: and would have been heard as second-tier James. Twenty years later
column8: though
column9: we’re hearing it with that aura
column10: that extra bit of longing that comes from how scarce music from James has become. And in that light
column11:
second tier is still very good indeed.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20696/homepage_large.387cd9e7.jpg|EX|3330.0|Plastikman|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mute']|2014-06-30 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:35:59.839889|"

There was a point in 1993 when it was possible to conflate the likes of Aphex Twin and Plastikman. With their iconic avatars
column2: both of these electronica artistic entities spoke to Philip Dick-ian replicas with their names
column3: and both made exemplary album statements that year
column4: Richard D. James with Selected Ambient Works II and the latter –the primary alias of producer Richard Michael Hawtin—with his acid to-the-point-of-blotter-cover Sheet One. While both albums were minimal to the point of being psychotropic
column5: it was only here that two of the greatest electronic artists were at this nexus. Aphex Twin would embrace drill’n’bass
column6: acid
column7: and twisted singles that doubled as maximal pop
column8: achieving cult of personality status before all but dropping out of view (at least until this month). Conversely
column9: Hawtin went deeper into minimalism while also remaining one of the most respected and prolific producers/remixers/DJs of the last twenty years.

column1: Pushing into new realms
column2: which included spelunking ever deeper into the sonic depths of Detroit and Berlin-styled minimal techno across his imprints
column3: Plus 8
column4: Probe and M_nus
column5: Hawtin is that rare tireless electronic artist
column6: booking residencies in Ibiza as well as multimedia installations in art museums. His extensive
column7: high-caliber back catalog makes him the minimal techno Tim Duncan
column8: spanning from the early '90s pared-down masters like Jeff Mills
column9: Dan Bell
column10: and Robert Hood to the Berlin “minimal trinity” alongside Ricardo Villalobos and Magda in the new century. While he retired the Plastikman moniker after the glum break-up vocalizations of 2003’s Closer
column11: an invitation last year to perform at the Guggenheim’s 2013 International Gala in New York City led Hawtin to revive the moniker.

column1: While crafted for a onetime live performance
column2: Ex isn’t quite a live album. It’s seven original tracks (all beginning with “Ex-“) that clock in just a hair under an hour. It’s better to conceive of Ex holistically
column3: rather than as seven individual tracks—in part because the album's distinct parts tend to blend into one another
column4: with little to differentiate them. One might not know of the illuminated monolith that was situated in the museum’s rotunda while listening to the album
column5: but it’s easy to imagine a beacon of some sort amid the slow opening 303 throbs of “EXposed”; when Hawtin sets the 303 to its most caustic
column6: it’s fun to imagine said light source being turned into a bug zapper for the glitterati in attendance.

column1: But long stretches of Ex find Hawtin twisting knobs not for sustained release but to make sure everything doesn't grind to a halt. The squelching melody at the center of “EXposed” is vintage Hawtin that fans will undoubtedly recognize
column2: but for an artist able to exact psychedelic profundity from agonizingly slow filter sweeps
column3: there are spans where he has nowhere to go with the 303
column4: the components of “EXtend” not quite pressurizing to warrant release. The slow
column5: steady movement from the spacious yet foreboding span from “EXplore” into “EXpire” is a move from valley to plateau (peaking with the aural hallucination of skittering percussion and synthesized orchestras) that feels like Hawtin at his most cinematic and ecstatic. But aside from a glimpse of such a peak
column6: one wonders what reviving the Plastikman moniker achieved that night in the museum
column7:
aside from proving the futility of wishing one could go back in time twenty years.
