No story of the Sheffield music scene is complete without mention of Cabaret Voltaire
column2: the post-punk outfit whose approach to electronic music was so feral it felt like you could hear it degrading in real time. The band formed in 1973
column3: a time when one of their formative influences
column4: Roxy Music
column5: were in their Eno-inspired pomp. Fired up on a diet of J.G. Ballard
column6: William S. Burroughs
column7: and Brion Gysin
column8: Cabaret Voltaire borrowed their name from a Zurich nightclub that was a gathering spot for pivotal figures in the Dada movement
column9: and by 1974 settled into a steady lineup of Richard Kirk
column10: Stephen Mallinder
column11: and Chris Watson. Some of their abstract work from that period was gathered together on a three-disc collection
column12: Methodology ‘74/’78
column13: released by Mute in 2002. But their story really starts in 1978
column14: with the band recording out of their own Western Works headquarters
column15: where they adhered to a do-it-yourself ethos that would link them to the bracket of groups loosely banded under the post-punk banner.

column1: The abundance of disused industrial spaces in Sheffield at the end of the 1970s worked in the band’s favor
column2: both as a suitably dystopian backdrop to get inspired by and as a place to find cheap or free spaces to work in. Out of that came Western Works
column3: a place Kirk describes as “Andy Warhol’s Factory on a fifty-pence budget.” Their debut EP
column4: Extended Play
column5: was recorded before they founded their own studio
column6: but the spirit was already fully intact. Represented here by two tracks
column7: notably “Do the Mussolini (Headkick)”
column8: it’s a masterpiece in detachment
column9: forming a sound so hollowed out and distant it feels like all three members of the band are sitting across the room
column10: fixing you with an icy stare. Photos and sleeves from the era perfectly complement the vision—the anti-art record covers
column11: in particular Extended Play and Nag Nag Nag
column12: look like they’ve been fed through a black-and-white Xerox machine countless times
column13: giving the shots of black-clad band members a suitably sub-Velvets air of mystery.

column1: Much of the material on #7885 (Electropunk to Technopop 1978 – 1985) will already be familiar to longstanding fans of the band
column2: its use mostly derived from the way it traces their creative arc over this period. Watson departed in 1981
column3: which may be the reason for the gap in material covered here—it spans ‘78-’81
column4: then picks up again with a clutch of material from ‘83-’85. Strangely
column5: one of their most popular songs from that initial era
column6: the TV evangelist-inspired “Sluggin’ fer Jesus”
column7: doesn’t feature. Still
column8: it’s practically a greatest hits set
column9: most notable for how they treated electronics and vocals in their formative days. Everything is so processed
column10: so tightly wound
column11: it often sounds like someone struggling to get out of restraints. At times it manages to be both big and small—”Nag Nag Nag”
column12: as close as Cabaret Voltaire get to a signature song
column13: is dominated by a vast organ grind
column14: matched to beats so flat they resemble the last exhale of a drum machine about to shuffle out of life.

column1: The cheap sound of the nascent Cabaret Voltaire appears to be born out of necessity as well as desire. This album charts the sound of a band improving
column2: filling out their vision
column3: leaving behind their origins simply because they had a better grasp on what they were doing. “Silent Command” from 1979 marks a huge sonic shift from “Nag Nag Nag”
column4: which was only released four months prior. It draws on reggae
column5: pop
column6: and even whimsical fairground organ
column7: as well as the signal-jamming vocal cut-ups they would explore in greater detail as they progressed. Clearly this was a band fascinated by the bridge between high and low culture
column8: particularly in the desensitizing effect of TV news
column9: which would spew out the topical fare Cabaret Voltaire would often pick up on in their songs
column10: beaming it out to an audience steadily anesthetized to shock. There’s an anger and an emptiness to a song like “Seconds Too Late”
column11: with Mallinder pulling off the familiar trick of throwing his vocal into the background
column12: relegated to a voice howling helplessly from the void.

column1: While never as overtly pop leaning as fellow Sheffield synth devotees the Human League
column2: there is a greater sense of polish to the post-Watson material. Backed by the Some Bizzare label
column3: who had a sizable hit with Soft Cell’s take on “Tainted Love”
column4: Mallinder’s voice is suddenly front and center
column5: and the sound strung somewhere between the Art of Noise
column6: a vintage Arthur Baker production
column7: and an industrial funk workout. The three tracks present from 1983’s The Crackdown all feel like they could have been hits—a feeling only amplified by the later “Sensoria” and “I Want You”
column8: both of which do a better job of marrying older Cabaret Voltaire fascinations (vocal cut-ups
column9: the pileup of information spewing forth into the culture) with something approaching pop structure. Despite notable differences
column10: there’s never a feeling of change being forced—it’s possible to trace a progression from “Nag Nag Nag” to “Kino”
column11: with the latter as wilfully stiff and hard-hitting as the former
column12: just with different tools and fascinations to draw on in the execution.

column1: With the post ‘83 material there’s a sense of Cabaret Voltaire getting swept along on the tide turn toward industrial-tinged electronic sounds in the UK mainstream
column2: although that sense of steely remove
column3: such a vital part of the band’s sound across eras
column4: always keeps them from the wider public’s gaze. It never feels like they were cognizant of anyone watching from the outside; despite the occasional sound locking the music into a particular era
column5: much of this music feels isolated from anything else going on
column6: with Kirk and Mallinder ultimately drawing strength from the separation they bring to their work. Anyone with the two Original Sound of Sheffield compilations may struggle to see why this material is surfacing again
column7: even if the versions here are sometimes notably shorter in length. But as an entry point into two of the distinct faces of Cabaret Voltaire
column8: #7885 is an undeniably valuable document
column9:
and one that’s as much about the importance of growth and change as it is about the birth of a sound.

Eaters are a collaboration between two young men from Brooklyn
column2: one named Jonny and one named Bob. Their music is dark without feeling oppressive and modern without ever feeling too slick. Most of their self-titled debut sounds like something that could’ve come out in the late 1970s or early ’80s
column3: a period when bands nominally classified as post-punk started messing around with synthesizers
column4: and peacocks like Brian Eno and David Bowie realized you could make rock that sounded cerebral and far-out without becoming Yes. The palette is gray
column5: the vocals are real Teutonic. Think of it as pocket goth: A sullen
column6: hooded tempest made at manageable scale.

column1: Jonny
column2: who in the interest of being official is named Jonathan Schenke
column3: is an engineer with credits on albums by Liturgy
column4: Frankie Rose
column5: and most recently
column6: Parquet Courts—all young rock bands that approach the idiom of rock music from very different perspectives. (Eaters has also been co-released on Dull Tools
column7: a label run in part by Parquet Courts singer and guitarist Andrew Savage.)

column1: Eaters
column2: too
column3: could be called a rock album
column4: though with the exception of “Through All” and “The Way” it features few obviously discernible guitars
column5: and most of its songs are shaped less like songs than like quasi-ambient miniatures that use the signposts of vocal melodies and propulsive drums to cover up for the fact that all Bob and Jonny really want to do is play with texture. And the textures on Eaters are beautiful: Grim and subdued but so rich you could raise tomatoes in them. More than any melody or song
column6: it’s the sound of the album that keeps me interested. So while I recognize that “Bury the Lines” and “Through All” feel calibrated to be singles
column7: they also feel beholden to convention in ways that weirder
column8: looser experiments like “Icarish” and “This Is Round” don’t.

column1: Along with bands like Merchandise and Total Control
column2: Eaters seem like part of a microshift in indie music away from color and variegation to something comparatively austere. Call it a momentary juke back into modernism as we crest the Aquarian age. Maybe it’s just the comfort of the past—that almost quaint way young bands mine old sounds the way people down in Williamsburg
column3:
Virginia keep making candles just like they did in the bloodletting days. The quiet irony of Eaters is that it feels like a period piece for a time in music when so many things felt new.

Stripped of their obfuscation

column19: but Will To Be Well uses its woozy

column22: Will To Be Well offers a warm

For the past three years
column2: RiFF RAFF has become a cult phenomenon
column3: and his proper debut
column4: Neon Icon
column5: is his movement’s anti-climactic culmination. It’s nearly impossible to criticize the album without coming across as an enemy of “fun
column6: ” due in part to RiFF RAFF’s knowing
column7: over-the-top branding as low-culture trash. But irony and irreverence can only do so much lifting on a record this thin. Neon Icon is hardly an affront to hip-hop’s very foundation; instead
column8: it’s an adequate
column9: listenable rap album
column10: and for a part-time rapper/full-time jaw-dropper
column11: there couldn’t be a more damning outcome.

column1: RiFF RAFF first reached the public eye on a reality show
column2: MTV’s “From G’s to Gents”. But as a primordial piece of internet culture
column3: RiFF RAFF’s star truly congealed in a wave of digital flotsam that crashed onto social media and YouTube around the turn of this decade
column4: replete with collaborations and co-signs from Lil B
column5: Lil Debbie
column6: and Soulja Boy. Stylistically
column7: his music originated in Houston’s laconic Swishahouse punchline style; personality-wise
column8: he has a flashy appearance
column9: garish tattoos
column10: and absurdist wit—often in his music
column11: but even more frequently on Twitter. His profile rose: he likely inspired James Franco’s role in Spring Breakers
column12: then appeared on “One Life to Live” impersonating James Franco. He’s a troll
column13: drawing accusations of minstrelsy
column14: sparking thorough investigations into his background and receiving coverage that fawned over his “brilliantly absurd” lyrics and “rangy
column15: Dadaist luxury rap.”

column1: Although he calls himself the “white Gucci Mane with a spray tan
column2: ” his lyrical prowess plumbs a much shallower pool than Gucci’s. On Neon Icon
column3: his rap style has atrophied into a game of hip-hop Madlibs
column4: the “White ____” and “Rap Game _____” one-liners that have so bolstered his Klout score. As on “How to Be the Man”: “Might hit the club and it’s the white Danny Glover/ Rap game Uncle Ben pulling rice out the oven.” What does this mean? Absolutely nothing. It’s arbitrary pop culture juxtaposition
column5: like Peter from “Family Guy” saying
column6: “You know what I haven’t had in awhile? Big League Chew.” RiFF RAFF wasn’t always this limited. His earlier work that broke through the digital noise—records like “Larry Bird”—still possessed the feeling of forward motion
column7: even if it just took the listener into strange little stoned circles.

column1: In the three-odd years since “Larry Bird” first appeared online
column2: RiFF RAFF has engaged in an uphill battle to keep the punchlines churning. As his audience has grown
column3: they’ve demanded an increasing level of ridiculousness
column4: so as it became necessary to efficiently produce newer
column5: more ridiculous music
column6: RiFF RAFF dropped the vestigial tool of narrative. So ridiculousness increasingly has become RiFF RAFF’s stock in trade
column7: and this has happened because of the fans he’s cultivated—in distancing himself from earlier collaborators like Soulja Boy and TKO Capone
column8: in signing with Diplo
column9: and recognizing that ridiculousness pays big bucks. Narrative connectivity is not a priority.

column1: What’s taken the place of that storytelling is something at which his label head Diplo excels: curation of cool. Thus
column2: we get a record with a diverse musical backdrop. Opener “ Introducing the Icon” is an unexpected burst of early ‘90s House of Pain-style combativeness. It’s also one of the album’s best songs
column3: swiping a retro costume that hasn’t been worn through with overuse
column4: and which meshes surprisingly well with RiFF RAFF’s sloppy Texas delivery. (In contrast
column5: one of Diplo’s weaknesses is songwriting
column6: so the his production “Kokayne” has all the style of hard rock with none of the function.) The Mike Posner-featuring “Maybe You Love Me” is easily the catchiest song on the album
column7: an earnest R&Bubblegum single that
column8: while not a likely Billboard hit
column9: is definitely on trend. And the album’s closing song
column10: “VIP Pass to My Heart”
column11: isn’t even a rap song at all
column12: but a twee club jam in the vein of Uffie’s euphoric club rat rap single ""Pop the Glock"".

column1: Ironically
column2: the cool-chasing half of the record seems only to have stumped fans of more straightforward tracks like “Wetter Than Tsunami” and “Tip Toe Wing in My Jawwdinz”. Music critic Anthony Fantano
column3: a fan of RiFF RAFF’s lyrical ridiculousness
column4: recently seemed confounded by the album’s musical breadth
column5: criticizing the neo trip-hop cut “Cool It Down” as a “Whitey Ford Sings the Blues song”. It’s a catch–22 for RiFF RAFF. The “cool” musical choices give what would be a monotonous record needed variety
column6: but they also threaten to delimit his audience to hipster trendspotters. Further muddying the waters is the presence of guest rappers Mac Miller and Childish Gambino
column7: whose respective styles seem tonally at odds with RiFF RAFF and Diplo’s approach. The effect isn’t so much that those rappers have confounded our expectations; instead
column8: their presence means the album’s overall direction comes across as confused.

column1: The bulk of Neon Icon resists coherence or purpose
column2: although “Cool It Down” does seem an oblique response to those who’ve attempted to unearth his past or reveal him as a fake or minstrel: “They wanna tell you what you can’t do based on former facts/ If I wanted to hear that bullshit I’d be in history class.” Perhaps it’s a bit of masterful stagecraft
column3: a knowing bit of irony
column4: but the song scans as a sincere. What if it is? What if it’s not RiFF RAFF who’s the problem
column5: but us?

column1: RiFF RAFF has had his background probed more than almost any rapper in recent memory. Early interviewers seemed convinced they would unlock his enigma
column2: which always entailed discovering whether he was “for real” or “joking”—a parody of hip-hop. These aren’t questions most rappers face; Lil B was celebrated for his eccentricity
column3: but seldom interrogated as a rapper critiquing the form.

column1: In a piece for ArtForum after Amiri Baraka’s passing last year
column2: the artist Adam Pendleton suggested that Black American Culture is seemingly legible through only two lenses: realism and expressionism. “If abstraction remains illegible in the work of the black artist
column3: ” Pendleton writes
column4: “This is because black individuals remain abstract.” Amiri Baraka’s work was proof that this constricted reading of black art was a lie. But that lie is the reason that many listeners experience a black artist’s eccentricity as pure expression
column5: as if their art might not be equally constructed. When an artist like Riff Raff <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column6: serif;"">comes along
column7: listeners jump to the obvious conclusion: as a white artist
column8: he must have agency. He must be faking it
column9: perhaps mocking black expressionism. And the investigation begins.

column1: But what if he isn’t? Convincing arguments have surfaced suggesting the real originator of the RiFF RAFF flow—as well as those of many other artists in Texas—is the rapper Yungstar. Hugely influential
column2: like several of the rappers in DJ Screw's Screwed Up Click
column3: he never rose to national prominence. If RiFF RAFF’s primary influence
column4: then
column5: isn’t a stereotypical Southerner
column6: but an influential yet obscure talent
column7: the notion that RiFF RAFF is simply making fun of black culture falls away—as do the fans for whom that is his primary appeal. This would require recognition from listeners and the press that our fascination with RiFF RAFF was based on a false premise in the first place. And at that point
column8:
the bland truth of his art’s consequence is revealed: he’s just another marginal talent benefitting from an unsung artist’s innovations.

Not quite halfway through Mosaics Within Mosaics
column3: Circulatory System ringleader Will Cullen Hart delivers this cryptic little chestnut: ""Funny how long it's been for the young rocks on the shore."" Circulatory System—Hart and most of the rest of the much-beloved Olivia Tremor Control
column4: minus the late
column5: great Bill Doss—have always seemed like a band in the loosest sense of the term
column6: touring infrequently and recording sporadically. And frontman Hart's multiple sclerosis—and the attendant bouts of exhaustion—have further affected their output: ""I want to write more songs
column7: he told an interviewer last year
column8: ""but I get sleepy and go to sleep. It sucks."" Mosaics is the first Circulatory System LP in half-a-decade's time
column9: the long-awaited follow up to 2009's Signal Morning. Should current patterns hold
column10:
there's a fair chance the next installment won't be hot on its heels.

And Hart and company seem to have designed Mosaics with durability in mind. Mosaics spends an hour sounding like an eternity: it's beautiful
column11: frustrating
column12: full-hearted
column13: foggy-headed
column14: time-distorting
column15: brain-bending stuff
column16: in the grand tradition of the Elephant 6 classics. More than anything
column17: though
column18: Mosaics just feels exceedingly generous; should Hart—for perfectly understandable reasons—only have one Circulatory System record in him every half decade or so
column19: he's gonna make damn sure that record gives you plenty to chew on. The layers upon layers Hart's built into Mosaics Within Mosaics seem designed to withstand the erosion that comes with deep listens. It's possible to imagine that
column20: five years from now
column21: we'll still be digging through Mosaics
column22:
turning over the old stones and shaking out the young rocks.

Mosaics Within Mosaics is built atop Hart's home recordings
column23: some dating back a dozen years. Once he did what he could back at the house
column24: Hart farmed out the embellishments and overdubs to the System's inner circle: Neutral Milk Hotel's Jeff Mangum and Jeremy Barnes
column26: Peter Erchick of Pipes You See Pipes You Don't
column28: and Dream Boat's John Fernandes. These newly fleshed-out tapes were then turned over to Faster Circuits' Derek Almstead
column29: who helped Hart wrestle the records into their final form. The methods may've changed from the days of communing around the same four-track. But the effect is largely the same. Mosaics Within Mosaics
column30: despite a gentler feel than much of Hart's work
column31: is trademark Elephant 6: ornately constructed with an off-the-cuff feel
column32:
an exploration into the mysteries of the universe set to wheezing pump-organs and trilling clarinets.

2009's dense
column33: dizzying Signal Morning was a peculiar animal; listen close enough
column34: and you could practically hear the ghosts of all the records Hart and company had scrapped
column36: or stripped for parts to push the long-gestating Signal Morning out into the world. Those ever-churning fantasias were plenty hooky
column37: but you had to fight through the charred remains of every song-that-wasn't just to get to them. Mosaics
column38: while recognizably a Circulatory System record
column39: takes a different tack: it's cleaner
column41: less riddled with maze-like constructions or clotted with endless overdubs. But there's still quite a lot to get your head around here
column42: an ever-shifting patina of march tempos
column44:
and the eternally wide-eyed Will Cullen Hart's increasingly wizened lyrics.

Over the years
column45: Hart's grown ever-fonder of symbols and signals
column46: and even the more plainspoken lyrics here feel characteristically cryptic. There are numerous references to a tension between the physical and the mental
column47: the age we're in and the age we feel we belong to. It's tempting to read something about Hart's current condition into these lines
column48: but the life of the mind
column50: and the boundless nature of the soul are longstanding fascinations for him
column51: and for psychedelia in general. That exploration of the point where the innerspace becomes outside blasts is where Hart shines; where so many post-60s psych-rock contents itself with the same old tangerine trees and marmalade skies
column52: Hart—even on what may be the the least capitol-P psychedelic record Hart's ever been involved with—does his best to articulate the combination of confusion and clarity at the heart of the psychedelic experience. Questions beget not answers
column53:
but more questions.

Hart and Almstead have taken great pains to give the far-flung Mosaics some structure and cohesion. Compared to the everything-all-the-time feel of Signal Morning
column54: each piece of Mosaics feels like its own discrete entity
column55: every oddball interlude allowed its proper space. Hart's collagist penchant for alternating ponderous fuzz-pop with out-of-nowhere soundbursts is fully intact on Mosaics; there are eight ""Mosaics"" peppered throughout the set
column56: everything from frazzled static to tinselly little guitar filigrees. The symbiotic back-and-forth between song and sound on Mosaics isn't always a perfect match; many of the songs here seem to stop themselves a bit short
column57: relying on the wriggling interludes that follow to fill in the gaps. But the playing on Mosaics is sumptuous and scrappy alike; Hart's faith in his collaborators
column58: most of whom he's known for multiple decades
column61: less concerned with standout moments than the overall impression given by its curious construction. The effect is very different than the skewed
column62: baroque-leaning pop of their much-loved 2001 debut
column63: or the sonic dogpile of Signal Morning; the quieter
column64: more contemplative Mosaics plays like a series of gentle breezes blowing through an open window
column65:
a soundtrack to watching the morning slip slowly into the afternoon.

Opener ""Physical Mirage/Visible Magic"" finds a wobbly-voiced Hart shakily declaring this a ""perfectly normal day""
column66: and by the time the utterly gorgeous closer ""Elastic Empire Coronation"" rolls around
column68: joined by his friends in a kind of declaration of weirdo solidarity: ""If you don't believe us
column69: we can slip on by."" There are plenty of wonky
column70: wriggling psych-pop tunes to be found amidst Mosaics' endless refractions: spiny and somewhat somber ""Bakery Spires"" is an ear-pricker of the highest order
column72: a kind of a doo-wop song sung from a vibrating hotel bed. But there's no ""Yesterday's World"" here
column73: no head-and-shoulders highlight to be had
column74: which gives Mosaics its feel of constant transformation. It's not a record about individual moments; it's about how those moments play off of each other
column76: continue to delight and disorient. With some big pop blowout to look forward to
column78:
the order seemingly shuffled and the arrangements reconfigured. It's possible to  listen to Mosaics 100 times and never quite hear the same record twice.

On early LP highlight ""Tiny Planes of Canvas
column79: Hart boasts of an ability to ""see the world that no one else can."" Hart
column80: operating largely from the confines of his bedroom
column81: has once again created a world unto itself: weird
column85: sanguine may not be a kaleidoscopic masterpiece like Circulatory System's debut—or those two eternally brilliant Olivia Tremor Control records—but it's possessed with that same spirit of discovery and wonder. It's a record just as baffling as it is beguiling
column87: a journey to the center of Hart's expansive mind. No one's making music quite like this
column88: not even the people who helped Hart making this very music
column89: so if we've got another five years to wait for another Circulatory System album
column90:
the spiraling mysteries at the center of Mosaics should be more than enough to hold us.

column11: It Takes a Train to Cry"". ""You don't know how she comes to me from time to time
column12: he sings on ""Time to Time""
column13: a gently love-drunk ballad.

column1: Those songs
column2: all from Places I Know
column3: were written as exercises in imitation
column4: tributes to Cooper's colleagues. They clear the path for the flights of imagination on Trout Steel and Machine Gun Co.
column5: in which Cooper's ensemble engages in flexible bursts of activity that abandon pop-song structure before relaxing back into it. Saxophonist Geoff Hawkins
column6: standup bassist Harry Miller
column7: and a coterie of other musicians wander in and out of the margins
column8: forming the core of a band that could do anything and go anywhere while preserving the fluid
column9: good-natured energy of Cooper's music. ""I've Got Mine"" wanders through 11 hushed minutes
column10: the sung verse alternating with extended jamming like honey running from a spoon.

column1: There are mildly abrasive moments—the spittle-flecked wailing of free saxophone on Machine Gun Co.'s ""The Singing Tree""
column2: for instance
column3: or the horns on ""Goodbye Blues
column4: Goodbye""
column5: which  break down like a St. Louis horn ensemble being dispersed by an angry traffic cop. But the albums mostly move in long
column6: heaving sighs—long
column7: free-flowing sections where Cooper plays in open tunings and clusters of instruments take their turns speaking to each other around him. In a way
column8: he's like Van Dyke Parks; equally in love with traditions and in thrall to eccentricity
column9: someone whose solo records build an alternate set of rules that their maker has no intention of spelling out for you.

column1: ""Improvisation is what I do—full stop. I am not interested in anything else
column2: Cooper told video artist and sometime collaborator Grayson Cooke. ""Improvisation is the reason to play music as far as I am concerned."" On paper
column3: this has a forbiddingly purist ring to it
column4: a pronouncement from a high temple
column5: but Mike Cooper makes music in a shack with the doors and windows open; for him improvisation is an allowance of all possibilities. He has name-checked Van Morrison's Astral Weeks
column6: and you can hear its liquid ease coursing through every moment
column7:
while Cooper remains a calmly rooted spot in the center.

In a guest column he wrote for Metalsucks in 2010
column3: Trap Them singer Ryan McKenney confessed
column4: “My sense of humor sucks.” Even back then
column5: this was not news. Trap Them released their Filth Rations EP that year
column6: and it was as complete a statement as any full-length they’d recorded to date—and just as joyless. Darker Handcraft followed in 2011
column7: and that album elevated McKenney and crew to a new level. Prior to that
column8: they were little more than another bunch of post-Converge metalcore miscreants; after Filth Rations and Darker Handcraft
column9: they sunk into a misanthropic pit of their own making. Misanthropy and humor
column10: of course
column11: can go hand-in-hand quite beautifully—but judging from Blissfucker
column12: Trap Them’s new full-length and first since Darker Handcraft
column13: McKenney is once again not laughing
column14: and he doesn't have to.

column1: There’s a grim
column2: twisted irony at the heart of Trap Them that gives the band a perverse dimensionality
column3: and Blissfucker brings it to the surface in a vivid blush of bruised black and blue. Where McKenney has long been a seething
column4: writhing hardcore frontman cut from the same cloth as Converge’s Jacob Bannon
column5: guitarist Brian Izzi is steeped in the vintage Swedish death metal of Entombed and At the Gates. Trap Them’s division of labor—and influence—has never been less distinct than on Blissfucker. The stylistic friction that defined the group has ground it down to the bone; hardcore and metal have finally bled together into an irreducible whole. “Salted Crypts” lays out an intricate template constructed of D-beat gallop
column6: razor-swift thrash riffs
column7: and pockets of charred melody; “Lungrunners” relies less on subtlety and more on time-lapse blast-beat erosion. Instead of detracting from McKenney’s nerve-tightening screams and abstract poetics
column8: it underscores his openly dire worldview. The only constant in life is change
column9: and that change comes quickly
column10: perilously
column11: and mercilessly.

column1: McKenney and Izzi are now the only remaining original members of Trap Them. Bassist Baudhuin and drummer Brad Fickeisen make their full-length debut with the band here
column2: with Fickeisen in particular having to fill a big vacancy—namely
column3: former Coliseum drummer Chris Maggio
column4: who brought his grenade-like intensity to Filth Rations and Darker Handcraft. As great as Maggio was
column5: Fickeisen is an upgrade. More precise and dynamic
column6: yet able to cultivate an air of chaos amid his calculation
column7: Fickeisen pushes the rest of the band—especially Izzi—toward a more freeform and flowing cadence. Even as it suffocates
column8: it breathes. On the sprawling tracks “Savage Climbers” and “Let Fall Each and Every Sedition Symptom”—whose only fault is sounding too much alike
column9: dual climaxes on an album that might have been better served by one final death throe—nothing is released. Chasms of feedback and wounded howls open up
column10: only to swallow themselves. And for every bomb the band lobs
column11: McKenney hurls his own body on top of it.

column1: The conceit that life and death are at stake every time a guitar is tuned or a microphone checked is
column2: in a sense
column3: romantic. McKenney
column4: it should be remembered
column5: doesn’t say that he has no sense of humor at all—only that his sense of humor sucks. There are no moments of lightness on Blissfucker
column6: not even the steely glint of gallows humor. But there is a weirdness to its nested levels of nihilism and noise
column7: as well as a subversive sense of both hardcore’s intransigence and metal’s melodrama. Too many shards of ideas are shoved into the long songs
column8: and Fickeisen’s flash sometimes borders on showmanship
column9: a glaring incongruity for a spartan outfit like Trap Them. Mostly
column10: though
column11: the new lineup locks into a trance of fatalistic terror
column12: one that culminates in a hopeless
column13: unhinged ecstasy. There may not be much to laugh about
column14:
but there’s definitely a punch line.

"|19565.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19565-trap-them-blissfucker/|7.3|Jason Heller

Rhett Miller occasionally watches the clock when he’s onstage. That’s just one of the revelations he makes on “Longer Than You’ve been Alive”
column2: the opening track from the Old 97's’ ninth album
column3: Most Messed Up. He also fesses up to washing down “mountains of weed
column4: a handful of pills” with “oceans and oceans” of booze. “None the hard stuff
column5: that shit kills.” He jumps off risers he shouldn’t even attempt to climb at his age
column6: bickers with the other guys in the band like they’re old married couples
column7: and still sometimes dreams of being the kind of rock star that simply can’t exist in today’s industry. “Rock stars were once such mythical creatures
column8: up there with presidents
column9: Playmates
column10: and preachers
column11: ” he explains. “Now you just do it cause it’s what you do.” When Miller sings
column12: “I’m not crazy about songs that get self-referential
column13: ” the universe threatens to collapse in on itself.

column1: Most Messed Up puts the ""old"" in Old 97's' bandname. The guys are all now in their 40s
column2: alt-country survivors who have the gumption to admit they can’t keep singing about romantic vindictiveness when they’re all married with kids. Bad backs and disillusioned fans are one thing
column3: but finding happiness can be disastrous for a band like this. So Miller tries to spice up his songwriting the way spouses try to spice up their marriages
column4: addressing the difficulties of maintaining a spark with your bandmates as well as your mate. “Let’s Get Drunk and Get It On” opens with him propositioning a woman post-show with a bottle of booze
column5: but it ends with him booking a room with a bottle of chilled champagne so he and the missus can have some time away from the kids.

column1: Self-aware and self-deprecating
column2: Most Messed Up seems like the kind of album that signals a comeback
column3: and certainly the band rumble through these songs like they’re not tired of each other. Songs like “Give It Time” and “Wheels Off” sound like the Olds at their rowdiest
column4: but they can’t really sustain that sense of abandon over a dozen tracks. “This Is the Ballad” and “The Disconnect” are far too fussy and clever from a guy who claims to hate self-referential songs
column5: and “Guadalajara” sounds utterly embarrassed as it recounts the tale of a businessman tempted by a woman losing her bikini top. And the title track closes the album with the least persuasive line Miller may have ever penned: “I am the most messed up motherfucker in this town.” Does anyone
column6: even Miller himself
column7: actually buy that?

column1: But the Olds were never a songwriter project. As distinctive as his lyrical voice can be
column2: Miller is still blessed beyond measure to have these three guys backing him. Ken Bethea still plays like he still thinks you can surf in Texas
column3: blending the Ventures and the Sir Douglas Quintet into super-melodic
column4: super-concise guitar lines
column5: and the rhythm section of drummer Philip Peeples and bassist Murry Hammond still swing just enough to give these songs some aggression. Sure
column6: the twitchy alienation of their earliest records is long gone
column7:
but the Old 97's are still fighting the good fight against respectability.

""

column1: Since then

column5: several tiers beneath his leader

column1: Ab-Soul

column5: Isaiah Rashad may have eaten his lunch. But These Days...

column1: ""Last-picked kid at gym class"" suits Ab best anyway
column2: since he reps the underdogs at every opportunity.  He has a thing for commercial pariahs: He is probably one of five living rappers in America who still eagerly namechecks Canibus as an influence; he called Slaughterhouse ""the illest lyricists in the game."" He's certainly the only Black Hippy member giving 16-plus bars to Asaad (""Stigmata"")
column3: a Philly firebrand best known for releasing a mixtape with 2Pac sodomizing Biggie on the cover.

column1: He's a proud pipsqueak
column2: in other words

column4: produced by Purity Ring's Corin Roddick (who's building an impressive sideline in hip-hop)
column5: he raps ""Got your lady with literature in her Louis bag

column7: while on ""Dub Sac"" he wants us to remember that ""martial law could happen any second!""  He embraces his outsider status

column1: The more human Ab-Soul dares to be on record

column6: I wonder if you ever forgave me.""

column1: That doesn't make him heavy

On the infectiously simple DNYC3-produced ratchet (""<a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0CCIQyCkwAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DZvXPAMc_5UI%26feature%3Dkp&ei=h-uqU-yHFYrIsATsoYGQDg&usg=AFQjCNEXYUsVByv2R7Kp0NF1icyK2syT0Q&bvm=bv.69620078
column3: d.cWc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Good Day
column4: ""<a href=""https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=0CCAQyCkwAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DLbouTdwOrVw%26feature%3Dkp&ei=pOuqU4eoKszlsASrpID4Cg&usg=AFQjCNEW5901E4Tp5YLv1dN15NpY07VZGQ&bvm=bv.69620078
column5: d.cWc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Faded"") cut ""Twact

He repurposes the chorus of Chief Keef's ""Love Sosa"" on ""Feelin' Us"" and mockingly signs a broken-down version of ""Hail Mary"" on the Danny  Brown-featuring ""Ride Slow"" as if he's purposefully misremembering it. On ""Hunnid Stax""

column8: when Ab freestyles endlessly for an impressed group of friends.

column4: Jay Rock

Total Control are five Melbourne men dead-set on pumping life into the spiritual tradition of post-punk exploration with little regard for sonic congruity. The lyric sheet for their new album
column2: Typical System
column3: reads like stream-of-consciousness beat poetry; in between songs
column4: it's dotted with manifesto-like musings that don't actually appear on the recordings. ""Our fragile subject confuses festivity for a grave militaristic orgy
column5: and pens a carol to document collapse
column6: reads the note following ""Bloody Glass""
column7: the minimal wave experiment that opens the album. In case you had a shard of faith that Total Control have even a strand of optimistic DNA
column8: here's the misanthropic footnote that follows ""Expensive Dog""
column9: a dramatic garage-punk blast: ""In contrast to barbarous gamblers
column10: the secure and prosperous demand companions of diseased and ill-fated breed. Mongrels prowl outside their gates."" Convention is hopeless.

column1: Perhaps these anti-conformist scripts are meta-commentaries on Total Control itself. Since the band's genre-smashing 2011 debut
column2: Henge Beat—which fused oddball sci-fi New Wave and subtle beats with punk aggression and ideology—they've amassed a cultish underground following as well as some attention in the music industry. They released a blackened 7"" on Sub Pop in 2012
column3: and
column4: had they preferred
column5: Typical System could have been released on a label bigger than tiny Seattle hardcore outpost Iron Lung. ""You don't need a safety net
column6: sings Dan Stewart
column7: detached frontman and resident nihilist philosopher
column8: on System's dreary synth-pop banger of a closing track. Whether these are self-subscribed mantras or not remains open to interpretation—but Typical System invites that. Across their discography
column9: Total Control have been so idea-driven that it is hard to not intellectualize what they do. What's the ""lonely operation"" raging on garage ripper ""Systematic Fuck""? Does ""Black Spring"" refer to the free-associating Henry Miller novel—and does the song's tense
column10: motorik quality imply that its end-times themes actually stretch eternal? Is the title Typical System an allusion to keeping underground autonomy in the face of commercial opportunity? Does it matter?

column1: Such questions are tempting
column2: and it's easy to read into Typical System's densities. But it's perhaps more satisfying to give oneself over to the record's bleak
column3: peculiar breeze. The approach is not hugely different from Henge Beat—they've still got the toolbox you'd imagine from guys who variously play tough-guy hardcore (Straightjacket Nation)
column4: primitive garage-punk (UV Race and Eddy Current Suppression Ring)
column5: and electronic dance music (Lace Curtain). Above all
column6: Total Control's fair bit of touring since Henge Beat has allowed them more technical muscle
column7: and thus a newfound tactility and energy streak.

column1: Typical System's dynamics surprise at most turns
column2: revealing their strange sense of humor. The soft sax wails of the underwater ""Liberal Party"" find Stewart deadpanning existentially on a ""Broken porch light/ Shattered sense of worth
column3: before leading into the militaristic scream and snarl of ""Two Less Jacks""
column4: which would not sound out of place on an Iceage record. Total Control benefit immensely from a knack for rhythm—their circling
column5: lurching guitar grooves often simulate the repetition of the minimal electronic found elsewhere. A sense of duality exists within the songs: the opener ""Bloody Glass"" is galactic and glossy with psychic
column6: pinging beats
column7: but it finds Stewart berating ""billionaires
column8: ""thieves
column9: and ""cowards"" alike
column10: as if they are all synonymous. Its dreary delivery makes the imagery all the more sinister: ""Spitting on foreign lands/ On bloody stumps/ On glass/ We dance.""

column1: Ghosts of new wave's past audibly haunt these songs
column2: and ""Flesh War"" is Typical System's most straightforward take on that sound. It's the widescreen
column3: mechanical-sounding focal point
column4: with synths soaring soft enough to rest your head on without worrying about getting clawed in the face. But it's not mere retro-styling. ""Flesh War"" looks for what's left in the endless possibilities of post-punk and says something real through it. The lyrics morbidly mutate: the ""breaking"" of the day becomes the cynical ""break-in"" of the day
column5: and a prayer to ""news"" and ""fame"" becomes a play to ""noose"" and ""flame."" ""Carve a space inside your brain
column6: the robotic Stewart sings
column7: ""Earn enough of that cruel gaze/ And bear it 'til your back would break."" ""Flesh War"" sounds like commentary on life under the relentless watch of overlords—further proof that electronic pop can be just as subversive as throat-shredding rock and roll. Even with their most aesthetically orthodox track
column8:
Total Control's total message is radical.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20655/homepage_large.5c5784f1.jpg|Anthology of Interplanetary Folk Music Vol. 1: Nommos/Visiting|31665.0|Craig Leon|[]|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Rvng Intl.']|2014-06-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:06.371159|"

In the 1970s—the decade during which he'd produced groundbreaking debut records by Suicide
column2: the Ramones
column3: Richard Hell
column4: and Blondie—Craig Leon went to see an exhibit of ancient art made by a tribe from Mali
column5: the Dogon. Although their people have lived in relative seclusion for centuries
column6: their ancestors developed an impressively complex system of astronomy. The Dogon worship amphibious
column7: extraterrestrial creatures called Nommos
column8: who are believed to have travelled to earth from the distant star Sirius B. All of which might sound a little out there—until you learn that in the 20th century
column9: modern astronomers were astonished to find how accurate the Dogon's ancient calculations were; somehow
column10: centuries before telescopes
column11: their ancestors had identified stars that were invisible to the naked eye. Leon was as taken with this mystery as he was with his growing collection of synthesizers. He decided to make an album of what he imagined would be playing ""on the Nommos's Walkman"" (""They would have had to listen to something on an interplanetary flight… otherwise it would have been very boring"") and
column12: in a cosmic nod to Harry Smith
column13: give it the playful title Anthology of Interplanetary Folk.

column1: The resulting collection is a masterpiece of early electronic music—a precursor to later explorations in industrial music
column2: new age
column3: and ambient techno—but up until now
column4: it's never been heard exactly how Leon intended. Leon composed the Anthology as two ""mirror image"" parts: The driving and metallic Nommos came out on John Fahey's Takoma label as a standalone LP in 1981
column5: and its sequel
column6: the softer and more subdued Visiting came out a year later. In the decades it's been out of print
column7: Nommos in particular has been bootlegged repeatedly
column8: and late last year the California label Superior Viaduct put out a reissue of Nommos against Leon's wishes. ""I had always envisioned a different version of the album being the definitive version
column9: Leon said
column10: and so the 2013 release spurred him into taking control of the record's legacy. This new authorized reissue
column11: put out with care by the Brooklyn label RVNG
column12: finally presents Leon's otherworldly achievement exactly as he wanted it to be heard
column13: with Nommos and Visiting side by side for the first time.

column1: A cliche you often hear about early synth-based music is that it ""still sounds like something from the future
column2: but what's interesting about Anthology is that it was always meant to sound like a transmission from the past. As his invented genre of ""interplanetary folk"" attests
column3: Leon was drawn to the interplay of apparent opposites: antiquity and progress
column4: earth and space
column5: and
column6: of course
column7: new age and punk. Anthology is not an anthropological attempt to replicate (or colonize) the sounds of the Dogon tribe
column8: but rather something more creative and personal—a sonic work of speculative fiction that uses ""new"" technology to imagine a time before recorded music. Neither primitive nor futuristic
column9: it still has this uncanny feel of music that exists somewhere outside of time.

column1: The atmosphere of Nommos is clanging and aqueous (because the Nommos could swim
column2: Leon wanted to make it sound like music heard underwater). Driven by a mesmerizing polyrhythmic beat
column3: ""Donkeys Bearing Cups"" is punctuated by sudden spurts of jagged-aluminum synths
column4: while the incandescent ""Nommo"" lulls you into a gentler (though no less immersive) trance. Anthology's centerpiece is Nommos' penultimate track
column5: the haunting 15-minute reverie ""Four Eyes to See the Afterlife""
column6: the last two-thirds of which build on a tinny loop and a wordless
column7: interplanetary siren song voiced by Leon's wife and collaborator Cassell Webb.

column1: Although it still captures a feeling of intergalactic awe
column2: Visiting is meant to evoke a more terrestrial vibe than its companion piece. The bright and lively ""Region of Fleeing Civilians"" is the closest the collection comes to a straight-ahead synth-pop instrumental (complete with percussion that sounds like handclaps)
column3: and ""Visiting"" introduces a tranquilly lilting guitar into the atmosphere. As far as its earth-bound kindred spirits go
column4: Anthology sounds attuned to the frequencies that had been coming out of Germany that decade: Nommos' ""She Wears a Hemispherical Skullcap"" has an ""Autobahn""-esque luminosity about it
column5: while Anthology's more muted moments echo Brian Eno's work with Cluster. Still
column6: as Leon explains
column7: the spirit of New York punk is pulsing through it
column8: too. ""The Lower East Side scene was very involved in counterculture art and poetry
column9: he recalled in a recent interview. ""It became populist later
column10: but if you look at Patti Smith
column11: Television
column12: Talking Heads
column13: even the Ramones… Nommos fit in with that.""

column1: The timing of this reissue couldn't be better. We're in middle of a modest but notable new age revival
column2: when a new generation of listeners are reassessing this often-misunderstood genre
column3: discovering its pioneers
column4: and uncovering its hidden DIY roots. Leon is a perfect embodiment of new age's unexpected punk past
column5: and it would seem the world is only now catching up with his vision
column6: over thirty years after his Anthology was released. A few months ago
column7: I had the pleasure of seeing Leon play Nommos in full at the Greenwich Village venue Le Poisson Rouge
column8: a short walk from the downtown clubs where he first saw Suicide and Patti Smith decades ago. His set featured spacey visual projections
column9: and he and Webb were joined by the stylistically adventurous string ensemble ACME—which
column10: actually
column11: was how he envisioned this supposed synth-classic all along. ""It was meant to be orchestral
column12: he admitted in a recent interview
column13: ""but we didn't have any money!"" Like these performances
column14: the definitive reissue finally brings Leon's landmark work full circle. Anthology of Interplanetary Folk is far from some kitschy relic of electronic music past; in fact
column15:
there may have never been a better time to join Leon for the ride.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20764/homepage_large.1850cbbf.jpg|White Reaper EP|32232.0|White Reaper|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2014-06-26 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:06.935940|"

The first song on the Ramones-idolizing
column2: Spider-Man-obsessed Kentucky trio White Reaper's self-titled EP is called ""Cool""; the second
column3: ""Funn"". Brothers Nick and Sam Wilkerson and frontman Tony Esposito do not appear to have any particular designs on world domination; for now
column4: they're more interested in catching the eye of that insomniac gal across the room. Esposito and the Wilkerson boys won the favor of their native Louisville with their spring-loaded live shows
column5: which they've more than ably translated to wax on this six-song EP. They're a young band
column6: and like most young bands
column7: they've still got a couple kinks left to be worked out. But
column8: for now
column9:
their youthful exuberance—and a half-dozen blistering hooks—are suiting them just fine.

Opener ""Cool"" lights the fuse
column10: then quickly explodes; within five seconds
column11: they are off and running. Atop a tight-as-anything smear of fuzzbox guitar and Nick Wilkerson's 90 MPH rhythms
column12: Esposito stars pitching woo. ""Oh-whoa
column13: she's so cool
column14: he sings in that classic American faux-Brit accent: a little bratty
column15: and a whole lot smitten. And that
column16: more or less
column17: is White Reaper: revved-up
column18: romantically inclined
column19: hook-heavy punkers with a keen sense of their strengths and the good sense not to overextend themselves. ""Should we settle down?"" Esposito wonders halfway through ""Funn
column20: then quickly provides his own answer: ""Oh
column21:
no.""

A Chuck Berry-inspired solo here and a touch of moddish organ there add a splash of color to the proceedings. But the appeal of White Reaper's music is mostly pretty black-and-white: these are catchy
column22: undemanding songs
column23: played beyond an inch of their lives. Esposito's quite the little howler; hard to say just how he'd fare with a ballad—the breathless White Reaper EP never slows down long enough to give him the chance—but when he opens wide
column24: that wail of his is more than enough. Sam Wilkerson's bass gets a bit lost in the melee
column25: but brother Nick's just about all the rhythm section anyone could need. Together
column26:
they blast through White Reaper's 16 minutes like sprinters looking to shave seconds off their time.

Is White Reaper's music formulaic? No question—but
column27: when the energy's right and hooks are there
column29: and it's a perennial favorite of the drunk and disorderly. White Reaper's lyrics—mostly about cool girls of their acquaintance
column30: their failure to not act ""so stu-pid"" around the aforementioned cool girls
column31: and said cool girls' difficulties getting home by themselves in the wee hours of the morning—aren't exactly laden with nuance
column32: and that's no accident: anything more would just slow them down. That they're so clearly indebted to a few well-known sources—the Ramones
column33: the earliest inklings of British Invasion-era proto-punk
column34: and the Jay Reatard/Ty Segall axis of the current garage-rock renaissance—simply places them in a tradition
column35: one they seem plenty keen to pick up

column1: It's true that there's a built-in ceiling with music this gleefully steeped in the past: White Reaper may do what they do well
column2: but what they do has been done many times before. A little energy goes a long way with this stuff
column3: and White Reaper's got energy to spare. But a little personality goes even further
column4: and White Reaper could probably stand to get a little more of themselves into their music to help shake up the tried-and-true formula to which they've adhered themselves. Still
column5: it's a mistake to assume every band can (or should) be important
column6: or influential
column7: or essential in some highfalutin' way. Some bands are just fun
column8:
and White Reaper are just that.

On Buenos Aires-born musician and composer Ulises Conti's new album
column2: he's fashioned 27 brief sketches
column3: titled from A to Z (don’t forget the Ñ)
column4: into billowing lines of musical verse that equally reward individual contemplation and cumulative immersion. Conti gives diverse musical forms to phonemes and diphthongs by drawing on a sound vocabulary that is limited
column5: but with nuanced differences of resonance and inflection. The music is somewhere between electronic ambient and post-classical sound art. Enigmatic themes for processed piano and guitar are humanized by manipulated field recordings of everyday things from amusement parks to insects. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">These compositions blend passages of airy light with dark
column7: cloistered ones
column8: as if traveling through patches of clearing and shade or through days and nights. When your landscape is an alphabet
column9: scale is elusive.

column1: Overall
column2: the music is austerely sacred
column3: melodically lush
column4: and elegiac
column5: highlighting the orphaned quality of isolated letters
column6: which communicate clearly only in their connections to each other. There are dreamy duets and trios for high-contrast timbres
column7: brooding piano ruminations
column8: and acoustic sounds processed into grainy drones and clipped pulses. The spirit of the album is soft and pensive
column9: but tightly coiled; it periodically gathers to peaks of compressed fury (""H""). Conti has a graceful way with flickers of mottled counterpoint (""I"" and ""J"")
column10: differentiating his simple
column11: revolving motifs. He packs satisfying amounts of development into short pieces while preserving their discrete musical perimeters.

column1: Occasionally
column2: the relationship between letter and sound is obvious—satisfyingly so in the cases of vowels
column3: such as the choral aspiration of ""A"" and the shivery shriek of ""E"". Elsewhere
column4: linking letters such as ""C"" and ""G"" to their corresponding notes feels like a slight failure of imagination. But mostly
column5: the interpretations are infinitely subjective
column6: engaging the listener's imagination. At times
column7: Conti captures the audible contours of a letter's sound
column8: at others
column9: its visual shape. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column10: serif;"">""K"" makes you suddenly hear that consonant's curt bite in the piano's upper octaves
column11: while the tightly swiveling sequence of ""L"" evokes turning back and forth through the letterform's right angle.

column1: The brilliant ""B"" combines both approaches: t
column2: serif;"">here are voluptuous curves in the piano and a ""buh""-like sound in the root note of the guitar figure. ""N"" and its tilde-bearing cousin are woven together in a lattice of bird song and tolling church bells that feels so notably sacrosanct you wonder if they have personal significance for Conti. The exhaling drones of ""H"" seem on the verge of asking ""Who?"" and then
column3: as the intensity increases
column4: ""Help!"" ""S"" has a sibilant thrum
column5: slithering on a cushion of air. ""V"" almost vanishes
column6: repeatedly tapering down into a silent vacuum. ""X"" is a burst of busy
column7: crisscrossing speed before the closing lullaby of ""Z"".

column1: Conti reveals letters to be so swollen with associations that his slender tracks feel like larger metaphorical conduits than they should rightfully be. The composer renews our sense of connection to these strange
column2: almost invisibly familiar little squiggles of code
column3: turning us into sonic cryptographers. Like the alphabet
column4: the small pieces
column5: in sum
column6: seem to contain everything in the world—a luxuriously full compendium of meaning
column7:
if only we could put it in the right order to reveal it.

From the beginning
column2: it was clear that Mastodon were never meant to be just another sludge band. Had they decided to get perpetually stoned and cycle through a minimal sequence of drop-A power chords
column3: the quartet could have gone on to earn Down-level renown based on instrumental ability alone. Instead
column4: they took the transcendent route
column5: using their filthy guitars to conjure terrifying worlds. Remission from 2002 explored the concept of death through the prism of fire
column6: inspiring a four-part sequence of concept albums with one of the most compelling cast of characters in rock history.

column1: There was Leviathan’s terrifying Moby Dick
column2: his arrival heralded by high-pressure riffs that seemed to issue forth from the Mariana trench
column3: and the anti-hero of the earthy Blood Mountain
column4: a direct invocation of American mythologist Joseph Campbell’s concept of “The Hero With a Thousand Faces”—and
column5: of course
column6: there was Crack the Skye’s Rasputin
column7: a historical villain recast as an otherworldly sage. Ambitious as Mastodon’s concepts were
column8: they avoided pretension by grounding their lofty thematics in crunchy
column9: timeless riffage and a cross-pollinated sound combining Black Sabbath’s doom
column10: Electric Wizard’s gloom
column11: and King Crimson’s hyper-literate mad genius. And so
column12: four guys from Atlanta quickly earned the reputations as metal’s smartest
column13: most unstoppable band of barbarians. If anyone could cross over
column14: they could.

column1: So it's easy to understand why
column2: when Mastodon’s elemental epic reached its conclusion in 2009
column3: they were tempted to set aside the prog epics in search of a new aural identity
column4: one that could sublimate the esoteric monoliths of old into an accessible and mature sound.  To some
column5: the end product of that venture
column6: 2011’s Mike Elizondo-produced The Hunter
column7: constituted Mastodon’s jumping-the-Megalodon moment: too poppy
column8: too giddy
column9: and downright flimsy when compared to the steely grooves of the past. The prospect of a major metal album overseen by a superproducer like Elizondo struck many as sacrilege
column10: but after a decade of weak-tea rock on the major labels
column11: one couldn’t help but feel thrilled at the prospect of four storytellers re-shaping the world of popular heavy music.

column1: Once More ‘Round the Sun
column2: the band’s latest
column3: tempers the mixtape approach of its predecessor. Nick Raskulinecz (Foo Fighters
column4: Alice in Chains) was tapped to produce this time
column5: and he brings a comparatively raw sound. Troy Sanders returns with a vastly improved vocal range
column6: one honed in the groove-driven supergroup Killer Be Killed
column7: and Brent Hinds remains the best screamer of the group—though it’s a shame he doesn’t get more opportunities to show it off. Occasionally their tag-team approach matches Mastodon’s lofty standards
column8: as on the title-track
column9: which deserves special mention for that goosebump-raising chord progression in the bridge. But the thin
column10: uninspired harmonies gets taxing by the album’s proggier second half
column11: and on the whole
column12: Once More ’Round the Sun is easily the band’s weakest effort to date.

column1: For two records now
column2: Mastodon have jettisoned the overarching concepts of old for a simpler mission: to be a hard rock band making hard rock records. Clearly
column3: though
column4: they’re not willing to abandon their proggy roots entirely
column5: leaving listeners (as well as themselves) trapped between two modes: the straightforward wallop of Foo Fighters-style rock
column6: and the hard
column7: nasty sludge of old. They never fully commit to either extreme
column8: resulting in a frustratingly liminal listen.

column1: Throughout the majority of the album
column2: those mammoth styles remain in constant collision with each other
column3: often within the same song. Opener “Tread Lightly” sets the template: Mastodon churn out a slithering groove
column4: segue into a good-not-great verse-chorus-verser adorned with some cool flourishes
column5: and then launch headlong into a warped solo from guitarist Brent Hinds and some psychedelic noodling
column6: culminating in a satisfactory raucous conclusion. Frequently
column7: however
column8: the band simply shrug and end with a bridge to nowhere (“Feast Your Eyes“)
column9: a lazy fade-out (“Chimes at Midnight”)
column10: or worse.

column1: Sudden transitions are certainly not without precedent in Mastodon’s case—they’re one of the reasons why
column2: even a decade later
column3: Leviathan remains so memorable. But where that album used abrupt transitions to lead the listener further down the chute toward the abyss
column4: Once More ‘Round the Sun leaves us with some undecipherable head scratchers
column5: like the ""Hey-ho/ Let’s fucking rock and roll"" coda provided by Mastodon’s Atlanta punk pals the Coathangers
column6: on the math-y “Aunt Lisa”.

column1: Once More 'Round the Sun is also marked by an overarching aimlessness. Brent Hinds has said that the band pushed for a “stream-of-consciousness” approach on this LP
column2: but too often
column3: the looseness diminishes the possibility of catharsis. “Aunt Lisa” and closer “Diamond in the Witch House”
column4: a collaboration with recurring guest Scott Kelly of Neurosis
column5: pack plenty of momentum
column6: but they waste it on clumsy transitions and Kelly’s directionless conclusion. Lead single ""High Road"" fares far better
column7: proving the band's alt-rock worthiness in a rare show of discipline combining crunchy guitars
column8: a belt-ready chorus
column9: and a cheekily victorious solo.

column1: “This time things’ll work out just fine
column2: ” sings Dailor as he pummels the kit into submission on “The Motherload”
column3: probably the band’s vaguest rocker to date. “We won’t let you slip away.” That's not the kind of promise you’d expect from a band so previously obsessed with white whales and holy grails
column4: but as the Georgia titans continue their slow-but-rightful ascent to the throne of mainstream heavy music—a prospect that necessitates a less caustic approach—it’s understandable they’d want to stick their heads over the fourth wall. As proud rejectors of such restrictions
column5: metal fans are all to quick to conflate heightened accessibility with a deliberate betrayal of their extreme upbringing
column6: and surely the quartet are aware of this.

column1: With all that in mind
column2: it's possible to view Once More 'Round the Sun as a vow to honor their roots
column3: even as they set out in search of broader horizons. So far
column4: however
column5: Mastodon’s paradigms simply don’t mesh the way they should. Evolution takes time
column6:
and Mastodon continue to publicly work out their growing pains as they determine which traits best represent the unified sound they’ve been chasing this decade.

The 1990s alt-rock boom produced a lot of rock stars who weren’t very good at being rock stars: too glum
column2: too suspicious of the mainstream audience they found themselves playing to
column3: or both at the same time. Few of them really seemed to really relish the role
column4: and the ones who stand out most
column5: looking back from two decades later
column6: were women: Kim Gordon
column7: Courtney Love
column8: and Royal Trux frontwoman Jennifer Herrema.

column1: While their contemporaries were imploding the classic rock golden-god mythos through a truculent refusal to follow the rulebook
column2: Herrema and Royal Trux's Neil Hagerty
column3: were accomplishing something similar by emulating its sickest qualities. Falling half-accidentally into a pile of the major label cash that was flying around
column4: Herrema and Hagerty put that money into drugs and druggy records that achieved the same kind of squalid junkie transcendence as Exile on Main Street
column5: with far less romanticism. Their carton-a-day croaks and fucked-up frames represented ""heroin chic"" taken to its scabrous logical conclusion
column6: and they reveled in its repulsiveness to an extent that terminally disconcerted much of the audience that their often achingly beautiful records deserved. The whole project sounded filthy and
column7: somehow
column8: glorious.

column1: Unlike a good deal of her contemporaries
column2: Herrema’s continued evolving as an artist since the '90s. After her partnership with Hagerty dissolved following 2000's Pound for Pound
column3: which explored Southern rock and the coke-addled disco side of the late-'70s Stones
column4: she formed and fronted RTX
column5: which added a scuzzy streak of hair metal into the mix. With her latest group
column6: Black Bananas
column7: she’s dragged that whole pile of classic rock influences into the present day. The group’s first album
column8: 2012’s Rad Times Xpress IV
column9: was a weird mishmash of stoner grooves
column10: flamboyant hair metal
column11: and the seedier side of the contemporary club scene
column12: the results sounding like someone dragged 1984-era David Lee Roth into at a basement DJ night and filled him full of cough syrup. It was a mess
column13: but like most messes Herrema’s involved in
column14: it was compelling.

column1: Electric Brick Wall is a far more coherent synthesis of those disparate influences
column2: and possibly her strongest record since the Trux’s peak. The album's female-fronted pileup of overblown drum machines and retro guitar riffage shares surface similarities with Sleigh Bells
column3: but instead of that band's shimmering
column4: pixellated gleam
column5: Black Bananas give off a debauched
column6: grimy aura. When they evoke the Sunset Strip in the '80s it’s not the fictionalized version served up by the Motley Crüe wannabes of the time but the seedy real-life version
column7: with rumbling rap beats mixed in for kicks.

column1: At other points
column2: the group ditches its retro references and shoots for an almost purely contemporary sound
column3: which Herrema’s seldom attempted previously. “Give It to Me” is a slick (by her standards) take on dance floor electro-pop
column4: while “Physical Emotions” is their take on straight-up radio R&B
column5: complete with Auto-Tune; even with the requisite amount of distortion that they slather on it
column6: it still has a modern sheen that even listeners attuned to Herrema’s wild stylistic impulses won’t see coming. After years spent ransacking the past
column7: she’s turned her sights on the here and now
column8:
and it’s as fucked-up and fascinating as anything she’s ever done.

In between creating albums of indelible
column4: secretly smart dance-pop
column5: the members of Hot Chip have indulged in solo projects that focus on specific aspects of the band’s sound. These projects are sometimes reminiscent of Hot Chip
column6: while almost always stopping short of the band's classic sound. Both on his own and as part of house-loving duo the 2 Bears
column7: Joe Goddard has explored the group's beat-driven
column8: clubby side
column9: while Al Doyle and Felix Martin have zeroed in on dance’s comedown moments
column10: first with the stately
column11: short-lived Lanark (whose elegant “The Stone the Builder Rejected” appeared on Hot Chip’s excellent DJ-Kicks mix from 2007) and then as part of the more downtempo New Build project.

column1: Similar to Goddard
column2: Alexis Taylor also works on his own and as part of a group
column3: releasing two records over the past three years with his avant-pop outfit About Group
column4: which also features members of This Heat and Spiritualized. Without hearing a note of music
column5: the group’s collective pedigree suggests that their music might be more difficult than Hot Chip’s glimmering
column6: weird accessibility—indeed
column7: they initially came together in 2009 to record an under-the-radar record of improvisational music. But although their music has lacked immediacy
column8: it still hews closely to traditional songwriting forms
column9: merging the yacht-rock predilections that have cropped up on Taylor-sung Hot Chip songs with a soft-focus songwriting approach reminiscent of one-time Taylor collaborator Robert Wyatt.

column1: Taylor’s solo work doesn’t so much diverge from his work in About Group as it does resemble a more isolated version of that band’s loosely drawn style
column2: slotting abstract sound experiments alongside simple songs that lean on a one main hook. (About Group is definitely the main reference point for Taylor’s solo endeavors; other than that solemnly gorgeous
column3: church-like voice of his
column4: his own material is so far removed from the Hot Chip canon that it barely resembles the band’s work at all.) Rubbed Out from 2008 carried a cheeky title that doubled as an explanation for the record’s off-the-cuff sound (“There wasn’t any thinking behind it
column5: really
column6: ” he told NME at the time) and last year’s Nayim from the Halfway Line EP leaned hard on experimentation
column7: serving as a depository for stray ideas. His latest solo effort
column8: Await Barbarians
column9: kicks off with a red herring to suggest that the listener’s in for more of the same: the two-minute “Lazy Bones” is all aimlessly plunked tones
column10: with the occasional pitch-bend that gives the track a first-time-using-a-keyboard feel.

column1: Luckily
column2: the slight piece of music isn’t representative of what follows
column3: instead acting as a portal for an intimate collection of home-recorded
column4: structurally melodic songs. Much of Await Barbarians is intrinsically catchy
column5: in the way that most simple
column6: basically pleasing melodies will get stuck in your head after one or two listens. Part of this is due to Taylor’s honeyed vocals
column7: which could make even a takeout menu sound exquisitely melancholy
column8: but the highlights suggest that Taylor’s capable of writing engaging songs even on his own. “Without a Crutch”
column9: the melody and title of which appears twice on Await Barbarians
column10: sways and swings with warm instrumentation that could make for a serviceable sitcom theme song; the dusky
column11: anti-gravity pull of “Immune System” resembles a stripped-down take on OMD’s more downtempo moments
column12: while the main melodic figure of “Am I Not a Soldier?” gently cascades on a bed of dry drum machine hits and slow-hand guitar.

column1: Much of Hot Chip’s music has gives back whatever feelings the listener puts into it; that is to say
column2: they’re not the most direct band lyrically
column3: and even at their most personal they maintain a distance. In the closing moments of 2012’s kaleidoscopic In Our Heads
column4: Taylor briefly broke that spell with the moony-eyed devotional “Always Been Your Love”
column5: but on Await Barbarians he seems to have retreated back into his shell again
column6: to the point where when he sings “Everyone knows what I mean” over the jagged guitar of “From the Halfway Line”
column7: it seems like he’s having a laugh. Wit has certainly played a large role in Hot Chip’s work
column8: especially their earlier records
column9: and on Await Barbarians a sense of humor occasionally rears its head. “If I don’t know where I am today/ It’s not because I’m far away
column10: ” he jauntily sings on the album’s first iteration of “Without a Crutch”
column11: following it up with a sorry-not-sorry sense of defeatism: “Or even ‘cause I drink too much/ Or then again
column12: not quite enough.”

column1: Listen hard enough and a few other glimmers of fascination eventually rise out of the album’s low-stakes murk—tucked away in the funereal march of ”Elvis Has Left the Building” is what could possibly be a strange allusion to Whitney Houston’s passing in 2011. But the downtempo trudge and repetitive structures of Await Barbarians are ultimately too imposing to demand the close attention they require. And that’s okay: at his best
column2: Taylor has sounded like someone caught up in the rapture of self
column3: a beatific presence unconcerned with what’s around him
column4: so a solo album made by himself and for himself isn’t necessarily surprising. Given what he’s proven capable of as part of his main gig
column5: though
column6: it’s hard not to wish that
column7: when left to his own devices
column8:
he made more of an effort to get outside of his own head.

Peter Matthew Bauer's Liberation! marks his first time singing
column2: writing lyrics
column3: and leading a band; it’s also the first project he’s worked on since his tenure as bassist and organist in the Walkmen
column4: who
column5: in Bauer’s own words
column6: are on a “pretty extreme hiatus.” Taking those milestones into account
column7: Liberation! is a bold stroke on a blank canvas
column8: with songs that celebrate freedom and fear in the same breath
column9: two emotions that definitely crop up when someone’s moving on in life.

column1: Bauer’s musical palette is broad and unique
column2: expanding past the sounds of his previous band: he implements polyrhythmic island music on the the title track
column3: the sounds of slow 1960s beat bands on “Shiva the Destroyer”
column4: and true American heartland rock on “Irish Wake In Varanasi (For Big Pete Devlin)”. The opening track “I Was Born in An Ashram” doubles as biographical fodder—Bauer was
column5: indeed
column6: born in an ashram—and as a means of setting up Liberation!'s theme shambling along the path to personal nirvana. He sings about religion and the “freedom” it affords as if he were taking part in a classic-rock exorcism
column7: which is evident in his singing voice
column8: moving between a Kurt Vile-esque drawl and a pursed-lip Mick Jagger croon. Accordingly
column9: the music occasionally takes on the lo-fi pluck of Constant Hitmaker and the swagger-psych of Their Satanic Majesties Request.

column1: Orthodox Hinduism
column2: Scientology
column3: Christianity
column4: and religious hokum all receive lashings from Bauer’s sharp tongue. Rather than possessing the snide reproach of a message-board atheist
column5: Bauer comes across as someone choosing to embrace mystery as its own religion
column6: as terrifying as that may be. “Only you can convince yourself
column7: ” he sings on “Shaved Heads & Pony Tails”
column8: which ma ybe the first indie rock song about a śikhā; the album's true mantra comes on the final track
column9: where Bauer exalts over a two-chord stadium-ready tune
column10: “You are the chapel
column11: and everything is wonder."" Elsewhere
column12: he lets his voice go on album closer “You Are the Chapel”
column13: dialing into the talk-anthem spirit of Bruce Springsteen
column14: while underneath the drums thunder louder than any other instrument featured on the album. It’s a great closing anthem made even better by an errant Oasis diss: “I see you looking like Oasis/ why does anyone want to look like Oasis?”

column1: Liberation! is most successful as a shaking off of Bauer's relative anonymity: he paints himself as a funny guy
column2: an American wanderer
column3: and someone eager to expel what’s been boiling underneath those bass parts for the Walkmen for so many years. Perhaps that’s why this album sounds like such an impulsive
column4: energetic mishmash that all comes out in a fury
column5: as Liberation! doesn’t feel dwelled-upon or over-wrought. There are points
column6: like his off-handed “ooo’s” at the end of “Latin American Ficciones”
column7: that could stand to be more filled out
column8: and sometimes the bare-bones production seems too small for the ideal size of the songs. But the ramshackle spontaneity is Bauer’s charm
column9: as the songwriting compliments the heady spiritualism of his words. Liberation! gives Bauer a voice
column10:
and the mystery of where he goes next is just as exciting for us as it is for him.
