'Daymare']|2014-06-25 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:12.336827|"

Eyehategod’s twenty-odd-year history is so rich
column4: dark
column5: and squalid that it’s nearly impossible to ignore when discussing the band’s formidable musical output. Alongside Crowbar and Down (both of whom are also riding high on recent releases)
column6: they are the quintessential Southern sludge band
column7: and were instrumental in articulating and perfecting that bleak
column8: swaggering metal-meets-punk sound that frontman Mike Williams still calls “heavy blues”. While it’s easy to wax romantic over what Eyehategod friend and occasional collaborator Phil Anselmo once dismissively referred to as “the Southern slow jam thing
column9: whiskey that
column10: rebel this
column11: ” Eyehategod are so much more than their backstory. (And
column12: anyway
column13: Mike prefers vodka.) The New Orleans institution refuses to either take themselves too seriously or be made victims of their own mythology. They’re just here to play
column14: and if you have a problem with that
column15: well
column16: they’re tougher than they look
column17: and they already look pretty damn tough.

column1: In the many years since they started the band and released 1989’s Garden Dwarf Woman Driver demo
column2: Eyehategod’s core members have collectively survived the worst luck imaginable. They’ve been battered by hurricane winds
column3: crippling addiction
column4: jail time
column5: depression
column6: and ultimately
column7: death; they've welcomed new drummer Aaron Hill into the fold following the untimely passing of original sticksman Joey LaCaze in 2013. LaCaze’s signature drumming style married swaggering looseness with a powerful physicality
column8: and his presence is felt all over the band’s new self-titled album. It’s a fitting epitaph for such a larger-than-life talent
column9: and an excellent sign for the future.

column1: The release of Eyehategod has been a long time coming: the band took their sweet time dithering over album titles and labels
column2: and the recording process was waylaid by fitful stops and starts
column3: as it began at legendary Dopesick producer Billy Anderson’s studio
column4: paused
column5: and was resumed at Anselmo’s home studio alongside Down producer Steve Berrigan. Anselmo’s Housecore label signed on to the release resulting album
column6: which marks the now-quartet’s first full-length studio recording since 2000’s Confederacy of Ruined Lives. The smoke's since cleared
column7: and the resulting eleven-song testament is well worth the wait.

column1: “Agitation! Propaganda!” is a full-bore rager that sounds more like Williams’ hardcore punk side project Arson Anthem than anything else. Eyehategod has always written fast songs
column2: but they’ve never opened an album like this before; typically
column3: they've preferred to catch their listeners off-guard with a mid-album burst like Dopesick's “Methamphetamine”
column4: or kick things off with a bait-and-switch a la “Blank” on Take As Needed For Pain. For a few nerve-wracking moments
column5: you’re left wondering whether Eyehategod have burrowed way back down to their punk roots and abandoned the heavy altogether
column6: but halfway through the song those dirty Delta blues riffs force their way back in
column7: and from then on
column8: it’s business as usual.

column1: Eyehategod resembles the band's most classic work through and through
column2: from the abject aural misery on “Robitussin and Rejection” to the feedback-heavy “Flags and Cities Bound”
column3: the latter of which sees Williams dip into one of his wild-eyed spoken word rants. Jimmy Bower and Brian Patton are in fine form as they pass leaden blues riffs back and forth
column4: teasing out grooves and smashing into teeth-out blasts of intensity when the mood strikes. They have some fun
column5: too; “Worthless Rescue” catches them smuggling in a straight-up Southern rock riff under loads of distortion
column6: and the “Framed to the Wall” gives them another chance to wrestle with sweaty punk riffs before stalling back down into syrupy sludge. Bassist Gary Mader’s got the most heavy lifting to do across the board
column7: matching LaCaze’s apocalyptic beats and anchoring the whole unsteady mess with dependably solid skill while Williams throttles both the mic and his own beleaguered vocal chords with a perverse alacrity. Acidic and unpredictable
column8: you’d never guess just how many times Williams’ voice has been put through the ringer. As always with Eyehategod
column9: those scars are internal.

column1: The band has been playing several of these songs live for years
column2: and there’s a reason “Medicine Noose” and “Nobody Told Me” have become set staples. The manic-depressive “Medicine Noose” is a lumbering behemoth of a song with a thick
column3: patient central riff that promises big and delivers bigger
column4: and the perfectly-executed  “Nobody Told Me” is the best song they’ve written in years
column5: with a perfect riff that's exactly what fans would ask for if Williams
column6: Bower
column7: and the fellas pulled them into the practice space for input. “The Age of Bootcamp” has William wailing like a sick animal atop a familiar punishing groove that
column8: more than anything else
column9: signals that Eyehategod is back
column10: and they aren’t going anywhere.

column1: You’ve got to admire the sheer force of will that has brought Eyehategod to this point. After fourteen years
column2: they’ve come out swinging
column3: armed with yet another of their often-renewed leases on life and still spoiling for a fight. That Eyehategod exists at all is a miracle in and of itself
column4:
but the fact that it is so damn great is simply extraordinary.

"|19381.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19381-eyehategod-eyehategod/|8.0|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20700/homepage_large.345ccda2.jpg|Sea When Absent|5171.0|A Sunny Day in Glasgow|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Lefse']|2014-06-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:12.982530|"

What would shoegaze sound like if it had its eyes on the sky? Over the course of several albums
column2: the intercontinental six-piece A Sunny Day in Glasgow have been toying with an answer to that riddle. Their latest and best record
column3: Sea When Absent
column4: has an atmospheric
column5: bleeding-watercolor quality that makes it sound a little bit like a My Bloody Valentine record if the moodiness and pensiveness were replaced with a feeling of almost violently explosive joy. Beneath dense textures
column6: melodies pop like fireworks. Like their previous albums
column7: Sea When Absent doesn't sound like much else out there; genre tags are only worth mentioning to show how they don't quite fit. It sometimes sounds like a psych record
column8: made not by the kids smoking up behind the bleachers but the most devoted members of the glee club.

column1: Since their freewheeling 2007 debut Scribble Mural Comic Journal
column2: A Sunny Day in Glasgow have flown under the radar
column3: apart from any discernible trends. Until now
column4: their greatest achievement has been their criminally under-heard 2009 album Ashes Grammar
column5: a panoramic collection of pastel-soft dream-pop that moved fluidly between ambient passages and hazy but immaculately structured pop songs like ""Failure"" and ""Passionate Introverts (Dinosaurs)"". Actually
column6: ""passionate introverts"" is a pretty good way to describe at least one member of the band: the guitarist and ostensible leader Ben Daniels
column7: a biostatistician who moved in 2009 from Philadelphia to Australia. ""I am pretty antisocial
column8: he said recently
column9: when asked if he still felt connected to the Philadelphia scene. ""I know that if I were in Philly I'd still mostly be hanging out in my apartment reading books and playing with synthesizers."" That makes sense: Even in its most ambitiously full-screen moments
column10: A Sunny Day in Glasgow's music has a certain bedroom-pop feel. Community often makes for great art
column11: but music as unique and unclassifiable as ASDIG's usually springs from somebody shutting himself in his room and trusting his own weird way of seeing the world.

column1: Ashes Grammar was a sprawling and occasionally drifting record
column2: but Sea When Absent finds the band tightening up their sound just enough
column3: bringing the interlocking vocals of their two singers
column4: Jen Goma and Annie Fredrickson
column5: to the forefront of the mix. For the first time
column6: they've brought on an outside producer
column7: Jeff Zeigler (War on Drugs
column8: Kurt Vile)
column9: and though he's helped clarify their sound
column10: that doesn't come at the expense of complexity. Each song on Sea When Absent structured like a maze: it's easy—and dizzying in the best way—to get lost in its twists and turns. ""The Things They Do to Me"" begins as weightless
column11: space-rock reverie and then abruptly makes a hard left into a more pastoral earth-bound soundscape; ""The Body
column12: It Bends"" pivots between an unassuming acoustic folk tune and a song that ought to have its own laser light show at a planetarium; a towering riff crashes down in the middle of ""Boys Turn Into Girls (Initiation Rites)""
column13: sudden as a summer storm. These tonal shifts are so dynamic that they sound fresh on every listen; you could hear these songs 100 times and they'd still find ways to catch by surprise.

column1: Music that overflows with so many ideas runs the risk of sounding cluttered
column2: but Sea When Absent manages to avoid that pitfall. And that's pretty impressive
column3: given the disjointed way it was recorded: The six members of the band (Daniels
column4: Goma
column5: Fredrickson
column6: drummer Adam Herndon
column7: bassist Ryan Newmyer
column8: and multi-instrumentalist Josh Meakim) are now scattered across Australia
column9: New York
column10: and Philadelphia
column11: and the album came together as they sent each other snippets of songs
column12: with creative decisions made via lengthy group email chains. The result is an album structured in layers with many overlapping ideas
column13: as fragmentary and luminous as light through a prism. The sweetly singsong-y ""MTLOV (Minor Keys)"" has the feel of a round
column14: with Goma and Fredrickson's voices braided into rich harmonies. Then there's the stone-cold gorgeous ""In Love With Useless (The Timeless Geometry in the Tradition of Passing)""
column15: which flirts with moments of dissonance and glitchiness (the pre-chorus sounds like nothing so much as a poorly connected Skype call) only to make the moments of sudden clarity feel that much more satisfying.

column1: When A Sunny Day in Glasgow put out ""In Love With Useless"" as a single
column2: they also released a lyric video for it—which is kind of funny
column3: because they're not exactly a ""lyrics band."" Granted
column4: they've pushed the vocals higher into the mix this time around
column5: but it's usually next to impossible to understand what Goma and Fredrickson are singing. Not that it matters; ASDIG's music is more about the experience of getting blissfully lost in a feeling
column6: and if their music were too literal or word-based it might take you out of that odd
column7: dreamlike state.

column1: ""When Ashes Grammar came out
column2: Daniels recently recalled
column3: ""I thought it was a really loud rock record for a year
column4: and then a friend was like
column5: 'This is really chilled-out and ambient.'"" With Sea When Absent
column6: A Sunny Day in Glasgow have finally made that loud rock record—full of crashing percussion and screaming guitars—but without abandoning the ambiance that makes them so distinct. Sea When Absent has the quality of one of those spectacularly bright summer days when they color in everything seems a little over-saturated
column7: and it induces the same dizzy
column8:
woozy feeling you get after staring directly at the sun. Play it loud enough to see spots.

"|19478.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19478-a-sunny-day-in-glasgow-sea-when-absent/|8.5|Lindsay Zoladz

“I was just an Indiana kid
column2: getting no one in my bed
column3: ” sings Timothy Showalter
column4: a.k.a. Strand of Oaks
column5: “but I had your sweet tunes to play.” That song
column6: mysteriously titled “JM”
column7: recounts long afternoons spent rebelling against his parents
column8: smoking in his car
column9: hating all his friends
column10: and playing JM’s sweet tunes at presumably high volume. The guitars swell and crash around him
column11: then lumber into the kind of crunchy jam that once upon a time had teenage misfits pumping fists or raising lighters in unison. Given that the song is set in Indiana
column12: JM could conceivably be John Mellencamp
column13: the Hoosier rocker laureate who used to sing about such kids
column14: but in fact Showalter has disclosed the song’s true subject: Jason Molina. “JM” is a moving tale of extreme adolescent alienation
column15: alleviated only by the narrator’s identification with a rock hero
column16: in this case one whose locality as a Midwesterner—and sometime Indianan—makes him all the more relatable
column17: more approachable
column18: more real.

column1: “JM” is the lynchpin on Strand of Oaks’ fourth album
column2: HEAL
column3: in that it shows two different versions of Showalter: the angry
column4: potentially violent teen blasting Songs: Ohia and the adult who now knows Molina’s fate. The song’s power lies not only in its barrage of guitars
column5: but in the sad wisdom gleaned from fallen heroes. On all of these songs
column6: Showalter comes across as the kind of character Molina certainly identified with and occasionally wrote about: a blue-collar
column7: dead-end kid with an uncertain future and some darkness in him. HEAL is an album as memoir: stark and at times emotionally harrowing as it recounts with bracing candor the artist’s struggles with friends
column8: family
column9: and most of all himself. The choruses may swoop and soar
column10: the guitars may churn valiantly
column11: but Showalter’s nostalgia for his own past is never rosy. There are still hints of shame and self-loathing in his voice
column12: as though he is still very much the kid he sings about.

column1: “Shame” and “self-loathing” are not words often used to describe great rock records—at least not those made outside the 1990s
column2: when personal darkness became rock’s eventually tiresome subject matter. The songs on HEAL
column3: however
column4: are more than just therapy sessions; in fact
column5: they reveal an idiosyncratic artist rummaging through his memories to find the source of his art. Opener “Goshen '97”
column6: named after Showalter’s hometown in the northern part of the state
column7: describes his first stabs at making music
column8: buying beat-up Casios
column9: “singing Pumpkins in the mirror” and finding his dad’s tape machine. The details are so vivid you hardly mind that he tries to sneak the line
column10: “That’s where the magic began
column11: ” by you. The song describes a lonely kid finding some comfort in music and some camaraderie in his musical idols
column12: so it’s perfectly apt that guitar hero J Mascis (another JM) shreds his way through “Goshen '97”.

column1: HEAL follows the young Showalter through his teenage years and into his twenties
column2: as he becomes
column3: in his own words
column4: “fat
column5: drunk
column6: and mean.” Showalter’s self-assessment can certainly be grizzly (“I was an abomination”)
column7: but he couches everything in vivid scenes: stashing porn under the bed
column8: listening to Sharon Van Etten on his headphones
column9: drinking a jug of wine to summon the courage to ask a girl home. This autobiographical mode is unusual for Showalter
column10: who as Strand of Oaks has not mined his own life for material—at least
column11: not to the extent he does here. Rather than rely on the typical confessional models that inform so much indie-rock and -folk songwriting
column12: his earlier songs addressed subjects that rarely
column13: if ever
column14: get sung about. This is a man who penned a revenge fantasy of Dan Ackroyd torturing John Belushi’s dealer. It’s not that those songs were impersonal; rather
column15: they portrayed him as an artist trying to find his reflection in the mirror of the world.

column1: On HEAL
column2: it’s not just the lyrics that are memoiristic
column3: but the music as well. These songs draw on the pop songs of Showalter’s youth—not just Molina’s epic Americana
column4: but also postpunk synth pop and heavy metal. If Strand of Oaks started as a primarily acoustic folk act
column5: it has morphed into something very different. There is lots of pre-grunge guitar on here: some actual shredding and soloing
column6: albeit no showboating. Synths play a much larger role on HEAL
column7: especially on the neon-lit title track and on “Same Emotions”
column8: with its video-game solo on the coda. It’s a way for Showalter to map his own past musically
column9: to fit his memories with a soundtrack based on what might have been playing when he bought that first keyboard or asked that girl out.

column1: There’s a rawness to HEAL
column2: a damaged quality to the music
column3: as though Showalter—who played almost all of the instruments—recorded everything in the old Goshen basement with his first rickety keyboards. The title track burbles with beats and synths that might be described “postpunk” or “motorik”
column4: but really they just sound like a guy fucking around with a Casio. That only makes the whoa-oa-oa’s on “Woke Up to the Light” and closer “Wait for Love” sound too easy
column5: an obvious means of conveying gravity and implying transcendence. Such moments are too similar to the wordless anthemizing of Coldplay
column6: which makes them too public and too current; they break the spell. As a result
column7: the album loses some of its urgency
column8: its specificity
column9:
and its narrative thrust as it progresses. But that won’t matter to the angry kid who discovers HEAL and blasts it in his own car. 

"|19536.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19536-strand-of-oaks-heal/|7.9|Stephen M. Deusner

It’s great to have a shortcut to inner calm
column3: and M. Geddes Gengras' latest release
column4: Ishi
column5: possesses that functionality. The experimental artist's new LP comes off of the two avant-reggae albums he recorded with Sun Araw and Jamaican legends the Congos
column6: as well as last year’s Collected Works Vol. 1 The Moog Years
column7: a collection of compositions for modular synthesizer that existed somewhere in between John Carpenter’s creepiest film scores and the more electronics-based parts of last year’s compilation I Am The Center: Private Issue New Age Music In America 1950-1990.

column1: Ishi finds Gengras continuing to take cues from the latter comparison point: its three tracks flow into each other subtly enough to qualify as passages rather than discrete songs
column2: building and releasing with a patient determination. The music moves unhurriedly from moment to moment in a way that traces the clear outline a strong compositional foundation
column3: producing an atmosphere that's both serene and substantial.

column1: It’s tempting to call Ishi ambient music
column2: but it possesses too much presence to fade into the background. It possesses an insistence that just stops short of dominating your attention. Although Gengras’ current mode relies heavily on slow-attack synth pads
column3: he frequently works in dissonant leads and unexpectedly harsh tones that can disrupt the peaceful mood you might find yourself lulled into. It’s a soothing record
column4: but one that’ll still keep you on your toes.

column1: Combined with the rich synthesizer sounds that Gengras comes up with
column2: that serene quality means Ishi is a good record to keep handy (along with a pair of good headphones). It's a sonically dense record
column3: with deep
column4: sustained low end and deft arrangements that are complicated but not cluttered. The bass lines move at whale-song pace throughout
column5: above which bits of melody—flickering clusters of sequenced notes
column6: sounds that resemble synthesized wind—fade in and out hypnogogically.

column1: Ishi is remarkably well designed to block out the world around you. The serene energy it gives off it makes for an effective psychic refuge—put it on in a train station during rush hour and it immediately begins to block out the atmospheric anxiety hovering over the crowd
column2: like an umbrella against the rain. The headspace it produces is calming but frequently
column3: dreamily surreal
column4:
and it often seems like a better place to live than the world outside it.

If Jobriath didn’t exist
column2: someone would’ve had to invent him a serio-comic off-Broadway musical about him. A classically trained pianist
column3: AWOL soldier
column4: male prostitute
column5: fledgling West Coast folksinger
column6: cast member of Hair
column7: psychiatric-hospital patient
column8: and an openly gay man at a time when even hippy-prescribed free love had its boundaries
column9: the Pennsylvania army brat born Bruce Campbell had already lived several script-worthy lives even before his fateful 1972 encounter with music-biz mogul Jerry Brandt. Under the former Carly Simon manager's tutelage
column10: Campbell—then already performing under the name Jobriath Boone—was reborn as a mononymmed glamboyant androgyne who made even David Bowie seem timid by comparison.

column1: However
column2: Jobriath’s story proved to be a tragic textbook case of how fame cannot be automatically attained through six-figure record contracts and Times Square billboard campaigns alone—particularly amid a musical mainstream not exactly tolerant of heterosexual rockers in high heels
column3: let alone an unabashedly queer one. After two lavishly produced but woefully underselling albums
column4: Jobriath’s star had flamed out as quickly as it had ignited. Consigned to the Chelsea lounge-singer circuit
column5: his profile would sink so low that
column6: as legend has it
column7: when ardent admirer Morrissey tried to book Jobriath to open his 1992 Your Arsenal tour
column8: even he didn’t know that Campbell had been dead for nearly a decade
column9: a casualty of the early '80s AIDS outbreak.

column1: Thanks in part to Moz’s ardent boosterism
column2: Jobriath has
column3: over the past decade
column4: been elevated from glam-rock also-ran/laughingstock into a mini-cottage-industry
column5: with Rhino reissues of his discography and a recent documentary
column6: Jobriath A.D.
column7: testifying to his enduring influence on everyone from Def Leppard belter Joe Elliott to performance artist Ann Magnuson (who recently crowd-funded an EP inspired by his life and songs). However
column8: As the River Flows adds an intriguing new dimension to his limited recorded legacy. So much of the Jobriath mythos is defined by grandiosity—the fantastical fashions
column9: the balcony-pitched pomp-rock overtures
column10: the titanic hype
column11: the spectacular failure. But as a collection of previously unreleased recordings made in 1971
column12: prior to his Brandt-engineered makeover
column13: As the River Flows presents an uncharacteristically intimate
column14: unvarnished portrait of Jobriath finding his voice and persona
column15: and shows how his considerable charm and magnetism—not to mention his killer piano skills—shine through with blinding radiance even in the absence of a major-label-bankrolled recording budget.

column1: Though often labeled the “American Bowie
column2: ” Jobriath was actually more like Elton John
column3: had the latter’s lyrical concerns been as outrageous as his outfits. The elements at play on As the River Flows—a mix of showtune sass
column4: gospelized soul
column5: and Aquarian-age hippy-dippy jam-rock—were hardly subversive for their time
column6: and much of this album would sidle up snugly alongside Elton’s “Take Me to the Pilot” on your mom’s favorite golden-oldies station. But then
column7: Jobriath was the sort of singer who could raise eyebrows just by showing up and talking about his day. In contrast to
column8: say
column9: the sci-fi-inspired narratives of Ziggy Stardust
column10: Jobriath sings frankly and non-chalantly about his routine habits—the pill-popping
column11: the cross-dressing
column12: the cock-sucking—with larger-than-life panache. And that charisma becomes all the more outsized when the recordings are stripped down to just voice and piano: the ivory-tickled “Wildfire in Memphis” is a male-hustler travelogue analogous to Lou Reed’s drug-copping odysseys on “Waiting for the Man”
column13: with Jobriath gamely rendering transactional sex as sport: “I know the name of every pick-up bar in town… do you?” Even more captivating is the early attempt at “I’m a Man”
column14: which would eventually get gussied-up for Jobriath’s 1973 self-titled Elektra release
column15: but is presented here as a dying-embered torch song
column16: its gender-bending sentiments (“I’m a man
column17: yeah
column18: I’m an elegant man/ satin bows and open toes are what I am”) delivered with an unflinching toughness that fleshes out the skeletal arrangement with full-blooded fervor.

column1: The appearance of “I’m a Man” here alongside fellow Elektra-era holdover “Inside” inevitably casts As the River Flows as a rough sketch for the more ostentatious music to come
column2: while freewheeling—and ultimately directionless—full-band guitar workouts like “Amazing Dope Tales” and “Ducky Lullaby” betray how much Jobriath benefited from Brandt and future producer Eddie Kramer’s direction and discipline. (Though one has to wonder if Jobriath’s fortunes could’ve turned out differently had the perfect-on-arrival space-bound lullaby “Little Dreamer” been re-recorded for his debut.) But on its own modest terms
column3: As the River Flows feels less like a proto-glam-rock artifact and more like an urbane companion piece to the recently reissued 1973 debut album from Lavender Country
column4: another record that cast the often-unforgiving gay experience of the time in a whimsical light
column5: coaxing humour out of hopelessness. Just as Patrick Haggerty built himself a homo-honky-tonk utopia on his band’s namesake theme song
column6:
Jobriath valiantly valorizes the hard-knock life on As the River Flows' graceful power-ballad standout “City Freak”—the sort of defiant outsider anthem that suggests Jobriath didn’t necessarily need to see his face plastered on Broadway skyscrapers to feel like he was on top of the world. 

"|19489.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19489-jobriath-as-the-river-flows/|7.5|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20710/homepage_large.a16fca86.jpg|Into Unknown Depths|32326.0|Harassor|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dais']|2014-06-24 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:15.401631|"

Harassor are a rare gem glinting up malevolently from one of Los Angeles’ countless dark corners. The band was formed back in 2002
column2: and after more than a decade of dues-paying and hell-raising
column3: they've finally started attracting attention for their savage extreme metal hybrid. 2011 saw their inclusion on Southern Lord’s well-received Power of the Riff compilation
column4: and two full-lengths later
column5: Dais came calling to secure the rights for the trio’s fourth LP. The venerable experimental/noise label and the regressive-minded metal band seem like an odd coupling
column6: but both parties seem chuffed with the arrangement and the result of their pairing speaks for itself. Into Unknown Depths is a delightfully dynamic approach to extreme metal’s usual grim-faced presentation. No two songs sound alike
column7: but each one sounds deadly.

column1: Harassor have been around the block and peeked behind the curtain
column2: but remain sworn to the dark. Despite the band’s intentionally lo-fi
column3: almost primitive take on its chosen genre
column4: the band personnel is about as far from the basement-dwelling black metal stereotype as one can get. Between the three of them
column5: this gang cuts their time between several other projects (Lord Time
column6: Lord Foul
column7: Moonknight)
column8: oversee operations at famed vinyl mecca Amoeba Records
column9: and peddle poison with the their own Rising Beast and Universal Consciousness labels. Their sound is tough and unwelcoming
column10: based heavily in black metal
column11: death/doom
column12: and thrash’s salad days.

column1: Harassor’s habit of cherry-picking riffs and patterns from all three genres makes for compelling listening
column2: as does the sheer amount of technical know-how deployed on these pitch-black compositions. With the caustic Pete Majors on the mic and the intimidatingly powerful Sandor GF holding down behind the kit
column3: James “Roach” Brown III has the ideal settings to show off plenty of light-fingered fretwork while wrangling the wild array of riffs he’s conjured. Despite the lack of bass
column4: the guitar tone on Into Unknown Depths is a force to be reckoned with
column5: thanks to a particularly clever set up and some help from a famous friend: Brown tunes his E string down to A
column6: running the whole unholy racket through a mammoth Peavey tube amp and one of doom legend Wino’s very own cabinets. That rumbling range comes in handy on lumbering death/doom cuts like the churning mid-tempo opener “Nine of Swords” or the perverse Incantation-biting riff that drives the ultra heavy “Unknown Depths”. “Increased Decay” lives up to its name by starting off with a straightforward black metal maneuver and unexpectedly breaking down into an elephantine doom riff at the halfway point.

column1: Harassor are adept at slow-burning death/doom (and the opening chords on “Devoured by Time” make for an inadvertent throwback to Sound of Perseverance-era Death)
column2: but they’re great at thrashy
column3: punked-up black metal. They take a more traditional route with the grim
column4: tremolo-fueled tension and flickering double bass of “Frozen Soil” and foggy
column5: depressive Finnish bent of “Winter’s Triumph”
column6: but are at their best when they inject a little rock’n’roll into the proceedings. The choppy punk beat
column7: hyper-aggressive vintage Darkthrone feel
column8: and snarled opening of “Die Forever” and swaggering black’n’roll stomp of “M.D.P.” make for album highlights alongside “Strangulated”
column9: which sees Pete Majors’ acidic vocals take the wheel for a quick and punk-infected two minute hate. The gloriously filthy blackened punk of “The Harassor” makes for a brilliantly self-aware anthem to carry the album through to its bitter end via raucous parting shot “Purest Hate.” It’s a satisfying conclusion to an uncommonly good album; with Into Unknown Depths
column10:
Harassor have wrought the first bloody signs of Armageddon upon the City of Angels.

How to Dress Well is a project that Tom Krell conducts with a particularly modern transparency: the music he shares is meant to illuminate the music that he makes. His most recent Soundcloud mixtapes
column3: No Words to Say and I Think Life Might Be Elsewhere (Hungover Mix)
column4: were heavy on what we’ve come to expect from him—along with his own work in progress
column5: we’d hear a very specific set of influences
column6: mostly R&B and hip-hop
column7: high/lowbrow dichotomies accepted by indie culture such as Lou Reed and Miley Cyrus
column8: Young Thug
column9: and GG Allin. But late last year
column10: early 2000s emo acts like the Starting Line
column11: Taking Back Sunday and Saves the Day started to infiltrate
column12: and surely he was trying to tell us why these bands speak to him. Whether it’s Chief Keef or Chris Conley
column13: Krell is informed by genre but driven by expression; in his mind
column14: pop music is anything that aspires for the most immediate and impactful connection
column15: even if it risks embarrassment in the process. As a result
column16: his transcendent third LP ""What Is This Heart?"" is a pop album of the highest caliber.

column1: It’s easy to be skeptical
column2: as he once treated mainstream music like an academic—pop rendered as ambient and insular experiences. His 2010 debut Love Remains didn't sound like anything else and still doesn’t
column3: as if William Basinski’s The Disintegration Loops were filled with cuts from early '90s R&B. Its follow-up Total Loss was sleek and solemn salon-soul
column4: interpolating Ashanti but still modeled by outré
column5: experimental artists ranging from Proem to Forest Swords to Steve Reich. The dubious term “indie R&B” already projected a degree of otherness on a white man in a primary black genre
column6: and Krell’s egghead influences and agamous lyrics gave his detractors plenty of additional dirt.

column1: But even in 2010
column2: it should’ve been fairly obvious that grad students and grade schoolers alike can dream of being Michael Jackson
column3: Bobby Brown or Beyoncé. Krell told us recently
column4: “I want my music to be pop
column5: but not populist—I want to be #1 on Billboard
column6: but I want to do it on my own terms.” Previously
column7: that might’ve smacked of indie defeatism
column8: of wanting to be admired for sticking to his guns by contrasting it against an impossible scenario.<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column9: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> But in 2014
column10: unique and truly weird polyglot R&B/pop records like Beyoncé
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">
column12: Channel Orange
column13: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> and Kaleidoscope Dream
column14: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">have achieved runaway commercial
column15: critical
column16: and artistic success. It’s completely within Krell’s rights to ask
column17: “why not me?”

column1: So
column2: here
column3: Krell lets the music catch up with his extroverted candor
column4: combining emotional risk and artistic confidence to figure out just how far How to Dress Well can go while retaining the project's essence. In retrospect
column5: Krell’s albums sound as tentative and sketchbook as his mixtapes
column6: as nearly everything on “What Is This Heart?” is a bolder
column7: more accomplished version of what came before. ""2 Years On (Shame Dream)” reiterates Krell's taste for unseemly reverie
column8: as a car ride with his family turns both surreal and hyperreal
column9: its ache presented in startling clarity—Tracy Chapman may have been on his mind as a starting point for bare
column10: acoustic folk
column11: but he needed to cover the uber-emo “At Your Funeral” over a Crash of Rhinos instrumental on his Hungover Mix to realize he was capable of doing it. “What You Wanted” pressurizes the subdued militance and tension of “Cold Nites” and releases it in the monstrous
column12: pitch-shifted vocals that deface “Face Again”. The orchestral ambitions of the Just Once EP and the redlining distortion of Love Remains are removed from their headphone-intended origins and given concert hall ambience on “Pour Cyril"".

column1: The stylistic range of “What Is This Heart?” lends credence to Krell’s “pop
column2: but not populist” ambitions—if he was to make a superproducer-per-song
column3: blockbuster album
column4: this is how it would likely turn out. However
column5: Rodaidh McDonald returns to produce and retains the stained glass sound of Total Loss: bright
column6: translucent
column7: and nowhere near as brittle as it may first appear. More importantly
column8: Krell’s voice is made the focal point rather than a texture. His singing can be parodied at this point
column9: meaning that it's something established as clearly his own: demonstrative and inclusive as good karaoke
column10: not performative in a way that’s meant to be judged. It’s spiritual
column11: though more borne of a monastic purity than a specific religion. And now
column12: it’s only distorted as a signature punctuation rather than using the effect as a white-out slather.

column1: Krell makes it known that he's got chops

column4: breathless coo reverbed and distended to emulate an emotive
column5: showstopping guitar solo. L.A. Reid should’ve desperately tried to smuggle the effervescent disco-pop of “Repeat Pleasure” onto Xscape and if there was every a doubt that a HTDW song could be a legitimate smash hit rather than a deconstruction of one
column6: there’s the arena-R&B of “Precious Love”

column8: unexpected key change that lasts about ten seconds just to stunt.

column1: In the true spirit of How to Dress Well

column4: to relate” on ""Precious Love"". Meanwhile
column5: the spirit of “Very Best Friend” is so plainspoken and eternal that it has to be some roller rink obscurity from his youth
column6: the source of which Krell is keeping from us all.

column1: For the duration of How to Dress Well’s existence
column2: Krell’s obsessive devotion to pop music has served as a connection he can trust
column3: as he lowers himself into the depths of unanswerable questions about spirituality and death. While that love remains
column4: Krell’s breakthrough on ""What Is This Heart?"" is a staggering paradox: as long as he holds onto that tether
column5: he’ll probably never get to the bottom.

column1: While Krell is sometimes still that college freshman listening to Jimmy Eat World with a “Childhood Faith in Love”
column2: he writes about love like the philosophy Ph.D. student that he is—much of this album recognizes a pop cultural paradigm where love is presented as a panacea
column3: the single most important thing a person can acquire. But the problem is that it’s so often conveyed through consumer products that love becomes one itself—something meant to be obtained
column4: consumed
column5: and replaced
column6: a simple prop to occupy one’s time.

column1: Krell recognizes his own complicitly in this situation both as a human and as someone who makes pop songs in How to Dress Well. The first words of “Words I Don’t Remember” are
column2: distressingly
column3: “You know that I love you
column4: baby”
column5: and he confesses with palpable guilt
column6: ""Said 'it was you' for the rest of our lives""
column7: referring to the joyous centerpiece of Total Loss.  “& It Was U” was indicative of how the brief flickers of happiness on past HTDW albums only served to remind you of the surrounding
column8: oppressive presence of death and depression. Though ""What Is This Heart?"" is by far Krell’s lightest
column9: most melodic album
column10: his lyrics are constantly prodding at a pervasive societal problem: a mistrust of intimacy
column11: fear of legitimate connection
column12: the idea of romance as a competitive sport.

column1: But if you think this is some kind of grad-level treatise
column2: remember that the title of this album is phrased as a question. Krell’s pain and pleasure is borne of in situ struggle—do you say just what you want and when you want it in pursuit of an honest relationship
column3: knowing that your most honest moments can be wicked? That’s the cruel irony at the center of “Repeat Pleasure”
column4: where the title doesn't instantly reveal its cynical view of sex. What initially sounds like a glittery valentine becomes a ""Dear John""-in-waiting
column5: as Krell realizes our tendencies to get caught up in routine:""I say there's no one above you/ But now there's a new place above that line.…Even if you're holding on for something unchanging/ And once you got it you'll want something else."" “What You Wanted” similarly provokes people who see others' hot love and emotion fade rather than continuing endlessly and assume that the same won't happen to them: ""Said I know that I want it/ Know that as soon as I've got it/ It'll change
column6: I'll hate it.""  Later
column7: on ""A Power""
column8: Krell seeks sympathy and serenity rather than carnality; during a tribal
column9: percussive breakdown and his most intense vocal performance
column10: he sings with desperate joy
column11: that if he doesn't share his desire to ""loved and lost in all directions""
column12: he'll be sucked into
column13: ""dark
column14: silence and the void"".

column1: Similar to Ezra Koenig
column2: Krell can be the smartest guy in the room by having the best questions and the least amount of answers
column3: and ""What is This Heart?"" does share important commonalities with the intellectually sound spiritual awakening of Modern Vampires of the City—their creators have always met their dull accusations of appropriation head on

column5: y’know

The cover of the Copenhagen band Lower's 2012 EP
column2: Walk on Heads
column3: featured vocalist Adrian Toubro
column4: head shaved
column5: singing dramatically in a live setting. Its look and feel was reminiscent of an early hardcore 7""
column6: and the music itself possessed a similar kind of fury. Their full-length debut
column7: Seek Warmer Climes
column8: features a more romantic
column9: refined image of a man in white lounging in the dirt
column10: announcing a shift in Lower's sound. (The photo was taken by Lower bassist Kristian Emdal
column11: who plays in Vår with Iceage's Elias Bender Rønnenfelt
column12: and who also did the cover art for Iceage's You're Nothing.) They're still noisy
column13: but this time around they're focusing more on the jagged
column14: wordy music you could easily term as ""post-punk"".

column1: The thing you'll notice first on Seek is the growth in Toubro's approach. He croons
column2: and sighs
column3: and doesn't shout as often. He possesses a writerly approach—the vocal lines often ramble and collide with the music as if he wants to cram in as many syllables as possible regardless of what the rest of the band is doing. His delivery smacks of the type of vocalists that gravitate towards new wave and death rock (and he somewhat resembles Bryan Ferry at times
column4: too).

column1: Lower aren't making pop songs
column2: but the best songs here have hooks. The central motif and narrative of opener ""Another Life"" (""Strive for another life/ Open your arms/ Invite it inside/ I'll show you what it takes to stay balanced"")
column3: along with Toubro's upbeat clip
column4: makes for a potent salvo; that energy continues onto the second track
column5: ""Dart Persuasion""
column6: which pairs rabid drumming with another nice central repetition that would fit well in a manifesto: ""For all the tragic scars of your past/ You pointed out/ With an eye pinned to your navel/ Should I be shocked to the core/ By your rigmarole/ Your snivelling narration.""

column1: ""Lost Weight
column2: Perfect Skin"" possesses a plastic surgery metaphor that comes across as ponderous
column3: but it possesses enough fire to match the sarcastic
column4: cutting sentiments within: ""Lost weight
column5: perfect skin/ Will bring the torment to an end/ Put the smile back on my lips."" The album's first single
column6: ""Soft Option""
column7: is another good example of Lower in the zone
column8: bringing in Morrissey-like background vocals with serrated guitars.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Seek can drag in a way that this kind of music shouldn't. ""Unkempt
column3: Uncaring"" echoes its title in its loose construction and doesn't leave much of impression; elsewhere
column4: the grand cacophony of ""Bastard Tactics"" and ""Craver"" don't amount to much more than that clatter. That said
column5: even in Seek Warmer Climes' less impactful tracks
column6: there are glimmering moments
column7: and it's a testement to Lower that it's hard to discount any of the songs in their entirety.

column1: Befitting such a curious band
column2: the best song on Seek Warmer Climes is the longest
column3: and the one that features accompaniment by two cellos. The 7-minute ""Expanding Horizons (Dar es Salaam)"" is about Toubro traveling to Tanzani in 2009 to work at an orphanage and finding that the religiousness of the place conflicted with his own change-the-world idealism. He left
column4: moved around Africa
column5: was almost kidnapped in Dar Es Salaam
column6: and so on. ""Expanding Horizons"" opens with him singing
column7: ""Here I stand/ On foreign land/ Expanding horizons/ Though nothing seems to match my fantasies/ I'm living a dream""
column8: and the song itself offers the spaciousness of travel. It's patient
column9: open
column10: and the build feels earned. When he repeats ""caress yourself"" a few dozen times toward the end
column11: you want him to keep going with that brief
column12: very effective phrase.

column1: It may not be fair
column2: but it feels necessary regardless to acknowledge that fellow Danish punks
column3: and associates
column4: Iceage have cast a large shadow that all young Danish punk bands are measured against. That group's 2011 debut New Brigade still feels like the perfect encapsulation of the scene's overall aesthetic
column5: and Lower strike me as the other Danish group from that scene who have it in them to reach those heights. Toubro has said that ""every song on [Seek Warmer Climes] deals in some way with personal development
column6: be it emotional or cosmetic. How to act in different social contexts
column7: and to acclimatize oneself into a given situation without losing face."" With that in mind
column8: the occasional sense of compositional confusion makes sense: even if it doesn't always result in a thrilling listen
column9:
Seek Warmer Climes captures a promising band in transition.

After decades of vilification
column2: disco began to gain traction in the culture once again in the early 21st century. Thanks to the productions from the likes of Daniel Wang and Metro Area
column3: a new wave of indie rock acts and DJs began to embrace the tropes of the genre. LCD Soundsystem
column4: !!!
column5: and Out Hud used those rubbery basslines and tireless drums for their own productions
column6: as did folks like Lindstrøm
column7: Prins Thomas
column8: and Todd Terje. But despite this renaissance for the hedonistic
column9: dance-til-10 a.m. pleasures of the form
column10: a crucial aspect was being whitewashed out of this nu-disco revival: its inherent queerness. Some nights out felt like the clubs depicted in Whit Stillman’s The Last Days of Disco: straight
column11: white
column12: and well-lit
column13: with very little dancing involved.

column1: Enter the four hirsute bears behind Horse Meat Disco: James Hillard
column2: Jim Stanton
column3: Severino
column4: and Luke Howard
column5: whose logo featured a five-legged horse and who have hosted a Sunday residency in south London once dubbed “the queer party for everyone.” That party has since expanded into residencies in other countries and there have been four compilations that have followed. The first
column6: released in 2009
column7: was a delirious mix of astral
column8: flute-trilled beatitude from the likes of Karen Young’s “Deetour” and the Smokey Robinson track that got aired at Paradise Garage. Throughout the series
column9: there’s been an emphasis on histrionic divas at their shrillest registers
column10: polyester-bright synths
column11: and symphonic strings so gaudy that Liberace might blush. More importantly
column12: HMD helped move the disco appreciation away from rockists and back towards its guiltiest of pleasures.

column1: There’s little left for the DJ crew to prove with the fourth installment of their mix compilations for Strut
column2: but that doesn’t mean that IV fails to please. If anything
column3: it clarifies that when it comes to crafting dance mixes
column4: Horse Meat Disco find a way to stretch out
column5: queue up the campiest of disco cuts from their shelves and wring the most aural pleasure out of them
column6: whether they’re from the dollar bin or in the triple digits.

column1: “Get yo hands off of my man!” a woman shrieks at the start of IV
column2: and a steady tamborine rattle lead into Opal’s early '80s cut
column3: “Ain’t No Way
column4: ” featuring two women fighting over their man. Cheesy
column5: sure
column6: but then the track suddenly reduces to an electronic trickle as a catfight breaks out and a bottle breaks
column7: landing somewhere between boogie and acid house. A macho chant of “Misaluba” with an Italo backdrop rises next.

column1: In HMD's brawny hands
column2: past and present slide together
column3: but the DJs aren’t afraid to take detours and have the mix drop from a boil to simmer. Joey Negro’s Sunburst Band's tough yet funky “Taste the Groove” hails from 2013

column7: it still thrills. The octave-jumping synth line that keeps scaling higher and higher is near delirium on a dancefloor

column1: My favorite stretch on this mix is when Gwen Guthrie’s sampled voice coos “I’m in love with you” on Phreek Plus One’s “La Spirale”. Her voice—originally heard on the Padlock EP (mixed by Larry Levan and a staple of the Paradise Garage in the mid-'80s)—now appears as a 2012 nu-disco track by an Italian trio. Remixed by former !!!/Out Hud bassist/sound alchemist-turned-producer Justin Vandervolgen
column2: it features eddies of echo and tingling windchimes
column3: all of which leads into a dubbed-out horn line that seems to blare from ""The Love Boat""’s white leather lounge. More recent delights follow from new artists like Chicago’s Shahid Mustaf MC and last year’s single from (deep breath) J. Boogie’s Dubtronic Science featuring the Pimps of Joytime. There are various iterations of “Love” that rise and fall in this mix

column5: straight or gay
column6:
Horse Meat Disco makes sure that love is always the message.

It speaks to Dan Melchior’s staggering prolificacy that Hunger
column2: the new album by his Dan Melchior und Das Menace project
column3: is made up of scraps. Culled from a pot of previously unused tracks Melchior has recorded over the past few years since adopting the Das Menace moniker
column4: the record erratically pins down his singular vision of art-damaged garage-rock. It’s a wormhole he’s been wandering down with increasing crookedness since his start in the 1990s as a more straightforward protégé of Billy Childish
column5: but on Hunger
column6: Melchior’s fractured
column7: punk-and/or-folk attack both helps and hinders his cause.

column1: Melchior hasn’t hidden his adoration of Mark E. Smith lately
column2: and a similar Dadaist scowl informs “A Wizard Doesn’t Need a Computer” and “Robotic Footprints”. The former stabs at a synthesizer until it emits a klaxon whine; the latter runs a beatbox through what might be Melchior’s own innards. Fragments of poetic nonsense are ground into chants. They’re fun
column3: but Das Menace isn’t able to summon enough of the Fall’s seething loathing of logic to push them over the edge.

column1: On the other end of the outsider spectrum
column2: “Birdz” and “Parakeet”—the unifying theme can’t be accidental—find Melchior putting on his Syd Barrett outfit
column3: stumbling through drifting zones of folk-saturated psychedelia and fields of diseased paisley. Melchior’s acid-troubadour inclinations are more convincingly heartfeltl; as a man who covered Jandek in the recent past
column4: he takes one more step in that direction on Hunger by delivering a beautiful rendition of Kevin Ayers’ “Town Feeling”
column5: beefing up the original’s imagistic haze with a “Be My Baby” beat and snarls of invasive guitar. It nests neatly in the territory between Melchior’s lust for ogre-like rock and his love of the elfin loner.

column1: Garage rock rears its homely head on just a handful of Hunger’s songs
column2: and it’s a welcome break from the disc’s less focused experiments. Like a cave painting converted into sound
column3: “Rip It To Pieces” harks back to Melchior’s Childish-influenced roots with his prior band the Broke Revue
column4: hurls boulder-sized riffs and blown-out fuzz backward toward the Stone Age. “Gonna rip it to pieces/ Gonna drop it in feces/ You’re an endangered species/ ’Til my anger decreases”
column5: he howls as his voice and guitar bleed together into a gritty
column6: joyous paste of hate. That punk catharsis finds a cleaner
column7: catchier vessel in the form of the album’s title track
column8: the closest Hunger comes to a pop moment. But on this record
column9: Melchior proves skittish; every time the surroundings start to feel approachable
column10: Melchior trawls a proto-metal groove
column11: as he does on “Dungeon Blues”
column12: or lapses into a murky
column13: spoken-word trance
column14: which renders the hooks of “Spooky Eyes” pretty much moot.

column1: There’s another reason behind Hunger’s gnarled chaos: Melchior didn’t pick the songs. John Dwyer of Thee Oh Sees—a kindred spirit if Melchior ever had one—is the album’s curator as well as its patron
column2: since it's being released on Dwyer’s Castle Face imprint. Dwyer’s ear for off-kilter garage-rock is impeccable
column3: but here he deals from a mixed deck. The tracks only barely hinge together with none of the hushed cohesion of Melchior’s last full-length
column4: 2012’s The Backward Path. Granted
column5: a specific mood
column6: if not a concept per se
column7: was guiding that earlier record.

column1: Melchior’s wife
column2: Letha Melchior Rodman—a guitarist of the unjustly overlooked '90s indie-rock outfit Ruby Falls as well the occasional bassist in Melchior’s band—has been battling cancer since 2010
column3: and The Backward Path was suffused with the couple’s quiet
column4: intimate struggle. In a way
column5: Hunger is also colored by that situation; it’s partly an effort to raise funds for Melchior Rodman’s medical treatment. The songs themselves don’t dwell on or directly address that
column6: though—which helps make Hunger feel fiercely if unevenly urgent
column7:
in more ways than one.

When the duo of Matteah Baim and CocoRosie’s Sierra Casady released their debut album as the Metallic Falcons
column3: 2006's Desert Doughnuts
column4: it seemed to signal the beginning of a vibrant new collaboration. Instead
column5: the Metallic Falcons project went dormant
column6: their lone album a fascinating one-off artifact. A captivating and inscrutable combination of shoegaze textures
column7: obscure art-rock flourishes
column8: and Southwestern desert ambiance
column9: Desert Doughnuts was the type of album that seemed specially tailored to one day become a cult favorite. (Fittingly
column10: Fred Armisen recently included Desert Doughnuts on
column13: 00.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a list of criminally underrated music.)

column1: In the interim
column2: Matteah Baim has since released two atmospheric solo albums
column3: each with a different group of backing musicians
column4: neither of which sounded much like Desert Doughnuts or even much specifically like each other. Falling Theater
column5: her third solo album and first since 2009’s <i>Laughing Boy
column6: doesn’t really evoke the Metallic Falcons’ soundscape either
column7: but it does find Baim in full command of her emerging skills as a songwriter and performer. Featuring a top-notch group of collaborators
column8: including Antony Hegarty and MGMT’s James Richardson
column9: Falling Theater is Baim’s most full-bodied and cohesive solo work to date
column10: and perhaps the first in her catalog that might someday rival Desert Doughnuts in its cult appeal.

column1: Baim’s most crucial collaborator on Falling Theater is veteran arranger/composer Maxim Moston
column2: who has previously worked with such artists as Antony and the Johnsons
column3: Rufus Wainwright
column4: and William Basinski. Moston’s arrangements here bring a sumptuous depth of field to Baim’s gentle songs
column5: calling to mind the late Robert Kirby’s work with Vashti Bunyan or Shelagh McDonald; his touch is an ideal match for Baim’s increasingly expressive vocals
column6: and such tracks as the gorgeous “All Night” or “Blossom” are packed with subtle but unexpected instrumental shades and turns. Baim’s style as a songwriter is folk-like and direct
column7: and though her songs typically lack oversized choruses her discreet melodies do find a way of grabbing hold.

column1: In addition to her musical work
column2: Baim is also a talented visual artist
column3: and Falling Theater reportedly draws inspiration from the slow decay of America’s ornate pre-war movie theaters
column4: as depicted on Lauren Dukoff’s album artwork and the work of photographer Matt Lambros.  Although the album’s lyrics are generally too oblique to reflect this inspiration directly
column5: there is a romantic sense of fading opulence in these songs
column6: evoking quiet evenings spent in theaters baroque and lavish enough to have once been referred to as movie palaces. Nevertheless
column7: Baim’s simple
column8: haiku-like lyrics (“Peach tree in moonlight
column9: can I stand like you tonight”) give little away
column10: but tend to involve those moments in life where you turn your full attention to an otherwise overlooked detail.

column1: One common thread that courses throughout Baim’s music has been her deliberate use of space and silence. The Metallic Falcons used open spaces in their music to conjure the vast nighttime desert
column2: while Baim’s earlier solo works featured moments of silence that could sometimes translate as hesitation
column3: as though the performers weren’t entirely sure where to follow the music next. On Falling Theater
column4: Baim’s use of dynamic space feels much more balanced and strategic
column5: as when the hushed “Familiar Way” briefly descends into a shimmering wordless drone that extends itself into circular chime of “Blindman’s Hands"". And on delicate pieces such as “Dude” or “Good For Two
column6: ” Baim’s duet with Antony Hegarty
column7: she is able to achieve a sweet date-night intimacy before allowing the songs to dissipate into the night like spent neon from the marquee.

column1: The deftness of her touch
column2: coupled with Moston’s thoughtful arrangements
column3: gives the album such a seamless quality that its individual tracks can sound almost jarring when isolated from one another. Fortunately
column4: given its brief length (8 tracks in an EP-like 25 minutes) and considerable musical charms
column5: Falling Theater is a listening experience that seems designed for easy repetition
column6:
ready to be queued up again before the house lights have a chance to come up. 

"|19474.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19474-matteah-baim-falling-theater/|7.6|Matthew Murphy

The Knife’s tour behind last year's Shaking the Habitual was
column5: depending on who you ask
column6: one of two things: that Emma Goldman quote about dance and revolution put into radical
column7: sweat-all-night action and tricked out with top-notch lights and choreography
column8: or a canned and confusing mess of lip-synching and interpretive dance
column9: an expression of social justice as told by the cast of The Best Christmas Pageant Ever. This probably had as much to do with your stance on Shaking the Habitual as your spot in the crowd
column10: because from Silent Shout on
column11: the Knife have commanded a massive fanbase who have been waiting almost a decade to finally see them live. Shaken-Up Versions
column12: an album of the remixes taken from the tour's setlist
column13: makes a serviceable substitute for the live experience
column14: and it's also a fine snapshot of where the Knife’s music is at right now: often challenging
column15: at times a little frustrating
column16: but at its core a thrilling body of work.

column1: Like most live albums
column2: the material captured on Shaken-Up Versions loses something when taken offstage
column3: since choreography and charged atmosphere is lost in the transition from arena to wax. Fortunately
column4: these remixes don’t need context. Shaking the Habitual
column5: like the theoretical texts it cites
column6: often seems like it’s been praised and referenced more than listened to in full
column7: so it would have been easy for the Knife to aim for easy accessibility—but the reworks rarely smack of obviousness. On record
column8: “Without You My Life Would Be Boring” possessed one of the stronger hooks on Shaking the Habitual—a quietly nagging synth line
column9: percussion like rattling speakers
column10: gonzo humor
column11: and the rallying cry: “What if we can’t make it/ But we say that we can?”—but the Shaken-Up version takes things in a more challenging direction by puréeing the hooks and pushing the dissonant flutes and vox up front. Without a live crowd to prompt you
column12: the remix is paradoxically easier to be studied than danced to
column13: but it’s the Knife
column14: so the polyrhythms and layers give you lots to work with.

column1: The remixes collected on Shaken-Up Versions aren't quite inaccessible
column2: though. The rework of “We Share Our Mother’s Health” takes on a handclap-buoyed
column3: infectious shuffle
column4: with synths like airhorns
column5: vocals pitched forward
column6: and everything engineered to get butts out of seats. Silent Shout's disturbing title track is transformed into a seven-minute breakdown that shudders with an even more anxious energy
column7: Karin’s new vocal frayed and tentative in place of the original's gravitas. The two deepest cuts are the most excitingly recontextualized
column8: both in terms of the Knife’s current sound and general outlook. “Got 2 Let U”
column9: from 2003's Deep Cuts
column10: loses its strident oboe sample and gains a tempo injection—think 2010's <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13974-tomorrow-in-a-year/""><i>Tomorrow
column11: in a Year as UK garage—while lo-fi synth fairytale “Bird”
column12: from the band’s self-titled 2001 debut
column13: practically jitters here
column14: with lines like “But you wanted me to be a girl/ Without feathers
column15: without urge” taking on extra symbolic meaning when paired with Shaking the Habitual’s message.

column1: Shaken-Up Versions truncates the Shaking the Habitual setlist
column2: so for those familiar with the stage show
column3: the omissions are inevitable. and here they’re both obvious (Jess Arndt’s galvanizing spoken-word “The Body Possum” that appeared in the middle of the show)
column4: and puzzling (Silent Shout cut “One Hit”
column5: a creepy track that would have nice company here). Yet
column6: it’s a credit to the Knife’s craft that Shaken-Up Versions regardless feels like a complete statement; there’s a logic to the sequencing (Silent Shout’s singles bookend the album
column7: while Shaking the Habitual’s statements of purpose make up the deeper cuts) and a throughline to the remixing choices that make it work on its own.

column1: Shaken-Up Versions doesn’t threaten replace anything in the Knife’s catalog
column2: but it does highlight the levity that’s always been present in their music—yes
column3: even on self-consciously
column4: unsubtly Important Albums like Shaking the Habitual. The centerpiece of both that record and this new one is one line: “Ready to lose the privilege.” To do that
column5: it helps to lose your inhibitions
column6: and you just might need a good beat
column7:
too.

Drew Daniel must have armadillo-thick skin—or
column2: a closet crowded with functional chainmail. On Why Do the Heathen Rage?
column3: his third album of propulsive electronica under the occasional name the Soft Pink Truth
column4: the Matmos member taunts perhaps the most reactive
column5: boundary-buttressing subgenre of them all: black metal
column6: a historic domain of hate crimes
column7: real blood
column8: ideological belligerence and institutionalized aggression. Daniel—a gay electronic producer who moved from San Francisco to Baltimore in 2007—recruited a cast of indie rock pals and heavy metallurgists to cover 10 black metal songs
column9: with relative standards from Mayhem
column10: Darkthrone
column11: and Sarcofago accompanying a sample of more obscure sides.

column1: But guitars appear exactly one time here
column2: blood-curdling tirades maybe three. Instead
column3: Daniel and his collaborators turn these tirades about fucking and killing
column4: desecrating and dying into dance-floor and pop-chart bait
column5: with bludgeoning house tempos
column6: mesmerizing hooks and prismatic synths. Why Do the Heathen Rage? is Daniel’s open invitation to name-calling
column7: a plea to be branded with poser status and homosexual slurs from a scene that’s often been happy to oblige. It’s perhaps the ultimate black metal troll
column8: an album meant to make the truest kvlt heathens
column9: well
column10: rage. The rest of us can simply move.

column1: The Soft Pink Truth began as a sort of dare for Daniel from the producer Matthew Herbert
column2: who challenged the experimentalist to make a house record. Likewise
column3: Why Do the Heathen Rage?
column4: the project’s first output in a decade
column5: began as Daniel’s dare for himself after DJing at Rainbow in the Dark
column6: a monthly “party for gay men
column7: satanists and metal enthusiasts.” Could he pair one obsession with another? Could he take the misanthropic might of black metal and tie it to the communal ecstasy of techno? Could a song like Mayhem’s existentially doomed “Buried by Time and Dust” be rewired for the club? Absolutely.

column1: In Matmos
column2: Daniel has used electronic music to explore audacious concepts
column3: whether that’s meant building a record from samples of surgical procedures to an album-length
column4: detail-laced tribute to the duo’s heroes. Why Do the Heathen Rage? takes a similar tack
column5: funneling far-flung resources into one intimidating concept. These risky reassessments come loaded with guests uniformly and uniquely suited to the challenge. In the prelude
column6: for instance
column7: Antony Hegarty trades lines of a poem about mysticism
column8: androgyny and witchcraft with Daniel. The gossamer ease of the former sits like a specter against the pitch-shifted
column9: Lucifer-deep growl of the latter. That juxtaposition sets the stage for a play between shades of pink and black
column10: a tension that the album—the whole project
column11: really—mines.

column1: “Satanic Black Devotion” calls on both guitarist Owen Gaertner
column2: who toiled through transcriptions of all of these songs for Daniel
column3: and Locrian’s Terrence Hannum
column4: a nominal “metal guy” with a particularly broad view of what that might mean. In four minutes
column5: the cover pinballs between Gaertner’s solemn electric guitar and Daniel’s drum machine punishment
column6: Daniel’s ghoulish chants and Hannum’s pained screams. An “I’ve Got the Power” sample precedes an atmospheric fade into pastel noise. The trio finds its own path through the melodrama of the Sargeist original but leaves room to point out that its self-serious malevolence is worthy of at least one laugh. Solo black metal dudes always have the power.

column1: For similar reasons
column2: Wye Oak’s Jenn Wasner emerges as the unexpected star of Why Do the Heathen Rage?. Along with Daniel himself
column3: she serves as the paragon of respecting the source material while repurposing it at will
column4: too. In its original form
column5: “Let There Be Ebola Frost” is a rote
column6: mid-tempo march from Finland’s short-lived AN. Its lunging riff and lacerated vocals mostly obscure the extreme essence at the song’s core
column7: as though the band were too shy to confess to their own apocalyptic vision of a “realm of flushed blood.” But Wassner commands this script
column8: delivering worldwide extermination orders without a hint of irony or innocence. “Feel it bleed so quick
column9: ” she coos in a moment of graceful comedown
column10: Daniel emptying the beat into a bed of graceful synthesizer sighs. “I don’t feel any kind of compunction.” She summons a sort of schoolyard song at the end
column11: turning a partial acrostic about annihilation into a cheerleading chant. Her turn on Sarcofago’s “Ready to Fuck” turns the fellatio demands of a dude named Antichrist into a subversively demure seduction
column12: full of starts and stops and squeals and background moans from both Wassner and a tamed demon played by Daniel. The take accomplishes what Sarcofago ultimately sought—that is
column13: sex
column14: or the suggestion of it—but reshapes the message by switching the sender.

column1: At such moments
column2: it’s tempting to praise Why Do the Heathen Rage? as an expert
column3: unapologetic sendup of black metal
column4: a massive fuck you to a caste that’s said exactly that to so many others as a matter of stylistic necessity. The cover even depicts dudes in corpsepaint running trains on one another and skinheads getting handjobs from longhairs who wield knives and spike bracelets. And the record ends
column5: too
column6: with a wild-eyed and reckless race through<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o5zrgO7fVkg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> “Grim and Frostbitten Gay Bar
column7: ” a cut from the most obscure act included here—Impaled Northern Moonforest
column8: the hyperbolic and hilarious black metal parody launched and dropped by members of Anal Cunt more than a decade ago. In spirit and sound
column9: it’s the most allegiant cover here
column10: a confirmation of a delirious mockery. The killer
column11: one might surmise
column12: has been killed.

column1: That’s too simple for black metal
column2: though
column3: and too simple for techno. Most of all
column4: it’s too reductive for Daniel
column5: an artist whose previous output doesn’t necessarily reflect his pedigree as a fan
column6: a writer
column7: a thinker and a person. (One doesn’t really stumble across AN without a rather serious investment in this stuff.) “It’s about a contradiction or about a double citizenship that I have as somebody that’s a gay dude who’s heard a lot of dance music in gay bars and… loves a lot of sounds
column8: a lot of imagery and a lot of ideas that are totally contemptuous of the ethos of dance floor music
column9: ” he told Steel for Brains. He’s not out to destroy black metal so much as to reconsider the source of its unrepentant attitude and redirect it into another form with equal gusto. He’s strip-mined one thing he loves in order to drive another. In doing so
column10: he’s found a wonderful
column11: unexpected kind of combustion.

column1: Yes
column2: that will get him called names
column3: and yes
column4: that will make some faithful truly rage on message boards and (anonymously) in comment threads. But in 1982
column5: above the belligerent stomp of “Black Metal
column6: ” Venom’s Cronos sang of “taking our chances with raw energy
column7: ” setting at least one cornerstone for the movement that followed. Daniel begins Why Do the Heathen Rage? with a trunk-rattling version of that anthem
column8: launching his own take on black metal primacy by co-opting one of its founding documents. He swaps guitar solos for breakbeats and turns the chorus into an ecstatic
column9: industrial chant. It’s meant to be shouted out with eyes closed and fists up—you know
column10: real
column11:
metal power.
