column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20699/homepage_large.c1eccc0f.jpg|Dark Comedy|30520.0|Open Mike Eagle|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mello']|2014-06-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:20.677834|"

Somewhere between Richard Pryor going platinum and the latest episode of Louie
column2: the establishment of comedy as a filter between the outside world and an individual's churning-brain anxiety took a deep hold in the mainstream pop-culture consciousness. The more that once-uncommon voices are allowed to speak as themselves
column3: the likelier it is that they'll slip their grievances and worries in under the cover of slyly built jokes.

column1: Open Mike Eagle's solo career pushed him from Project Blowed cog to a spotlight that gave him space to ruminate over his fights against orthodoxy
column2: starting with hip-hop's (his first two album titles: Unapologetic Art Rap and Rappers Will Die of Natural Causes) and working his way outwards from there. In the process
column3: he's found a strong lane as an MC who cracks wise in both senses of the term. For each handful of fans that came to him through a connection with the Los Angeles underground hip-hop community
column4: there's at least one who heard about him through stand-up stars like Hannibal Buress or Paul F. Tompkins.

column1: So his latest album
column2: Dark Comedy
column3: pipes in a laugh track on its semi-titular opening track
column4: ""Dark Comedy Morning Show
column5: and Mike Eagle makes sure it comes in clear after the more raw-nerved lines—""I flew off the handle
column6: and boy are my arms tired""; ""If another dude calls me a racist
column7: I'm'a snap""; ""There's mad shootings on the news/ Unless it's in the Chi
column8: cause blacks and Mexicans can die"". The song sums up the whole album's ""on that laugh to keep from crying tip"" operating mode in just three verses
column9: but there are new angles and transformative concepts that keep the balance unpredictably gallows-humored throughout.

column1: ""Informations"" sets up some Tetsuo the Iron Man-meets-Videodrome body horror that plays to smartphone-addiction fears
column2: then leavens it with scatological humor (""When I pass gas it sounds like a fax machine"") and a sense that he's actually thrilled with the man-machine fusion. The line in ""Doug Stamper (Advice Raps)"" where he admonishes white rappers to ""Quit rappin' in your hood voice/ Sound like a clown 100-pounder that took 'roids"" both cuts closer and leans goofier when he actually imitates it as a dopey ""HARR RAAR RAAR RAAR RAAAGH"". Even when he threatens to lean towards unadulterated stress-rap
column3: he undercuts it by titling his most severe bout of venting ""Sadface Penance Raps"" and cutting it off after less than a minute and a half under the pretext that the beat malfunctioned. The sung hook
column4: lifted from They Might Be Giants' ""Don't Let's Start""
column5: that falls victim to this truncated ending: ""No one in the world ever gets what they want
column6: and that is beautiful.""

column1: Mike is an artist who thrives on working through some potentially inaccessible or confrontational thoughts and feelings using a very upfront and deceptively easygoing way with jokes and wordplay. That's not just in the references he throws around (""Thirsty Ego Raps"" gives not-entirely-non sequitur nods to Dave Gahan and Michel'le in consecutive lines)
column2: or his knack for internal rhymes and verse construction that actually scan like well-timed improv asides; it's also in how he builds up a self-portrait that establishes his own agency while still opening himself up to the possibilities of camaraderie and community.

column1: ""Qualifiers
column2: which he recorded a live version of in a laundromat
column3: should stand as his newest signature song for that reason. He pits party-rocking impulses alongside unglamorous but important fatherhood work by rhyming ""get up and dance"" with ""I wipe my son's ass and get shit on my hands
column4: jabs at hood-pass-hungry vultures questioning his cred (""Fuck you if you're a white man that assumes I speak for black folks/ Fuck you if you're a white man who thinks I can't speak for black folks"")
column5: and builds a hook that upends ego-tripping with weasel words: ""we the best
column6: mostly/ Sometimes the freshest rhymers/ We the tightest kinda/ Respect my qualifiers"". It's frank modesty in terms that any independent artist ever prone to self-second-guessing should recognize.

column1: That nervous energy radiates through everyone in Mike's orbit
column2: whether it's a characteristically mellow/jittery Kool A.D. feigning ignorance and riffing absurdist logic on ""Informations"" or Buress turning basic common courtesy into snarky older-brother wisdom on ""Doug Stamper (Advice Raps)"" with a Biz-caliber rap verse. (Sample line: ""Wash your hands when you touch your l'il dirty dick/ And dry 'em off before you come tryin' to shake my shit"".) Even the beats—Ultra Combo's Cloud Rap for Airports-esque ""Very Much Money (Ice King Dream)""
column3: Dibia$e's chunky synths bouncily ambling in low-g on the dream gig with a catch story ""Jon Lovitz (Fantasy Booking Yarn)""
column4: Jeremiah Jae laying down treated strings that sound like aluminum being table sawed on ""A History of Modern Dance""—hang on a precipice between whimsical irreverence and real to-the-gut emotional immediacy.

column1: It all builds off a feeling that this anxiety touches everyone
column2: that even if Mike's a singular kind of weirdo
column3: his worries are our worries. So he's feeling out the process of coming to happy terms with the weirdness he and his friends inhabit
column4: while still wishing it came with easy communication or self-sufficient success. Whether it's through casual observation or the to-the-bone identity struggles
column5:
Open Mike Eagle's overlap between amusing insights and uncomfortable truths makes for one of the most compelling indie-rap listens of the year so far.

"|19477.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19477-open-mike-eagle-dark-comedy/|8.0|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20690/homepage_large.b4a9a21e.jpg|Band of Brothers|3107.0|Willie Nelson|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Legacy']|2014-06-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:21.437395|"

As he enters his 80s
column2: Willie Nelson remains both a national monument and an impossibly prolific artist
column3: playing hundreds of shows every year and releasing albums at a pace that makes Guided By Voices look like Guns N' Roses. Even with such undiminished output
column4: however
column5: Band of Brothers arrives with a great deal of expectations. It’s his first collection to feature predominantly newly penned songs in nearly 20 years. The last time he debuted so many compositions on one record
column6: the result was 1996’s Spirit
column7: which stands alongside the best in his long career. Which is saying a lot: As a Nashville songsmith in the 1950s and 1960s
column8: he wrote such hits as Patsy Cline’s “Crazy”
column9: Ray Price’s “Funny How Time Slips Away”
column10: and Faron Young’s “Hello Walls”. As a solo artist in the 1970s
column11: he practically defined the outlaw movement with albums like Shotgun Willie
column12: Red-Headed Stranger
column13: Stardust
column14: and one of country’s best-selling albums
column15: Wanted! The Outlaws
column16: with Waylon Jennings
column17: Tompall Glaser
column18: and Jessi Colter. So Band of Brothers has a lot to live up to.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Nelson isn’t writing from the point of view of an 80-year-old. There’s no grimness on Band of Brothers
column3: no bleak admissions of mortality or putting-affairs-in-order solemnity that damned late-in-life albums by Johnny Cash and Kris Kristofferson. Age ain’t nothin’ but a number to Nelson
column4: who will likely be touring and toking long after we’re all dead. Even on “The Wall” and “Bring It On”
column5: both of which reminisce about the hardships and regrets of a life spent on the bus
column6: Nelson sounds triumphant rather than weary. “I hit the wall
column7: ” he sings
column8: less like a beaten man and more like Joshua at Jericho: “And the wall came down.”

column1: If he sounds like a man who just can’t wait to get on the road again
column2: Band of Brothers suggests that he’s motivated less by wanderlust than by the camaraderie of his fellow scribes and musicians
column3: many of whom have been with him since longer than you or I have been alive. This is nothing new for Nelson
column4: who has been portraying the touring life as a mobile party since the early 1970s. His band on Brothers tears through these sad songs and waltzes with unfussy professionalism
column5: nimbly navigating the wanted-man recklessness of “Wives and Girlfriends” and the spry Western Swing” of “Used to Her”. And Willie sings them like he can’t believe he gets to hear Mickey Raphael play harmonica every night.

column1: The least satisfying songs on Band of Brothers address the music business itself and the changes Nelson has seen since earning his first credit more than half a century ago. His version of ""Hard to Be an Outlaw""
column2: a new song by first-gen outlaw Billy Joe Shavers
column3: takes contemporary tailgate country to task for oversell its barnyard bona fides: “The record people nowadays keep spinning ‘round and ‘round/ Songs about the backroads that they never have been down
column4: ” Nelson sings
column5: chagrined that “they go and call it country
column6: but that ain’t the way it sounds.” But he doesn’t do bitter very well
column7: and both “Hard to Be an Outlaw” and Shaver’s other credit
column8: “The Git Go”
column9: sound dark
column10: dirgelike
column11: and out of place among so many uptempo numbers. (Shaver includes better versions of both songs on his upcoming album
column12: Long in the Tooth.)

column1: Nelson has always had an easy way with a wistful melody
column2: and even though his voice has gained new grain over the years and lost some of its range
column3: it’s more agile and commanding here than it has been on his last few albums. Still taking massive liberties with meter
column4: he underscores the default optimism of closer “I’ve Got a Lot of Traveling to Do” and imbues “The Songwriters” with a sly wink. That light touch compensates for the convoluted concept of “Used to Her” and almost manages to sell the lines
column5: “You’re like the measles
column6: you’re like the whooping cough” on the otherwise fine “I Thought I Left You”. Nelson sings about romance like it’s still a vital concern for the eightysomething
column7: which probably has less to do with his day-to-day life and more to do with his old-school approach to country songwriting. Even if it can’t measure up to Spirit
column8: Band of Brothers is still a showcase for what Nelson does best. These songs pare the personal down to the universal
column9: speaking eloquently to experiences common to every listener: love
column10: friendship
column11: hardship
column12:
trouble. 

"|19468.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19468-willie-nelson-band-of-brothers/|7.4|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20678/homepage_large.b062b58e.jpg|Promulgation of the Fall|27719.0|Dead Congregation|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2014-06-20 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:21.966333|"

It’s been a full six years since Dead Congregation released their last full-length album
column2: Graves of the Archangels. That record blew the roof off what people thought “death metal” could be
column3: and with it
column4: Dead Congregation elevated the sound to nearly unsurpassable heights before stepping back to watch the next wave of “old school death metal” surge and strain towards the bar that they’d set. Now that the sound they helped reintroduce to the masses has reached critical mass and started to fall back out of favor
column5: these godless Hellenics have returned to reap what they have sown—and show the rest of ‘em how it’s done.

column1: Promulgation of the Fall is coming from a band entering into its tenth year of existence with an impeccable reputation and slavishly devoted fanbase
column2: and they've spent the past six years fine-tuning the eight compositions on this release. That they’ve spent the better part of that decade engaging in fairly regular live performances shows in the writing
column3: too
column4: so songs sound tighter and the tension at work is impeccable. The four men leading Dead Congregation have always held themselves up to the highest standard of quality in this band
column5: and this latest release is no different
column6: showcasing the band at its most confident and powerful. Vocalist/guitarist A.V.’s imperious growl has never sounded stronger
column7: the whole rhythm section locks together like clockwork
column8: and the guitars are caked in gritty
column9: graven tones that entice as much as they intimidate.

column1: After “Only Ashes Remain” comes roaring to life on the back of V.V.’s maniacally precise drumming and a thoroughly commanding central riff
column2: title track “Promulgation of the Fall” ambles in with its prolonged intro and trundles along in saturnine fashion until the bottom drops out near the end and we’re treated to a satisfying taste of Dead Congregation’s loyalty to the low end. It’s an odd sequencing decision
column3: as “Promulgation...” sounds like the clear choice for album opener
column4: but it makes for one of the album’s nearly nonexistent missteps. “Serpentskin” starts off fast and furious
column5: but its real power lies in the mid-song break
column6: when it slows down to an unbearably slow
column7: ponderous groove. It’s the kind of tricky maneuver that is incredibly easy to screw up
column8: but Dead Congregation make it look like an afterthought. Most of their songs follow that same formula in different measures: some songs linger within that thick
column9: sluggish tempo
column10: while others revert back to blunt force in quicksilver blasts
column11: but that same comfortable fast-slow-fast dynamic pervades the entirety of this dark
column12: doomy death metal opus. It has worked for them in the past
column13: and it surely works just fine now.

column1: Unlike so many of their Greek brethren
column2: Dead Congregation has never stood for innovation. Instead of pushing extreme metal's boundaries into strange new dimensions
column3: A.V. and his cohorts have concentrated on perfecting a very specific sound that invokes a very specific atmosphere
column4: drawing from a very specific sonic template in order to achieve that vision. That’s not to say that Promulgation of the Fall is boring or homogenous; on the contrary
column5: it offers an embarrassment of riches for the death metal connoisseur
column6: and plenty of surprises for the newly initiated. The guitar work on""Immaculate Poison"" is ripped straight from Slayer's earliest
column7: most evil efforts
column8: and when the screaming solo and rippling fretwork on “Nigredo” slices up and out through the quagmire of distortion or apocalyptic chords of album closer “From a Wretched Womb” come howling from the void
column9: it’s clear that there is something special happening here. Most importantly
column10:
they leave us wanting more.

"|19457.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19457-dead-congregation-promulgation-of-the-fall/|7.9|Kim Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20679/homepage_large.52ca9b43.jpg|Reality Testing|29381.0|Lone|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['R&S']|2014-06-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:22.839519|"

Over the last four years
column2: Matt Cutler has steadily established himself as one of dance music’s most exciting producers. The Nottingham-based artist is a master of indulgence
column3: jamming his tracks with jagged
column4: aggressive rhythms and glistening melodies. Cutler draws heavily from rave music’s more explicitly colorful side
column5: embracing the all-out intensity of breakbeat techno and hardcore’s effervescent steamroll; like many of his contemporaries
column6: he was barely old enough to ride a bike when those strains of dance music emerged the first time around
column7: so his work as Lone is essentially a reconstruction
column8: an alternate version of the past put together by someone who wasn’t around to experience the sound's genesis.

column1: Cutler sidesteps claims of misplaced nostalgia through sheer inventiveness. After working in earnest near the end of the 2000s
column2: he first caught a larger audience’s ear with 2010’s kaleidoscopic Emerald Fantasy Tracks
column3: released on his own Magic Wire imprint. An eight-track collection that felt less like a unified whole and more like a collection of singles
column4: Emerald Fantasy Tracks gave a brighter tint to to the dazzling grit of techno luminaries like Underground Resistance. Resurrected European techno label R&S took notice and signed Cutler
column5: and two years later he released what stands as his magnum opus
column6: Galaxy Garden. It was a massive achievement and also startling in its originality. Upon its release
column7: Cutler told The Stool Pigeon that the record was “influenced by nothing
column8: and although rave music loomed larger than ever in his sound
column9: the comment made some sense. Galaxy Garden is one of those records that truly feels boundless
column10: a head trip that practically overflowed with beatific melodies and inviting textures. (It’s unsurprising that
column11: in the same year
column12: Glasgow's Rustie tapped Cutler to contribute a new track to his era-defining contribution to BBC’s Essential Mix series; maximalism is a central tenet to the Lone sound.)

column1: One of the decade’s singular electronic records
column2: Galaxy Garden was a thrilling document that made you wonder where Cutler would take his sound next. Reality Testing turns out to be both a left turn and a back-to-basics move. Largely abandoning rave’s warp-speed tempos and sensual overload
column3: Reality Testing finds Cutler shifting his focus to the dusty hip-hop grooves of auteurs like J Dilla and Madlib
column4: two artists regularly name-checked by European dance producers as formative influences. Cutler’s no exception: his early work drew from those artists’ loping knock as much as it did from the hazy electronic music of Boards of Canada
column5: with 2009’s Ecstasy & Friends (released on Actress’ continually ahead-of-the-curve Werk Discs imprint) being the last time he explored those sounds so thoroughly.

column1: Depending on the your relationship Cutler’s earlier music
column2: the shift in focus on Reality Testing can prove initially disappointing—there’s no shortage of producers currently attempting to hardwire hip-hop motifs to Boards of Canada’s iridescent glow
column3: and he's covered some of this ground before. It might take a few listens to get on Cutler’s current wavelength
column4: but approaching Reality Testing with an open mind yields great rewards. It’s one of his most assured and confident efforts and it provides a perfect gateway into the Lone sound.

column1: I've heard comparisons between Reality Testing’s more explicitly hip-hop-influenced cuts and the work of Wolverhampton producer Stephen Wilkinson’s Bibio project. The two artists operate in different lanes—Wilkinson’s more predisposed to song-based structures
column2: whereas Cutler derives his energy from dance’s lack of set definitions—but the similarities are there. “Restless City” is all tumbling claps and record-skipping sounds
column3: with a few needle-drop effects to add a sense of halting texture; “2 Is 8” sounds deliciously retro
column4: with vocal samples occasionally intruding on the track’s knocking drums and steam-pipe melody that resembles an alternate take on the “Sesame Street” theme. “Meeker Warm Energy” oozes West Coast lackadaisical vibes
column5: with honeyed static slathering a Dilla-aping beat; early single “Airglow Fires” takes the hat-tipping a step further by calling back to the vocal sample from Dilla’s Donuts neck-whipper “The Twister (Huh
column6: What)”
column7: speeding up the easygoing tempo and covering the thing in chunky chords reminiscent of Detroit techno.

column1: The sounds of early-gen Detroit dance music is Reality Testing’s other main influence; the hollow chords that anchor “Aurora Northern Quarter” bring to mind Derrick May
column2: and “Vengeance Video” is the album’s most straightforward house cut
column3: a patiently skipping tune that benefits from a loopy synth entering at the halfway point. Another of Cutler’s frequent touchstones
column4: the clean sparkle of new age
column5: is all over Reality Testing. Although the embrace of new age in dance music has become a common trend among young producers
column6: few apply those textures as effectively as Cutler does. Wind chimes enter and exit—opener “First Born Seconds” is literally two minutes of swarming
column7: spa-ready drone—while closer “Cutched Under” calls back to the downtempo glory of the Anneka-featuring Galaxy Garden capper “Spirals”
column8: melding warm tones to the type of marching percussion that overtook Bristol’s bass sound circa 2010.

column1: Cutler’s ear melody takes center stage on Reality Testing. His touch is distinctive and generous—the Lone remix of Radiohead’s The King of Limbs cut “Feral” wrung benevolence out of that album’s most abstract
column2: slight track—and here his jams run free
column3: from the delectable yo-yo synth line that crashes through the head-nod of “Meeker Warm Energy” to the sparkling pan pipes that whirl around the speedy house motifs of “Begin to Begin”. Similar to kindred spirit and Cologne producer Motor City Drum Ensemble
column4: Cutler proves most effective at applying personal dabs of melody to his own vision of the past.

column1: Reality Testing is Cutler’s easiest listen—you can imagine this music playing over coffee shop speakers as much as you could put a rapper on top of it—and as such it may seem less innovative when placed up against his previous two full-lengths. It’s more spare than the dense Galaxy Garden
column2: but it’s also a few minutes longer than that album
column3: and by comparison its relatively placid back half blurs together a little more than the acid-infused pyrotechnics of its predecessors's losing cuts. Regardless
column4: Reality Testing stands as one of the year's best
column5: most luxuriant
column6: and accomplished electronic albums
column7: more proof that when it comes to forging a new future out of what’s already taken place
column8:
Cutler remains at the top of his game.

"|19458.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19458-lone-reality-testing/|8.0|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20671/homepage_large.13ad89b7.jpg|In the Lonely Hour|31101.0|Sam Smith|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2014-06-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:23.620511|"

From the beginning
column2: Sam Smith seemed set for stardom: his debut came at the start of Disclosure's world domination and gave them a show-stopping performance on the lingering mega-hit ""Latch"". Less than a year later
column3: he appeared on Naughty Boy's ""La La La""
column4: a summer smash that went to number one in the UK and the top of the charts in the rest of Europe. By the time he released ""Money on My Mind"" at the beginning of 2014
column5: it was already a done deal. The young 22-year-old
column6: the son of a wealthy London banker who was fired for spending too much time trying to jumpstart his pop career
column7: would be the UK's next big thing. And here we are: the week where his debut In the Lonely Hour
column8: sees release in North America
column9: the album is sitting at number one in the UK for the second week in a row
column10: riding two chart-topping singles and edging the US top ten with its latest.

column1: So why all the hubbub? If you've heard ""Latch""
column2: you already know about that voice: Sam Smith possesses one hell of a set of pipes
column3: able to go from a commanding lower register to an inhumanly high squawk in record time. (“I remember hearing ‘Latch’ and thinking
column4: ‘No person can go through that many vocal ranges at one time without going through a computer
column5: ’ ” said one of his A&R reps in a recent feature.) That talent is central to ""Money on My Mind""
column6: an itchy-feet drum'n'bass number with a chorus so high-pitched you might mistake Smith for a bird. More importantly
column7: however
column8: he details his signing to the record label and his apparent unwillingness to kowtow to record label demands
column9: attempting to set himself apart as a freethinker. ""I do it for the love
column10: he insists on the chorus
column11: and ""You say
column12: 'Could you write a song for me?'/ I say
column13:
'I'm sorry I won't do that happily'"" in the verse. But the main problem with In the Lonely Hour—and all of Smith's music up to this point—is exactly the opposite: it feels like the record company has groomed him within an inch of his life.

With undeniable pipes weighed down by generic songcraft
column14: Smith makes me think of Duffy
column15: a blue-eyed soul singer recruited in the wake of Amy Winehouse to capitalize on the sudden hunger for retro soul music. While Smith doesn't tap into that sound as directly
column16: the emotional impact of the syrupy strings
column17: by-the-book lyrics about heartbreak
column18: and trite chord progressions is the same.

column1: In the Lonely Hour is meant to be Smith's love letter to a man who never returned his feelings; it's an affecting idea
column2: and Smith's inexperience—he hasn't yet been in a relationship—should provide for a fascinating level of sincerity
column3: but too often it feels like he's being held back by an oppressive sense of musical conservatism. ""Stay With Me"" (currently making its way up the U.S. charts) has all the elements of a stunning ballad
column4: a plea for a lover to stay over after a one night stand just for some human contact. Unfortunately
column5: a hammy choir over-emotes all over his delicate late-night vulnerability
column6:
taking Smith's raw honesty and overcooking it to a grey pallor.

There are other moments of lucidity that pop up amidst the midtempo mush. The tender ""Good Thing"" has Smith expertly navigating tangled lyrics about obsession (""Too much of a good thing won't be good anymore/ Watch where I tread before I fall"")—but then there's an inexplicable blast of cheesy Hollywood strings in lieu of a bridge. ""Leave Your Lover""
column7: meanwhile
column8: has a disarmingly direct chorus: ""Leave your lover/ Leave him for me
column9: all sung matter-of-factly in his most gorgeous falsetto. He repeats the conceit on ""Like I Can""
column10: this time a mess of clichés built on a trendy acoustic guitar stomp
column11: a sound that's more representative of the rest of the album. ""Not in That Way"" is a histrionic weeper with all the subtlety of a Susan Boyle song
column12: and the type of lyrics written by high-schoolers still stuck rhyming ""moon""
column13: ""June""
column14:
and ""spoon"". 

Still
column15: most of In the Lonely Hour is enjoyable just for Smith's voice alone—so unusual
column16: unpredictable and utterly pleasing that it can be wonderful to listen to even through the most egregious of lite-FM tropes. But so much of the album remains hard to swallow otherwise
column17: lost underneath layers of industry polish and focus-grouped lyrics. Though there's no doubt In the Lonely Hour comes from a personal place
column18: it doesn't end up feeling like a very personal record. Except for one part: on the album's very first line
column19: Smith quivers ""When I signed my deal/ I felt pressure."" Judging from how In the Lonely Hour turned out
column20:
his suspicions were for good reason.

"|19450.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19450-sam-smith-in-the-lonely-hour/|5.5|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20667/homepage_large.e22fb394.jpg|Music for Heart and Breath|32312.0|Richard Reed Parry|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deutsche Grammophon']|2014-06-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:24.431476|"

If your heartbeat were a conductor's baton
column2: it would be an exasperating master—lagging a millisecond here
column3: quickening two paces there. Think of your own as heard through a doctor's stethoscope: mine always speeds up
column4: as if the doctor and I have caught it dawdling. Richard Reed Parry
column5: the multi-instrumentalist for Arcade Fire and a composer as well
column6: keys into this most basic of all rhythms for Music for Heart and Breath
column7: his first full album of classical compositions. The performers
column8: who range from yMusic (with help from the National's Aaron and Bryce Dessner and Nico Muhly) to the venerable Kronos Quartet
column9: wear stethoscopes over their chests to keep time. Their pulse is also the piece's. In some cases
column10: one performer's breath dictates the ensemble's movements; in others
column11: the ensembles work together
column12: playing in and out of sync with each other in heterogeneous clouds.

column1: It's a remarkable concept
column2: and it seems impossible that no composer has thought of it before. Composers have previously consulted the I Ching
column3: rolled dice
column4: tossed coins; Olivier Messiaen searched all the way back to 17th-century plainchant to free himself from the tyranny of the organized beat. How no one thought to look at their own chest
column5: rising and falling
column6: and make this primal connection
column7: beggars belief. Parry himself seems incredulous: ""For awhile I thought
column8: for goodness sake
column9: has somebody really not done this?"" he told Sinfini Music.

column1: The conceit animates the music
column2: figuratively and literally. There is a palpable aliveness to the performance that makes the makes the six pieces
column3: written for different configurations
column4: feel like a guided meditation. This is body music
column5: unquestionably
column6: and by the end of the album the music's subtle internal rhythms have reconfigured your own.

column1: Parry's touch as a composer is pensive and delicate. There are a few startling outbursts here and there
column2: but they recede gracefully
column3: and the overall impression is of groups of notes judiciously dotting vast white space rather than swarming the canvas. The mood is still
column4: serene
column5: similar to Western mystics Lou Harrison and Terry Riley. In the ""Heart and Breath Sextet""
column6: violins slide down some minor thirds
column7: bent back like bamboo branches. Pianos push gently in the opposite direction with rising figures. It's the sound of sighs and chatter
column8: a foyer filling up with arriving dinner guests—but just as soon
column9: these voices back away into silence again. The effect is mournful
column10: muted; if Parry's method is skewed toward the sounds of humanity
column11: his ear leads him away again into silence and emptiness.

column1: Each piece traces simple
column2: profound gestures and then tapers away
column3: leaving a troubling impression. Interruptions comprises seven miniatures
column4: only one longer than four minutes: the   plucked strings
column5: guitars
column6: and gracefully staggered woodwinds of ""Sticks/Tension"" hit the ear like a handful of pebbles splashed into a pond. ""Duet for Heart and Breath"" pairs Parry with yMusic's violist Nadia Sirota
column7: who draws breath audibly before bowing some feather-soft harmonics.  ""Freeform Winds/String Drones"" is just that
column8: overlapping washes of sound that move in unpredictable surges.

column1: Parry's writing is shimmering
column2: jewel-like. His firm grasp of mood and color recalls Messiaen's Quartet for the End of Time
column3: but his music doesn't end time so much as atomize it and spread it out—things happen in Music for Heart and Breath at roughly the same pace as they do in real life. There are no fixed points
column4: just motion along a spectrum
column5: and we never know exactly where we are. But the uncertainty
column6: familiar as it is
column7:
is oddly soothing. 

"|19446.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19446-richard-reed-parry-music-for-heart-and-breath/|8.0|Jayson Greene

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20689/homepage_large.16919bb6.jpg|Auto Music|32178.0|Brian Reitzell|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Smalltown Supersound']|2014-06-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:26.023604|"

Brian Reitzell ghosts behind popular culture
column2: having a significant impact upon it without ever seeming to crave the need to see his name in lights. He’s best known as a film composer and music supervisor on Sofia Coppola’s movies
column3: while his work in bands—Air and Redd Kross among them—is something of a footnote in their respective biographies. When Reitzell talks about music
column4: he often mentions similarly anonymous figures as inspiration
column5: finding kinship in krautrock acts and Daniel Lopatin’s Oneohtrix Point Never project. Yet
column6: he clearly commands a special kind of respect in the people he approaches to work with him. How else to explain his teasing of Kevin Shields out of semi-retirement to work on the Lost in Translation score
column7: or getting reclusive Talk Talk frontman Mark Hollis to make his first music in an age
column8: for (of all things) the Kelsey Grammer-starring TV show ""Boss""? In his own quiet way
column9: Reitzell’s a powerful figure who can exert influence in the most unlikely places.

column1: For his debut solo album
column2: the Los Angeles-based composer turned to a swathe of his influences as inspiration
column3: while also bringing on board a select band of notable collaborators. Shields surfaces again
column4: contributing organ
column5: while Jim James of My Morning Jacket worked up seven-part harmonies for “Ozu Choral” that Reitzell subsequently manipulated for his own means. There are a bunch of fellow backroom musicians working alongside him here
column6: too
column7: including Mike Dillon
column8: Dave Palmer
column9: and Roger J. Manning Jr.
column10: making the whole enterprise resemble something like a cooler version of session-musician supergroup Toto. But Auto Music doesn’t sound like group music
column11: instead touching on areas Reitzell has clearly obsessed over in his film work
column12: including the spacey qualities of The Virgin Suicides score (“Last Summer”) and the hazy shoegaze fug that permeated throughout Lost in Translation (“Ozu”
column13: “Oskar”).

column1: The nine wordless songs here don’t have much to link them thematically
column2: although Reitzell sees them as soundtracks to long West Coast drives through vast
column3: open plains. It’s a record that was recorded over a long period—begun over a decade ago
column4: according to this interview—causing a lack of cohesion at times. Mostly
column5: it’s an interesting curio from someone who clearly spends a great deal of time thinking about music but can’t quite reach beyond the sounds he hears to get into his own sphere. So “Gaudi” touches on the jazzy atmospherics of Talk Talk’s later works
column6: while “Honeycomb” brings in the creaky
column7: piston-like dynamics of certain Cluster songs; “Auto Music 2” resembles his play for a contemporary update of Kraftwerk’s “Autobahn”. It’s enjoyable on a base level for anyone interested in those styles
column8: even if there is a creeping feeling of musical dress-up being played.

column1: Auto Music provides insight into Reitzell’s thought process behind his film scores; listening to a song like “Ozu”
column2: so clearly indebted to the rough-around-the-edges version of My Bloody Valentine that Shields was honing on Isn’t Anything
column3: it makes sense that Reitzell would undertake the (at the time
column4: seemingly impossible) task of persuading him to release music again. Ultimately
column5: that’s not enough to make Auto Music shine in its own right
column6: although there are moments that cut through the surface noise. As “Ozu” makes its descent out of MBV-land
column7: it echoes around repeating slabs of guitar
column8: verging on its own weight instead of borrowing someone else’s. Perhaps this is the inevitable end product of the music supervisor—someone who spends so long observing other work that they can’t get into their own space. There’s something poetic about that
column9: a man’s own advances stalled by the very things he loves
column10:
and that struggle at least gives Auto Music a dose of tension at its heart.

"|19467.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19467-brian-reitzell-auto-music/|6.5|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20313/homepage_large.bf82f743.jpg|The Living Ever Mourn|32146.0|Nightfell|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Parasitic']|2014-06-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:26.617216|"

Nightfell are a Portland metal duo that bring together key players in the city's metal and hardcore scenes. Drummer and vocalist Tim Call runs the Parasitic label and has played in a slew of groups including Aldebaran
column2: the Howling Wind
column3: and Weregoat; guitarist/vocalist Todd Burdette plays in Tragedy and Severed Head of State
column4: and was a former member of influential crust band His Hero Is Gone. <span style=""font-style: normal;"">Their debut
column5: The Living Ever Mourn
column6: serves as a bridge between their own tastes and influences.

column1: True to their origins
column2: Nightfell alternate between resembling a slowed-down version of Tragedy or a sped-up take on Aldebaran; they're also heavily influenced by Call's love of funeral doom
column3: namely groups like Skepticism and Mournful Congregation (who Call has also played live with). Funeral doom is as depressing as it sounds; motion is halted in favor of creating a overwhelmingly glum atmosphere. Mourn's two interludes—an oddly syrupy keyboard sequence and a track punctuated by acoustic guitars and drawling vocals—further underline the genre's presence. Still
column4: traces of the melodic crust Burdette popularized with Tragedy and His Hero Is Gone are found in his guitar work for Nightfell
column5: especially in his leads on “I Am Decay”.

column1: “Altars to Wrath” is the most successful union of their personalities; Call delivers some D-beat in the middle of the track
column2: while Burdette unleashes monstrous death metal riffs that Asphyx or Disma would be envious of. Tragedy's last record
column3: 2012's Darker Days Ahead
column4: suffered from a lack of urgency; while Mourn is a slower-sounding record
column5: the tempo change doesn't come across as labored because Call and Burdette's chemistry works
column6: even with music as slow and morose as this.

column1: Their partnership is especially engaging when Burdette lends some clean guitars to “The Hollowing”
column2: producing soothing tones while Call wails away on the drums. It creates a fruitful tension
column3: as there isn't much room to breathe throughout Mourn. When a pick-slide comes in and a crusty charge dominates the final seconds of the song
column4: the intrusion doesn't feel jagged. Similarly
column5: on “Dirge”
column6: Burdette's clean playing fights with Call's militaristic snare. For less experienced players
column7: such experiments could come across as clunky; for them
column8: it sounds natural.

column1: After getting a digital and cassette release earlier in the year
column2: The Living Ever Mourn is seeing vinyl via Southern Lord
column3: which makes sense. They started out as a doom-oriented label before getting into black metal
column4: and more recently
column5: the label has shifted towards putting out many crust-influenced hardcore records. With Call and Burdette's combined backgrounds
column6:
Mourn shrinks the disconnect in Southern Lord's roots and their present-day activities.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Anti-']|2014-06-18 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:27.235304|"

The Antlers have grown up in their own way: slowly. The project’s first full-band effort
column3: 2009’s Hospice
column4: followed two collections of roughshod solo material from lead vocalist Peter Silberman
column5: records that sounded as if he were fumbling in the dark; Hospice
column6: then
column7: was light making its way into the room
column8: a collection of indie rock that drew from the sounds you’re likely to find on an iPod owned by someone in their mid-20s—sparkling chamber-pop
column9: angsty
column10: emotive vocal surges
column11: gaping shoegaze guitars. Two years later
column12: they returned with Burst Apart
column13: a transitional effort that found the Antlers getting weirder
column14: incorporating the kind of saucer-eyed ambience familiar to anyone who’s ever heard Sigur Rós in a smoke-filled dorm room.

column1: If Burst Apart was the sound of the Antlers dipping their toes into unfamiliar waters
column2: on the following year’s mini-LP Undersea they took the plunge: notions of immediacy and concision were discarded
column3: replaced by a slow-handed approach to space rock that valued detail over the type of explicit melodicism showcased in their earlier work. In opposition to the music that was being put forth
column4: the shift on Undersea was startling
column5: bold
column6: and more than a little brave. By industry standards
column7: the Antlers were growing—Undersea was their first release for Anti-
column8: a significant step up in visibility from their previous label
column9: NYC-based farm-team indie Frenchkiss—but as the lights were increasingly trained on them
column10: the band managed to find their own darkened corner in the musical landscape. Hospice could sound like the work of a band that was very good at sounding like other bands; Undersea was the point at which the Antlers found themselves. Familiars
column11: the Antlers’ first full-length in three years
column12: confirms that they are operating in their own zone. They’ve doubled down on Undersea’s somnambulant moodiness and increased focus on atmosphere
column13: resulting in their longest
column14: most subtle release.

column1: As with every Antlers record since Hospice
column2: Familiars was self-produced
column3: and the group’s collective ear for texture continues to take hold as its own expressive instrument. As ever
column4: drama is in no short supply either. Silberman’s lyrical predilections
column5: in particular
column6: have long possessed an emotional scope that speaks to the honest naiveté associated with stumbling through your young adulthood: Hospice essentially compared love and loss to a children’s cancer ward
column7: Burst Apart was all house fires and metaphors for sexual frustration
column8: and Undersea explored the age-old concept of water-as-emotional metaphor. In an interview with Pitchfork
column9: Silberman name-checked filmmaker Gaspar Nóe’s trippy opus Enter the Void
column10: a movie that treats death as an orgasmic act of self-exploration
column11: as one of a few inspirations for Familiars’ funeral-pyre slow-burn. “There are different ways to look at death
column12: ” he said
column13: “and they don’t have to be depressing at all.”

column1: In that same interview
column2: Silberman claimed that the Antlers are frequently pegged as a “sad band
column3: ” and while no one will mistake the breathy ruminations of Familiars as “happy music
column4: ” the record’s instrumentation has a transcendent brightness
column5: not unlike what you might see when closing your eyes after staring into the sun for too long. The spacious lope of “Intruders” is made up of muted guitar stabs and molasses-slow drum work
column6: surrounded by heavy swirls of space and dotted with the occasional horn and keyboard flourish; “Surrender” rests itself on a gently descending guitar figure that
column7: at the six-minute song’s midpoint
column8: reaches upwards to impossible heights before dissolving in pedal-abused piano and horns soaked in warmth.

column1: Whether they’re reaching above their heads or to the deepest depths
column2: on Familiars the Antlers are even more concerned with catharsis
column3: resulting in a string of patient
column4: beatific crescendos. (The word “patient” is
column5: at this stage of the Antlers’ career
column6: operative: only two of Familiars’ 10 songs finish before reaching the five-minute mark.) The elegiac “Director” spends its first two minutes and change moving at the pace of a burning stick of incense
column7: as Michael Lerner’s brushed cymbals create a suitable bed for drowsy guitar; then
column8: the weight shifts in the form of rolling drums and just enough six-string fuzz
column9: evoking the type of soft psychedelia that Spiritualized have occasionally turned to. Opener “Palace” is essentially five-and-a-half minutes of declarative melody that comes on strong and stays there before vanishing completely
column10: while “Revisited” is the record’s torch song—but one without resolution
column11: as Silberman repeatedly switches between anguished vocals and receding into the background
column12: breaking into a elliptical guitar solo near the song’s end that floats above the fizzy electronics.

column1: As a vocalist
column2: Silberman’s never shied away from theatricality; on Hospice’s “Sylvia”
column3: he seethed and cried to match that song’s bursting guitar burn of a chorus
column4: and every successive release has seen him expanding his register to match the music’s at-times skyscraping qualities. On Familiars
column5: Silberman cements himself as one of indie rock’s most compelling and distinctive singers. He’s capable of projecting a wide
column6: complex range of emotions—angry and defeated on “Hotel”
column7: cautiously hopeful on “Intruders”. On the straightforward saunter of “Parade”
column8: he takes on the ruminative prognostication of someone looking at a yearbook and wondering if the future and past possess any connection at all.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Silberman’s very much in his therapist’s-couch lane on Familiars
column3: with a few subtle shifts in his mindset that you’d expect anyone currently reaching the end of their late 20s to undergo. “Maybe when I’m older
column4: ” he optimistically states in the beginning of “Intruders”
column5: “I’ll be clearer/ More attuned and understanding.” On “Refuge”
column6: he morbidly turns his gaze to what life’s endgame means—”When you lift me out of me/ Will I know when I’ve changed?”—but despite that and other brief meditations on death-as-release
column7: Familiars’ thematic focus is a bit more scattered than Silberman name-checking The Tibetan Book of the Dead would have you believe. This time around
column8: the theme he returns to most is identity—who we see when we look in the mirror
column9: what happens when we don’t recognize who’s staring back—and on “Intruders”’ emotional peak
column10: he confronts the terrifying possibility of encountering a dopplegänger with what sounds like murderous intentions: “When my double scales the wall/ I’ll know exactly where he’s landing/ And I’ll surprise him.”

column1: Indeed
column2: even as Silberman’s stuck with his most literary affectations—full-sentence lyrical statements
column3: a heavy reliance on symbolism—he and the Antlers have loosened in terms of pretense over the last five years
column4: taking on more self-absorbed concerns as their music has grown more insular and drowsy. The 28-year-old Silberman was barely of drinking age when he released music under the Antlers guise in earnest
column5: and in the eight years since he and his band have aged publicly
column6: charting their own distinct course while making music about the small-scale challenges faced when you feel truly lost in the world. Against all odds
column7: they’ve become one of the most interesting indie rock bands working
column8: and the stately beauty of Familiars is the latest satisfying effort from a band that continues to reward those listeners who give them the attention their elegant
column9:
secretly weird music deserves.

Though few of their songs contain actual words
column2: Mogwai have always been fond of big statements. Having emerged during the late-1990s post-rock boom
column3: the Scottish quintet used every means possible to distance themselves from the sullen stereotype that defined so many instrumental art-rock brooders of their era. EP titles were turned into protest placards
column4: interviews inevitably became merciless slag fests
column5: and concert t-shirts doubled as a form of music criticism. Even the abrupt calm-to-chaos eruptions that defined the band’s 1997 debut
column6: Young Team
column7: seemed to be delivered with devious
column8: mischievous grins. So naturally
column9: the band came up with a doozy of a title for their second album (and the first to receive a proper U.S. release via Matador): Come On Die Young
column10:
a two-fingered retort to the “Live Forever” platitudes of the Britpop they so despised.

As such
column11: it was no surprise that Mogwai’s would open the album with a song called “Punk Rock:”
column12: even if it wasn’t a punk rock song at all. Rather
column13: overtop a foreboding
column14: percussion-less guitar instrumental
column15: we hear the voice of Iggy Pop in a televised 1977 interview with Canadian broadcaster Peter Gzowski
column16: explaining the difference between the commoner’s caricatured conception of punk and his own more spiritual
column17: empowering interpretation of the term. But as much as it overtly asserts Mogwai’s allegiance to the rock iconoclasts of yore
column18: the track also betrays the band’s own frustration with being misunderstood; beyond being propped up as post-rock poster boys
column19: Mogwai had been variously hyped as the Scottish Slint and the new Pink Floyd. Tellingly
column20: “Punk Rock:” ends on an open-ended note
column21: with an increasingly exasperated Iggy asking Gzowski
column22: “Do you understand what I’m saying
column23: sir?” The question is left hanging in the ether
column24:
as if to suggest that no amount of reasoning will change the opinions of those who’ve already made up their mind about you.

So on Come On Die Young
column25: Mogwai went about becoming the most sullen
column26: brooding post-rock band they could possibly be
column27: with each melancholic guitar refrain and desolate
column28: dead-of-night snare-drum tap serving as a deliberately set breadcrumb trail to more Spiderland comparisons. But by playing to post-rock type
column29: Come On Die Young ultimately expanded Mogwai’s emotional vocabulary. Where they once shocked with volume and dissonance
column30: Come On Die Young disarms with elegance and grace. Even the sudden
column31: eardrum-blasting jolts of Young Team signature “Like Herod” are no comparison to the surprise that occurs when the ominous
column32: pressure-building hum of “Punk Rock:” dissolves into the teary-eyed tranquility of “Cody”
column33:
which sees Mogwai hitch themselves to Galaxie 500’s “Tugboat” and—thanks to a rare and surprisingly affecting lead vocal from guitarist Stuart Braithwaite—produce the most quietly devastating song in their canon to date.

By uncanny coincidence
column34: this 15th-anniversary reissue arrives mere weeks after Slint’s more randomly timed 23rd-anniversary Spiderland box set was released
column35: but revisiting both records in tandem highlights their differences as much as their similarities. Here
column36: Mogwai aren’t so much copying Slint as envisioning the more expansive
column37: exploratory band they could’ve evolved into: “Year 2000 Non-Compliant Cardia” may swipe its jagged opening strums straight from the “Good Morning Captain” playbook
column38: but redirects them into a slumberous
column39: opium-den psychedelia that counts as one of this album’s few moments of levity; “May Nothing But Happiness Come Through Your Door” embellishes the “Cortez the Killer”-inspired lurch of Slint’s “Washer” with glockenspieled counter-melodies and a gradually intensifying climax. And in lieu of creepily whispered Brian McMahan-style narratives
column40: Come On Die Young sees Mogwai deploy found-sound dialogue to equally unnerving effect. The mournful “Helps Both Ways” is interlaced with color commentary from an NFL game
column41: but far from undermining the track’s mournful tone
column42: the chatter enhances it—the song feels like a cathode-ray-lit crime scene
column43:
as if we’re surveying the aftermath of some terrible domestic tragedy while ""Monday Night Football"" unsympathetically blares in the background.

So much instrumental rock music is often described as “soundtracks to movies that don’t exist
column44: ” but Come On Die Young always felt like the unofficial score to a film that did. Four months after the album was released
column46: and my memories of each tend to blur into one: there’s the shared desolate woodlands setting (the album was recorded at Dave Fridmann’s Tarbox Road Studios in Upstate New York) and chilly
column47: frosty-breath atmosphere (thanks to Fridmann’s uncharacteristically stark
column49: never mind the fact that Come On Die Young’s eerie cover shot of bassist Dominic Aitchison could easily pass for a still from the film. And most tellingly
column51: Come On Die Young moves at a slow
column53: incremental pace that can test one’s patience and make one long for the high-voltage immediacy of Young Team
column54: but oh-so gradually ratchets up the tension. The heart-palpitating payoff finally arrives in the form of late-album colossi “Ex-Cowboy” and “Christmas Steps”
column55: which once again see Mogwai charting new extremes of effects-pedal abuse
column56:
but without overwhelming the songs’ expertly chiseled definition.

That sense of discipline is all the more apparent when wading through the bounty of bonus material on this deluxe edition. While none of the demos here differ dramatically from their finished versions
column57: you get a clearer picture of just how much studious fine-tuning went into the final tracklist: in its original form
column58: “Christmas Steps” was a couple of minutes shorter
column59: before the band wisely decided to stretch out its nerve-wracking build-up even longer; a rough-sketch version of “Punk Rock:” suggests even this seemingly simple composition underwent a few passes before achieving the right spectral ambience. (“Hugh Dallas”
column61: would have been a keeper on any other Mogwai release
column62: but its breathy Braithwaite vocal and elegiac sway drift a bit too closely to “Cody”.)

column1: Some supplementary tracks
column2: on the other hand
column3: provide a welcome respite from Come On Die Young’s meticulous approach: the included Travels in Constants
column4: Vol. 12 EP—a limited-edition release for Temporary Residence’s mail-order series—both hearkens back to the post-shoegaze drone of Mogwai’s earliest work
column5: while anticipating the anthemic surges of the subsequent Rock Action. The EP’s mix of tremulous guitar reverberations
column6: flute-like melodies
column7: and pretty piano reveries may boast a decidedly different tenor and texture than Come On Die Young
column8: but are nonetheless a product of that album’s guiding philosophy: For all its seeming ideological alignment with crash-and-burn punk-rock nihilism
column9:
Come On Die Young is the sound of Mogwai committing themselves to the long haul.

When Big Freedia began getting booked on the rock club circuit outside of New Orleans a few years ago
column3: her then largely white
column4: hip-focused audience lacked a specific context for the aggressively glitchy lo-fi electronic music she rapped over—never mind the fact that it was a six-foot-tall
column5: regally poised black person of indeterminate gender who was doing the rapping. To those in the know
column6: there was legitimate concern that her new fan base might have been motivated by the novelty of the latter aspects
column7: but Freedia's powerful
column8: indelible charisma nonetheless transformed rooms full of normally staid indie rockers into a mob of sweaty
column9: ass-shaking maniacs. With a seemingly never-ending series of tour dates and a reality show now entering its second season
column10: it’s clear that Freedia's natural star power
column11: rather than any identity-based quirks
column12: drive her popularity. She’s teetering on the brink of reaching a mainstream audience
column13: and Just Be Free is her attempt to bring her music to that level.

column1: Freedia’s earlier material possessed a redlined sonic aesthetic that matched its manic energy
column2: resembling a drum machine on the verge of a speed-driven breakdown through a maxed-out PA. Its raw
column3: frenetic charge was a good match for her outsider status
column4: but as they’ve charted a course for crossover success
column5: she and longtime producer BlaqNmilD have changed their approach appropriately. With help from producer Thomas McElroy (Madonna
column6: En Vogue)
column7: they’ve reworked Freedia’s trademark sound to make it cleaner
column8: fuller
column9: more nuanced
column10: and more befitting a pop diva.

column1: Much of Just Be Free is aimed squarely at an EDM audience that so far has somehow eluded Freedia
column2: despite the fact that bounce has steadily grown in that world's presence—largely thanks to Diplo and Nicky Da B's “Express Yourself”. “Turn Da Beat Up” expands Freedia’s sonic vocabulary to include Prodigy-style breakbeats
column3: precipitous bass drops
column4: blatting low brass
column5: and a four-on-the-floor breakdown that invokes both house music and arena-rock. “Dangerous” is festooned with filter sweeps
column6: dubsteppy synth bubbles
column7: and sub bass tuned for a large-scale sound systems. “Lift Dat Leg Up” has the epically scaled melody suited for the apex of a big-room DJ set.<span> Most notably
column8: the album’s lead single “Explode” is a riot of overclocked drum machines and Freedia’s joyously hollered commands to lose yourself in her music. Just the idea of hearing it in a DJ set is enough to make you sweat.

column1: As much as Just Be Free is intended to facilitate Freedia’s big break
column2: it doesn’t neglect the fans who’ve followed her up to this point. While she makes some big strides here as an artist
column3:
she’s also made sure to keep one foot planted firmly in the style that some of us consider nearly perfect.

An unspoken ideal behind the quest for below-the-radar music is that somewhere out there
column2: a random stranger might be churning out homemade songs that're better than the ones you can find through more established channels. The methods of discovery
column3: the sub-genre descriptors
column4: and the artist names change
column5: but that faith in some undiscovered loner who defies the odds and draws a diehard following (at least somewhat) independently has remained constant. In 2014
column6: one of the most enticing of these bedroom singer/songwriters is Alex Giannascoli
column7: a Temple University student who has built up an audience through putting material out there on the internet.

column1: Recording as Alex G
column2: the Pennsylvania native's gnarled
column3: wobbly
column4: unfailingly melodic guitar pop evokes Big Star
column5: Elliott Smith
column6: and Built to Spill
column7: as well as more recent low-key breakouts like Youth Lagoon and Jackson Scott. His first-ever mastered full-length
column8: DSU
column9: also happens to be one of the first vinyl releases for Brooklyn's fledgling Orchid Tapes
column10: which already this year has offered the emotion-wracked electronic dreamscapes of Ricky Eat Acid's Three Love Songs
column11: along with the label comp Boring Ecstasy. DSU is worthy of its moment
column12: a 13-song set of warped
column13: idiosyncratic sketches each capable of wending its way to a distinct place into the hearts of anyone who ever warmed to the idea of ""indie rock"".

column1: The elements here are fairly limited
column2: with spidery electric guitar
column3: shambling acoustic guitar
column4: and a smattering of watery keys joining rudimentary bass and drums to frame Giannascoli's sometimes pitch-shifted
column5: fragile coo as he delivers sparse
column6: impressionistic lyrics about the mundane. But what's impressive is the array of potent songs Alex G wrings from those basics
column7: his self-recorded stone soup. There's the strummy innocence (and ambivalence about success) of ""Harvey""
column8: the feedback-streaked pleading of ""Black Hair"" (""It's not what you are/ It's just what you did"")
column9: the barbed howls of ""Axesteel"". But there's also the PBR-spilling post-chillwave groove of ""Promise""
column10: the frosty regret of ""Sorry""
column11: and the stair-spiraling guitar anti-heroics of ""Serpent Is Lord"".

column1: Giannascoli's voice is definitely of his do-it-yourself idiom; a comparison that strikes me is Joan of Arc member Bobby Burg's Love of Everything project
column2: so the arguably superfluous chipmunk'd effects on songs like the cavernous ""Icehead"" will probably be one of the record's more divisive decisions. But it's heartening that Alex G's willing to make off-kilter choices like that one
column3: especially when he veers off into the oddball crackle at the end of ""Rejoyce"". Even the songs that are closer to fragments have memorable turns
column4: like the wordless harmonies of ""Skipper"" or the piano goofing of ""Tripper"".

column1: The most powerfully appealing song on DSU doesn't arrive until the end. ""Boy"" is one of the album's gentler tracks
column2: a stray-dog reflection centered around piano and acoustic guitars; you could almost imagine it as some forgotten post-Beatles remnant that might've appeared on an early Wes Anderson soundtrack. ""I am not the boy you knew
column3: Giannascoli insists. Fact is
column4: he's another in a long line of young people who've found their own weird way to (only slightly) left-of-center acclaim. But his project
column5: like the guy himself
column6: has clearly reached
column7: if not maturity
column8: drinking age at the least. If Alex G keeps it up at this rate
column9:
the next round'll be on him.

White Lung aren’t subtle—but then again
column2: neither is the doorman who assumes every woman with a band is either a groupie or the merch girl. Nor is your average comments section in response to just about any article posted about a female artist. Nor are the standards of physical beauty
column3: relationship dynamics
column4: and personal happiness promulgated by pop culture. Nor is drug addiction. Nor is the #notallmen hashtag. Nor is questioning Sky Ferreira about how much her breasts are responsible for her success
column5: nor are authorities liable to ask “what were you wearing” to every accuser of sexual assault. White Lung’s bracing third LP Deep Fantasy is a product of its environment
column6: that environment being “the real world in 2014
column7: ” filled with people who refuse to be a part of the solution because they won’t even admit there’s a problem.

column1: So
column2: White Lung are not subtle. But Deep Fantasy is definitely savvy
column3: ensuring its staunch ideals are delivered by a riveting
column4: relatable frontwoman and 22 minutes of vicious
column5: compact musicianship and addictive melody. It’s an uncompromising feminist punk record that can be grasped by anyone who finds themselves compelled by kickass rock music and basic human decency.

column1: The importance of White Lung’s potential reach can’t be overstated. Formative influence Courtney Love has specifically expressed hope for White Lung to “achieve some kind of mainstream success”
column2: noting
column3: “It means there are more people listening
column4: and you're affecting the zeitgeist more.”<span style=""font-family: Georgia
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> It’s hard to imagine a rock band of any kind to be allowed the platform that Hole
column6: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">
column7: or even less commercially fortunate acts like L7 and Babes in Toyland
column8: could have two decades ago. However
column9: Deep Fantasy
column10: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> is being put out by the same people responsible for Animal Collective
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">
column12: Real Estate
column13: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> and Arctic Monkeys
column14: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> records.  In 2014
column15: this is the equivalent of a major-label debut.
column16: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">

column1: The result is a best case scenario retaining the accessibility that marked White Lung’s 2012 breakthrough Sorry
column2: while amplifying the parts that translate to a bigger stage. <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column3: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Sorry producer Jesse Gander returns
column4: and he did a pretty good job last time a long-overlooked Vancouver punk band had the opportunity to put everything on the line.  As on Japandroids’ Celebration Rock
column5: the sound of Deep Fantasy is not slick so much as knife-like: piercing
column6: bright
column7: precise and forged under a great amount of pressure.

column1: And it leads with the sharpest part—opening duo “Drown With the Monster” and “Down it Goes” assumes you’ve never heard White Lung before
column2: and they're the best and hookiest demonstrations of what they do. These are doomed
column3: minor-key dirges sped up to the point where they become anthemic
column4: performed at the highest possible velocity where they can still qualify as potential pop. Anticipatory guitar roars are required to take off after Anne-Marie Vassiliou's held cymbal-crash introductions and they keep pace with a rigid
column5: doubled-up hardcore rhythm and fill-free drumming. Mish Way often inverts typical song structure
column6: hanging high notes perilously over sludgy
column7: drop-D chords in the verse while she takes a lower
column8: more menacing and tense register on the choruses. Guitarist Kenneth Williams uses technical precision for texture
column9: as harmonics and high treble flicker like sparks from a buzzsaw against metal.

column1: It’s thrilling
column2: and White Lung don’t do much else from that point on. Even compared to 2014’s other high-profile
column3: high-BPM
column4: sub-half-hour feminist punk LP
column5: Deep Fantasy is sonically blinkered—there are no ballads
column6: no ambient noise instrumentals
column7: and the few seconds of feedback that close the album is about as close as you get to “atmosphere.” White Lung does just about one thing musically on Deep Fantasy
column8: but it's one thing that no one else is doing right now. Though often positioned in the lineage of bands from a time when Lollapalooza was a traveling circus
column9: White Lung are a modern creation
column10: their kohl-streaked punk more Black Sails in the Sunset than Black Flag. Occasionally
column11: the cohesion of Deep Fantasy can be taxing
column12: but for the time being
column13: this is the band taking their sound as far as it can go.

column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Way's lyrics can be just as condensed as the music itself
column3: but they're more like concentrate
column4: expanding on contact and allowing the listener to come up with their own formulation. Considering ""Drown With the Monster""'s nasty snarl of a hook
column5: some poor sap from an energy drink company might try to mindlessly co-opt it for a commercial
column6: which is a tribute to how open-ended “Drown” is; Way struggles with an undefined addiction and never quite says whether she’s giving in
column7: giving up
column8: or giving herself another chance to fight. “Down It Goes” and “Snake Jaw” are likewise dense and comprehensive
column9: touching on the threatening imbalance in sexual pursuit  (“You fear my thick skin/ I’m thinking there’s a knife”)
column10: dysmorphia (""You drag me behind/ Like bitter squirming swine"")
column11: body image (“If I get fat one day
column12: will you run away?/ I’ll starve if you promise to save me”) and disordered eating (""Here comes my dinner now/ It's for the win"").

column1: Deep Fantasy does work best as a multimedia affair; it almost certainly requires its lyric sheet to be understood
column2: and Way’s outside writing supplements her work rather than disenfranchising the listener of their personal interpretation. At Deep Fantasy's center
column3: there’s one song that can be effectively heard as a straightforward demonstration of self-confidence
column4: of friendship
column5: of support. Way explained that it’s the one written as a reaction to rape culture
column6: and it takes on a new
column7: demolishing power upon the realization that its title is the last thing a sexual assault accuser is likely to hear—“I Believe You”.

column1: Just about every aspect of White Lung’s music is aggressive and sounds angry and invective
column2: though “I Believe You” stresses the resonance and empathy; while Way’s philosophical and theoretical leanings might not be considered “mainstream
column3: ” <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column4: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">it’s a compliment to Deep Fantasy
column5: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> to say that none of its calls for dignity
column6: for humanity
column7: for understanding sounds remotely radical—rather
column8: they’re pretty fucking rational. Plenty of people with progressive tastes in politics and pop culture still could reasonably think “feminist punk” (or any political variant of any music) isn’t something they’d necessarily enjoy listening to
column9: and while Hole sold millions of records
column10: surely a great deal had access to their underlying message because they saw “Miss World” jammed between Live and Candlebox videos on MTV. This is principled music
column11: not doctrine
column12: and while inspired by its surroundings
column13: it’s defined by its leader making bracing art. Deep Fantasy is a product of its environment
column14:
as well as one hell of a survival guide to live through this.

Shortly before the halfway point of “Angel”
column3: the eighteen-minute centerpiece of Boris’ latest record
column4: the band's guitarist Wata chases after God. The instrument of her noble pursuit is an extravagant
column5: elegiac solo: her axe weeps and wails like a professional mourner
column6: eventually tearing the surrounding space asunder to allow everything—the dark and the light
column7: the leaden and the featherweight—to rush in. It's this sensation that's earned the Japanese trio a seat at the pantheon of heaviness: this alchemy by which the act of listening to loud rock music is transformed into an encounter with the sublime.

column1: A self-proclaimed “noise” band renowned for Melvins-style sludge and Merzbow collaborations
column2: Boris excel at playing around with magnitudes. But they’re sneakier than they appear: their true calling card isn't brute force
column3: but carefully calculated punishment. The patient approach that Boris took on 2000's Flood indicated that they’d rather have listeners climb the summit slowly
column4: stopping to admire the pretty scenery up to the moment that they hit the precipice and tumble into a free-fall. With the release of their new LP Noise
column5: all of the panoramas the band has crafted over the past two decades—stoner rock
column6: shoegaze
column7: ambient
column8: pop—have coalesced into one massive
column9: smoldering landscape. Eighteen-minute mammoths stride alongside sprightly two-minute cuts
column10: thrash metal pops up out of nowhere to stick a shiv in post-rock’s back. Imposing
column11: insane
column12: and all-over-the-place: in other words
column13: par for Boris' course.

column1: Noise boasts one of the most engaging openers on a Boris album to date: the haunting
column2: and disarmingly catchy “Melody”. The persistent downward pull of the guitars creates a grungy line of tension that the band is all too willing to exploit. Ever wonder what it would sound like if Garbage went avant? Wonder no more: through smooth harmonies and even smoother production
column3: Boris replicates the blueprint of slick alternative rock and then some
column4: both on “Melody” and its craggier cousin “Vanilla”. On the other hand
column5: the limp “wo-oah”s and recycled wasted-youth tropes of “Taiyo no Baka” present irrefutable proof that Boris aren't cut out for pop.

column1: Between the rabid hardcore of the nine-minute “Quicksilver” and the slow
column2: steady suffocation of “Heavy Rain”
column3: fans of Pink and Heavy Rocks will most likely find something to enjoy on Noise. That said
column4: there’s a fine line between drone and fatigue
column5: and at times
column6: Boris get bogged down by the latter on many of the longer songs. Delicate as it may be
column7: even the the final portion of “Angel” can’t help but feel like a slog when it features several minutes of insignificant repetition.

column1: To listeners who are intimidated by the prospect of leaping into the band’s extensive discography
column2: Noise provides a better incentive: as both look back and a step forward
column3: it serves as a possible gateway album
column4: and more intriguingly
column5: it hints at a new chapter in the band’s chameleonic career through which all their scattered points of reference might operate in beautiful
column6:
deadly unison.
