column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20680/homepage_large.24d297e4.jpg|Eccentric Soul: Capitol City Soul|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2014-06-17 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:31.549424|"

Somewhere along the line
column2: Numero Group's focus shifted from reissuing to storytelling. All reissues worth their time and effort manage to put together some kind of insightful narrative
column3: but from the first Eccentric Soul collection onwards
column4: Numero's research and legwork—and their resulting discoveries—have given the label's releases the value of providing a window into the humanity and community inside a scene that exists far beyond what you can hear in the music alone.

column1: The music's no afterthought
column2: of course: all that pavement-pounding
column3: networking
column4: hobnobbing
column5: and intricate packaging has brought out an archival collection of independent vintage soul and R&B practically without rival
column6: from lightning-in-a-bottle one-offs to the gateway-to-fame early moments of household names. But something about the way it's presented in these collections
column7: curation in the truest sense of the word
column8: inspires the kind of deep curiosity and what-if speculation that keeps musical obscurities in demand.

column1: Two of Numero's new releases dig deep into two of the more fascinating stories they've mined in their history—one of them
column2: a heartening followup to their very first collection from 10 years ago; the other
column3: a tumultuous decade-long trip through a label where cops rubbed elbows with numbers runners and a legendary running back was recruited to secure national distro. Both the Capsoul and Way Out labels were based in Ohio
column4: the former in Columbus (hence the ""Cap"" in ""Capsoul"") and the latter up in Cleveland
column5: but these collections' near-concurrent release and Ohio-based commonality hide the fact that both of these collections fascination for entirely different reasons.

column1: Eccentric Soul: Capitol City Soul is notably symbolic—it bears the catalog number of 51
column2: marking the 50th release for the label since 2004's Eccentric Soul: The Capsoul Label. That first collection bore the weight of what then felt like unrealized
column3: long-post potential
column4: right down to the water-damaged photo on the cover; that picture
column5: like most of the comp's material
column6: was <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column7: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">significantly cut down when label head Bill Moss' personal archives were soaked in a friend's basement flood. And yet
column8: after launching renewed interest in the Capsoul label with their first release
column9: Numero's staff discovered that the label's influence was significantly wider in the Columbus area than the scraped-together remnants of Moss' collection even hinted at. Capitol City Soul's 20 tracks include long-lost material by Capsoul acts highlighted on the first collection; four unreleased recordings by the sweet-harmonizing Four Mints and a trio of raw but powerful demos by the balladeers Kool Blues are ideal supplements to the material unearthed 10 years ago.

column1: But the artists that show up here from affiliated labels and other Capsoul-orbiting spots in the local soul circuit make for equally compelling surprises—if not as musicians
column2: then as stories
column3: though usually both. A handful of mid-late '60s tapes by a group called the Chandlers were pulled off the shelves of the still-operating Musicol studio and reveal a band deeply in tune with the Motown sound
column4: yet still operating in a stripped-down mode that foregoes dense orchestration and production for more tight-knit group dynamics. Drummer Dean Francis and his group the Soul Rockers contribute a couple tracks that slot somewhere between Memphis twang/scratch and Bay-to-Georgia brass
column5: with ""Funky Disposition"" providing both the collection's best James Brown analogue and a sketched-out technical diagram loosely outlining the song's accompanying dance move. And in an inspired bit of sequencing
column6: the Soul Partners' Southern-fried
column7: horn-driven deep soul cut ""Lose the One You Love"" and the Vondors' more Midwestern-leaning
column8: harmony-backed cosmopolitan soul number ""Look in the Mirror"" are put back-to-back—they're the same band
column9: wrangled into double duty by Moss to ramp up his chances of getting his label's 45s on the radio. Can't fault a man for being a little dishonest in the service of some solid jams
column10: though.

column1: Where Capitol City Soul serves as a long-brewing second chapter in a previously told story—a chapter that's more beneficial for its exhaustive nature and close focus on a handful of artists than its quality as a front-to-back listen—The Way Out Label is a stranger
column2: more unwieldy
column3: and ultimately more interesting collection. Much is made in the liner notes of Way Out's location in a rough area of Cleveland's east side
column4: where the studio was protected on off hours by a trigger-on-a-string shotgun trap hooked up to a doorknob. Skimming through the archival materials in the liner sends you careening through an abstracted assemblage of vintage R&B history from the tail end of the doo-wop era through the full bloom of psychedelic soul. (The latter is memorably played up by an ad for the Sensations: ""Who knows what sounds lurk in the hearts of men? The Sensations know. They've crossed the time zone deep into the '70s. And listened. Surrender now to the new experience."") And the connections
column5: deals
column6: and discoveries laid out in the liner notes' narrative is a sprawling tour through a succession of unlikely characters: a singer named William Bell who
column7: after his group the Soul Notes disbanded
column8: traveled down to Memphis for a Stax audition and was informed for presumably the first time that they already had a William Bell on their roster; Laura Greene
column9: a singer who jumped from Way Out to a succession of major labels
column10: then to an acting role in Robert Downey
column11: Sr.'s 1969 ad-world spoof Putney Swope before appearing in TV commercials for real; NFL icon Jim Brown
column12: whose financial patronage in helping break Way Out on a wider scale was rewarded with an extremely short-lived vanity label called Big Jim.

column1: And the music on the collection
column2: 40 tracks in all
column3: is just as dizzying in its reach. It runs the gamut from the vintage soul of 1964 sides by Lou Ragland & the Bandmasters—keening
column4: ghostly doo-wop on ""Never Let Me Go""
column5: sax-blasting instrumental house party soundtrack on ""Party at Lester's""—through the waning days of 1972-73 and the valiant attempts by artists like Jesse Fisher (""Why""
column6: ""Don't Cheat on Me"") and Sammy Jones (""You've Got to Show Me""
column7: ""She Didn't Know"") to keep Way Out's pulse beating through velvety loverman grooves. Picking out a peak era for the label is thankfully tricky
column8: as the lush mid-late '60s sides by orchestrally backed vocal group the Sensations
column9: the Soul Notes' sophisticated intensity (get a load of William Bell's breathless out-of-nowhere mid-song narrative on ""I Got Everything I Need"")
column10: and the bittersweet yearning of Bobby Wade's belting on his late early '70s 45s (""Can't You Hear Me Calling""; ""I'm In Love With You""; ""Four Walls and a Window"") all make a case for Way Out's potential to become a sort of Brunswick on the Erie.

column1: Like their Columbus counterpart in Capsoul
column2: Way Out saw its end before the '70s hit their midpoint. And like Capsoul
column3:
they've also been done thorough justice by the kind of archivists who know full well that music doesn't have to reach millions to mean something—especially when it's so easy to hear echoes of other familiar pasts inside it.

column9: Numero's staff discovered that the label's influence was significantly wider in the Columbus area than the scraped-together remnants of Moss' collection even hinted at. Capitol City Soul's 20 tracks include long-lost material by Capsoul acts highlighted on the first collection; four unreleased recordings by the sweet-harmonizing Four Mints and a trio of raw but powerful demos by the balladeers Kool Blues are ideal supplements to the material unearthed 10 years ago.

column1: But the artists that show up here from affiliated labels and other Capsoul-orbiting spots in the local soul circuit make for equally compelling surprises—if not as musicians
column2: then as stories
column3: though usually both. A handful of mid-late '60s tapes by a group called the Chandlers were pulled off the shelves of the still-operating Musicol studio and reveal a band deeply in tune with the Motown sound
column4: yet still operating in a stripped-down mode that foregoes dense orchestration and production for more tight-knit group dynamics. Drummer Dean Francis and his group the Soul Rockers contribute a couple tracks that slot somewhere between Memphis twang/scratch and Bay-to-Georgia brass
column5: with ""Funky Disposition"" providing both the collection's best James Brown analogue and a sketched-out technical diagram loosely outlining the song's accompanying dance move. And in an inspired bit of sequencing
column6: the Soul Partners' Southern-fried
column7: horn-driven deep soul cut ""Lose the One You Love"" and the Vondors' more Midwestern-leaning
column8: harmony-backed cosmopolitan soul number ""Look in the Mirror"" are put back-to-back—they're the same band
column9: wrangled into double duty by Moss to ramp up his chances of getting his label's 45s on the radio. Can't fault a man for being a little dishonest in the service of some solid jams
column10: though.

column1: Where Capitol City Soul serves as a long-brewing second chapter in a previously told story—a chapter that's more beneficial for its exhaustive nature and close focus on a handful of artists than its quality as a front-to-back listen—The Way Out Label is a stranger
column2: more unwieldy
column3: and ultimately more interesting collection. Much is made in the liner notes of Way Out's location in a rough area of Cleveland's east side
column4: where the studio was protected on off hours by a trigger-on-a-string shotgun trap hooked up to a doorknob. Skimming through the archival materials in the liner sends you careening through an abstracted assemblage of vintage R&B history from the tail end of the doo-wop era through the full bloom of psychedelic soul. (The latter is memorably played up by an ad for the Sensations: ""Who knows what sounds lurk in the hearts of men? The Sensations know. They've crossed the time zone deep into the '70s. And listened. Surrender now to the new experience."") And the connections
column5: deals
column6: and discoveries laid out in the liner notes' narrative is a sprawling tour through a succession of unlikely characters: a singer named William Bell who
column7: after his group the Soul Notes disbanded
column8: traveled down to Memphis for a Stax audition and was informed for presumably the first time that they already had a William Bell on their roster; Laura Greene
column9: a singer who jumped from Way Out to a succession of major labels
column10: then to an acting role in Robert Downey
column11: Sr.'s 1969 ad-world spoof Putney Swope before appearing in TV commercials for real; NFL icon Jim Brown
column12: whose financial patronage in helping break Way Out on a wider scale was rewarded with an extremely short-lived vanity label called Big Jim.

column1: And the music on the collection
column2: 40 tracks in all
column3: is just as dizzying in its reach. It runs the gamut from the vintage soul of 1964 sides by Lou Ragland & the Bandmasters—keening
column4: ghostly doo-wop on ""Never Let Me Go""
column5: sax-blasting instrumental house party soundtrack on ""Party at Lester's""—through the waning days of 1972-73 and the valiant attempts by artists like Jesse Fisher (""Why""
column6: ""Don't Cheat on Me"") and Sammy Jones (""You've Got to Show Me""
column7: ""She Didn't Know"") to keep Way Out's pulse beating through velvety loverman grooves. Picking out a peak era for the label is thankfully tricky
column8: as the lush mid-late '60s sides by orchestrally backed vocal group the Sensations
column9: the Soul Notes' sophisticated intensity (get a load of William Bell's breathless out-of-nowhere mid-song narrative on ""I Got Everything I Need"")
column10: and the bittersweet yearning of Bobby Wade's belting on his late early '70s 45s (""Can't You Hear Me Calling""; ""I'm In Love With You""; ""Four Walls and a Window"") all make a case for Way Out's potential to become a sort of Brunswick on the Erie.

column1: Like their Columbus counterpart in Capsoul
column2: Way Out saw its end before the '70s hit their midpoint. And like Capsoul
column3:
they've also been done thorough justice by the kind of archivists who know full well that music doesn't have to reach millions to mean something—especially when it's so easy to hear echoes of other familiar pasts inside it.

Indie label heads and music scribes alike might rail against the increasingly ludicrous reissue trend
column2: wherein the past obfuscates the present—or rather
column3: the past blocks out the present on 180 gram pink splatter vinyl—but it continues unabated. Reissue culture tilts critical scales and gums up record pressing plants
column4: and it’s not enough now to simply reissue a forgotten album and allow it bask in the spotlight of public consciousness for one fleeting moment more. Forgotten records–no matter how obscure—now receive additional adornment in the form of feature-length documentaries
column5: reunion tours
column6: and demo-scraping follow-ups
column7: all wringing out every last drop of interest in the original record.

column1: When LITA reissued Sixto Rodriguez’s two studio albums back in 2008
column2: it sparked an Academy-winning documentary film and countless sold-out stadium shows. Drag City unearthed the raw power of Death
column3: which led to a documentary
column4: a tour with the surviving members
column5: and two more demo-scraping albums. It’s but two examples of this exhaustive trend. Donnie & Joe Emerson
column6: the two rural Washington farm boys who had a log cabin studio replete with “Camp Jammin’” concert venue built for the teen boys to realize their musical vision in
column7: were beneficiaries of this reissue trend as well. And the reissue of forgotten homemade album
column8: Dreamin’ Wild
column9: was well-deserved
column10: meaning that some four decades after having that dream go unrealized
column11: the brothers got to play their first-ever live shows in Seattle and New York City.

column1: Still Dreamin’ Wild: The Lost Recordings 1979-81 presents that secondary stage of reissue culture
column2: culling demos in the years after the younger Emerson graduated high school and began traveling to Los Angeles in the hopes of realizing his teenage dreams. Older brother Joe was already turning his attentions to the family farm
column3: his presence only heard on two of the album’s twelve tracks. Donnie’s polymath musical skills are on full display
column4: from drums to poly-Moog synth
column5: and his ability to mimic the more popular hits on the radio of the day remains uncanny.

column1: While Dreamin’ Wild seemed to float just out of its time
column2: Still Dreamin’ for the most part embraces the tropes of early '80s pop radio. Had “Overture” lasted beyond a half-minute
column3: it might have been a lost Panda Bear track
column4: but it instead leads into the clean guitars and drums of “Don’t Fight.” The uptempo “Big Money”
column5: featuring brother Joe’s walloping drums
column6: is an album highlight
column7: even if it only lasts two minutes.

column1: That perceived “songs of innocence” sentiment of Dreamin’ Wild is tempered a bit here. “Ride the Tide” is about a lady in Los Angeles who comes and goes
column2: a surfer girl who toys with the country boy’s heart. Donnie’s layered vocals convey that sense of confusion and heartbreak
column3: but the chintzy synth line and tinny drums undercut it. Same goes for “Everybody Knows It”
column4: whose synth presets border on karaoke backing track. The guitar tone of “Ooh Baby Yeah” evokes Big Star for a moment
column5: before it smoothes out into a pedestrian oldies track.

column1: Rather than the wonder and sincere ache of something like “My Heart” or “Baby” from Dreamin’ Wild
column2: the album too often brings up memories of treacly early '80s AOR
column3: from Don Henley to Jackson Browne to Kenny Loggins. That isn't inherently a bad thing: In another world
column4: I can envision Donnie Emerson opening for the likes of the War on Drugs
column5: who similarly take the most cringeworthy of '80s productions styles and amalgamate them into something transcendent. In the review of 'Dreamin Wild
column6: I cited the likes of Chuck Mangione
column7: Bread
column8: and Boz Scaggs
column9: but this time around
column10:
these songs fail to transcend such influences.

column9: more

column11: four years) having taken on perhaps the single-most common form of non-American dance-rock hybrids: that of <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eFuE-thYZ1A"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Don’t Fight It
column12: Feel It” shamanism. The song titles could pass for Madchester Successories—“Children of the Sun”
column13: “A New Reality”
column14: “Invisible Forces”
column15: “There is No Other Time”. Just by scanning the tracklist
column16: you know what to expect.

column1: Beyond the lack of imagination
column2: Love Frequency is a baggy record regardless of which definition you prefer
column3: whether it’s hearkening to “Loose Fit” or just the way their previously punchy hooks have been swapped out for paunchy beats. Synthesized drums bang with almost no variation for up to five minutes at a time
column4: an introductory chorus explains the song’s title before shifting to a custodial
column5: time-killing verse—and then it returns in time to remind you which song is “Show Me a Miracle” and which one is “Invisible Forces”. It’s pointless to quote the lyrics at length
column6: not because they’re ridiculous
column7: but because they’re not ridiculous enough to generate the kind of conviction you need to pull this stuff off. Reynolds sings
column8: “We’re the masters of distraction/ In a time of hyperaction” on “A New Reality”
column9: and it's unclear as to whether Klaxons want to be part of the problem or part of the solution
column10: or whether they have any idea of what they’re trying to get across.

column1: Though a coterie of name producers were involved here—Chemical Brother Tom Rowlands
column2: James Murphy
column3: and Erol Alkan—their contributions are imperceptible here without the credits at hand. You could wager a guess by way of the songs' individual tempos and when the rhythms are cranked
column4: Love Frequency is at least enjoyable in a functional way. And maybe functionality and depersonalization is the endgame. Klaxons aspire for elemental sentiments by using elemental imagery—qualities available to everyone and belonging to nobody
column5: not the least of all Klaxons. The sawtoothed synths on opener “A New Reality” and the curious Earth
column6: Wind & Fire harmonies throughout are brief allusions to the fact that you are listening to a Klaxons album and not any number of E-popping revivalists. Otherwise
column7: there’s barely any trace of Klaxons on Love Frequency
column8: and that's a strange complaint when the best songs here are the ones where the band come closest to disappearing completely
column9: as on instrumental “Liquid Light” and the muted
column10: distant shuffle of “The Dreamers”.

column1: Love Frequency isn’t a complete disaster
column2: if only because the new
column3: chastised
column4: and chaste Klaxons aren’t really capable of doing anything that could inspire that sort of animus. At their best
column5: Klaxons dredge up the kind of sounds that keep the Coachella Sahara Tent bumping all weekend
column6: composed to be aggressive and participatory
column7: yet strangely ambient and easy to ignore. At its worst
column8: it’s the kind of hi-BPM
column9: lo-IQ
column10: alt-electro inanities that are responsible for filling the lineup of KROQ's Weenie Roast and will make you seriously reconsider your position on Coldplay and Avicii’s “A Sky Full of Stars”.  For the most part
column11: Klaxons spend most of their time in between
column12:
a frequency stuck between stations.

Dutch producer Martijn Deykers' debut album as Martyn
column2: 2009's Great Lengths
column3: marked him immediately as a synthesist
column4: the album serving as a flash point in bass music's adoption of more traditional rhythms and structures. Deykers has since fashioned himself into a bit of a dance music vagabond
column5: moving freely between labels and styles while running his 3024 imprint. He's part of the firmament of underground dance music at this point
column6: something he's accomplished largely by sticking his fingers in a lot of pies. His third full-length
column7: The Air Between Words
column8: finds him on yet another label
column9: Ninja Tune
column10: and continues his move toward big
column11: melodic structures.

column1: Since Great Lengths
column2: fans and critics have gone well out of their way to note how little Deykers has to do with dubstep. They've spent less time defining just what Deykers is making these days
column3: in large part because it's difficult to pin down just where his work settles. His productions are robust and melodic
column4: with table-setter percussion making way for ropey basslines and quivering pads. While nothing here qualifies as an anthem or a banger
column5: Deyker's productions exhibit enviable power and finesse.

column1: In this way Deykers' work is growing closer to the type of sumptuous techno peddled by Detroit legends such as Derrick May and Carl Craig
column2: both artists who made big-room tracks for small-room DJs. It's a style that has found more success in Europe than in the United States for decades
column3: which makes Deykers a classicist
column4: if not a nostalgist; certainly
column5: The Air Between Words is his most conventional work.

column1: Deykers will occasionally employ percussive vocal samples
column2: offering up shouts on ""Empty Mind"" and dubby luxury on ""Like That"" (an easy candidate for a single). ""Drones"" slips into the type of insouciant jazz-house Theo Parrish popularized; ""Two Leads and a Computer"" is punchy
column3: modern aceeid. A collaboration with outre troubadour Copeland
column4: ""Love of Pleasure""
column5: is gently sour
column6: a fine follow up to Great Lengths' vocal triumph
column7: ""These Words"". ""Glassbeadgames""
column8: which finds Four Tet adding his usual pinch of beatific prettiness
column9: is more basic.

column1: Deykers has a professional's range and thoroughness
column2: sometimes to the detriment of his albums. The Air Between Words fails to establish a coherent mood
column3: perhaps the single most important task for a dance music album. And while Deykers is no mimic
column4: it's difficult to locate a distinct personality in his work
column5: a problem that also plagued 2011's Ghost People. The spark that Great Lengths' friction yielded is missing
column6: and without it
column7: he's just making some tracks. Good tracks
column8: no doubt
column9: but tracks that have failed to establish meaningful context. So it's also difficult not to feel disappointed by The Air Between Words
column10: a solid
column11:
conventional effort by an artist who once seemed so vital.

Young and in the Way came raging out of Charlotte
column2: NC in 2009 with the independently-released Newborn EP
column3: and have been steadily gathering steam ever since. They've been aligned with Baltimore hardcore stronghold A389 since 2011's breakout I Am Not What I Am and have settled comfortably into a niche within the new breed of metallic hardcore that references Entombed and Avskum instead of
column4: say
column5: Botch or Converge. The band's newest recording has found a home on Converge frontman Jacob Bannon's Deathwish label
column6: a pairing that makes sense: along with the cover art's sleek black and white design scheme and a fixation on occult imagery
column7: the association cements YAITW’s nebulous status as a band making black metal for hardcore kids.

column1: When Life Comes to Death is the band’s fourth album
column2: and it seems like they've finally figured out how to properly wield the cluster of influences they flirt with: Swedish hardcore punk
column3: chunks of spit-shined metallic hardcore
column4: and a few different flavors of black metal. The scarcity of d-beats and overall lack of grime torpedoes the band’s professed allegiance to “blackened crust

column1: YAITW have indeed upped their game
column2: especially in terms of incorporating black metal into their sound; what's more
column3: the depressive tendencies of their earlier work have been upgraded to blistering fury. The rollicking grimness of album highlight “Loved and Unwanted” owes plenty to Scandinavian black metal
column4: “Fuck This Life” flaunts the band’s excellent grasp on the genre’s cold
column5: aggressive side
column6: and “Self Inflicted” hinges on murky melodies. The three members clearly know what they’re doing and what they want to accomplish
column7: and it’s not surprising that they each play in more straight-up grindcore and black metal bands on the side. It’s typical of American extreme metal’s proclivity towards intermingling
column8: and that melting pot approach breeds stronger
column9: more interesting results than clinging to orthodoxy yields.

column1: When Life Comes to Death is homogenous as a whole
column2: but its second half throws a few curveballs that go a long way towards livening up this death-obsessed manifesto. “We Are Nothing” is slow and sickly with moments of triumphal melodic intensity
column3: while “Take My Hand” is quiet and desperate as the vocalist begs to be left alone. There’s not much room for weakness or emotion in either hardcore punk or black metal
column4: space that YAITW try to carve out—but it doesn’t always work. The atmospheric
column5: acoustic “Shadow of Murder” aims to be a sombre
column6: haunting affair but ultimately feels like a failed experiment; the clean vocals are stilted
column7: and the timing feels off as riffs bump into one another. It's encouraging to see them explore this kind of sound
column8: but if they’re serious about incorporating such elements into their sound
column9: they’ve got a long way to go. After that
column10: album closer “Embrace Extinction” is a dirgelike hardcore epic
column11: stomping through nearly ten minutes without leaving much of an impression either way.

column1: As solid as the music generally is
column2: much about YAITW feels calculated and contrived
column3: from their slick aesthetic and Watain rip-off logo to the name itself
column4: which pegs them as a swaggering millennial answer to the Dischord bands of old. They’re just a minor threat
column5: no matter how badly they want to be seen as the poster children for evil
column6: crusty black metal.  Their music is interesting
column7: creative
column8: but ultimately safe
column9:
a fine introduction to the dark arts that shouldn’t be taken as gospel.

If you need proof that ""bad press"" as a concept is largely a thing of the past
column4: look no further than Death Grips. The shifting collective—sometimes a trio
column5: occasionally a duo
column6: and at one point consisting of no members at all—have spent the last two years staging a public
column7: low-level coup on people's attention spans that
column8: in terms of subversiveness
column9: has fallen somewhere between egging someone's house and stealing your neighbor's WiFi. Their actions have scanned as humorous
column10: aggressive
column11: contemptible
column12: and puerile—sometimes all at once—and despite any high-minded claims
column13: the ends to the means have been excellent promotion for a body of work that's proved increasingly confounding. Their first record
column14: 2011's Exmilitary
column15: remains their most overlooked work even as it represents Death Grips at their most elemental
column16: a potent
column17: nasty mix of blasted rap figures
column18: percussive mania
column19: and corroded noise that smacked of a modern-day Judgment Night soundtrack featuring collaborations beteween Dälek and Lightning Bolt.

column1: A year later
column2: Death Grips returned with The Money Store
column3: a dizzying rush of an album with a title that likely referenced the group's short-lived major-label contract with Epic. At the time
column4: band mastermind Zach Hill—a veteran drummer who
column5: after a decade-plus of alternating between the roles of reliable sideman and unsung noise-scene hero
column6: has undoubtedly benefited the most from Death Grips' notoriety—claimed that label honcho L.A. Reid air-drummed to the band's music upon signing and compared them to Whitney Houston. The former is a funny image
column7: the latter ostensibly a tasteless joke
column8: but upon engaging with <i>The Money Store
column9: all attendant information becomes irrelevant. A thrilling document of puckered melody and blue-screen-of-death chaos that stands as the project's strongest release to date
column10: The Money Store resembled the revolting
column11: ultra-violent conclusion to director Nicolas Winding Refn's Pusher films: a dead body hung upside down
column12: its contents drained and shoved into a garbage disposal.

column1: Later that year
column2: NO LOVE DEEP WEB arrived without warning and free of charge
column3: triggering a well-documented war between Death Grips and their cash-flow overlords. Quite possibly the most dissonant album ever recorded at the Chateau Marmont
column4: NO LOVE DEEP WEB found Death Grips doubling down on sonic viscera. It's a thick
column5: sludgy record in which the group's wild-eyed mouthpiece Stefan Burnett sounds like he's trapped in hell
column6: dragging himself through a landscape of destruction. Rather than capitalize on the comparatively bright accessibility of The Money Store
column7: it suggested Death Grips were prepared to get weirder. Last year's Government Plates headed even further into left-of-center territory
column8: drawing inspiration from the glitchy terror of IDM's more aggressive elements.

column1: Like its predecessor
column2: Government Plates was released suddenly for nothing—and so it goes
column3: too
column4: with Niggas on the Moon
column5: the project's latest missive that arrived last Sunday evening. An eight-track release that stands as Death Grips' shortest effort to date
column6: Niggas on the Moon comes bearing a title that possibly references Gil Scott-Heron
column7: along with claims of a high-profile collaborator: Björk
column8: who's no stranger when it comes to working with inhumanly talented drummers from the noise scene.

column1: But nothing is quite as it seems in Death Grips' world
column2: so within 24 hours of Niggas on the Moon's release it emerged that rumors of Björk's contributions may have been greatly exaggerated. ""i am proud to announce my vocals landed on the new death grips album !"" she exclaimed in an official statement the day after Niggas on the Moon dropped. ""i adore death grips and i am thrilled to be their 'found object' !"" The phrase ""found object"" suggests that she wasn't so much an active artistic partner as much as a passive supplier of source material
column3: another sound thrown into Death Grips' culture-wiping meat grinder. Her presence on the album is
column4: similar to Venus Williams' guttural cries sampled on The Money Store cut ""System Blower""
column5: mangled and distorted beyond recognition.

column1: Whether Björk's presence is the result of Death Grips' sampling her previous work or her providing fresh vocal takes for the band's disposal
column2: Death Grips largely lean on her propensity for ecstatic crescendos. On ""Have a Sad Cum"" and album closer ""Big Dipper""
column3: her cries are looped in perpetuity
column4: producing a hallucinatory effect not unlike the trippy repetition of Chicago footwork; ""Billy Not Really"" opens with a perpetual build anchored by glottal coos
column5: while ""Say Hey Kid"" opens with hyperspeed bass-and-drums a la Squarepusher before twisting Björk's voice into what sounds like panpipes
column6: over a bed of rustling electronics.

column1: Death Grips have remixed Björk before. They contributed takes on ""Sacrifice"" and ""Thunderbolt""
column2: two songs taken from her 2011 album Biophilia
column3: to 2012's remix collection Bastards; their remix of the former tune is especially notable in that it recycles the march-of-death bassline from ""System Blower"". Similarly
column4: Niggas on the Moon finds Death Grips drawing from themselves rather than pushing things forward
column5: a deviation from their mission statement. Anyone familiar with the band's mix of aggressive electronics
column6: barked non-sequiturs
column7: and collapsing song structures will find plenty to like here. After three years of aiming to confuse and shock
column8: Death Grips are approaching reliability
column9: and the presence of truly thrilling moments has decreased accordingly.

column1: Complacency doesn't suit Death Grips very well
column2: but Niggas on the Moon's high points suggest regardless that
column3: for now
column4: Death Grips-as-Death Grips occasionally yields satisfying results. Opener ""Up My Sleeves"" is a prime slice of mania that
column5: should the band ever release a ""Greatest Hits"" collection (imagine that)
column6: would fit right in with their highest highs. ""Black Quarterback"" possesses a gleeful skip punctuated by inside-out percussion that hits like repeated punches to the abdomen; the processional gait of ""Big Dipper"" sounds like poisoned marching-band music
column7: as Burnett throws out bon mots that highlight Death Grips' still-undervalued sense of humor: ""I'm a bullshitter/ I'm a shitty stripper...I'm a fucking downer.""

column1: As a vocalist and lyricist
column2: Burnett draws strength from his surroundings. When chaos engulfs him
column3: he thrives on the energy; during Death Grips' more downtempo moments
column4: he sounds adrift
column5: his anti-sloganeering coming off as ridiculous and deflated
column6: his audience laughing at rather than with him. Niggas on the Moon is
column7: as a whole
column8: Death Grips' least intense album
column9: which doesn't work in Burnett's favor. Many of the record's songs have midsections that dial down the intensity before revving up again
column10: and while Burnett's phonetic emphasis occasionally pulls him through
column11: elsewhere he sounds listless. Death Grips achieve potency when sounding frantic
column12: untamed
column13: and unstable; Niggas on the Moon's more subdued moments
column14: comparatively
column15: resemble a brisk walk on a treadmill
column16: and as a result it's less immediate than their previous work.

column1: With the arrival of Niggas on the Moon came the news that the record is part of a forthcoming double-album
column2: The Powers That B
column3: set for release later this year on the band's own label
column4: Third Worlds
column5: as well as Harvest
column6: a subsidiary of major-label entity Capitol. Death Grips are
column7: indeed
column8: featured on Harvest's website
column9: so their second flirtation with the music industry's explicitly corporate arena seems to be as structurally legitimate as their first time around—then again
column10: this is a band that prides itself on the capability to catch its audience off guard
column11: so who knows how the rest of the year will play out for them.

column1: With Niggas on the Moon
column2: though
column3: it's hard to shake the feeling that Death Grips might benefit from a change in aesthetic and conceptual focus. Even setting aside the creative stasis the music embodies
column4: the major-label affiliations and surprise-release gimmick produces a stale whiff of deja vu. Without new tricks and fresh aggression
column5: Death Grips risk coming across as safe and ordinary
column6:
a mess of broken teeth summarily replaced by a gap-toothed smile.

Julianna Barwick’s Rosabi EP was created in collaboration with Dogfish Head Brewery
column2: a fact that feels strange to type. There's nothing new or particularly notable about smaller artists from independent music partnering with brands from another sphere
column3: but the Barwick/Dogfish meeting feels weird regardless. Her music
column4: built on her ultra-ethereal voice and treated and looped into what can resemble hymns
column5: seems so private and intimate and
column6: for lack of a better word
column7: “pure” (to borrow the title of the first song here). Also
column8: her career seems modest in terms of sales and her profile
column9: so notions of brand synergy are
column10: from one angle
column11: counterintuitive.

column1: Whatever the case
column2: the pairing hasn’t altered Barwick’s approach to music. The one concession to the partnership is that elements recorded inside the brewery have been added to the compositions—you can hear some background banging
column3: hissing
column4: and rattling here and there
column5: but small touches like these have been present in Barwick’s music on her last two full-lengths. So unless you get the limited 10"" edition that comes with bottles of Dogfish’s contribution
column6: there’s no real reason to think of this as anything other than a new Julianna Barwick release.

column1: Indeed
column2: Rosabi sounds very much like music by Julianna Barwick
column3: which
column4: for fans
column5: is a comforting thought. It doesn’t have the added instrumentation of the last two releases and is comparatively stripped down—an approach that's closer to her earlier
column6: pre-studio work—but the overall effect is identical: gorgeous repeating vocals forming a cozy bed underneath Barwick’s melodic flourishes. Her records are such that individual tracks will jump out at certain people based on a personal memory or association
column7: not because any one song necessarily is “better” than another. The fact that a sound so uniform can move different people in different ways speaks to why Barwick’s work can feel so close—you really do hear it and go into yourself. For me
column8: that highlight is the closing “Blood Brothers”
column9: whose repeating “da-do-da-da” refrain just guts me
column10: even if I can’t quite put a finger on why.

column1: As much as I love letting Rosabi wash over me
column2: it also raises some interesting questions about what happens when an artist continues with an aesthetic they’ve more or less perfected. There’s no real reason to think that Julianna Barwick couldn’t keep making lovely music that sounds something like this for the rest of her life
column3: and there’s also no reason to think I wouldn’t continue to listen to and enjoy each new release in turn. But does that mean that as long as she stays on this path it’s impossible for her to fail? Does that matter? Is “growth” something she can concern herself with
column4: or not
column5: as I continue to enjoy what she comes up with? How will I distinguish between Barwick releases and what will inform my decision to play one instead of another? It’s a lot to think about
column6: and I enjoy pondering these questions
column7:
especially while having this 16-minute slice of simple beauty on repeat. Eventually I’ll try enjoying a beer while doing so and see how that goes.

Los Angeles trio clipping. are a collaboration between rapper Daveed Diggs and producers Jonathan Snipes and William Hutson. Snipes is a sound designer
column2: film composer
column3: and experimental musician who records <span><span>glitchy
column4: snarky pop-deconstructionist noise music under the name Captain Ahab; he and Hutson are in the noise band Unnecessary Surgery
column5: and co-created the score for the recent documentary Room 237. Initially
column6: clipping. made power electronics-influenced remixes of rap songs
column7: a formula that they stuck fairly close to when they recorded their 2013 debut Midcity after recruiting Diggs to provide original vocals.

column1: Their second album
column2: clppng
column3: opens with a solid minute of the kind of dissonant
column4: legitimately painful high-pitched feedback that sadistic noise guitarists favor
column5: along with some vigorous cypher-style spitting. It’s a clear provocation and a quick primer on the group’s aesthetic aim
column6: which is to deconstruct rap music while staying within the genre's confines—and it’s also a summation of the group’s two major flaws
column7: which are that the tracks go just a little too far in their eagerness to challenge their audience and the raps they’re sharing space with are too banal to make the challenge worth it.

column1: Snipes and Hutson are good at coming up with uniquely weird
column2: aggressive sounds. In interviews
column3: they’ve stressed that they begin with a clear idea of how their songs will sound and feel
column4: and that meticulousness is evident on CLPPNG
column5: like on the interplay between a suffocatingly dense bass synth and roomy
column6: bell-like metallic samples on “Work Work”. The duo frequently embrace oddball samples that sound like they were pulled from field recordings; a judiciously edited instrumental version of CLPPNG could make for an interesting contemporary take on musique concrete.

column1: When it comes to turning those sounds into proper rap songs
column2: clipping. falter. There are a few moments where their approach pays off
column3: offering an appealingly mutated version of the more commercial-leaning rap they used as source material in their earlier efforts. “Work Work” resembles a shroomy hallucination of a DJ Mustard beat complete with a verse by Cocc Pistol Cree
column4: who coincidentally appeared on Mustard’s mixtape manifesto from last year
column5: Ketchup. “Tonight
column6: ” featuring Gangsta Boo
column7: pairs a two-note synth part that could have been pulled from an Atlanta rap mixtape with a fascinatingly bizarre electronic gurgle that sounds like a synthesizer’s death rattle.

column1: More often
column2: though
column3: clipping.'s deconstructionist impulses run wild
column4: as the group ignores some of the more crucial elements a rap beat needs. Most of these songs have tediously static arrangements
column5: including “Get Up”
column6: which uses an alarm clock beep as a rhythmic synth lead but fails to build on the conceit; the result sounds like an alarm clock going off for three whole minutes
column7: which isn’t something most people want to hear. Many tracks don’t have proper drum parts
column8: which speaks to the group's tendency to prioritize experimentation over cohesiveness.

column1: It's possible that a capable MC might have balanced CLPPNG's deficiencies
column2: but Diggs is far from capable. His backpacker-y flow sounds shopworn compared to the radically out-there beats
column3: and his lyricism is lacking overall; hip-hop may be a massively self-referential genre
column4: but the fact that nearly every track has at least one reference to an older Top 40 rap song seems like a grab for borrowed interest. Considering clipping.'s left-of-center style
column5: he’s not particularly weird
column6: and the persona that he projects—smart and misanthropic—is muddled at best. Overall
column7: CLPPNG is chock full of ideas
column8: and if its failure is due to overambitiousness
column9: well
column10:
there are worse ways to fail.

"|19431.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19431-clipping-clppng/|5.6|Miles Raymer

Consistency in art is a laudable goal
column2: but also a risky one. Do the same thing over and over
column3: no matter how well
column4: and some will file you away as easily understood
column5: even predictable. This is a bigger hazard when your chosen style itself relies on consistency. Take ambient drone: it’s all about held tones
column6: sounds that change slowly (if at all) and demand patient focus. It’s easy to let ambient drone drift into the background
column7: presumably safe in the assumption that it won’t suprise you.

column1: So it's easy to take an artist like Kyle Bobby Dunn for granted. He’s made music for 12 years
column2: and it’s all been ambient drone. It could be assumed that listening to just one of his albums is all you need to understand his art; he’s even encouraged that assumption by naming one of his stronger albums A Young Person’s Guide to Kyle Bobby Dunn. But all of his releases are worthwhile
column3: and even if his consistency isn’t flashy or surprising
column4: it’s rare. He’s continually found new ideas using the same sturdy M.O.

column1: This doesn’t mean his records are all of equal quality: a few transcend his standard level
column2: pushing his sound up to a singular plane
column3: and Kyle Bobby Dunn and the Infinite Sadness is one of those records. There are a lot of reasons why
column4: one of them simple to comprehend: the songs are pretty short. Though the album lasts two hours
column5: most of its 19 tracks hover in the range of five minutes
column6: and only two are longer than ten
column7: which gives the music extra urgency. Often Dunn gets right to the point
column8: setting each piece’s structure quickly and succinctly
column9: rarely messing with extended intros or sitting on a single idea for long. It’s not that his work here is more “song-like” than before—it’s just more focused
column10: more laser-like in the way it hits its marks.

column1: This focus has the added benefit of making the album’s few long pieces more effective. By carefully picking his spots
column2: Dunn earns the right to stretch out when his ideas deserve it. The nine-minute “Variation on a Theme by St. Dipshit” (Dunn has a healthy knack for piss-taking titles) feels grand in a subtle
column3: almost humble way
column4: its high-pitched waves unfurling with patience but no stasis. The album’s best piece
column5: the ten-minute “Where Circles Never Become Circles”
column6: offers an elongated crescendo that grows at exactly the right pace; it would sound gratuitous if it reached its heights more rapidly.

column1: Gratuitousness is always a danger with ambient drone; it’s easy
column2: and often tempting
column3: to go for a dramatic chord or a soundtrack-ready swell without the setup needed for a true payoff. But it’s just as easy to hold back and let the music become mechanical and bloodless
column4: more conceptually admirable than emotionally engaging. Dunn knows how to find a range between those two poles
column5: and here never loses sight of that rareified middle ground. Often he gets there through simplicity: take the binary rhythm of “Duck-Faced Fantasy”
column6: the small variances of “Boring Foothills of Foot Fetishville”
column7: or the gradual crest of “On Top of Timeless Hour.” At their best
column8: those tracks suggest moods and images
column9: but also offer open shapes for the listener to fill in.

column1: The fact that Dunn can keep his sound so open after honing it for so long isn't really surprising
column2: but it’s still impresssive. You may know what got him to this point
column3: you may be able to guess what this record sounds like
column4: at least on the surface
column5:
and you may even have a line on what he’ll do in the future—but Kyle Bobby Dunn & the Infinite Sadness is proof that even the most consistent artists can still impress.

"|19379.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19379-kyle-bobby-dunn-kyle-bobby-dunn-and-the-infinite-sadness/|7.8|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20589/homepage_large.446d0e2e.jpg|Symmetry in Black|32287.0|Crowbar|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Entertainment One']|2014-06-13 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:40.026282|"

Crowbar are pioneers of the New Orleans sludge sound
column2: driven by doom metal and hard Southern living
column3: and as such
column4: they aren't immune to drama. Vocalist and guitarist Kirk Windstein
column5: the band's only consistent member
column6: has struggled with drinking issues throughout the band's two-decade existence and recently left Down
column7: his longtime project with former Pantera vocalist Phil Anselmo
column8: Eyehategod's Jimmy Bower (who also drummed for Crowbar at one point)
column9: and ex-Corrosion of Conformity guitarist Pepper Keenan. Despite the internal strife
column10: Crowbar have always managed to sound more straightforward than their peers
column11: and that's still evident in their latest LP
column12: Symmetry in Black.

column1: Their last album
column2: 2011's Sever The Wicked Hand
column3: found Crowbar warming themselves back up after a six-year recording hiatus
column4: so Symmetry is the sound of the band back in the saddle. Lead single “Walk With Knowledge Wisely” sums up the essence of Crowbar—chunky sludge riffs
column5: thrash breaks
column6: bluesy leads
column7: and Windstein giving his inner demons room to frolic. The hardcore breakdown at the song's end speaks to Crowbar's influence on modern hardcore groups like Xibalba and Harms Way
column8: and their status as genre forebears shines through via Symmetry's crunchy production.

column1: “Reflection of Deceit” is an improvement on Wicked's “Let Me Mourn”—the opening riff is more grandiose
column2: the production breathes life into the song
column3: and Windstein sounds even more mournful than before. His voice sounds older than it does on Crowbar's earlier records; given the band's themes and sounds
column4: this works in their favor. He achieves what radio-rock bands can't do—that is
column5: incorporate clean vocals without coming off as over-dramatic.

column1: Even for an album that's a chronicle of personal trials
column2: Black ends on a particularly bleak note with “The Piety of Self-Loathing
column3: ” an instrumental track that's reminiscent of “Nothing”
column4: a song from 1996's Broken Glass that still stands as one of the most depressing songs Crowbar's ever made. The mood is overtly lachrymose
column5: boarding all the windows up so that no sunlight can break the darkness.<span style=""text-decoration: none;""> Whereas most Crowbar songs end with a resolve to carry on
column6: the continual down-plod of “Piety” hints that <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=407YNmRKvQs"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">all Windstein had
column7: he gave; regardless
column8: Symmetry in Black inspires hope this isn't the end for Crowbar
column9: but just another part of their rich
column10:
perpetually sunburned and hungover career.

"|19373.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19373-crowbar-symmetry-in-black/|7.3|Andy O'Connor

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20637/homepage_large.273344b0.jpg|Led Zeppelin|2439.0|Led Zeppelin|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Rhino']|2014-06-12 00:00:00|1969|2016-06-11 16:36:40.557334|"

As time moves on and “The 60s” and “The 70s” become not so much historical periods as media creations
column2: it's harder to take for granted what the significant cultural touchstones of those eras actually mean to current-day society. Some of the artists that were once universally appreciated are slipping from memory
column3: while others are having difficulty translating to new generations. The furor greeting each new Beatles enterprise shows their music and image are indeed proving timeless
column4: and they remain relevant for teenagers and septuagenarians alike—but other giants from the late 1960s and early 70s aren’t having it so easy. The Who’s stock has plummeted in the last decade
column5: and it’s getting tougher to find anyone under 35 who cares about a note of their music made after 1971. The Rolling Stones have been at it so long that it’s difficult for younger people to believe that they were once actually good. Pink Floyd still reach some alienated kids
column6: but their most devoted fans are among the graybeard audiophile set. And then there's Led Zeppelin.

column1: Zeppelin occupies a unique place among this group of bands
column2: in part because their position was hard to pin down while they were active. They were unimaginably popular from 1969 to 1980
column3: but critical respect was elusive. Their suspect reputation has been somewhat overstated (in the U.S.
column4: Rolling Stone panned them early on but eventually came around
column5: while Creem and Circus took them seriously all along) but Led Zeppelin never quite registered with the intelligentsia. They made the heaviest hard rock records ever recorded
column6: but their lyrics tended toward loopy mysticism when they weren’t either stealing ideas outright or wallowing in a kind of hedonism where misogyny was a given.

column2: Led Zeppelin is typically viewed through one of three lenses: those among the 50-plus set who were actually there hear their music with a nostalgic ear
column3: remembering the days of their youth. There are those who grew up with the assumption that Led Zeppelin were important—let's say 30 to 50 years old—hear them filtered through a second wave of nostalgia
column4: from movie titles like Dazed and Confused and the memory of classic rock radio. To these people (including me)
column5: Zeppelin defined an otherworldly image of '70s rock deities
column6: conquering the world on the strength of volume
column7: arena shows
column8: and the baddest riffs the world had ever heard. And then there’s the younger set for whom Zep might seem a little comical
column9: a faintly embarrassing relic from another era even as a certain amount of the music remains undeniable. In one sense
column10: this latter group have more in common with the skeptical critics of the first wave
column11: possessing expectations of ""what music should be"" that don’t necessarily apply for a band that sounds like this.

column1: These reissues of Zeppelin’s first three albums are an attempt to reach all of these people
column2: using every tool at the band and label’s disposal. The primary reason these sets are being presented and received as a Big Deal is that they are the first reissues of the digital era (and here I’m using the term to include CDs
column3: which means we’re going back more than 30 years) to include bonus material. The reissues are remastered and are packaged with bonus discs that include previously unreleased live material and studio cuts. The PR push surrounding a big reissue in 2014 inevitably involves sharing things that can spread on social media and hence reach younger kids
column4: while other elements—unheard versions
column5: improved sound—ostensibly entice older fans to re-buy the records.

column1: Jimmy Page
column2: always Led Zeppelin’s sonic architect
column3: heard the blues differently. He heard it as sound first
column4: rather than a form or tradition or product of personalities—maybe that’s why he felt so cavalier about ""borrowing"" from blues records without attribution
column5: since you can't copyright a sound—and he understood the trance-inducing element of blues repetition better than anyone: blues as a consciousness-expanding ritual. All of this is clear from the very beginning
column6: as Led Zeppelin is one of music's most assured and fully realized debuts; individually
column7: Jimmy Page
column8: John Paul Jones
column9: and John Bonham were great players
column10: but the whole of their sound somehow exceeded the sum of its parts. But even above the instrumental virtuosity
column11: Led Zeppelin is a triumph of production
column12: each part clear and forceful but adding up to something even more powerful.

column1: Just about everything Zep would do at one point is presented here somewhere—trance-rock (“Dazed and Confused”)
column2: gorgeous acoustic folk (“Black Mountain Side”)
column3: catchy guitar pop (“Good Times Bad Times”)
column4: updates on straight blues (“I Can’t Quit You Baby”). They’d do most of these things better later
column5: but this is where they appeared first. Zep sounded so brilliant right out of the gate because Page was already a veteran of the music scene when they started; working as a session guitarist and later with the Yardbirds
column6: he took in the scene and saw what was missing. As much as Zeppelin understood music
column7: at this point words were more or less just sounds.

column1: Led Zeppelin also set the tone for a decade of dippy lyrics. If Zep was never accepted as hip in some circles
column2: it’s partly because of the knuckle-dragging worldview of songs like “Dazed and Confused”. It’s hard not to laugh or cringe in 2014 when hearing a line like “Every day I work so hard
column3: bringin' home my hard-earned pay/ Try and love you baby but you push me away
column4: ” but it’s equally difficult not to acknowledge that Robert Plant delivers them with a certain histrionic power. And then a bar later
column5: John Bonham’s slow fills and Page’s terrifying guitar screech come in
column6: and the true meaning of the music is found.

column1: It’s truly impossible to oversell how brilliantly these records are produced; “rock” as an idea is really a ’70s idea
column2: and Led Zeppelin established what that would mean and what it would sound like
column3: which was as much a matter of arrangement as it was knowing where to set the microphones
column4: how high to mix the bass. You can hear that on the bonus disc to the first album
column5: which was recorded live in Paris in 1969 and aired on radio. The recording fidelity
column6: for a release by such a major band
column7: is remarkably poor—which goes to show how well the vaults have already been cleared out—but there’s no doubting just how much this band could rip in their first year. Of particular note is the attack of Plant’s singing
column8: as he comes over like the unhinged 22-year-old he was. The earliest live recordings by bands are so exciting in large part because the vocalist hasn’t yet learned how to pace himself; Plant sings these songs like Zeppelin might last a year and this is his one chance to get it right. By the late ’70s
column9: purely as a matter of survival
column10: he’d learn how to coast on stage.

column1: There is no arguing with a riff. It’s a conversation-ender
column2: something resistant to analysis that strips away the intellectual to situate the music in a purely physical space. Of the 100 greatest guitar riffs in the history of rock music
column3: Jimmy Page might have written 20
column4: and a good number of those can be found on Led Zeppelin’s second album from 1969. If you or someone close to you has ever been within 10 feet of a radio tuned to a classic rock station
column5: you’ve heard them all
column6: many times—maybe too many. For every young person who discovers “Whole Lotta Love” and “Heartbreaker” and “Living Loving Maid (She’s Just a Woman)”
column7: there’s an older person who gets sick of them from overplay and doesn’t need to ever hear them again. Part of the challenge and excitement of revisiting a record upon reissue is trying to hear the music again with fresh ears
column8: seeing if you can tap into that feeling of discovery that came from hearing it the first time. When I’m able to mentally put myself into this place— the kid who got his driver’s license a month ago
column9: driving around listening to II on tape—the reissue sounds as thrilling as ever.

column1: Every track on this record is musically brilliant
column2: and in the span of just a few months it’s amazing how much Page had enriched the band’s sound. Chiming acoustic guitars provide the contrast to the crunch in a whole new way on “Ramble On” and “Thank You”
column3: offering yet another template for mixing folk with proto-metal. “Whole Lotta Love” might have gotten the band sued by Willie Dixon
column4: but there was no sonic precedent for it in rock music—it’s a sound that would have been unimaginable without the rise of drug culture. If you are not a drummer
column5: it’s hard to imagine listening to “Moby Dick” very often
column6: but better evidence of John Bonham’s genius is found elsewhere on the record. Zep’s rhythmic underpinning
column7: especially the locked-in tandem of Jones and Bonham
column8: was always their secret weapon
column9: the thing that divided them from contemporaries like Black Sabbath. They could swing
column10: they loved James Brown and Motown
column11: and they took pride in the fact that people would dance at their shows. The bonus disc is a mildly interesting amalgam of alternate mixes and rough takes—the kind of stuff anyone but the most dedicated obsessives will listen to only once—and there’s little advance here lyrically from the debut
column12: but II is still close to perfect.

column1: III is
column2: indirectly
column3: Led Zeppelin’s own version of Pink Floyd's Meddle—the folky
column4: pretty early record that was never too popular and hence a favorite of indie types skeptical of such a massive mainstream band. That it opens with “Immigrant Song”
column5: one of their top few rockers
column6: only makes the later acoustic loveliness that much more affecting. The strings laid atop the acoustic guitar on “Friends” foreshadow “Kashmir”; “Tangerine” has an amazing tension between the minor-key verses and the open
column7: joyous chorus
column8: as good an example of any of Zep as a pop band. The melancholy ache of “That’s the Way” is Zep with their guard down—it goes down as easy as a great Cat Stevens song—and then by the end of the record things start to get a little weird
column9: with the heavy acoustic hoedown of “Bron-Y-Aur Stomp” and the acid-fried chug of the blues standard “Shake ’em on Down”
column10: a nod to the hypnotic one-chord version by Mississippi Fred McDowell. III has easily the best bonus material too
column11: including a fantastic unreleased version of the old blues song “Keys to the Highway”. Depending on your age
column12: you might remember III as “the one with the Viking kittens song” or “the one with that pretty song that played during an interlude of Almost Famous”; for someone who doesn’t necessarily want to be inundated with songs and riffs that became clichés
column13: it might be the best place to start.

column1: For some
column2: the interest in these sets is the remastering
column3: an alleged improvement in sound
column4: which makes sense for a band so song-oriented. I’ve always thought that Zeppelin
column5: like Neil Young
column6: were best heard from nice-sounding pressings from the ’70s that were utterly ubiquitous in used LP bins in the ’80s and ’90s. Back then
column7: you could collect the entire Zeppelin catalog for something like $30
column8: where the inferior sounding early CD masters would run you more like $150.

column1: These days the gap between different versions seems to be closing. I attended a listening session for these reissues in New York
column2: hosted by Jimmy Page
column3: and at one point he was asked which version sounded best
column4: vinyl or CD. Page responded with saying the best version was the original analog tape
column5: but “unfortunately I can’t invite you all ’round to listen to it.” Suffice to say that these remasters sound very good
column6: a bit louder but not overly so
column7: but we’re likely reaching a point of diminishing returns. That said
column8: I’m very glad these new remasters and the attendant publicity push exist
column9: to get us all listening to and talking about Led Zeppelin again
column10: where they stand and what they might mean. However you feel about them and their brand of ultra-huge arena rock
column11: there has never been another band like them
column12:
before or since.

column1:
2|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20639/homepage_large.8006f4ec.jpg|Led Zeppelin III|2439.0|Led Zeppelin|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Rhino']|2014-06-12 00:00:00|1970|2016-06-11 16:36:40.557334|"

As time moves on and “The 60s” and “The 70s” become not so much historical periods as media creations
column2: it's harder to take for granted what the significant cultural touchstones of those eras actually mean to current-day society. Some of the artists that were once universally appreciated are slipping from memory
column3: while others are having difficulty translating to new generations. The furor greeting each new Beatles enterprise shows their music and image are indeed proving timeless
column4: and they remain relevant for teenagers and septuagenarians alike—but other giants from the late 1960s and early 70s aren’t having it so easy. The Who’s stock has plummeted in the last decade
column5: and it’s getting tougher to find anyone under 35 who cares about a note of their music made after 1971. The Rolling Stones have been at it so long that it’s difficult for younger people to believe that they were once actually good. Pink Floyd still reach some alienated kids
column6: but their most devoted fans are among the graybeard audiophile set. And then there's Led Zeppelin.

column1: Zeppelin occupies a unique place among this group of bands
column2: in part because their position was hard to pin down while they were active. They were unimaginably popular from 1969 to 1980
column3: but critical respect was elusive. Their suspect reputation has been somewhat overstated (in the U.S.
column4: Rolling Stone panned them early on but eventually came around
column5: while Creem and Circus took them seriously all along) but Led Zeppelin never quite registered with the intelligentsia. They made the heaviest hard rock records ever recorded
column6: but their lyrics tended toward loopy mysticism when they weren’t either stealing ideas outright or wallowing in a kind of hedonism where misogyny was a given.

column2: Led Zeppelin is typically viewed through one of three lenses: those among the 50-plus set who were actually there hear their music with a nostalgic ear
column3: remembering the days of their youth. There are those who grew up with the assumption that Led Zeppelin were important—let's say 30 to 50 years old—hear them filtered through a second wave of nostalgia
column4: from movie titles like Dazed and Confused and the memory of classic rock radio. To these people (including me)
column5: Zeppelin defined an otherworldly image of '70s rock deities
column6: conquering the world on the strength of volume
column7: arena shows
column8: and the baddest riffs the world had ever heard. And then there’s the younger set for whom Zep might seem a little comical
column9: a faintly embarrassing relic from another era even as a certain amount of the music remains undeniable. In one sense
column10: this latter group have more in common with the skeptical critics of the first wave
column11: possessing expectations of ""what music should be"" that don’t necessarily apply for a band that sounds like this.

column1: These reissues of Zeppelin’s first three albums are an attempt to reach all of these people
column2: using every tool at the band and label’s disposal. The primary reason these sets are being presented and received as a Big Deal is that they are the first reissues of the digital era (and here I’m using the term to include CDs
column3: which means we’re going back more than 30 years) to include bonus material. The reissues are remastered and are packaged with bonus discs that include previously unreleased live material and studio cuts. The PR push surrounding a big reissue in 2014 inevitably involves sharing things that can spread on social media and hence reach younger kids
column4: while other elements—unheard versions
column5: improved sound—ostensibly entice older fans to re-buy the records.

column1: Jimmy Page
column2: always Led Zeppelin’s sonic architect
column3: heard the blues differently. He heard it as sound first
column4: rather than a form or tradition or product of personalities—maybe that’s why he felt so cavalier about ""borrowing"" from blues records without attribution
column5: since you can't copyright a sound—and he understood the trance-inducing element of blues repetition better than anyone: blues as a consciousness-expanding ritual. All of this is clear from the very beginning
column6: as Led Zeppelin is one of music's most assured and fully realized debuts; individually
column7: Jimmy Page
column8: John Paul Jones
column9: and John Bonham were great players
column10: but the whole of their sound somehow exceeded the sum of its parts. But even above the instrumental virtuosity
column11: Led Zeppelin is a triumph of production
column12: each part clear and forceful but adding up to something even more powerful.

column1: Just about everything Zep would do at one point is presented here somewhere—trance-rock (“Dazed and Confused”)
column2: gorgeous acoustic folk (“Black Mountain Side”)
column3: catchy guitar pop (“Good Times Bad Times”)
column4: updates on straight blues (“I Can’t Quit You Baby”). They’d do most of these things better later
column5: but this is where they appeared first. Zep sounded so brilliant right out of the gate because Page was already a veteran of the music scene when they started; working as a session guitarist and later with the Yardbirds
column6: he took in the scene and saw what was missing. As much as Zeppelin understood music
column7: at this point words were more or less just sounds.

column1: Led Zeppelin also set the tone for a decade of dippy lyrics. If Zep was never accepted as hip in some circles
column2: it’s partly because of the knuckle-dragging worldview of songs like “Dazed and Confused”. It’s hard not to laugh or cringe in 2014 when hearing a line like “Every day I work so hard
column3: bringin' home my hard-earned pay/ Try and love you baby but you push me away
column4: ” but it’s equally difficult not to acknowledge that Robert Plant delivers them with a certain histrionic power. And then a bar later
column5: John Bonham’s slow fills and Page’s terrifying guitar screech come in
column6: and the true meaning of the music is found.

column1: It’s truly impossible to oversell how brilliantly these records are produced; “rock” as an idea is really a ’70s idea
column2: and Led Zeppelin established what that would mean and what it would sound like
column3: which was as much a matter of arrangement as it was knowing where to set the microphones
column4: how high to mix the bass. You can hear that on the bonus disc to the first album
column5: which was recorded live in Paris in 1969 and aired on radio. The recording fidelity
column6: for a release by such a major band
column7: is remarkably poor—which goes to show how well the vaults have already been cleared out—but there’s no doubting just how much this band could rip in their first year. Of particular note is the attack of Plant’s singing
column8: as he comes over like the unhinged 22-year-old he was. The earliest live recordings by bands are so exciting in large part because the vocalist hasn’t yet learned how to pace himself; Plant sings these songs like Zeppelin might last a year and this is his one chance to get it right. By the late ’70s
column9: purely as a matter of survival
column10: he’d learn how to coast on stage.

column1: There is no arguing with a riff. It’s a conversation-ender
column2: something resistant to analysis that strips away the intellectual to situate the music in a purely physical space. Of the 100 greatest guitar riffs in the history of rock music
column3: Jimmy Page might have written 20
column4: and a good number of those can be found on Led Zeppelin’s second album from 1969. If you or someone close to you has ever been within 10 feet of a radio tuned to a classic rock station
column5: you’ve heard them all
column6: many times—maybe too many. For every young person who discovers “Whole Lotta Love” and “Heartbreaker” and “Living Loving Maid (She’s Just a Woman)”
column7: there’s an older person who gets sick of them from overplay and doesn’t need to ever hear them again. Part of the challenge and excitement of revisiting a record upon reissue is trying to hear the music again with fresh ears
column8: seeing if you can tap into that feeling of discovery that came from hearing it the first time. When I’m able to mentally put myself into this place— the kid who got his driver’s license a month ago
column9: driving around listening to II on tape—the reissue sounds as thrilling as ever.

column1: Every track on this record is musically brilliant
column2: and in the span of just a few months it’s amazing how much Page had enriched the band’s sound. Chiming acoustic guitars provide the contrast to the crunch in a whole new way on “Ramble On” and “Thank You”
column3: offering yet another template for mixing folk with proto-metal. “Whole Lotta Love” might have gotten the band sued by Willie Dixon
column4: but there was no sonic precedent for it in rock music—it’s a sound that would have been unimaginable without the rise of drug culture. If you are not a drummer
column5: it’s hard to imagine listening to “Moby Dick” very often
column6: but better evidence of John Bonham’s genius is found elsewhere on the record. Zep’s rhythmic underpinning
column7: especially the locked-in tandem of Jones and Bonham
column8: was always their secret weapon
column9: the thing that divided them from contemporaries like Black Sabbath. They could swing
column10: they loved James Brown and Motown
column11: and they took pride in the fact that people would dance at their shows. The bonus disc is a mildly interesting amalgam of alternate mixes and rough takes—the kind of stuff anyone but the most dedicated obsessives will listen to only once—and there’s little advance here lyrically from the debut
column12: but II is still close to perfect.

column1: III is
column2: indirectly
column3: Led Zeppelin’s own version of Pink Floyd's Meddle—the folky
column4: pretty early record that was never too popular and hence a favorite of indie types skeptical of such a massive mainstream band. That it opens with “Immigrant Song”
column5: one of their top few rockers
column6: only makes the later acoustic loveliness that much more affecting. The strings laid atop the acoustic guitar on “Friends” foreshadow “Kashmir”; “Tangerine” has an amazing tension between the minor-key verses and the open
column7: joyous chorus
column8: as good an example of any of Zep as a pop band. The melancholy ache of “That’s the Way” is Zep with their guard down—it goes down as easy as a great Cat Stevens song—and then by the end of the record things start to get a little weird
column9: with the heavy acoustic hoedown of “Bron-Y-Aur Stomp” and the acid-fried chug of the blues standard “Shake ’em on Down”
column10: a nod to the hypnotic one-chord version by Mississippi Fred McDowell. III has easily the best bonus material too
column11: including a fantastic unreleased version of the old blues song “Keys to the Highway”. Depending on your age
column12: you might remember III as “the one with the Viking kittens song” or “the one with that pretty song that played during an interlude of Almost Famous”; for someone who doesn’t necessarily want to be inundated with songs and riffs that became clichés
column13: it might be the best place to start.

column1: For some
column2: the interest in these sets is the remastering
column3: an alleged improvement in sound
column4: which makes sense for a band so song-oriented. I’ve always thought that Zeppelin
column5: like Neil Young
column6: were best heard from nice-sounding pressings from the ’70s that were utterly ubiquitous in used LP bins in the ’80s and ’90s. Back then
column7: you could collect the entire Zeppelin catalog for something like $30
column8: where the inferior sounding early CD masters would run you more like $150.

column1: These days the gap between different versions seems to be closing. I attended a listening session for these reissues in New York
column2: hosted by Jimmy Page
column3: and at one point he was asked which version sounded best
column4: vinyl or CD. Page responded with saying the best version was the original analog tape
column5: but “unfortunately I can’t invite you all ’round to listen to it.” Suffice to say that these remasters sound very good
column6: a bit louder but not overly so
column7: but we’re likely reaching a point of diminishing returns. That said
column8: I’m very glad these new remasters and the attendant publicity push exist
column9: to get us all listening to and talking about Led Zeppelin again
column10: where they stand and what they might mean. However you feel about them and their brand of ultra-huge arena rock
column11: there has never been another band like them
column12:
before or since.
