column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20557/homepage_large.6065a0c4.jpg|Stay Gold|29087.0|First Aid Kit|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2014-06-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:41.115617|"

Outside of high school curricula and motivational posters
column2: Robert Frost is not an especially popular literary influences these days. Two roads diverged in the woods and most people could give a shit. When sisters Johanna and Klara Söderberg named both a song and their third album together as First Aid Kit after Frost’s poem “Nothing Gold Can Stay”
column3: from his Pulitzer-winning 1923 collection New Hampshire
column4: the choice seemed to reflect their youth: The sisters signed their first record contract in 2008 when Johanna was 17 and Klara 14
column5: both around the age when most readers have Frost thrust upon them. On the other hand
column6: the Söderbergs are Swedish
column7: not American. And instead of stopping by woods on a snowy evening
column8: they’ve chosen Frost’s elegy to the natural state of entropy. “Nature’s first green is gold
column9: her hardest hue to hold
column10: ” he writes. “So dawn goes down to day. Nothing gold can stay.”

column1: It’s a darker and more fatalistic sentiment than we typically expect from Frost
column2: a sunny reminder than nothing continues in its ideal state. Everything fades. We all die. First Aid Kit understand this inevitability
column3: yet they have the tenacity and optimism to fight against that falling apart. “What if our hard work ends in despair?” the sisters ask on “Stay Gold”
column4: as a guitar plucks out a stoic theme and the percussion echoes against canyon walls. “What if the road won’t take me there?” They’re not jaded—at least not yet. The Söderbergs remain romantics in an unromantic world
column5: not only writing lyrics about fighting the good fight but making the kind of wide-eyed
column6: ‘70s-tinged folk-rock that thrives on soaring vocals
column7: warm harmonies
column8: big choruses
column9: and heart-on-sleeve lyrics.

column1: There’s plenty of each on Stay Gold
column2: their first record for Columbia. It’s certainly their grandest and arguably their most consistent release to date
column3: even if there’s nothing here as undeniable as “Emmylou”
column4: from 2012’s The Lion’s Roar. With its affectionate hook
column5: that song was both a paean to country music romance and a mission statement; ostensibly the lyrics were directed toward a male counterpart
column6: but it sounded more like the sisters were inviting each other to sing along. Stay Gold similarly conveys the joys of musical collaboration—their voices always sound good together—yet they’re not quite so convinced of the merits of the music industry. These are weary songs about transience: touring constantly
column7: missing home
column8: losing friends and lovers. It’s darker than Roar
column9: but also wiser
column10: more mature in its conflicts. First Aid Kit still can’t sell a line like
column11: “Shit gets fucked up and people just disappear
column12: ” but they convey the dusty self-assertion of “The Bell” like it’s gospel.

column1: “I’d rather be moving than static
column2: ” they sing together on a song called “Shattered and Hollow”
column3: before promising each other
column4: “We are gonna get out of here.” Touring life is a tricky theme for any artist to address
column5: as it potentially alienates an audience that has never hired a booking agent
column6: never had to worry about label contracts
column7: and never had to deal with prying journalists. What’s bracing about Stay Gold
column8: then
column9: is how universal the Söderberg sisters make that life sound. Rather than dwell on the particulars of long days on the road
column10: they pare their experiences down to sentiments that sound more relatable and identifiable
column11: whether it’s leaving home
column12: discovering new places
column13: or defining your own destiny before the gold fades. In a sense
column14: First Aid Kit have managed to establish a touring diary as a metaphor for young womanhood
column15: which makes the music more powerful. “Girls they just want to have fun
column16: ” they sing on “Waitress Song”
column17: “and the rest of us hardly know who we are.” The song gallops at a dramatic pace
column18: with that insistent acoustic guitar and ornate filigrees of pedal steel instilling the chorus with a sense of immense yearning.

column1: To record Stay Gold
column2: the Söderberg sisters again flew to Omaha to work with Mike Mogis
column3: who produced The Lion’s Roar. Naturally
column4: the folk-rock reference points remain
column5: even if the duo paint with a broader palette. There’s more color here
column6: like the sympathetic flute on “Fleeting One” and the hoedown momentum of “Heaven Knows”. Mogis’ production sounds shinier
column7: however
column8: more elaborate and dense
column9: with a vague shimmer pervading every note. While it broadcasts a kind of coming-of-age melodrama
column10: this fuller
column11: more self-consciously produced sound undercuts the immediacy of the sisters’ songwriting
column12: such that songs like ""Cedar Lane"" and ""The Bell"" seem to be less about working through thorny issues and more about recalling confusions tucked away safely in the past. The music threatens to rob them of their youth
column13:
but these two women have the poise and presence to sing like they're still in the yellow woods pondering which path they should take.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20643/homepage_large.a6095461.jpg|Making the Saint|5494.0|Chris Schlarb|['Jazz']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Asthmatic Kitty']|2014-06-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:42.458850|"

Guitarist and producer Chris Schlarb's collaborated with Wilco’s Nels Cline
column2: Dirty Projectors' Dave Longstreth
column3: Daedelus
column4: the Philip Glass Ensemble’s Mick Rossi
column5: Sufjan Stevens
column6: and pedal steel guitarist Dave Easley. That list of collaborators speaks to his eclectic sensibility; under his own name and with the groups Create(!) and I Heart Lung
column7: he's blurred avant-garde jazz into electronic ambient
column8: minimal classical and pop-folk. Schlarb’s music has a pensive
column9: numinous feel
column10: emphasizing fine-grained and muted
column11: sparkling textures. He assembles large ensembles and lets the music come out of the configuration of personalities
column12: and this humble collective approach is probably why Schlarb remains overlooked; to date
column13: his greatest moment of recognition was for a cover of the Beach Boys’ “Til I Die” with Stevens
column14: Castanets' Ray Raposa and Cryptacize's Nedelle Torrisi. The solid but low-key Making the Saint probably won’t elevate Schlarb's profile
column15: but it's definitely a standout release in his catalog.

column1: This time around
column2: he's taken a solo approach to making music
column3: giving a rare glimpse of his unfiltered sensibility. In a gap between ensemble tours
column4: he found himself in a cabin in the San Bernardino mountains and spent a few days recording these structured improvisations for guitars and electronics. “I love small records
column5: ” he writes of the record
column6: citing Fripp & Eno’s No Pussyfooting as one. Schlarb’s idea of “small” is surprisingly large: for Making the Saint
column7: he produced two very long tracks of monumental proportions centered on the electric guitar
column8: and two short ones for acoustic guitar.

column1: The debt to Fripp & Eno is evident on the patient 19-minute title track
column2: which evokes a guitar solo unfolding on some grander
column3: slower
column4: more liquid order of time. Two electronic waves—one deep
column5: one a flickering overtone—have the black
column6: silky sound of woodwinds
column7: coiling for more than a minute before a slightly dirty electric guitar appears. The entire piece is less of an arc than a series of linked plateaus that gently rise and fall
column8: carrying us through harmonically related passages of bedraggled rock
column9: desert blues
column10: and ruminative involutions woven through the implacable backing track.

column1: Though Schlarb manages the long game skillfully on “Making the Saint”
column2: the other epic
column3: “The Fear of Death is the Birth of God”
column4: is more active
column5: transformative
column6: and diverse in timbre. Heavy
column7: dark hues replace the title track’s slow-motion fireworks
column8: building around the lattice of a guitar figure that climbs down through the tape hiss like a ladder leading into a tomb. The various elements—a screaming cello-like tone that has the scoured metallic ring of a singing bowl
column9: crumbling strums that trail silt
column10: gong-like washes
column11: electronic bends and wobbles—widely revolve around and deeply interpenetrate each other
column12: creating a feel that is ancient and mystic at times
column13: nearly symphonic at others.

column1: The two short acoustic pieces are sequenced
column2: respectively
column3: as a cleansing oasis and a brief coda. The outro is a perfectly pleasant instrumental version of “My Foolish Heart”
column4: a popular song from the mid-20<sup>th</sup> century
column5: while the Bibio-like “Great Receiver” is the only time the record falls flat. A crying and squeaking electric guitar solo briefly wakes up an otherwise sleepy track burdened by Schlarb’s tentative
column6:
toneless singing. But a bum three minutes among nearly 40 compelling ones isn’t bad. Making the Saint is a refined yet minor record that works as an intimate aperture into the subtle wonders of Schlarb’s catalog.

Before the Proustian flashbacks to the angst-and-Cinnabon-scented gloom of your local Hot Topic store circa ‘11
column3: metalcore used to mean something—and given heavy metal and hardcore punk’s close musical and cultural proximity to each other
column4: their fusion was pretty much inevitable. The same can be said for the progression from the rudimentary rage of pioneers like Biohazard and Integrity
column5: as well as the acrid genius of Converge’s 2001 magnum opus
column6: Jane Doe
column7: an album that
column8: over a decade later
column9: remains the genre’s greatest achievement. Conversely
column10: the rise of metalcore breakdown composer apps seemed to come out of nowhere
column11: turning what was once a rapidly-evolving crossover scene into a perennial punching bag for fans of heavy music.

column1: As metalcore struggles to reassert itself in the wake of some unforgiveable disasters
column2: it’s clear that the genre needs a new champion. Enter Enabler
column3: a young Milwaukee trio formed from the ashes of local hardcore groups Harlots and Abbadon. Their 2012 debut LP
column4: All Hail the Void
column5: quickly established themselves as potential saviors
column6: eyebrow-raises over their original drummer (Fall Out Boy’s Andy Hurley) be damned. Now
column7: two years and more than a few lineup changes later
column8: they’re back with La Fin Absolue Du Monde
column9: a fierce follow-up that imbues what many consider to be a dying art form with a fresh
column10: if still developing
column11: sense of purpose.

column1: In-demand noisecore producer Steve Austin
column2: best known for his work with Today is the Day
column3: manned the boards for the La Fin Absolue
column4: and his mix borders on self-cannibalizing. Fanged
column5: full-bodied guitars hog most of the space
column6: locked in a constant struggle for space with the hollow blast-beats of drummer Ryan Steigerwald’s kit. Even with their propensity for earworm riffs and slower tempos
column7: the Milwaukee trio is plenty rabid
column8: so when these two artists team up
column9: they strike a fierce balance between catchy and crusty.

column1: Opener “Close My Eyes” showcases the strength of such an approach
column2: its pulverizing blows softened by hummable guitar hooks and scream-along choruses plucked from hardcore’s halcyon days. The resulting palette suggests Earth Crisis by way of Coliseum
column3: or alternately
column4: an accessible take on the gravelly punk pushed by contemporaries like Trap Them. It’s metalcore
column5: all right—but between the d-beat instrumentation
column6: swampy sounding licks
column7: and the odd droning passage
column8: you’d be hard pressed to find these guys on the Warped Tour circuit even with the melodic boost (not that they'd want to play a fest like that—in a 2012 interview
column9: frontman/chief songwriter Jeff Lohrber referred to the vast majority of metalcore acts as being <a href=""%E2%80%9CEverything%20that%E2%80%99s%20popular%20these%20days%20is%20void%20of%20guitar%20riffs
column10: %20void%20of%20soul.%20It%20annoys%20the%20living%20piss%20out%20of%20me%20and%20I%20feel%20like%20I%20have%20to%20do%20something%20about%20that.%E2%80%9D%20%20%20Read%20More:%20Enabler%20Vocalist%20Jeff%20Lohrber%20Hates%20Modern%20Metalcore%20With%20a%20Passion%20%7C%20http://noisecreep.com/enabler-all-hail-the-void/?trackback=tsmclip"" target=""_blank"">""as dispensable as hair bands in the '80s"").

column1: The title of Enabler's LP is derived from the French for “the absolute end of the world”
column2: so we’re talking eschatology to the extreme here: not just hellfire and asteroid impacts
column3: but rampant corruption
column4: greed
column5: and a complete lack of justice for the dispossessed (see “Sickened By the Wake”
column6: its funerary traits sublimated into tools for protest). Then again
column7: the band’s willing to bet that we were dead to begin with; partway through “I’ve Got a Bad Feeling About This”
column8: Lohrber barks
column9: <span>”No future
column10: no fate/ There's nothing but the lies we make
column11: a strangely sticky chorus that doubles as the album’s overarching mantra.  Such a mentality necessitates batshit instrumentation
column12: and La Fin Absolue delivers
column13: from “Linear Existence”’s cascade of sludge to the war waged by “New Life”s dueling guitar lines.

column1: After such apocalyptic fury
column2: it’s only right to expect a skull-crushing finale—but closer “Consequence” proves the album’s biggest disappointment. Fatigued
column3: directionless
column4: and in dire need of an editor
column5: its mangled grooves get hijacked halfway through by one of the blandest stoner jams of recent memory
column6: the final minute consisting of a strange decrescendo-crescendo that makes no attempt to hide its laziness. Enabler's world thus ends not with a bang
column7: but with a sigh—a real shame
column8: considering that the album is otherwise successful in its attempts to build up cathartic energy. Chances are
column9: humanity (and metalcore) will still be doomed when time Enabler decides to churn out a follow-up
column10:
granting them the chance to accompany us into the abyss once more.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20580/homepage_large.3474f844.jpg|The Oregon Bootleg Tapes|32283.0|Stick Against Stone|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['MediaGroove']|2014-06-12 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:43.459723|"

One of the most interesting elements of the recently issued live album by 1980s punk-funk collective Stick Against Stone is that it exists at all. The odds of a videotape of a concert by a brutally obscure band surviving in playable condition for three decades are slim
column2: an official reissue of the contents of the videotape even slimmer. But we’re living in a golden age of reissues
column3: where there’s seemingly nothing—from vintage self-released New Age records to compilations of rock bands who sang about Dungeons & Dragons—that’s too arcane for a repress. The bigger surprise
column4: then
column5: is that an audio rip of a 30-year-old VHS tape of a performance by a punk-funk band playing at a hippie craft-and-food market in Eugene
column6: Oregon it not only deserves to be listened to
column7: but nearly demands it.

column1: Stick Against Stone have long been one of the missing pieces in the history of the American punk avant-garde; founded in Pittsburgh in 1981
column2: the group combined a wide-ranging collection of influences (free jazz
column3: ska
column4: Afrofunk
column5: hardcore) with an intensively revolution-minded political spirit that infused every facet of the band
column6: down to its collective organization as a functionally anarchistic “leaderless collective”. They were essentially an American version of Crass

column1: The Oregon Bootleg Tapes were recorded in 1985

column6: anxious energy that it shared with New York City's No Wave scene and a few UK post-punk bands. By the time they got settled in Oregon
column7: they’d acquired a confident looseness that translated into smoother
column8: deeper grooves that set them apart from their contemporaries

column1: “The Hopping Frog” is the strongest example of Stick Against Stone's jittery take on ska that they return to several times throughout the set. It’s also a showcase for front woman Sari Morninghawk’s talents as both a vocalist and a percussionist with a frenetic
column2: focused style

column4: and they also distinguish themselves by the amount of stylistic ground that they cover. In between the amped up ska-funk numbers
column5: they experiment with reggae
column6: blissed-out New Wave pop
column7: and
column8: on the track “Rhetoric”
column9: a hard-edged
column10: angular
column11: and thoroughly unique funk shot through with the unpredictable energy of classic
column12: Ornette Coleman-style free jazz.

column1: In a market flooded with reissues

but they were playing 20 years into the future.

Even though they were reared amid San Francisco’s lo-fi bonanza
column2: it didn't take too long for the Fresh & Onlys to opt out of the garage rock arms race. On the Bay Area quartet’s 2012 LP
column3: Long Slow Dance
column4: it swapped lo-fi gristle for nu-romantic vibes
column5: pairing up singer Tim Cohen’s surreal but self-conscious lyrics with shimmering
column6: Smiths-like guitar riffs. But if you expected jangle-pop ebullience while approaching “Bells of Paonia
column7: ” the first single from the band’s fifth full-length
column8: House of Spirits
column9: you might come away feeling a bit confused. The song’s stark
column10: fuzz-bleached minimalism is an inversion of what's expected from the typical Fresh & Onlys track; it's zoned-out
column11: rather than urgent
column12: and the chugging chords are blurred by a generous dose of distortion. The drums have been stripped down to the steady thud of a single kick
column13: and sunshine only sneaks in via the barbershop-style vocal harmonies that buoy the chorus. The shift in style takes a little bit to get used to.

column1: House of Spirits finds the Fresh & Onlys in a gloomy place. It’s a spooky
column2: desert-rock answer to the Cure’s Faith
column3: another record awash in both reverb and metaphysical turmoil. “The point of forgetting is so you can live
column4: ” despairs Cohen on the chilly “Animal of One”. “The purpose of living is harder to find.” The Fresh & Onlys’ music has touched on downcast themes before
column5: but in the past
column6: these bummin’ sentiments were often tempered a touch of self-effacing humor. Here
column7: Cohen’s gonzo imagery and weirdo-narratives feel more earnest in their evocation of hard times.

column1: To be fair
column2: there’s been a lot going on for the Fresh & Onlys’ over the last couple of years: most of the band’s San Francisco garage rock comrades have split town
column3: bassist Shayde Sartin’s apartment burned down
column4: and Cohen had a kid and temporarily re-located to an isolated Arizona horse ranch
column5: where he demoed most of the record’s songs. On prior LPs
column6: the rest of the band—Sartin
column7: guitarist Wymond Miles
column8: and drummer Kyle Gibson—took Cohen’s home demos and pushed them into headier territory
column9: transforming a mostly acoustic track like ""Tropical Island Suite"" into the 7-minute centerpiece from 2010’s Play It Strange. On House of Spirits
column10: the divide between the singer's folksier solo output and his work with Fresh & Onlys has gotten a little harder to spot. With it’s clean guitars and bobbing rhythm
column11: “Ballerina” could have easily slotted into River of Souls
column12: Cohen's latest effort with his side project Magic Trick.

column1: On the second half of House of Spirits
column2: the mood leavens a bit. ""Hummingbird"" and ""April Fools"" find Fresh & Onlys sounding a little more like their old selves—and if the bulk of House of Spirits is lacking a bit of urgency
column3: the band compensates in other ways. When they were still recording the bulk of their music at home
column4: the Fresh & Onlys worked fast and as a result it sometimes seemed like the clock was working against Cohen’s lyrics
column5: which recycled or smudged only a few words from verse to verse. House of Spirits
column6: then
column7: contains some of his most uniquely weird and vivid work
column8: whether he's contemplating supernatural-style domestic unrest on ""Home is Where"" or reconciling abandonment issues with a demonic possessor on ""Who Let the Devil"". Album closer ""Madness"" finds Cohen reflecting on an LP's worth of emotional unrest with a touch of nostalgia. ""Madness has a heart
column9: letting me rejoice in the most peculiar things
column10: he sings. ""Your occurrence in my heart
column11: giving me a voice
column12: is the most beautiful thing.""

column1: When the Fresh & Onlys' released their first 7"" back in 2009
column2: the band was preoccupied with scuzzy psych-rock homage. Since then
column3: they've covered more grounds than most of their Bay Area peers
column4: swapping in stylistic nods to the gothy end '80s LA punk and '80s UK guitar rock. House of Spirits doesn't bring much in the way of sonic surprises beyond a few drum machines and synths
column5: but it does find the band making subtle changes to its M.O.
column6: delivering a set of songs that's less urgent
column7:
but—in a freaky-yet-endearing way—more personal.

Tomas Barfod churned out more new material over the first three months of 2014 than most artists produce in a full year: with a solo EP

column10: mid-tempo body music until you grant him your grudging admiration.

column1: Pulsing was a stopgap effort where Barfod began to straddle vocal electro-pop and abstract
column2: instrumental fare in equal measure; with Love Me
column3: he devotes an unprecedented amount of his energy to the former realm
column4: realizing his vision with the help of a small group of close collaborators. He's steadily built a diverse personal universe of songwriting partners

column8: strange dream pop as Sleep Party People)

column11: nicely varied feel

column13:
which is rendered lonely and distant by way of vocal processing.

Barfod’s prinicipal collaborator is Swedish vocalist Nina K
column14: who appeared on Salton Sea highlight “November Skies” and Pulsing’s title track
column15: the latter of which also appears on Love Me. Nina is featured on four of the album’s eleven tracks
column16: all of which can be counted among its finest moments; their chemistry remains palpable
column17: as they’ve learned to strike just the right balance between Barfod’s beat-heavy
column18: rhythmically forward production and the lightness of Nina’s vocals. The moody
column19: string-swooning “Aftermath” sets a new high water mark for their partnership; yearning and raw
column20: it comes off as their own downcast version of Robyn and Kleerup’s masterful “With Every Heartbeat”
column21:
still a standard-bearer for heartbroken electro-pop balladry.

The success of the non-Nina K collaborations scattered throughout the remainder of Love Me depend on the vocalist: “Bell House” thrives thanks to a alien performance from pop-folk nomad and Here We Go Magic frontman Luke Temple
column22: while back-half features by Kjellberg and Pell sink unmemorably into the morass. One downside to Barfod’s chosen compositional style—tempos that rarely stray from middle-ground territory
column24: rhythms that split the difference between organic and machine-based—is that the onus to shape his songs is largely on his collaborators
column25: so when he's not working with Nina K

but a greater overall consistency might garner him the love he’s seeking.

The Atlas Moth's success has always come from compelling composites. Though they began as a formidable sludge outfit
column3: the Chicago band’s old mold had broken by the time they recorded their second album
column4: 2011’s An Ache for the Distance
column5: which turned black metal torment into post-rock splendor
column6: mid-tempo marches into alternate-universe alternative rock
column7: and late-album comedowns into psychedelic dreamstates. Even the band’s personnel confirmed those polyglot tendencies; screamer Stavros Giannopoulos and singer David Kush traded guttural yells and grand refrains
column8: conjuring incredible tension through variety and unpredictability. On An Ache for the Distance
column9: you could hear the Atlas Moth sorting through a few dozen passions and touchstones on every song—from Deftones and My Bloody Valentine to the Allman Brothers Band and Neurosis. At any moment
column10: their next move was always a question mark.

column1: The Old Believer
column2: their first following three years of personal and professional turmoil
column3: embraces many of those same sounds. “Collider” pivots between a great burst of swollen
column4: righteous groove rock and prismatic psych

column6: too. “City of Light” puts neon electronics beneath a stuttering
column7: snapping beat
column8: synthesizers undulating beneath the hook in a wonderful kosmiche haze. More than ever
column9: the Atlas Moth depend upon the dynamic between Giannopoulos and Kush; they alternately take separate verses
column10: nest opposing lyrics inside of one another’s voices and
column11: during the album’s most dramatic moments
column12: even sing together.

column1: The two-frontman approach suits The Old Believer’s the album’s fraught
column2: searching content. Since An Ache for the Distance
column3: Giannopoulos lost his mother and his girlfriend
column4: Kush his grandfather
column5: producer and guitarist Andrew Ragin his hips
column6: and the band veteran drummer Anthony Mainiero. They explore self-doubt and existential quandaries
column7: wondering about any afterlife and searching for an escape in the liquid drugs of South America. Near the end of the album’s most emblematic track
column8: “The Sea Beyond”
column9: Giannopoulos and Kush cycle around one another
column10: Giannopoulos lamenting loss as Kush repeats “I know you’re always with me” as a maxim of self-assurance. Giannopoulos eventually joins him
column11: the shouting and the singing perfectly and unexpectedly balancing despair and hope.

column1: But by and large
column2: the Atlas Moth’s variety seems to have begot its own homogeny here
column3: so that each move the band makes now feels like one you’ve either heard before or would have imagined upon prompting. Perhaps to accompany the more somber subject material
column4: the Atlas Moth drift deeper into the shoegaze interests that have previously been only dalliances. The guitars hang low and loud
column5: and twinkling keyboards fill cracks that spiderweb throughout the sound. More often than not
column6: though
column7: the softness mitigates the heaviness
column8: or at least couches the blows until the impact all but disappears. Even when Giannopoulos is seething about dejection above surging guitars during “Halcyon Blvd”
column9: the power seems padded
column10: and the slow
column11: steady wallop of “Hesperian” feels like a choice between the distortion of shoegaze and doom gone unmade
column12: leaving the song to linger in the ineffectual middle distance. After the heavy touring cycle behind An Ache for the Distance
column13: The Atlas Moth split with Mainiero
column14: a dynamo capable of meeting and adding power to the band’s stylistic shifts. But part of the flat-line predictability here stems from Daniel Lasek
column15: the new drummer who loves to find a mid-tempo beat and rarely leave it. For a band that’s flourished through a sense of whiplash
column16: he’s an overly steady
column17: cautious chauffer.

column1: The cover of The Old Believer depicts an alabaster-skinned woman in a matching white dress
column2: blending into the walls like a camouflaged angel. She’s seated
column3: staring calmly at the camera. But if you hold the cover beneath water for a few seconds
column4: the scene goes hellish: The black walls of some dim chamber appear. She grows horns
column5: and her eyes become black pits
column6: a sanguine stain shaping a thin V beneath them
column7: from her neck to her waist. For Profound Lore

column9: the trickery is tantamount to a picture disc or a limited-edition release. Designed by Ryan Clark
column10: both images are beautiful
column11: and the effect is chilling. It’s too bad
column12: then
column13: that the metaphor feels so off for The Old Believer. The Atlas Moth hope to be heavy and heavenly
column14: aggressive and accessible
column15: to exist in worlds of light and dark simultaneously. In this instance

hidden in flat gray instead of beautiful white or harrowing black.

As Irish black metal aesthetes Altar of Plagues reached their career peak
column2: it was clear that frontman James Kelly had other interests. After 2013's electronic-focused Teethed Glory and Injury
column3: he called an end to that band's aggression and physical brutality in favor of the morose atmospherics of his bass-focused solo project WIFE; the first full-length to emerge out of Kelly's fractured electronic inclinations
column4: What's Between
column5: draws from the same barren palette as his past work
column6: but it attempts to approach that darkness through uplifting synth swells and dead-eyed vocalizations rather than screeches and squalls.

column1: At his most focused
column2: Kelly's work recalls the beat-driven bleakness of Ross Tones' Throwing Snow (whose Left_Blank label released WIFE's first missive
column3: 2012's Stoic EP) or his new Tri Angle labelmates. In particular
column4: ""Dans Ce"" batters Kelly's saccharine vocal with abrasive percussion scrapes and pointillist synth parts
column5: warping his pop predilections into something less easy to apprehend. Because Kelly is given to flighty genre exercises
column6: though
column7: What's Between often feels fragmented and mangled; the leftfield house banger ""Living Joy"" sidles right next to the creeping Burial-isms of ""A Nature Shards""
column8:
and the brooding vocals and distant clinks that finish off the moody closer ""Further Not Better"" couldn't be further away from the sunny-eyed emoting of the record's opening salvo ""Like Chrome.""

That sonic inconsistency can work in Kelly's favor—check the nearly-nauseating transition from the skulking ooze of ""Tongue"" and the vacant
column9: reconstructed R&B of ""Heart Is A Far Light""—but his lack of focus robs What's Between of a definite collective identity. Gone are Altar of Plagues' high-minded ideas and 18-minute movements
column10: and in their place are disfigured attempts at inky beat-pop. Kelly is
column11: as ever
column12: able to conjure disaffection and gloom from his expansive instrumentation
column13: but he hasn't quite figured out how to turn digital desolation into something that matches the emotional and narrative force of his influences. What's Between provides some compelling glimpses at Kelly's cimmerian headspace
column14: but knowing that he possesses the ability and the vision to flesh out his own ideas
column15:
it's hard not to be left wanting more.

column2: some thumps from the studio

column4: and a loaded question: “What do you see when you look at me?” Whether deliberate

column9: serendipity is how Skisser and its follow-up EP II—released together as Boman’s North American debut—came to be. Boman recorded a couple demos but hadn’t totally committed to releasing them; then

In pop music
column2: 82 seconds can be an eternity. That’s how long Primal Scream’s “Velocity Girl” lasts
column3: and the song was enough to have crystallized an entire era and established an undying narrative. As the opening track of C86—a 22-song cassette compilation of British indie bands released by the legendary music magazine NME in 1986—“Velocity Girl” has become iconic. Around the time of its release
column4: Primal Scream’s frontman
column5: Bobby Gillespie
column6: left his post as the drummer of the Jesus and Mary Chain. Disentangled from that band's major-label whirlwind
column7: he resumed activity with the virtually unknown project he'd initially formed in 1982. Primal Scream then proceeded to reduce the pop song to its subatomic essence: quick
column8: breezy
column9: quirky
column10: and above all
column11: exquisitely small.

column1: “Velocity Girl” sounded humble
column2: but it was not without ambition. It falls shy of the minute-and-half mark
column3: and shyness can be heard in the song’s desperate refrain: “Leave me alone
column4: ” Gillespie pleads in a Glaswegian warble as guitars ring like chimes around him. It was the sound of soaring punk rock as filtered through the Byrds
column5: and its expression of angry introversion— told in an almost Morrissey-esque manner
column6: via the tale of a troubled
column7: sensitive young woman— was only the first stage of evolution for Primal Scream
column8: whose sprawling 1991 album Screamadelica would all but eclipse their formative work. Regardless of what the future held for Gillespie
column9: “Velocity Girl” became C86’s signature song
column10: and it’s the track that
column11: more than any other on the tape
column12: helped turn C86 from a comp into a genre.

column1: After 28 years of being held by many as the gold standard for indie-pop—and of being a hefty influence
column2: direct or otherwise
column3: on everyone from My Bloody Valentine to Belle and Sebastian to the Strokes—C86 is getting a lavish reissue with two bonus discs have been assembled by one of its original curators
column4: former NME writer Neil Taylor
column5: who also supplies copious liner notes (drawn in part from his upcoming book
column6: C86 & All That:Indie 1983-86). These 50 bonus tracks represent an additional fifty bands that Taylor claims should have been contenders to be on C86 in the first place
column7: and his claim is correct. Not only does the expanded reissue provide context and insight
column8: it’s packed to the back teeth with song after head-spinning song. One of the joys of C86 has always been its impressive lack of filler
column9: and even expanded to a staggering 72 songs
column10: this holds true.

column1: Two words pop up most often in discussions about C86—“jangle” and “twee”—and although those who make those associations aren’t inaccurate
column2: the descriptors don't tell the whole story. Inspired largely by the bands on C86’s ancestor
column3: 1981’s C81 compilation—which featured
column4: amid various post-punk
column5: industrial and ska luminaries along with the wiry romanticism of Josef K
column6: Orange Juice
column7: and Aztec Camera
column8: three alumni of Glasgow’s Postcard Records—the jangly
column9: twee bands on this reissue wholeheartedly embrace their forebears. The Pastels
column10: who had yet to install themselves as stalwart upholders of the C86 torch
column11: crawl along forlornly with “Breaking Lines
column12: ” while Miaow—who recorded for Factory Records and were led by NME writer Cath Carroll
column13: later immortalized by her unabashed fans in Unrest—brought a jaunty spring to their indie-pop step. McCarthy
column14: featuring future Stereolab mastermind Tim Gane on guitar
column15: waltzes wistfully with “Celestial City”. On one of the bonus discs
column16: B.M.X. Bandits (featuring a pre-Teenage Fanclub Norman Blake)
column17: finally get their due with the charmingly remedial “E102”; in 1989
column18: the band cheekily titled their debut album C86. A mere three years after the release of the compilation
column19: it was already being mythologized.

column1: While some stereotypes affiliated with C86 have been overstated over the years
column2: there is an aching
column3: shimmering delicacy at the heart of the compilation's more elfin contributors—but the ghost of punk past still lingers. Razorcuts named themselves after a line from Buzzcocks’ “Love You More”
column4: and their track that appears here
column5: “Sad Kaleidoscope”
column6: is an unabashed homage to Pete Shelley’s warbling
column7: wimp-punk songcraft. The Buzzcocks don’t get mentioned often as an influence on the C86 school
column8: but on this reissue
column9: the evidence is everywhere—from Pop Will Eat Itself’s buzzing “Mesmerized” (made before they became sample-heavy provocateurs
column10: and before frontman Clint Mansell scored Darren Aronofsky films) to Talulah Gosh’s lo-fi
column11: pop-punk romp “I Told You So” (made before sugar-spiked singer Amelia Fletcher formed the more refined Heavenly). The Wedding Present fall loosely into this camp
column12: too
column13: even though their song for the original C86 tracklist
column14: “This Boy Can Wait (A Bit Longer)”
column15: demonstrated just how much mastermind David Gedge seemed to want to one-up his peers in regard to heart-pounding desperation

column1: The line between C86’s jangly
column2: dreamy representatives and its more distortion-smothered counterparts is blurred by bands like 14 Iced Bears. An oddity both then and now
column3: the group’s song featured here
column4: “Inside”
column5: alchemically combines droning noise

column8: Cry” by 14 Iced Bears’ Sarah Records labelmate
column9: St. Christopher
column10: is underlain with an atmospheric smear of static that might as well be a wormhole to the next three decades of noise-pop.

column1: On the other end of the gentleness spectrum
column2: Meat Whiplash’s “Here It Comes” is Cure-indebted goth with a Metal Machine Music fetish
column3: a bizarre formula that nonetheless feels as much like proto-shoegaze as anything on the 4AD roster in 1986. And the Jesus and Mary Chain
column4: one of the prime sources of C86’s DNA
column5: are officially canonized in the compilation's canon with the inclusion of “Inside Me”
column6: from its 1984 debut Psychocandy. The similarity between the titles of 14 Iced Bears’ and JAMC’s tracks isn’t likely intentional
column7: but it’s eerily telling: again
column8: the specter of introversion—of masking one’s mumbling sweetness behind sheets of lacerating
column9: pseudo-psychedelic treble—is raised
column10: and loudly.

column1: Every precious stereotype associated with C86
column2: however
column3: is blown out of the water by the box set’s avant-garde contingent. Big Flame’s “New Way (Quick Wash and Brush Up with Liberation Theology)” is a Manchester-bred doppleganger of Minutemen’s funky
column4: sardonically militant post-punk; Stump exhibits bona fide musical virtuosity on “Buffalo”
column5: even if it’s bent toward a Carl-Stalling-meets-Captain Beefheart cartoonishness that ultimately provides one of C86’s most singular
column6: brilliant moments. The Nightingales—a veteran of the '77 punk scene that included ex-members of the Prefects
column7: who toured with the Clash for their legendary White Riot Tour— feed wobbly folk into post-punk on “Part Time Moral England”
column8: right around the time that their contemporaries Mekons were beginning to do the same. The spirit of '77 manifests itself in an entirely different way on Pigbros’ “Hedonist Hat”
column9: a clanging
column10: churning
column11: art-rock spasm that draws reverently from Brian Eno’s 1977 album Before and After Science. Partly in defense of these perpetual C86 outliers—the geeks so weird that they make the other geeks nervous —The Guardian recently a piece titled “C86: The myths about the NME’s indie cassette debunked”. As well-intentioned as it is
column12: it misses the point: The sounds may be different
column13: but the souls are simpatico.

column1: As eclectic as C86 is
column2: by no means does it try to encompass the entire British indie scene circa 1986. As Taylor recounts in his liner notes
column3: “The aim […] was to take an aural snapshot of the moment. Were these acts representative of the state of a certain kind of indie music at that time? Very much so. Was C86 intended to be the be-all and end-all of independent music at that time? Of course not”. In fact
column4: some bands refused to be included
column5: fearing it would lead to being pigeonholed—like the June Brides
column6: one of the major players in the admittedly loose-knit scene that C86 gathered together. That’s been rectified by the reissue
column7: with the June Brides’ horn-punched
column8: Burt Bacharach-like gem “Just the Same” serving as the first song on the box set’s first bonus disc. And some bands that were surely nowhere near being seriously considered in the first place— such as Happy Mondays
column9: whose undercooked “Freaky Dancin’” is a minor skirmish of the dancefloor havoc they’d go on to wreak— serve more as a historical curiosity than a corrected omission.

column1: Hindsight has been more than kind to C86
column2: but not everyone agrees on its place in the indie firmament. In Marc Spitz’s new book <a href=""http://www.amazon.com/Twee-Gentle-Revolution-Television-Fashion/dp/0062213040/ref=la_B001IQWPVW_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1401983258&sr=1-1"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""><i>Twee: The Gentle Revolution in Music
column3: Books
column4: Television
column5: Fashion
column6: and Film
column7: Sarah Records cofounder Matt Haynes maintains that
column8: “Even by the time it was released
column9: C86 was being treated as a term of abuse
column10: and most of the writers [at NME] were embarrassed by it. These days
column11: people tend to think of it as a landmark moment
column12: but… I think that’s a slight rewriting of history.” Revisionism
column13: though
column14: is the prerogative of the reissue curator—and that prerogative is exercised impeccably by Taylor
column15: who glosses over none of the conflict or confusion of the era in either his liner notes or his choice of bonus material. This reissue triumphs by celebrating
column16: rather than denying
column17:
the richness and invention—the dissonance and paradox—at play within a small scene of bands whose joyously erratic racket was much huger than their humble songs could contain.

The best dancehall album of the year so far is also
column2: interestingly
column3: one of the best pop albums of the year. Popcaan
column4: aka Andre Jay Sutherland
column5: is the current leader in the neverending battle for supremacy among Jamaican deejays
column6: but unlike previous kings of the hill (most recently
column7: Mavado and Vybz Kartel
column8: the latter who also has functioned as Sutherland’s mentor) he’s not overly concerned with projecting the image of a badman. He’s a lover
column9: not a gangster
column10: and it’s an impressively broad kind of love that he’s putting out. Where We Come From is a party
column11: and everyone’s invited.

column1: The album was executive produced by Brooklyn beatmaker and Mixpak label owner Dre Skull
column2: aka Andrew Hershey
column3: who’s become an unlikely heavyweight in the Jamaican music scene thanks to jubilant compositions like the Kling Klang and Loudspeaker riddims. He also worked on Snoop Dogg’s reggae rebrand as Snoop Lion alongside Diplo and Ariel Rechtshaid
column4: and Where We Come From feels like another attempt at doing what last year's Reincarnated failed to do: connect dancehall with an American pop audience that hasn’t seen an actual dancehall artist on the pop charts in years.

column1: Sutherland and Hershey make a great team. Sutherland has a super-melodic flow (he’s what is sometimes referred to as a “singjay”) and nimble sense of melody
column2: so Hershey's beats offer a lot of opportunities to exploit both talents
column3: even as they stick to chord progressions that don't stray from dancehall's conventions. Hershey's production skills also make a good platform for Sutherland's expressive delivery
column4: converting the plaintive strings and funereal tolling bells of “Hold On” into triumphant uplift and the stroboscopic rave synths of “Ghetto (Tired of Crying)” into a meditation on violence tinged with hint of hopefulness.

column1: Overall
column2: Where We Come From isn’t animated by solemnity
column3: or even the salaciousness that infuses “Number One Freak” and “Love Yuh Bad”
column4: but an ecstatic joy that transcends genre. Sutherland is a massively charismatic character
column5: and it’s hard not to get caught up in the elation that he so obviously feels when he gets from finding the perfect groove. That feeling permeates every corner of the album
column6: but it comes through strongest on two particular tracks. The thematic concerns of “Everything Nice” are right there in the title
column7: and it’s easy to feel the same way while the song is playing
column8: thanks to a buoyant
column9: bliss-inducing beat by Mixpak-affiliated producer Dubbel Dutch (who’s responsible for five of the 13 tracks).

column1: “Waiting So Long
column2: ” on the other hand
column3: bursts with kinetic energy. The beat
column4: by Swedish producer Adde Instrumentals (who also produced Sutherland’s 2011 Jamaican hit “Ravin”)
column5: is a techno-bubblegummy pileup of whining synths
column6: string stabs
column7: and handclaps that
column8: boosted by Sutherland’s recursively loopy vocal melody
column9: constantly reaches higher and higher towards giddy new levels of euphoria
column10: exploding kaleidoscopically like the all-out finale of a fireworks explosion that lasts three straight minutes. It’s the type of song that can push everything else completely out of your field of attention for its entire duration
column11: one of those pop moments that fully deserves to be called “transcendental.” In a perfect world
column12: it would be a smash; as far as the one we live in now
column13:
it’s noticeably better for having this song  and Where We Come From in it.

Chrissie Hynde has been making records for over three decades
column2: but until now she’s never released a proper “solo” record. Under the guise of the Pretenders
column3: Hynde operated as the leader of a constantly evolving gang
column4: a dynamic that always seemed of paramount importance to her. The power of the Pretenders hinged explicitly on Hynde's personality and musical force
column5: but she always made clear that the Pretenders were a band
column6: and that she was no solo act—so Stockholm
column7: the first album Hynde's released under her own name
column8:
represents a left turn for her career.

Stockholm was recorded in the album’s titular city with Peter Bjorn and John's Björn Yttling
column9: who also co-wrote most of the songs and contributed guitar; the record also features contributions from Neil Young
column10: the Caesars’ Joakin Åhlund
column11: and—most inexplicably—tennis legend John McEnroe. Despite its wily pedigree
column12: though
column13: Stockholm is a relatively staid affair. Hynde’s voice remains one of the most distinctively emotive in all of rock music and
column14: to his credit
column15: Yttling has the good sense to always place it high in the mix. Still
column16: Hynde’s vibrato is too often matched with bland lyrics and production that's overly glossy.

column1: Hynde is at her best when delivering withering
column2: offhand indictments
column3: so “Dark Sunglasses” is one of the album's treats. Dismissing those who have traded their integrity for the cache of coolness—“A kind of glamour you can lend yourself/ Like dark sunglasses/ And you'll remember how good it tasted/ Inside the ruling classes”—the song hints at the kind of thorny
column4: playfully acerbic persona that has made Hynde such a force to be reckoned with throughout her career. Unfortunately
column5: on Stockholm
column6: Hynde’s usually effortless badassery too often gets buried under forgettable tunes. There is a weird irony in hearing Hynde sing “I’ve become what I criticized” on “Down The Wrong Way”
column7: a track tugged along by Neil Young’s blistering guitar work but dogged by a sing-songy chorus that would've barely made it as a Pretenders B-side back in the '80s. “You or No One” and “Sweet Nuthin'” are serviceable pop exercises
column8: but they also lack any discernable bite
column9: trading in clichés rather than revealing anything interesting about Hynde herself—a shame
column10:
since she’s arguably lived a very fascinating life.

It’s only when she seems to let her guard down
column11: as in the lovely album closer “Adding the Blue” that Hynde’s genius shines on Stockholm. A doleful
column12: truly beautiful attempt to memorialize a past love
column13: it’s a stunning reminder of how Hynde’s voice can make even the simplest lines truly heartrending. When she sings “I can't draw from memories or photos/ I need blood and breath
column14: but you left me nothing
column15: ” it’s as stirring a moment as anything from her expansive back catalog; ""Adding the Blue"" also leaves one wishing that the rest of Stockholm could have been as emotionally arresting.

column1: In Stockholm’s press materials
column2: Hynde says
column3: “I wanted to make a power pop album you could dance to—Abba meets John Lennon.” It’s frustrating that the results don't match the aims; here
column4: she’s made a mostly fine
column5: overly polished adult contemporary record that feels oddly generic
column6: especially coming from her. At this point in her career
column7: Hynde has sold more than 25 million records
column8: so she has certainly earned the right to do whatever the hell she wants. Still
column9: for someone capable of crafting truly perfect pop songs like “Talk of the Town” and “Message of Love”
column10: the treacle that shows up time and again on Stockholm is confounding. As a distilled 5-song EP
column11: Stockholm might have served as a refreshing slap in the face—a potent reminder of what a vibrant jolt of lightning Chrissie Hynde can be—but instead
column12: it's a rather wan listen. She remains one of rock music’s most fantastically singular talents
column13: but with this experiment now behind her
column14:
maybe it’s time to get the old band name back together again.

Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: two teens from the suburbs of Los Angeles with a nonsensical band name make a sloppy but inspired psychedelic racket
column2: get signed to a Secretly Canadian subsidiary imprint
column3: and make an album under the tutelage of an older
column4: more seasoned mentor. That’s the Foxygen origin story in a nutshell
column5: but just a year after that band’s Richard Swift-produced breakthrough
column6: We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic
column7: their 23-year-old guitarist Jonathan Rado is already eager to replay the script—only this time
column8: he’s promoted himself to the big-brother role.

column1: Dub Thompson—that is
column2: singer/guitarist Matt Pulos and drummer Evan Laffer
column3: both 19—hail from Agoura Hills
column4: the next burg over from Foxygen’s native Westlake Village. And one presumes Rado saw some of Foxygen’s industrious
column5: irreverent spirit in his fellow county-folk
column6: resulting in an invite to record their debut album in a house Rado was renting last summer in Bloomington
column7: Ind. But the band heard on 9 Songs proves to be less Foxygen’s dutiful doppleganger than its evil twin. Where Foxygen put an absurdist
column8: playful spin on the canonical classic rock of Dylan
column9: the Beatles
column10: and the Stones
column11: Dub Thompson proffer a combustible collision of various record-collector subgenres—’60s proto-punk garage
column12: Beefheart-ian skronk
column13: Krautrock
column14: discofied post-punk
column15: hardcore
column16: mid-‘80s American indie
column17: and
column18: yes
column19: even a daub of dub—all captured by Rado in a perfectly grainy patina that makes it sound like the band is performing on a live pirate-radio broadcast in the basement.  And though Dub Thompson wear their rough edges proudly—and don't yet feel the urge to develop their melodic craft beyond one-line lyrics and monotone shouts—the unfinished veneer feels less a product of slackadasical whimsy than an urgency to cram as many oddball ideas into their songs as possible.

column1: But for all the hyperactive energy and compulsive structural shifts in effect here
column2: 9 Songs rarely feels like a mess. Fortunately
column3: this is a band that gets most of the silliness of its system through nomenclature: 9 Songs actually only contains eight tracks—one of which is an acid-splattered instrumental titled “9 Songs”. And while there are songs about dinosaurs (“Pterodactyls”)
column4: there are also songs that sound like they’re about dinosaurs but actually aren’t (“Epicondyles”
column5: which is the bone joint prone to tennis elbow—no doubt an epidemic malady in their hometown). But for the most part
column6: Pulos and Laffer attack their material with an authority and simmering menace that allows seemingly incompatible elements to come together in surprisingly complementary ways: the no-verse
column7: all-chorus single “No Time” finds an ideal home for a Nuggets-worthy harmony hook in the midst of a reggafied funk strut; “Dograces” hitches a deadpan vocal and grimy 4/4 groove to a regal keyboard fanfare and marching-band breakdown that suggests LCD Soundsystem gone prog.

column1: Inevitably
column2: when a band is being pulled in so many directions
column3: they’re bound to drift down a wayward path
column4: and the carnivalesque prance of “Ash Wednesday” makes you wonder why Dub Thompson saved their most focused performance for their most tedious song. But if not all of Dub Thompson’s ideas work
column5: the more important takeaway is that
column6: at this early stage
column7:
they sound like a band with no lack of them.

Justin Paul Vallesteros started out making guitar-centered
column2: conventionally structured
column3: and reverb-heavy music that’s most often described by some conflation of “bedroom pop” or “indie rock”. Similar to the majority of artists in that field
column4: his Craft Spells project wouldn’t have stood a chance if it was evaluated by the standard metrics of pop and rock: melodic ingenuity
column5: sonic innovation
column6: whether or not it actually “rocks”. The main appeal of Craft Spells is how the music gives the listener an ability to parse the many subtle differences in the various states of being by one’s self—there’s the attractive aspects (solitary
column7: lone) and the not-so-attractive (isolated
column8: lonely). The former were covered by his 2011 debut Idle Labor
column9: a solo record by necessity that dealt with crushes
column10: dates
column11: makeout sessions and of course
column12: post-breakup recoiling.  Influenced by Vallesteros’ admitted
column13: unhealthy relationship with social media
column14: Nausea unsurprisingly finds him erring towards the latter.

column1: This is a peculiar result
column2: as Craft Spells has left the proverbial bedroom
column3: enlisting a real producer and becoming a real band
column4: so the crude drum machines that often lent songs on Idle Labor a necessary
column5: rigid structure are swapped out for acoustic percussion that allows these new ones the chance to swing
column6: to shuffle
column7: to approach something close to typical rock catharsis. Likewise
column8: Vallesteros wrote the entirety of Nausea on piano
column9: while the harsh
column10: digital reverb is now soft and analog.

column1: Nausea often sounds disembodied
column2: as every instrument's given a glassy
column3: shellacked quality. “Twirl” nearly achieves liftoff in its chorus before tapering off
column4: lest it overheats and melts the surrounding coat. Nausea’s eerie sense of removal is most effective on the Elephant 6 reverie of “Komorebi”
column5: which takes its title from a Japanese word that loosely translates to “when sunlight filters through the trees”. At its best
column6: Nausea takes after “Komorebi” in evoking a feeling that doesn’t have an exact verbal equivalent while sounding anachronistic in a way that’s both unnerving and fascinating
column7: like watching colorized black & white movie.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the production and arrangements often have to compensate for the monochromatic songwriting. The conception of Nausea was delayed as Vallesteros battled writer’s block; after the release of 2012’s Gallery EP
column3: the Stockton transplant became bored with guitar
column4: intimidated by the Bay Area's focus on raw garage rock and hip-hop and paralyzed by his reliance on social media. These are topics that are ripe for exploration
column5: of feeling displaced and connected at the same time.

column1: And yet
column2: while nearly every track on Nausea finds Vallesteros trying to grapple with these issues
column3: he rarely wrenches out any insight or personal detail. Both plainspoken and vague
column4: the lyrics of Nausea sound like the result of someone simply trying to overpower a mental deadlock. What's more
column5: without the plug-and-play immediacy of Idle Labor
column6: the limitations of Vallesteros’ abilities as a legit frontman are put into sharper relief. “Changing Faces” taps into the feline playfulness of Japanese Whispers-era Cure by all but stealing its hook from “Let’s Go to Bed”
column7: but it’s overshadowed by a distracting
column8: offbeat verse that just sounds like it could use a better vocal take. Meanwhile
column9: if “First Snow” has the most instantly ingratiating melody
column10: it’s because Vallesteros slightly reworks the one from Idle Labor’s “After the Moment”
column11: his best song to date.

column1: Just because melody and verve aren’t the primary considerations for music of this sort doesn’t mean those considerations fail to matter. In fact
column2: those are often the exact things that allow artists to stand out; it’s not Vallesteros’ fault that he shares a label with Wild Nothing
column3: who created a standard to which Nausea appears to have aspired. But whereas Jack Tatum sounded emboldened by his success and richer production values on Nocturne
column4: Vallesteros retreats. There's evidence of his craftsmanship
column5: like “Komorebi” and the muffled trip-hop outlier “If I Could”
column6: which sound removed from the styles favored by his peers
column7: and it's fitting: as you’d expect from a record whose title alludes to Vallesteros' reaction to Internet overload
column8:
he’d be well advised to get some fresh air.

Whenever he talks about the White Stripes
column3: Jack White always stresses Meg White’s importance to the band—and how could he not? She was the only other person up on stage. In the current issue of Rolling Stone
column4: he says
column5: “I would often look at her onstage and say
column6: ‘I can’t believe she’s up here.’ I don’t think she understood how important she was to the band
column7: and to me and to music. She was the antithesis of a modern drummer. So childlike and incredible and inspiring.” That quote is a bit uncomfortable in its patronizing and primitivizing attitude toward Meg
column8: but the White Stripes emphasized the “childlike” in nearly every aspect of the band
column9: from their red-and-white wardrobe to their imaginative videos
column10: to songs like “We’re Going to be Friends”.

column1: Her chops might have been rudimentary
column2: but Meg kept Jack’s guitar virtuosity in check and kept their music from being merely a display of technique. He soloed frequently but never pointlessly
column3: and indulged none of the ostentatious jamming that defines blues rock: no white-boy blues face
column4: no standing at the lip of the stage
column5: no look-how-deeply-I-am-feeling-these-notes bullshit. That playful sound is what made the White Stripes so revolutionary in the 2000s. The blues has always prized instrumental prowess
column6: but blues rock typically equates that trait with authenticity of emotion. After so many generations of Eric Claptons and Jonny Langs
column7: it was refreshing at the turn of the century to hear someone have fun with the form again. Like first-gen punks
column8: the White Stripes proved you didn’t have to be good to be great
column9: that your limitations could enable rather than hinder expression. Theirs was a little room
column10: as Jack sang on White Blood Cells
column11: but they still found many corners.

column1: Since the White Stripes split
column2: however
column3: Jack moved into a bigger room
column4: surrounded by musicians who are capable in the traditional sense of the word. His work has become fuller
column5: of course
column6: more elaborate and more conventionally ambitious; his idiosyncrasies have dimmed a bit
column7: too
column8: so his music is less subversive
column9: less culture-shaking
column10: less special. Despite their pedigree
column11: the Raconteurs never really figured out their mission (although hiring country singer Ashley Monroe might be mission enough). The Dead Weather can be admirably heavy and darkly savage
column12: but also dour and claustrophobic
column13: as though the riffs are closing in on you. White’s debut album
column14: 2012’s Blunderbuss
column15: reportedly inspired by his divorce from Karen Elson
column16: sounded uncharacteristically bilious
column17: especially from the man who wrote “Dead Leaves and the Dirty Ground”. In fact
column18: nowadays White might be most compelling as a label impresario who releases new singles via balloons and coaxes Neil Young to record a covers album in a modified phone booth. It’s the one role where he displays the same sense of childlike whimsy that motivated the White Stripes.

column1: Lazaretto makes all of his other projects sound a bit scrawny by comparison. It’s the densest
column2: fullest
column3: craziest
column4: and most indulgent that White has sounded with or without Meg—almost pointedly so
column5: as though he’s trying to shake the minimalism that defined the White Stripes. It’s an almost self-consciously busy-minded album
column6: chockablock with ideas and sounds
column7: all colliding violently and sometimes brutally. There’s a lot of pedal steel
column8: a lot more barrelhouse piano
column9: some folksy strumming
column10: some rock-rapping
column11: and the persistent buzz of White’s guitar. The most decorous and over-the-top song on Lazaretto (and arguably the standout) “Would You Fight for My Love?” plays like an exquisite corpse: It opens with a low
column12: Lynchian hum
column13: the kind you hear in your bowels
column14: then morphs into something like a rock ballad
column15: with Ikey Owens pounding out power chords on the piano. With its flatulent bass
column16: the bridge sounds like Goblin scoring a murder scene
column17: complete with spooky disembodied vocals. The song ends up in a Celtic honkytonk
column18: somehow.

column1: The instrumental “High Ball Stepper” is loaded with Bernard Hermann anxieties
column2: while “Temporary Ground” elaborates gently on rural folk music
column3: opening with a violin dancing gingerly around Maggie Björklund’s pedal steel (the song was reportedly inspired by gigantic lily pads that can support a man’s weight). “Just One Drink” plays like a Coca-Cola jingle; “Entitlement” is stately C&W. Not everything fits together fluidly
column4: but that might just be the point: These disparate sounds are not just accessories to be applied to blues rock
column5: but rich veins of tradition that compete for primacy on Lazaretto. White invites us to see the craft here
column6: to notice the seams
column7: to consider the contrasts—not necessarily out of any self-congratulatory impulse
column8: but out of awe for the endless permutations of American popular music.

column1: White comes across like a man out of time on Lazaretto
column2: a role that proves more sympathetic and relatable than the embittered lover he played on Blunderbuss; he seems to be having a lot more fun yelling at the kids to get off his lawn. “There are children today who were lied to
column3: told the world is rightfully theirs
column4: ” he sings on “Entitlement”
column5: a countercultural anthem that political midpoint between “Signs” and “Okie from Muskogee”. “Don’t they feel like they're cheated somehow? I feel like I've been cheated somehow.” His is not necessarily a generational complaint
column6: though; instead
column7: he just can’t understand why something given could ever be as precious as something earned.

column1: In its volleys of nimble-fingered riffs and its willy-nilly combination of styles
column2: Lazaretto is all about virtuosity
column3: with White reverting back to the idea of blues rock as a form of emotional confession: a space where you can project feelings and re-enact age-old dramas. Yet
column4: White sneaks in a few jokes at the idea. Witness this scene from “The Black Bat Licorice”: “She writes letters like a Jack Chick comic
column5: just a bunch of propaganda/ She makes my fingers histrionic
column6: like this [paint-peeling guitar riff] and this [paint-peeling guitar riff]!” It’s a funny little moment in a song that otherwise sounds leery of desire
column7: wary of love
column8: simultaneously burdened and freed by sex. Somehow
column9: even with White rapping his lyrics like leprous carnival barker
column10: it’s a great

""I consistently felt myself to be not male or female

column4: and they come to mind when hearing the music made by Shamir Bailey. With a piercing countertenor somewhere between Prince masquerading as Camille and the cracking adolescent soul of the teenage Michael Jackson
column5: the 19-year-old North Las Vegas native dismantles the expectations maintained for vocalists based on their gender
column6: demanding instead that the focus be placed on his agile
column7: fluttering performances. His debut EP
column8: Northtown
column9: is named for the dusty suburban neighborhood where he grew up; it finds Shamir moving back and forth between sweet
column10: almost holy purity and unearthly hysteria over churning
column11: minimal house tracks.

column1: Shamir is still a new hand at writing and recording dance music; raised on an omnivorous musical diet of rock
column2: hip-hop
column3: jazz
column4: and R&B
column5: the first explicitly beat-driven track he wrote ended up launching his career. “If It Wasn’t True” remains a stunning opening salvo

column7: threatening instrumental tones before devolving into a chaotic mess
column8: swallowed by a haphazardly firing synth corroding in real-time. It’s a contrast that’s employed several times throughout Northtown
column9: and it manages to retain its effectiveness because it’s so stark and clear
column10: as Shamir’s fragile
column11: yearning voice is pitted against aggressive
column12: hard-charging electronics that actively warp and decay as the songs develop.

column1: The toughness and rigidity of the instrumentation plays well against his lyrics
column2: too. Shamir spends most of Northtown in a state of constant romantic turmoil
column3: and thanks to the delicacy of his voice it sounds like he’s exploring new depths of disappointment with each new track. On “If It Wasn’t True”
column4: he’s trying to process a relationship that quickly soured
column5: eventually settling into a tenuous but deadened peace; the core of the filthy
column6: pulsing “Sometimes a Man” is his resigned sigh
column7: “Sometimes a man ain’t what he says he is/ Sometimes a man is just a man.” You can picture him rolling his eyes and exhaling slowly while a synth spirals out of control
column8: leaping around like a Roomba gone rogue before falling into a dead-eyed pulse. The volatile electronics seem like windows into Shamir’s psyche: anger and resentment made into ferocious backing tracks
column9: shielding his heartbreak.

column1: The one song on Northtown that deviates from the distorted electronics first glimpsed on “If It Wasn’t True” is its closer
column2: a cover of Canadian country singer Lindi Ortega’s 2013 track “Lived and Died Alone” that Shamir cut with a single microphone in just one take. Accompanied by just an acoustic guitar
column3: it’s a lonely lament that quickly blackens into something a little more sinister: resigned to a solitary existence
column4: he journeys in the dead of night and excavates a bunch of graves
column5: giving the deserted dead the love he never had the chance to receive himself. It’s strange
column6: surprisingly tender
column7: and blessed with an alien beauty; in other words
column8:
a perfect fit for Shamir.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20642/homepage_large.f3d4ec76.jpg|Savage Gold|22209.0|Tombs|['Rock'
column3: in retrospect
column4: like a working laboratory for the success of Savage Gold
column5: their third album and one of the year’s absolute heavy metal masterstrokes. For the first five years of their existence
column6: Tombs felt undecided
column7: a college kid cycling through survey courses while searching for a major. On a series of EPs

column11: Path of Totality

column13: seething black metal and prismatic psychedelia
column14: forcing those forms into inchoate but intriguing shapes.

column1: But Savage Gold betrays no such indecision
column2: from the production choices to the stunning execution. Working with American death metal demigod <a href=""http://www.manarecording.com/mana-clientlist.php"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Erik Rutan in his St. Petersburg
column3: Fla.
column4: recording studio
column5: Tombs mostly mustered the heaviest elements of its sound—breakneck blast beats and high-stacked guitars
column6: irascible screams and punishing repetition—for a cohesive
column7: propulsive
column8: and definitive statement. Tombs made the decision to keep it relatively simple on Savage Gold
column9: and that mandate has reanimated the band for 57 extreme and urgent minutes.

column1: Tombs begins these 10 tracks with an ominous groan of organ creaks and doom guitar sweeps
column2: but the lull is short-lived: Drummer Andrew Hernandez II slaps his kit twice and then steps on the double-bass pedal
column3: commencing a blast beat that swells and shrinks but doesn’t actually stop for the song’s first two minutes. Across Savage Gold
column4: Hernandez emerges as the hero
column5: not only guiding the band through its twists between riffs and breaks between verses but also constantly redoubling each song’s intensity. He often sets a pace and then
column6: at just the perfect moment
column7: fills the space between the beats
column8: acts of sudden escalation that push Savage Gold from a series of plateaus into a succession of peaks. “Ashes” nods to Darkthrone
column9: particularly in Hill’s scabrous Nocturno Culto vocal homage.

column1: But it’s Hernandez who does the heavy lifting
column2: switching—seamlessly
column3: repeatedly—between breathless blitzes
column4: stuttering turnarounds and driving
column5: four-on-the-floor wallop. Hill
column6: guitarist Garrett Bussanick and bassist Ben Brand often split the leads and the distorted textures and counters that surround them. They pass the riffs around and decorate them in a way that emphasizes the momentum more than the melody itself. By shifting so much of the movement to Hernandez’s drums
column7: Savage Gold is locked in motion that’s more felt than heard
column8: more intuited than observed. The decision makes the eight-minute ""Echoes"" seem much shorter; the whole record becomes an unending rush.

column1: Savage Gold has breaks in the armor
column2: of course
column3: moments where the drumming thunder and the piercing guitars acquiesce to less identifiable
column4: less forceful sounds. The tripwire riffs of “Echoes”
column5: for instance
column6: decay into a slow cycle of feedback
column7: while
column8: just before the end
column9: “Portraits” pulls back on its headlong rush to reveal a gale of bristling tones beneath the beating. But those passing moments—and even the cold
column10: five-minute stare of the album’s only reserved track
column11: “Severed Lives”—serve mostly as setups for a takedown
column12: spreading a calm canvas for the band to soon rip through it.

column1: Just when the electric whorl of guitars at the close of “Portraits” starts to feel almost safe
column2: Hernandez leads the attack of “Seance”
column3: his drums puncturing the reverie as the guitars coil around another militant meter. “Severed Lives” is a menacing drift of hissed vocals and slowly loping bass; after four minutes
column4: it even sublimates into a bowed
column5: sinister drone. It’s only a feint
column6: a trap for the explosive finale of “Spiral
column7: ” the radiant and complicated closer that recapitulates the enthusiasm and magnetism of the entire album. Again and again
column8: Tombs mitigate the rumble between a string of onslaughts
column9: tempering one moment only to make the next more effective.

column1: Tombs’ sense of timing
column2: economy and impact throughout Savage Gold suggests the successes of Aesthethica
column3: the second album by another similarly searching Brooklyn metal band
column4: Liturgy. But Hill has no manifestos
column5: no flashpoint politics
column6: elements that would only distract from his band’s newfound decisiveness and direction. Still
column7: Savage Gold’s energy suggests the same sort of “ecstasy” as Aesthethica
column8: a feeling that also gives it concomitant crossover appeal. Maybe that’s a surprising suggestion
column9: that the album where Tombs digs its heels into heavy metal and works with one of the genre’s bulwark producers might be the one that pushes its reputation farthest afield of metal itself. But you can feel their newfound focus and commitment here
column10:
racing through every new crest Hernandez hits or each burly refrain Hill bellows. It seems like a valiant journey through what he calls “Shades of darkness/ Kingdoms of ashes”—triumphant and without trepidation.

Watter is a post-rock project that just drifted into view out of nowhere and will probably exit in a similar manner. Post-rock is a genre full of such maneuvers—the Tortoise family tree
column2: for example
column3: is scattered with one-off projects that flickered into life then ended before they really had a chance to begin. At some point in the 1990s
column4: you could barely pick up a record on Thrill Jockey without it bearing a credit from John McEntire or one of his bandmates. It’s possible that Watter is more of a long-term proposition

column6: Zak Riles from Grails
column7: and Louisville musician Tyler Trotter
column8: plus guests Rachel Grimes (Rachel’s) and Tony Levin (King Crimson)—clearly have other things in mind beside this band. This World is a selection of six instrumentals that plays to their collective strengths
column9: which essentially involves slow
column10: patient builds; acres of repetition
column11: touches of prog-like guitar
column12: and subtle piano and electronic elements that underpin everything at all the right moments.

column1: If Walford comes off as something of an enigma—a view only enhanced by the recent Slint documentary
column2: Breadcrumb Trail—there won’t be any further light shed on his character from this album. There’s a faint arc that builds through the record
column3: essentially heading from the resolutely downcast “Rustic Fog” then expanding gradually into the light until the feeling is positively bright by the time the closing title track emerges. But mostly it’s a series of question marks and false trails
column4: driven by music caught up in the divide between simple and complex gestures. It’s pretty
column5: at times

column7: illustrating how well this band can settle into a comedown state

column1: Despite deviations into brevity
column2: Watter is clearly a band most comfortable when working at length
column3: as illustrated by the two 12-minute-plus tracks at the center of This World. “Small Business” is all loops of thickset rock guitar that only misfires when it heads toward an overly familiar loud-quiet-loud dynamic that feels like the band just hit the autopilot button and checked out for a while. “Seawater” is the better of the two longer songs
column4: mainly because it manages to forge connections between industrialized electronics
column5: a drum sound that has the power of Walford’s playing on the Breeders’ Pod
column6: and quasi-medieval plucking that turns into strident rock riffing. On “Small Business” the band sounds lost
column7: but on “Seawater” they're fully in control

column4: it felt like McMahan was travelling through a range of material both tightly wound and loosely constructed

column6: too

column8: or at least form an idea of one and head toward it. There’s hope and warmth in these tracks
column9: even when they’re at their most gloomy. Musicians who work in this field often seem to find it difficult to talk about what inspired them to make music this way

Walford has struggled to explain Spiderland in recent interviews on the topic. In Watter he’s found another suitably inscrutable vehicle to skew his ideas around.

column9: admonishment-flinging second of Bodies finds Priests—Greer

column12: and bassist Taylor Mulitz—all revved up and ready to go: for them

you just made the list.

Bodies—which follows two small-batch cassettes and a 7"" on the band's own Sister Polygon imprint—may be Priests' big coming-out party

column19: volunteering at storied District hotspot Fort Reno. After launching Priests in 2012
column20: they quickly made a name for themselves on the back of their fiery live shows. Even on record

column22: largely unconcerned with polish
column23: careening fitfully from one provocation to the next. Jaguar's deranged-surfer anti-riffs and Mulitz's corkscrewing basslines chase each other like junkyard dogs
column24: never letting each other out of their sights for very long. Daniele's deeply innate drumwork is the cool-headed counterpoint to her bandmates' writhing and reeling. And Greer

column28: splitting the difference between control and chaos.

column1: Sure

column4: and NYC b-movie-obsessives the Cramps

column8: from the first blast of feedback to the flirtation with light treason that closes it out

column10:
it has neither the time nor the patience for fucking around.

While promising enough
column11: Priests' pre-Bodies releases too often seemed resigned to simple sloganeering
column12: to placing message above medium. Songs about the pernicious influence of television
column13: product placement
column14: and
column15: er

column18: two more seemed pulled from the pages of a dog-eared Punk 101 textbook. At its best

column20: a powerful weapon to train on a more deserving set of targets. On ""Powertrip

column22:
she's reminding us how often creature comforts place a wedge between the haves from the have-nots. ""Right Wing"" reels off a laundry list of invasive police-state maneuvers; ""Modern Love/No Weapon"" lifts lines from punk progenitor Jonathan Richman and image poet Diane Wakoski as a way of outlining its ""plans to disrupt.""

It'd be reductive to pigeonhole Priests as merely a political act

column25: ""but you go into an old house
column26: and everything is so scary."" You can take ""New"" as a charred childhood memory or a quick-take comment on our disposable culture; for Priests

column29: which kicks off with purse searches and pep rallies. Still
