column32: but its first few lines imagine an Elmer's-huffing teen scribbling something about ""monkeys and robots
column33:
monkey and robots"" in the folds of a math ledger.

Does Greer contradict herself? Sure
column35: and there are times when it seems she's throwing just about everything at the wall in the hopes that some of it'll stick. But political lyrics—or any lyrics
column36: really—need not be coherent to hit home; they've just got to be compelling. Greer occasionally treads over well-worn territory; sometimes she seems to sling her lyrical Molotovs at anything that isn't bolted down. And there are plenty of moments where Greer seems almost pressed for time; the onslaught of interviews Priests have given in the run-up to Bodies illuminate many of the EP's less readily apparent messages
column38: portions of Bodies remain open to interpretation

too.”

Priests are still a relatively new band

Sébastien Tellier has never been one to shy away from huge concepts. Since launching his career in 2001 with an assist from his pals in the frothy French pop duo Air
column3: he’s laden his albums with the weight of terms like Politics and Sexuality. Even when he’s taking a more personal tack
column4: like on 2012’s My God Is Blue
column5: he still supplies lofty backstories
column6: and his new record
column7: L’Aventura
column8: is no different: the album is supposed to be a musical reimagining of his childhood
column9: a fantasy inspired by the sights of sounds of Brazil rather than the reality of his French home.

column1: Tellier likes to jump between genres with a dilettante’s flair—in his decade-plus of recording
column2: he’s flitted between traditional chanson
column3: lewd French touch
column4: and completely orchestral composition
column5: with varying degrees of success—so his dive into the rich world of Brazilian music should be taken with a grain of salt or two. To wit: in an interview with Noisey
column6: he admitted that he tried to limit his interaction with Brazilian music before making the record as a means of preserving the childlike naiveté necessary for a genuine revision of his youth. Thankfully
column7: he solicited some help realizing his vision: veteran French musicians Jean-Michel Jarre and Philippe Zdar (of house duo Cassius) participated in the album’s recording and mixing
column8: and celebrated Brazilian composer Arthur Verocai contributed many of the album’s string and backing vocal arrangements. Verocai also helped to secure the collaboration of Brazilian jazz drummer Robertinho Silva
column9: whose percussion can be heard throughout L’Aventura.

column1: Tellier’s choice to trust experienced
column2: highly skilled Brazilian session players with the fruits of his imagination is one of the best decisions of his career. L’Aventura sounds immaculate
column3: verdant
column4: and rich; strings swoop and fly in the background
column5: cascading around Tellier’s thick baritone
column6: while bass lines pop and rhythms dance with a surprising lightness. These are densely arranged
column7: complicated songs
column8: so buoyancy and deftness are unexpected and very welcome elements. That’s not to say that Tellier doesn’t occasionally go overboard; his liberal application of animal noises wears thin pretty quickly
column9: and his vocal takes always tread the line between velvety smoothness and smarmy lecherousness. “Love”
column10: flecked with jazzy flute and fluttering vocal tapestries
column11: edges dangerously close to hypothetical Anchorman 3: Ron in Rio soundtrack territory
column12: but for the most part L’Aventura avoids such overripe missteps.

column1: When the album succeeds
column2: its joy and precision transcend any language barriers that might exist; though the album is almost entirely sung in French
column3: its sweeping arrangements and sunny melodies make it easy for non-Francophones to accompany Tellier on his journey through his hypothetical youth. “Sous Les Rayons du Soleil” (“Under the Sun’s Rays”) glides effortlessly
column4: like a boat slicing through calm water; the dark
column5: turbulent “Ricky L’adolescent” (“Ricky the Teenager”)
column6: which depicts Tellier meeting a druggy
column7: grumpy 15-year-old version of himself
column8: is a funhouse farce with stabbing strings and funky
column9: percolating synth lines. Listeners who can’t interact directly with Tellier’s lyrics might have to dig a little to optimize their experience with L’Aventura
column10: but it’s thrilling to hear him attempt to pull off his high-concept ideas solely through smart composition and musical skill.

column1: The album’s most ambitious moment is also its most impenetrable: “Comment revoir oursinet?” (roughly
column2: “How to See Oursinet Again”) is a 14-minute odyssey that splits the album into two halves
column3: moving from spacey synth-pop to soaring balladry and back as Tellier journeys in search of the titular bear
column4: a common figure in French Christmas stories. The song takes a while to unfold and compromises the album’s flow
column5: but its scope and sheer breadth is undeniably impressive. More than a decade into his career
column6: Tellier can’t help himself—he’s still a sucker for the big moment
column7: the lofty idea
column8: the EP-length monolith
column9: and with <i>L’Aventura
column10:
he’s done a fine job of sticking the landing.

The music of Mayhem has rarely
column2: if ever
column3: been able to scream for itself. As much a brand as a band
column4: they epitomize the intersection of fame and infamy in black metal. They are co-architects of a sound and style
column5: yes
column6: but they’ve been so beset by the trail of their actions and attitudes that the substance of that sound has often been a secondary concern. Talk about their 20-year-old
column7: still-thrilling debut
column8: De Mysteriis Dom Sathanas
column9: generally doesn’t center on its lurid
column10: feral sounds
column11: the unstable song structures or even the mania of fill-in frontman Attila Csihar. It focuses
column12: instead
column13: on the preceding death of singer Dead and the talismans cut from his splintered skull
column14: or how a substitute bassist and general henchman came to kill the band’s leader and label head before the album could come out.

column1: There’s also the Nazi skulduggery that came with their reunion
column2: fits of violence offstage and onstage
column3: and the near-constant member turnover. At best
column4: those messes are sidecars for the risky string of records they’ve made during the last three decades; most of the time
column5: they dominate the conversation. Mayhem are the heavy metal equivalent of an incredible
column6: ignominious professional athlete whose record-setting career statistics are pockmarked by a series of asterisks for steroid use
column7: gambling scandals
column8: and generally bad behavior.

column1: Esoteric Warfare
column2: their newest album and first since 2007’s scraping-and-clawing Ordo Ad Chao
column3: does not altogether dispatch with the controversy. Yet again
column4: Mayhem has a new lineup: their guitarist of 13 years
column5: Blasphemer
column6: exited soon after the last album
column7: replaced by Teloch
column8: a mechanical but experimental type who played with drummer Hellhammer in the overlooked Norwegian band Nidingr. He's the third key guitarist to play on a Mayhem album; they've at least managed to keep Attila as a frontman
column9: making this the first time he’s ever appeared on two consecutive Mayhem albums.

column2: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">Though no current member is also a permanent one
column3: Mayhem have existed for 30 years
column4: making them elder statesmen of a scene and sound that's currently reaping the rewards of an international youth infusion. But they don’t play like old men: if anything
column5: the controversy and the instability it fosters keep the band’s music (ironically
column6: the very thing from which it distracts) invigorated by a wide-eyed sense of possibility. All of Mayhem’s albums
column7: for better and worse
column8: have seemed like searching
column9: unapologetic quests for internal reinvention; fables and murders
column10: suicides and idiocy notwithstanding: that’s the reason to care about a new Mayhem album in 2014.

column1: Esoteric Warfare isn’t as far-reaching as some of its predecessors
column2: but it’s still an adventurous and energetic record built on stylistic explorations and enthusiastic shifts that you wouldn’t expect from a band that’s had three decades to codify its own sound. They remain
column3: at their core
column4: a black metal act. “Trinity” is a rudimentary convulsion with drums that can’t stop shaking
column5: and guitars that can’t choose between suffocation and laceration—but it’s also the stock black metal song here
column6: and one of the album’s least remarkable moments as a result.

column1: Mayhem are better when testing their limits. During “Psywar
column2: ” Teloch almost plays against himself
column3: pitting a militaristic churn with oblong counter-riffs that pull against the momentum. “Corpse of Care” steps gradually from am ominous spoken-word lull into a barbaric grindcore tantrum
column4: shaping the song into an ever-morphing phantom. Everything seems to happen at once on opener “Watcher”
column5: one of the best and most involved songs of the band’s career. It’s a slingshot of hyperactivity
column6: jumping from an all-angles attack to a slow-motion doom lurch and back again. Attila has rarely sounded like such a commanding frontman
column7: either. Within these six minutes
column8: he shifts between a demented yammer and the low-end incantations familiar from his stints in Sunn O))). He laces between both with the throat-singing ululations that have become his trademark. He’s found a way to make his multiple music personalities collaborate
column9: not compete.

column1: Esoteric Warfare is an album of lyrical child’s play
column2: a teenager’s diary of paranoia and petulance. If black metal was born of adolescent hardcore rage
column3: Mayhem has taken care not to forsake that spirit for Thelemic conjecture or ideological manifestos. Instead
column4: Attila writes about the madness of mind control (“Brainwaves in hyperspace
column5: transmitting fear!”)
column6: the conspiracies of corporate ruin (“Poison Frankenfood … Forced vaccinations!”)
column7: and the arrival of alien overlords systems (“Spikes of electrodes injected into the skull!”).  He worships the restart button of the atomic bomb and
column8: like a misanthropic Tom Robbins
column9: shouts the word for evil from 18 different cultures. Maybe those woes seem pedestrian
column10: but they serve as powerful
column11: primitive fodder for Mayhem. “Throne of Time”
column12: the one about aliens
column13: radiates anxiety with its starts and stops and riffs that continually cycle back on themselves
column14: afraid of what might come with progress. And “Posthuman
column15: ” the one about the bees and the food and evolution’s end
column16: stomps through its list of grievances like a child. They pick up the pace in bursts
column17: but Mayhem generally act as Csihar’s hangdog vehicle of existential despair
column18: framing his worry in barbed noise and broken rhythms.

column1: There is one elder aspect worth noting here: Mayhem now chooses its battles wisely. Grand Declarations of War dove headlong into song suites and electronic convolutions. Chimera tested a metalcore edge. Ordo Ad Chao wrestled with abstruse song structures. But Esoteric Warfare feels like an attempt to balance experimental impasses with sustained belligerence
column2: low tempos with unchecked speed. Where there once might have been a twist
column3: there is now silence or a return to order. This is a less audacious Mayhem
column4: then
column5: but perhaps a more distinct and sustainable one
column6: too. After 30 years
column7:
Esoteric Warfare is a Mayhem album worth talking about more for its sounds than its associated baggage.

In his 1995 book Morrissey: Landscapes of the Mind
column2: author David Bret recounts the events of March 15
column4: the day after Morrissey’s Vauxhall and I was released. Bret attended Morrissey’s first ever autograph-signing party in Great Britain to promote one of his solo albums
column5: and for such an unprecedented event
column6: the HMV on Oxford Street in London had planned for a crowd of five hundred. Three thousand people showed up. While tossing out his customary gladioli at the long queue of his followers
column7: a badge pinned to his tweed jacket was visible. It read
column8: “Famous when dead.”

column1: The scene’s a tableau straight out of the collective mythological dream of Morrissey fandom. But Morrissey had actual death on his mind at the time
column2: and not just the romantically morbid vision of it he’d been singing about since his time in the Smiths. Former David Bowie guitarist Mick Ronson—a hero of Morrissey’s who had produced his prior album
column3: 1992’s Your Arsenal—had succumbed to cancer months earlier
column4: and Morrissey’s manager and his video director both had died around the same time. The remastered 20th anniversary reissue of Vauxhall and I doesn’t reveal the album to be a work of spiritual reassessment in the face of loss
column5: nor some rote meditation on mortality. But in hindsight
column6: it’s clearer than ever that Morrissey—whose self-obsession has always worked hand in glove with a yearning for connection—infused Vauxhall and I with a bone-deep acceptance that aging and dying might be more than just dramatic devices.

column1: To be clear
column2: Vauxhall and I doesn't lack drama; its major fault is a surfeit of the stuff
column3: which is saying something considering Morrissey’s threshold for thespianism. Never a stranger to literary references
column4: he structures “Billy Budd” around the Herman Melville novella of the same name—hardly an obscure source
column5: and purloined with brazen exactness—and “Now My Heart Is Full” isn’t any more coy about its debt to Graham Greene’s Brighton Rock
column6: even going so far as to list by name the book’s main characters including its antihero Pinkie Brown
column7: the archetype of Morrissey’s sexually conflicted
column8: sensitive-bad-boy persona. The two songs are just as blatant in execution: Where “Billy Budd” is fast
column9: forceful
column10: and full of wah-pedal guitar hooks—a bracing break from the glam/rockabilly hybrid established on Your Arsenal—“Now My Heart Is Full” is a sweeping
column11: nearly orchestral crescendo that builds and builds into infinity. “I just can’t explain/ So I won’t even try to”
column12: Morrissey sings
column13: aiming his voice at the angels. And then
column14: as one does
column15: he keeps explaining.

column1: Morrissey’s emotional over-enunciation takes on new dimensions on Vauxhall and I
column2: to mixed results. “The More You Ignore Me
column3: the Closer I Get” became a hit single on both sides of the Atlantic
column4: and for reasons that are still evident: it’s a sterling pop gem
column5: jangling yet airy
column6: with Morrissey going the extra mile to put the “play” in wordplay. “I will be in the bar/ With my head on the bar”
column7: he croons
column8: grinning at his own deceptive daftness. But he’s also toying with his own public image as a sexless recluse while neatly turning the tables on his hordes of obsessive fans by lampooning the way they might feel about Morrissey himself.

column1: Acknowledging and then tinkering with the very mechanism of fame was something Morrissey had already been aiming at long before 1994 rolled around. His solo career had finally taken off
column2: proving that his early success with his 1988 solo debut
column3: Viva Hate
column4: hadn’t been a fluke born of post-Smiths goodwill. If Viva Hate had tried desperately to sound like The Smiths
column5: Vauxhall and I marked the point at which Morrissey became fixed on a forward trajectory that would occasionally falter but never change. Morrissey was indeed being ignored by the media
column6: at least relative to his platinum-selling
column7: alt-rock-vet contemporaries like R.E.M. and the Cure. Vauxhall and I went in at number-one on the British charts
column8: a feat that made “The More You Ignore Me
column9: the Closer I Get” a self-fulfilling prophecy in earworm form.

column1: What imbalances Vauxhall and I is an overabundance of ballads that border on the bland. A full half of the album—“Hold on to Your Friends”
column2: “I Am Hated for Loving”
column3: “Lifeguard Sleeping
column4: Girl Drowning”
column5: “Used to Be a Sweet Boy”
column6: and “The Lazy Sunbathers”—are musically unremarkable
column7: scraps of patterned wallpaper that don’t stretch Morrissey’s range or imagination into new places the way Johnny Marr’s restless
column8: unpredictable compositions once did in the Smiths. Morrissey’s voice itself is a gorgeous moan on these tracks
column9: textured and resonant
column10: and he explores a broad dynamic of themes
column11: from decadent
column12: morally negligent beachgoers during World War II to piercing pleas for the valuation of friendship—a topic that hit considerably closer to home in the wake of his recent grief.

column1: But guitarists Alain Whyte and Boz Boorer—not yet confident enough to push-and-pull with their boss
column2: songwriting-wise—hang back for too much of the record
column3: leaving Morrissey’s vocal melodies to do all the heavy lifting. Steve Lillywhite’s production is layered and immaculately atmospheric
column4: which fits the ballads beautifully
column5: while also making rockers like “Billy Budd” sound muddy rather than punchy
column6: faults that don't improve even with the solid remastering job the reissue has been given. In that regard
column7: “Spring-Heeled Jim” is the most successful song on Vauxhall and I: throbbing with menace and shrouded in stage fog
column8: it’s a tough
column9: tender
column10: and erotically encrypted character study
column11: perfectly suited to Lillywhite’s shimmer and the stalking riffs of Whyte and Boorer.

column1: Morrissey’s bitterness ebbs and flows like the tides
column2: and it’s rising on Vauxhall and I. His court battle over royalties with his former Smiths bandmate Mike Joyce was still on the horizon in 1994
column3: but he was already sharpening his knives. “Why Don’t You Find Out For Yourself” is one of the album’s best tracks
column4: and one of Morrissey’s most quietly magnificent solo songs: “I’ve been stabbed in the back/ So many
column5: many times/ I don’t have any skin
column6: ” he sings
column7: weariness overtaking defiance. It’s a monument to artful passive aggression—another Morrissey hallmark brought to a new level on Vauxhall and I—but the song’s strength lies in the stark contrast between medium and message. Too much of the album melts together into a shapelessly lovely mass of melancholy and reflection; on “Why Don’t You Find Out For Yourself”
column8: rage and resignation are reconciled
column9: or perhaps just deliciously confused
column10: while Whyte and Boorer strum along
column11: gentle yet jaunty
column12: adding a bracing shot of ambiguity and tension. And on “Billy Budd”
column13: the Melville homage is lowered just long enough for Morrissey to mount an attack against—or maybe just a wink toward—the band that made him famous. “Things have been bad/ But now it’s twelve years on
column14: he laments
column15: and it can’t be possible he was unaware that the Smiths had formed exactly twelve years before Vauxhall and I was made.

column1: Only one Smiths song makes it onto the live album

column3: that comprises the bonus tracks of the Vauxhall and I reissue: “London”
column4: a speedy
column5: stomping throwaway that feels like more of a snub to the audience than if he’d played no Smiths songs at all. The rest of the concert is performed obediently

column3: it gives a bit of extra context: In ’94 and ’95
column4: Britpop was on the ascendant
column5: and Morrissey found himself trying to keep up with Oasis
column6: Blur
column7: and Suede—three disparate
column8: competing bands that
column9: at the least
column10: agreed on the greatness and influence of the Smiths. As a solo artist
column11: though
column12: Morrissey never settled comfortably into the Britpop paradigm
column13: which adds that much more of a sense of estrangement to the stoic loneliness that permeates his work
column14: even as he should have been embracing his role as a Britpop elder statesman.

column1: Morrissey is a funny man
column2: but there are few light moments in Vauxhall and I. “I am close to breakdown at life’s inevitably disgusting final summons
column3: ” he writes
column4: a bit tactlessly
column5: in last year’s Autobiography while recalling a funeral for a close colleague he attended in 1993
column6: just as he was gearing up to record Vauxhall and I. Nothing like the death of a friend might unsettle one’s stomach. But that’s always been one of Morrissey’s most magnificent talents: not just turning a phrase
column7: but twisting sentimentality itself until it’s sharp enough to sting. The barb jabs both ways
column8: even when that joke isn’t funny anymore. <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ownZDWNIRs"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">“Fame
column9: fame
column10: fatal fame”
column11: he sang while in the Smiths; by 1994
column12: a “Famous when dead” badge was one small symbol of how he’d internalized the acclaim that he’d fought so long to get. Besides being one of Morrissey’s most vital solo albums
column13: Vauxhall and I is also his first truly mature one
column14: and flaws and all
column15:
it’s as essential—and as perversely alive—as ever.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20623/homepage_large.c2050df7.jpg|Early Riser|32229.0|Taylor McFerrin|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brainfeeder']|2014-06-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:57.999166|"

Taylor McFerrin's debut Early Riser has been in the oven for a while. In the fall of 2010
column2: a three-track sampler briefly made the rounds
column3: and then not much else was heard in the intervening years from the composer/multi-instrumentalist and son of improv legend Bobby McFerrin. Now the album's arrived on Brainfeeder—Flying Lotus' ever-expanding imprint that has become a haven for artists who consider themselves neither round nor square pegs—there are traces of that original sampler that remain. That link to an earlier incarnation of Early Riser is ""Place in My Heart""
column4: a pleasing if somnolent dollop of funk that finds most of its structure in vocalist RYAT's contributions.

column1: As a straight-up producer
column2: McFerrin has a knack for knowing just how many elements he can balance before things topple over
column3: which speaks to his proclivities as a jazz fusionist; but Early Riser is by no means the kind of affair that'll leave you struggling to orient yourself. The majority of the album passes by in a pleasant swirl
column4: to the point that McFerrin's efforts could be mistaken for complacency. For every moment of undeniable beauty
column5: such as the more recent single ""The Antidote"" and the moving ""Decisions""
column6: there are just as many that feel like closing your fist on a handful of sand. When ""Degrees of Light"" finishes
column7: any imprint it left evaporates immediately with it. Without a strong anchor
column8: much of Early Riser floats away into the atmosphere long before you even notice it's gone.

column1: On Early Riser McFerrin often builds towards an unforseen point without reaching a clear resolution
column2: but this approach occasionally yields positive results. ""Postpartum"" gradually swells
column3: picking up pieces along the way like a musical Katamari; it never quite achieves liftoff
column4: but the slow
column5: exaggerated stretch is pleasing regardless. The aforementioned ""Stepps"" circles higher and higher over five minutes without ever finding a release.

column1: That moment of release finally arrives on the album-closing ""PLS DNT LISTEN""
column2: a necessary jolt of adrenaline on an album that otherwise takes its time thawing out. At its conclusion
column3: Early Riser's title proves a misnomer—this is an album built for slow weekend mornings spent in bed with a loved one more than brisk
column4:
early-morning runs.

"|19406.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19406-taylor-mcferrin-early-riser/|6.8|Renato Pagnani

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20591/homepage_large.7b82b321.jpg|Third Time to Harm|32288.0|OBN IIIs|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tic Tac Totally']|2014-06-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:36:58.811114|"

The current landscape of garage rock is overrun by bands who find heroes in Sabbath and the Stooges
column2: so it's rare in 2014 to find an artist that invokes the masters of ultra-mainstream radio rock from the late 1970s and early 1980s
column3: a sub-genre that the comedian Marc Maron recently described as townie music. We're talking Van Halen
column4: AC/DC
column5: Skynyrd
column6: Nugent
column7: ZZ Top—bands that binged on masculinity and guitar heroics and made hit records that sounded really good when they were played loudly. They made songs that were ideal for pushing the speed limit
column8: lifting weights
column9: getting in bar fights
column10: flirtin' with disaster
column11: and for those moments where you ain't talkin' 'bout love.

column1: This aesthetic void is handily filled by Austin shredders OBN IIIs
column2: who revel in their own pose. They once made a music video in which all of the members murdered each other for the purpose of stealing booze and record money. On the cover of their new album
column3: Third Time to Harm
column4: frontman Orville Bateman Neeley III is flipping triple birds. They're surly in all their surface imagery
column5: their lyrics are plenty macho
column6: and sure enough
column7: that churlishness finds its way into their beefy sound.

column1: ""No Time for the Blues"" is a roaring roadhouse burner that finds a welcome place in the canon of songs for driving way too fast. Neeley blurts a few brusque
column2: blunt screams of ""NO""
column3: and the band tear through a few guitar solos. Drank-too-much anthem ""The Rockin' Spins"" packs a chugging melody and bluesy harmonica flourishes; later
column4: they veer toward Blue Öyster Cult-esque mysticism with ""Beg to Christ"". It's an album heavy on momentum
column5: shredding
column6: and
column7: yes
column8: balls.

column1: But much like the lords of townie rock before them
column2: OBN IIIs pose a specific challenge: although they deliver some genuinely exciting
column3: all-American rock'n'roll music
column4: they require their listeners to clear some boneheaded lyrical hurdles
column5: too. ""Uncle Powderbag"" is as sleazy as its title implies
column6: while ""Queen Glom"" is about a woman who mimics your thoughts
column7: steals your friends
column8: ""borrows"" money
column9: and so on. That song comes across as especially mean-spirited when Neeley describes the woman in question in overly chauvinistic terms (""She'll even glom on to your dick"").

column1: Third Time to Harm isn't unmatched in its thrilling-yet-troglodyte outlook—it pairs well with the Timmy's Organism album Raw Sewage Roq
column2: which had similarly sketchy gender politics paired with muscle-headed barroom rock'n'roll. On OBN IIIs' ""Worries""
column3: though
column4: it's hard not to draw comparisons to early Van Halen—Neeley's voice recalls David Lee Roth's baritone register while additional voices echo the chorus in unison. There's also a huge guitar solo
column5: naturally. In a way
column6: it's a shame that Third Time to Harm came out in 2014: in 1980
column7:
this thing would've been a mainstay in teen boys' tape decks everywhere.

Well$ is a 19-year-old rapper living in Charlotte

column3: listening to French rap as well as American. ""Growing up African is like you’re in limbo
column4: Well$ has said. ""To the white people
column5: you’re black
column6: and to the black people you might as well be white.""

column1: The title of his new mixtape

column7: he admonishes on ""Savoir Faire""
column8: while on ""Cercle Vicieux""

column10: he raps
column11: ""No cell phone
column12: just pimpin off this land line/ Scared to tell these hoes I got a bed time
column13: which is goofy and endearing.

column2: who produced Nothing Was the Same's ""Worst Behaviour""
column3: and the song sounds like Take Care's ""Under Ground Kings."" ""Black Swan""
column4: which gets inside the head of the most wearisomely flogged stereotype in rap --the former ""Daddy's little girl"" that ended up on the pole-- even quotes Drake when explaining how no man could ever want her again: ""Cuz no man wanna hear those stories about his lady.""

column1: Even if Well$ is derivative
column2: he's promising
column3: and the highlights here push against the issue of originality. When he addresses his own life
column4: being teased for being African
column5: on ""Revenge of the African Booty Scratcher""
column6: he finally touches upon something volatile
column7: contentious
column8: and his own. ""My peoples never slaved to that master
column9: but they still think they past us
column10: why's that?"" he grumbles.  The song opens with the clip of the ""booty scratcher"" scene from Boyz N the Hood
column11: and the beat quotes one of the most iconic sounds from the movie: the rolling and clacking of the steel stress balls in Furious Styles' hand as he grimly waits for his son Tre to return home. ""These African-Americans making fun of they roots
column12: like where the fuck do you think you come from?
column13: Well$ seethes. It's a startling peephole into something deeply personal in Well$
column14: and unfortunately
column15:
there isn't enough of it on this tape.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20575/homepage_large.e32208fe.jpg|Dereconstructed|32277.0|Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Pop']|2014-06-05 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:00.010905|"

Like so many of us
column2: Lee Bains III is a conflicted Southerner: heir to a questionable legacy of racism and regressive politics
column3: yet also to a culture defined by nonviolent dissent and artistic innovation. To complicate things even further
column4: the singer-songwriter hails from Birmingham
column5: Alabama
column6: which bears the brunt of so much disdain for people who associate the South solely with white racism. Yet
column7: the city birthed a civil rights movement that prized love
column8: equality
column9: and dignity as the foundation for a moral society. On his second album with the Glory Fires
column10: Bains continues to plumb the vagaries of Southern heritage as well as his own mixed emotions toward it. Dereconstructed can be fiercely intelligent
column11: but more often it is frustratingly blinkered; his lyrics can be defiantly blunt
column12: but they’re often elbowed out by music that is dumbly bombastic.

column1: Formerly of the late
column2: great Tuscaloosa rockers the Dexateens
column3: Bains certainly knows his stuff: That album title is a sly reference to the period of Reconstruction
column4: whose policies and practices still define a certain Southern mindset. Opener “The Company Man” hints at the connections between local steel companies and white supremacy organizations
column5: which the knotty history of the area actually bears out. The song’s opening verse paints a powerful image of Bull Connor
column6: who was responsible for some of the most brutal tactics against marchers and demonstrators
column7: sitting proudly in church like he has no sins to confess: “Putting profits in the black with businessmen on Sunday
column8: Monday morning
column9: beating prophets black and blue.”

column1: Other songs confront the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church
column2: about strip malls replacing historic storefronts
column3: about the gentrification of downtown Birmingham
column4: about the irony of the Alabama state motto (“We Dare Defend Our Rights”). Bains peppers them all with the kind of Biblical references that add import but no substance
column5: and there’s not one but two songs that crib directly from the old African American spiritual “I'm Working on a Building”. Bains sings it all in a raw bur that ably navigates the syncopated riffs of “Burnpiles
column6: Swimming Holes” but occasionally indulges in some hokey gospel whoops.

column1: As socially progressive as Bains may be
column2: Dereconstructed enacts a direly conservative conception of rock'n'roll
column3: one that is beholden to the past even as they comprehend their sound as new. The Glory Fires specialize in riff-based blooz rawk
column4: and while the idea of the MC5 jamming with Skynyrd certainly has its appeal
column5: the band doesn’t allow much variation in their guitar attack. Every song is pitched at a feverish clip
column6: but from one track to the next there’s little nuance or dynamic
column7: just a continuous pummeling of staid licks and rusty-barbed-wire distortion. There’s little boogie in these guitars
column8: but almost too much gospel fervor. As a result
column9: songs like “The Kudzu and the Concrete”
column10: “Mississippi Bottomland”
column11: and “Flags!” are uniformly ostentatious
column12: to the point where the album quickly becomes tedious.

column1: That monochromatic musical palette reveals a similarly limited worldview in the lyrics: What’s missing on this album is any sense of empathy
column2: any attempt to see the world through others’ eyes. Every song either explains Bains’ position or imagines a loved one counseling him on his views of local history. That may seem like a minor shortcoming
column3: but it’s what separates Dereconstructed from Southern albums like Randy Newman’s Good Old Boys
column4: R.E.M.’s Fables of the Reconstruction
column5: and the Drive-By Truckers’ Brighter Than Creation’s Dark
column6: which are filled with enlivening and even enlightening characters both real and imagined. By contrast
column7: Bains can only view the South’s problems as they immediately affect him as a white liberal dude
column8:
which suggests that two hundred long years of tumultuous regional history exist solely to give him something to sing about.

column3: above all
column4: a stylist. Before he came to be known as the yawpy mouthpiece co-fronting Brooklyn indie rock outfit Parquet Courts
column5: he was one-half of Denton
column6: Tx. duo Fergus & Geronimo
column7: where he and bandmate Jason Kelly made the type of reference-heavy experimental rock that was practically designed to catch the ears of rock nerds as much as it was bound to confound casual passersby. Their sense of humor and slavish devotion to past sounds was reminiscent of Ween
column8: if Ween wrote songs about parasitic music writers and trust-fund hippies. 2011's Unlearn opened with a song called ""Girls With English Accents"" (try and guess what it was about); the following year's Funky Was the State of Affairs kicked off with Savage and Kelly doing the best ""'Allo
column9: guv'nor"" affectations they could muster. Funky was a sorta-concept album that carried thematic allusions to Funkadelic's Maggot Brain while sometimes resembling if Gang of Four covered ""Peter Gunn"" in double time.

column1: It only took two albums for the delightfully
column2: inscrutably weird Fergus & Geronimo to sound like they were running out of steam
column3: and by the time Funky Was the State of Affairs saw release
column4: Savage had put up roots in New York City and was wielding the influences of his new home in Parquet Courts. The band's debut release
column5: the 2011 cassette American Specialties
column6: featured cover art ripped from the light-box Chinese restaurant menus that are ubiquitous throughout the city; the following year's Light Up Gold paired musings about pushy street-team clipboard-brandishers and being stoned in Queens over music smacking of the literate
column7: nervy rock music that emerged after punk's first wave burned out in the late 1970s.

column1: In interviews
column2: Savage hasn't been shy about his aspirations to claim a place in NYC's considerable rock lineage. Inarguably
column3: the city hasn't seen a unified
column4: geographically-defining scene emerge since the days of Julian and Karen
column5: so Parquet Courts sound less like a ""New York band"" than they resemble a band that carries qualities that people have associated with New York bands of years past—structural slackness paired with paranoid energy
column6: topped off with a sense of wit that exudes book-smarts as much as it smacks of smart-assedness.

column1: On their third and best album
column2: Sunbathing Animal
column3: they continue to expand their musical horizons by offering more of their own takes on older sounds: there are sonic nods to the spiky energy of Wire circa Pink Flag
column4: the Velvet Underground's relentless chug
column5: Television's more straightforward moments of elegance
column6: Bob Dylan's braying ramble
column7: surf rock's angular riffs filtered through amphetamine-poisoned blood. Most surprisingly
column8: the loping ""Dear Ramona"" comes off as a post-collegiate update of frat-rock luminaries Cake's ""Short Skirt/Long Jacket""
column9: swapping the latter's shiny fingernails and cupholder armrests for black coffee and moleskine notebooks.

column1: Above all
column2: the spectre of sly-smile indie-rock kings Pavement looms over Sunbathing Animal
column3: more so in execution than in explicit resemblance. If Light Up Gold carried the dashed-off basement charm of Slanted and Enchanted
column4: then Sunbathing Animal is Parquet Courts' Crooked Rain
column5: Crooked Rain
column6: a record that focuses more on structure as the band deploys melodic tricks with greater subtlety and precision. Crooked Rain still stands as the Stockton-hailing Pavement's most West Coast-sounding album
column7: and the humidity of Sunbathing Animal similarly calls back to Parquet Courts' Texan roots
column8: its wide-open sprawl sounding freed of the band's explicitly urban trappings.

column1: Recorded over the course of three days
column2: the propulsive energy of Light Up Gold sometimes resembled a quartet of short-distance runners about to collide into each other
column3: limbs akimbo
column4: while reaching the finish line. Sunbathing Animal
column5: then
column6: sounds like the work of long-distance pavement-pounders who have learned when to store up energy
column7: and when to release it. As an album
column8: it's impeccably structured
column9: with the slow-burn cuts placed in just the right places to break up the band's steady crunch; Parquet Courts' newfound sense of control works in miniature
column10: too
column11: as evidenced by the coiled guitar breakdowns on opener ""Bodies Made Of"" and the back half of ""Black & White""
column12: where the band's scraping choogle spins out into freewheeling zonked-out noise before pulling back to reveal a shimmying rhythmic duckwalk
column13: anchored by hand claps.

column1: The increased focus of pacing on Sunbathing Animal means that
column2: at first blush
column3: it's a less immediate album than its predecessor; at 46 minutes
column4: it's a little less than a quarter-hour longer than Light Up Gold
column5: and there's a few extended jams—the molasses-tumble of ""She's Rolling"" and ""Instant Disassembly""'s folksy ramble both go beyond the six-minute mark—that take cues from the anti-anthem ""He's Seeing Paths""
column6: from last year's Tally All the Things That You Broke EP. The hooks are stronger and more distinct
column7: though
column8: in the sense that Sunbathing Animal registers as 13 separate songs
column9: a change from Light Up Gold's energizing blur. The guitar work
column10: courtesy of co-frontmen Savage and Austin Brown
column11: is clever and accomplished without being too showy; in their hands
column12: the instruments squeak
column13: saunter
column14: and roar
column15: sometimes simultaneously. On the title track and the album's most aggressive cut
column16: the duo merge to create an impenetrable wall of strings
column17: soloing recklessly underneath each other as drummer Max Savage (brother to Andrew) bashes away in a manner reminiscent of <a href=""http://stream1.gifsoup.com/view/994208/animal-drums-o.gif"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a specific
column18: not-always-sunbathing animal.

column1: ""Sunbathing Animal"" is four minutes of impassioned fury that doubles as a solid punk tune and as a speed-addled take on pre-Beatles rock'n'roll—but forget the video
column2: all you need is the lyric sheet to tell that Savage is singing from the perspective of a housecat. ""I want to flee/ But I can only stare
column3: he laments furiously
column4: one of many times that he and Brown get lyrically weird on Sunbathing Animal. The sloganeering and sneering found on Light Up Gold is gone
column5: along with most notions of straightforwardness
column6: as the closest either singer gets to clarity is on the back-from-touring grievance-list ""Always Back in Town"". Otherwise
column7: the lyrics are stranger
column8: more elliptical
column9: less ""Stoned and Starving"" and more just plain stoned. ""What color is blood?/ Still the same that it was?
column10: Savage yells over the ascending strut of ""What Color Is Blood""
column11: taking on the bug-eyed paranoia of David Byrne circa More Songs About Buildings and Food; on ""Instant Disassembly""
column12: he conflates love
column13: anxiety
column14: and protection before admitting that the firmament containing those virtues is in serious decay: ""There's nothing left to dismantle/ The house it just collapsed on itself.""

column1: Yet again recalling Pavement in their glory days
column2: Parquet Courts remain inscrutable even as their talents grow
column3: a band less willing to show their hand as they are interested in describing why hands are such weird body parts to begin with. The closest thing Savage offers as far as a lyrical clue to the band's general mindset is buried in the middle of ""Instant Disassembly"": ""Turn on the white noise murmur of the AM band/ And the last classic rock band's last solid record creeps in."" The couplet could
column4: in a way
column5: be a joke about the permanence of musical obsolescence—but it doubles as a mission statement
column6: too
column7: as Parquet Courts are a band using the past to write their own version of the present. If you're looking for something ""new
column8: you aren't going to find it here
column9: and that's totally okay: Sunbathing Animal's considered
column10: whip-smart rock revivalism is a work of substantial growth from a band that already did ""simple"" quite well
column11:
placing Parquet Courts in their own distinct weight class.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20627/homepage_large.af41f42f.jpg|Dalliance|29647.0|Gold-Bears|['Rock'
column3: the second record from Atlanta quintet Gold-Bears
column4: is the sound of a guitar band figuring out how much fun it can be without becoming a bore. Endearing lines about young love and fond memories are parceled with energetic hooks
column5: exuberant cymbal crashes
column6: and singer Jeremy Underwood’s dogged yelp. It’s an immensely present and viscerally enjoyable album

column1: In his Pitchfork review of their debut album

column3: David Bevan noted the similarities between Gold-Bears and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart
column4: another Slumberland alum burying honeyed melodies underneath layers of fuzz like a precious gem wrapped in tissue paper. Pains have adjusted to their upwardly scaled ambitions by toning back the distortion
column5: while Gold-Bears have headed in the other direction: Dalliance is thicker
column6: as its guitars squeal into a heady
column7: enveloping rush without losing fizzy pop effervescence. Underwood’s voice leaps from the mix
column8: revealing him as another entrancingly nasal pop-punk pugilist along the lines of the Thermals’ Hutch Harris.

column1: There are heartfelt truths revealed in the lyrics
column2: but Gold-Bears are most apt at communicating a feeling with just a few seconds at their disposal. “Yeah
column3: Tonight” is packed with knowing lines about what the night might hold
column4: but the urgent refrain says everything you need to know. You could listen to how “Chest” describes a complicated love
column5: or let the wistful harmonies at the end do all the work. A song like “From Tallahassee to Gainesville” sets an intimate scene (”On our way from Tallahassee to Gainesville/ We listen to songs in the dark/ Somehow you convince me that we weren’t really that smart”) before riding a few pregnant pauses and the eternally sweet “Be My Baby” drum beat toward a breathy denouement.

column1: Dalliance is a noise-pop record in an era where there's plenty of noise-pop bands made up of people who grew up listening to noise-pop bands—an obvious modern-day analog is Joanna Gruesome
column2: another Slumberland act who are thanked in the liner notes—and the obviousness of their influences can be noted both with a charitable nod or dismissive wave of the hand. “It’s not like I wake up and say
column3: ‘Man
column4: I can’t wait to write a song that may sound like it was written in the 90s
column5: ’” Underwood once said in an interview. “It just sort of happens.” Still
column6: Gold-Bears are sharp enough to catch your attention
column7: as evidenced in the way “For You” opens with a big yell of “You’re a mistake!” before progressing to sparkling outro awash with chimes and white noise
column8: or how Underwood’s insistent vocal pulls “Memo” together on sheer effort
column9: or the bleary
column10:
romantic finale of “Hey Sophie”. Dalliance is the sound of a good band tightening to the point where they become something greater.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20629/homepage_large.9b862507.jpg|This Machine Kills Artists|32324.0|"Buzz ""King Buzzo"" Osborne"|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ipecac']|2014-06-04 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:01.705171|"

Some of the heaviest musicians on the planet can commune beautifully with the quietude of folk. Buzz “King Buzzo” Osborne has been faithfully dredging the depths of his own sludge ocean since 1983
column2: when Melvins established the molasses-in-January pace for waves of grunge-mongers and extreme metalheads to come—but Osborne's always had a way with a tune
column3: and one of the reasons The Melvins have lived long and prospered is the fact that he’s so adept at wringing weird hooks out of the primordial muck. Folk
column4: though
column5: can bring out the stuffiest and most sober sides of songwriters—especially those who are more accustomed to letting the volume knob do the talking. Luckily
column6: Osborne’s solo acoustic debut
column7: This Machine Kills Artists
column8: is a refreshing breath of unplugged
column9: fuck-it-all folk.

column1: The album’s title suggests Osborne obviously doesn’t cotton to the notion of folk music’s preciousness or self-importance. Still
column2: he can play the hell out of the genre: droning
column3: minor-key cuts such as “Rough Democracy” and “Drunken Baby” writhe and smolder
column4: even when they sound no different than what Alice in Chains or the Cult might sound like in an acoustic setting. There’s conviction to Osborne's execution
column5: even when he undermines himself humorously on “Instrument of God” and ‘Good and Hostile”
column6: where he lets his voice’s cavernous rumble climb into a froggy
column7: whining caricature of itself. It’s all part of Osborne’s long-established sensibility
column8: but without a greasy glacier of distortion behind him
column9: that tongue-in-cheek alchemy sours slightly. Osborne deserves a lot of credit for keeping the album a truly acoustic affair—but
column10: eventually
column11: the skeletal sameness becomes more numbing than a million Melvins riffs stacked end on end.

column1: Osborne's flirtations with folk are
column2: essentially
column3: a lark
column4: but there are moments when novelty is not enough. On one of This Machine Kills Artists’ best tracks
column5: “How I Became Offensive”
column6: Osborne picks at his instrument mock-melodramatically

column3: the second album of side-length improvisations by guitarist Tom Carter and synth controller Pat Murano
column4: takes its title from a particularly foreboding passage of John Milton’s Paradise Lost. Milton lists and explains the rivers of hell and the woeful lake into which they empty—the black Acheron and the hate-filled Styx
column5: the aggressive Phlegethon and the gripe-choked Cocytus. In other collaborations and in their respective solo work
column6: Carter and Murano have often plundered such <a href=""http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=5&ved=0CFAQFjAE&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.preservation.com.au%2Fproduct%2Ftom-carter-christian-kiefer-from-the-american-song-book&ei=Y5uHU-SJKOausASW5oAw&usg=AFQjCNHl__et3LpAwT9z6s_61nDsDoq78Q&sig2=BFm2dlmqAFm03pbY9HhcOg&bvm=bv.67720277
column7: d.cWc"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">fables and symbols for fodder. Here
column8: they not only attach the names of those mythic flows to each of these tracks but also use them as spirit guides; these 20-minute pieces are singular rushes of gathering and often-ferocious sound
column9: built with guitars that scream and then scatter the blues and electronics that wade through fluid distortion and oscillation. “Phlegethon
column10: ” for instance
column11: goes from eerie to irate
column12: “Acheron” from quiet and pensive to clipped and impenetrable.

column1: Despite the doom and the din
column2: Four Infernal Rivers is a wonderfully conversational album
column3: a partnership between two restless improvisers locked deep inside these moments. Carter and Murano are comfortable with one another’s styles and instincts
column4: and they respond to one another as old friends. In fact
column5: for all this talk of fire
column6: these instrumentals feel rather like a set of late-night fireside chats
column7: full of gripes and wit
column8: opinions and ideals. When these four sides have all been flipped
column9: you get the sense that you’ve outlasted the night with these two
column10: aggravated and excited by their strange companionship.

column1: The pair recorded their only previous release
column2: an eponymous two-piece LP issued in 2012
column3: at Black Dirt Studio
column4: a comfortable space where each of their better-known outfits—Carter’s Charalambides and Murano’s No-Neck Blues Band—have previously worked. For this one
column5: though
column6: they met at Carter’s Long Island City house for several sessions early last year
column7: congregating around his four-track. Aberrations that might’ve been buffed out in a studio
column8: like the un-grounded amplifier hum at the start of “Acheron”
column9: become subtle charms
column10: intimate moments that put the listener in the living room as a kind of witness. Carter and Murano move past the hesitant and inchoate atmosphere of their earlier work into an unflinching
column11: boisterous dialogue. Passing musical ideas
column12: like the flickering tones that begin “Cocytus”
column13: are taken to their extreme ends. Murano’s gloaming synth morphs into a sheet of caustic noise
column14: while Carter’s shimmering notes spiral into a veil of high-end abrasion. Nearly 20 minutes later
column15: when the track slow-fades into distant silence
column16: you can hear echoes of that introduction
column17: outlasting the intervening squall.

column1: That narrative quality makes Four Infernal Rivers particularly magnetic. These four improvisations evolve and surprise
column2: but they move through their 20 minutes with a sequential logic that resembles thoroughly arranged pieces. During “Phlegethon”
column3: they harmonize
column4: Carter’s piercing
column5: acid-lead guitar slicing through Murano’s sympathetic synthesizer line; it’s almost as if they’ve agreed to meet at this specific place but made a game of choosing their own routes to that intersection. When they split apart
column6: Murano chases a set of decaying beats with damaged industrial tones; Carter
column7: meanwhile
column8: pursues a circular guitar moan
column9: suggesting an incensed Loren Connors. They meet again at the end
column10: steadily settling into stillness like the autumn dusk.

column1: Although they play different instruments across Four Infernal Rivers
column2: Carter and Murano allow the sounds of guitar
column3: synthesizer and drum machine to dissolve into one another

drifting into the same space and coming up for a break only when one side of the record is full.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20585/homepage_large.1807e295.jpg|Love Fail|27568.0|David Lang|['Rock'
column3: David Lang won the Pulitzer Prize for a work called The Little Match Girl Passion
column4: which paired four singers with some small hand bells. That was it: the rest was ringing silence
column5: Lang's careful
column6: mazelike vocal writing
column7: and a quiet mournfulness that troubled and changed anyone who heard it. Love Fail feels like a revisiting
column8: or extension
column9: of that work—it's also scored for four voices
column10: this time the vocal group Anonymous 4
column11: and it also features hand bells. The source water
column12: the English madrigal
column13: is the same. But the temperature is a degree or two warmer
column14: more hospitable to cellular life; the 15 pieces
column15: spread across 50 minutes
column16: touch on emotions closer to mundane existence—the difficulty of communication
column17: the impossibility of remaining in the right.

column1: As with much of Lang's recent work
column2: Love Fail exists in a purposeful
column3: elegant stasis—things change
column4: but barely. His music is
column5: in a sense
column6: process music; you can hear
column7: or feel
column8: the motor that Lang feeds his ideas into whirring beneath the surface. He talks openly in interviews about being an ideas-first composer
column9: one for whom sounds and notes come afterward. But his music always comes out sounding luminous
column10: gorgeous
column11: a reminder that processes are what people make of them. The material David Lang feeds into his processes contains his doubts
column12: fears
column13: bleak thoughts—his
column14: or someone else's—that he is empathetic enough to channel directly into his music. They come out scrambled
column15: but they quickly reassemble themselves in our perception
column16: in much the same way our minds flip the upside down image our retina captures.

column1: It is this empathy that lifts his music into an exalted
column2: secular realm -- a place where we're forced to understand each other. On Death Speaks
column3: he turned the figure of Death into someone beautiful
column4: someone worth loving. On The Little Match Girl Passion
column5: he rendered the slow death of the titular figure
column6: alone on the street
column7: into a gentle transfiguration
column8: like a time-lapse video of a flower blooming. On ""Forbidden Subjects
column9: Lang examines a couple rendered slowly mute by an unnamed tragedy: ""Soon most every subject they might want to talk about/ Is associated with another unpleasant scene/ And becomes a subject they can't talk about/So that as time goes by there is less and less they can safely talk about."" The mood is grave
column10: but quiet
column11: and tender—there are dark forces in his pieces
column12: but they don't necessarily hold anything against you.

column1: The complex emotions at the center of ""He was and she was"" circle around regret and loss: ""She was so charming/ She was so lovely""; ""He was an admirable man/ He was so admirable."" Lang's scoring of the text draws the ear to the only word that matter to him in this construction: ""was."" The ""he was"" and ""she was"" are broken up into bits
column2: one simply a repeating interval while another washes whispers of ""hewashewashewashewashewas"" around the feet of the piece. The specifics of what these people were aren't important; Lang wants us to meditate on the fact that they were
column3: and no longer are.

column1: ""Right and Wrong
column2: meanwhile
column3: parses a series of mesmerizing
column4: unnavigable rules about the divide in its title: ""She knows she is right/ But to say she is right is wrong/ In this case
column5: to be correct and say so is wrong/ In certain cases she may be correct
column6: and may say so in certain cases/but if she insists too much
column7: she becomes wrong/ So wrong that even her correctness becomes wrong by association."" Read those lines on paper
column8: and they drone like stereo instructions. But listen to Lang's setting of this text—two lower voices intoning like intercom beeps
column9:
the other two fluttering up like birds scared from a tree—and feel the grace of his animating touch. His mind can turn even the sharpest mental scrutiny into something resembling a loving caress.

Upon its release on March 8
column3: Superunknown wasn’t just a highly anticipated album from a critically acclaimed rock band—its multi-platinum success and Grammy wins practically felt predestined. This was Soundgarden’s long overdue turn to come out on top. Though they were the first late-’80s Seattle-scene spawn to sign to a major label
column4: and dutifully embarked upon traditional career-building exercises like opening stadium tours for Guns N' Roses
column5: they would be soundly leapfrogged on the charts by their Emerald City peers in Nirvana and Pearl Jam; by comparison
column6: Soundgarden’s metallic sonatas were seemingly too knotty (and naughty) to inspire the same magnitude of crossover success. Sure
column7: 1991’s Badmotorfinger landed a bare-chested Chris Cornell on the cover of SPIN
column8: and an MTV ban of the allegedly blasphemous “Jesus Christ Pose” video brought the band more attention than if the station had actually aired it
column9: but Soundgarden appeared destined to be the perennial bronze medalists in the Grunger Games.

column1: By early 1994
column2: however
column3: the playing field had changed considerably: Though Pearl Jam were still the most popular rock band in America
column4: they were actively trying to be the least visible one
column5: declaring a moratorium on videos and interviews in an orchestrated (and ultimately successful) campaign to kill their own hype. Nirvana
column6: likewise
column7: were in the midst of a similar retreat
column8: and though their story had yet to reach its tragic conclusion
column9: ominous warning signs were in the air. But as a band that enjoyed a steadier ascent than their flannelled friends—and whose records got progressively better after jumping to a major—Soundgarden didn’t seem so conflicted about success. Their response to the Seattle-scene media storm wasn’t to try to avoid it
column10: but transcend it
column11: and embrace the opportunity to
column12: for a moment
column13: become the biggest band in the land.

column1: Usually
column2: it’s a bad sign when the wild-child frontman of your favorite group cuts his hair and starts wearing shirts. But the clean-cut Cornell that emerged with Superunknown was emblematic of the album’s mission to deliver maximal effect with minimal histrionics. With its despairing worldview
column3: gold-plated production
column4: and CD-stuffing 71-minute running time
column5: Superunknown is a quintessential ’90s artifact. But thanks to its still-formidable high-wire balance of hooks and heft
column6: the album nonetheless represents
column7: some 20 years later
column8: the platonic ideal of what a mainstream hard rock record should be. And even if that’s an ideal to which few contemporary bands aspire (aside from
column9: say
column10: Queens of the Stone Age)
column11: Superunknown remains a useful model for any left-of-center artist hoping to achieve accessibility without sacrificing identity.

column1: For Soundgarden
column2: the push toward pop was the result of incremental evolutions rather than a spectacular leap. Where Badmotorfinger introduced flashes of psychedelia and paisley-patterned melody amid Kim Thayil’s pulverizing riffage
column3: on Superunknown
column4: these elements become featured attractions. The once-oblique John Lennon references gave way to unabashed homage—centerpiece power ballad “Black Hole Sun” is pretty much “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds” turned upside down and dropped in a heap of soot and coal. That song counts as Superunknown’s most wanton act of subversion—setting its apocalyptic imagery to a tune so pretty
column5: even Paul Anka can dig it—but if that element of surprise has been diluted by two decades of perpetual rock-radio rotation
column6: the album boasts a wealth of less celebrated deep cuts (the queasy psych-folk of “Head Down
column7: ” the dread-ridden doom of “4th of July”) that retain a palpable sense of unease.

column1: Even the album’s eternal fist-pump anthems—“The Day I Tried to Live”
column2: “Fell on Black Days”
column3: “My Wave”—are infected with misanthropy and malaise
column4: making Superunknown the rare arena-rock album that makes just as much sense in blacked-out bedroom. (And yet
column5: despite the junkie intimations of its title
column6: “Spoonman” is really just about a man who plays with spoons.) That said
column7: if you don’t hate the world now quite as much as did when you were 18
column8: you may find yourself skipping over the leaden likes of “Mailman” and “Limo Wreck
column9: ” while developing a newfound appreciation for how bassist Ben Shepherd’s India-inspired oddity
column10: “Half”
column11: injects a welcome dose of absurdity into the mix.

column1: By fortuitous coincidence
column2: Superunknown hit stores the same day as Nine Inch Nails’ The Downward Spiral
column3: an album boasting a similarly expansive scope and thematic framework
column4: albeit approached from a drastically different set of influences (’80s new wave
column5: goth
column6: and electro as opposed to ’60s classic rock). The connection between the two albums is strong enough that the two bands toured together in 1994 and—despite some shit-talkin’ in the interim—are reuniting once again this summer for a joint-20th-anniversary jaunt. For casual Soundgarden fans who still own the record
column7: a concert ticket may ultimately be a more efficient way of celebrating Superunknown’s birthday than by shelling out for this reissue (available in two-and five-CD box set iterations)
column8: whose bonus material mostly amounts to demos and rehearsal tapes that cast this epic album in a more normalizing light. However
column9: you do develop a greater appreciation for the final product when you hear the ideas that got scrapped along the away or relegated to B-sides
column10: like the dirgey embryonic arrangement of “Fell on Black Days” (a.k.a. “Black Days III”)
column11: the free-form ambient stew of “Jerry Garcia’s Finger”
column12: and a club-friendly industrial funk mix of “Spoonman” by Steve Fisk that sounds like a test run for his beat-driven project Pigeonhed.

column1: You also get a glimpse of the band’s future course with a beautifully spare acoustic treatment of “Like Suicide” that points the way to 1996’s more temperate Down on the Upside
column2: the album that effectively triggered Soundgarden’s subsequent 13-year break-up. But then the go-for-broke
column3: peak-conquering triumphalism of Superunknown was itself a harbinger that the writing was on the wall for this band at the time. When Cornell sings
column4: “Alive in the superunknown” on the album’s acid-swirled title track
column5: it’s both a valorous testament to Soundgarden’s last-gang-in-town fortitude and a telling prophecy of the uncertainty to come
column6: with grunge’s early ’90s stranglehold on alt-rock radio soon to be loosened by the emergence of pop-punk
column7: Britpop
column8: electronica
column9: and nu-metal. But amid a musical landscape now splintered into infinite subgenres
column10: Superunknown remains the very definition of no-qualifiers-required rock—a tombstone for a once-dominant aesthetic
column11: perhaps
column12: but also a solid
column13:
immovable mass that endures no matter how dramatically its surroundings have changed.

"|19407.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19407-soundgarden-superunknown/|8.5|Stuart Berman

Depending on your disposition
column2: Clap Your Hands Say Yeah are either a band to pity or one to envy. Their much-adored 2005 self-titled debut continues to tower over their entire subsequent discography
column3: but then ringleader Alec Ounsworth seems more comfortable lurking in the shadows than basking in the spotlight. A glance at the band’s current touring itinerary reveals venues half the size of the ones they were headlining nine years ago

column6: say

column9: the ever-resourceful Ounsworth is beholden to no entity

column1: But as Clap Your Hands Say Yeah’s fourth full-length Only Run illustrates
column2: there’s a difference between feeling boundless and sounding rudderless. The album’s conception was preceded by the departure of three fifths of the band’s formative line-up
column3: leaving just the core of Ounsworth and drummer Sean Greenhalgh. Accordingly

column7: manipulated voice effects
column8: sampled dialogue
column9: and song fragments pieced together like unevenly aligned Lego blocks. The one constant through the CYHSY canon
column10: of course
column11: is Ounsworth’s excitable tremble of a voice
column12: and
column13: on an album-by-album basis (both within the band and without)
column14: he’s been eager to recast it in as many different contexts as possible. But Only Run often compacts this catholic approach into the span of a single song
column15: with frustrating results.

column1: While the circular drum pattern
column2: synth-smeared ambience
column3: and New Order-esque guitar lines of the opening “As Always” lend the track an ascendent grandeur that sounds more like a proper Dave Fridmann production than anything on the last album CYHSY recorded with him
column4: in the final minute
column5: the arrangement drops out to leave Ounsworth singing the verse melody on his acoustic guitar. It’s a classic songwriter ploy—to prove a tune is sturdy enough to stand on its own in the absence of studio embellishment—and
column6: in this case
column7: an effective one. But when the same trick is repeated on “Blameless” and the title track
column8: wherein Ounsworth’s voice left to float in a desolate haze for extended stretches
column9: the sense of structural randomness starts to feel like a crutch in and of itself.

column1: And like a child playing dress-up with their parents’ wardrobe
column2: Only Run’s impulsive change-ups can result in some ill-fitting looks: “Your Advice” aims for a Kid A-style deconstruction of a standard rock song
column3: but the separation between Ounsworth’s clear-eyed
column4: straight-forward melody and the ambient swirls floating behind it is so pronounced
column5: it comes off like an unfinished remix with mismatched console levels. But even that seems complete compared to “Coming Down”
column6: a trainwreck of a song that smashes together an overdriven fuzz-bass riff
column7: melody-averse muttering
column8: and a door-crashing cameo from Matt Berninger that feels less like a triumphant class-of-2005 reunion than him getting his decade-in-the-waiting revenge against CYHSY for upstaging the National on the latter's 2005 tour behind Alligator.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Only Run finally hits its stride in its more focussed second half
column3: with Ounsworth and Greenhalgh strategically building upon simple ideas rather than trying to cram them together and see what happens. “Beyond Illusion” is essentially Only Run’s “Idioteque”
column4: a drum-machined strut that retains its twitchy tension even as the mid-song appearance of Greenhalgh’s booming drums offer some levity. And if the unlikely collaboration with Kid Koala on the slow-motion sci-fi lullaby “Cover Up” proves anti-climactic
column5: the shimmering “Impossible Request” yields the fully realized fruits of Only Run’s grab-bag experimentation
column6: transmitting the band’s inherent ramshackle charm through an expanded palette of space-age sonics. But
column7: of course
column8: this being Clap Your Hands Say Yeah
column9: bliss and balance can only ever be temporary states
column10: as Ounsworth closes out “Impossible Request” with a promise-cum-threat worthy of being chiseled on his tombstone: “Please don’t ask me where I’m going… I’ll tell you again
column11: I never know.” Though
column12: at this point in Clap Your Hands’ perpettually zig-zagging career course
column13:
he need not ask us not to ask.

Tigers Jaw claim to be “equal parts Fleetwood Mac and Brand New”
column2: and what’s surprising is that the claim's true on multiple levels. To a certain extent

column5: Brianna Collins and Ben Walsh’s harmonies have a glassy

column1: But while three of the five members decided to quit before Charmer was recorded
column2: they did everyone a solid by finishing the album as a parting gift—which possibly explains how Charmer still comes off like a smooth segue into a new incarnation of the band rather than a sudden
column3: painful break or an awkward growth spurt. Though Tigers Jaw have been around for nearly a decade
column4: remaining members Collins and Walsh just recently graduated college
column5: the standard forum where pop-punk kids are not only expected to discover more “mature” and credible sources of independent rock music

column8: Balance and Composure
column9: and Title Fight

column11: instrumental economy
column12: and the belief this stuff should be MTV-friendly even if that forum isn’t going anywhere near bands like them.

column1: True
column2: you’ve probably heard the descending jangle progression of “Cool” and the minor key power chord riff of “Nervous Kids” hundreds of times in the past year alone
column3: but rarely presented in a manner where the vocals are put so clearly to the fore
column4: presented as a lead instrument rather than something custodially glommed onto fuzzy guitars. Beyond that
column5: Tigers Jaw use sneaky ways to exhibit their pop smarts. Many of Charmer’s songs work the same riff throughout their entirety
column6: with only small variations throughout
column7: maybe a slight chord inversion or a harmonized lead riff or Collins’ pencil-thin synth colorings. But that one riff is usually so sturdy and easy to build off of
column8: the end result is a song with all hook; while the glowing chorus of “Hum” only appears once
column9: it’s more of a resolution than a climax.

column1: Those are the aspects of the album that take after the positive connotations of “charmer”: subtly ingratiating
column2: enjoyable in a low-key kind of way. But Tigers Jaw turn Charmer into something more resonant by teasing out the negative connotations of its title: manipulative
column3: emotionally callow
column4: inauthentic. To put it bluntly
column5: there isn’t a single nice person populating Tigers Jaw’s lyrics
column6: and their varying exhibitions of misanthropic behavior are explained in the opener’s chorus: “It’s a cruel world
column7: but it’s cool.”

column1: It could be read two ways; McIlwee is either conceding to cynicism as a natural state or reveling in it. My guess is the latter
column2: judging from his deadpan disdain when delivering lines like “Don’t you wanna be my perfect bae instead?” and ”I’m out in California now/ And Ari gave me his new car/ And all the girls are so champagne.” Of course
column3: none of Charmer should be taken as an endorsementof that kind of attitude
column4: just a depiction of it. People primarily motivated by their sexual desires and loneliness can be self-absorbed and not all that concerned with their effects on other people. <span style=""font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">It happens
column5: and it’s not like anyone onCharmer seems happy about it
column6: as its dreary emotional state can be too convincingly mirrored by the music at times. However
column7: those lulls end up creating the simmering tension that gets relieved on “Slow Come On” by a flurry of drum rolls and McIlwee’s vocals just nearing a scream. It’s a chilling example of an asshole revealing his true colors
column8: telling someone who doesn’t turn him on about the kind of person who does—“I don’t even care how mean they are/ So I don't ever take your calls.”

column1: When McIlwee yells
column2: “Why am I so cruel?” towards the end
column3: it’s about as close as he gets to a confession or culpability
column4: acknowledging himself as a man who wants the ones he can’t have
column5: rejects the ones he can and internalizes the resulting loneliness as some kind of perverse pleasure. When his affections are returned
column6: the other is seen as compromised for having sunk to his level. Closer “What Would You Do” is a total outlier
column7: detailing a sad
column8: codependent hookup over lumbering funk like a vintage Afghan Whigs track
column9: while “Frame You” is just as candid—“You couldn’t leave me alone/ Because I was a wreck and you were the savior type.”

column1: All of which makes lead single “Hum” very misleading in retrospect. For one thing

column3: when she sings
column4: “You left a permanent scar”

Charmer ends up sounding more influenced by another example of uber-90s television—the one where people stop being polite and start getting real.
