column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20635/homepage_large.c930bec6.jpg|Separate Oceans|32317.0|Ned Doheny|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2014-06-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:06.731796|"

Is Separate Oceans a rarities comp or a bizarro-world greatest hits? The set is comprised of 19 songs from Ned Doheny’s three albums from the 1970s
column2: seeded with demos and alternate takes featuring some of his more famous friends. There are no hits per se
column3: but songs that should have—and likely could have—been hits. Scion of oil barons for whom L.A. streets and beaches have been named
column4: Edward “Ned” Doheny was part of the SoCal scene of singer-songwriters couch-jumping around the canyon and dreaming of stardom. He came from extreme wealth
column5: but that only seems to have reinforced his desire to succeed as a pop musician: to prove himself as an artist instead of an heir.

column1: He was one of the first signees to Asylum Records
column2: but the label spent his mastering budget to market Jackson Browne’s debut. After Doheny raided his trust fund to finish the songs
column3: the album flopped unspectacularly. So did his follow-up
column4: Hard Candy
column5: in 1976. So did Prone in 1979. Still
column6: some of his songs were hits for other performers (such as “Get It Up for Love”
column7: which Tata Vega rode into the top 20)
column8: and his LPs are doggedly pursued by vinyl collectors and crate diggers.

column1: Pretty much every song Doheny ever recorded or released classifies as a rarity
column2: which means for most listeners Separate Oceans will be an introduction into his sun-drenched world. The Numero Group has certainly timed the release perfectly: these songs are summer jams from an alternate universe where the Eagles slid quietly into obscurity and Asylum had the good sense to shill for Ned Doheny instead of Jackson Browne. The music sounds like it’s been preserved in amber
column3: so sharply redolent of the time and place of its creation. It’d be too easy to dismiss these songs as “yacht rock”
column4: a recently coined term that sounds satirical and derisive. In the Separate Oceans liner notes
column5: Numero co-founder Ken Shipley defers to the phrase “marina pop”
column6: which is arguably more precise and certainly softer in tone
column7: and ""beach funk"" might be an even more apt descriptor. These songs percolate casually
column8: with spry guitars and beachball basslines cohering into superlatively breezy grooves.

column1: It helps that Doheny is blessed with a voice like a lens flare
column2: and his guitar playing
column3: a style combining folky strums and classical dexterity
column4: is nimble and creative. Even the slower tracks
column5: like “A Love of Your Own” (co-written with Average White Band's Hamish Stuart)
column6: sound aggressively chipper
column7: and the lyrics never tax your brain. In fact
column8: these songs can sometimes be mesmerizingly meaningless
column9: as Doheny crafts lyrics from stray clichés and non sequitur platitudes. “Don’t you be afraid to give your heart/ You never know until you try it!” he advises on “A Love of Your Own”. Rhyme typically takes precedence over meaning. As he explains on “When Love Hangs in the Balance”
column10: “You can’t let it slide/ It can’t be denied.”

column1: It’s not like Browne or the Eagles were deft wordsmiths either
column2: so the lyrical vacuousness of Doheny’s music only identifies him as a product of his scene. An excessive headiness might weigh these songs down and rob them of their weightless quality
column3: so it's good that Separate Oceans is aerodynamic to a fault
column4: sequenced to emphasize the craft behind the music itself. Numero frontloads the set with finished studio takes in all their luxuriant glory
column5: showcasing Doheny’s ear for prismatic melodies and sophisticated arrangments
column6: so side A of this double LP doubles as a revealing SoCal pop artifact and a near-perfect summer EP for 2014.

column1: As the comp progresses
column2: the demos strip away some of the veneer just enough to show the creative decisions Doheny was making. The plush “Get It Up for Love” burbles with futuristic synths and a playfully jazzy piano riff
column3: and the song’s punchline is right there in the title—the best and cleverest line written by this self-described “avatar of casual vulgarity”—but it takes on new gravity on the demo version of the song
column4: which closes Separate Oceans. Doheny struggles to get the tone right. Is the song flippant? Serious? Both? Ultimately
column5: all that matters is his jittery strumming
column6: as sharp and directed as ever.

column1: During the comp’s second half
column2: it’s not hard to detect some rain clouds on the horizon
column3: threatening to intrude on Doheny’s sunny-day pop. “I Know Sorrow” is exactly as blunt as its title suggests
column4: paring complex emotions down to those three simple words. It might be too heavy
column5: too unwieldy—at least on this collection—were it not for that high-flying piano jam on the coda
column6: which sounds rambunctious and even joyful. That sense of creativity and musical invention staves off melancholy and self-absorption
column7: even as it becomes clear that the music business has hurt Doheny much more than any lover ever could. “That old rock and roll will break your heart
column8: ” he sings on “Fineline”
column9: “or make you whole.” To his considerable credit
column10:
he sounds like half a man on these songs. 

"|19416.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19416-ned-doheny-separate-oceans/|7.9|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20513/homepage_large.3a065d53.jpg|Emma Jean|28088.0|Lee Fields & the Expressions|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Truth & Soul']|2014-06-03 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:07.306639|"

Lee Fields isn't really a throwback—he's always been singing
column2: even when nobody was listening. There's both an agelessness and a versatility to his soulful inflections that makes his voice too nebulous to evoke anything specific enough that would scan as direct nostalgia. So once you get rid of any feeling that you might be listening to something reminiscent of another time—admittedly
column3: a feeling fueled by the fact that the golden era of Southern R&B is when he first built his chops—it's replaced by the impact of hearing a lifer professional doing his thing at what seems like a continuous peak.

column1: If there's any downside to longtime consistency
column2: it's that surprise gives way to reliability
column3: so his new album
column4: Emma Jean
column5: isn't really a huge revelation. And it doesn't need to be: after the previous albums Fields did with his band the Expressions
column6: starting with his late '90s revival and his Brooklyn-borne run on the Desco
column7: Soul Fire
column8: and Truth & Soul labels
column9: it's simply another notch in a heavily hash-marked belt. But any opportunity to revel in Fields' voice is a good one
column10: especially when his voice is so rangy. While he was acknowledged at times in the past as a sort of James Brown soundalike
column11: his points of comparison render him more original the wider they're spread out. The gravelly warmth of Bobby Womack
column12: Otis Redding's emotive ache
column13: Syl Johnson's sweet intensity—and
column14: sure
column15: Mr. Dynamite's raspy authority—are more points of triangulation than direct references
column16: with a nuanced vitality that makes his sixties sound like most artists' thirties.

column1: With a band that can (and should) get away with releasing purely instrumental editions of their work—which the Expressions did
column2: on 2012's Faithful Man—Fields can really bring it on home. There's one notable example on Emma Jean
column3: the dawn-of-disco 4/4 conga thump of ""All I Need
column4: that goes on for a bit before it becomes apparent that Fields isn't coming in anytime soon—and the instrumental melody
column5: a canny blend of stinging guitar and creeping horns
column6: carries nearly as much lively soul-stirring lead-attraction status as the headlining artist does when he finally lets out a few wordless
column7: last-minute moans at the end. The Expressions are a who's-who of session players and all-stars that've helped make up the sprawling
column8: definitive nucleus of Brooklyn soul
column9: but they're still finding new
column10: appealing routes through it; the countrypolitan twang to their cover of JJ Cale's ""Magnolia"" and the humid
column11: Afro-Latin War-isms of ""In the Woods"" are odd little inflections that flavor the familiar approach without pulling it too far out of bounds.

column1: All that travelling goes into an album with a wistful
column2: set-adrift emotional impact that lingers
column3: even when the words don't. The try-to-work-it-out pleas in ""Just Can't Win"" or the breakup finality of ""Paralyzed"" don't read like much when they're written down
column4: but the words are only a third of the definition where this record's concerned. Thematically
column5: Emma Jean is a record that's front-to-back frustration instilled with the anxiety of loneliness and alienation—the wishes expressed in the song titles of ""Eye to Eye""
column6: ""Talk to Somebody""
column7: and ""Standing By Your Side"" aren't easily attainable
column8: but Fields and the Expressions don't wallow or kick at the dirt. They push up tempos
column9: channel low-down feelings into high-up catharsis
column10: and make sure every punch connects. Even though you know just what you should be getting from an album like this
column11: Lee Fields & the Expressions play like the stakes have never been higher: they lay it all out there
column12: put it on the line
column13:
and make damn well sure you feel it.

"|19304.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19304-lee-fields-the-expressions-emma-jean/|7.5|Nate Patrin

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20617/homepage_large.688c5f49.jpg|Glass Boys|5160.0|Fucked Up|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador'
column2:
'Arts & Crafts']|2014-06-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:08.022802|"

Get past the audacious concepts
column3: the profanity
column4: and Damian Abraham’s boarish grunt
column5: and Fucked Up are essentially pragmatists
column6: driven by a mission to rage within the machine. While Abraham may be conflicted about playing shows with Foo Fighters
column7: being nominated for major awards and appearing on TV networks that still can’t say his band’s real name
column8: they’re all necessary to give Fucked Up’s message the populist outreach it requires to be effective. Because unlike previous insurrectionists-turned-inside-operatives like the Clash or Refused
column9: Fucked Up’s message isn’t political.

column1: Rather
column2: Abraham is hardcore's ?uestlove
column3: a burly
column4: gregarious
column5: and eloquent music nerd maintaining a likable “What am I doing here?” outlook regardless of his successes
column6: fixated on making the State of the Art as important as the State of the Union. Coincidentally
column7: Glass Boys is similar to the Roots’ most recent album
column8: ...And Then You Shoot Your Cousin—a relatively compact
column9: dense piece of metacriticism taking an unsparing look at the genre of its creators and its social mores. The problem is that its message is also far more developed and interesting than the medium.

column1: Glass Boys clocks in at 10 songs and 43 minutes
column2: a canny move that preemptively neutralizes backlash or skepticism that would’ve arisen had Fucked Up tried to top 2011’s hour-plus rock opera David Comes to Life in any measurable way. It’s obvious that the aspirational Abraham conceded to guitarist/producer Mike Haliechuk’s desire to make a record befitting a “normal band.” And yet
column3: with no ostensible “plot” and Abraham as the only recurring character
column4: Glass Boys is more complex and thought-provoking than its predecessor. Most of the time
column5: it’s like a Talkhouse piece-on-tape
column6: with insider intel regarding art vs. commerce
column7: nostalgia vs. forward thinking
column8: individual vs. community
column9: and why we have to frame these things as dichotomies to begin with. So make no mistake
column10: this is heady stuff: while Abraham pours mulch and gravel all over his florid poetry (""Rejuvenations ocean spume perfume"")
column11: Glass Boys alludes to the patronage system
column12: Greek mythology
column13: primitive ritualism
column14: pre-verbal communication
column15: and basically everything short of the 2001 monolith to present Fucked Up as a tiny blip in the eternal timeline.

column1: For all of its discourse and rhetoric
column2: Glass Boys remains a very personal work and
column3: more crucially
column4: one that doesn’t preach or provide answers —though Eurycles pops up in a cameo
column5: the album's inquisitive
column6: open-ended discussion is more influenced by Socrates.  In opener “Echo Boomer”
column7: Abraham gives voice to Haliechuk’s reminiscence of being a 15-year old mesmerized by the possibilities of music. But by the penultimate “The Great Divide”
column8: he looks back puzzled and guilt-ridden
column9: wondering if youth is wasted on the wasted youth who put their faith in bands like Fucked Up rather than something greater (“We ushered in all that corrupts/ Now we’re drowning in the glut”). In between
column10: Abraham and Haliechuk cop to confessional songwriting as a ""Jesus Christ Pose""-style farce (“Paper the House”) and spitefully air grievances (“Led By Hand”)
column11: before ultimately accepting their fate as part of the continuum as an honor. After all
column12: if an echo booms and no one hears it
column13: did it even happen?

column1: These are conversations worth having
column2: and you can have them simply by reading the lyrics sheet
column3: watching the videos
column4: and reading interviews with the band. For all the talk of Fucked Up getting streamlined and concise
column5: it turns out that streamlined
column6: concise songs are nowhere near as interesting as their wildest
column7: most highfalutin concepts; Glass Boys finds a Great Punk Band making a Good Rock Record that’s weirdly superfluous.

column1: And let’s be clear
column2: this is a rock band
column3: increasingly a hardcore-derived version of the Hold Steady
column4: with static classic rock riffage serving as a platform for functional
column5: verbose one-note vocals (the Van Halen-evoking “The Art of Patrons” could even be swiped from Separation Sunday). On their early breakthroughs Hidden World and the Chemistry of Common Life
column6: Fucked Up set themselves apart not by pushing hardcore in a new direction so much as completely blowing it wide open in a manner unseen since The Shape of Punk to Come or even Zen Arcade. But now
column7: Fucked Up have channeled all of their symphonic ambitions for the sole purpose of making Glass Boys sound like it has as many overdubs as a record four times its length.

column1: That’s literally the case as far as the drums go: Jonah Falco is playing four different drum tracks throughout Glass Boys
column2: another example of Fucked Up’s delightful
column3: crackpot scheming—it’s a cool idea that no punk band would pursue
column4: either out of economic hardship or just the innate knowledge that playing four drum tracks at the same time might detract from the visceral impact of the music. There’s even more of a homogenizing effect on the guitars; rather than contributing contrast
column5: melody
column6: dynamics or texture
column7: it’s the kind of indiscriminate layering that appeared on Be Here Now and MACHINA/Machines of God
column8: turning a presumably hard-hitting rock record into a gelatinous ooze that surrounds and consumes the listener rather than attacking their ears. Though less so than on David Comes to Life
column9: Abraham remains omnipresent and indistinct
column10: a grit amidst a sound that emanates like toothpaste.

column1: At times
column2: the saturation of Glass Boys creates a wonderful
column3: psychedelic effect—“Echo Boomer” is possibly meant to describe Abraham and Fucked Up as reverberations of a punk rock Big Bang
column4: though it’s every bit as applicable to the actual sound of the song. Meanwhile
column5: “Touch Stone” is an aural illusion where a two-chord modulation sounds like it’s endlessly
column6: upwardly cresting.  Combined with the spirited call-and-response of “Sun Glass”
column7: the opening salvo of Glass Boys bears the promise of everything a direct and hook-filled Fucked Up album could be. But after “Warm Change” unravels into aimless guitar soloing and panned drums
column8: Fucked Up usher in a second half that fails to distinguish itself in any way. Once again
column9: there are guest vocalists supplementing the symphonic guitars—the credits lists cred-deficient Canucks such as Tragically Hip’s Gord Downie and Alexisonfire’s George Pettit
column10: as well as indie heroes J. Mascis and Kurt Vile; with the exception of Mascis’ donkey bray on “Led By Hand”
column11: they’re all just faint echoes struggling to be heard.

column1: Glass Boys is a record dense with metacommentary
column2: so it's possible that the record's claustrophobic production is meant to reflect Abraham and Haliechuk’s concerns about the walls closing in on Fucked Up. They’ve been deferential and self-effacing about their legacy
column3: admitting they’ve lasted about a decade longer than even most successful hardcore bands. But they opted out of actual hardcore long ago; since signing with Matador
column4: the genre has served as a theoretical control group for Fucked Up
column5: something to compare the results of their experiments. Now
column6: you can only hear faint echoes of their past greatness underneath the lard-laden production; it’s something that will please the fanbase Fucked Up have deservedly built and enrage the younger
column7: angrier hardcore bands who will dismantle and try to improve on it
column8: fueled by their own ideals and self-belief
column9:
however foolish it may seem in retrospect. Which actually validates Glass Boys’ ideas about hardcore's cycle of life—it just doesn’t make the music any more thrilling.

"|19400.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19400-fucked-up-glass-boys/|7.0|Ian Cohen

When the Orwells appeared on ""Letterman"" last January
column3: they did exactly what any upstart rock ‘n’ roll band making their network television debut should do: make complete asses of themselves. The suburban-Chicago quintet chugged through the first verse of their single “Who Needs You” without incident—but by the second verse
column4: frontman Mario Cuomo (no
column5: not that one) stopped singing as if defying some non-existent CBS lip-sync policy
column6: splayed himself across the floor in front of his monitors to perform a couple of yoga bridge poses
column7: and curled up on the couch to become Dave’s most non-communicative guest since Joaquin Phoenix. If the point of the spectacle was to show just how little they give a fuck about impressing the public
column8: it failed miserably: not only did Dave and Paul Shaffer enthusiastically applaud the performance
column9: they begged the befuddled band to keep playing
column10: before Shaffer just took matters into his own hands. In that moment
column11: you can see the daunting challenge the Orwells are up against: to authentically reinvigorate a style of music that
column12: after nearly 50 years of perpetual garage-rock revivals
column13: can now be so easily neutered into geezer-embraced showbiz shtick.

column1: Still not old enough to legally drink in most states but old enough to go to war
column2: the Orwells are fully aware they’re reinventing a wheel that’s been essentially worn down to the rim. As if the Black Lips-inspired juvie-punk of their 2012 debut
column3: Remember When
column4: didn’t make their allegiance to snot-rock tradition obvious
column5: the album was laced with samples of old Elvis interviews and 1950s-era preachers railing against the delinquent effects of rock ‘n’ roll. (Interim B-sides
column6: meanwhile
column7: were given titles like “Open Your Eyes (A Misfits Ripoff)”.) The King connection continues with the band’s first major-label outing
column8: Disgraceland
column9: though this time
column10: the Orwells clearly have loftier ambitions than cracking the Rust Belt garage circuit. With the alt-rock production dream team of Dave Sitek
column11: Chris Coady
column12: and Jim Abbiss behind the boards
column13: the goal appears to be nothing less than supply their generation with an Is This It to call their own—
column14: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">a midwest-slacker answer to the sort of urbane
column15: effortlessly cool rock ‘n’ roll records the Strokes
column16: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;""> stopped making 10 years ago.

column1: For their part
column2: the Orwells have cleaned up their act quite nicely
column3: scraping away the surface scuzz to foreground Matt O’Keefe and Dominic Corso’s radiant but not-too-glossy guitar lines
column4: while filling out their sound just enough to justify the big-budget production. Cuomo’s lyrical concerns
column5: however
column6: remain as puerile as ever—Disgraceland essentially constitutes a repetitive Groundhog Day-esque cycle of boozin’ and cruisin’ for “a handful of ass.” Not graced with an especially melodic voice
column7: Cuomo doesn’t so much sing his songs as barge into them—on “Norman
column8: ” the chasm between his belligerent delivery and the song’s “Just Like Honey”-ed sway is so wide that it's like he’s doing karaoke to his own band. But Cuomo knows how to exploit his limited range to rousing effect
column9: from the Jim Morrison-esque howls that give the simmering psyched-out eruptions of “The Righteous One” some extra heat
column10: to the excitable anti-authoritarian kiss-offs that transform “Who Needs You” into the Orwells’ own “Last Nite” (in the no-tomorrow
column11: rather than yesterday-evening
column12: sense).

column1: “Who Needs You” is also one of a handful of songs here that hints at another of Cuomo’s favorite indulgences—firearms—betraying the more sinister side to modern-day teenage kicks. As he admits at one point
column2: “My daddy’s got a 12-gauge/ I hope I don’t find it
column3: ” an uncannily topical line that’s all the more striking given that it pops up in “Gotta Get Down”
column4: an upbeat bubble-grunge highlight that proves
column5: even if the Orwells don’t become the next Strokes
column6: there’s no shame in being a 21st-century Spacehog. Ultimately
column7: they're at their most engaging when maintaining an ironic distance between subject matter and tone: in contrast to the song’s congenial jangle
column8: “Bathroom Tile Blues” sees Cuomo already expressing his ennui toward a hotel-trotting
column9: model-shagging rock-star lifestyle he has yet to actually achieve. But Disgraceland also proves there’s a fine line between writing songs about being bored and just being boring: the atypically stern lead single “Let It Burn” is nihilism-by-numbers with a hookless chorus
column10: while “Dirty Sheets” offers nothing more than love-’em-and-leave-’em lechery. And yet
column11: in contrast to the instant messianic complex so many would-be rock saviors seem to acquire
column12: Cuomo is refreshingly honest about his band’s shortcomings. As he sings
column13: “From the east and to the west
column14: we ain’t the worst
column15: we ain’t the best.” By that measure
column16:
Disgraceland is truth in advertising.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20621/homepage_large.e146b85b.jpg|Beauty & Ruin|2842.0|Bob Mould|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2014-06-02 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:09.237462|"

This year has seen the 25th-anniversary reissue of Bob Mould’s solo debut
column2: 1989’s Workbook
column3: a release that helped put his alternatingly brilliant and muddled post-Hüsker Dü career in perspective. On the heels of the Workbook reissue comes Beauty & Ruin
column4: Mould's eleventh solo album and his second with the monstrous rhythm section of bassist Jason Narducy and Superchunk/Mountain Goats drummer Jon Wurster. By all accounts
column5: Mould is on a roll: His 2011 autobiography
column6: See a Little Light
column7: went past being an illuminating read to the point where it felt like a work of catharsis for its author. Mould spent so much of his adult life clashing with former bandmates
column8: struggling with his homosexuality
column9: and groping toward a musical identity distinct from Hüsker Dü without alienating the large percentage of his fanbase that will always prefer the Mould of days past: distorted
column10: angst-ridden
column11: and swinging sword-sized hooks.

column1: Silver Age from 2012 was as much of a capitulation as a triumph; it gave long-tolerant Mould fans the rush of rock riffs and burst blood vessels that had been largely absent since the breakup of Mould’s '90s-alt-rock powerhouse Sugar
column2: but it also came across as Mould taking the path of least resistance
column3: since his time with Hüsker Dü will always press down on him. So Beauty & Ruin feels like an extension of Silver Age’s impassioned buzz and thrust; less fortunately
column4: it’s more of an appendix than a sequel.

column1: Still
column2: an appendix to the vigorous Silver Age—or even to Mould’s career up to this point—isn’t anything to sneeze at. Accordingly
column3: the trio punches the clock with a vengeance on the punky eruptions “Kid With Crooked Face” and “Hey Mr. Grey”
column4: a pair of tracks that circle back to Hüsker Dü’s SST days. “Kid With Crooked Face”
column5: corrosive and supersonic
column6: could even pass as a long-lost Metal Circus outtake
column7: only tightened and cleaned up considerably. And on “Hey Mr. Grey”
column8: Mould goes so far as to echo Flip Your Wig’s “Hate Paper Doll”
column9: even if it feels more like an unintentional lapse into familiar phrasing and melody than some kind of homage to his past.

column1: That said
column2: there’s no denying that “I Don’t Know Anymore” is cut from the same cloth as Hüsker Dü’s “I Apologize” and Sugar’s “If I Could Change Your Mind""
column3: and the similarity goes deeper than the song titles. For all of Mould’s experimentation over the past twenty years—a hit-or-miss penchant for reinvention that encompasses everything from chamber-folk to electronica—Beauty & Ruin sticks to just a handful of well-worn gears. On “I Don’t Know Anymore”
column4: he hews to the sound he once tried so strenuously to outrun: the bittersweet
column5: fuzz-fueled
column6: pop-punk open letter to the object of his angst. This latest iteration of that formula ranks up there with his catchiest
column7: but it also comes across like a numbingly comfortable rehash of Mould’s tuneful discomfort.

column1: Nothing on Beauty & Ruin truly resembles experimentation
column2: as Mould
column3: unburdened of so much baggage of late
column4: seems joyously unconcerned with proving anything to anyone other than the fact that he can still craft hook after hook. “Little Glass Pill” opens with a airy folk intro before plowing straight into a bleary-eyed
column5: Sugar-style rager
column6: while “Forgiveness” feels forced in both its ham-fisted jangle and its stiff attempt to add some small amount of textural dynamic to the album. Thankfully
column7: ""Forgiveness"" is the only track here that feels disposable
column8: although “Let the Beauty Be” and “Fix It” come close; the back-to-back songs usher out Beauty & Ruin on a sentimentally gooey note that finds Mould content to mouth banalities like “It won’t seem so bad” and “Time to fill your heart with love”.

column1: Mould may have largely emptied himself of the venom that’s filled him for decades
column2: but when needed
column3: he still taps into enough of that old poison to infuse “Low Season” with a churning
column4: Black Sheets of Rain moodiness and “Fire in the City” with some inspired chord changes and wrenching twists of power-pop desperation. On the rousing “The War”
column5: he plies one of the most predictable riffs of his career while singing
column6: “Listen to my voice/ It’s the only weapon I kept from the war.” Of course
column7: that’s not true: after so many years of pummeling at everything and everyone
column8: himself included
column9: he’s found a measure of acceptance—but he’s also kept his brass knuckles on
column10:
just in case.

column1:

There's a contradiction at the core of Terre Thaemlitz's album as DJ Sprinkles
column2: Midtown 120 Blues

column6: pan-cultural utopia—that house music is for everyone. She does this
column7: however

column10: after just five years
column11: though the record's scarcity and limited reach justify that decision.

column1: Thaemlitz is best known as an experimental
column2: electro-acoustic composer
column3: and she has released difficult
column4: conceptual works for labels like Mille Plateaux since the mid-90s. (With 2012's Soulnessless
column5: she claimed to have released the longest-ever album
column6: anchored by a 29-hour piano meditation.) In the early '90s
column7: before she was releasing experimental works
column8: Thaemlitz worked as a DJ in the type of midtown clubs that defined Times Square before it was corporatized later in the decade. These formative spaces gave a home to the different strains of house music emanating from New Jersey and New York
column9: a sound more contemplative than that which was coming out of Chicago: slower
column10: jazzier
column11: more reflective. It was music made and then defined by disadvantaged communities: by latinos and blacks and the LGBT community.

column1: Thaemlitz has produced house music under a number of different aliases
column2: but the deconstructivist instincts that dominate her experimental works aren't as dominant here. Midtown 120 Blues travels familiar territory
column3: working through lived-in hi-hat patterns and familiar
column4: calming electric piano chords. It helps the medicine go down easier
column5: sure
column6: but there's not that much medicine. You get the sense that this style is so dear to Thaemlitz that she's less willing to fuck with it
column7: at least on a sonic level. Midtown 120 Blues
column8: at nearly 80 minutes
column9: is almost womb-like in its immersion
column10: though Thaemlitz rejects the idea of the club as a healing
column11: safe space. You don't ""lose yourself"" in Midtown 120 Blues; it's a reflection on feeling lost.

column1: Thaemlitz began documenting this scene in 1998
column2: shortly after those clubs were elbowed out of downtown
column3: with the Sloppy 42nds 12""
column4: her first work under the DJ Sprinkles alias. Midtown 120 Blues again took this baton a decade later
column5: chronicling the turbulence and violation that existed in Thaemlitz's communities; it's an album that seethes
column6: however prettily
column7: as Thaemlitz laces her patient
column8: supple grooves with short speeches.

column1: One poignant segment of ""Ball'r (Madonna-Free Zone)"" finds her railing against Madonna
column2: whose ""decontextualized
column3: reified
column4: corporatized
column5: liberalized
column6: neutralized
column7: asexualized
column8: re-genderized pop reflection"" of the vogue scene not only misrepresented the scene's origins but left the queen ""who actually taught [Madonna] how to vogue"" broke. Thaemlitz is a compelling speaker
column9: and the hurt and anger in her voice is obvious; she's also deft enough to let the preachers
column10: whom she often samples
column11: do the preaching. Midtown 120 Blues feels far more personal than political.

column1: Midtown 120 Blues is a remembrance
column2: but it's also a travelogue
column3: loosely documenting Thaemlitz's move from her childhood home in Missouri and her immersion in midtown's scene. ""Grand Central
column4: Pt. II (72 hrs. by Rail from Missouri)"" functions largely like the KLF's Chill Out
column5: organizing samples into an ambient collage that holds your attention even as it drifts for eight minutes. Moments like these feel like a salve for Jesse Jackson
column6: who burns through his (sampled) vocal chords on ""Sisters
column7: I Don't Know What This World is Coming To"" and the nervous
column8: pendulous piano of ""House Music Is Controllable Desire You Can Own"".

column1: Like punk music
column2: house music was an underground phenomenon that offered an outlet to people who really needed an outlet. And like punk music
column3: its history is romanticized to the point that the ills and misdeeds that still permeated the community are largely ignored. In the mid-'90s Thaemlitz was fired from a prominent DJ gig because she refused to play Gloria Estefan
column4: a frequent request from the johns who would frequent the club; the johns
column5: after all
column6: kept the club open.

column1: Thaemlitz quit
column2: exhibiting the kind of principled stubbornness that has guided her career. This persists: Midtown 120 Blues will not be issued on vinyl
column3: a medium unable to provide an accurate stereo bass response. Still
column4: there's a fondness to Midtown 120 Blues
column5: not least in its closing shuffle
column6: ""The Occaional Feel-Good"". There is love here
column7: however guarded. At its best
column8:
Midtown 120 Blues simultaneously acts as a corrective to house's ahistorical narrative and reminds us just how potent and beautiful New York deep house can be.

Hype Williams never made it easy. In an age where a cloak of mystery seems more rule than exception
column2: Dean Blunt and Inga Copeland's (presumably) fake names and slippery interview tactics always felt like an altogether different beast. They somehow managed to combine total transparency with a shroud of secrecy; with all those obfuscations flying around
column3: you could never be too sure where anything stood with them
column4: even when they seemed to be giving it to you straight-up. Their music similarly existed in the cracks between genres: too out-there for post-dubstep
column5: too amorphous for IDM. With no neatly packaged narrative to bounce off of
column6: listeners had to seek answers in the music itself: no mean feat
column7: when—much like its makers—that music never quite seemed to stay in one place long enough to wrap your head around it.

column1: Copeland and Blunt parted ways in 2013
column2: after the release of Black is Beautiful
column3: a record that stripped away some—but certainly not all—of the willful obtusity of their previous shapeshifting. As Blunt offered up the Redeemer—a presumptive breakup record that sported some of the most straightforward
column4: soul-baring music of his career—Inga Copeland issued the brief
column5: bracing <i>Don't Look Back
column6: That's Not Where You're Going EP
column7: an occasionally puzzling
column8: frequently beguiling array of corroded electronics and clamorous calls-to-action. Now
column9: Copeland's returned with her debut full-length
column10: Because I'm Worth It
column11: another strange
column12: singular record that offers as many questions as it does answers. It's not an easy listen
column13: but Copeland wouldn't have it any other way.

column1: Opener ""Faith OG X"" begins with a discomfiting crackle of static. It's soon overtaken by a queasy
column2: lurching synth
column3: and then
column4: two minutes in
column5: a thought-swallowing
column6: concentration-decimating beep. The effect of this incessant ping proves wildly disorienting; after a few spins
column7: you'll learn to anticipate it
column8: but you'll never quite get used to it. That's true for much of Because I'm Worth It
column9: a nebulous
column10: deviously off-kilter listen
column11: impossible and intriguing in roughly equal measure
column12: constantly rearranging itself for maximum discombobulation.

column1: Over the whinny-and-pop of a door on a hinge
column2: ""Advice to Young Girls""—produced in conjunction with her fellow UK beatmangler Actress—finds Copeland in direct-address mode. ""Sneak out the window and meet your friends on the corner
column3: she urges. ""Together
column4: you're strong. You walk the streets: face the city
column5: face the night. The city is yours."" ""Advice"" is Worth It's finest hour
column6: a near-perfect meeting of music and message; between Copeland's uncompromising aesthetic and her appeals to self-expression and sisterhood
column7: ""Advice"" feels bold
column8: urgent
column9: necessary.

column1: ""Advice to Young Girls"" is one of few vocal-centric tracks on Worth It; most of the rest is given over to Copeland's clattering
column2: claustrophobic production. At barely half an hour
column3: Because I'm Worth It is a dank
column4: foreboding listen
column5: a difficult space to accustom oneself to
column6: at once enervating and intoxicating. The murky
column7: pitched-down voice buried near the back of ""Insult 2 Injury"" is largely obscured by its sputtering rhythms and frosty synths
column8: while the dank
column9: zero-gravity dancehall of ""Inga"" finds her voice slathered in effects
column10: rendering them half-incomprehensible. This is slippery
column11: expectation-upending stuff; even after umpteen listens
column12: you'll never quite feel as though you've acclimated yourself to the darkness.

column1: There are moments—the morse code tappings of ""Serious""
column2: the jolting beat and transmogrifying synths of closer ""L'oreal""—that seem just little too hermetic
column3: too impenetrable
column4: lost down the hall of mirrors Copeland's built around them. And while the briefer pieces—""Serious
column5: again
column6: and the strange
column7: sinewy ""DILIGENCE""—help tie everything together
column8: neither holds a candle to the denser
column9: more enveloping darkness that surround them. Taken together
column10: though
column11: all these abstractions and interjections forge a dingy
column12: disquieting dreamscape that seems to operate by its own laws of physics. The oft-bewildering Worth It is
column13: like every record Copeland's put her name to
column14: a deeply challenging
column15: deliberately unorthodox listen. But you're not likely to hear another record quite like it anytime soon
column16:
and the impression it leaves isn't an easy one to shake.

Ben Frost’s interests are vast

column8: directed his own theatrical adaption of Iain Banks’ novel The Wasp Factory. Frost also co-produced experimental saxophonist Colin Stetson’s New History Warfare
column9: Volume 3 in 2013

column14: astronomy
column15: literature
column16: nature
column17: art
column18: professional basketball. For all this

column1: Frost’s latest album

column3: offers his best example yet of this sort of aural suffocation. The uptick could partly be due to a new approach: Unlike his past work

column6: or stringed instruments; instead

column1: That feeling of distance coincides with the facts of A U R O R A’s creation: Frost wrote most of the collection on a laptop while working with photographer/filmmaker Richard Mosse in the Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. (Mosse and cinematographer Trevor Tweeten
column2: in turn

column4: volcanoes

column5: punk
column6: and metal. Instead of the noisy
column7: meditative openers of past outings
column8: A U R O R A's first track
column9: “Flex”
column10: sounds like an airplane taking off; the steady
column11: escalating synthesizer gives way to frantic jazz drumming partially consumed the crackling
column12: loose wires around it. This bleeds into “Nolan”

column15: synthesizers lapping. Like much of A U R O R A

column8: Demdike Stare

column10: but he never stays in one place
column11: and the album is filled with variety and a great sense of dynamics. The previously mentioned “Nolan” takes an Eastern turn
column12: and mixes in wind chimes beneath a gale force surge. “No Sorrowing” is a hazy

and it stands above the rest of his discography.

It could be a reminder that skate kids and Thrasher subscribers have always dug the more aggressive side of rap. Or it might just be the band and Alchemist share a similar interest in shoving your face into concrete.

column1: At any rate

column3: and Trash Talk plunge directly into ""Jigsaw""
column4: the sort of formally immaculate purist hardcore they've been making since their inception. There is another minute-long Alchemist contribution near the album's end
column5: and King Krule also shows up on the bonus track ""Stacking Skins""; he sounds spectacular
column6: inviting the imagination-firing notion of a Krule-fronted hardcore band. But otherwise<i>
column7: No Peace sounds

column1: But Trash Talk don't need to move beyond hardcore's lockstep for new ground; they are finding plenty of room within it. No Peace runs to sixteen tracks and half an hour—several lifetimes' worth of music in the suicide-sprinter's world of hardcore

column4: adding microhooks

column6: and song structures to the lean skeletons of their songs to see what they can manage without adding wind resistance. No Peace is their most sustained effort in this regard

column1: Frontman Lee Spielman's lyrics
column2: meanwhile

column4: he screams on ""Jigsaw""
column5: a song about sorting through your life. The screamed
column6: pit-rallying chorus of the song is ""Think it through""
column7: and Spielman is letting us hear him think more intensely in his songs with each release. He's not giving us dissertations—this is still hardcore
column8: where your point needs to be screamed in sharp syllables. But the slogans on No Peace point emphatically inward: ""All these songs about sleep/And I can't catch a wink
column9: he says on ""Locked In Skin""
column10: a vulnerable admission that hits with surprising force.

column1: The songs on No Peace feel like character sketches as often as personal narratives--dispatches
column2: possibly
column3: from the ravaged neighborhood in Los Angeles where they now live and record. On ""The Hole""
column4: Spielman declares
column5: ""I won't look the other way for anyone but me/ And that's the way it's always gonna be."" On ""Body Stuffer""

column8:
it tap into reservoirs of power that Trash Talk are only beginning to explore.

Hercules and Love Affair is an amorphous project with a roster that
column4: aside from the group’s mastermind and artistic director Andy Butler
column5: has turned over completely with each of its three albums so far. But its mission has remained consistent throughout: to breathe new life into the sounds and structures of early dance music
column6: particularly the interplay between producer and vocalist that underpinned the genre’s formative years. On the group’s first two records
column7: 2008’s self-titled debut and 2011’s Blue Songs
column8: they accomplished that goal by exploding the tropes of early house music while simultaneously paying fealty to them
column9: resulting in tracks like the quasi-operatic
column10: Antony-led “Blind” that reincarnated the style into ambitiously strange shapes.

column1: For The Feast of the Broken Heart
column2: Butler and his team (which this time around includes Viennese house-and-techno revivalists Haze Factory and industrial music stalwart Mark Pistel) color inside the lines a little more than before. If the first two Hercules records were tributes to the dawning era of dance music thirty or so years ago
column3: Feast is more of a flat-out homage. The sounds
column4: the structures
column5: and the entire approach more closely resembles the source material—the propulsive
column6: hard-edged descendant of disco that pioneers like Larry Levan were spinning in the '70s and '80s. Having spent years deconstructing old house music
column7: Butler's now become a considerably more faithful and accurate emulator.

column1: There are drawbacks to any artistic undertaking with an explicit retro-revivalist agenda
column2: and Feast suffers accordingly—in particular
column3: there's the subtle but ever-present sensation that
column4: for all the excitement that the music generates
column5: it’s still an echo of someone else’s good time that happened decades ago. Butler and company mitigate much of that feeling by giving their influences a sonic touch-up
column6: dirtying and tweaking out the vintage drum machine and synthesizer sounds they’re working with (check the noisy synth that puts an intriguing wrinkle into the smooth lines of “My Offence”)
column7: in the process infusing them with a wily energy that more fastidious retro reproductions can’t manage. Hercules and Love Affair give these tracks more room to breathe than the sometimes claustrophobically compact arrangements on older house records.

column1: To some extent
column2: The Feast of the Broken Heart bounces back against those drawbacks because of the nature of the style Hercules and Love Affair working in. Compared to the other major pop genres
column3: dance music has historically been immune to the effects of nostalgia because it’s spent so much of its existence
column4: at least in America
column5: as a subcultural style with an audience that’s been removed from the mainstream (partly because it’s been so relentlessly forward-looking from the genre's beginnings). The recent arrival of younger rave revivalists and old-school house fanatics
column6: however
column7: has caused the genre as a whole to take a good look at its past and try
column8: in earnest
column9: to replicate it.

column1: Like Hercules’s first two records
column2: Feast transcends mere homage not only through sonic innovations but by the quality of the emotional connection it makes with its audience. Butler is both a gifted producer and a crafty A&R
column3: and throughout the album he fits an unexpected cast of singers to songs based on criteria much more subtle and significant than their vocal range. The stage performer Rouge Mary imparts disco-diva uplift to the self-realization anthem “5:43 to Freedom”
column4: elevating a hokey line like “Be yourself/ Like there ain’t nobody” into something that could genuinely inspire a dancefloor epiphany. On “My Offence”
column5: singer-songwriter Krystle Warren
column6: whose own work normally leans towards rootsy chamber pop
column7: brings a raspy low range and gleaming high range with the same kind of casual fuck-you attitude that's similarly animated other statement-of-identity house tracks offering spiritual solace to several generations of club-going social misfits.

column2: featuring alt-folk singer and former Czars front man John Grant. It’s about Grant’s experience finding out he’s H.I.V. positive
column3: and knowing that about the song can make it a gutting listen
column4: especially on the choruses where he crooningly pleads
column5: “I don’t understand
column6: help me please.” But instead of backing him up with a dirge
column7: Butler and his crew give him a raucous
column8: thumping floor-filler. To some

column10: <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">but it’s exactly this refusal to bow to tragedy that kept the original house music scene alive through the ravages of the AIDS crisis. With it
column12:
Hercules & Love Affair tap into an essential part of house music’s history that’s far more profound than just the music.

In a reissue-frenzied world where even the smallest scene is exhaustively curated into a fine-tuned history
column2: it's weirdly refreshing to stumble across a compilation that makes no further claims than ""Here's a bunch of crazy stuff I dug up"". Marc Bowles
column3: b/k/a Mr. Thing of the UK turntablist collective Scratch Perverts
column4: is ridiculously dedicated to the art of unearthing what-on-Earth 45s and stringing them together with little regard for genre
column5: national origin
column6: or much of anything else besides a certain feel of knuckleball unpredictability. In 2008 and 2009
column7: the first two volumes of his BBE series Strange Breaks & Mr. Thing pulled double-duty as the type of curation efforts that are obscurity-hunters' dreams
column8: as well as mixes that personify the philosophy of vinyl-slingers from the Gaslamp Killer all the way back to David Mancuso. Once the momentum's established

column1: The series' third volume is as characteristically preposterous as the previous two
column2: crammed with what the sleeve dubs ""Rock
column3: Funk
column4: Soul
column5: Jazz & Soundtrack Breaks for Modern Living"" and threading them into a free-for-all that scans as hip-hop

column7: there are some gutbucket funk sides

column1: But it's the more peripherally funk curios that give the collection its real personality. The DJ's secret weapon of left-field library-music cuts gets some time in the repertoire
column2: via James Asher's regrettably exoticized-yet-effectively slinky ""Oriental Workload""—and even that cut comes across as relatively basic compared to a cover of the theme to UK cop-show ""The Sweeney""
column3: courtesy of the Woolwich Polytechnic School Concert Band. Weaving in a few other nods towards international flavor—a re-edit of music from a belly-dancer instructional record
column4: a steel-drum cover of Ripple's ""I Don't Know What It Is
column5: but It Sure Is Funky""—bypasses the audio-tourist kitsch potential for the kick-snare whomp that lies beneath. Sometimes
column6: the draw of Bowles' selections are almost purely atmospheric; Sharon Cash's version of the old standard ""Nature Boy"" eventually crescendos into pin-you-down orchestral funk bombast

Blackest Ever Black are quick to note that Dead Unique is not a reissue. Rather
column2: it's an album recorded in 1995 that just never got released. How it ended up that way—well
column3: nobody really remembers. (How's that for self-mythologizing?) But let's back up a bit: what the hell is Officer!
column4: you ask? It was the baby of Londoner Mick Hobbs
column5: a quirky rocker who had his start in the RIO scene—that's Rock in Opposition
column6: a UK movement started in the late '70s to promote ""progressive"" and non-commercial bands in the wake of both punk and corporate rock—with stints in groups like the Work and Half Japanese
column7: among others. By no means a solo project
column8: Officer! was a revolving-door band that centered around Hobbs' uniquely zany persona
column9: a little bit psychedelic and very English. They released a few cassettes (one of which
column10: 1984's Ossification
column11: just got its own reissue)
column12: but Dead Unique
column13: the project's most recent work
column14: might just be its most fully realized
column15: as well as its most unhinged.

column1: Officer! sound like the madcap psychedelia of Syd Barrett bred with the whimsy of Canterbury psychedelic bands
column2: executed with the frayed mental state of post-punk. Sometimes
column3: they barely sound like a functioning band on Dead Unique
column4: but other moments showcase a tight ensemble tying in blues and progressive rock into their patchwork weave. If that all sounds a little out of place on a label like Blackest Ever Black—usually home to dark electronics from the likes of Raime and Tropic of Cancer—that's because it is
column5: but nonetheless there's a menacing undertone to Officer!'s strange nursery rhymes. Paranoia surfaces in tracks like ""Go Back""
column6: where Hobbs sings ""People of the world/ Lie to us/ Like you lie to me
column7: a choked phrase that you imagine coming out from a crooked smile with rotten and missing teeth. It's the kind of crackpot worldview you get from someone who's taken a little too much acid in their lifetime
column8: but coming from Hobbs it feels tongue-in-cheek
column9:
delivered with a nod and a wink.

This off-kilter sensibility also lends some of the songwriting a manic quality. ""Go Back"" somehow resolves into a motivational climax
column10: with Hobbs impelling repeatedly
column11: ""You lose
column12: you learn/ You advance/ But you always go back."" ""It Goes Up"" is bustling
column13: haplessly layered with shrill sax and chaotic chatter
column14: while ""Shrug/Good"" finds itself in a vaudeville costume after starting out like a power-pop jam. Meanwhile
column15: the chunky ""Nardis"" has the dextrous feel of a crack bar band
column16: navigating guitar lyrics and syncopated rhythms with dazzling ease
column17:
but the vocals are bleated out through a wall of filters. Nothing's ever quite as it seems on Dead Unique.

What's most striking about Dead Unique is how much it sounds like Ossification. Aside from a slight improvement in sound quality and some studio embellishments
column18: Dead Unique sounds like an even weirder version of the album that came eleven years previous
column19: which is good news for existing fans of Hobbs. His muse is so frantically diverse that the album's eighteen tracks can sound overwhelming
column20: but its sprawl is all contained in the same world. Listening to Dead Unique is like walking through the different sets of some imaginary fantasy series—there are monsters here
column21: strange animals there
column22: a wide array of dazzling trinkets and colours
column23: and it's all distinctly artificial. The considerable list of personnel adds to that fact too
column24: with artists like Patrick Q (the Legendary Pink Dots)
column26: and John Dierker adding their own vocals
column27:
violin and even clarinet to the LP's endlessly expressive sound palette.

Dead Unique's centrepiece is buried towards the end: the five-minute spoken-word screed ""The Pony Was Contented"" stalks and spurts forward like a cartoon character trying to sneak up on someone
column28: all while telling a stream-of-consciousness story with a whole lot of subject confusion about the pony for good measure. The way Hobbs holds the words ""my little pony"" in his mouth becomes unsettling after a while
column29: but even when you can't figure out what the hell is going on
column30: he and his band are as captivating as they are confounding. The tune represents one of many peeks into Officer!'s strange little environment on Dead Unique
column31:
a world as vibrant as a children's storybook but written with the acerbic wit of an eccentric Englishman.

The second full-length from Hundred Waters is not an evolution so much as a refinement. If 2012’s self-titled effort saw the band sketching out the borders of their sound
column2: The Moon Rang Like a Bell finds them zeroing in on what they do best and going deeper. The production is improved in every way
column3: but given how hushed and quiet they can be
column4: the effect is still pretty subtle. Acoustic instruments have been jettisoned; the pillowy synths and layered vocals of singer Nicole Miglis nestle easily in the mix
column5: sometimes leaving questions as to when one end and another begins. Indeed
column6: the key to Hundred Waters’ rich and tactile atmosphere is that their machines never sound quite like machines
column7: but everything sounds close; on “Murmurs”
column8: distant piano is buried under reverb and digital crackle
column9: sketching out chords with a vaguely gospel feel
column10: as a strange voice sings a tune while so near to the microphone you can hear a tongue clicking against teeth. It’s an album that always feels like it’s whispering in your ear.

column1: The band’s approach is difficult to place in a specific time. That’s not because their aesthetic is especially innovative or new
column2: or because it seems like it’s from the future; rather
column3: they bring to mind a moment when updating dusty old song structures with the tools of the present seemed like the next logical step in music. “Digital folk” was the term used in a review of their self-titled debut
column4: and that captures it as well as anything: music that is both earthy and disembodied
column5: with humans and electronics joining at some blissful halfway point. Hundred Waters thrive in the place where post-rock meets freak folk
column6: and sing-song melodies are twisted into strange shapes by circuitry.

column1: The connection to Björk is hard to overstate. Part of The Moon’s appeal is that it hearkens back to the style of Vespertine
column2: the last album when Björk’s restlessly experimental music still had a foot in accessibility
column3: before she took such a conceptual turn. There’s a similar sense of music-as-place here
column4: and a desire to fuse ancient and modern in search of a new mode of expression. And in that respect
column5: oddly enough
column6: Hundred Waters remind me of another group from Iceland—Múm
column7: in particular their 2000 album Yesterday Was Dramatic—Today is OK
column8: an album sometimes described at the time as “folktronica.” These aren’t influences I’m talking about
column9: necessarily
column10: but ways of hearing what Hundred Waters are doing. It’s not a coincidence that these signposts are from music made around the turn of the millennium
column11: when rapidly changing technology meant the future sound of pop was up in the air.

column1: But if much of Björk’s power comes from her unpredictability
column2: the feeling that a breathy sight could turn into a scream and a song might explode
column3: Hundred Waters are always set to simmer. That mostly works in their favor on The Moon Rang Like a Bell
column4: as the album’s strength comes from its gradually accruing moments. So the spell of the minute-long a cappella opener “Show Me Love” is broken by clear piano chords and miniature percussive explosions on “Murmurs” and then the following “Cavity” raises the intensity before the bright and twinkly “Out Alee” brings it back to earth. Sequenced beautifully
column5: the record is full of these gentle arcs
column6: and the sound is so consistent it can feel like a 49-minute piece broken into 12 movements. The impact of any one song is heightened by its proximity to what came before and what follows.

column1: In an interview
column2: Miglis highlighted the importance of her lyrics to The Moon Rang Like a Bell
column3: but for me the album functions more like an instrumental album
column4: where meaning comes from the sonics. On the page
column5: her words are allusive and fragmented
column6: hinting at moments of doubt and turmoil
column7: but on record
column8: the words come over as pure sound. There’s a moment about halfway through “Innocent” where Miglis breaks away from language and sings a “dah-dah-dah-do-dum” phrase
column9: but with her voice coated in processed fuzz
column10: she sounds like an amphibious creature prone to reverie. This line communicates as well as any phrase on the album. “Is it only in my head?”
column11: she asks a moment later
column12:
and it wouldn’t be a bad subtitle for an album so steeped in imagination.

Ryan Lott's most recent album as Son Lux

column3: communicated an ambivalence with the modern world
column4: with Lott yearning for an escape to undefined ""alternate worlds"". There was a real sense that Lott thought this proverbial Shangri-La was impossible to actually reach
column5: but amidst the album's density there was also a deep-rooted optimism that suggested that utopia could still be found on the rock we're currently floating through space on. On his new EP
column6: Alternate Worlds
column7: which reconfigures songs from Lanterns
column8: that sanguine outlook has been all but scrubbed away
column9: and what's left is darkened and clouded over until it resembles something closer to weary skepticism
column10: if not outright cynicism.

column1: Nowhere is this philosophical recalibration more apparent than on ""Easy (Switch Screens)"". Of the four tracks Lott reimagines on Alternate Worlds
column2: ""Easy"" is the most dramatically reworked
column3: and its revised form leaves the greatest impression thanks to the presence of Lorde
column4: who adds a sense of menace that Lott previously hasn't elicited on his own. It's an inspired bit of recasting
column5: the creeping tentacles of Lorde's voice tightening around the track as Lott hollows it out even further
column6: leaving an irradiated husk for Lorde to slither in and out of with her vocals. Any sunlight present on the original has been blotted out completely
column7: and the result is a chillier and more seductive take on what was
column8: in its previous form
column9: one of the highlights on Lanterns.

column1: Lott takes a similar approach with the other three tracks here
column2: stripping them back in hopes of finding something more elemental
column3: but this approach proves hit-or-miss. In Lott's world
column4: more is more
column5: a songwriting mindset that hasn't always produced optimal results

column1: That said
column2: the reconfigurations featured on Alternate Worlds are largely improvements on the songs they draw from; ""Alternate World (Alternate Age)"" slathers Lott's vocals in a number of effects (almost a winking admission that his vocals have never been a main draw)
column3: and ""Build a Pyre (Begin Again)"" is even itchier than the original ""Pyre""
column4: sounding like thousands of ants crawling underneath the listener's skin. But with the exception of ""Easy (Switch Screens)""
column5: these tracks remain on the inessential end of the spectrum. These darker-if-not-darkest-timeline versions possess fewer dimensions than their original incarnations did
column6: even if they pack more of a punch
column7:
and that's the paradox that surrounds these Alternate Worlds.

But Witch clearly got into the right hands at some point during its early phase; it’s widely assumed to have been heard by a number of trip-hop figureheads

column1: Winer lived in England at the time of Witch but her backstory takes her all over. Originally from Western Massachusetts

column1: But stopping at the title track would mean missing out on the rest that Do It Again has to offer. The relaxed format gives Robyn and Röyksopp space to sprawl out in some rewarding

""It hurts so good.""

Working as Haunted Hearts
column3: Dee Dee of Dum Dum Girls and her husband Brandon Welchez of Crocodiles have made an album loosely based around the S&M scene in New York during the 1970s and ‘80s. Romanticizing the New York of decades past—never mind its taboo fetish clubs
column4: celebrity­-filled S&M dungeons
column5: and the pervasive sexual landscape of pre­-Giuliani Manhattan—is a tricky task in 2014
column6: when just a few clicks away are hundreds of no wave
column7: post­-punk
column8: and electroclash bands who were actually there at the time. Haunted Hearts don’t exactly unearth the scabrous New York of yesteryear; rather
column9: they become the Ghost of Manhattan's Past and fly us over punk
column10: sex
column11: rebellion
column12: and death-marked love while never taking us deeply into it.

column1: Still
column2: it's honest music from the noise-­pop couple
column3: both of whom come into this project having broadened their sound within their own respective bands. Dum Dum Girls’ LP from earlier this year
column4: Too True

column6: dreamier decades

column8: while still nipping at the heels of the Jesus and Mary Chain and other Ray Ban­-wearing bands of the ‘80s
column9: expand its sonic range on Crimes of Passion. Call it holy matrimony
column10: but husband and wife pull each back to the safe zone on Initiation—these songs sound good and comfy. The power of Dee Dee’s belt or Welchez’s fuzz stomp all defer to a beautiful bluish gauze
column11: one that only sort of reflects the kinky cynicism that sits at the core of these songs.

column1: They write at pain and pleasure fairly overtly in ""Something That Feels Bad Is Something That Feels Good"" and continue in the same vein on ""Up Is Up (But So Is Down)."" The latter plays out like a scene from some '70s art house film with characters calling the ""trash man"" to ""get their garbage flowing"" and a mother who ""flushes all her fun to keep her brain from humming."" It's a lonely song that lazily gyrates to a drum shuffle that recalls just about everything J. Spaceman and Richard Ashcroft have ever done. There are a few surprises here
column2: but their comfort with each other gives these songs a certain ease. Hang up red curtains
column3: shine a flashlight on a tiny disco ball
column4: throw on a sequin dress
column5: and sway back and forth until you are on the same page with Haunted Hearts. That's the scene to set if you really want the blend of their voices and the hum of the synths to move you.

column1: Problem is
column2: the fuzzy approximations of heroin kisses and blissed­-out dreams just never find an identity of their own. When ""Johnny Jupiter"" comes on
column3: just the name ""Johnny"" brings to mind one of the most iconic names used in music to being so cool
column4: to being angry
column5: to being a shooting star
column6: to name only a few. It speaks to Haunted Hearts' obsession with the knee-jerk signifiers that surround the record—devil-may-care anti-heroes
column7: drag queens and Hubert Selby Jr. novels
column8: intravenous parties and dead-eyed dancing. But it just stays so symmetrical. Dee Dee and Welchez sing about love in such a detached way
column9: you won't know where their ennui ends and yours begins.

column1: The Dee Dee­-featured ballad ""Love Incognito"" is a welcome ray of sunshine. She finally opens up on the chorus with words plain and sweet
column2: ""I see you/ Yes I do/ You didn't think I could."" Thanks to her energy on the chorus
column3: the song blossoms out in a way the mid­tempo mod rock surrounding it never quite does. But it still all adds up to something so familiar and unspecific—straight songs whose subject matter beg them to be anything but. Maybe it's the intimacy they shared recording this together in their apartment while holed up over last winter
column4: spinning krautrock and Spiritualized records that drove them so far away from the outside world and into themselves. On the closing epilogue ""Bring Me Down""
column5: the couple coo to each other
column6:
""Well you've been bad/ But you're the best I've ever had.""  It plays like the last song on a Love Mixtape they made for each other; a comp about Haunted Hearts' little secrets and favorite music that ultimately means more to Dee Dee and Welchez than anyone else.

Popstrangers are a peculiar sort of New Zealand nationalists: proud enough of their homeland to name their 2013 debut album Antipodes and to fully embrace the country’s indigenous indie-rock tradition of jangle and drone
column2: but not so sentimentally attached to it that they didn’t get the fuck as far away from Auckland the first chance they got. In hindsight

column4: with the band’s current home of London
column5: England situated at the polar opposite location of their native soil. With Popstrangers’ big move to Blighty comes an equally pronounced uptick in ambition

column1: Trading in Antipodes’ frazzled fuzz for greater focus
column2: Fortuna’s arrival is fortuitously timed to take over cranial-massage duties from your played-out copy of Tame Impala’s Lonerism. Popstrangers may not boast the headphone-blowing studio-science intricacy and widescreen wallop of Kevin Parker’s project (at least
column3: not yet)

column4: or
column5: more frustratingly
column6: when Flyger’s words fail him: “Tonight” could be Fortuna’s most immediate
column7: irresistibly catchy song
column8: but also its most lyrically clichéd
column9: yet another in the long line of rock songs using a garden metaphor as a hippy-dippy signifier of the feminine mystique
column10: <span style=""font-family: Georgia
column11: serif; font-size: 15px; line-height: 24px;"">and describing desire as a ""disease.""

column1: But for the most part

column3: arm-swaying chorus of “Her” even suggests latent Oasis-at-Knebworth fantasies. And while Popstrangers haven’t buffed off all their edges (see: the post-punky pair of “Distress” and “Right Babies”)
column4: the most patiently paced moments on Fortuna prove to be the most potent—like the intensifying

Popstrangers won’t have to uproot themselves halfway around the world again to get there.

Three years ago
column2: Douglas Mcgowan (the man behind last year’s resplendent new age compilation
column3: I Am the Center) sent a parcel of strange records my way
column4: including one from Seattle-based musician Marc Barreca which seemed to hover in between many genres: new age
column5: industrial
column6: soundtracks. Barreca's record was released on the obscure Palace of Lights imprint run by another musician operating in the mists of the Pacific Northwest
column7: Kerry Leimer
column8: who himself had self-released a handful of his own work.

column1: Investigating Leimer’s albums—specifically
column2: 1982’s Land of Look Behind and 1983’s Imposed Order—revealed a curious artist. While the pastoral synths might scan as those of a new age practitioner
column3: the weird loops of bass and noise eddying throughout suggested someone with more avant-garde tendencies. And when the drums burst into those otherwise ambient pieces (Look Behind drew on field recordings made in Jamaica of nyabinghi drumming
column4: while Order used drum machines)
column5: it complicated matters further. These albums are long out of print
column6: so it makes sense that the erudite RVNG imprint—already responsible for reviving forgotten artists ranging from Harald Grosskopf to Franco Falsini—would claim Leimer as one of their own.

column1: A Period of Review (Original Recordings: 1975-1983) posits K. Leimer as the American Eno
column2: and while there are sonic ties back to the likes of Cluster
column3: Faust
column4: and Jon Hassell
column5: Eno is the only predecessor that Leimer admits to
column6: telling writer Dave Segal in the liner notes: “None gave me more of a push than Eno
column7: specifically…No Pussyfooting. The attractor was the loops: the loop provided an instant structure.” The Eno fandom is obvious on one of the set’s rare vocal pieces
column8: “Lonely Boy
column9: ” where Leimer laments being a composer watching tiny lights blinking at him. “I don’t know what to do/ With instruments and all these wires
column10: ” he intones
column11: even nailing Eno’s dry British deadpan. Another song title is perhaps too on the nose: “Eno’s Aviary.”

column1: Despite that namecheck
column2: there is something distinctly punk coursing through this compilation of thirty previously unreleased tracks. The sleeve art of other Palace of Lights releases (which RVNG also plans on compiling later this year) are odd pencil drawings: heads morphing into home stereos
column3: diagrams where fingers become entangled with bass strings. It suggests that strange time period after the Sex Pistols exploded overseas but before punk crossed the Atlantic and crystallized into hardcore. Much like other punks of that era who didn’t really want to shove a pin through their nose
column4: Leimer was more than a trained musician who simply wanted to vent frustration and make some noise with tape loops.

column1: One of the set's pleasures is that although Leimer doesn’t quite know what to do with the  instruments on hand—primarily a Rickenbacker bass
column2: a Mini Moog
column3: Revox tape decks
column4: and a handful of effects pedals—the results are entrancing. The drum machine beats feel primitive yet intuitive on pieces like “Entr’acte” and “Archie’s Dub”
column5: which possess a strange layering of dub effects that bring to mind Eno’s collaboration with David Byrne on My Life in the Bush of Ghosts (Leimer’s band Savant would explore that polyrhythmic sound even further). For an album featuring so many dreamlike
column6: drifting passages
column7: it’s startling to look at the runtimes and realize that only four pieces ever top the 4:30 mark; beautiful ambient tracks like “Almost Chinese”
column8: “At Daybreak”
column9: and “Two Voices” take you much further afield than their concise runtimes suggest.

column1: These pieces most closely evoke the work of Roedelius and Moebius in Cluster: meditative
column2: wistful
column3: lovely
column4: giving off gentle glimmers of light. In trying to think of the closest American corollary for this set
column5: the possibility emerges that Kerry Leimer is one of the lone examples of American kosmische music
column6: that elegant hybrid that falls somewhere between the Velvets-styled mesmerism of Can in the early '70s and the placid tones of new age music that arose in the next decade. It’s a sound that applies to mid-70s Cluster
column7: Ash Ra Tempel
column8: Popol Vuh
column9: the second side of Kraftwerk’s Autobahn
column10: and others. Yet while import copies of such records no doubt made their way back to the States
column11: it’s rare to find the American version of such a sound. There’s cosmic overtones to be found in jazz from that era (Miles Davis’ “He Loved Him Madly” in particular) as well as from more academic composers like Terry Riley and Laurie Spiegel
column12: but for most bands and musicians of that decade
column13: kosmische seems to have not been emulated. In experiencing this evocative set some three decades later
column14:
Leimer’s music sounds like the road not taken.

From the first notes of her 2009 debut
column2: Because I Was in Love
column3: New Jersey native Sharon Van Etten wrote with seeming effortlessness about the depravations of romance and the contortions of a heart either committed or broken
column4: displaying a penchant for wrenching turns of phrase laden with dire implications. When she sang
column5: “The moral of the story is don't lie to me again
column6: ” on “Consolation Prize”
column7: it was the “again” that stuck in your gut
column8: suggesting a pattern of aggression and acquiescence that would not necessarily end with the song. Her voice toggled fluidly between brave and broken
column9: dogged and defiant—often within the same line. She whispered
column10: then jumped to a fierce vibrato that could stop an army. Disclosing her darkest moments proved both empowering and unnerving
column11: as though startled by her own strength. Even on her debut
column12: she displayed the poise of a pro.

column1: As with so many singer-songwriters—for whom lyrics and vocals take primacy over every other element—Van Etten never sounded quite so self-assured musically. Because I Was in Love showcased her quiet vocals and surprisingly nimble guitarwork
column2: with producer Greg Weeks of Espers mostly staying out of her way. That subdued sound was going to be impossible to sustain for another album
column3: much less an entire career
column4: so it seemed almost inevitable when she introduced a full-band sound
column5: complete with flourishes of pedal steel
column6: on her follow-up
column7: Epic. On 2012’s career-making Tramp
column8: she worked with the National’s Aaron Dessner and emerged with her fullest and most fully realized album to date
column9: even if it occasionally sounded overly decorous
column10: even fussy. Her catalog has been a series of trials and experiments
column11: driven by restlessness and perfectionism in equal measure
column12: although weirdly the transitions between albums only serve to render each one more volatile and unpredictable.

column1: It is
column2: then
column3: notable that Van Etten herself produced her fourth album
column4: Are We There
column5: with some assistance from Stewart Lerman. The two met while working on the second soundtrack to Boardwalk Empire and decamped to his New Jersey studio to record these new songs. Lerman’s work with Loudon Wainwright III
column6: the Roches
column7: and other singer-songwriters makes him a good fit for Van Etten
column8: but perhaps more than any of her previous records Are We There sounds self-determined and self-directed. The music fits snugly against her vocals
column9: with her guitar and piano foregrounded on opener “Afraid of Nothing”. As a result
column10: these songs move fluidly and dramatically
column11: but never ostentatiously. Even the woodwinds on “Tarifa” sound understated
column12: as though careful not to distract from Van Etten’s performance.

column1: It’s the most comfortable she’s sounded since Because I Was in Love
column2: which is not to say the music lacks color or character. “Your Love Is Killing Me” is built on a Jenga-style assemblage of post-rock guitars and jittery snare taps
column3: and even as it sprawls into a six-minute jam (her longest song to date)
column4: it never topples. Instead
column5: the music only reinforces her repeated proclamation
column6: “You tell me that you like it.” Elsewhere
column7: Are We There softens and quietens. A purposefully stiff drum loop lends “Taking Chances” its brooding
column8: conspiratorial tone
column9: reining in the chorus and setting up an effective one-chord organ solo. The stark piano on “I Love You But I’m Lost” flutters nervously
column10: as though reminding you that Van Etten’s whispers can convey screams. There is a live quality to the music
column11: as though she has crafted each note with concerts in mind. Her songs emphasize the moment
column12: both in the quality of her performance and in the rawness of her lyrics. As a result
column13: Are We There may be her most present-tense album to date
column14: her most immediate and urgent—the peak of a steady upward trajectory.

column1: Even as she has settled into a successful solo career
column2: Van Etten continues to write incisively about the volatility of love
column3: with no loss of urgency or investment. Her songs tend to be excruciatingly confessional
column4: largely indistinguishable from the singer herself
column5: and Are We There reveals a new self-awareness with regard to her primary subject. On “I Know”
column6: which features Van Etten alone on piano
column7: she declares
column8: “I sing about my fear and love and what it brings
column9: ” as though we didn’t know that already. On closer “Every Time the Sun Comes Up”
column10: she asks
column11: not entirely rhetorically
column12: “People say I'm a one hit wonder
column13: but what happens when I have two?” It’s a sly way to preempt any complaint that she has only one emotional or musical setting
column14: but the next line turns the song upside-down: “I washed your dishes
column15: then I shit in your bathroom.” Recently
column16: Van Etten told Pitchfork that the line was originally a joke with her band
column17: but it’s not hard to see why this incredibly anti-romantic line would have stayed in. It reveals the driving idea behind the album: It’s not the big moments that define or doom a relationship
column18: but the everyday routines
column19: the small sacrifices that accumulate over time
column20: the stark realities of sharing your life with another person. You see them at their best and their worst
column21: their most beautiful and their most vulgar. To her credit
column22:
Van Etten has never shrunk from this horrible and wonderful understanding.

column1: Clues to its enduring appeal can be found in its most immediately noticeable quality: the relentless repetition of a small handful of themes. Almost every song here mentions rain

column7: heavily reverbed sound

column1: MacLean has always been open about his influences: surrealist poetry
column2: found-object art
column3: the fathoms-deep atmosphere of Galaxie 500. From the surrealists he learned a rich vividness with language; lines like “Bicycles have drifted through these leaves still wet with rain” (from “Bicycles”) and “6 am in morningside

The freighted imagery inflates mundane objects and situations into impossibly grand tableaus; these songs invite you to look a little more deeply at your surroundings
