column1: Indeed
column2: Suburban Light evokes a lonely world. One of the reasons the record sounds so dreamlike is that the narrator is completely in his own head; he wanders lamp-lit streets and sees a carnival crowd dispersing but feels a million miles away. The scenes describing human contact seem to happen more in imagination than reality. So in addition to romanticizing the mundane
column3: Suburban Light also makes moving through the world in solitude and observing it carefully seem like a state of grace.

column1: Driving home all these quiet scenes and minute observations is music that is unfailingly gorgeous. MacLean is an inventive guitar player and he sings with real emotion
column2: and he also has the songwriting chops to hang with his earlier pop heroes. Part of why Suburban Light feels so bound to memory is because the constructions of the songs hearkens back to an age when the right chord change
column3: when paired with the precise melodic turn
column4: counted for everything. The songs seem old in part because their melodic conception is from another era
column5: one when competition for penning tunes was thick. And the extreme reverb
column6: sometimes reminiscent of the ghost halo of echo surrounding voices in the Flamingos' “I Only Have Eyes for You”
column7: evokes a particular era of radio
column8: one we know now only filtered through many generations of media.

inhabiting a world so lovely and unreal.

The vision of late 1960s and early '70s Seattle R&B as laid out by Light in the Attic's 2005 comp Wheedle's Groove permeated everything in reach of your speakers: the West Coast vibe of the times shipped up North
column3: sprawled out under an overcast mist
column4: and infused with the deep rawness of nightly club gigs turned trial-by-fire proving grounds. Like many Northern cities that were second-or-third tier destinations for Black Americans during the Second Great Migration from the '40s through the '70s
column5: Seattle had to strain its soul and funk through ""unofficially"" segregated clubs and scenes
column6: and the opportunities for nationwide breakthroughs to emerge out of a regional touring itinerary were slim at best. But Wheedle's Groove collected more than enough gems to prove that the Emerald City could pull off raw soul
column7: searing balladry
column8: and spaced-out funk with a panache that could go toe-to-toe with any scene Northwest of Memphis.

column1: After nine years and a vise-tight All-Star jam session that resulted in an album
column2: Kearney Barton
column3: by a Seattle-vet band that took on the Wheedle's Groove name

column6: boogie funk
column7: disco
column8: electro

column7: with rapid-panning Fender Rhodes

column10: Bold
column11: & Together

column13: despite being something of a stylistic outlier

column15: falsetto-pierced harmonies—and its high-in-the-mix 4/4 conga groove and cymbal rides points at what was to come in popular music afterwards.

column1: That creeping sense of the then-future is why it's worth noting that once things get to flat-out late '70s disco territory

column6: too: '78-vintage cuts like Epicentre's sprightly ""Get Off the Phone"" (sung by Bernadette Bascom

column8: but it's not hard to imagine them sounding like the better entries in a block of decade's-end Top 40 radio.

column1: From there
column2: it's just a quick step or two to the stripped-down turn towards synthesized grooves that made funk both more futuristic and more budget-conscious in the '80s. The less-heralded versions of the sounds emerging from L.A. and Minneapolis are well-represented here

column1: So Blu's latest
column2: Good to Be Home
column3: is especially aggravating in that it's a decent record from a way-better-than-decent artist. The album operates under a concept that
column4: typically
column5: either results in pro forma nostalgia or immediately resonant memory restoration: a West Coast rap ""Back to the roots"" homecoming
column6: hence the title. Good to Be Home doesn't really fall under either category
column7: though—instead
column8: Blu's gathering memories he found spilling out of an old shoebox and taking stock without feeling the need to tie any of it together. The end result is too vague to resemble overt wistfulness
column9: or for that matter
column10: a uniquely insightful autobiography—the latter of which he nailed amazingly on his and producer Mainframe's 2008 self-titled effort as Johnson&Jonson.

column1: Good to Be Home does possess a certain duality
column2: revisiting a hazy-yet-formative Angeleno G-funk upbringing while filtering it through the lens of abstracted
column3: flow-first free-association lyrics and dusty-soul production that keeps in line with the L.A. underground. The juxtaposition makes sense; Blu's always integrated a contradictory complexity into his persona
column4: struggling between frustration and triumph
column5: widescreen observations and introverted tunnel-vision focus. He builds ancillary details into perceptive storytelling or
column6: inversely
column7: breaks down the big picture into separate components.

column1: An indie auteur too mercurial for the majors cutting his teeth on Pac isn't unheard of
column2: but it points to an intriguing artistic backstory that Blu could conceivably give vivid insight into. Unfortunately
column3: he doesn't. He's equally talented at constructing personal
column4: detail-riddled narrative lyricism as he is spinning impressionistic takes on his daily existence; those gifts work best when paired in tandem
column5: but when he operates almost exclusively in the latter mode
column6: he generalizes his more human-sounding sentiments instead of owning them powerfully. ""The West"" finds Blu simultaneously looking at yesterday and tomorrow
column7: blending memories of his parents' disapproval with his unaffiliated
column8: gangsta-coded gear (""Sagged and rocked rags when my folks ain't condone it"") with rapidfire shifts in focus.

column1: But it often takes deeper readings between the lines to find the sparse details on Good to Be Home that listeners who aren't '80s L.A. babies can latch on to. The thematic focus on youthful rap-steeped cockiness rolls along aimlessly like an unplanned weekday teenage summer evening spent driving without a destination
column2: the first half's steady stream of N.W.A. memories and driver's-seat sermons (""The Return""
column3: ""Boyz N the Hood""
column4: ""Whip Creme"") coasting on Daytons that look like they're standing still even when the car's rolling. Influences frequently emerge
column5: from pop-rap standbys (Skee-Lo's ""I Wish""
column6: DJ Jazzy Jeff & the Fresh Prince's ""Summertime"") to bicoastal street-rap canon fodder (Nas' ""Life's a Bitch""
column7: Ice Cube's ""It Was a Good Day"").

column1: Blu is clearly focused in his intensity when he rattles off these pieces of a past that haven't entirely vanished from his present. The beats from relative unknown Bombay aren't that innovative or surprising; when he's not on some under-quantized
column2: shrill-stringed
column3: obscure-soul-loop I Can't Believe It's Not Madlib business
column4: he's reaching for known quantities like Kool & the Gang's ""Summer Madness"" or Gil Scott-Heron's ""Angel Dust"". But Blu's dedication to Blake Griffin-ing every syllable and punching in the internal rhymes like a Tekken combo keeps the momentum charging ahead.

column1: On those rare moments where Bombay keeps the beat sparse
column2: like the melted-on-the-dashboard G-funk creep of ""Rap Dope
column3: the individuality that's sometimes missing in Blu's lyrics springs out in his voice
column4: the past tense of his memories' waypoints rattled off with the snarl of someone yet to come down from the adrenaline high and the ensuing rush. Maybe that's the point: Good to Be Home's recollections are only meant to be alluded to
column5:
a summer-jam album riddled with familiar nods to shared experiences but still walled off from observers who think they really know Blu.

Austin foursome Future Death are the second band to name themselves in honor of the third best Flaming Lips album—and
column2: like the first such group
column3: they share very little aesthetically with their source inspiration beyond a root interest in the collision of melody and noise. However
column4: while the band is barely two years old
column5: it’s not premature to suggest that Future Death are capable of pulling off a Lips-like evolution from acid-punk misfits to balloon-popping art-rock visionaries.

column1: Like their 2013 self-titled EP
column2: Future Death’s debut full-length Special Victim favors unapologetically tinny
column3: distorted production that suggests it was captured on an iPhone Voice Memos app and replayed at internal-speaker-frying volume. (It was actually recorded at a former Dallas funeral home-turned-studio owned by indie super-producer John Congleton
column4: possibly from inside one of the leftover coffins.) But rather than flatten out their sound
column5: the limited sonic range mostly accentuates the increasingly sophisticated songcraft trying to poke through the surface squall.

column1: Much of that first EP was written by drummer Alton Jenkins and guitarist Bill Kenny prior to the arrival of bassist Jeremy Humphries and Craiglist-sourced vocalist Angie Kang—and yet
column2: the fact that Special Victim was a complete group effort only serves to amplify the band’s inherent contradictions. Future Death often sound like a band at war with itself
column3: exhibiting the form of a prog-rock act but the lo-fi ferocity of a garage-punk band
column4: as Kang’s beaming
column5: sugar-coated melodies are brutally pushed around by the convulsing arrangements like a pinball permanently caught between two bumpers. With the blissfully berserker opener “Riot Trains”
column6: the joyride abandon of “Basements”
column7: and cymbal-crashing fireworks of “Roman Devices
column8: ” Future Death effectively pair the in-the-red assault of Perfect Pussy with the see-saw
column9: guitar-scrambled sing-alongs of Marnie Stern
column10: rendering anarchy and ecstasy as one and the same.

column1: The pancaked production doesn’t always complement Future Death's songs; at times
column2: it renders the band’s boundless energy as an indistinct blur. (In particular
column3: the compulsively contorting “Speedweed” begs for greater clarity that would allow Jenkins’ oft-astonishing Zach Hill/Greg Saunier-inspired stickwork to propel the song
column4: rather than be reduced to background clatter that clashes with Kang’s chorus line.) But you can also hear the band pushing against their preset parameters to open up their sound into unchartered territory: “Junkhummer” begins as a shrill
column5: staccato math-punk pummel but
column6: two minutes in
column7: Jenkins trips up the beat and sends the song spinning off into a delirious extended coda
column8: with Kang’s voice smeared into the sort of eerie
column9: oscillating screams you’d hear from riders trapped on a malfunctioning amusement-park ride. In terms of confidence and scope (if not fidelty)
column10: Special Victim is an impressive step up from Future Death’s inaugural EP outing—but
column11: as their band name not too subtly suggests
column12:
the truly killer stuff could still be to come.

Drop into random sections of the two-and-a-half-hour long block that is 10 Years of Full Pupp and you're liable to hear very different sounds. Some will resemble 1970s psychedelia a la the Steve Miller Band; some the breastbeating passions of Depeche Mode; some New Age
column2: some disco with the flamboyance toned down and sequined unitards replaced by breathable hemp tees. Everything feels engineered for a kind of stoned wonder
column3: like something you might encounter during an evening show at the planetarium.

column1: Pigeonholed as ""space disco""—a term addressing the idea that this is music people might want to dance or relax to in equal measure—the truth of the music is
column2: as is often the case
column3: messier and less catchy. ""When I started playing out again around '93
column4: I didn't know any other way to do it than to mix it up
column5: Pupp's founder
column6: Prins Thomas
column7: once said. ""I was playing stuff from Bitches Brew together with early acid house and Beatles instrumentals."" That nobody vaudeville-hooked him off the stage with a cane suggests he was onto something
column8: and in the intervening years
column9: Pupp became known as a place less concerned with the orthodoxy of house and techno than with all the genres that surround them
column10: constellated like stars in playful
column11: inventive ways.

column1: 10 Years is divided into two mixes edited by Thomas
column2: half old material and half new
column3: blended together. For those who have been paying attention
column4: some of these names will be familiar: Thomas
column5: diskJokke
column6: Blackbelt Andersen
column7: Casiokids
column8: Øyvind Morken
column9: Andre Bratten—none of them besides Thomas having strong individual recognition but all friends at the party
column10: releasing a single or two a year and the occasional album. A few entries—Randaberg Ego Ensemble's ""You Can't Do It Right
column11: for example—are by artists who haven't put out anything since 2007
column12: and have only ever released with Full Pupp. The impression here is more of a community than a business
column13: of sly Norwegians twisting out their troubles in the dark.

column1: These mixes are good companions. The tempos are closer to walking pace than anything else
column2: and the occasional climax fizzes away like mist. It's slow compared to a lot of techno but rarely feels heavy
column3: in part because it spends a good amount of time laughing. Amidst the serious prog-rock intimations of the void are boing-boing noises and Copacabana beats to remind you that the first thing on their agenda is fun—as is the second and likely the third
column4: if they have not thrown the agenda in the trash by now or gotten it messy with cake. (Todd Terje
column5: who also tends to serve his epiphanies with a joke
column6: released his first singles with Full Pupp
column7: and is missed. Note also that ""pupp"" in Norwegian means ""tit
column8: though what ""full tit"" means is a question best enjoyed by the imagination.)

column1: ""If you play within the style of techno than you have to be really good
column2: because there's a lot of really good techno DJs
column3: Thomas once said in an interview
column4: adding
column5: ""I'm more like a piano bar entertainer."" Like Terje and several of his other peers
column6:
Thomas comes off like a goofball who uses self-deprecation to avoid how boring it can be to bear your soul and have others bear theirs to you. His sleight of hand is that he's more clever than he lets on.

column2: murder

column1: Early last year

column8: we can’t go on like this

column1: The singer receiving the email was Neige
column2: the leader of France’s Alcest and one of the key figures in carrying black metal past its atavistic beginnings. In Lantlôs

column6: sophisticated
column7: metal-barbed rock. But with Lantlôs
column8: he could still scream. Now they didn’t need him anymore. “I want to do vocals on this thing
column9: ” Siegenhort wrote to Neige of the next album. “I am so proud and I feel like my voice suits the music that I feel like it was nonsense giving it away for the sheer sake of friendship.”

column1: Given the genteel manner of Neige’s excommunication

In spite of the ostentatious production
column4: though

column1: On Melting Sun

column4: his mid-range croon ferried upward by a set of gentle effects. As with Alcest

column3: to some extent

column6: and the Body during the last few years. After all

not the end.

column1: In many ways

column1: In some ways

At the onset of 2006
column3: the sound collagist Leyland Kirby started a project called VVMT365 that entailed releasing one new track every day for an entire year. He finished with 602
column4: and this was in addition to three albums as V/Vm and one as the Caretaker. One of those albums
column5: V/Vm's The Death of Rave
column6: was 20 hours long. Calling Kirby's ethic ""prolific"" stretches the word too thin. Keeping up with his catalog is like watching the wheels of a car accelerate: It makes sense for a second
column7: but quickly becomes a blur.

column1: Kirby's music is cloudy and abstract
column2: but the concepts behind it are clear enough to put on a sandwich board. Rave
column3: part of which has just been remastered and released in physical formats
column4: is based on old techno tracks slowed down and blown out to the point of sounding like ambience. Admittedly
column5: I wouldn't have had any clue that this was the case without Kirby's direction
column6: which is to say that there are times when his concepts lead me into thinking about the music in a way that the music wouldn't on its own. (Kirby
column7: who seems like a thoughtful guy but never presents himself as academic
column8: would probably say that context is interesting but doesn't mean much unless you get some emotional use-value from the music itself.)

column1: Rave is hollow music
column2: with the weight and presence of an empty room. Most of its sounds don't start or stop so much as they bleed in from some unseen edge. Little changes
column3: and when change is present
column4: it's gradual. Even when something threatens to happen—and Rave is music of constant
column5: if subtle
column6: threat—Kirby holds back. In 2014
column7: the idea of music based on salvaging the decaying and half-remembered strains of anything feels ironically old-hat
column8: but in 2006
column9: it was new
column10: so Kirby was a pioneer
column11: as were Ariel Pink and Burial. Even as new releases
column12: their albums had the grain and anonymity of a relic
column13: like something made before being abandoned and left out to rust.

column1: It makes sense that Kirby has always favored longer projects with little discernible rise or fall: His music is more an environment than an experience. Even my favorite stand-alone albums of his—Eager to Tear Apart the Stars and the Caretaker's An Empty Bliss Beyond This World—are things I usually play on loop
column2: three and four times over. They recede into the background
column3: less the object you focus your eyes on than the tint of the glasses you're wearing.

column1: ""In the past
column2: I've done stuff and just thrown it out there
column3: like the 365 project
column4: but in the end it was too big
column5: Kirby told Resident Advisor in 2009. ""No one really noticed it."" His reformation has been marginal. Earlier this month
column6: he uploaded a new album to his Bandcamp page called We Drink to Forget the Coming Storm. The project was in part to celebrate his 40th birthday. It is three hours long.

column1: Kirby's albums as the Caretaker—much of which sounds like early romantic composition or old ballroom jazz trapped in amber and playing from some distant room—have always been more legible to me than his other projects
column2: and more heartfelt too. As the vandalistic aggression of V/Vm mellowed it left him with nothing but sentiment: tenderness
column3: beauty
column4: the saturation of a moment fully lived. Normally
column5: Caretaker music is based on loops of old 78 RPM records; We Drink
column6: which bears cosmic resemblance to that project
column7: is mostly piano
column8: digital strings and synthesizer choir—a less grainy sound than some of his others

column1: 1|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/20632/homepage_large.ab278ecc.jpg|We Drink to Forget the Coming Storm|32292.0|Leyland Kirby Presents V/Vm|['Rock'
column3: the sound collagist Leyland Kirby started a project called VVMT365 that entailed releasing one new track every day for an entire year. He finished with 602
column4: and this was in addition to three albums as V/Vm and one as the Caretaker. One of those albums

column6: was 20 hours long. Calling Kirby's ethic ""prolific"" stretches the word too thin. Keeping up with his catalog is like watching the wheels of a car accelerate: It makes sense for a second
column7: but quickly becomes a blur.

column1: Kirby's music is cloudy and abstract
column2: but the concepts behind it are clear enough to put on a sandwich board. Rave
column3: part of which has just been remastered and released in physical formats
column4: is based on old techno tracks slowed down and blown out to the point of sounding like ambience. Admittedly

column7: who seems like a thoughtful guy but never presents himself as academic
column8: would probably say that context is interesting but doesn't mean much unless you get some emotional use-value from the music itself.)

column1: Rave is hollow music
column2: with the weight and presence of an empty room. Most of its sounds don't start or stop so much as they bleed in from some unseen edge. Little changes
column3: and when change is present
column4: it's gradual. Even when something threatens to happen—and Rave is music of constant
column5: if subtle
column6: threat—Kirby holds back. In 2014
column7: the idea of music based on salvaging the decaying and half-remembered strains of anything feels ironically old-hat
column8: but in 2006
column9: it was new

column11: as were Ariel Pink and Burial. Even as new releases
column12: their albums had the grain and anonymity of a relic

column1: It makes sense that Kirby has always favored longer projects with little discernible rise or fall: His music is more an environment than an experience. column4: but in the end it was too big

The video for “They Don’t Know”
column3: the opening track off White Sea’s debut In Cold Blood
column4: features M83 singer/keyboardist Morgan Kibby and friends partaking in a river baptism
column5: swimming around in a slow motion riot of Greek statuesque bodies and billowing
column6: brightly colored sheets. Paired with the song’s soaring vocals
column7: tribal drums
column8: and clanging church bells
column9: the whole affair resembles “Circle of Life” performed by a Wilson Phillips-fronted Skid Row—a reminder that
column10: when it comes to indulgence
column11: Kibby just can’t help herself. “I really have a taste for drama
column12: ” she told Norwegian singer Susanne Sundfør. “Sometimes I have to remind myself to rein it back.”

column1: On In Cold Blood
column2: the theatrics are comparable in ambition to the music that Kibby's had a hand in as part of M83. It’s not as tastefully epic
column3: but Kibby deserves props for fully realizing the vision outlined on her debut EP
column4: 2010's This Frontier. She’s turned into a formidable synth sorceress; on ""Warsaw""
column5: Kibby claims she can travel in time and through walls

column9: Past Lives”
column10: she sustains a robust vibrato through her lower midrange all the way through her falsetto
column11: shooting skyward like a balloon set free.

column1: But there’s a fine line between power singing and over-singing
column2: and sometimes Kibby oversteps it with over-the-top embellishments: there's the corny vocalizing on “Warsaw”
column3: the squealing electric guitars in the background of “Ex-Pats”
column4: and a liberal sprinkling of fairy dust over the strings-and-piano ballad “Small December”. Granted
column5: this is music that embraces extremity—“NYC Loves You”'s soaring chorus
column6: thundering drum rolls
column7: and slide guitar
column8: is pure Journey in the best possible way—but Kibby’s dramatic flourishes and musical inspirations are
column9: at best
column10: an acquired taste.

column1: At any rate
column2: In Cold Blood’s '80s-redolent enthusiasm is an improvement on This Frontier’s tepid electro-pop
column3: and its strongest moments— ""Future Husbands""
column4: ""They Don't Know""
column5: and ""NYC Loves You""—find the balance between ""cheesy"" and ""cool"" by reining in the former impulses while staying thematically consistent so the instrumentation complements Kibby's voice rather than matching or overpowering it. Kibby's willingness to push boundaries makes In Cold Blood worth listening to—and
column6: who knows
column7:
maybe one day its songs will make for some great karaoke.

It’s difficult to imagine how Michigan duo Windy & Carl approach making music alone after 20 years of recording together. They have worked separately in that time—memorably
column2: in Windy’s case
column3: on the 2008 album I Hate People
column4: although even that bears an engineering credit for Carl on the sleeve. But here’s Tomorrow
column5: a debut solo work from Windy’s partner
column6: now shedding both the personable first-name-only approach and some familiar musical tropes from years past. It’s a small release
column7: highly limited in vinyl and CD form
column8: complemented by a download with extra tracks that push the runtime to around two hours. There’s nothing small about Hultgren’s intentions here
column9: which
column10: like most of Windy & Carl's work
column11: demonstrates his way of creating sound that simply engulfs
column12: albeit with a greater preference for fragility over his thickened drone sound.

column1: There are no vocals on Tomorrow
column2: and
column3: at times
column4: not much more than guitar lines echoing and repeating—sometimes getting drenched in reverb
column5: sometimes following a cleaner path. A dreamy
column6: druggy feel remains throughout
column7: sometimes recalling other artists who have forged an almost spiritual path into psychedelia. On “No Other”
column8: Hultgren’s in the same celestial sphere as Spacemen 3's “Come Down Softly to My Soul”
column9: spinning music so delicate it feels entirely lacking in weight. The gossamer touch doesn’t make this any less enveloping; it’s just a different type of absorption to the one Hultgren practices in Windy & Carl. There are touches of Cocteau Twin Robin Guthrie’s chorus-pedal blues in the earlier parts of Tomorrow
column10: coupled with a similarly drifty feel that dispenses with any earthiness.

column1: For Hultgren
column2: these changes come with a change of scenery—he moved in 2011 and began recording this album just after
column3: with a shift in musical direction mirroring the switch in landscape. There’s further movement internally within Tomorrow
column4: as he deviates into a country inflected lament (“In This Land”)
column5: a pile-up of clattering guitar loops (“Hidden”)
column6: and an ambient piece that reflects Brian Eno’s work in the field (“Found My Home”). The centerpiece
column7: “Transparency and Light”
column8: mostly draws on the latter discipline
column9: giving up 18 minutes of Hultgren’s soul in the form of a piece so still it’s like time stopped dead in its tracks around it. His best music often has that effect
column10: becoming akin to the way a moth gets transfixed by a light
column11: causing the world to just fall out of view for a while.

column1: The additional
column2: digital-only tracks on Tomorrow continue its theme
column3: although it’s notable how the instrumental take on the Windy & Carl song “I Walked Alone” doesn’t quite fit here. Most interesting is “Found My Home”
column4: presented in both six-minute and nineteen-minute versions
column5: a choice that offers insight into Hultgren’s thoughtful editing approach. Something notable about both the main body of Tomorrow and its additional material is the way he constantly fills the air with something
column6: even if it's just a quiet din clanging away in the background. There’s always a light bed of noise shimmering in the distance behind more prominent guitar lines
column7: or times when that foundation becomes the predominant force in a song (“Invisible”). It’s quiet music that’s strangely deafening in its way
column8:
never letting up in its constant tide of sound.

Plaid have been reliable fixtures in “intelligent dance music” since the genre first rose to prominence in the 1990s. Ever since their career-launching debut
column2: 1997's Not for Threes
column3: Andy Turner and Ed Handley have released carefully composed recordings full of warm tones
column4: friendly melodies
column5: and interesting technical sleights of hand; they've often found themselves situated between the genre's mercurial virtuosos (Aphex Twin
column6: Squarepusher) and a legion of hacky glitch engineers.

column1: Their latest
column2: Reachy Prints
column3: is full of new sounds. Handley and Turner are dedicated tech geeks who embody the genre’s commitment to exploring off-label uses of different gear in order to see if it makes any interesting noises. “Nafovanny” possesses an intriguingly detuned lead
column4: while “Tether” generates an edgy atmosphere from a fascinatingly ugly
column5: dissonant synth patch. The arrangements are familiar
column6: though
column7: and the album fits in comfortably with the rest of Plaid's discography
column8: defined by a relaxed-but-peppy energy and well-mannered songs that evolve smoothly with as few shocks as possible. (The exceptions to this rule appeared on 2011's Scintilli
column9: which featured some uncharacteristically aggressive and bumpy tracks and was all the more intriguing for it.)

column1: IDM has always been devoted to challenging approaches to experimentation
column2: so consistency isn’t necessarily a virtue in the genre; while Plaid's latest batch of material should satisfy those who have kept track of the duo's output thus far
column3: it doesn’t push many boundaries. Interestingly
column4: though
column5: the type of electronic music that Plaid makes—melodic enough to be accessible while retaining glitchy qualities—has
column6: over the last twenty years
column7: moved from the very fringes of the pop landscape to a little closer to pop's center. Specifically
column8: Aphex Twin's become a touchstone of sorts for rap producers
column9: and his influence has trickled up to the point where it’s not unusual for chart-placing songs to feature the stuttering rhythms
column10: tweaked-out synthesizers
column11: simulated vinyl brakes
column12: and other various controlled malfunctions that Aphex and
column13: by extension IDM’s known for.

column1: So as the pop world has tilted in a way that’s moved Handley and Turner’s music in a closer vicinity to the mainstream
column2: which suits them better. The qualities that previously constrained their music—specifically
column3: their melodic affability
column4: especially compared to the compellingly malicious vibe their contemporaries give off—now work in their favor
column5: but that also means that as an experimental electronic album
column6: Reachy Prints comes off as milquetoast.

column1: As a pop album
column2: though
column3: it sparkles: the oscillating beat
column4: flickering melodies
column5: and cooly dark atmosphere of opening track “OH” could have fit in nicely on Saint Heron
column6: last year’s Solange-curated compilation of alternative R&B. The pair have worked with vocalists regularly in the past
column7: and “Lilith
column8: ” their collaboration with Bjork on Not For Threes
column9: is not only one of the best songs of their early career but one of hers too. If Turner and Handley embraced their poppier tendencies
column10:
they could conceivably reach a new level of success—stranger things have happened.

""I don’t want [to] get too big
column2: said Noel Gallagher back in 1994
column3: squinting into the crystal ball a couple of months before the release of Oasis' debut album
column4: Definitely Maybe. ""I'd love to do Wembley Stadium
column5: but where do you go after that?"" At the time
column6: the guitarist and songwriter was talking to a fanzine and getting ready to play the lame
column7: 400-capacity East Wing venue in Brighton
column8: England. So not only was Noel looking forward to playing the UK's most storied venue—which was more than 200 times bigger than the East Wing—he was basically already over the fantasy. ""I didn’t think we’d get to this stage here for another two years
column9: and in a way it’s fuckin' pissed me off
column10: he continued
column11: talking about the tumbling hype that had followed their first single
column12: ""Supersonic""
column13: which debuted on the UK charts at #31 earlier that year. ""We were going to be this maverick outcast band from Manchester…we were going to shove it up them for two years and then we’d split up.""

column1: Oasis did eventually sell-out Wembley three times over at the end of 1997
column2: but by then they were already mired in bloated obsolescence—and they did split up
column3: but only after about 15 years of spinning their wheels. Noel knew his grandest rock'n'roll dreams could lead to trouble
column4: even when they were still merely outsized ambitions in '94. All of those dreams—the platinum plaques
column5: the American crossover
column6: the record-breaking festivals—came true in spectacular fashion over the course of the next three years
column7: and then Oasis really did have no idea where to go. They were terrible at being The Biggest Band in the World
column8: but as this 20th anniversary reissue of their first album makes sparklingly clear
column9: they were amazing at wanting to be The Biggest Band in the World.

column1: Definitely Maybe was made by five losers from the dreary Manchester suburb of Burnage
column2: a locale Noel has described as ""a little shitty town where fuck-all happens—it’s one pub and a chippie and a bookie and that’s it."" They were second-generation Irish working-class roustabouts who used their government assistance money to buy smokes
column3: drugs
column4: and pints on the weekend before heading back to their dead-end jobs. As Alex Niven writes in his well-rounded new 33 ⅓ book on Definitely Maybe
column5: the boys in Oasis were emblematic of the socio-economic demoralization brought on by England's every-man-for-himself Conservative policies of the 1980s and early '90s. As Noel once said
column6: ""Where I come from
column7: people didn't become rock stars. That happened to other people.""

column1: But Oasis were also a signpost of hope for an emerging new version of England that was finally mobilizing after being beaten down by the Thatcher years. Against this backdrop
column2: the Gallagher brothers and company emerged: All the anger and nihilism of a go-nowhere existence channeled through Noel's blaring guitar tones and brash
column3: drugged-up lyrics
column4: along with Liam's attack-dog snarl. Definitely Maybe is the sound of people who feel like they need to scream to be heard—and even then
column5: the chances of anyone actually listening seems depressingly unlikely.

column1: And yet
column2: not wholly impossible. The album's first lines are: ""Live my life in the city
column3: there's no easy way out."" Pretty bleak. But that song is called ""Rock 'N' Roll Star""
column4: and it's about the possibility of escape via substances
column5: or standing on a stage in front of a dozen people (as Oasis did many times in the early years)
column6: or your own head. ""In my mind my dreams are real
column7: sings Liam
column8: and who can argue with that? Dreams play a big role on Definitely Maybe and its accompanying B-sides—all of which are collected in this three-disc re-release
column9: along with many live performances and demos from the period—though they often read as both wistful and demanding
column10: owing to the one-in-a-billion ying-yang chemistry between Noel's words and Liam's delivery. On paper
column11: Noel's lyrics often read as bittersweet; then 27
column12: he was beginning to look at his youth as a lost era. But placed in 22-year-old Liam's mouth
column13: ""Rock 'N' Roll Star"" transforms from a flight of fancy into something like an inevitability. Yes: This man sounds like Lennon and Lydon's sneering son. Yes: He will stop at nothing until these wanting words become physical fact. Yes: Here is your rock 'n' roll star
column14: because there isn't anything else for him to be.

column1: The contentiousness between the brothers fueled Oasis' best moments
column2: and
column3: early on at least
column4: both seemed to understand the situation—even if they couldn't stand each other. Referring to Noel in an interview from '94
column5: Liam said
column6: in no uncertain terms: ""That's why we'll be the best band in the world—because I fuckin' hate that twat there."" Like vintage Oasis itself
column7: Liam embodied just enough classic rock
column8: just enough punk
column9: and just enough ""I'll spit in your fucking eye"" to make his unfiltered id stick. Usually
column10: this type of rock persona is associated with more combustible or aggressive music
column11: but Noel tempered the abrasiveness with a trace of melancholy or a fuzzed-up bubblegum melody
column12: as on career highs like ""Live Forever"" and ""Slide Away"". Then
column13: now
column14: and forever
column15: Liam is the Definitely and Noel is the Maybe.

column1: I couldn't express any of this when I first saw Liam's strobed face on MTV in the ""Live Forever"" video as a 13-year-old middle-class kid from Long Island
column2: but I got my mom to drive me to Nobody Beats the Wiz to buy the CD all the same. At that time
column3: I thought Axl Rose was an insane genius and Kurt Cobain—who died six days after the release of ""Supersonic""—was an inscrutable weirdo. And in America
column4: Oasis were practically an underground band; they were amazingly cool
column5: and I felt cooler for liking them. They were blatantly inspired by all of the canonical rock bands I knew
column6: but they possessed the feeling of now. Their version of infinity guitars and attitude made me feel invincible
column7: the same sensation I got a few years later while getting into hip-hop—another working-class-bred artform known to utilize the past
column8: via sampling and respun rhymes
column9: to accentuate the present. (""Never be afraid of the obvious
column10: Noel once said
column11: ""because it's all been done before."") Oasis started from the very bottom and
column12: from that very first note
column13: it was obvious where they were going next.

column1: But just as Oasis' undesirable upbringing incited them to lash out through feedback and distortion
column2: you could argue that it stunted their continued artistic existence. Middle-class art-schooler Damon Albarn may have lost the popular vote during Blur's notorious mid-90s battle with Oasis
column3: but with partial thanks to a relatively comfortable adolescence and education
column4: he's clearly won the war
column5: remaining relevant and inquisitive to this day. Oasis' woeful decline
column6: meanwhile
column7: makes a specific line from ""Shakermaker"" sound a bit heartbreaking in hindsight: ""I'd like to be somebody else and not know where I've been."" Eventually
column8: the Gallaghers turned into the same rich dicks they were trying to usurp on Definitely Maybe—a sad vengeance. But on the way up
column9:
they marked millions. Maybe that should be enough.

As footwork’s gained a certain cachet of “cool” over the past handful of years—swelling gradually from regional curiosity to global movement—there’s been a refreshing lack of “cool” surrounding Traxman. It’s not the fact that he’s been in the game longer than just about anybody: he practically wrote the rulebook
column2: DJing and producing over three sprawling decades of mutations that Chicago house’s DNA underwent
column3: gradually percolating into juke and abstracting into footwork and blurring the lines between all of the above. There’s a cheeky-yet-deadly earnest wink to much of his work
column4: the kind that sits parallel to irony but couldn’t be further from it; in a sphere that rewards overt humor—see DJ Rashad and Freshmoon’s doofily hysterical “Everybody”
column5: built around a meme from the TV show ""Intervention""
column6: or snarky DJ Slugo numbers like “Wouldn’t You Like To Be A Hoe Too”—Traxman’s sense of humor has persistently tended towards kitsch. He’s not into the long sell
column7: since people are supposed to stay dancing while listening to this stuff
column8: remember?

column1: The first volume of Da Mind Of Traxman
column2: his 2012 Planet Mu debut and arguably the first great solo footwork full-length
column3: reveled in these kinds of tenderly shlocky moves
column4: forgoing esotericism for pointedly ham-fisted and ultimately democratic gestures—ideologically
column5: the precocious lovechild of Dilla’s samplemania and 2 Chainz’ knee-slappy dad punchlines. For the owner of one of Chicago’s most renowned record collections
column6: encyclopedic and meticulously organized
column7: Traxman’s never been one for going over his audience’s heads
column8: even when shit gets weird. That would be inefficient
column9: and besides
column10: he can do weird all by himself; that album’s most surreal moment
column11: “Let There Be Rockkkkk”
column12: was built from a cock-in-hand AC/DC sample.

column1: Da Mind Of Traxman Vol. 2 is trimmer and more muscular
column2: even as it maintains his signature playfulness. Where its predecessor threw the whole fridge in the blender and delighted in making his friends drink it
column3: here Traxman seems interested in doing more with less
column4: probing the limits of each individual component
column5: experimenting with song structure. Samples misbehave and are duly punished
column6: though there’s an obvious tenderness with which they’re handled even as he brutalizes them. Sticky
column7: honey-coated bursts of Rhodes and horns and xylophones over-eagerly trip on each other
column8: threaten to fall out of sync
column9: then jump back in line on opening track “Time Slip”. “Let It Roll Geto” is an ungodly mash of chopped “Sunglasses At Night”-y synth arpeggios and ghostly
column10: gargled mermaid-soul
column11: all of which gets shoved around by stuttering ghetto-house vocal tics
column12: exponentially accelerating into barked orders like a long-lost Tae-Bo video where Billy Blanks tries PCP.

column1: Footwork cuts typically end up either ""garish"" or ""great""
column2: with very little room in between those two poles—and there’s certainly a bit of the former here too. “Bubbles” aims for restraint but grows mind-numbingly repetitive
column3: and not in the transcendent
column4: mantra-like sense of footwork and juke at its most effective (like
column5: say
column7: hypnotizing in its deceptive simplicity). “Tha Edge Of Panic” starts off intriguingly enough
column8: a gracefully gut-wrenching sequel of sorts to “Let There Be Rockkkkk”
column9: but unravels into brutal hysteria
column10: a nightmare of roid-rage grindcore. That’s the tax for taking these kinds of try-anything-once risks
column11: one that’s fairly inevitable in an 18-track album of any sort
column12: but especially with footwork. By their nature
column13: footwork tracks tend to exist in and of themselves
column14: specific tools in a set moreso than cogs in a unified machine; in heavy doses
column15: they can overwhelm a casual listening session (namely
column16: while multi-tasking and sober).

column1: All the same
column2: continuing to classify footwork as a primarily functional art form in 2014 presents something of a paradox. At its core
column3: the claim rings true
column4: and always will—above all else
column5: this is music for dancers who want to be challenged and DJs eager to oblige—but it can also be limiting
column6: particularly taking into account the past four or so years of full-length releases that have aimed not to alter the genre
column7: but to let it transcend its intended context for a bit. It begs the question: what exactly does a great footwork album—a whole greater than the sum of its parts—entail
column8: if it’s even possible? Double Cup
column9: the late DJ Rashad’s 2013 magnum opus
column10: is proof enough that it is; at the very least
column11: it’s the closest a footwork full-length has gotten to perfection. Da Mind Of Traxman Vol. 2
column12: for the most part
column13: is a stellar collection of songs—playful
column14: ballsy
column15:
informed by the past but living very much in the present—but they’re songs that relate more as cousins than as siblings.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20606/homepage_large.85c259af.jpg|Faces|30111.0|Mac Miller|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2014-05-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:31.855477|"

On last year’s Watching Movies with the Sound Off
column2: Mac Miller earned an elusive measure of cachet among rap diehards by burrowing into his record collection and trying on the irreverent frenzy of Odd Future
column3: the offbeat whimsy of MF Doom
column4: and the gonzo electronics of the Brainfeeder squad. He ended up with the best work of his young career
column5: a satisfying leap from the bushy-tailed
column6: eager-to-please kid brother raps of his early work towards tighter rhymes fixated in a knottier headspace.

column1: Mac has since worked tirelessly to prove Watching Movies’ gains were no fluke
column2: showcasing his range on a series of off-the-cuff side projects: Delusional Thomas featured an impishly pitched-up Mac cutting loose on a half-hour mixtape of gutbucket murder raps
column3: while Live from Space documented the plush sonics of Miller’s summer 2013 Space Migration Tour
column4: which fleshed out Watching Movies’ spacier cuts with the help of Syd tha Kid and Matt Martians’ project the Internet. Odd Future associate Vince Staples’ Stolen Youth featured Mac in the producer’s chair unfurling hypnotic soundscapes under his Larry Fisherman pseudonym.

column1: Mac Miller’s most ambitious post-Watching Movies project arrived in the form of a Mother’s Day mixtape called Faces
column2: which advances on his last LP's heady sprawl with a palette stretching from rainy day introspection to playful wordplay exercises. Where Watching Movies was equally concerned with refining his writing skills and presenting a personality you wouldn’t mind sparking up a j with
column3: this mixtape prizes frankness over curation. On cuts like opener “Inside Outside” and “Here We Go”
column4: the latter in which Mac pridefully scans his growing empire and notes that he “did it all without a Drake feature”
column5: the joy is infectious.

column1: Mac gets downcast for the midsection body shot combo of “Happy Birthday”
column2: “Wedding”
column3: and “Funeral”
column4: a passage that moves seamlessly from excitement to fear and uncertainty (“Do you ever reach to touch her
column5: but there’s nothing there?/ Do you tell her that you love her
column6: but she doesn’t care?”) into despair (“Doing drugs is just a war with boredom
column7: but they’re sure to get me”). Faces goes where Watching Movies wouldn’t
column8: picking over the fallout from a teen rap sensation suddenly becoming nouveau riche.

column1: Much of the time
column2: that means picking apart Mac’s infatuation with drugs. Hard partying bleeds into unexpected corners of the proceedings
column3: from the debit card covered in “snowflakes” on “Friends” to the cautionary PCP comedown tale of “Angel Dust”. Miller catalogues reckless substance use like a news anchor would a traffic jam: he matter-of-factly calls himself a “drug absorbent endorphin addict” with a “drug habit like Philip Hoffman” on “What Do You Do?”
column4: and even “Therapy”’s lightweight account of a night out with a girl contains a bout of self-medication. “Malibu” warns that “The good times can be a trap” and toys with the idea of checking into rehab before resolving to just save the remainder of the coke for another day. There's a troubling sense that Mac is tiptoeing down a well-lit path toward self-destruction and that he either feels too helpless or else too enrapt to change course
column5: but if Faces’ good-times-are-killing-me terrors seem overbearing
column6: they’re often offset by a sense that music is his salvation.

column1: On the technical end
column2: Faces is Mac Miller’s high watermark. The wordplay is limber and odd
column3: as flows shift mid-verse and imbue otherwise nonsensical turns of phrase with jerky life. It’s enough to make unrepentantly dark lines lively. When “Polo Jeans” opens with “I give no fucks when I go nuts cause I smoke dust
column4: overdosed on the sofa
column5: dead/ Woke up from the coma
column6: pulled up in a Škoda
column7: smoked
column8: went back to bed” you’re more likely to run it back for the deft internal rhymes than the plot point about a potential overdose.

column1: Miller’s finally able to play ball with his esteemed rap friends
column2: too; where he once played outfield for guys like Earl Sweatshirt and Staples
column3: here he’s matching them bar for bar. By the time Rick Ross shows up for verse three of “Insomniak”
column4: Mac’s already run the beat ragged. Miller’s advances as a self-taught auteur also extend to production: he crafted the majority of the beats here
column5: and he’s arrived at an unfussed
column6: sample-based melodicism that both harkens back to the jazzy boom bap of the 75 Ark and Fondle ‘Em Records era and stays the hell out of the way of the raps.

column1: Faces finds Mac Miller embracing a typical 2010s rapper trope: the exploratory between-album mixtape. Its 24 tracks run nearly an hour and a half
column2: each restlessly tinkering with his songwriting and production talents. The sprawl gives Faces a directionless feel
column3: so it’s doubtful you’ll ever play it all in one sitting—regardless
column4: the kid’s turning out the best work of his career
column5: transforming adversity and discouragement into intriguing art. It might seem daunting
column6: drug-crazed and unwieldy at the outset
column7: but given the proper time and patience
column8: the mixtape proves to be Mac’s most consistently honest and personal work to date. Early on “Here We Go” advises that he “ain’t little Malcolm with the baby face” anymore
column9: and whatever memory of that goofy
column10: affable kid remains
column11:
Faces is its slow and methodical death and dismemberment.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20560/homepage_large.aa81370a.jpg|The Sleeping Beauties: A Collection of Early and Unreleased Works|32298.0|Vangelis Katsoulis|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Into the Light']|2014-05-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:32.442330|"

Not to be conflated with fellow Greek countryman Evangelos Odysseas Papathanassiou
column2: whose “Chariots of Fire” theme has become ubiquitous Muzak the world over
column3: this particular Vangelis is also a composer of dulcet tones
column4: yet one whose body of work has hovered just under the radar outside of his native country since the 1980s. Discogs lists nine studio albums credited to Katsoulis
column5: which span from 1986’s Minimal Suite to his most recent
column6: 2011’s Pictures from Inside.

column1: But the first time most 21st century listeners might have heard Katsoulis was on the fascinating compilation Into The Light: A Journey Into Greek Electronic Music
column2: Classics & Rarities
column3: which was released less than two years ago and now fetches ludicrous sums online. That comp introduced Greece’s fertile
column4: if unheralded music
column5: scene and heretofore-unknown artists like George Theodorakis and Costas Charitodiplomenos
column6: all of whom blur the lines between ambient
column7: avant garde electronic composition
column8: and New Age drifts in a heady manner. While Vangelis’ contribution didn’t quite break the two-minute mark
column9: it showed an intriguing voice at work.

column1: All three aforementioned genres appear in Katsoulis' oeuvre
column2: and this handy introduction to his work shows this composer’s wide range. The track included on that comp
column3: ""Improvisation"" opens side two of this album; it's a dizzying mix of crisp percussion
column4: pillowy synth chords
column5: and finely minced “choir” presets that could easily be mistaken for something off of R Plus Seven. The track suggests that what might have scanned as New Age softness back in the '80s now offers up a glimpse into the 21st-century avant-garde.

column1: The eleven tracks compiled here are ephemeral and lovely
column2: if not always memorable. Four of them first appeared on his 1987 album The Slipping Beauty (the title a play on Tchaikovsky’s “The Sleeping Beauty”) and the title track reveals the kind of shimmering poly-rhythmic tones that bring to mind the likes of Philip Glass. Yet
column3: on “Earth Beat”
column4: heavy drums mix with featherweight keys and a foreboding synth note that sounds like the ominous opening bit of Michael Jackson’s “Beat It.” There’s flute trills on “The Eternal Return”
column5: mixed into a bass glissade
column6: screwed-down vocal growls and hand drums that give the track a strange feel of being both airy and dark. The electric bass on “Longing” sounds like Katsoulis is doing his best overly-busy-solo-Sting impression
column7: but the violin melody remains evocative.

column1: In the composer’s notes
column2: Katsoulis writes that his work is closely related to the processes of time
column3: and one particular aspect fascinates him most of all: “Beauty
column4: which being subject to decay
column5: has such a fleeting nature.” The most intriguing moments on The Sleeping Beauties are those that both comment on time and also take their time revealing their quirks and charms. The nearly ten-minute “Enigma” is an odd mix of what might otherwise scan as interstitial music on an afternoon talk show
column6: now dilated into long form modern composition.

column1: The two pieces that close the set also hover in that expanded space. The previously unreleased “Imago”
column2: from 2012
column3: builds from a rippling keyboard line that is a sonic speedball
column4: at once mimicking the brightness of steel drums and the pensive moments of an '80s cop show. Soprano saxophone
column5: violin
column6: guitars
column7: keyboard and percussion comprise “Epilogue”
column8: each element cycling as new timbres are introduced. It’s an evocative piece
column9: one that showcases the type of minimalism that informs not just Steve Reich pieces but also waiting room music
column10:
each in its own manner soundtracking the passage of time.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20555/homepage_large.a0c0cea3.jpg|Keine Oase in Sicht|32269.0|Datashock|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dekorder']|2014-05-22 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:32.961513|"

Many bands call themselves “collectives
column2: ” but few make music that actually sounds communal and leaderless. In those rare cases
column3: individual voices converge into shared vision
column4: but strands in the resulting web stay distinct rather than blurring into anonymity: think of the natural waves of Japan’s Taj Mahal Travellers
column5: the fuzzy trips of Germany’s Amon Düül
column6: the free-flowing rock of Sweden’s
column7: +Gr%C3%A4s+Och+Stenar"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">Träd
column8: Gräs Och Stenar
column9: or the rattling jams of New York’s No-Neck Blues Band.

column1: It might be premature to rank German collective Datashock among those legends; even their own label has called them “young punks pretending to be old hippies.” But their work over the past decade suggests they could join that echelon. They frequently catch magic moments of emergence
column2: as a patient assemblage of exploratory sounds grows into something transcendent. They’ll wander around with their heads pointed skyward until at some point – often one you don’t notice until they’ve already passed it – they shift into a higher gear.

column1: Moments like that abound on Keine Oase in Sicht (German for “No Oasis in Sight”)
column2: Datashock's best effort to date. There are times when it feels like they’re toying with their own powers
column3: meditating so long you start to think they’ll never uncover an epiphany—and
column4: inevitably
column5: a climax arrives to justify the group’s long mountain climb. The album opens with the longest climb
column6: the 14-minute “Mudschahidin der Liebe”
column7: whose oscillating organ tones and rave-up crescendo resemble a stretched-out Spiritualized. “Rubinregen aus der spirituellen Sphäre” waltzes stonedly to a peak in the vein of Bardo Pond or Eternal Tapestry
column8: and “Her mit dem Kelch
column9: (das) hier muss es sein” is practically funk—James Chance reimagined as a hippie. Even something as gaseous as “Desert Lustgerte
column10: Goldnougat Gobi” ends in a miniature flash of rolling beat that retroactively reveals direction in the sounds that led to it.

column1: Compared to other groups who deal in this kind of slow-burning ascension
column2: Datashock are rarely noisy or cacophonous. Instrumental music that’s largely improvised has the tendency to become clutttered
column3: but Datashock express profundity within a clean
column4: spacious sound. Every element is easily legible
column5: but there’s still a dense atmosphere throughout
column6: borne of keen communication and palpable dedication to a common cause.

column1: Much of Keine Oase in Sicht is mellow and soothing
column2: but it’s never boring. Such accessibility could make Datashock the underground avant collective for people that like overground psychedelic rock—stranger things have happened—but external validation is
column3: most likely
column4: low on Datashock’s list of priorities. When you’re banded together toward a greater vision
column5:
the periphery isn't a big deal.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20572/homepage_large.a8877cbb.jpg|Hyperdub 10.1|0.0|Various Artists|[]|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2014-05-21 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:33.639699|"

In 2003
column2: writer Steve Goodman
column3: now known to keyed-in music nerds as the producer Kode9
column4: was interviewing Kevin Martin
column5: the mastermind behind the bombed-out dub project the Bug
column6: for dance publication XLR8R. The conversation turned to dubstep
column7: the roots of which were just starting to take hold in London; Martin heard a track of Goodman’s
column8: who was just then cutting his teeth as a producer
column9: and he encouraged him to start a label to release it
column10: promising to help find a distributor. Less than a year later came HYP001
column11: “Sign of the Dub” b/w “Stalker”
column12: a collaborative release between Kode9 and UK rapper Spaceape (then credited as Daddy Gee).

column1: For Hyperdub’s first four years
column2: the label moved carefully when it came to releases. Most of their output from 2004–2006 was credited to Goodman and Spaceape
column3: including the duo’s debut LP Memories of the Future
column4: but they also worked with some guy named William Bevan
column5: whose self-titled debut LP as Burial came in 2006
column6: a year after Goodman put out the project’s wobbly first 12“
column7: South London Boroughs. Burial was a modest record that initially attracted curiosity more than it did accolades
column8: but in 2007 Bevan returned with the excellent Ghost Hardware 12” and the instant classic Untrue
column9: a record that came to define dubstep for legions of new listeners seven years before Merriam Webster decided to define it themselves.

column1: One of the most influential electronic records  in recent memory
column2: Untrue cemented Bevan as one of the decade’s most vital producers and introduced dubstep (more as a concept
column3: less as a sound) to a much wider audience. So you can imagine what its success did for Hyperdub. A brief glance at the label’s chronological catalog resembles a dam about to burst
column4: and Untrue was the low frequency that shook the firmament to the point of collapse. In 2008 came releases from up-and-coming names that
column5: six years later
column6: are familiar to anyone in the know: bass music basket case Zomby
column7: abstracted pop outfit Darkstar (who at that point were working with a more explicitly dance-focused sound)
column8: dubstep-gone-freestyle queen Ikonika. Martin’s lover’s rock-focused King Midas Sound project even put out their first release for the label that year.

column1: Hyperdub marked their fifth anniversary in 2009
column2: but despite a half-decade of existence
column3: the label’s creative surge had kicked into high gear only two years previous. So the excellent 5 Years of Hyperdub was as much an overview of where Hyperdub had been as it was a chance to draw on the increased exposure electronic music was receiving and define something approaching a “scene.” Ace cuts from Los Angeles hip-hop auteur Flying Lotus
column4: Dutch dance producer Martyn
column5: and dub-as-fuck mad scientist Mala appeared alongside catalog highlights from label regulars Kode9
column6: LV
column7: and yes
column8: Burial.

column1: 5 Years of Hyperdub was the culmination of a series of five 12"" releases collecting label highlights—5.1
column3: you get the idea—and the expanded approach Hyperdub’s taken to that concept for their 10-year anniversary is indicative of how quickly Goodman’s label has grown
column4: both in size and influence. 10.1 is a two-CD set—the first in the series
column5: no less—with one disc collecting tracks from the label’s last five years and one with entirely new material. Each compilation will have a theme
column6: and 10.1 turns its focus towards dancefloor-centered cuts
column7: so those waiting for a collection of Hyperdub’s stranger entries might have to wait a little longer.

column1: That said
column2: 10.1 is more proof that Hyperdub can’t help but embrace left-of-center even as it focuses on club fare. This is far from a bad thing: Hyperdub’s released some of the most appealingly odd and oddly prescient electronic music of the last 15 years
column3: and the glaring omissions from this volume’s disc of catalog cuts—Terror Danjah’s fiery grime tune “Acid” from 2010
column4: Ossie’s bubbly UK Funky cut “Set the Tone” from 2011
column5: the jagged piano-house of Laurel Halo’s “Throw”
column6: from last year's Behind the Green Door EP—only serve to highlight the wealth of material the label has released.

column1: Dance music label comps serve a dual purpose: 1) provide an accessible way for non-collectors to obtain material that might’ve received limited release; 2) offer labels a way to define their legacy or current position in the music landscape. 10.1 fulfills the first function simply by existing
column2: and effectively flips two middle fingers towards the second. One of the most intriguing elements of Hyperdub’s output is its sheer unpredictability and refusal of easy categorization. The closest thing to dubstep proper on the first disc is Burial and Spaceape’s Burial cut “Spaceape”
column3: an obvious nod to Hyperdub’s humble beginnings; from there
column4: we’re hit with variations on the breezy skip of Funky (Funkystepz’s “Hurricane Riddim”
column5: Ill Blu’s “Clapper”)
column6: 8-bit fantasias (Ikonika’s “Idiot”
column7: Walton’s “Aggy”)
column8: low-slung hip-hop (Mark Pritchard and Om’mas Keith’s “Wind It Up”)
column9: and effervescent grime (Kode9’s “Xingfu Lu”).

column1: In addition to shining a light on the difficulty of categorizing Hyperdub
column2: the old-stuff collection is further proof that the label’s vision is always trained forward. Appearances from regulars Ikonika and Cooly G are a reminder that
column3: along with Laurel Halo and Canadian techno-pop architect Jessy Lanza
column4: Hyperdub’s been one of the few of-the-moment dance labels to consistently showcase female artists. Stylistically
column5: they’ve also found themselves ahead of the curve: Morgan Zarate’s as-of-yet-underappreciated “Hookid”
column6: from 2011
column7: is a tangled sigh of staircase tones
column8: phased-out bass hits
column9: and cascading synths ripped from Southern U.S. hip-hop. At the time
column10: it was a curiosity; in 2014
column11: it sounds like a trap precedent
column12: if that sound’s basic elements were scrambled in a blender and poured all over some poor sap’s kitchen counter.

column1: The new-stuff disc offers few hints as to where the label is headed next
column2: which is unsurprising
column3: but the variety on display is only matched by the quality of the tunes themselves. Detroit techno fiend Kyle Hall’s “Girl U So Strong” builds and breaks with wheezing tones and backbeats
column4: a throaty diva shout occasionally popping up to offer an anchor; Zarate returns with the hard-hitting “Kaytsu”
column5: a track even more explicitly trap than the genre-predicting “Hookid”
column6: while the relatively quiet producer Kuedo (whose 2011 LP Severant still stands as an overlooked gem) returns with a track dubbed after his namesake and sporting his signature Vangelis-meets-Big Tymers style of aural hypnotism. Following the explicit reggae of his Essential Mix from last year
column7: Mala delivers one of his meanest anthems to date with the stomping “Expected”
column8: while Japanese producer and Hyperdub mainstay Quarta330 closes out the disc with the hyper-colorful “Hanabi”.

column1: The “what’s to come” section takes up the back half of 10.1’s fresh-jams collection
column2: in the form of a stretch of footwork primarily from the Teklife crew. Footwork continues to gain a greater presence in the electronic world
column3: aided by fellow UK label Planet Mu’s scene-surveying Bangs & Works compilations and cemented by last year’s classic LP from the late DJ Rashad
column4: Double Cup. Earlier this year
column5: Goodman told The Japan Times that he was drawn to getting involved with the genre by way of Planet Mu founder Mike Paradinas: “Mike said to me
column6: ‘Go on
column7: release this stuff
column8: because everyone thinks I’m crazy.’”

column1: Paradinas had a point—footwork in its rawest form can be grating
column2: and the stretch of brown-sound bass hits and repetitive vocal samples that mark the back half of the first disc of 10.1 may lead to a few headaches. But Hyperdub’s embrace of the genre was perfectly timed
column3: and the cuts presented here showcase a scene that is further mutating and innovating as it gains more widespread attention. Taso & Djunya’s “Only the Strong Survive” pairs footwork’s intense focus with a starry-eyed sense of wonder
column4: DJ Spinn“’s ”All My Teklife“ features synths that glisten so bright they threaten to overpower everything else around them
column5: and DJ Earl’s ”I’m Gonna Get You"" hammers its titular phrase home to the point of aggravation until the sample drops out with a sense of relief before revving up all over again.

column1: Rashad appears posthumously on both discs of 10.1: along with DJ Taye
column2: he had a hand in DJ Earl’s other cut on the new disc
column3: the typically intense “Bombaklot”
column4: and Rashad and Gant-Man further explore Double Cup’s acid techno flirtations on the enjoyable “Acid Life”. He also closes out the disc of catalog highlights—the comp was announced well before Rashad’s sudden and tragic death last month
column5: so this is an unusual occurrence of timing above all else—with the epochal “Let It Go”. A titanic track that could be considered footwork’s own “Strings of Life”
column6: “Let It Go” has a classic
column7: immovable sound
column8: as a lone drum machine kicks things off before meeting up with the endlessly
column9: blissfully repeated vocal sample. Some warped strings enter
column10: and for a second it seems like things are off—“Something doesn’t sound right” is
column11: granted
column12: an understandable reaction to most footwork—but then the vocal sample completes itself with a diva’s cry
column13: “Baaa-by/ Bayyyyyy-beeeeee”
column14: that hits like a gut-punch.

column1: “Let It Go” was released on March 18
column3: as part of Rashad’s excellent Rollin’ EP for Hyperdub; a year
column4: one month
column5: and eight days later
column6: he was found dead at his home in Chicago’s West Side. Before his death
column7: I must have personally listened to “Let It Go” at least eight or nine times a week
column8: and every time I put it on
column9: it took me places that only the most impressionistically beautiful pieces of music can go. I’ve listened to it while feeling sad
column10: happy
column11: unsure
column12: frustrated
column13: in love
column14: out of place—basically
column15: it’s music I put on when I want to feel something. After Rashad’s death
column16: the urge to latch onto the track’s more melancholy aspects is there
column17: but every time I reach for “Let It Go”
column18: the flood of emotions remains rich and complex. Rashad touched a lot of people with his visionary
column19: melodic approach to footwork
column20: and the dance community has only begun feeling the effects of his legacy; amidst the incredible collection of tunes on 10.1
column21: “Let It Go” is proof that
column22: even in the ever-changing world of electronic music
column23:
it’s possible to create something that sounds absolutely timeless.

"|19356.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/19356-hyperdub-101/|8.5|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/20567/homepage_large.3a9d7a66.jpg|American Football|76.0|American Football|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|1.0|['Polyvinyl']|2014-05-21 00:00:00|1999|2016-06-11 16:37:34.246181|"

“Honestly I can’t remember all my teenage feelings and their meanings.” Any list of Great Moments in Emo Lyricism would be incomplete without this curious Mike Kinsella-sung line during “Honestly?”
column2: the third track from American Football’s only album
column3: released in 1999. But really...honestly? We are
column4: after all
column5: talking about a genre assumed to be in constant contact with the feelings of teendom—but the next line gives more context: “They seem too/ See-through/ To be true.” Rather than someone cutting themselves off from or invalidating their own teenage feelings
column6: Kinsella’s just outside that time frame trying to figure out how the emotions and music that moved him during his formative years figure into his current life. That’s why
column7: as self-identifying emo bands are making music that’s more mature
column8: refined
column9: and exploratory than anything that came before it
column10: American Football is currently the most influential album in the genre.

column1: This deluxe reissue of American Football benefits from unusually good timing—and unlike most solemnly revered anniversary sets
column2: this isn’t a mobilization of fan dollars after countless inclusions in Best Of Decade lists
column3: and it's not a case of “You had to be there” nostalgia
column4: either. The raw 4-track demos
column5: generous liner notes (written by guitarist Steve Holmes)
column6: and candid photographs are meant to welcome the people who weren’t “there” back in 1999
column7: a grouping that includes pretty much everybody at this point. Still
column8: the album's reach in 2014 is estimable: American Football recently sold out an entire weekend at Webster Hall in New York in the matter of minutes—each night they'll play to a crowd ten times bigger than any they saw during their entire existence.

column1: Personally
column2: it took me damn near a decade to find and appreciate American Football
column3: and looking back
column4: it's easy to understand why it didn’t have made an instantaneous or seismic impact upon its release. After the implosion of Cap’n Jazz
column5: Mike’s brother Tim was the more public
column6: combative and divisive party; meanwhile
column7: the Promise Ring had just released Very Emergency  months prior
column8: one of emo's preliminary pushes towards the center. Consequently
column9: American Football came together quickly
column10: stirred up a decent amount of anticipation from a formative EP (its exclusion is the only disappointment the reissue provides)
column11: and disbanded almost immediately after the release of the LP.

column1: Of course
column2: hardcore fans claim plenty of one-off collectors’ items as landmarks
column3: and in retrospect
column4: American Football’s existence as something of a cul de sac rather than a connection to Kinsella’s later work as Owen or Owls further serves to show what a unique record it is. American Football’s greatest innovation was successfully removing any trace of punk rock while still functioning within the genre. This was a bold maneuver
column5: since the genre's hardcore roots were about the only thing that gave its practicioners even the slightest bit of credibility. American Football weren’t the only ones headed in new directions (see: the Appleseed Cast)
column6: but whatever you think “punk rock” means
column7: they got rid of it on American Football—there’s no confrontation
column8: almost no distortion
column9: no power chords
column10: and none of the verse/chorus structure that was maintained even when emo became virtually synonymous with alt-rock.

column1: In actuality
column2: American Football is one of the more subtle post-rock records of its time—a variation on what the Sea and Cake and Gastr Del Sol were doing a few hours north in Chicago
column3: but crucially operating from the heart rather than the brain. Only “Honestly?” bears some remnant of proper “rock” music
column4: its main riff a twang-free rendering of “Rebel Rebel”. The cascading coda of “Stay Home” alludes to Slowdive's Pygmalion
column5: while “The Summer Ends” recasts the pastoral free-form
column6: flowing hymnals of late Talk Talk as a swooning mash note.

column1: In the reissue's liner notes
column2: Holmes makes numerous mentions of the band emulating Steve Reich and Miles Davis—typical namedrops for people in their early 20s who want to make it clear how seriously they’re taking music these days. There is trumpet on the record
column3: courtesy of drummer Steve Lamos
column4: and no one will mistake its sounds for anything the Prince of Darkness ever conjured. But Lamos’ amateur ingenuity perfectly suits the album's informality. The jarring blue note that introduces “The Summer Ends” sounds like a mistake at first
column5: but by playing it twice the wrong note becomes the right note; it's a Choose Your Own Adventure Breakup Song that leaves its conclusion open-ended
column6: even if you just know something’s forever lost. Likewise
column7: over the glimmering motifs of “For Sure”
column8: Lamos' sighing
column9: brassy wail lets you know that when Kinsella whispers “Imagine us together”
column10: the whole thing will end in tears.

column1: Minimalism
column2: repetition
column3: and subtle virtuosity were rare elements amidst Cap’n Jazz’s spazzed-out arpeggios
column4: the Vagrant label's lockstep pop
column5: and the severe start-and-stop musicianship of Jade Tree and Deep Elm bands. So what
column6: exactly
column7: makes American Football emo? Upon announcing their reunion
column8: the band explained their return by joking
column9: “Obviously
column10: we knew the time was ripe for three middle aged dudes to play some old songs about teenage feelings
column11: and stand around tuning guitars for a long time."" It’s actually the latter part of that statement that points to American Football's constantly shifting
column12: implacable emotional pull. There isn’t much insight as to what inspired Kinsella’s lyrics and he didn’t emote harder or rawer than anyone else. But Holmes and Kinsella’s guitar playing is the most emotive the genre has been privy to
column13: inverting the typical power trio dynamic and rendering Kinsella’s minimal lyrics as a platform for elaboration rather than the final word.

column1: Very little of American Football is in a minor key and almost none of it can be performed on a single guitar
column2: so it’s not explicitly heartbroken music
column3: nor is it ever entirely joyous. Rather than pinpoint an emotion
column4: the record exists on a continuum. There’s no right answer as to whether “The Summer Ends” is a devotional
column5: a last goodbye
column6: or some combination of the two—the ache and beauty are intertwined. Instrumental ""You Know I Should Be Leaving Soon” is the album's most playful cut
column7: and it’s similarly open to interpretation: is it about leaving soon because everyone has to eventually get on with their day after spending the night together
column8: or is it about leaving—like
column9: for good? Nothing suggests a typical narrative arc
column10: but it's worth noting that the song that follows ""You Know I Should Be Leaving Soon"" is called “But the Regrets are Killing Me”
column11: and after that
column12: “I’ll See You When We’re Both Not So Emotional” (let it be said
column13: these guys had a sense of humor). American Football operates from a mindset where everything is about to happen
column14: and that inability to stay present is a feeling that’s neither teenage nor see-through nor false.

column1: American Football was released in September of 1999
column2: which lends the album a real-time immediacy: the lyrics begin in June and end in August
column3: surely a powerful period of time for teenagers and college-bound kids (American Football were University of Illinois students at the time). Unless you’re a teacher or NFL player
column4: though
column5: the typical adult's day-to-day doesn’t change all that much during the summer—it’s hotter
column6: there are dumber movies in the theater
column7: and that's about it. And yet
column8: those same see-through teenage feelings can still manifest during the change of the seasons
column9: regardless of age; there are many reasons “Indian Summer” is one of the most frequently covered indie rock songs
column10: and similarly we're only now beginning to recognize how American Football struck an emotional chord
column11:
one that’s proven to be every bit as resonant.
