Ultima II Massage
column2: the latest full-length from Tom Fec's Tobacco project
column3: finds the Black Moth Super Rainbow frontman moving from the gently corroded Technicolor psych-prog of 2010’s Maniac Meat to a full-on barrage of wobbling
column4: low-end-heavy bizarro pop. Fec’s work as Tobacco is frequently approached as a dichotomy of beauty and ugliness; on Ultima's front half
column5: the ""ugly"" quotient has been ramped up to match the project's warped
column6: grotty imagery.

column1: The album's standouts signify an evolved sound. Obscene
column2: rowdy
column3: and fun
column4: “Eruption (Gonna Get My Hair Cut At The End of the Summer)” is aggro-R&B cut with a dose of Minneapolis funk
column5: while album opener “Streaker”
column6: which features Beck collaborator Brian LeBarton
column7: is grindhouse glam rock with heavy artillery.  Fec claims in a press release that Ultima II Massage is the “definitive end” to his conceptual aims
column8: and he ends up with a zombified mix of Marc Bolan and Prince doused in the industrial scuzz and slime of Tobacco’s customary sonics and executed with puerile glee.

column1: Lyrically
column2: Ultima II Massage is in line with previous Tobacco efforts. Fec is
column3: in his own way
column4: a sensual songwriter
column5: his lyrics are calculated for visceral impact—so there’s plenty of material about popsicles
column6: ejaculation
column7: and fruit
column8: naturally
column9: along with various skin-crawling ephemera. Obscenity is applied liberally
column10: moreso than on past releases; Fec has said that Tobacco's associated imagery draws inspiration from a pre-pubescent mindset
column11: and here he possesses all the excitement of a kid who’s just discovered the full power of the word “motherfucker” for the first time.

column1: Ultima’s less gentle tracks are a welcome evolution in Tobacco's music
column2: but the old
column3: swooning BMSR sound--scarred
column4: melodic music that sounds as if it’s just starting to rot--pops up now and again. Occasionally
column5: Fec finds a sweet spot between the two poles
column6: an approach that's crystallized on the violently saccharine “Lipstick Destroyer”. “Creaming for Beginners”
column7: meanwhile
column8: is a heavily distorted ballad with a blistering
column9: slow-burning melody.

column1: Overall
column2: though
column3: Fec doesn't always achieve that balance
column4: so there's several mid-album cuts here that jog in place despite their inherent prettiness
column5: speaking to the album's uneven momentum as a whole. While Ultima II Massage starts off with material that's heavier and meaner than anything he’s done previously
column6: the lighter sound of the album's back half can't help but come across as a drop in ambition
column7:
turning down the volume on what could've been the most dynamic Tobacco record to date.

Last summer Simon Reynolds published an update to his seminal book on rave music
column2: Energy Flash
column3: that included his thoughts on
column4: among other recent trends
column5: dubstep. ""Instrumental music goes international so much easier
column6: he mused
column7: explaining how one knobby
column8: London-centric bass sound—dubstep—had elbowed another—grime—out of the spotlight. Reynolds looks prescient now: grime
column9: minus its thickly accented MCs
column10: saw a major resurgence in 2013. The sound went global
column11: too
column12: as producers from Texas to Tokyo aided a gaggle of UK artists in re-introducing grime's cagey melodic contortions to club culture.

column1: As heads of the Butterz label (and the eponymous recurring party)
column2: Elijah & Skilliam have been central to London grime's re-emergence. Their imprint outstrips newfound interest in the style: since 2010
column3: their label has housed grime veterans (Terror Danjah) and fostered new talent (Royal-T). Their weekly radio show on Rinse FM has served as a hub for the sound's widening pallette. Alongside Keysound Recordings
column4: Hyperdub
column5: and Night Slugs Butterz has erected a platform for grime more durable and prominent than that of its heyday
column6: clearing space for veterans such as Wiley and Footsie to co-habitate with the upstarts.

column1: The genre now encompasses everything from Visionist's nimble dub mutations to Preditah's reptilian lumber
column2: but it's generally characterized by stabbing mid-range synthesizers
column3: spare
column4: idiosyncratic percussion
column5: a deep-space sub. The mark of a good grime track seems to be just how unstable it can sound
column6: taking a childlike glee in contrasting pretty
column7: ethereal melodies with amoeba-like sub-bass.

column1: Fabriclive 75 is the pair's second official mix CD
column2: following their 2011 effort for Rinse's series. They're unique in that they're not producers
column3: instead functioning as true scene stewards. As such
column4: Fabriclive 75 serves as an overview of the producers and tracks in their orbit rather than as a representation of their DJ sets. They peddle a distinctly UK sound
column5: largely focusing on grime's chunky mid-range gymnastics but also incorporating the clubbier house sounds of UK Funky while ignoring recent trap and footwork influences. There are lots of dark
column6: outre sounds on Fabriclive 75 but the overall effect is cheeky and effusive. It's difficult to imagine dancing to much of Fabriclive 75
column7: but it is party music
column8: better suited for having some beers and bouncing around than getting stoned in your living room.

column1: When you listen to old grime tapes (the Wire has a potent collection here)
column2: their roughness is inescapable: awkward cuts
column3: run-backs
column4: dropped sound
column5: lots of airhorn. Even more recent efforts
column6: such as DJ Slimzee and the always golden Flow Dan's Radio 1 mix
column7: have a homespun
column8: improvisational quality to them. Grime MCs
column9: like the jungle and UK Garage MCs before them
column10: emerged from the storied tradition of reggae soundclashes: a constant dialogue with the selector interspersed with boasts and taunts. In retrospect
column11: it's obvious why grime MCs never made good hip-hop records: these guys are inveterate shit-talkers
column12: not storytellers. (Grime as a pop phenomenon
column13: though
column14: has also experienced a resurgence in the UK.)

column1: The 70-minute mix DJ mix
column2: in comparison
column3: is a relatively ascetic
column4: formal environment
column5: one where rough cuts can't simply be attributed to the DJs playing to the crowd's energy. Fabriclive 75 suffers at times
column6: due in part to Elijah & Skilliam's choice to showcase such a wide variety of sounds. Mixing in and out of tracks such as Joker and Swindle's blockbuster anthem as 040 ""Let It Be Known"" and Murlo's slinky lullaby ""Into Mist"" is difficult even under more forgiving circumstances. Some of the best cuts the duo selects—DJ Q's ""Two Faced"" into Sir Spyro's grind-worthy ""Pull It Up""—have more to do with house and R&B than grime.

column1: Fabriclive 75 survives some rough patches
column2: though
column3: because it's a bounty of vibrant
column4: creative music. A couple of proper dubs—with grime MCs hyping Elijah & Skilliam over familar tracks—are a nice touch and a nod to the increasing frequency with which MCs are being invited back into the booth.  It's a bit difficult to recommend in light of Elijah & Skilliam's Rinse mix—less comprehensive but fiercer—and
column5: more importantly
column6: their weekly (and downloadable) show for Rinse
column7: which is both free and a more natural way to follow the ebbs and flows of the scene. As a jumping off point for further exploration
column8: though
column9:
you won't find a more concise or considered collection of grime's talents.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/20568/homepage_large.88076201.jpg|Lullabies Help the Brain Grow|32275.0|Big Boys|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Light in the Attic']|2014-05-21 00:00:00|1983|2016-06-11 16:37:35.759296|"

Post-hardcore’s point of conception is as vague and debatable as that of post-punk
column2: but a strong case can be made for placing the former's genesis at “Sound on Sound
column3: ” a remarkable track from Big Boys’ 1983 album Lullabies Help the Brain Grow. The title is a tipoff: “Sound on Sound” is built on a stratum of radio-degraded voice samples and static
column4: and over all of that
column5: a lopsided rhythm of minimal drums and wiry bass limps along
column6: stretching empty space over its own rickety skeleton. Guitar harmonics ping like sonar
column7: and no riffs are brought to bear. Guitarist Tim Kerr takes the mic from the band’s buoyant
column8: bellicose frontman Randy “Biscuit” Turner
column9: and instead of bellowing
column10: he speaks simply yet cryptically
column11: his voice both intimate and distant. It’s spacious
column12: but that space screams. Contemporaries like Mission of Burma sound metal by comparison. The subtle stasis of tension and release is enough to pluck nerves.

column1: Lullabies
column2: along with Big Boys’ swansong
column3: 1985’s <i>No Matter How Long the Line at the Cafeteria
column4: There’s Always a Seat
column5: are being reissued as discrete entities after spending two decades shoehorned together on the Touch and Go anthology The Fat Elvis. Post-hardcore is not what either album is best known as; while the band’s fellow pioneers of the Austin punk scene—most notably MDC
column6: the Dicks
column7: and Offenders—each nailed down its own consistent vision of punk rock
column8: Big Boys loved funk. Granted
column9: they weren’t the first to do so
column10: as Gang of Four and Minutemen will attest. Lullabies is particularly beholden to the latter
column11: as gleefully evident on jerky
column12: syncopated songs like “Jump the Fence” and
column13: well
column14: “Funk Off”.

column1: But Big Boys had much more going on in their sound than simply providing a bridge between Minutemen and Red Hot Chili Peppers. “We Got Your Money” sports a shout-along
column2: garage-rock populism that openly mocks the frat boys who loved them. More convolutedly satirical is the funk-fired
column3: horn-injected “White Nigger”
column4: especially in light of the Big Boys’ legendary feud with Bad Brains over homophobic taunts (the late Turner was openly gay). Musically and lyrically
column5: the song is only a hair away from being a parody of Wild Cherry’s “Play That Funky Music”
column6: one that acknowledges its creators’ whiteness in a far more confrontational and problematic way. It’s so far from “Sound on Sound”
column7: it’s hard to believe it’s the same band. At a time when hardcore brooked little ambition or experimentation
column8: that’s ultimately a good thing.

column1: The horns—but thankfully not the racial commentary—reappear on No Matter. The two years between the two albums sheared off some of Big Boys’ loose ends
column2: as No Matter is more cohesive
column3: settling into a punk-funk groove that closes the gap between circle pit and campus kegger. Turner's ragged howl had taken on a soulful melancholy as he grew less sure of hardcore—and less sure of his place in it—and that battle-scarred maturity is best heard on “Which Way to Go”. Sung in tandem by Turner and Kerr
column4: it’s a cousin to the ringing
column5: melodic
column6: introspective mutation of hardcore that Rites of Spring was playing at the same time in Washington
column7: D.C.—one that Hüsker Dü had helped instigate
column8: too. Big Boys didn’t invent emo
column9: but with a singular
column10: heart-piercing song
column11: they helped shape it.

column1: In the same way that punk was nowhere near finished when post-punk rose in the late ’70s
column2: hardcore still raged in 1983 as Big Boys set the pace for what was to come—and still
column3: hardcore rages on during both Lullabies and No Matter
column4: records that boast far more restlessness and recklessness than almost any of its contemporary influences. The former's “Brickwall” is a 40-second dry-heave of asphyxiated punk that doesn’t even provide enough processing time for panic to set in
column5: and No Matter’s opening song
column6: “No”
column7: is a sneer-and-squeal spasm of angst that imagines Jello Biafra seizing control of Black Flag.

column1: Still
column2: Big Boys were never a self-styled street-gang perpetrating Reagan-era nihilism. A bleak sense of humor and a desperate underbelly lurked beneath their alternately derivative and innovative stream of anthems—but they lit and lifted that darkness with a surplus of savage joy. Post-hardcore would ultimately take a more dour route; heard as a whole
column3: though
column4: Lullabies and No Matter comprise a pastel-smeared
column5:
bursting-with-life reminder that things could have gone another way.

column3: then you'd understand."" That glistening anti-koan punctuates the chorus of Coldplay's skyscraping 2005 single ""Speed of Sound""
column4: and the lyric's profound meaninglessness has doubled as a mission statement for the mega-band's career thus far. They've established a reputation as mainstream rock's koi pond architects
column5: designing music that's deceptively shallow but
column6: if caught at the right moment
column7: shimmeringly beautiful
column8: to the point that you could focus on it for hours.

column1: Impossibly indulgent on a sonic level while retaining the intellectual depth of a cell phone commercial
column2: Coldplay's catalog is largely experiential—a reflecting pool for the hopes
column3: dreams
column4: and heartaches that listeners wish to apply to the music. This pliability has meant that Coldplay can come off as impersonal
column5: a gaseous giant of anonymity in rock music's solar system; nearly 10 years ago
column6: the stultifyingly dense third album X&Y threatened to swallow the band completely
column7: as Coldplay refined the post-post-punk affectations of 2002's A Rush of Blood to the Head until they were left with an immobile monolith.

column1: On the verge of overreaching
column2: Coldplay doubled down with 2008's Viva La Vida or Death and All His Friends
column3: a world-beating document of giddy experimentation and costume-rock bathos that stands as their most thrilling
column4: impressionistic work. Mylo Xyloto followed three years later
column5: which took its predecessor's widescreen template and enlarged it to IMAX-size
column6: indulging in rave-y piano stabs and night-flight flourishes with the color-filled exuberance of a child that can't stop eating crayons.

column1: Mylo Xyloto was further proof that Coldplay are at their best when they embrace their corniest impulses; their sixth album
column2: Ghost Stories
column3: finds them taking a sharp left turn. Preceded by the non-single ""Midnight""
column4: a watery electro-folk Bon Iver facsimile accompanied with a video reminiscent of an iTunes visualizer
column5: nearly everything about the arrival of Ghost Stories has seemed small: the nine-song tracklist
column6: the spartan
column7: deep-blue angel's-wings cover
column8: the disappointing lack of costumes. The absence of grandiosity signaled to eager fans and sneering bystanders alike that
column9: this time around
column10: something might be a little off.

column1: That something can be traced to Martin's marriage to actress and $600-hand-cream guru Gwyneth Paltrow
column2: which quietly imploded in March of this year. More a separation than an outright divorce
column3: recent court documents revealed that the couple are still living together
column4: and in a 2008 SPIN profile
column5: the only subject that the otherwise affable Martin bristled against discussing was his personal life with Paltrow. As long as the world's known him
column6: Chris Martin has also proved impossible to truly know
column7: so whether his recent familial troubles would seep into his band's latest was anyone's guess.

column1: And yet
column2: Ghost Stories is unmistakably Coldplay's ""breakup album
column3: a subdued work that finds Martin and his band crisply moping through mid-tempo soundscapes and fuzzy electronic touches that have the visceral impact of a down comforter tumbling down a flight of stairs. Featuring production from longtime collaborators Daniel Green and Rik Simpson
column4: along with behind-the-boards pro Paul Epworth
column5: drone-techno auteur Jon Hopkins
column6: and Kanye West collaborator Mike Dean
column7: the record is serene and weightless to a fault. Coldplay abandon the musical tourism and extroverted strides of their last few albums and find themselves adrift.

column1: The closest the record comes to a bona fide anthem is the moderately enjoyable ""A Sky Full of Stars""
column2: a rocket-fueled single on the level of ""Clocks"" and ""Speed of Sound"" tainted by Swedish dance producer AVICII's cheap-sounding drum presets and boilerplate synth motifs. ""I don't care/ If you tear me apart
column3: Martin wails at the peak of the song's endless chorus
column4: a passionate exclamation that doubles one of the most nakedly personal admissions he's made on record.

column1: Ghost Stories certainly sounds like the product of someone working out their private pain in public; unfortunately
column2: the results are less Blood on the Tracks and more ""Can I Borrow a Feeling?"". Coldplay's catalog has plenty of examples where Martin's words have failed him
column3: but his diaristic reflections on Ghost Stories are abnormally painful. ""Tell me you love me/ If you don't
column4: then lie
column5: he coos on the Spandau Ballet-gone-Disney ballad ""True Love""; during the plodding ""Another's Arms""
column6: he ruminates on lost domestic bliss watching TV with a loved one
column7: ""Your body on my body."" If the expression of carnal closeness-via-TiVo makes you cringe
column8: imagine how he feels.

column1: ""Ink"" is the album's most indefensible moment
column2: musically and lyrically
column3: and the song handily snatches the title of Worst Coldplay Song from X&Y's impossibly leaden
column4: fuckin'-magnets stinker ""What If"". ""Got a tattoo/ And the pain's alright
column5: Martin cries while running through a series of love-as-permanence metaphors
column6: over rippling guitar and burbling atmospherics ripped from Phil Collins' Tarzan soundtrack. The last time Coldplay indulged in ""rainforest rock
column7: it was Viva La Vida's transcendent
column8: gorgeous ""Strawberry Swing""
column9: which featured Martin exclaiming beatifically
column10: ""It's such a perfect day""; on ""Ink""
column11: he moves from vine to vine until swinging in solitude at the track's end
column12: exclaiming with a sigh
column13: ""All I know is that I love you so/ So much that it hurts.""

column1: Fittingly

column3: and that's partially due to Martin's lovely-as-ever vocals; when not chronicling his own pain
column4: he occasionally breaks into appealing birdsong
column5: a wordless pitter-patter that marks the chorus of the record's pleasant-enough lead single
column6: ""Magic"". Otherwise
column7: Ghost Stories is a collection of unmemorable songs from a band that's made enough memories to last a lifetime. Everything sounds pristine—this is a Coldplay album
column8: and instrumentally the band is as exacting as ever—but by the dreary piano-led closer ""O""

column10: plain
column11: and forgettable.

column1: Conventional wisdom says X&Y is Coldplay's worst album
column2: but amidst that record's shiftless bloat

column4: and thus threatens to rob X&Y of its dubious title. Its intimate nature shares the most kinship with Coldplay's first album

column6: that album sounds like the work of a different band

their best moments are truly behind them.

Shoot for the moon—even if you miss you’ll...probably end up making a total fucking faceplant. That’s a lesson many people in have learned the hard way in Hollywood
column3: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/features/update/9172-cold-cave"">and to hear Wesley Eisold tell it
column4: he's one of them. His last Cold Cave record
column5: 2011’s Cherish the Light Years
column6: was an explosive lunar launch that embraced every opportunity to tell you how awesome it was—nothing but souped-up goth-rock jock jams
column7: bombastic lyrics and hyper-loud Brick Wall of China production. And yet
column8: it failed to satisfy the one person most invested in its success:  Wesley Eisold. Eisold told us that Cherish the Light Years is “the Cold Cave I can’t stand to hear
column9: ” and in the time since
column10: he’s treated 2011 like a rejected transplant.

column1: But in addition to separating himself from former collaborators
column2: dealing with his internal demons and external demonization
column3: Eisold got a prosthetic limb after spending his entire life hiding his missing left hand. The metaphor wasn’t lost on him—it’s a sign of being accountable
column4: refusing to think of himself as a victim. These are themes that Eisold dealt with on the singles he intermittently released during 2013 as a free agent from Matador Records
column5: and Full Cold Moon collects them to create an account of the imperfect progress of someone trying to take back control of his life.

column1: So is Full Cold Moon the ""new Cold Cave album""? Not really—though in a strange way
column2: the familiarity of these songs make it far more “singles”-packed than the overtly commercial Cherish the Light Years.  Eisold claims the new material is more “honest” as well
column3: and that can be taken a number of ways
column4: depending on whether you think the tag is a preemptive strike against the idea that he didn’t have much choice but to make more humble-sounding music. It’s clear that Eisold can’t stop writing anthems
column5: as “Don’t Blow Up the Moon”
column6: ""God Made the World"" and “People are Poison” are every bit as broad and striving as their titles indicate.  But while the songs are fully-formed
column7: the production has a demo-like starkness and the underlying instrumentation is dank
column8: rudimentary stuff that sounds like one man in his home studio
column9: accountable to no one besides himself.

column1: On opener “A Little Death to Laugh”
column2: synths bleep like first-gen ringtones over unyielding
column3: old-school machine beats and wormy bass while Eisold inverts his prior vocal performances
column4: sounding like he’s being deflated rather than projecting outwards. “Oceans With No End” and “Black Boots”
column5: two singles which immediately recall the rock dynamics of Eisold’s recent past than the New Romantic S&M of Loves Come Close
column6: are among his strongest and most passionate work—but they’re also the songs on this release that could’ve used bolder presentation or a dynamic shift to turn their choruses into legitimate singalongs.

column1: That said
column2: even if Chris Coady’s hyper-compressed production on Cherish the Light Years is occasionally missed
column3: over the span of an entire album
column4: it was like a corset—meant to enhance and excite the onlooker
column5: but it sure seemed painful for long periods of time. Eisold sounds freed on the first quarter of Full Cold Moon
column6: which is almost an EP unto itself that reminds you Eisold is Cold Cave
column7: and the project will sound however he chooses. After ""A Little Death to Laugh""
column8: “Young Prisoner Dreams of Romance” is a black-on-black leatherbound punk burner that’s over almost as soon as you read the title
column9: immediately followed by the off-kilter
column10: strangely beautiful coldwave instrumental “Tristan Corbière.”

column1: But Full Cold Moon is more honest in the sense that Eisold is asking himself harder questions than he did on songs like “Underworld USA”
column2: which were necessarily blank. It’s a shame that Eisold’s vocals are mixed curiously low; for one thing
column3: they minimize the impact of his melodies
column4: the immediate advantage he has over the hundreds of mid-fi coldwavers working in a similar range. Without the lyrics sheet
column5: you can completely overlook his searching
column6: often searing self-reckoning. During “A Little Death to Laugh”
column7: Eisold mutters “I lost a limb on the left hand path/ And I never ever got it back”
column8: a double entendre with a hell of a lot of resonance considering Eisold’s life story as well as Cold Cave's aesthetic. Meanwhile
column9: “People are Poison” sidesteps the potentially Reznor-esque notebook scrawling to flatly state
column10: “You better die young or you will be me or something/ And then they will say ‘in your prime
column11: you were nothing.’”

column1: There’s a good chance your appreciation for Full Cold Moon will be inversely proportional to your appreciation of Cherish the Light Years’ flair for the dramatic
column2: but remember that Cherish the Light Years is actually an outlier in Cold Cave’s discography—go back even further beyond the industrial New Order of Love Comes Close
column3: to the days when Cold Cave was a noise project closer to former bandmate Dominick Fernow’s Prurient than Depeche Mode.

column1: As to what Cold Cave is now
column2: “Meaningful Life” is coincidentally stuck right in the middle of Full Cold Moon and is presented as a kind of spiritual crossroads for Eisold. It’s an eerie
column3: free-floating meditation of organ and flutes reduced to 8-bit versions of themselves. As for Eisold: some people live very meaningful lives
column4: some don’t. Which one will he choose? And what does ""meaningful"" even mean?  Eisold intimated that the next true Cold Cave album will be called Sunflower
column5:
so that probably gives an indication he’ll be choosing the right hand path out of the darkness.

The liner notes for Light in the Attic’s new reissue of L’Amour
column2: the only known album by an artist known as Lewis<i>
column3: read more like a murder mystery than a making-of. In 1983
column4: a guy named Randall Wulff showed up at Music Lab studio in Los Angeles with a white Mercedes convertible
column5: a beautiful girlfriend
column6: perfect hair
column7: and a handful of ethereal synth-pop-folk tunes. Wulff then hired photographer Ed Colver
column8: best known for documenting the West Coast punk scene
column9: to shoot the starkly monochromatic album cover. By the time Colver realized the check had bounced
column10: Wulff had disappeared. There were rumors that he had gone to Las Vegas or possibly Hawaii
column11: but most likely he had returned to Alberta
column12: Canada
column13: where nearly twenty-five years later a vinyl collector named Jon Murphy came across a copy of L’Amour at a flea market.

column1: Full of gently dissolving melodies and gossamer synths (credited to a guy named Philip Lees
column2: also a mystery)
column3: the album has become crate-digger lore
column4: as much for the backstory as for the music itself. As of this reissue
column5: Wulff remains at large. Was he a con man
column6: as some claim? A drug dealer
column7: as others attest? An apparition? An alien visitor? A record collector hoax? Did he really have connections to the Duke Power fortune? Was he really involved with Christie Brinkley? How does cowboy novelist Louis L’Amour fit into the story? And where is Wulff now
column8: if he is still around? Jack D. Fleischer
column9: the filmmaker/historian who penned the liners and spent years looking for the artist
column10: tracked down Wulff’s nephew
column11: who had vivid memories of his uncle but lost touch with him many years ago. Fleischer came across another pseudonym under which Wulff recorded a few other albums
column12: but he neglects to disclose the name. “As of this writing
column13: ” he notes
column14: “Randall is essentially a ghost.”

column1: The hazy story doesn’t bolster the music
column2: but rather seems an extension of this strange and singular album. If you think of Los Angeles in the early ‘80s
column3: you’re probably thinking New Wave synth-pop
column4: cocaine-fueled and neon-lit—and L’Amour is anything but. Rather than sunny and hook-laden
column5: these songs convey an ephemeral melancholy
column6: blurred at the edges yet more potent for being somewhat indistinct. This is music of retreat
column7: not assertion. The synths rise and ebb curiously
column8: occasionally punctuating the songs with quiet starbursts but mostly moving with a logic of their own
column9: often with no regard for Lewis’s vocals or piano playing. He doesn’t sing so much as he mumbles melodically
column10: as though perpetually falling awake. The effect is quieting but too spooky to be New Agey. If Randall Wulff was an L.A. player
column11: then Lewis was a bedroom auteur.

column1: L’Amour sounds like double-exposed film: full of odd
column2: unrecognizable shapes that fade and overlap seemingly at uncalculated angles. Any concrete theme must be deduced not from the lyrics—which are persistently unintelligible—but from song titles like “I Thought the World of You” and “Even Rainbows Turn Blue”
column3: which hint at the album’s ruminative mood. Lewis intimates romantic longing on a cellular level
column4: and even the reveries implied by “Let’s Fall in Love Tonight” and “Romance for Two” (dedicated to Brinkley) sound more like memories of bliss than promises of future happiness. Yet
column5: despite the album cover's implication
column6: Lewis is no weepy miserability; rather
column7: these songs project a world-weary dignity. “Love Showered Me” ripples with sci-fi synth burbles
column8: as Lewis testifies tenderly
column9: his voice fading from a relatively assertive croon to a hollowed-out whisper. It’s a peculiar performance
column10: yet powerful.

column1: The jauntiest tune here is “Cool Night in Paris”
column2: which mixes vague chanson with what sounds like acoustic blues picking. Lewis’s voice is all cooed vowels
column3: as though you’re overhearing a passerby speaking a strange language
column4: yet he nimbly punctuates his sweet nothings with a sharp
column5: decisive guitar lick
column6: which may be the most straightforward thing on the entire album. It’s the Seine glimpsed in a half-remembered dream
column7: referring not to a particular place but to the idea of that place. Likewise
column8: the subtle allusions to ""Can't Take My Eyes Off of You"" on ""Romance for ""Two"" and to ""Funny How Time Slips Away"" on ""Things Just Happen That Way"" are inscrutable
column9: especially because Lewis doesn't seem to inhabit the same world as Frankie Valli or Willie Nelson.

column1: Did Wulff intend those specific references? Or are the resemblances merely in the imagination of the listener trying to make sense of the music? It’s impossible to tell with this Rorschach of an album. These songs work by insinuation: the way the synths sidle up to the piano on “Like to See You Again”
column2: the way Lewis’s illegible vocals imply indecipherable meaning
column3: the way the album ultimately invades your imagination. It can be weirdly addictive
column4: with each subsequent listen promising to reveal some essential secret or shed light on the man on the album cover. Instead
column5: somehow L’Amour sounds less there with each spin
column6:
beckoning you into its hazy world even as it dissolves into gray. The mystery is so perfect that it’d be a tragedy to solve it.

To date
column2: Emma Ruth Rundle’s stabs at crafting a musical identity have been tentative ones. As the frontwoman of the L.A.-based projects the Nocturnes and Marriages
column3: her eerie voice has been all but smothered by male accompanists
column4: prog denseness
column5: cyclonic distortion

The fact that she’s a stunningly supple and versatile guitarist—her skills are a vital component of the post-rock ensemble Red Sparowes—hasn’t given her that much reason to step up her vocal game. Even her previous solo material has been guitar-centric and mostly instrumental. But Rundle’s new solo album
column7: Some Heavy Ocean
column8: is different. She not only sings
column9: she does so a lot—and when she does
column10: she soars.

column1: That’s not to say the album sounds triumphant. Some Heavy Ocean is a black hole of anti-happiness
column2: a heart-shaped growth of dark matter. Veins of inky folk run through “Shadows of My Name” and “Oh Sarah”
column3: songs that encompass the scope of Rundle’s acoustic prowess: On the former
column4: she attacks her strings as if they’re barbed wire that must be breached with her bare hands; on the latter
column5: she fingerpicks with fluid delicacy. As sharp and vivid as her playing is
column6: though
column7: the clouds are always near. Swathes of strings and overdriven twang cast long shadows
column8: and the intermittent drums rattle like bones in a box. Even the two brief
column9: ethereal interludes
column10: “Some Heavy Ocean” and “Your Card the Sun”
column11: seem more like frozen chunks of time than mere placeholders. Far more than anything she’s done prior
column12: the album is a dynamic
column13: breath-snatching statement of intent that’s part lullaby
column14: part night terror.

column1: The biggest leap found on Some Heavy Ocean is Rundle’s voice. On “Shadows of My Name
column2: ” her reverb-shrouded vocals dart in and out of the mix

Throughout the rest of tracks—particularly the mournful yet urgent “Run Forever”—Rundle’s comes across like a student of both Chelsea Wolfe’s frigid intonation and Marissa Nadler’s gloomy coo. As a singer
column5: Rundle now sounds whole
column6: and better yet
column7: she’s gravitated toward a timeless resonance. The post-metal and shoegaze sounds she’s employed before have been left for something broader. When
column8: on “Haunted Houses”
column9: she warns of a distance that must be kept between her and the unnamed target of her simmering wrath
column10: she evokes Stevie Nicks; having another song titled “Oh Sarah” only reinforces that impression
column11: although that track’s candlelit
column12: folk-rock balladry bears just a vague kinship to Fleetwood Mac’s “Sara”.

column1: Rundle’s lyrics
column2: where they can be fully pieced together
column3: are the weakest element of Some Heavy Ocean. There are only so many mentions of ghosts and graveyards that a record can take before it starts to feel cartoonishly goth
column4: even when those motifs are woven into the music with such conviction and subtle shades of mood. That atmosphere works best when it strips away any hint of pale cliché and plunges under the ice; “Living with the Black Dog” is a droning
column5: distorted
column6: shadow-draped leviathan of a song

column8: ambitious note
column9: it reconciles every medium she’s worked in so far: melody
column10: noise
column11: softness
column12: severity
column13: and a sense of quiet drama and melancholy. Some Heavy Ocean stands as Rundle’s first fully realized release as a singer-songwriter—and while its monochrome scale is narrow

she makes harrowing grays out of it.

Mason Bates
column2: a DJ and composer
column3: never quite manages to escape an interview—and he's given many—without being asked how it is he manages to work in both fields. Orchestral composers are presumed to be so sealed off from popular pursuits
column4: it seems
column5: that he may as well be a Catholic priest that skydives
column6: or a Supreme Court Justice with a sideline in mixed martial arts. A line he often feeds journalists is that the orchestra is like ""the world's greatest synthesizer
column7: an analogy so head-patting in its patronizing simplicity I imagine he's rolling his eyes inwardly as he says it.

column1: But the analogy nonetheless points to the way Bates works—he's fascinated by sounds
column2: and it doesn't matter where they come from. His imagination for tone colors and textures is obvious on Stereo Is King
column3: and they unfold across a spectrum. Like the composer Daniel Wohl
column4: Bates' recorded music explores a rich nexus where organic sounds blur into digital ones
column5: and Stereo Is King basically eradicates your need
column6: while it is playing
column7: to even make such distinctions. When he performs his pieces live with an orchestra
column8: he pointedly underlines this approach
column9: standing all the way in the back of the massed forces
column10: hunched over a laptop and sending little glitches and ripples out over the seething field of sound around him.

column1: On Stereo Is King's title track
column2: Bates paints a landscape of a thousand noises on an equal playing field. The first minute of the title piece has marimba
column3: glockenspiel
column4: bells
column5: possibly some sampled chirping crickets—all in the first minute. Some light smudges of digital activity crackle in the corners and in the foreground. These graceful intrusions hit the surface of his orchestral writing like a skipping rock. They remind us forcefully that in our headphones
column6: the separation of ""real"" and ""fake"" sounds is a trick we play on ourselves.

column1: There are many different kinds of pieces on Stereo—""Observer in the Magellanic Cloud"" pairs choral chanting with rolled ""r""s and a metronome beep. The choral writing fans out into grunts and exclamations before assembling again
column2: like a gas cloud
column3: into a reverent hum. The metronome beep fades
column4: imperceptibly
column5: into the choral writing
column6: and back out again—a tagged tracer for Bates' ideas about the mutability of sounds. ""White Lies for  Lomax""
column7: meanwhile
column8: dreams up new field recordings that Lomax never happened across
column9: the piano wandering airily in and out of concrete blues language. Six minutes in
column10: an actual field recording floats in
column11: but so quietly that it seems to be intruding into your headphone space from outside. (The first time I listened
column12: I actually took my headphones off to make sure it was part of the music.)

column1: What unites all of these pieces is
column2: simply
column3: Bates' roving mind. ""Terrycloth Troposphere"" lovingly disassembles some of the key parts in  Terry Riley's ""In C"". ""String Band"" re-imagines classic string band music as a bunch of straining tendons
column4: strings that moan and approach snapping. All of them travel from their origin point into Bates' world

gathering overhead like helium balloons ready to slip.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/20463/homepage_large.bdeac243.jpg|Upside Down Mountain|6908.0|Conor Oberst|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch']|2014-05-19 00:00:00|2014|2016-06-11 16:37:40.103495|"

Conor Oberst is a 34-year old married man. He’s been a musician in the public eye for nearly half of his life
column2: and over the past decade
column3: he’d be most accurately described as a folk artist. His latest album Upside Down Mountain is being released on Nonesuch
column4: a label whose release slate includes the Black Keys
column5: Natalie Merchant
column6: and Nickel Creek. The cover art is designed by one of the guys in the Felice Brothers
column7: and he’ll be trekking around the country with Dawes. The moment you hear Oberst sing
column8: though
column9: you will forget every single one of these facts and remember every positive and negative association you have with Bright Eyes instead—there’s just no mistaking him for anyone else at this point
column10: and it’s unclear how he feels about that. While claiming “this is a return to an earlier way I wrote""
column11: Upside Down Mountain is Oberst’s latest documentation of his obsessions with escape
column12: death
column13: the passing of time
column14: and the potential of finding serenity in an assumed identity.

column1: That said
column2: Upside Down Mountain isn't a Bright Eyes album
column3: so Oberst’s not driven by the same incessant need for romantic and artistic validation that kept him going until Lifted
column4: nor will circumstances ever align the way they did for his protracted 2005 critical breakthrough. On the plus side of the ledger
column5: you can understand what the hell Oberst is talking about most of the time on Upside Down Mountain
column6: which makes it an immediate improvement over Cassadaga and The People’s Key
column7: two albums that somehow managed to be cryptic and pedantic at the same time.

column1: Besides possessing one of the strongest melodies Oberst has ever penned (and there are plenty here)
column2: “Time Forgot” is a welcome reintroduction to the guy who never had trouble getting his point across. Here
column3: he longs to grow a beard
column4: to be left alone
column5: to let the wind scatter thoughts
column6: to just listen. This puts him in a similar mindset as he was on his self-titled record from 2008
column7: the last truly great thing he’s put his name on. But there’s been an unmistakable change of perspective—on Conor Oberst cuts like “I Don’t Want to Die (In the Hospital)”
column8: death was impending because he was Conor Oberst
column9: the wildly talented and self-destructive rock singer. Here
column10: he’s not chasing death
column11: but death will catch up with him because he’s Conor Oberst
column12: human being.

column1: The most resonant moments of Upside Down Mountain follow suit in deconstructing Oberst’s myth of himself—during the otherwise chintzy
column2: rhinestone cowboy pop of “Hundreds of Ways”
column3: “I hope I am forgotten when I die” is the most poisonously enunciated line on the LP. Meanwhile
column4: on the mesmerizing minor-key whisper of “Artifact #1”
column5: Oberst just wants to be forgotten while he’s alive—“I don’t want a second chance to be an object of desire/ if that means slipping through your hands.” Sometimes he even has a sense of humor about it all; though “Kick” is addressed to a luckless Kennedy
column6: it’s not a “Diane Young”-style philosophical treatise
column7: but rather one fuck-up relating to another. And when he admonishes a self-absorbed drunk during “Enola Gay”’s rummy strut
column8: it might just be himself. The evocation of solitude in a crowded club links it back to his atomic self-pitying from Digital Ash in a Digital Urn's “Hit the Switch”
column9: but anyone can learn from its hook: “The world’s mean
column10: getting meaner too/ So why do you have to make it all about you?”

column1: But elsewhere on Upside Down Mountain
column2: he wields populist observation like a politician
column3: trying to utilize his homespun wisdom from an elevated plane. Over a decade ago
column4: he claimed “There is no truth
column5: there is only you/ And what you make the truth”
column6: and that sounds more convincing than his attempts to convey his own version of the truth as the genuine article. During “Time Forgot”
column7: he muses
column8: “They say everyone has a choice to make/ To be loved or to be free”
column9: but
column10: really
column11: who says that?  He’s got a lot of big ideas about love throughout—“True love hides like city stars”
column12: “Love was the message...full stop”
column13: “Freedom is the opposite of love”
column14: “Our love is a protective poison”
column15: “There is no dignity in love.” It's easy to think of him like Don Draper
column16: hacking out emotionally manipulative and impeccably worded pitches on a Coronet until something sticks.

column1: His facility with pat truths is most evident in “You Are Your Mother’s Child”
column2: a song that bears an instant resemblance to <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11683-im-wide-awake-its-morning-digital-ash-in-a-digital-urn/"">I'm Wide Awake
column3: It's Morning's homemade valentine “First Day of My Life” in its unadorned simplicity. It’s open-ended enough to be adopted by anyone who wants it to be about their child
column4: but after a striking
column5: writerly first verse
column6: an adolescent’s all-American upbringing feels less like an actual person’s experience than it does a songwriting exercise. It could’ve been written about anyone
column7: but it also could’ve been written by anyone.

column1: But it couldn’t have been sung that way
column2: and the saving grace of Upside Down Mountain is that it makes the case for Oberst as a truly unique and remarkable vocalist.  Earlier in his career
column3: his tremble
column4: quaver and vibrato were seen as affectations of an amateur
column5: but here they're all confidently and carefully utilized like a mastered instrument. For the most part
column6: it gives character to gauzy C&W like “Double Life” and the chugga-chugga festival-folk of “Zigzagging Toward The Light”
column7: but he still has a way of throwing in awkward phrases that stick in your craw like popcorn kernels—“Snickers bar”
column8: “Japanese arcade”
column9: “Klonopin eyes”

column1: One line in particular stands out—“I stole all the rhinestones from Carolina/ And sold them out in Bakersfield for cash.” Maybe it’s playing to and against type as the rambling folk artist
column2: since Carolina and Bakersfield are as real as it gets
column3: even if they’re being used as placeholders. It's the kind of line Ryan Adams would unspool—a fitting association since Upside Down Mountain is essentially Oberst’s Ashes & Fire. It's gorgeous to the point of near gaudiness
column4: a “return to form” after a strange decade evolving from wildly prolific
column5: heartbreak soundtracking
column6: Winona Ryder-dating enfant terrible into a domesticated Americana bard no longer interested in why to be young is to be sad. Hopefully
column7:
Oberst will find a way to make ""older and wiser"" just as revelatory.

If you're an artist making genre-bending R&B and mysteriously obscuring your identity on the Internet in 2014
column2: you have to work hard to stand out from the crowd. But if you
column3: say
column4: had a hand in one of the best pop albums in years

column8: WinterSpringSummerFall.

column1: As Boots
column2: whose real name is Jordan Asher
column3: showed on signature Beyoncé cuts like “Haunted” and “Blue”
column4: he's adept at building tense
column5: pretty atmospheres with his sweeping production. Most of WinterSpringSummerFall finds him working in the same realm
column6: seamlessly moving through clattering
column7: dance-oriented drum patterns
column8: fuzzy synths
column9: burbling bursts of electronic noise
column10: and subdued piano ballads. While this scuzzy
column11: genre-bending sonic palette doesn't deviate from what's come out of left-of-center R&B in the last couple years
column12: Asher's take is just flat-out better than much of the comparable stuff out there
column13: boasting more technical command and
column14: particularly
column15: a more thorough knowledge of electronic music. Throughout much of the album
column16: particularly in places like the romantic
column17: dreamy “EST” and the sad
column18: delicate “Atom”
column19: WinterSpringSummerFall is unequivocally pleasant and pretty
column20: with enough of a searing edge and emotional point of view to avoid falling into generic anonymity. Asher's voice is capable
column21: if not exactly distinctive.

column1: Jordan Asher has explained that the album is his chance to share his story with those who were aware of his involvement in Beyoncé and wanted to know more. It goes something like this: Asher bounced around between bands and states of homelessness in Miami before he eventually moved to New York and signed a deal with Roc Nation. Career backstory aside
column2: Asher alludes to incidents on the record that have serious resonance: his best friend drowned
column3: and he also watched Joshua Basin
column4: a 20-year-old who was shoved onto Brooklyn's Bedford Avenue subway station tracks and hit by a train in 2012
column5: die in his arms. Unfortunately
column6: apart from these brief moments
column7: the tales told on WinterSpringSummerFall are kind of boring
column8: and as a result the album frequently works best where Boots is saying the least.

column1: Asher's songwriting often lacks inspiration
column2: particularly when it leans on his wholly uncharismatic rapping. There's a common (and
column3: in some cases
column4: sexist) assumption that great pop music is mostly the work of the producers behind it
column5: but
column6: WinterSpringSummerFall suggests that
column7: despite Asher's obvious talent and good instincts
column8: he needs collaboration to bring out his best work  (as contributions from Kelela and Jeremih here show). As he mentioned in his interview with Pitchfork
column9: Beyoncé's input strongly shaped and reshaped the way he produced certain songs on her album
column10: and the lack of guidance is clearly felt on WinterSpringSummerFall's missteps.

column1: Asher has the tendency to hamstring his songs with clumsy raps; his delivery has the kind of slick patter and heavy-lidded
column2: personality-bereft tone that's common for artists who are primarily singers. Since he doesn't provide much of his own personality to latch onto
column3: it's hard to identify with his ranting about girls who only want to meet him so they can meet Jay Z
column4: or meatheads in the Meatpacking District. Sometimes
column5: he's sanctimonious (“That's 32 [bars] and I didn't even mention one motherfucking car”); elsewhere
column6: his boasts sound hollow
column7: especially since his good fortune is obviously not due to his talents as a rapper. The reasons for WinterSpringSummerFall's lack of substance go beyond Asher's rapping skills: “Ride Ride Ride” ride
column8: ride
column9: rides the same pattern for too long
column10: an embrace of repetition that might work if a vocalist more dynamic than Asher were delivering it. (It doesn't help matters
column11: either
column12: that his contributions to Beyoncé linger over this project
column13: beyond the titular singer's enjoyable
column14: if minor
column15: contribution to album closer “Dreams”.)

column1: That said
column2: Asher isn't entirely adrift on his own. “My Heart Is A Stone Today (Unharmed)” coasts on a lovely falsetto and builds with a propulsive
column3: insistent beat and scattered dance rhythms before breaking apart into a stunning piano ballad
column4: and the simple house music nod “Fade Away” is the kind of whirlwind performance that could captivate an entire field of festival-goers. But most of WinterSpringSummerFall doesn't connect quite so obviously
column5: and it ultimately feels like what it definitely is: a talented producer's unwieldy
column6:
overly long solo project.

If there’s a constant in the career of Arto Lindsay
column3: it’s in the way he positions deep contrasts in close proximity to one another. He’s an American musician who spent a great deal of time growing up in Brazil
column4: ultimately getting spewed out into the the public consciousness in the late 1970s No Wave scene as part of DNA. The band were short-lived
column5: just like fellow New York corrupters Mars
column6: but in Lindsay’s case it made sense that he’d want to move on quickly. Raised on a diet of tropicalia
column7: punk
column8: and avant garde impulses
column9: he clearly wasn’t the kind of musician to get locked down in one style. The arrogance of youth played a part
column10: too. On talking of DNA’s short history in Pitchfork contributor Marc Masters’ book No Wave
column11: Lindsay said: “We had managed to make a great band—then I just tossed it away because I thought I’d do something else.”

column1: Where that “something else” took him is documented on this compilation
column2: a two-disc set released by Northern Spy that includes a fistful of tracks spanning Lindsay’s solo career circa 1996-2004. There’s a cohesion to the first disc
column3: which includes 12 tracks culled from various albums
column4: and often settles into the lilting tropicalia-influenced material Lindsay practiced following music made with John Lurie’s Lounge Lizards
column5: the Golden Palominos
column6: and his Ambitious Lovers project. On the second disc
column7: containing solo live recordings taken from performances in various venues between 2011 and 2012
column8: he gets more abrasive
column9: throwing shards of noise in among the prettiness
column10: covering Al Green and Prince along the way
column11: and generally illustrating how his no-fear approach to art has stuck with him as he enters his fifth decade of gelling inverse properties.

column1: The first disc's standouts feature Lindsay vying with his peers
column2: or at least leading them astray into his vision. On the wonderfully doomy “4 Skies” from O Corpo Sutil (The Subtle Body) he’s joined by Brian Eno (credited with “sonics”) and Amedeo Pace of Blonde Redhead; Ryuichi Sakamoto lends piano and keyboards to two of the breezier tracks
column3: “Simply Are” (from Noon Chill) and “Child Prodigy” (another Subtle Body cut). Lindsay’s approach is fascinating largely because of the way he flicks from relaxed to tightly wound in a heartbeat
column4: making it sound like he’s soaking up the sun on some back porch somewhere and then unleashing a beat-heavy strain of claustrophobic electronics. On “Personagem” from Salt he’s somewhere in between all those things
column5: filling the air with scratchy guitar
column6: unhurried vocals
column7: and arresting horns.

column1: The misfires are few—which is surprising
column2: considering it’s coming from someone so keen to look for joins where none are apparent. “Complicity” from 1996's Mundo Civilizado bears the marks of the times a little too overtly
column3: with its reliance on overly compressed electronics and DJ Spooky guest appearance. Still
column4: Lindsay rises above it
column5: largely due to his sharp enunciation
column6: positioned somewhere between wistful and hurt. The live material on the second disc feels like a great release of pressure after the meticulously arranged studio compositions that precede them. Lindsay barks and wails
column7: shouting into the loneliness as his guitar feeds back against him
column8: making it sound less like he’s playing and more like man and machine are brawling on the floor. The atonal workover of Prince’s “Erotic City” even elicits a few laughs from the crowd until Lindsay pummels all the sexuality out of it with great lumps of dissonant guitar.

column1: The best way to experience this side of Lindsay’s career
column2: to get a feel for where he likes to go and then utterly disembowel it
column3: is to stack up versions of the same song from discs one and two of Encyclopedia. The original “Invoke” is all swooping strings and bright electronic pulses
column4: while the live version sounds like someone being smacked in the face with a piece of sheet metal; “The Prize” is positively funky in recorded form
column5: being built on a bedrock of dark analog bass synth
column6: while live it’s utterly mechanical
column7: stripped of all momentum
column8: swapping swagger for tension. In most hands
column9: a live album tacked onto a best-of compilation might seem like a cheap piece of padding
column10: but this is a rare case where both documents feed off one another
column11: even if it is in the most hostile way imaginable. Instead of trying to make sense of things
column12: to summarize the unsummarizable
column13:
this compilation simply pits chaos and order against one another and lets a beautiful mess unfold.

Nearly a quarter century has passed since the poker-faced
column3: tongue-in-cheek trio of Trans Am began making post-rock on its own terms: synthesized
column4: mysterious
column5: and obsessed with classic-pop/rock kitsch. They’ve made great albums
column6: as well as horrible albums

column1: Lacking relevance to current trends isn’t necessarily a bad thing
column2: but the lack of focus and force on Volume X
column3: the unkillable band’s unsatisfying tenth full-length
column4: doesn't help their cause. One of Trans Am’s stocks in trade
column5: new-wave pastiche
column6: is represented in a halfhearted fashion this time around. New-wave means a lot of things to a lot of people
column7: but in Trans Am’s case
column8: that meaning has always been narrow and rigid: synth-pop of the icy
column9: Kratfwerk-ian extraction. Aptly
column10: “Night Shift” is a spacious
column11: Giorgio Moroder-esque instrumental that also dips slightly into pinging krautrock; if placed against wallpaper
column12: you would only notice the wallpaper. The band is far more successful on “I’ll Never”
column13: an homage to Dazzle Ships-era OMD
column14: albeit with hints of Suicide. With reverb-and-vocoder-chilled vocals intoning
column15: “Come a little bit closer/ For the very last time”
column16: the song is a 1980s prom anthem crooned by the nerdy kid who hasn't found transcendence.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Trans Am doesn't maintain that tender alchemy between corniness and poignancy. Singer/multi-instrumentlist Phil Manley has lately been busy with his Life Coach side project
column3: which has veered toward the more metallic end of Trans Am’s spectrum
column4: and that facet gets indulged on a pair of Volume X’s gravest missteps. “Anthropocene” sounds as if Uriah Heep had pioneered the use of synths—instead of stodgy old organs—in the pursuit of fantastic
column5: early 70s proto-metal. Understandably
column6: the result is incomprehensible
column7: a mess of mixed signifiers that sounds like Spinal Tap trapped in an Atari. If that idea had been developed further
column8: it could have been amazing in the hands of Trans Am; instead
column9: “Anthropocene” is answered by “Backlash”
column10: a possible shout-out to Metallica’s “Whiplash” that jabs jokey thrash into mock-industrial mechanization.

column1: A handful of tracks on Volume X are decent placeholders that do nothing to expand or appreciably reinforce the band’s aesthetic
column2: but “Ice Fortress” stands out to represent everything Trans Am does right
column3: as propulsive
column4: arpeggiated synth chords bounce gracefully off one another while swells of bass-like waveforms rise and fall menacingly. The mood is familiar yet alien—Trans Am’s sweet spot
column5: when it’s able to find it these days. The song’s stoned motorik pulse owes as much to Pink Floyd’s “On the Run” as it does any Neu! or Cluster track from the same era. Straddling the fence between the stadium and the obscure is where Trans Am sits proudest
column6: and that alternate-history vision of pop is what makes “Ice Fortress” so vital—and the rest of the album limp by comparison.

column1: With Volume X
column2: Trans Am have made it clear that they have as many chops as ever. They shouldn’t go away
column3: nor should anyone want them to. But when they’ve persevered for so long
column4: where so many bands of their '90s post-rock peer group haven’t
column5: maybe a little survivor’s guilt would be a positive thing. Anything to get them making urgent
column6: absurd
column7:
ambitious records again.

Herzog’s Boys is a record you’ll never be able to mistake for anything else because all its ideas are laid out plain as day
column2: ready to be soaked up by sad boys and girls who grew up on Weezer’s Blue Album
column3: Thin Lizzy
column4: cheap beer
column5: and suburban ennui. The band's music is “subtlety-free
column6: ” according to their Facebook

column8: most fully realized record begins with a raucous vocal asking
column9: “Hey you indie rockers/ Is everybody in?”
column10: less a snarky call-out and more of a call to arms. They're literally asking if everyone’s in the room so they can begin.

column1: Pitchfork’s Ian Cohen described Herzog’s sound as “loud fuzz and slightly less loud fuzz”
column2: and it's easy to expect that template resembling yet another pro forma garage band indistinguishable from its peers. But Boys is defined by how much fun it is to listen to

column4: they follow the snappy line “I used to write

column6: resembling a FIDLAR song with lyrics that don’t make you feel stupid when you listen hard. (Surprisingly
column7: the song is a tender ode to a single mother.) At one point on the album
column8: they sing
column9: “What’s the point of writing songs if nobody ever wants to sing along”
column10: and Boys is indeed hook-heavy

column2: but luckily the band's got a few curveballs in their repertoire. “Teenage Metalhead” rewrites Weezer’s “In the Garage” with the assumption that the kids eventually got out of the garage and learned to dance (or
column3: at least
column4: sway)
column5: detailing a road trip to Cleveland and buying weed from an Englishman “with a crooked tooth and a yellow van” before seeing the Black Sabbath exhibit at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. “Saint Scrapyard” baits you into thinking it’s gone quiet with a few brushes of fluttering drums
column6: before kicking back into a shared scream.

column1: Boys is obsessed with interior states and vagaries of youth
column2: singing about drunken nights that get broken up by the cops (“Oh No”)
column3: jokes from the sixth grade that are still funny (“It’s Hard Getting Old”)
column4: former rivalries that mellow out with time and maturation (“You Are Not the Villain”). You can’t deny the album’s focus on the titular male persuasion
column5: not when they’re singing lines like “I write songs for boys/ ‘Cause I’m one of them” and “This is a theme for all the boys/ Playing guitars and making noise.”

column1: And there’s something endearingly juvenile about openly referring to oneself as a “boy”—but it's also possible to become excessively aggravated by consuming yet another piece of media that revels in having XY chromosomes. Also

column4: and then follows it up with a whine about having to go to a show by himself because all his friends stayed home. But Herzog are talking about themselves

column6:
you might find there’s a lot to recognize.

On their third album
column2: Days of Abandon
column3: the Pains of Being Pure at Heart frontman Kip Berman is a young romantic in a state of flux. The Pains' still-stellar self-titled debut and 2011's Flood-helmed
column4: fully Corgan-ized Belong put precious little distance between Berman's heart and his sleeve: these were head-spinning
column5: chest-swelling records
column6: drunk on romance
column7: dizzy with possibility. Abandon doesn't completely ditch the heart-bursting intensity that powered the Pains' previous work
column8: but it's no longer its driving force. Once a starry-eyed daydreamer pitching woo at anybody in earshot
column9: Berman now sounds like a guy who's seen his share of heartbreak
column10: and is looking to reconcile his youthful idealism with the complexities and complications of post-adolescent coupling.

column1: For some
column2: Belong's buzzsawing guitars and brazenly romantic lyrics were all just a bit much. Still
column3: given the leap between the debut's mid-fi melodrama and Belong's amplified alt-rock ambitions
column4: it seemed only natural that Berman might take the Pains into bigger
column5: more bombastic places on his new record—and that notion dissolves just a few seconds into ""Art Smock""
column6: Abandon's delicate
column7: Felt-referencing opener. From the very first notes
column8: Abandon is subtler
column9: more graceful and
column10: sure
column11: more ""mature"" than any Pains record before it. The spindly
column12: hushed ""Smock"" might just be the single most delicate song in the Pains catalog
column13: but more tellingly
column14: it's easily the most nostalgic as well
column15: a sweet-and-sour remembrance of a relationship-that-wasn't. So many of Berman's songs seem to take place in the immediate present: whatever's being felt
column16: it's being felt right then and now
column17: and the vibe of ""all we have is this moment"" gives his best songs their crackling urgency. Up against those early records
column18: ""Smock"" feels more reflective
column19: more wistful. It's a look at the present through the lens of the past
column20:
in which Berman allows lived-in experience step in and take over for all that untempered passion.

This fine-tuning of Berman's emotional outpouring—more pragmatic
column21: less excitable—carries throughout much of Abandon. ""Tell me that we're still so young
column22: Berman sighs atop the high-test twee of ""Beautiful You""
column25: so wrong."" On ""Until the Sun Explodes""
column27: at the bedside of his betrothed
column28: making big promises. This is hardly Berman's first song about unwavering devotion
column29: but with its implication of mutual addiction and somewhat startling reference to ""funeral clothes""
column30: it's probably his most complicated. As he sings on bouncy lead single ""Simple and Sure
column31: Berman wants something that just feels ""absolutely right."" But that's the ideal
column35: looking on helplessly as the object of your affection breathes through a tube. These wrinkles—anxious memories
column37: none-too-idyllic scenes from the past—are all over Abandon. Berman's certainly turned in sweeter
column39:
but he's never written anything that feels quite so true to life.

In the wake of Belong
column40: Pains underwent a fairly seismic personnel shift: several original members—singer/keyboardist Peggy Wang
column41: guitarist Chris Hochheim and bassist Alex Naidus —have either left the band or taken diminished roles
column42: leaving just the core lineup of Berman and drummer Kurt Feldman. On Abandon
column43: the pair are joined by Beirut's Kelly Pratt and A Sunny Day in Glasgow singer Jen Goma; when she's not matching Berman harmony-for-harmony
column44: Goma—like Wang before her—takes the lead on several of these tracks. Goma's sweet yet knowing tone makes a good foil for Berman's delicate heart-to-hearts
column45: as her spry turn on the buoyant ""Kelly"" is maybe Abandon's finest moment
column46: its sputtering drumbeat at one point all but backing up just to make sure it doesn't miss anything she's saying.

column1: Musically
column2: Abandon's the fizziest Pains record yet. Gone are the plumes of distortion
column3: and in their place there's a crisp
column4: effervescent gallop
column5: splitting its time between dreamy balladry and spotless indie-pop. Granted
column6: it's not all perfect: the sun-dappled insurance-commercial chug of the too-rousing-by-half ""Coral and Gold"" gets smothered by its own bombast
column7: while elsewhere
column8: Pratt's lighter touches fade gently into the background. But there's a newfound patience to just about everything else here
column9: a deliberate
column10:
well-heeled sound that sits well with Berman's more ruminative lyrical turns.

On first contact
column11: Abandon can come across as muted and brittle
column12: lacking the laid-bare emotional charge that carried its predecessors. Berman's in fine voice (faux-British accent and all) throughout Abandon
column13: and—the overblown ""Coral and Gold"" aside—these melodies are sturdy
column14: even regal. But it's certainly a less thrilling record than what came before it
column15: more refinement than reinvention
column16: more likely to gather its thoughts than spill them out to anyone within earshot. the fact that Berman didn't try to outdo the grandiose Belong is a good thing
column17: but Abandon can't help but come across as a transitional record
column18: the first entrant in the Pains' ""mature"" period
column19: with the promise of more to come.

column1: Berman's called Abandon the most personal Pains record to date
column2: and there's no reason to doubt him: he's applying the lessons of his own life to this music
column3: all the tiny triumphs and harrowing heartbreaks that come from being young and in love. So as good as Abandon is
column4: one can't help but think the more he goes through
column5: the richer and more resonant his music will become. ""He’d come to my garret
column6: and we’d make something like love
column7: Goma recalls halfway through the bustling ""Life After Life"". Still
column8: she says
column9: ""The flowers he gave me have wilted/ But I keep them
column10: like I keep him."" Some love lasts forever; most dries up like tulips in a vase—but with every heartbreak comes a well-earned lesson
column11: a souvenir to keep until the next one comes along. On Abandon
column12:
an increasingly wizened Berman seems to've picked up plenty.

For a band that’s spent the last 15 years gracefully and aggressively testing the limits of the sound that heavy metal makes
column3: Portland’s Agalloch have committed very few errors. From 1999’s primitively produced but ambitiously built Pale Folklore to 2010’s arching and magnetic Marrow of the Spirit
column4: Agalloch have twisted black metal into a fabric of folk reverie
column5: classical grandeur and atmospheric washes. There have been exultant harmonies and disembodied howls
column6: chamber music interludes and industrial noise ruptures
column7: gilded acoustic fantasies and barbaric electric marches. From the start
column8: Agalloch created new ways to work these disparate elements into complicated prog-rock forms—song suites
column9: lengthy tracks
column10: uninterrupted albums—while maintaining momentum. More than the metaphysical gaze of their lyrics or the relative mystery of their music
column11: Agalloch has thrived on that rarified mutualism of immediacy and intricacy. After four largely flawless albums
column12: that combination has made them a guiding creative light of American metal.

column1: But Agalloch offered the infrequent human blunder with 2012's Faustian Echoes
column2: a one-track
column3: 22-minute EP. The band spliced samples of the Goethe play into a stepwise
column4: rote rise-and-fall into loudness. The result was spirited
column5: sure
column6: but for Agalloch
column7: it felt basic and empty
column8: a studio-experiment stopgap that didn’t meet the enormous expectations set by the popular breakthrough Marrow of the Spirit. It upheld only one end of the Agalloch bargain. In retrospect
column9: it’s best to consider Faustian Echoes a test run for legendary metal producer Billy Anderson
column10: who’d been mixing the band’s onstage sets since 2010 but had never before recorded them in the studio. Anderson returns for The Serpent & the Sphere
column11: the fifth Agalloch album. It proves that proves the folly of Faustian Echoes was worthwhile: The Serpent & the Sphere not only delivers the depth and development that have become synonymous with Agalloch but
column12: across nine wonderfully imagined and vividly realized tracks
column13: amplifies those qualities by often turning the amplifiers themselves down.

column1: The Serpent & the Sphere includes some charged crescendos

column3: as though leader John Haughm’s grand lyrical reflections on death and cosmic rebirth cast a temperate shade across the music itself. Three of these pieces are pensive

column7: is an instrumental beauty
column8: as radiant as the best work of Mono and triumphant as the heavy metal royalty its piercing twin guitars suggest.

column1: But it's the album's opener
column2: “Birth and Death of the Pillars of Creation”
column3: that immediately and brilliantly casts the record’s somber
column4: reflective mood. For 10 minutes
column5: Agalloch dances at the edge of eruption
column6: using the promise of a climax as only a temptation. The quartet moves from meditative electric guitar murmur to earth-quaking drums
column7: pounding against a pillow of keyboards and harmonies. In the past
column8: Agalloch has launched from such lurking moments into black metal sprees. Rather than cash in
column9: they use that move as a feint three times here
column10: arriving always in a sort of readymade post-rock aurora. “By way of light across a vast millennia
column11: I can behold this grandeur at its infancy
column12: ” Haughm whispers at one point
column13: his words and careful voice perfectly capturing the nebulousness of both the introduction and album that follow.

column1: These quiet retreats reappear throughout The Serpent & the Sphere—not only during the classical guitar comedowns but during the proper rock numbers
column2: too. “Vales Beyond Dimension”
column3: for instance
column4: dips into quick
column5: placid valleys between peaks of volume
column6: with drums receding into a trot and guitars drifting into a slow gaze; the quiet
column7: deliberate moments add power to the louder sections and songs through sheer relativity.

column1: Agalloch’s expert momentum have always depended on an aptitude with dynamics
column2: and on The Serpent & the Sphere
column3: they've made it a science of patience and timing. After that slow-motion opener and a subsequent instrumental
column4: “The Astral Dialogue” springs ahead with a mid-tempo
column5: bass-heavy wallop
column6: emptying without warning into one of the album’s few belligerent blast-beat blitzes. Agalloch maintain that seesaw effect
column7: baiting difficult transitions with the eager feeling one gets while peering around a bend
column8: trying to anticipate what’s coming next.

column1: “Celestial Effigy”
column2: meanwhile
column3: ripples through a litany of ideas and influences
column4: built into one uninterrupted
column5: seven-minute flow. Haughm's guitars
column6: along with and the versatile
column7: brilliant playing of Don Anderson
column8: dance in ornate rituals
column9: flickering notes stabbing at distended riffs and pristine tones countering sheets of distortion. At once
column10: there’s metal and prog
column11: along with blues-rock and a little pop
column12: too. You can practically envision drummer Aesop Dekker and bassist Jason William Walton nodding at each other through the song’s counterintuitive rhythmic shifts; at one point
column13: the bass sits still
column14: embodying a cold doom stare
column15: while the drums sprint ahead
column16: agile and unapologetic. That conflict epitomizes the separate sources of tension—quiet and loud
column17: slow and fast
column18: acoustic and The Serpent & the Sphere
column19: black and folk metal
column20: hard rock and soft comedowns—that allows Agalloch to be at once immediate and intricate. Even in these songs’ most placid passages
column21: the band behind them never sits still.

column1: The Serpent & the Sphere might disappoint fans of Agalloch’s more seething output. This is the band’s gentlest and most lucid album to date
column2: and the musical knots that characterized Marrow of the Spirit’s long tracks have been pulled apart like strands of yarn. But Agalloch have never aimed for simply being brutal or destructive. Instead
column3: their sense of shock has stemmed from their ability to surprise with unexpected wormholes and complementary contrasts
column4: to build rather than break. In that respect
column5: The Serpent & The Sphere is their most refined and generous album to date
column6: an elegant trip to unexpected ends
column7: as Agalloch continue to find new ways to reassemble and reorder their long-standing tricks. They're as singular and instantly identifiable as they were on Pale Folklore
column8: but The Serpent & the Sphere reveals a familiar Agalloch that you’ve never quite heard—evermore patient
column9: risky and

free of fault.

2 Chainz is rap’s court jester of the moment
column2: and he's requested by rappers far and wide to deliver on that talent: precise bars
column3: quotable lyrics (“Money tall like Jordan”)
column4: and his trademark adlibs wrapped in his crude but charming persona. In his solo work
column5: nearly every line is a result of his desire to get a laugh
column6: and FreeBase
column7: his recently released free EP
column8:
allows 2 Chainz to stay in character without overstretching his shtick.  

FreeBase remains as sonically adventurous as 2 Chainz’s previous two albums. Mike Will Made It’s lumbering stomp on “Wuda Cuda Shuda” and Young Chop’s eerie speedboat-chase music on “They Know” demonstrate why they have been go to producers of the last few years. The tape's padded out with samples from Richard Pryor and the absurdist comedy Step Brothers
column9:
providing a framework that makes the EP more than a pack of leftover tracks from an old recording session.
 
On repeated listens
column10: 2 Chainz’s punchline-focused style turns initial smirks into outright laughter. His sense of humor is most potent when riffing on familiar rap tropes
column11: but it can be hard to stomach when he turns to pure misogyny on tracks like “Flexin on My Baby Mama”.  Regardless
column12: FreeBase has its genuinely funny moments
column13: such as when 2 Chainz
column14: who has worked with everyone from Kanye West to Lil Boosie
column15: states “I’ve done a song with everybody from Jermaine Dupri down to Papoose
column16:
” which is at the least an interesting selection of artists to namedrop.

2 Chainz can appear on a song with any rapper or pop star
column17: but he also wants to throw his weight around in the area of modern rap that A$AP Rocky namechecks on “Crib in My Closet”: fashion. ""Crib in My Closet"" sounds like a 2000-era Big Tymers boastful track where 2 Chainz
column18: A$AP Rocky
column19: and Rick Ross fight for the “Best Dressed” crown
column20: with Rocky delivering the knockout punch by name-dropping the Met Ball and Anna Wintour. It should be said
column21: though
column22: that 2 Chainz's obsession with fashion also provides the best intentionally ironic line
column23: as he yells “I don’t respect my elders
column26: he's the oldest rapper to appear on the EP. 2 Chainz been rapping for over a decade
column27:
but now his music sounds like he’s just entertaining himself during late night recording sessions and (correctly) assuming his audience is along for the ride.
